She was great, very attentive. I also had the toronja sour which was actually perfect for me since I'm a big grapefruit lover. This place also has live music in the evening. Spacious, and trendy. Will always come back if I'm ever around the area.

I had a life revelation at The Meatball shop. My whole life, I have never liked meatballs. Its a weird consistency, its bulky and awkward to figure out how to eat, and I just would rather have meat sauce. We were with a large group, and wanted somewhere on a Fri that we could just walk in to at 8pm. Thankfully, they were able to take us. The menu is a a little confusing because it has you picking all the options yourself... but in the end thats probably the best thing ever! You first choose the type of meat (Veggie, lamb, veal, beef, pork etc,) then your starch (pasta, spaghetti, rice, risotto etc), and then sauce (mmMMm) and veggie. I went with the chicken meatball, parmesan cream sauce and risotto and it was unbelievable. UNBELIEVABLE. They also have this 'a la carte' option for sandwiches and burgers. I am not sure what made the food so great, but for my first 'real' meatball experience, it was so delicious, flavorful, creamy. I think the risotto was the best risotto I have ever had. Only two of us wanted dessert, thankfully, and we split the classic ice cream sandwich... which was INCREDIBLE.The first few times it was suggested to come here, I am not gonna lie I was hesitant and perhaps a bit pessimistic. I fully admit that, and am happy that I gave it a chance. I have a feeling this is going to be a staple to our UES life.

This place is a freakin' treasure. I don't believe I've ever had Cambodian cuisine, but after this experience, it's officially been added to my map of deliciousness. Bold statement alert: might be the best sandwich I've ever had.It was lunch time and the line was out the door long, but for good reason. Pro tip: order on an app and pick up. Not naming any apps because there are a few out there, but the one I ordered from was excellent and put me right at the front of the line so I could get back to work in a timely fashion.Ordering to go lunches is sometimes a nerve wracking option, but this pulled pork sandwich stood the test of the 5 block walk. The bread was crunchy and fresh. Each ingredient danced together beautifully and my eyes widened with every bite. The perfect amount of spice, fresh crunch, and sweet, savory, perfectly cooked pulled pork.After I was finished, my mouth was watering for more. Still is. Add this place to your bucket list if you want to make sure you live a good life. I will gladly dodge the chaos of Chelsea Market for another go at Num Pang Kitchen.

Vida Verde has the hottest rooftop for dining in Manhattan and just in time for Summer Friday season. This bi-level Mexican restaurant is located in the Midtown West area open almost a year ago but their rooftop just open a little after the Memorial Day weekend. Their vibrant rooftop includes a beautiful mural of Frida Kahlo done by Victor Quinonez, colorful, the perfect amount of greenery, and colorful tables and chairs. The chef created a menu that is a perfect blend of traditional and contemporary Mexican food. The dinner menu at Vida Verde is designed to be shared and their small plates includes items such as chipotle BBQ wings, tacos, guacamole, ceviche, carnita sliders, and more. Their popular guacamole is made table-side and at your desired level of spice and comes in two different sizes as well.  Brunch is the most important meal for us weekend warriors and Vida has a boozy brunch that they refer to as Boozy Brunchacha that includes an entree and 90 minutes of bottomless drinks that ranges from $40 - $50 based upon the type drinks you get. The brunch menu includes items such as sunrise quesadilla, huevos rancheros, duck hash, and the garden fritta. Brunch is available Saturday and Sunday from 11 am - 6 pm and I strongly encourage reservations (which can be made via OpenTable, Resy, or Yelp). Vida Verde has a number of specials which include their happy hour that runs from 4 - 7 pm and then a reverse one from 11 pm - close. Their happy hour include:$10 - margarita$10 - sangria$6 - draft beer$5 - Tecate$6 - wine$10 - Tecate & tequila shot Vida Verde is a large restaurant but I what I enjoy about them the most outside of the amazing food is the great customer service. The communication between the front and back of the house is seamless and it explains all of the high ratings and reviews they have received on multiple platforms. Don't be the last of your friends to check out this rooftop!Personal favorites: GuacMahi Mahi TacosNachosTres Leches cakeBBQ WingsShrimp Quesadilla

The Quick: Great free above ground walking path in the best neighborhoods in manhattan. Perfect for when out of town guests who are visiting or locals who want to live some of the Nyc glory without going to Times Square (God forbid). The Details: Such a nice walking path with views of west village, Chelsea, the water, artwork, gorgeous new buildings and great people watching. The High Line is also being extended so it gets longer with more areas to explore. Enjoy!Pro-Tip: do NOT donate to the fake monks walking around. It's a scam! The Damage: FREE! With expensive food and drink options on the path, local artwork, and more.

It is worth it, Let me slurp itThese rice noodles are slippery as shitBut... they're mmmm mmmm mmmm mmmm mmmm mmmmMmmm mmmm mmmm mmmm mmmm mmmmThey got big uh (portions), let me tell yaI'll do whatever I can to really sell thatMmmm mmmm mmmm mmmm mmmm mmmmMmmm mmmm mmmm mmmm mmmm mmmmI'd like to get to know ya so I could show yaPut the chili oil on ya like I told yaGet some mifen (rice noodle soup) and hunan salad, do you need more?All the pickled veggies got me going gagaThe service is so friendly, they keep comin overNo need to call before you come and you can bring your own bottle of liquorGain a few pounds and ma waist expandThe decor is so simple yet still so grandRa-ta-ta-ta-ta-ta-ta-ta-ta-taFood so good I say blah-blah-blahWork it, I need a glass of wata(it's a little spicy !)Boy, oh boy, I'm glad to know HunanIt is worth it, Let me slurp itThese rice noodles are slippery as shitBut... they're mmmm mmmm mmmm mmmm mmmm mmmmMmmm mmmm mmmm mmmm mmmm mmmm

So the queen of soul died. So I went to the Apollo and paid my RESPECTs to Aretha Franklin. The Apollo always has a celebration of live when a legend passes on. They play music and fans stop by and leave photos , flowers, trinkets. Fans just feel the love and comfort from like minded peeps. I've seen concerts here too. Really the inside is pretty fab. Beautiful. Enjoy the photos of the world BEST ENTERTAINERS that have performed here!!. Such history!!They have theater tours and you can take lots of pics and hear the stories!!Make sure you see The Tree of Hope!!

Phenomenal, awesome, fantastic - no exaggeration, no embellishment, just amazingness in abundance. If you love meat & cheese, it's hard not to love this place. And they are incredibly generous with samples, although if the sample boards are empty they will grumble a little bit because it's a busy place and a little bit of scruffiness is to be expected but they've never said no and they always oblige. Sorry, but when so many of the meats look the same and their descriptions sound very similar, something needs to actually sell the product, and they've always let me taste for myself what's what. And boy do they have some good stuff here, and although it's not cheap, there are definitely some deals to be found, and it's a whole lot of wonderful.

A few reasons for five stars:1. Convenient location for mid-work day coffee breaks2. Oat milk available3. Incredible cookies that probably have crack in them 4. Though I've only tried the spanokopita (v. good), the other food also looks amazing5. Strong coffee6. Matcha latte tastes like I'm drinking mouthfuls of grass, and I love it7. They have cupholders for cold drinks! And ones that don't melt from all the condensation!8. While not cheap, also not more expensive than other similar coffee shops (Bluestone, Blue Bottle, etc.)

Thinking back to the Spicy Tan Tan Noodles ($18) that I tried is making me salivate...it was sooo tasty! The pork broth was super flavorful and the noodles were chewy and fresh. The crushed nuts gave the ramen an extra nice texture. Everything from the meat to the vegetables in the bowl satisfied my taste buds.The interior of the restaurant doesn't look traditionally Japanese at all...or you can count the minimalist design that makes it Japanese. Instead, it's a very hip and modern space.

One of the top dining experiences in NYC period! While it has taken me this summer restaurant week to dine here- it does not diminish a very fine culinary moment. Elegant, windowless room, feels VIP club like with fresh flowers and very attentive, professional service. We were a party of three at a corner banquette.Ate:Cauliflower and mushroomsBrook troutChocolate cremeux with chocolate covered cashewsTotal: $42A lovely salted brioche starts the service and the food was stellar, start to finish. My British buds equally loved the food and dining experience.

Excellent!! I was born in San Juan, PR but raised in Cayey, little town 30 minutes of San Juan ( capital of Puerto Rico ). Cayey is the home of Guavate , Pork Land!!!! So I know if the pork is good or not hahaha.  First I am not into eat pork every day but once in awhile is good. I like to walk, so I found this place walking my dog. When I saw the yelp review I knew this place was a must!!!  I have been here a couple of times and every time the server is very nice and attentive!  It's a very little place, so I always order to go.  Food! Pork! Excellent! If you like chicharron ( fried pork) tell them to put more hahahha. People love chicharron , I am not big fan but my hubby is ! . For what I have seen the pork combination is 10 dollars and pernil combination is 11 dollars.  Sauce - they have a garlic sauce! Is mojito ! And is home made ! Excellent!  Rice and beans are great. This place is awesome!!! Kudos to the Chef !

Officially my new go to noodle spot on the UES. I triple double dog dare you to find a place with a more authentic, gourmet, delicious pasta offering for less money in Manhattan. Go on. I'll wait.Now that the liars are gone, please let me continue to heap loads of praise on this humble establishment. The staff is great, friendly and always smiling. They always remember me and service is quick and painless. I'm slowly making my way across the entire menu because I've had 3 dishes so far and have yet to be disappointed.Go here, or don't at your own peril.

By far my favorite tea shop in the city. $66 tea for 2 people is an awesome price, and you get your money's worth of delicious tea and pastries.The tea menu is extensive, with options I haven't seen before. We tried chocolate hazelnut and almond with caramel and absolutely loved them. Food wise, the scones steal the show. They were warm, buttery and melt in your mouth good. Also really liked the lemon macaroon and chicken curry sandwich.

Fasten your seatbelt and fly into the night of this easy breezy oasis in a New York cool looking locale of East Broadway where the lower east side meets Chinatown. I'd passed by this place before, not knowing what it was, with its handsome large windows, white Pueblo exterior, and dark interior with an orange glow of light creating black silhouettes of a lively happy crowd. I was jealous. I so wanted to be there. My vegan friend and I came here spontaneously after a day at the beach.This place was on our wish list, and just from the Mexican angle, as being both Texans - we were in absolute heaven. The dining room was full but not overcrowded and not over loud.  The space has the feel of an old villa that someone's cool uncle owns in Mexico City, so it feels antiqued, modern, and casual.This menu is vegan Mexican, and with a name like jajaja - Spanish for hahaha - the place feels expectedly lyrical but it's surprisingly sophisticated too. Let me tell you what we ate - Chips and salsa $3We chose the salsa verde, and let me tell you the salsa was SO spot on that we saved the small bowl of it after we had finished our chips and at the end of our meal we split it and did a celebratory shot of it. The salsa had a weight to it so it wasn't liquidy, the tomatillos and peppers tasted so fresh, and the heat was active. This warmed our hearts and our stomachs.  The only imperfect part of the meal were the chips, which weren't homemade, and while good they tasted like they came out of a bag. Mole enchiladas. $14I'm a big mole fan, and let me tell you this dish, made with jackfruit knocked it out of the park. The taste was spot on, the ingredients were lively fresh, and the jackfruit was a fun protein replacement that had texture and felt honest. The rice was perfectly done - not over cooked but fried to a crispness on the outside. My buddy had the chile relleno $13, which was also perfectly executed and had a meaty texture with the vegetables that while we're just trying to be vegetables gave you that kind of satisfaction you get from meat.We sort of kept just saying wow wow wow, another possible name for this place. Then dessert came.My friend chose churros, $8, and while those aren't my most favorite thing, I was delighted. They were freshly made, crunchy and maybe coated with nuts. The Coconut dipping sauce was more like a paste but it was delicious. This lovely cool little place feels special. You'll feel like you're a cool kid. The place is dark but not pretentious. The food is wonderful and healthy but affordable. The place was rather busy and our waitress actually smiled throughout the entire meal and even wished us good bye. Thanks jajaja - please consider changing the name of the place to wowowow!Y muchas gracias !

I won't bury the lede here - Sushi by Bae is probably my go-to omakase place in New York.I have been following "Bae" (aka Oona Tempest) since I saw a Vice/Munchies video on Tanoshi in the Upper East Side almost three years ago. To my disappointment, when I eventually did visit Tanoshi, she was not my chef. So, when my friend suggested Sushi by Bae, I could not have agreed faster.We showed up right on time and were seated promptly, although the setup sharing a sushi counter with this Sushi by Bou location took some getting used to. But once the sake started flowing and fish got eaten, we felt right at home in this omakase-speakeasy concept. The selection is of course seasonal, but my favorites on the night were the rosy sea perch, shrimp (surprisingly sweet!), and of course the toro hand roll. The sushi was faultless, but what really makes Sushi by Bae exceptional is none other than Oona herself. Her warmth and enthusiasm stand out from the more reserved sushi chefs you may encounter elsewhere. We chatted throughout the night about the sushi landscape in New York City as well as her place as a non-Japanese woman in a field dominated by Japanese men. Nevertheless, what she has most in common with the typical sushi chef is her humility, that most Japanese of qualities. Since we were the last seating on the night, we lingered for over an hour after the last dish, and would have felt right at home staying even longer.At a flat $100, Sushi by Bae is one of the best values for omakase in the city. With Oona's effervescent personality and Daft Punk (also heard: Kanye West's "All Falls Down", Britney Spears' "Toxic") setting the mood, the restaurant is a refreshing change of pace from the more conservative sushi spots that the city boasts. I cannot wait to see what Oona does next - make sure to catch this rising star before she gets too high!*I had to save my 200th review for someplace special, and Sushi by Bae is exactly that!

The food here is really really good.The pizza is made right and they have some good choices. We came out to celebrate my bday with some of my long islander fam and we ordered calamari (good), pumpkin ravioli (yes in the summer and it was BOMB), drinks and more drinks, the st Nick (my fav pizza with mushrooms and truffle oil and prosciutto), honey truffle pizza (was good), margarita pizza (meh whatever kids ate it) and the thaitalian - spicy Thai pizza which was good.Server was good super cool dude.

One of the best rooftop bars i've been to in NYC. The view of the Empire State Building is phenomenal while the atmosphere is great. I don't think a lot of people know about this place so it's never too packed. The bartenders are great and the drink specials are interesting. All comes at a reasonable NYC price.If it's too cold they have heaters you can turn on. If you got smoker friends, you can essentially smoke anywhere on the rooftop section. You can expect me to be a weekly customer here.

Yum Yum Yum! Came here for date night with the boyfriend and this place is just as beautiful as its sister restaurant in the West village. High ceilings, beautiful lighting and design of a French restaurant. This place is great as it's spacious, great for dates or group hangouts.Appetizers - We started with the escargot which came out bubbling. It was plentiful to share between 2-4 people,super buttery with plenty of oils to soak up from the delicious complimentary bread they provide. We also got the quail(caille farcie). Such a great app. The bird is tender and stuffed with foie gras. It is so good. The flavor of the foie gras beautifully compliments the quail and balsamic glaze. Definitely one of my favorites.Entree -One thing this place doesn't disappoint on is portion size. Their plates are large in size and sooooo good. You will never leave hungry! The steak was perfectly cooked to medium rare which we requested. Their fries...oh their fries. I just love love love their fries. Tastes doubled fried. Super crispy on the outside with a potatoey inside. I just looooove it. Get it as a side if it doesn't come with the entree. You will not regret it. We also got the rack of lamb, medium rare. 4 racks, beautifully portioned on carrots and tomatoes. The lamb was cooked perfectly as well, super tender and moist. The glaze on the lamb complimented the meat well, shining both flavors. Dessert- we ended with the chocolate mousse. Super smooth and creamy with some fresh strawberries. The perfect end to a delicious meal.Cocktails - I got the Mexican war which was made with mezcal. Delicious with a good hit of acid from the lime. Definitely a favorite of mine. I also got the Matterhorn. This was also very good but may only appeal to certain palates as this drink has a strong taste of licorice. I liked it very much in the crushed ice.Overall, a great dinner with super nice service in a beautiful restaurant!

This is a warm hotel with lovely staff members. I stayed here during my partner's birthday weekend and I fell in love with this hotel. I will most likely try to stay here as often as I can.At first, my plan was to check in early to surprise my partner but check in wasn't until 3pm. I arrived to the city with my luggage around 10am and planned to go to the hotel to check my bags while I run my errands and come back at check in time but the lovely agents at the front desk gave me a complimentary upgrade to a suite! While I was checking my bags I was rambling to her about how I'm excited because it's my partner's birthday and I can't wait to surprise him and she asked me if I wanted to check in right now, at 11am! At first I was a little confused and a little shocked. She not only upgraded my room but she let me check in while I was there at 11am, long before my partner would arrive! How sweet! I even received a personal letter with my full name on it encouraging me to let them know if I would need anything else. I felt very welcomed and it was a perfect start to my partner's perfect birthday weekend. Everything was great! My only regret is that I kept forgetting to get cash so I could leave a nice tip for the front desk agent and our lovely housekeeper. By the time I remembered, I had to rush to checkout to catch my train. I kept the tip envelope with me so the next time I stay here, which should be soon, I can hand it in! I would recommend this hotel to anyone who is commuting into NYC and needs to relaxing and comfortable place to feel at home.*we stayed in room 203

My friend and I took out our friend out to Per Se as a graduation gift to congratulate him on making it through culinary school. It took months to plan but totally worth it in the end.Service is, of course, top notch. If you're going to fine dine & pay a premium price, I sure hope the restaurant staff does it correctly!Food was amazing from beginning to end. There were so many courses. We were so stuffed. And thank you for all the complimentary dishes as well (since our friend interned there)!Just a fair warning, this will be a long dinner. Gents, don't forget a jacket. Be prepared for 3-4 hours of deliciousness in formal attire.

Before I begin the review, a few misc info: 1) Soft opening the week of 5/26/18! 2) Bathroom in the basement! 3) Seats around 25-36 people!____________________Okay, so the karage chicken is one of the best chicken karage that I've had in NYC. Im comparing this to chicken karage like bessou and other karage. While bessou's karage is 4.5/5, this Raju karage would be 5/5. My first bite into the chicken reminds me of chicken nuggets. It is juicy and tender on the inside. Beware of getting burned if you take a large bite. Everytime I go to Raku, I will order that karage. I hope they can maintain that standard. For oxtail noodle, the noodles were handcut, texture was smooth and firm even after sitting in the broth. The broth was also very umami. If I had to compare the noodles to tsurutontan noodles (4.2/5), Raku noodles would be 4.1/5. The main reason is that the noodles are portion controlled. I like tsurutontan with their generous portions. This is one of those things that are good, but limited in quantity. Savor it while you can.The agedashi tofu is pretty good. Reminds me of fish tofu from hotpot. A nice vegetarian appetizer if you want something lighter. (4/5)Overall the place is very new and has that Japanese culture feel. Shoutout to my waitor for being so attentive.Cleanliness 5/5Service 5/5Food 4.3/5Overall 4.7/5

Holy hell, this is making my revisit all of my conceptions about omakase. My initial reaction to the $58 price tag was that it sounded too good to be true. You get 12 pieces of utterly sublime fish (as well as the option of a $12 wagyu and uni handroll), no tipping, no tax. The downside is that you're eating it in a cramped little space at the back of the Bowery Market within sneezing space of strangers and you have 30 minutes. But think of it as practice for building up your express train stamina and I definitely didn't feel rushed. If anything, I liked how they kept things moving. Reservations: You need one. Not sure what it was like when they first opened but it was pretty easy. You text a number with your name and preferred date and they give you a bunch of options. Being the grandma that I am, I went with the 5:40 seating but I think they have at least two every hour. Space: You'll sit on top of your neighbor as you stuff your face. Food: I'll always order fish over meat but good god, that wagyu and uni was an umami bomb that I wanted 15 pieces of (check out my pics but they don't really do the taste justice). It's like trying to describe the taste of chocolate to someone who's never eaten it before. If you want some dinnertime entertainment, it's always fun to watch the chef use a flame torch and see that wagyu spark and glisten and burn to a red, heady hue. In general, the pieces were a little more adventurous than places like Yasuda/Nakazawa, which stick to the classic Nagiri of fish + rice without much additional seasoning beyond wasabi and ginger. Sushi on Jones steps a little outside the box, with additions like charcoal salt on top of scallop. Which was amazing.Oh and definitely plop the $12 down for the wagyu uni handroll. It's worth it, I promise, since the size worked out to about 3-4 small pieces. You can also order some extra pieces but be prepared to scarf them down as the customers for the next seating start trickling in. Price: $58 for the base omakase. I thought the caliber was up there with places like Tanoshi and Nakazawa for a fraction of the cost. Life motto: Less talk, more eating.

What more can really be said about this place?? Honestly not much so I will keep this short & sweet. I Tried this place for the first time not long ago liked it so much we came back the next day. Yes, the slice to try here is the Spicy Pepperoni Sicilian it simply is amazing, not spicy in my opinion Lordddd all mighty the combo of the crispy crust, tons of cheese & pepperoni make this slice heaven..wow simply delicious. Next time I gave the Margarita slice a try, very good, loved the cheese & taste of the pizza. Small location with standing room only, so far never had to wait too long on line which was great but the line does move rather quickly. Cool to entertain yourself with the fun pics on the wall nice to see that some of these famous peps enjoy a normal not over priced pizza place. Service was quick, prices are cheap what more can u ask for!This place has become a new favorite the pizza is totally worth the try will for sure continue to visit from time to time.

I can't believe it's taken me this long to get around to reviewing Mother's Ruin because I'll probably have my ashes spread here once the bony arms of death open to embrace me. TL;DR: I love this place. MR is a tiny little neighborhood bar with a limited selection of beers and cocktails that are fairly steeply overpriced for their (lack of) inventiveness. Why, then, do I religiously find myself stumbling into this rather nondescript bar at least once a week? Surely it's not due to the rather gruff bouncer or the bartenders, who, while friendly, rarely go above and beyond the bare minimum service. Nay, my affection for this watering hole rests upon an unshakable tenet of my existence: to love a waffle fry is to see the face of God. I live and breathe by these waffle fries with their seductive aroma and perfect crisp. Picking between the french onion dip and the hot sauce is the closest I'll ever come to knowing - fully grasping - how Meryl Streep felt at the climax of the 1982 classic Sophie's Choice. The burger is really top notch too.Tangential but important side note - every one of my friends I've ever taken here has fallen in love with it too. I'll probably end up having my wedding here.

Where do I begin? First off, let me say that this restaurant has given me reason to actually get up earlier on the weekends, since this place gets PACKED during eating hours. I've been here like, five times in the past two months, so I know what I'm talking about. You can also forget about coming here on Fri/Sat between the hours of 6-9, because you'll wind up waiting something ridiculous like two hours. There are no reservations here, and you can no longer call ahead to get a number- you must physically be there in order to get a ticket. Strategies to actually getting seated here: Try coming for lunch (they are open all days of the week) around 11:45. Make sure your whole party is present, or they won't be willing to seat you. You can also come here earlier in the week, like on a Tuesday, and arrive around 5:30-6:00 PM. Additionally, try coming as a party of two, as I've noticed that the party of two tables tend to have a higher turnover.Moving on, the food here is actually fantastic- the best I've had in New York when it comes to Sichuanese food. I think every Sichuanese place has something that they're good at, but SMH not only does many dishes well, but also hits all the smaller things too: service, ambiance, decor, etc etc. Below are some of the dishes I've tried.1. Sliced Pork Belly w. Chili Garlic Sauce (Liang Yi Bai Rou) This appetizer dish is what these guys are known for. The menu description is pretty accurate, but the main feature of this dish is its presentation. I'd say it's good for first timers visiting the restaurant, but is not too filling. As a regular here, it's great but I wouldn't get it every time.2. Stewed Fish Filet w. Pickled Cabbage & Chili (Lao Tan Suan Cai Yu): This is my favorite dish here, and I order it almost every time I come here. It is fish fillets, so no bones. It comes with pickled cabbage, and a white, slightly sour broth. It's slightly spicy, but not overly so.3. Pineapple Fried Rice: I don't know why everyone complains when I want to order this dish. It is probably the best version of this dish I've had, like, ever. Not only is the fried rice cooked to perfection, but you also get quite a lot of shrimp thrown into the mix- when combined with pineapple and a fried rice cooked with the right amount of oil, it is orgasmic. This isn't a dish I'd make my 'number one', but if you don't want regular white rice, this is a solid go to.4. Stir Fried Chinese Long Beans ( Si Ji Dou): One of the perennial favorites at Sichuan places, the beans here are as expected: not bad. I say that because across almost all Chinese places in NY, this dish is served, and it's never bad. I feel like if you're going to come here, may as well skip the vegetables.5. Stir Fried Pea Shoots w. Garlic ( Dou Miao): This is one of those vegetables on the menu which is listed at market price, which means what you wind up paying depends on the season. Pea shoots are considered to be a winter food, so you're likely to pay more for these in the summer, when scarcity kicks in. It was good, but again, it's kind of a waste to come here, stand in line for an hour and order vegetables, which can be made at home.6. Fried Shrimp w. Salted Duck Egg Yolk: This dish is not too bad and has a distinct duck egg taste- you can tell it's not an ordinary chicken egg due to the consistency of the yolk sauce which coats the shrimp. I thought the flavor was good, but my problem with this dish is that the shrimp isn't peeled, but instead cooked with the shell on. That means not that much of the yolk actually penetrates the shrimp, and you're left sucking on the shells if you want to get any of the taste.7. Some chicken dish I can't remember rn- stay posted.DESSERTS8. Steamed Sweet Purple Potato/Taro: There seems to be confusion surrounding this dishes' name, principally because I remember it being listed as a taro, and because it seems the word "potato" has been misspelled on some menus here as "patato". Rest assured, it is just taro. The first dessert on the menu, this is their most and only innovative dish, a kind of like a taro puree atop a cracker. The taro is also infused with some sort of sugary pop rocks. It's an interesting dish, but I wouldn't recommend it- it feels weird in your mouth due to the pop rock effect, doesn't taste the best, and is the most expensive dessert here. 9. Boiled Rice Ball in Sweet Rice Wine: First of all, there's no alcohol in this dish. Secondly, you should get this one because it's probably their best dessert here. I have always been a fan of yuan zi, and if it's your first time here, it's a light dessert and a good conclusion to any meal. Keep in mind though that this might not be made in house, but rather store bought.10. Boiled Rice Dumplings w/ Sesame Filling: The third dessert on the menu is not bad either. It is filled with black sesame paste, and is a sweeter choice for dessert. It is also possibly not made in house.

"When you're in this neighborhood... just go" When you walk in you will feel the warm local New York love you were meant to feel. This is your local sports bar, so as I stepped on I noticed well placed tvs all over the bar so at any time I can look up for a second and catch any game that's on right now.they have plenty of beer on tap from ciders to stouts, there's something for everyone here. The food is really tasty as well! They have burgers and wings and even tacos to name a few. Overall goodness for your tastebuds."So what events do they do there?"During the weekday, they do events like game night on Wednesdays and trivia on Thursdays. They also do pay per views, so if you are looking for the upcoming UFC or Boxing match you know you will have a seat to watch with friends."Overall"Come with friends, bring yourself and get to the bartenders and server, everyone will get to know and appreciate you.

Excellent fusion of Asian and Latin.I ordered the Chicken Tikka nachos, and the Thai beef paratha tacos.The paratha came flakey and not too greasy. The Thai beef had a sweet mango flair to it. Mixed with the crispy veggies, I was amazed at how good the tacos were.Nachos came loaded. Love the Indian take on the nachos. The sauce wasn't excessive so most of the chips stayed crispy. Both dishes came covered with beautiful and fresh veggies. All the textures and flavors complemented each other well.

Came in here during a sudden rainstorm completely soaked. Got the fresh Grandma slice at their recommendation. The guy at the register (who might be the owner) waived the $8 credit card minimum fee, citing that I was "drenched, and don't worry about it." It's a kindness that was so appreciated. When I sat down for my slice, I was happily surprised by how thick and hot and cheesy it was. Perfect for a post-drinks rainy night. Thank you, Village Pizza! I'll be back to try more. 5 Stars!!!!!

Two words. Fried. Chicken. I cannot rave about their fried chicken enough. The crispy skin with a blast of flavorful spices is a perfect wrapper for the juicy wing. It is an unreal experience. And oh yeah, they have a bunch of other things going for them too, such as their buffalo cauliflower, which I prefer to buffalo chicken wings! The service here is amazing. This is one of those establishments that can and should become a go-to spot for anyone within a 5-mile radius. Their room in the back is nice for private events.

Oh. My. G*d. Hands down one of the BEST quick bites you can grab in all of FiDi (king of grabbing fast bites)!!!!!!!!!Sakura's stand is like a high class Halal stand. You go up and wait on that damn line down John Street no matter what. Besides, the line moves quite fast and before you know it you're indulging in a platter full of delicious rice, veggies & the BEST teriyaki chicken you've ever had. The chicken is succulent, tastes like real chicken, juicy and the sauce is perfect to eat with the leftover rice. So so so yummy. BONUS: If you check in on Yelp they'll give you extra chicken! Cha-ching (that usually costs like $3). You cannot beat this $8 lunch it's just too good! Huge portion too. I split the portion with a friend and we were both full. Awesomeeeee place highly recommend

Who the hell are you people? How is Sweetgreen 3/3.5 stars? Am I in the twilight zone right now? Are pigs flying? What is HAPPENING?Sweetgreen is the grand poobah of salads. I literally hate eating lettuce. The thought of eating lettuce with some crap drizzled on it gives me anxiety. A friend of mine suggested Sweetgreen for lunch. Great, I thought. Time to pay $14 to eat some grass. The traditional salad bars that I see in NYC just don't look appealing. I look at the ingredients presented before my eyes and I'm all like "no thanks, I'm good."I walk in to Sweetgreen and I feel like I'm in the lunch room at a swanky country club. You have these ladies smiling behind a glass divider cutting fresh ingredients, a line literally out the door and around the corner (that moves fast), and the most heavenly ingredients straight from salad heaven right before your eyes.I walked up and was all like uhh..uhh.uhh I've never been here before. If it's your first time, it's a challenge because you don't know "the deal", aka how many toppings you get for free, how much additional toppings are, what the dressings taste like, etc. I managed to get lucky my first time because my gf was a PRO at this. I made my own salad with shrimp and got the spicy cashew dressing. Shut the front door! This was the best dressing I ever had in my life. I had to ask them to give me an extra one on the side so I could on the low smuggle that back to my apartment. Also....shrimp?! Say what? I don't think I ever saw a salad bar with shrimp at a to-go/fast food type of place. They must have known shrimp are my favorite.The shrimp, you ask, were they overcooked? Were they chewy? I thought for sure they would taste like crap. Shrimp sitting out all day? Bound to go bad and harden/become chewy. Ohhhhhh no no. You're in the Sweetgreen alternative universe where shrimp tastes good all damn day! So get in line honey!I've also made salad with chicken, mesclun, arugula, cucumbers, spicy broccoli, carrots, croutons, and balsamic vinaigrette. MMMM baby! I think that for someone just trying out Sweetgreen, you need to try all the dressings. You don't want to get stuck with one and be like "awww shit this salad sucks" because trust me, Sweetgreen has the freshest/tastiest ingredients out of any salad chain HANDS DOWN. 100%. You heard it from me! So just take your time and ask them can I try a few? And the staff is awesome so they will let you try whatever you want!My favorite dressings are the spicy cashew and balsamic vinaigrette.Pro tip: Once you get your salad, put the cover on and shake it up. It distributes the salad dressing better.DELISH DELISH DELISH Sweetgreen I love you!

Here's how much I love Chikarashi: I recently served on a jury at the nearby courthouse, and I honestly hoped that the trial would drag on longer than expected so I could keep eating here for lunch every day.Why did I wish that the wheels of justice would spin slowly? Because, silly, this is poke bowl perfection.Every element is on point: Seafood that's fresh af, produce that's crisp and vibrant, rice that's warm and slightly sticky. Crucially, for my preferences, the bowls are predesigned and done so with restraint, so you can order quickly and also avoid the temptation of adding a bazillion toppings. The chic, minimalist ambiance seals the deal -- you feel like you're having an actual meal, not just some quick calories in a fast-casual joint.I dined at Chikarashi three straight days during the trial, and I only craved it more as the days passed by. In fact, I'm wishing I had a bowl right now, when I'm miles away, and when the trial has, sadly, come to an end.

We came here on a Saturday night at like 9pm and still had to wait 20 minutes because it was so busy. We were seated on a bench for two that was fixed to the ground. Interesting enough, they offer both the normal and large size as the same price, the only difference being more udon noodles. Large selection of hot and cold udons that I absolutely loved. Started with an order of asahi beer, which they were kind enough to split into two glasses. I ordered the tsurutontan deluxe, which was absolutely massive! There was an incredible amount of meat inside, making it a very well balanced meal. Plenty of carbs from the udon, yet plenty of protein from the chicken, beef, eggs, and shrimp. IMO, a very well balanced bowl of udon that I couldn't get enough of. The fried sesame leaf was a nice touch, but all I could really taste was the batter. Girlfriend ordered the mantaiko kamatama udon, which was a completely different style compared to mine. It had a light, creamy caviar sauce and also comes cold. Unique flavor that I've never really had before in a bowl of udon. It almost tastes like liquid sushi with the caviar and mantaiko mixed together. Absolutely stuffed after finishing the meal. I'm looking forward to my next visit to try out all the other bowls of udon.

I don't usually give 5* to a place at first visit but this bar/restaurant deserves it.We all Know Hells Kitchen has a gazillion bars to choose from and adding 1 more to the mix wont help much, but thats where you are wrong.The signage outside does not say much, its dark and blah. I think its genius. Here is why, No or very low tourist traffic come into this place. As a New Yorker i tend to stay away from tourist traps and this does a great job at that.The decor is not fancy but dark looking and cool. Small tables, large bar and back seats make the place feel confortable. The dimmed lights that everyone seems to have are placed very strategically and makes it for a welcoming ambiance.The Drinks: I ordered "The Mayor", mezcal based drink similar to a Manhattan but with Mezcal. OMG i wanted more.. The bartenders here have over 25y experience combined and they show it with the specialty drinksThe food, this is where they turn the magic on.The Chef, He is great at what he does, seriously here is the magic.I think there are only 2 places in NYC that sell Chicken wings with white BBQ sauce. Thats Right White BBQ sauce. The wings themselves do not need anything besides the seasoning that comes with them but the sauce just adds that "crack" to it.The Steak Toast: OMG so delicious and simple steak on top of toast that they get from a Brooklyn bread company. The steak is juicy and the Chimichurry sauce is just amazin'The Icing on the Cake is: Drum roll please: "the Bone Marrow" This was on "fleek". It contained Red Roe (dont remember if is tuna or salmon) that gave the already delicious Marrow more of a twist. I personally enjoyed this the most. Remember these are shareable plates aka Tapas style but they are all delicious.From now on, this is the place to go, do not pass go without going here.

You simply can't go wrong at any NYC, Luke's Lobster location. The Plaza Hotel food court location does not have salads.So, here's why I love Luke's Lobster:This is a company that cares about seafood sustainability . The seafood at Luke's Lobster comes from Maine, where sustainability is the law. This means that only a certain number of lobsters may be caught. I just read something within Luke's Lobster's newsletter or emails that said & showed photos of how Maine Luke's Lobster Fishermen & WOMEN will not take a female lobster if they see the eggs, a notch is made on part of the shell to indicate that it is a female, & it goes back into the sea. This helps with sustainability . I applaud Luke's Lobster !! IMHO--I think Luke's Lobster roll is the best there is; at least I can say, it is my favorite . I also love the shrimp roll, and crab roll. The lobster is sweet , I believe it's because it's from Maine. If you love lobster, shrimp, or crab, try a Luke's Lobster Trio, or just order one, but try it. You'll love it.

Wow, this place surprised me! I usually prefer ramen or soba to udon, but that was because I never had a great bowl of udon. Fukusuke is changing my mind. Because it opened recently, the restaurant is pretty empty most of the time so getting a table is easy. The space is small, but clean and tidy. We started with the Japanese Omelette with Spicy Cod Roe which was fully and sweet and contrasted nicely with the salty and spicy roe. I got the Sansai (wild plants) Udon with an add-on of kitsune (fried tofu) and it was delicious! The clear broth was very flavorful, though a bit on the salty side; the sweet-salty kitsune was a nice offset to the broth. The noodles had a great chewy texture, and is much better than the stale and overly cooked udon from other spots. I rarely finish all the noodles and broth, but I very happily shoveled this bowl down. My boyfriend got the duck udon and was happy with his choice as well; the duck was a nice pink. As a side note, the happy hour deal seems pretty good. It's everyday 5:30 - 7, $5 house sake / wine / chu-hi, $4 Asahi, and $3 bar snacks (edamame, takoyaki, gyoza, etc). Service was nice and quick. The chef came out to ask how our meal was and was very enthusiastic. Please give them more business so he can continue making great udon!

It's taken me a long time to gain the courage to finally write this.I know you know how I really feel. You see me flush red. I sweat, I stutter, my heart skips 8 beats at once.I've dated many gyms before you. Equinox made me feel like a pampered princess. Crunch was practical and reliable -- my parents liked him. But you, Tone House, you're the one I'm crazy about. The one I go home and dream about. I toss and turn in bed. I dream about doing a low sled push across the turf with 5 bags. My heart aches for you -- but more than that? Every muscle in my body aches for days after I see you.30 dates later and I still get sickeningly nervous the minute I walk in.Sometimes I hate you. You make me feel weak, and empty, and you push me to drink a ton. Of water. But most of the time I hate you because I know the truth -- that I love you and I love what you make me. I am a better person having known you, because I know what the limits of my body and mind are. And I have visible obliques now. WHAT! Never thought that would happen for me.You're beautiful. Your locker rooms are clean and full of great products. You have foam rollers and ice tubs and toys galore.You're so kind. I've met the best people through you. My only complaint is that my FAVORITE -- Coach Callie -- is now gone forever to the upper east side location. Luckily all other coaches are still amazing.Thank you for the gallops and the pain and the impossible TRX exercises. Thank you for introducing me to the medieval torture devices known as valslides. Thanks for making my quads quiver. I can't wait to gallop down the aisle and marry you.

This is an extremely rare find in the UES. A beer garden, full of college aged kids. But it works and its great. We have now been a handful of times, and its good for so many occasions... Sunday funday, pre-gaming, a tinder date, watching soccer or sports. It's definitely a destination to relax in, not so much to go out.. but it always seems to be very crowded. They have large tvs, lots of classic "beer garden" vibes with long wooden tables, jenga, connect 4, trivia on all of the tables. They have ping pongs and arcade games. While it may seem overwhelming, they still carry the chill "Beer garden" vibe. The music is great, the average age is probably 25, and they have a large section for outdoor seating on the side walk. The food is your classic beer garden food.. germanish, massive pretzels, burgers, fries, and best of all free popcorn machine. They have tons of delicious craft beer options, although the beers add up fast. This may have just been because I was trying to win at Jenga, which happened to take a long time.

When I made the appointment, I was shooting for like, hoping for like, but it ended up being love!I have been buying product from the Rescue Spa in Philly for a while and was super excited to hear they were opening a Manhattan outpost. On a random Sunday, I booked a classic facial with Katya. The aesthetic of the spa is minimalist with a Soho vibe - definitely luxurious. They have a lot of high end products in the shop part of the spa but no heavy sales push. The spa area is lovely, clean and plush. After you check in, they offer you tea or fruit infused water. The facial itself was terrific. The extractions were noninvasive but thorough. My skin looked clean and glowing with zero redness. The facial was very relaxing and my skin is still glowing a week later. There is no heavy product push. Katya asked what I was using and suggested switching the order of the products (which had a fantastic result) but no "you must have" or "you need this."I will definitely come back!

You order the tasting menu and your first course is one radish. ONE RADISH. You look at it and you're thinking, ONE RADISH?!? What the hell?!? How does that count as an entire course?! Then, even though you don't like radishes, you put that radish in your mouth because it's the only thing to eat on your table.Then your brain says... Ooooohhhhhhhhhhh.... it's not just ANY radish, it's the most flavorful bit of purple and white vegetable fiber you've ever put on your tastebuds. Then you start to wonder how they put that much flavor into one radish, and why other radishes can't taste this amazing.... and suddenly you spent five goddamned minutes thinking about that ONE RADISH.Every course is a bit like that. Every dish. Every beer. Every wine. It feels absurd, until you put it in your mouth and realize it IS ABSURD, because it's so damn good.I hate you Blue Hill, because it makes me angry how good you made a single radish taste.

This place was YUM. I've been eating a lot more vegan food, and replacing things in my own fridge with vegan options (cream cheese, shredded cheese, milk), but I haven't fully converted. I think my Italian side is struggling with the letting go of all the delicious real cheeses out there. Needless to say, I've been trying more and more to cook vegan, but sometimes I'm still a little skeptical of meat replacements. Here I ordered an avocado "BLT" and was wondering what the "B" would taste like... It was shockingly good. No idea what in the world the replacement was, but it was brilliant. The way they smoked that vegetable was impressive to say the least. It came as a wrap, not a sandwich, which I didn't mind. Just a side note in case that's a deal breaker for anyone. Since there wasn't any thick bread, just the thin wrap, you really tasted all the flavors of the inside. Thinking about this right now is making me hungry. I also had the avocado fries (avocado slices deep fried), which I split with two other people. It's a lot for one person if you're also going to have a main course, but two people can easily finish as an appetizer. My friend ordered the carrot cake, and I wasn't going to try it but curiosity got the best of me. DEE-LISH. The coffee was really bad, but I mean... whatever. The three things I did try blew me away. Maybe my review will change after I've had a million vegan dishes, but I still am very impressed when there's an all vegan meal and I don't miss cheese or eggs. I really want to go back and try one of their burgers. Or honestly, pretty much anything on the menu.

** super cute décor; one of the walls is hand painted - very IG-able**** Located a few blocks away from the B&D trains **** Free WiFi, which leads me to believe this is a good space to bring your laptop and get personal or professional work done **** they take card here **** street parking available **I read about this place after it was featured on an eater nyc article that appeared in my feed this past Friday evening and decided to come check it out over the weekend since I'd be in the area. On the block that this place is on, this place definitely stands out as it is the most modern looking one amongst old-school storefronts. The décor and ambiance is very cute and homey. There are 4 big tables that can seat a group of 4-6, one bar high table with two bar stools, and there's also a bench. This place is a good place to eat and catch up with friends since it's easy to chat in here without having to scream at the top of your lungs.I heard about the infamous avocado coffee smoothie and had to try it. It looks that the price of the avocado coffee smoothie has decreased based on the initial reviews below. Currently it is priced at $7, which I am not mad about for three reasons 1) they use a shot of Toby's Espresso, which is expensive enough on its own if you've ever had a Toby's latte (which is about $5), 2) they use half an avocado in the beverage, which is more than a scoop of guac at chipotle and they charge you an additional $3 for that, and 3) the avo-coffee smoothie is really creamy, filling, and can be a on-the-go meal replacement. This drink is the bomb and I would most definitely buy it again.I also tried the lox avocado toast ($12) and this was really tasty as well. The price for this can be a turn-off at first but it is much better when you see the plate since everything is at a 1:1 ratio. The toast comes with cream cheese, avocado, a hearty helping of lox, paprika, and a side salad. If you're thinking that this is a bit pricey you should consider the other factors. A standard lox bagel in the city is $8-$10, and that comes with bagel (the main filler item), cream cheese and lox. For $2-$4 more you get avocado, a side salad, and a nice indoor place to sit, which pretty much leads to a more balanced mid-day meal.A toast + 1/3 of the avo-coffee smoothie will fill up a small person, while a toast + majority, if not all, of the avo-coffee smoothie will fill up a normal person who can eat.Perhaps think about creating a rewards program linked to the credit card used. Personally I find myself returning to establishments where there is a reward perk in place.

Wow. I'm stunned. This place is amazeballs. We got reservations for 940 on a Saturday night (texted on Friday night before ). Before we arrived, I got in a huge fight with my dining companion. When we got there, there was a huge confusion on seating and we had to wait for everything to be sorted out. We get seated all the way at the end near the employee room smooshed together . The lovely manager, Josh, gives everyone free sake and extra sushi for the little delay. Mind you, the wait wasn't even that long-def not something to be complaining about, but def the way to get me coming back for more though.The first couple of pieces were sooo good. I looove ikura A LOT and the ikura did not fail to shine-"ikura lot" about this roll. All this time, I still have not forgiven my dining companion. And then, the uni came. Let me tell you, "u-ni-'d" this. This was soooo good that it was able to warm the cold shoulder treatment I was giving to my table mate and I just HAD to forgive him to tell him how good the uni was. My cold shoulder treatment is usually prescribed for at least a good strong 4 hours --that's how good the uni was. Josh (manager) tells us that they buy their uni depending on the tides at the time, so you're guaranteed the best of the best!Service is excellent here. Josh saw my resting bitch face during the beginning of the meal and was so worried that the seating fiasco/food was ruining our mood and he purposefully came up to us to make sure everything was ok. He's in charge of quality management, which is great cause he really knows his stuff-his first omasake was in JAPAN when he was 17-quality definitely managed! When talking about affordable sushi, sugarfish is my usual go to restaurant to talk about. Sugarfish is about 40$. This is 50$-and this "bou-'d" sugarfish waaayyyyy out of the water. Def more than worth the extra ten dollars. Not even comparable. Sushi by bou makes me want to change my sugarfish rating from a 4 star rating to just a 3 because this place sets a very high bar for affordable good sushi. ALSO Some Japanese places don't offer soy sauce or wasabi on the side-any extras the sushi needs is already added in by the chef. This place also encourages you to eat with your fingers -the proper way to eat sushi. They give you a little wet napkin to wipe your in between pieces. So if you don't wanna look like a sushi amateur, eat with your fingers not chopsticks and DONT ask for extra wasabi or soy sauce.

Wah Fung No. 1 truly is number 1 in my book in terms of price, quantity, and quality of food served. This meager space on Hester Street has a perpetual line out the door, and for good reason. At just $5.50, you can expect two meals worth of savory, flavorful meats and vegetables. Roast Duck and Roast Pig will cost you an extra $0.50, but it's worth the small hike in price. They also allow you to half and half between meat selections at and equivalent charge. Meats come with an option of rice and cabbage or noodles. Out of all the varieties I've tried so far, the roast pork is by far my favorite. The thin slices are chewy and tender with a hint of sweetness to keep your taste buds engaged. The roast pig is also a popular item; crunchy pig skin with fatty, soft pork gives you added texture and enhanced salty, savory flavors. Be sure to come here early if you're interested in the roast pig.. it sells out fast!This is one of the best bangs for your buck you can hope for in Manhattan. If you don't mind a small wait, this is the place to be for a casual bite to go.

Out for a solo dining expedition and still under the weather last night, I decided to try out Davelle, a new and unassuming all-day Japanese spot on the LES. As few of my usual dining companions appreciate oden, the focus of their evening menu, I figured this was a good one to scout on my own first.Around 7 pm on a weeknight, it wasn't crowded, just a few small groups coming and going. Similar to their sister spot Izakaya in the East Village, the decor is simple but thoughtfully considered. Exposed brick complements a weathered metal wrap-around bar and hanging bunches of dried flowers. It's very cozy and a little rustic. Chill music like Tame Impala played over the speakers at a reasonable volume.The menu is dominated by oden. For the uninitiated, it's a simmered dish with components like hardboiled eggs, stewed vegetables, sausages, and various kinds of tofu. The broth is light in body but a little earthy. If you've never tried it before, some of the components can seem a little intimidating, as there's some names you may not have heard of and some unusual textures, but the flavors are typically mild and wholesome, and I don't find it to be much of an acquired taste. The staff is also happy to explain pieces and help you pick.In many places, oden is served all together like a hotpot, but here they served each piece to me individually, possibly because I was eating alone and not in a hurry. You can order by the piece (most $3-5) or get a set ($14 for 5 or $25 for 10). I found the five oden set to be filling and quite a good deal, though my appetite is on the smaller side.If you're not in the mood for oden, they have several Japanese comfort food entrees like Napolitan spaghetti and pork curry, as well as a share plate section with fried chicken, pickles, and the like. Do note that tax and service is included in the prices.For my five oden set, I went relatively traditional, with enoki mushroom in tofu, konjak (yam cake), gobou stick, fish cake, and fried tofu. Each piece was beautifully rendered. My favorites were the mushrooms, tucked away in a speared tofu pouch dusted with chili seasoning, and the gently flaking fish cake. The broth was simple and warming. This food is almost meditative.Each piece was brought out individually once I had finished the previous bowl, resulting in my visit lasting about half an hour. This was one of my most successful solo dining adventures yet-- I always had something to do instead of just scrolling through my phone, and I could take my time. I never felt awkward, and left feeling relaxed. Staff was very polite and sweet.I hope they can both succeed in this space and maintain their peaceful atmosphere. For now, it's BYOB, and it sounds like they'll be getting their liquor license in the next few months. I'll be back to try out their daytime offerings.

Recently revisited for a date night, and had a much better experience this time around. I made a reservation online easily for 7:30 a few weeks in advance, but the restaurant didn't have many empty tables while we were there so I'd definitely plan ahead.Started off the night with the Royal Engagement and The Don for drinks, both of which were very sippable. The Don came with a side of chocolate candies to enjoy with the drink as well.As many other reviewers have noted, the complimentary bread and butter is amazing. You get an entire mini loaf of fresh baked bread (seriously, when we cracked it open it was still steaming) and salted, whipped butter. For food, we split a half dozen oysters, ox cheek mac and cheese, and the baked chicken for two. Everything was delicious (especially that mac and cheese). The chicken was prepared 3 ways - the white meat came plated with morels and some sort of puree, while the dark meat came in mini sliders and a separate pot with jus poured over it. So good! Not as good as the Nomad chicken, but still delicious.Dessert was the apple tarte tatin for two (the panna cotta from last time is no longer on the menu, thankfully), which was seriously one of the best desserts I've had. Nothing fancy about it, just a perfectly prepared apple tart with caramel sauce drizzled all over it, and I couldn't ask for more.Meal ended with complimentary almond financiers. Would definitely come back here for another special (or even not so special) occasion. Also - they have the best smelling hand soap I've ever used.

The Quick: Loved the old location, and I'm now obsessed with the new location. Delicious empanadas, great sangria, overall fun vibe, and plenty of seating. Great at any time but phenomenal for late night eating when you don't want the party to end!The Details: sober or drunk this place is great! Everything I've had has always been tasty, and the vibe is always on point. Not sure if people come to start the party or on the party, but either way this place is fun.The Damage: $3-$4 an empanada plus plenty of entrees and sides available too

Vibe: oh these pastel colors are sooo lovely and pleasing to the eye!!! It's cool neon colors and you can't miss it. The more you walk in, the more you feel like cotton candy and there are cozy seats in the back!!Service; the cashier was nice and ivan is chill. They're pretty kind and don't give u an attitude. They are welcome to feedback!Drinks: we got the Butterfly one and green apple! Both were very creamy and interesting texture! Price: it was about 5$-7$ for a drink pretty avg in NYC.I def like this vibe and would visit if I'm around! I know my friends would want Instagram photos here@ayoxannna

I thought I left a review about my visit here a year ago with a coworker for lunch, so I make good on spreading the good word. Surprised I didn't review this spot, but I confine my review to this particular visit since there're so many locations throughout NYC.Reliable spicy (and a few non-spicy, but spice level is not much editable at order as their recipes are largely proudly fixed) lovely goodness at all opening hours at a great value. I always order the Mt Qi. and here it was the same reliable favorite as it is at its many other NYC locations with the same awesome tender beef, superly flavored and spicy soup, perfect noodles, all presented with fresh speed in an efficient environment. The same all-important napkin holders are at a few spots.This location's memorable namely for that long corridor from the kitchen towards the rear where there're many more seats and a 2nd kitchen thus a 2nd pickup window and no loft/balconey/mezzanie level seating thus a pretty backed up crowd for ordering and seating and eating all thru the door even (or especially) in the winter months.

Totally in love with this place. But note: it's on the east side of 8th, though the number is even (and below 55th, the odds are on the east side). I ate the same meal two weeks in a row on Sunday's post-yoga at my friend's around the corner, and could eat here twice a week and not tire of it. Lamb and chicken kebab to die for. The lamb is tougher but the spices are unlike anything I've ever experienced. The chicken is tremendously tender and that yogurt dipping sauce I could eat by the gallon. The rice is also phenomenal. I don't know why but it's just addictive. 24 hours too! Best meal in NY at the price.

Seductive, stately dining room with ornate details, I ate here Wednesday and the front room is stunning. Nola and fancy Southern food in NYC with some updated twists. Shades of Rott & Bone nearby.Ate:Vegan catfish Shrimp & gritsBrussel sproutsI am not a vegan, but appreciate the effort. The peppery Brussels & super seasoned heads on shrimp of the shrimp & grits rocked my palate. Awesome service too, but the old school hip hop was a tad loud for my taste.

I'm never one to be on the lookout for pizza or burger places, but I have to say that Emily blew me away. We had reservations maybe a month in advance for a Friday night dinner, and they were definitely required as we heard others being turned away with 2+ hour waits. We ordered the classic combo that was recommended by friends and the waiter - an Emmy burger and a Grandma pizza. Our waiter said his personal favorite was one of the pinks (pizzas with vodka sauce), the Arenstein, so we dove straight in for that choice. The pepperoni, pickled chili and honey combination was the perfect medley with savory deliciousness accented by a hint of sweet. The burger's pretzel bun was divine, and the fact that it came with curly fries was just the cherry on top. Definitely come here ASAP, your taste buds deserve it.

Great beers, super staff, terrific space. Five stars for Milk and Hops!My beer group had a meetup here recently and it was universally well received. I did not eat but the people who did liked the meats that they had.  The beer selection had a great variety and there was a beer for everyone's taste. The space is clean and easy to navigate, which is important when we have a big crowd. Due to the volume of beer that was being consumed, the bathroom line was usually about four deep at any given time, but otherwise, ther were no logistical issues. Service was stellar from everyone. Fast and friendly....we had over 30 people in the group and nobody had to wait for a beer.  Will definitely be back.

I just had a trip in Lisbon where I had some of the best egg tarts in the world and I knew when I came back to New York I would never have the opportunity to eat such delicious treats ever again..until Frankie Portugal came into the picture. I saw someone had a box of their egg tarts at a bar in the east village so I bookmarked it on yelp. And then I came and devoured! For a box of 6 it was $19. It is definitely worth a try here. We were fortunate enough to get it right out of the oven. It was still hot when I had my first bite. This place can definitely compete with Lisbon's. The crust was super flakey with multiple layers of crisp. The egg custard was super creamy on the inside, sweet and delicious. Sprinkle on some powdered sugar and cinnamon like the Portuguese. So good. I had the remaining cold and it was just as good. YUMMMMMY! I will definitely be back again devouring these little goodies.

This is the best park we have here in New York City. It goes all the way from 59th -to like 110th. I've been to Central Park a lot of times today I attempted to walk the entire park and I did! (Well kind of) the thing about Central Park is that you can easily get lost or walk around in circles lol. My journey began at 59th Columbus circle  Right at this entrance you have the horse and carriage as well as bike and rental . This park is beautiful and has plenty of things to do on a gorgeous sunny or rainy day. They have boat rides ,restaurants , museums and many playgrounds for children. In the summer time there's even more to see such as Victoria gardens, the pool , carousel and the list goes on. What I love about this park is the beautiful views, all the hidden cascades and of course the flowers. Central Park it's great for hiking, jogging and walking. On top of that they also have a zoo! Not as large as the Bronx or queens but a decent zoo. In the winter time they have the ice skating ring so plenty to do all year long. There's also lots of hot dogs stands and about 2-3 restaurants (tavern on the green and loeb boathouse). I want to say that I started out at 59th street and then I walked to like 94th and somehow ended up again back at 59th street so be careful as there are many paths that may lead you back to point A! lol it's a maze but a very beautiful one to get lost in.

This place has great service. I never ran out of water or had a need that went unattended despite this place being packed for cinco de mayo! We watched the tables near us get flipped within minutes. They have a very strong busser/runner staff. Our server was great too. Even though it was apparent that he was very tired and has probably been working all day, his attitude was still very positive. The food was great as always! The Arroz Con Pollo was a tad bit undercooked but everything else was so delicious! The oxtail empanadas isn't an actual empanada but it's still damn good.If you eat pork, definitely order their mac & cheese. The LAST BUT NOT LEAST THEY HAVE THE BEST WHIPPED CREAM I HAVE EVER TASTED. It has a thick Greek yogurt consistency and it doesn't melt quickly. I always love coming here.

If you call Carbone anything other than the apotheosis of a perfect dining experience, your soul will promptly exit your body.I read about forty seven reviews before I dared enter Carbone. The Yelp reviews for Carbone are in the same vein as the infamous Amazon reviews for Haribo sugar-free gummy bears or the Three Wolf Moon T-shirt; while scrolling, you lose yourself in the lore of what people write and begin constructing an alternate universe out of the facts and fiction, neither of which are distinguishable from one another.The first fact-or-fiction moment begins on the corner of Bleecker Street, where Carbone's effervescent letters cast neon on passersby, the sign acting as either a beacon or a hooded figure leaning from under a shadow to warn that your life will fundamentally shift after you pass through.The Carbone experience is an experience that happens to you. I purposefully chose "to" as the preposition to follow "experience" because Carbone unfolds and draws you close; the staff flutters about, dishes are served as if delivered by a stork, food likely to be the best food you'll eat in your entire life is waxed lyrical before, during, and after consumption, and an ineffable feeling of ease among all guests settles in as gently as a penumbra.The staff at Carbone is comprised of human talismans who eddy through the restaurant on panache and conviviality. Ask for the location of the restroom and you'll be escorted to it via Moses separating the sea, or dine on distilled colloquialness from the waiter and you'll feel like old pals.James Joyce once wrote, "The artist, like the God of creation, remains within or behind or beyond or above his handiwork, invisible, refined out of existence, indifferent, paring his fingernails."Joyce's quote is the foundation on which I imagine the owners of Carbone: three masters cloaked in velvet burgundy suits hidden behind a Julian Schnabel painting poked with peepholes, observing their patrons marveling at the spicy rigatoni vodka and how they'll never again enjoy vodka sauce because Carbone's is so perfect it could be consumed as soup, tearing up at the sight of a cast iron skillet of meatballs borne by divinity, and gasping at how all future life experiences involving veal parmesan are forever ruined by Carbone's lionized and utterly unmatchable dish."'What is life if not the shadow of a fleeting dream?'" says one of the owners, quoting Umberto Eco.Another owner, swirling the last drops of an orange and cinnamon margarita over ice in a glass that catches the glint in his eye, says, "What is Carbone but the fleeting dream itself?"

Wow! Dinner for two at Boucherie Park last night. They have certainly raised the bar for fine dining on Park Avenue. The restaurant is gorgeous. Upon entrance, the huge bar is on the left with lots of table seating on that side. The regular tables are on the right and go back into the distance. The whole place is decorated with white subway tiles and huge framed mirrors on the walls. Authentic Paris bistro surroundings. The menu has interesting French selections and there is a separate menu for steaks, several selections are for two persons. For starters We selected mussels with a wonderful cream sauce and small slices of sausage. I had the arugula salad with candied pecans, scrumptious. We each had two glass of generously poured red wine. I had the 16oz center cut fillet mignon served perfectly medium rare, just the way I like it. Julie had a beautiful portion of cod served upon a nice orange sauce. We shared a desert of pistachio ice cream served on a chocolate cookie. Two coffees with refills and we were stuffed. The waitstaff, hostess and everybody we came in contact with couldn't have been more gracious. They treated us like long lost friends. I have to say that this is the finest Saturday night dinner we have had this year. This is a new place. My advise, get in there soon before reservations become difficult to get.

To the staff at Gem, thank you for an amazing dinner!!!The fact that you can get a delicious tasting menu at a fairly decent price is a winner. And the fact that this is more of a homey setting, not a fancy schmancy restaurant where you can be casual and have an amazing time? I am SOLD.My friends booked this place for my birthday and I am so grateful to eat here. They just changed the menu for the day so I can't compare it to a prior menu but every dish was delicious from beginning to end. I was actually surprised that the cabbage was one of my favorite dishes (I'm not a big fan of cabbage...).Chef Flynn is a rising star who's food you have to experience for yourself. And the staff was on point for the entire service.Reservations are a must. But I loved this restaurant so much, I booked it for my best friend & his fiancé in celebration of his engagement. Thank you for delivering!

Where do I even begin with this one? This place is beyond amazing and that's coming from a REAL NY'er who knows a thing or two about pizza. If you're not familiar with Artichoke Basille's pizza well you've been warned that eating anything more than one slice might just be overkill. The slices here are huge but not obnoxiously big. Their dough is different from what you'd get from most other pizzerias in that it resembles more of bread type consistency which is necessary to hold whatever sauce is on it. I usually go with their classic artichoke slice which reminds me of artichoke dip on top of a pizza with a nice amount of mootz..Its heavy, keeps my belly full, and is a bit pricey for a slice but you get what you pay for 10x.That's all there is to really say about Artichoke Basille's. DO IT!!

While I intended to search for a decent steam room in NYC, I instead discovered Modo Yoga in freezing snowy weather, a hot yoga studio where students practice in a heated room. What I really liked about this studio is that it is not only a studio where students practice yoga in a heated room, but there is also an incorporation of spirituality and safe space, which is something rare when it comes to hot yoga or classical yoga. There's this calming effect after the practice which is something that usually I feel after practicing kundalini. So far I have taken only two classes and I really liked Sasha's class... his class had me coming back for a double and considering about signing up for a month unlimited. Modo Yoga is located two doors down from Benefits, and you have to walk up the stairs because the elevator does not go to the second floor. The staff members are really nice and the mats, blankets, towels, and re-usable bottles are on-the-house for first time students, even if you come back for a double on the same day with a few hours gap. For a re-usable stainless steel bottle, you have to leave your ID at the front desk. They have filtered water to fill up your bottles... and hot tea too. After practice, the mats are to be wiped down by each individual students on the hanging rods. The changing rooms are equipped with lockers with built-in locks, two sinks, three toilets and four shower stalls. It is recommended to drink about two glasses of water 90 minutes prior to the practice and two glasses of water with lemon, sea salt, or an electrolyte replenisher after the practice. $40 for the first month unlimited and $115 afterwards.

I have sworn up and down that Levain is the best cookie there is to find in this beautiful city of ours but I'll be damned if Chip doesn't inch close. I now present a highly scientific comparison of the two and while I think Levain still comes out ahead, there's no way I'd ever turn down a Chip cookie. Variety: This one is in Chip's bag. While I appreciate Levain's philosophy of sticking to three tried-and-true cookies (CCC and walnut, oatmeal raisin, and chocolate and PB), Chip throws down the gauntlet with a dizzying array of options. Thus far, I've tried the S'mores, Nutella with sea salt, and white chocolate and macadamia. They are all reasons why God intended you to eat one or two whole cookies and take a restorative nap. And trust me, it took some real willpower not to just throw in the butterscotch and triple chocolate too. Taste: Pretty much the same. Both boast an enormous gooey center and taste kind of like a scone or biscuit. Both are more spherical pucks than a traditional flat cookie. Both are better in your belly.Bang for your buck: Levain is a smidge bigger for roughly the same price. Ugh, this was entirely unproductive and I think I'm a few pounds fatter from all of this scientific research but it was worth it. Buy two, get yourself an ice cold bottle of milk, and then eat them in the sun in a park with some puppies playing at your feet to achieve nirvana.

Turquoise velvet couches, colorful warm flowers, puffy and scrumptious pastries, hints of gold-finished furniture, and marble decor -- what more can you ask for? This cafe (soon to be restaurant) takes up the nicely-lit half of an upscale furniture store. With the flower shop in the corner, the bar in the other corner, and an open kitchen behind the counter, high ceilings and large windows, the ambiance is incredible. Though I imagine there will be some hiccups with service and organization in the beginning, I expect La Mercerie to be the next highly anticipated cafe/restaurant in the area.I enjoyed a finely crafted cup of cappuccino ($5) and a bowl of 12 choquettes ($7) and they were delightful! (Almost finished the entire bowl before my friend arrived). Whether it's to catch up with a friend, have a date night with your significant other, or spend some time by yourself, La Mercerie will be a welcoming place. I have high expectations for their full menu, which will be available early-February.

Two Little Red Hens consistently makes me want to come back for more. I highly recommend a visit to this tiny but famous bakery whether you're a local or not. Don't be shunned when you see a line out the door. This place is really tiny, but the line moves at a decent speed. I have yet to try everything, but I can speak to several of their desserts.I will note first if you are coming by around the holidays, expect a long line out the door. Order ahead if you want something guaranteed. Also, they serve pies in the morning, cupcakes in the evening, and specific flavors on certain days of the week. I have tried numerous things here: the mini key lime pie, key lime cupcakes, peanut butter cupcakes, brooklyn blackout cake and cupcakes, red velvet cupcakes, chocolate/vanilla sprinkled cupcakes, holiday themed cheesecakes, coconut creme pie, chocolate mousse pie, tri-berry scone, chocolate chunk cookies, and oatmeal raisin cookies.Everything is amazing. My personal favorites are the key lime cupcakes, key lime pie, and chocolate mousse pie. Their selection can be limited or sold out by certain times of the day, so your best bet is to come in the morning or early afternoon, except if you want cupcakes. All their cookies are large, soft baked, and delicious. Their creme pies have a wonderful texture. The list can go on, but I would recommend their creme pies and cupcakes first. I love this place. It's become one of my favorite neighborhood spots. For parties, I've made sure to stop by and get some dessert to bring. The reaction has always been positive.
