It's a definite must visit in the Upper East.

Like many others, the thought of having artichokes on my pizza was very different for me. But I can honestly say that Artichoke is one of my favorite pizza slices of all time. Let's be honest... it's a different creation than any other slice.Things I like here: Every single slice they serve but I highly recommend the artichoke slice of course. Bigger crust and dough, creamy and cheesy goodness along with the size of this slice makes not only every late night drunks dream but even for those who are looking just to enjoy this beast. I mean if I can't eat more than 3 slices then their slices must be beast (I can serious chow down on some pizza).Things I don't like: I've been to a many of their locations and like many of others, this one gets packed, especially late nights....... oh! and its super small so the line does out the door. I think those are the only issues I have here. (thinking........)The service is quick which makes the line less scary and despite being bombarded by a million hungry New Yorkers they seem to keep it friendly...... seriously guys! How do you do it? The patience is unreal! I've never been the biggest fan of paying $5 bucks for a slice, but I make an exception for how good these slices are. Basically... what I'm trying to say is that YOU MUST TRY AN ARTICHOKE AT LEAST ONCE IN YOUR LIFE!!!

The cutest little, cozy Thai/Vietnamese/Malaysian restaurant located in East Village. Cute spot for a date night or just catching up over yummy eats with your gals! Food: DELICIOUS! They have a little bit of everything - vietnamese pho, Malaysian noodles, and thai curries! I loved having all these options and makes it the perfect spot for when you're out with a bigger group and just want some variety! We ordered the red curry with chicken which wasn't as spicy as I was hoping but it was still delicious nonetheless!The chicken pad kee mao noodles were a great and the chicken was spiced to perfection. For both, I was happy to see they didn't skimp on the amount of chicken or veggies :) ps. Free checkin gets you a yummy thai iced tea! Cost: worth the food and the portions! We ordered one appetizer and two entrees -- a lot more than we needed really! Portions are big. They also had a lunchtime special but not sure if the portions are different for that. Staff: super attentive and quick! Our food was served very quickly and our waiter was able to answer any questions we had about the menu. Will I be back? Definitely want to bring more friends here! With all the variety on their menu, an easy crowdpleaser.

What an absolute New York City gem! As you enter, follow the pub/bar-lined pathway to the end where there is usually a sweet smiling host to greet you. The restaurant is quaint and the decor gives you a feeling that you're sitting in an English countryside cottage. The restaurant is always busy so the noise level may get a bit high, but the atmosphere is filled with laughter and people uttering lots of food-loving sounds.I have not had a single bad dish here. The lamb shank with orange zest is an absolute mouth-watering explosion of flavors with meat so juicy and soft, you won't need a knife. English Indian at its best! The lamb in the Shepherd's pie puts a whole lot of oomph in a what is typically a bland dish. And the fried chicken and waffles is worth every single, delicious calorie. The portions here are generous. But, order lots and you won't regret it. The extras tastes just as amazing the next day.

Best Pork Tacos // Great HorchataFast Serve // No Alcohol or SeatingEvery time I pass by I try to stop in. Pork and Chicken are my favorite. Time and time again... there is a line. Tastes so good your taste buds will thank you for the adventure!The Scene: VERY Casual, Quick, AuthenticDestination Rating: 9Date Rating: 4Hob Nob Potential: N/AStrong Suggestion: Grab an app and a beer elsewhere... plenty of options nearby.

My eyes lit up right away when I first chomped into a bagel at BO's. This was, I said to myself, a truly goddamn remarkable amazing life-changing bagel of doom.After several subsequent visits, I still feel that way. And I know other people do too -- pay attention when you visit and you'll see first-timers looking astonished as they come to grips with BO's airy, bubbly, crisp, chewy marvels that practically reinvent the bagel.P.S. Don't sleep on the bialys, they're packed with obscene amounts of onions and garlic, and they're wonderful.

Review strictly for Cronut: As a marketer, there is something incredibly fascinating about the success of the cronut (trademarked legally by the James Beard winning "fancy nancy" Dom. Ansel). I remember the hype several years ago, and all the other hybrid foods it created. I also remember rolling my eyes at the "hype" and how everyone will get over the "cronut" till the next food trend comes out.Well, I was surprised to learn there is still a huge line outside to get cronuts. Also, this location only makes a set number of cronuts per day (your loss if you're too late), and sometimes with a maximum number you could buy per day (two is the limit with a huge line)...basically there has to be something good here if this keeps selling out.And I can safely say that the cronut is worth the hype. It has dimension, a trifecta of flavor, and it's just the right size for the steep price ($6.50 per cronut). This month's flavor is blackberry & buttermilk and it was absolutely delicious and worth the possible 700+ calories.I'm not sure if I will be back every month to try the "flavor of the month," but this is not a bad option if you're feeling down (or happy).

A rare gem in NYC. Exquisite food, wonderful service, and a rustic ambiance make this one of my new favorite restaurants in NYC.We came to Gramercy Tavern as a party of 7. Originally I had made it for 6 people and added 7 at the last moment. I was worried that they would be unable to accommodate our last minute change but they were able to increase our table size.I was also worried due to the fact that we were such a large party, and we had a special cake that we wanted to present at the end of the evening, that things might not go entirely as planned. Side note, the last time that I had a special "surprise" cake that I wanted to present at the end of the dinner, our waiter (at another restaurant) walked right up to the host of the evening (who the cake was for) and asked "when would you like your cake to come out" when uh...it was supposed to be a surprise. Yikes! We were nervous to say the least.We all started with cocktails and champagne and the entire table opted for the seasonal tasting menu which had several courses (6-8 perhaps). The wait staff was on point. They all assembled at the table together to remove dishes as well as to bring new items. They did not interrupt your conversation which I really liked as there's nothing I can't stand more than being in the middle of a story and someone butting in with "would you like still or flat water?" Just give everyone a minute to settle in and look at everything! That, they did. I was impressed. I would describe it as overly attentive without you even noticing.The food was just, you have to try it for yourself. Definitely opt for the larger tasting course menu as there are some real gems on there. I don't want to go into the food too much to ruin anything but honestly everything was out of this world. On par (or even better) than a lot of the 3-star Michelin restaurants in NYC.The cake event went on flawlessly as they brought the cake in its entirety on a beautiful raised plate so our guest could see it (as it actually had her photo on it) and then they cut the pieces up and brought everyone a piece (and the guest was given the "face" cut-out from her cake, it was very cute). There also was no cake fee which I was shocked by. Usually places charge around $8 a person to cut and serve the cake. I find that ridiculous and sometimes it deters us from certain restaurants.I really enjoyed our time at Gramercy Tavern and want to go back. I felt like for the price and the quality of food, it was well worth it.

I'm so happy that this place has opened in my neighborhood. Angelo Iezzi has brought an amazing thing like pizza al taglio to NYC and it will have me coming for more and more and more.They have so many incredible options of pizza romana, aka square slices, and you'll wanna try each and every one of them. I remember growing up in Italy and loving a slice of the potato one, as well as the simpler ones with just tomato and mozzarella and basil. The dough is almost like a thin focaccia and trust me, it will change your life! They have a truffle oil one - and OMG it's so insanely good. And if you love truffles like I do you cannot miss out on this little gem. Make your way to the UES and savor these amazing pizze quadrate romane. BTW absolutely love the play on "SPQR" turned into PQR - I'm obsessed! Thank you Angelo (and San Matteo) for partnering up and bringing a piece of the Belpaese to NYC. Couldn't be happier.

Everything about this place is SO important. The atmosphere is classy but approachable. It's like going to dinner at your richer-than-you friend's house. You want to be mad, because your friend's life is put-together, and perfect, and so aesthetically pleasing, but you can't be mad because she's also down-to-earth and friendly and looks at you in the eyes and genuinely nods when you tell her about your peasant problems.It was so pretty in there that as we sat down, my friend said to me "wow, let's fall in love tonight". The waitress smiled but seemed like she'd heard that before. And if we weren't already in love, this dinner would have made it happen.Spiced coconut chips are so delicate and flavorful and important. Waitress almost took the dish away before we had cleaned up the last crumbs and we both involuntarily yelled at her with absolute, desperate fear. She left the bowl, we licked it clean.Vegetable curry was perfectly warm and healthy and delicious and IMPORTANT. I tossed the mint chutney all over it and also had to lick this bowl clean. Busy night for my tongue, gotta say. Side of beluga lentils was thrilling and well worth $4. Beluga lenTHRILLs.Service is super fast and friendly and everyone seems to care about eating healthy wholesome food!Go here to fall in love asap.

All this hype about this place and I've never been. HOWEVER. I finally was able to hit this spot last night (2/10/2018). I absolutely did not expect there would be a huge wait at 6:30 pm. It really took me by surprise especially since this place is hidden on the 2nd floor in a building of ktown. Once the elevator opened, there were so many people waiting for a table. Luckily for my boyfriend and I, our friends were already seated and waiting for us patiently.I had no idea what to expect since I've never really done KBBQ. The only KBBQ I've had is Picnic Garden from Flushing and it's only alright since it's a buffet. We ordered the Beef and Pork Platter and oh my gosh. It was amazing. I liked the fact that the waiters will help cook it and cut it for you too!I really liked both the pork platter and beef platter. The pork belly in the pork platter is crispy but not overcooked (thank you waiter). And you can order rice on the side, which I highly recommend, and it goes really well with it! The condiments that come with the meal are also super yummy--like the bean paste, ugh. I am so obsessed with that bean paste. I can eat it by itself or just the bean paste with the rice. The beef platter.. Super dreamy. I love it. I want to come back here already! My body and soul is ready to relive this experience.*FYI- Listen to the beautiful sound of it sizzling. It's.. delightful and soothing..Will definitely come back soon!

Love being able to have bowls other than your typical Chipotle and poke! One of my favorite cuisines is Korean so of course, I had to try their Seoul bowl!I love all the flavors that were encompassed in the Seoul Bowl! The sauce was mildly spicy with a bit of a sweet/tanginess to it. The bean sprouts provided a crunch when mixed in with the rest of the toppings and quinoa. I was really happy with the freshness of ingredients and the option to have quinoa instead of rice. Also to note, they had a lot of Asian flavored canned drinks, which to my surprise was really good. I tried their Lychee!

We were tipsy one night, and couldn't get into any karaoke bars. We must have decided that we wanted to eat, cus we sat down to a diner at about 12:15am. Just to prove how good this place is, there was a 30 minute wait. Everything about this experience was incredible, until Gster ate all the pierogis. This was my first Ukranian dining experience, and had I been fully aware, I may have thought twice about going. Thankfully I didn't. Patch and I split the French Toast + 8 peroigis, Sean got the stuffed cabbage, and Gster never ordered. I was so excited to try the pierogis, and once they were served, we were too busy eating the french toast that before we knew it, we looked down and there was only 3 left! Patch knew not to blame me, since I had never had them.. so Gster was the easy culprit. Gster didn't even realize we had ordered them, not him! Thankfully I still got to try a few and I actually really liked them, but liked the cheese ones the best. It's like a dumpling ravioli. The french toast was perfect, and I can only imagine what the omelettes are like. The stuffed cabbage was apparently really good, but a little cold. The beers were massive, and the service was excellent. This is an absolute must, and I can't wait to go back.

What a great new place for fresh teas! I love the fresh fruit in their fruit teas. So far I've tried the grapefruit green tea, and the super fruit green tea, and they have both been delicious! Their spicy tuna roll also tasted very fresh and is a nice touch if you're looking for a light meal or snack. The employees have been helpful and attentive, and it really feels like they pay special attention to their craft. I'm excited to come back to try additional items on their menu!

No doubt in my mind, this is the best pizza in New York City. This is saying a lot, since there are so many great pizza parlors in the city. Of course it's a matter of personal taste. Some like their pizzas greasy, so the oil drips all over their fingers. Some like their crust thin, others like theirs thick. Preference for toppings is all over the place. The only pizza that's awful is sold at the now ubiquitous 99-Cent/slice stores that sell re-heated pre-frozen pies. My Pie makes authentic Roman style pizza. The flour for the dough is imported. The ingredients are fresh. The slices are square. It tastes like the pizza I eat in Rome at the Pizza Franco e Cristina on the Via del Portico d'Ottavia. Even if you try it and don't agree that it's the best you've had, at least you can say you had authentic Italian pizza right here in Manhattan, near Bloomingdales.

I just found out Keki opened another store in Koreatown so I had to run over to make sure it was real. I just sampled the GreenTea cheesecake and it was delicious. I had wanted to buy Greentea cheesecake a while back in their chinatown store but they discovered they no longer made it. The workers are real nice and told me they only made greentea in this store now. I should have asked it was permanent flavor or seasonal, but I assumed it was permanent. I didn't buy anything, but I shall be back very soon to load up.

Three things I've learned from eating here and from friends' reviews:1) Avoid the "typical" stuff like pad Thai, noodle dishes, etc.2) Avoid most of the lunch specials, a bunch of #1's dishes are offered and the quality just isn't that good.3) Avoid chicken dishes.That being said, this is one of my favorite Thai places. The service is friendly and the Isan food is great if you know what to get. Some of my favorites:Papaya salad (som tum) - Both the Som Tum Thai (with dried shrimp and peanuts) and the Som Tum Poo Plara (with preserved crab and pickled fish) are delicious, though the latter is more pungently flavorful. I love spicy food, but this papaya salad is too beast for me. Everything at the bottom soaks up that fiery, vibrant marinade, so the closer you get to finishing, the more it burns. I always have to remind myself to go pansy mode and get this mild. The few times I've forgotten have been heaven and hell all at once.Spicy ground meat salad (larb) - I always get this with crispy pork (moo krob) and wrap it in the various veggies they provide. Larb is listed as with ground meat, but this is just thinly cut, slightly bigger pieces of meat. The vinegary, sour, and sweet flavors go so well with the crunch in this dish.Pad ped - This comes with Thai eggplant, bell peppers, basil, and wild ginger in a spicy curry paste. It's nicely savory with a bit of sweetness. I usually get it with catfish (pla dook), so I have to deal with the minefield of bones, but it goes so well with the sauce. I don't like eggplant, but Thai eggplant is an exception. It's small and green, and the sliced pieces look a bit like okra but are way better (I hate okra with every fiber of my being unless it's in stew).Sauteed morning glory with fresh chili (pukk boong fai dang) - Such a good side dish. I had it with crispy pork once and there was too much fattiness, so now I get the simpler one, but it never lacks flavor and a bit of spice.Spicy lemongrass soup (tom yum) with seafood - So fragrant, sour, and the hot broth feels so comforting... until the spiciness hits. They put a good amount of shrimp, squid, and mussels inside.Frog legs - This is one of the first places I ever tried frog legs in. I always get them with basil sauce. They have a slight crunch on the outside but are tender inside. I've tried the version with garlic sauce, which is okay but much milder. I doubt I'd choose it again over the basil sauce.Make sure to get sticky rice. It's a great accompaniment for many of the entrees. Grab a small ball, smooth it into a disk, layer some meat and veggies in, make a little wrap, and enjoy. Their Thai iced tea is a bit more sweet than I'd like, but it's good for washing down the spiciness.I've taken many people here. I view it as a rite of passage for our friendship: If you enjoy the food here, we'll be just fine. If you don't, it's probably better that we cut ties and go our separate ways.

one of the best baguettes to grace a banh mi in terms of mouth feel!the lightly crisped thin-crusted bread while still being soft on the inside did not shred my gums. This was the best part. Most banh mi baguettes have really hard thick crusts, while crisp and crunchy, it will shred the roof of your mouth and gums. I ordered this via eat24 and the sandwiches arrived still warm and crispy even with the below 30-degree temps outside. good job Xe May.Get the duke sandwich. While $9 is a lot for a banh mi, the bread and meat combination works here. The meat to bread ratio was on point. not too much bread with an acceptable amount of meat. Its Viet meatballs that taste like sweat and zesty mixed with savory corn beef hash. Mixed with the crispy veggies, jalapenos and aromatic crispy bread, this was a symphony of flavors and textures. I also tried the classic sandwich and I suggest passing on it.For $8 for Viet ham and headcheese, it doesn't taste any better than your $5-6 banh mi besides having excellent bread. plus they use the same zesty sauce in it as the duke. IMO, the classic Viet sandwiches need to have mayo and pate instead. It's good, but I rather get it from another place.

Freshness rules here & it is part, a major part, of what makes Mimi Cheng's so good. A really fresh dumpling is sublime, & that's what you can count on here. It is Nov 2017 & the Monthly Special Dumpling is: (drum roll please--)--Thanksgiving Dinner Dumplings. De lish!!! Anyone visiting NYC, come here & try FRESH Dumplings! Any time of year.The woman at the counter where I placed my order was very nice. Service with a smile. I'll be back, for sure.

Who doesn't love a good blow-out. I need them to just simplify my life and not spend hours doing my super thick hair. This is why Kim is an angel. She does the most amazing job, and honestly does it in way less time than I have had for other blow-outs. Beautiful salon, Kim is the only person I have seen here but she is so lovely, and I can't suggest her enough! Also they have rosé.

Oh Au Za'atar, how special you are indeed!What a warm and inviting spot in the East Village that exceeded all of our expectations. Beautiful wood paneling, brick wall backdrop, long draped curtains and dim lighting for all your date night and group needs. The owner Tarik was the sweetest host, as were his servers (our main guy being Khalid). Water constantly refilled, table checked up on by 4 different waiters; they were aiming to please throughout the evening. My friends and I spent a good 3 hours there and weren't rushed at all. As a matter of fact, we received a round of Prosecco and their knafeh dessert on the house, and invited to stay even longer. All the while as the restaurant was getting packed with nearly all the tables taken.The French Lebanese food was so beautifully prepared. They started us off with pita bread covered in za'atar and a side of yogurt dipping sauce. Delicious and creamy, the pita a perfect vehicle for dipping. We ordered the Mixed Grill Platter Supreme $68, a huge tray of beautifully grilled meats including baby lamb chops, filet mignon, beef kafta kebab, chicken kafta, and shrimp. It came with sides of pita and sumac fries, and numerous dipping sauces that were sublime, especially the za'atar garlic aioli. Mezze & Dips Tray $48 was delicious as well, each with its own flavor profile. The Batata Harra (spicy roasted potatoes), Arnabeet Bi Tarator (cauliflower in tahini sauce), and Baba Ghanoush were particularly outstanding. I couldn't get enough of their dips and mezze spread all over the pita bread. We were oohing and aahing when the platters were presented, and mm mmming after every bite. A telltale sign of a meal done right. A++ location in the East Village that I'm dying to go back to!

Eleven Madison Park was nothing short of magical. The price may be a pain point for some (especially if you're opting for the wine pairings), but when you're devouring course after course, the rest of the world comes to a complete halt, and nothing else matters. You sit there, a fork in one hand and a knife in the other, with an expression that can only be described as a stupid, dumbfounded grin. Because in that moment, you are not the you who strolls down Fifth Avenue with shopping bags in hand, or the you who takes trips to Europe to eat the best of what chefs around the world have to offer, or even the you who works tirelessly to scrape up enough disposable income to treat yourself to a night out here. In that moment, you are part of the EMP family, and you will unquestionably be treated as such from the second you step into their doors.To get some of the logistics out of the way, I came here on a Friday night at 6:15PM with my mom to celebrate her birthday. I called ahead of time to let the restaurant know the special occasion, in addition to my aversion to cheese. Along with the tasting menu, we opted for the wine pairings, along with a table-side brewing of the High Mountain Oolong tea at the end of the meal. In total, the food came out to $642 and change, and the beverages an additional $406.Overall, I just wanted to share my thoughts on a few different points:1. Wine PairingsWhile I enjoyed the wine pairings, if I were to return, I don't think I'd be getting it again. The wines were interesting, and they definitely paired well with the food that was presented, but ultimately, I don't think the varieties we were served justified the high cost. A vast majority of the wines were French - not really an issue, just something to keep in mind if you're not the biggest fan of wines that taste earthy and heavily reflect the terroir of where the grapes were grown.2. Prolonging the EMP ExperienceAt the conclusion of the meal, the restaurant gifted us a bag filled with a jar of house-made granola from that morning, along with a cleverly designed menu of all the courses we tasted that night. The menu itself is folded in the same tin can that the caviar course was presented in, and was a nice touch compared to the plain paper menus that were handed out in the past. In addition, for my mom's birthday, they also included a large chocolate bar in her bag that she has yet to taste.3. Table-side teaAt first, I didn't think the $24 price tag on a table-side experience would be worth whatever EMP had in store. Thankfully, I was proven wrong, and I actually learned a great deal about the restaurant's philosophies in brewing both tea and coffee, along with some of the science and art behind a great cup of brewed tea. The Gaiwan set they used looked and felt amazing in its pure simplicity, and the tea sommelier was kind enough to provide an extra steeping of the Oolong as well.4. FoodTo quickly touch on the courses we were served that night:* Black and White Cookie with Cheddar and Apple - B* Scallops with Sea Urchin, Scallop Butter, and Scallop Broth - A+* Caviar Eggs Benedict with Smoked Ham and Sturgeon - A+* Foie Gras marinated with Squash and Pumpkin Seeds - A+* Poached Halibut with Turnip - A* Mushroom Tart with Cremini and Black Truffle & Portobello - A+* Venison un Croute with Foie Gras and Civet - B* Roasted Carrot with Buckwheat and Mustard - B+* Baked Potato with Horseradish and Bacon - B+* (Instead of Grilled Cheese) Chocolate Tuile with Creme Fraiche Ice Cream and Cranberry - A-* Pear-Cranberry Donut with Mulled Wine Ice Cream - A* Chocolate Covered Pretzel & Apple Brandy - A-While EMP didn't wow us with an impeccable menu suited to our exact taste buds course after course, overall, we had a sublime evening. The granola they sent us home with is fantastic, and I'm still very happy about the fact that we got to bring home the tin can with the EMP insignia branded on the top - I actually considered just taking it during the caviar course but decided against it.Reservations may be difficult to come by and try for, and the price tag may be even more difficult to justify, but given the chance, I would do it all again in a heartbeat. Chef Daniel Humm has created not only a stunning, innovative menu that will pique your interests throughout the meal, but also an experience that you will cherish for years to come.

I was a bit skeptical about this place, both from their $50, 30-minute omakase business model and their controversial chef, David Bouhadana. My visit to Sushi by Bou started inauspiciously with me falling down their metal stairs. (Watch your step on those.) The hostess quickly ushered me inside, bandaged me up, and helped me with a lot of warmth that went beyond the typical cover-your-ass stuff. She was sweet as pie and offered me a complimentary glass of sake, as well as a discount on my meal.Thankfully, my experience was only uphill from here. Sipping on a lovely, often-refilled green tea and my sake, which was refreshing and balanced, I was treated to 10+ pieces of fish. Here's what I remember: yellowtail, two kinds of tuna, salmon, toro, scallop, uni, ikura, wagyu-uni, eel.The fish quality was uniformly very good. A few stood out: the uni, which I don't always enjoy, was creamy and sweet, from Santa Barbara; the toro was melt-in-your-mouth; the scallops were pleasantly clean tasting, set off by a nice burst of ashy garnish; the eel at the end had the perfect caramelization. I was also skeptical of their wagyu-uni (seems like throwing two rich, buzzwordy ingredients together), but it went together surprisingly well. Rice was also uniformly good.Some pieces had garnishes or sauces, which were judicious with a couple of exceptions: the sweet soy glaze on the yellowtail was too heavy, and the yuzu on the salmon was spoiled by too big of a wasabi kick.Unfair to compare this to the sushi temples of New York, but was head and shoulders above gourmet-budget options like Sugarfish and Kazunori. It's definitely punching above its $50 weight.It is a pretty quick pace, and some of these were pre-sliced for speed. It's super intimate, with about 8 seats. It's well decorated and there's a nice smell from the rice and blowtorching. The staff was chatty and friendly-- I enjoyed talking with the bartender about his travels in Japan after I finished up. David wasn't working, but I got to talk a bit with my sushi chef. I always feel a little nervous about dining solo but they made me feel welcome.Reservations weren't hard to come by for lunch (I texted a day out), but I would imagine you'd need to plan further ahead for dinner. They bill this as a pre-theater option, but this worked great for me as a quick lunch off the desk.

I was looking for a fun festive place for my friends and I to celebrate a holiday dinner, and came across Havana Central. Reservation was a breeze, they tried their best to accommodate all our needs on a very busy holiday weekend.The extremely welcoming and friendly hostess sat our party immediately upon our reservation time, we were given a great table and the best waiter Ivan. Ivan kept us entertained and laughing all night.The food was great, we were all very happy with our entrees, the highlights were the:Lobster Stuffed Avocado with plantains Mashed Yucca and theChurro Ice Cream Bowl.Best of all was the live music later in the night, the musicians kept us all dancing in our seats. My friends and I will definitely return and recommend this restaurant to anyone looking for good food, music and a fun festive friendly atmosphere.

Same delicious mini cupcakes for a dollar each. Same story I told in my tip today. No pick and choose. It's take what you can get. Same great flavors. Great holiday gift box for an additional charge. Employees were wonderful. Friendly and available as you enter. No hard sell. Great location close for me. Just a half mile walk. I'll return for sure. I can't wait until it's full service like the other locations. For now it's a pop up. Maybe full service by Valentines Day or shortly after!! I'm a fan!

I love this store!We were trolling the Lower East Side and stumbled upon the mecca of all things Chanel. The 2 gentlemen who run this boutique are super friendly and helped me make my selection. The vintage jewelry selection is terrific and all the items are in very good shape. The bags are beautiful and carefully curated. The clothing looked lovely and none of that "thrift store" smell. Everything looked and smelled fresh. I will definitely be coming back to expand my vintage Chanel collection!

Love this place! I am finally writing a review after coming here for more than two dozen times to give them the credit they deserve :)They have clean and bright dinning room, space is decently big for Chinatown. Everything tastes great, I pretty much had everything on their menu: Roast duck/chicken/pork, congee, wonton, noodle, rice rolls, and of course the Bao Zai Fan. Delicious, satisfying and authentic. The best part? Everything costs almost nothing (NYC standard). Every time I come, I end up ordering too much, but without the guilt of hurting my wallet. Brought my parents visiting from China here for brunch one day and they approved as well.

Clinton Street gets funky. A newly revived restaurant row has sprouted and Lil Gem is the jewel on the crown. Minnie, Simply Hooked, Speedy Romeo's and Byggz Sandwich shop and more. Lil' Gem offers a room with cushioned baguettes, and a beamed ceiling. The room transports you to a Middle Eastern living room Clever Mediterranean flavors really shine from the open kitchen.Preview menu on the opening night.Ate:Muhamarra & flatbreadFried cauliflowerWhole fishTotal: $43The muhamarra is a red pepper dip topped with walnuts(toasted) Exotic flavor and crunchy walnuts is the ideal spot to dip this double zero flour hot flatbread. Lemony fried cauliflower also works great with the dip. The whole fish was melt in your mouth- simply seared with salt, pepper and garlic- the seafood equivalent of a perfectly cooked steak. Scrumptious! Super friendly and welcoming room and bringing monstrous Mediterranean flavors to the LES!

It is true that the increasing price of the menu is annoying, but for now I consider Contra one of my favorite restaurants in the city. I find their tasting menu very unique and well-executed in the balance of flavor and creativity. I've come here in a group for the regular menu back in 2017 (when it was $67) and recently again for the pricier but longer Valentine's day menu. Haven't gotten the wine pairing so can't speak on that - ordered a bottle and cocktails each time. The bread is amazing, as many have mentioned, and probably my favorite bread ever. I don't remember the specifics of the meal from last year, but the highlight of this year was the blissfully buttery Long Island duck with leg fat wrapped in morels and the apple semifreddo with lemon meringue. The cod was cooked perfectly as well. I think both experiences started with an amuse bouche involving a chip or some sort which was crisped to perfection. The main draw for me is how intentional all of the ingredients are and the fact that there are really not many dishes like them out there.I will say the somm on Valentine's was not very good and recommended some wines incorrectly based on our specifications, but we ended up happy with the bottle she picked. I also found the last dessert too chocolate and moussey for my taste. Overall, I'm still going to highly recommend Contra to anyone looking for a Michelin star experience and a different take on New American.

As someone who went through a Tesla obsession back in the day, there's so much I love about this place...The accordian-wall/door of Patent coffee that opens up to reveal the secret hallway to the speakeasy, the interesting light fixtures, the menu with experiment sketches, and of course the fact that it's in the Radio Wave building! You feel like you're sitting where history was made, as you sip on a cocktail. Our favorite was Radio Waves, the cucumber tequila/mezcal drink. I also enjoyed the Odd love. Nice to see some of the drinks incorporate Patent coffee! There are also some simple bar bites and sandwiches available. The only slight downer was that I almost got stuck in the bathroom! The door latch tends to get jammed... And the second time I went I almost couldn't unlodge the latch. Ten minutes later... I found my way out. Glad I had my phone and could wirelessly transmit distress signals to my friend... Or maybe it Tesla's experimental setups were still present in the vicinity... I could've used the dim, vintage lights in the bathroom to send my SOS message. Haha I know, terrible reference, but it had to be done!

Great quality ice cream. I tried the ube. It wasn't for me in large quantities but objectively it was good. Highly recommend it if you like the flavor. It was full of ube flavor. I instead got the mix of matcha and black sesame. I loved it. The soft serve was super creamy. The flavors of both were well pronounced. I coupled it with a chocolate cone which was a dollar extra. The ice cream came out to be about $5+, not bad given the quality and quantity. Definitely can be shared I feel. Btw CC minimum is $5. Overall, great ice cream!

Cozy dimly lit fun wine and whisky bar on Stone Street. Great selection of cocktails, wines by the glass and small bites. Honoring Robert Burns month I ordered the "Fall of Eve" Very tasty and blasphemous! Afterwards, we savored some wine with various small bites:Salmon Tartar, Garlic shrimp, fois gras with toast, manchego, camembert, olives. Good cheerful spot on a cold winter's night. Acoustics are a bit loud, thus you will be screaming to be heard at some point. Cheers!

HUZZAH I've finally found an ice cream parlor with a small enough ice cream cone for me to actually finish on my own. Yes, I know that sounds absolutely ridiculous because who can't finish an ice cream cone by themselves, but before you judge me, let me first tell you something even more ridiculous so you can really properly judge me for the weirdo that I am... I... just...really... don't... like... ice cream. I KNOW I KNOW IM SORRY I'm this way guys but I just can't seem to ever get excited about ice cream. Halfway into a cone and I'm usually already regretting my decision and force-feeding the rest of it to my boyfriend/sister/whoever else is in my vicinity. That's why I'm SO thankful for La Newyorkina because I can actually finish their little bb cones and not have to face judgement by the rest of the ice cream loving world.Not only do they have the cutest little cones, but they also have the most delicious Mexican flavors. Like, don't even get me started on their Tres Leche ice cream. I mean I don't even really like ice cream and I'm ALL about their Tres Leche so that has to tell you something about how damn good it is. Now, I can't say I'm ever really craving ice cream because I just don't do crazy things like that (#jokes), but the next time I want to feel like a normal ice-cream loving human being, you know where I'm going!

I don't know if I got lucky for not, but it looks that way as I was able to be seated immediately as there was only two of us that wanted to give this place a try from all of the raving fans.Everyone greeted you that worked here regardless if they were your server or not. Policy for working there? Possibly. It was cool and welcoming. The atmosphere is dark and lit very dimly via lights and candlelights, but was loud from the background music and clamor within.The food did not disappoint. I ordered the Hot Chicken Sandwich with a Left Hand Milk Stout. This might be the only spicy meal they got, or the only one I was able to see in the dimly lit room, but the spiciness is no joke. I was sweating from it being unexpectedly kicking me. The biscuit is really good that came with the food. I'm not a big pickle guy and the pickles they served here made me reconsider if I liked them or not. Well done I guess. I now ask myself if I really dislike pickles or not. Until next time I guess I will find out.

Came here on the recomendation of a friend and It did not disappoint! First up this place can be confusing because there are two topaz places next to each other. This is for the noodle bar! Next this place is kind of small Even for a hole in the wall, so we made a reservation which made us getting a table for 4 really easy! Missed out on the check in offer for the lychee mimosa But I still enjoyed my meal with a thai Ice Tea (in a huge glass) and a Chang beer. As for food, I had a pad thai shrimp whmich was delicious along with the coconut milk soup. The pad thai is definitely in the top 3 for pad thai dishes I have ever had. It was also a huge portions But I was able to take It home. I also want to comment on the service here! Definitely 5 stars. There was Even an incident I witnessed Where a Lady ordered to go and then preceded to demand a table so she could eat her meal there. When denied, the customer wanted to cancel her order and then order a whole new dish from the menu. I felt terrible for the staff to have to deal with this. I know some people order to go and then eat there But this place is not one of those fast food places Where that is aceptable. Overall good food, great service. One of my new favorite thai places in NYC!

All across the isle Manhattan, tourists and natives alike forge claims about the best slice of pizza. The city's love for a classic New York style pizza pie is centripetal to understanding Manhattan's food culture, and perhaps equally important is how a person's favorite slice can narrowly define their love for a particular time, place, person, or memory in their life.It's worth noting that someone's claim for their "favorite" pizza can be tinted with marinara-colored glasses. Just because your Uncle Frankie took you to your favorite pizza spot when you were nine and taught you raunchy jokes every other Sunday because your parents needed a break doesn't mean the slice at that pizzeria is the ultimate best, but it also doesn't mean your love for that slice is any less valid. We all have an Uncle Frankie and we all have parents who more or less didn't want to deal with us, so if the pizza shrouding that nice memory in your life is also wearing a crown that reads "BEST PIZZA IN MANHATTAN," then all the power to you.Regardless of Uncle Frankies, what I'm getting at here is that someone's favorite pizza slice may be incredible to them via sentimentality, but the slice might not be incredible objectively. I believe there's no such thing as a truly bad slice of pizza, but there's definitely a difference between okay pizza, great pizza, and pizza that takes words out of your mouth, wakes you up in the middle of the night when your subconscious remembers it, and forces you to go back to the pizzeria the next day when its doors open.Let's get to the gravy here: Pizza Suprema. As you may have guessed from the dissertation preceding this, I was told by someone that Pizza Suprema is their favorite. "Favorite" is a strong word and not a word I toss around, but definitely a word I'll explore when given the opportunity.The array of pizza toppings and pie variations is almost as astounding as Pizza Suprema's old-fashioned cash register, both of which are not nearly as astounding as the fullness in which the pizza lives up to the word "favorite." I sampled slices of plain and Sicilian to get a foundational understanding of Pizza Suprema's overall taste and style. I ate both slices at an exorbitantly slow pace and enjoyed every morsel of tomato, cheese, and ultra-thin crust. Words taken, night-woken, plotting to go again.Edward Hopper never used a pizzeria as a subject in his paintings of stoic American life, but if he did, Pizza Suprema would be his muse. More welcoming than midtown pretends to be, coppertoned, and filled with isolated moments saturated with narrative suggestion, a Hopper painting of Pizza Suprema would sell at Christie's for $200m, easy. You can feel nostalgia resting in the rows of booths, hear jokes told to kids given away for the day, and breathe pure pizzeria redolence as you experience an amalgam of delicious slices waiting to be claimed as your favorite.Where there is an absence there is also a need, but in the case of New York City, the surplus of pizza doesn't mean we need less pizza. In fact, the more pizzerias the better! Every brick oven, white paper plate fading into translucence with grease, pile of cornmeal, owner with an accent thicker than Sicilian crust, and pizza-inspired smile as fluid as the viscosity of the Hudson offers an opportunity for someone to create a new moment of nostalgia to revisit one day with their old favorite slice.

I usually don't go this far into Battery Park but I was accompanying a friend her ex co-worker's going away party. This was a pleasant surprise to try somewhere new and with good company! Although we didn't plan to stay long, it was a really fun and chill evening. The space here has an upstairs area, but that night we were here, it was closed for a private event. We all were able to find space by the bar pretty easily as there are a lot of side tables and bartenders working at the bar. The prices were decent and service is also pretty good. The music was fun and some people were dancing, though there is no official dance floor. This is not really a club but just a long bar with pretty scenery. There are also a lot of televisions if you would like to watch one of the games. You get a great view of the water and Statue of Liberty. I would love to come back and check out the space upstairs sometime.

Thank you for bringing such a great omakase experience to my neighborhood! Came here the week it opened to beat the rush and I'm so glad I did!Where it's located kinda creeps me out (I don't like to be around funeral homes, etc), but once you're inside, you'll see that the space is beautiful and modern. Taking over a previous club space, Juku has three different floors - main floor serves Izakaya, 2nd floor is the 12-seat omakase counter, and in the basement, they are currently working on a lounge/private space. Can't wait!During our visit, they had two options - a 12 piece for $80 and 15pc + handroll for $120. Seems like their website now says that the prices vary based on market pricing, so TBD I guess! To try everything, we opted for the larger omakase. To start the meal, I also got the cutest cocktail called Big Wet's Sugoiii Tiki...came in an adorable buddha shaped tiki cup haha. All the cocktails looked delicious, all paired with some kind of Japanese flavors (yuzu, sake, shiso, sesame, japanese whiskey, etc). We got the pieces below:Striped JackSoy Marinated Blue Fin TunaGolden Eye SnapperTasmanian King SalmonScallop from Hokkaido with Smoked Salt and Lemon Juice*Chopped Horse Mackerel with Ginger and Scallions (this is Chef Yoshida's favorite piece if I overheard correctly haha)Forgot to label piece #7 :(Snow CrabSeared Japanese BarracudaBaby Sardine*Botan Shrimp with Dried Fish EggSea Eel*Otoro (literally puts a piece of toro on toro :D!)Big Eye Snapper*Uni from Hokkaido*Tuna Handroll*my favorites!To end the meal, some super yummy Tamago (it's more like a sponge cake tamago...amazing), and a light yuzu sake.I like how delicate their pieces are, seasoned perfectly and with perfect rice consistency that is slightly warm. But note that these pieces are smaller than most omakase places out there (I would say probably 3/4 of the size). Forget the chopsticks, just use your hands! They actually also offer a $20 uni sampler that you can tack on at the end (5pcs of different types of uni, including a fermented one). We wanted to add it but the chef advised against it as we already got the 15pc omakase and tried the best uni they had that day already. Next time though...will perhaps try the smaller omakase combined with the uni sampler!Juku gives a lot of bang for your buck at this price point in NYC, so take advantage :) They are available for reservations under Resy. Thanks to Chef Kei for an amazing meal! **Doesn't seem like either of the chefs are involved with 1OR8 anymore (I don't even think they serve omakase anymore!).

Calling it right now - Kushary is gonna trend in 2018.This is a super hip take on an Egyptian classic, and if I've learned one thing about Egyptians, having married one, it's that they can and will feed you the most delicious food til your pants don't fit anymore.Kushary is traditionally a mixture of rice, lentils, pasta, and chickpeas - AKA carbs on carbs on carbs. Kusharista takes this king of comfort foods and gives it a more health-conscious spin, adding protein options like grilled chicken and shrimp, as well as veggies like lettuce, tomatoes, and of course kale.At around 8 or 9 bucks a bowl, you're getting a great value. The bowls are hearty but not heavy and definitely make for a complete meal.If you're looking to try something new and different between your sweetgreen salads and poke bowls, give this place a shot!

As good as it gets! I love donuts and have a donut problem. Ill be the first to admit it.Before I ever stopped in to grab some goodness I knew the Donut Pub was doing something right because Ive heard more than a few people rave about this place. What appeals to me is the REAL NYC flavuh' this shop has. Its probably been around forever and the people who work here aren't hipster scum either.The actual donut I had was amazing. I went with the cronut at around 11:30PM knowing that there was a chance it might be stale but it was as fresh as it would be at any other time of the day. It was moist and fluffy and had a nice sugary glaze. I devoured it.Ignore the negative reviews on here as they seem to have been written by hipster donut snobs. Nothings wrong with this place. Ill be be back and recommend you give them a try!

Two words: Vegan Mexican. I honestly wasn't sure what to expect for an all vegan Mexican restaurant. Everything I love about Mexican food is centered around meat. On top of that, Vegan alternatives can be super hit or miss. Thankfully, it was a definite hit on their part. First of all, the smell upon entering this place is absolutely mouthwatering. The staff are accommodating, welcoming and check up on you regularly which is always nice. As for the food, I was blown away. My friend and I ordered their vegan nachos and cocktails to start. I tried the Matcha y coconut (very sweet and refreshing) and my friend got their margarita (extremely sweet, but still so good). The nachos were stupid good, topped with this amazing vegan cheese, meat, and mountain of guacamole. Like, I can die happy. We both ordered fish tacos, which we weren't sure how we felt about "vegan fish." The fish is a cucumber-like veggie that was breaded. It was okay, but I wish I had tried something else on the menu that wasn't trying to mock fish. Overall, I cannot wait to be back. They also have a smaller shop connected to the restaurant if you want to order to-go.

The ramen here delivers. The in-house made springy noodles with perfect texture and thickness in creamy, rich but not too heavy tonkatsu broth were exactly what I needed on this cold winter night.The veggies were balanced. The thinly sliced spring onions were delicate and did not overwhelm the broth. The two pieces of chili oil bamboo shoots were a good addition as well. The thin slices of pork added a refined feel to the dish, though I personally prefer fatty, carmelized pork chunks. The egg came out perfectly soft boiled and beautifully placed. They care about the artistry and execution of their ramen.The Brooklyn Kura was nice. It was on the sweeter side and but thoroughly enjoyable. Topped off with some hibiki whiskey, a perfect end to a perfect meal. The servers were also very friendly and easy to chat with. Loved the vibe and the experience here. My list of favorite Manhattan ramen places are now:1. Totto ramen (hearty, rich, chunky broth)2. Tonchin (for vibe + ramen + price point)3. Ippudo (refined ramen but a little too snooty and the wait is unbearable)4. Jin Ramen (not amazing, but conveniently close to my apartment!)

Omar's has saved my life plenty of late dinners in the office. I've found that Mediterranean food is perfect for working: light enough to keep you from feeling sleepy while substantive enough to power you through (as I don't drink coffee and will otherwise eat all of the candy to stay awake). I've only gotten delivery so I can't say what the restaurant dining experience is like but my food's always been on time and kept relatively warm. My go-to orders:- Eggplant salad with extra pita bread. There's a fair amount of lemon and tahini, just the way I like it. - Vegetarian platter. There's usually way too much food for one sitting and for one person but even if I inhale the whole thing, I don't feel absolutely disgusting. It's $13 for about two meals' worth of food - you get falafel, hummus, baba ganoush, and pita bread. Their hummus is one of the best I've ever had. - Chicken shawarma. I was a little suspicious that the chicken would be dry and tough after I forgot about my order and left it sitting for half an hour but it turned out delicious. They give you a heaping mountain of meat. - Baklava. A small piece complimentary with each order! Such a nice touch and it never fails to make me smile. - This one hot sauce they have. After practically wrenching the little tub inside out to get every last drop, I've learned to ask for extra. Thanks, Omar's! You're awesome. The crazy lunchtime lines should speak volumes about how consistently good this place is.

This is a neighborhood spot that seems to be building a reputation as a destination point for wine and gastropub enthusiasts. It may be attributable to the great variety of wines presented in whimsical and casual atmosphere. In addition, having friendly knowledgeable employees encourage your wine journey is sublime. Not to be missed are the food choices that are uniquely curated for this place that will be envied by any hipster establishment. When seeking a wonderful variety of wines aligned with cuisine that deserves some note worthy press, this may be on your must list. It definitely is on mine.

FIRST REVIEW OF 2018!This was the perf meal to kickstart the weekend off the NYC "bomb cyclone" aka stay-burrowed-in-my-apt-under-seven-different-blankets. Despite the frigid weather and the below zero wind chills, The Noodle Bar was worth the trek down to TriBeCa!The Noodle Bar isn't reaaaaaally a speakeasy as it's pretty easy to find inside Brushstroke: just take a right when you walk through the doors. The space is very minimalist and has soft ambient lighting so it was super relaxing. The bar area seats 8, so we had to wait about 20 mins for our party of 4. There is a small waiting area right outside so it wasn't too bad, except for the draft we felt every time someone opened the door - but I digress!Once we were seated, we decided to order:- Two of the Miyazaki Wagyu Gyoza ($5 for 3 pcs): PERFECTION. Soooo delish and melt in your mouth. Make sure you use a spoon so you don't lose any of the yummy soup.- Two of the Scallop Mushroom Gyoza ($5 for 3 pcs): Wasn't my fave but good to try.- Brushstroke Tonkotsu Ramen ($17): SO good. Perfect broth - not overly salty - coupled with thin noodles (prefer wavy, but these were silky smooth), and the most delectable 3 pieces of porky perfection. Hubs got the same ramen as me, but our two (more adventurous) friends ordered the Duck Miso and the Roasted Sweet Corn Butter Soy. The corn ramen was OFF. THE. CHAIN. I swear the flavors deepened in complexity as you ate the dish...PLUS, wavy noodles y'all! Would def return for this. Throughout the evening, there was a steady wait of around 2-4 ppl. Not sure if this is the norm because it was just TOO cold out - but not too bad of a wait if you find yourself here on a Friday evening!Such a yummy way to kick NYC winter in the behind. Would def return!

Coffee coffee everywhere! This place has some of the best coffee and coffee beans in the neighborhood... all reasonably priced. Definitely a worth visit for all coffee lovers. They have different types of coffee beans from many countries, all labeled. They also carry many unique items such as different types of coffee presses, filters, mugs, post cards, jars, drip kettles, vintage coffee grinders, chocolates, etc. The customer service is also very professional...I especially like the lady who serve in the morning during the weekdays because she is very efficient at what she does. Remember to pick up a punch card when you purchase a drink...free drink after every 5 drink purchases and each drink comes with a piece of chocolate. If they don't give you the chocolate, just ask.Also, this is a walk in and go spot, so no seatings available inside. However, there are two benches outside for some good vibe people watching if desired.

Que gran experiencia en El Barrio! Stepping across the threshold has you transformed from Spanish Harlem into an esthetically pleasing, invitingly bright yet peaceful spa environment. I was greeted cheerfully by Dani at the Front Desk, the main liaison for scheduling and rescheduling my appointments. After being greeted by Dani, Yasmine, the owner of Uplift Spa, came to the front to greet me too. Both offered a very nice welcome and were a delight to chat with throughout my visit. There were no shortcomings to the hospitality. After completing the obligatory short questionnaire, I was brought to the treatment room by my technician Alexa. The room played to all of my senses by being clean and dimly lit, there was also a soothing aroma and tranquil spa music playing in the background...this setting was what I was looking for. By sense of touch, Alexa worked wonders on my Brightening Facial. She also had a calm demeanor and was informative and pleasant to talk to. All necessary senses were satisfied and had me relaxed during my entire visit, I couldn't have asked for anything more. Except one more thing, with the 50 min Facial completed, Alexa had my face left with that natural glow. Uplift Spa is on another level and brings a spirit of diversity to Spanish Harlem. It was truly worth the visit and if scheduling allows, I would no doubt go back to support this oasis smack dab in the middle of El Barrio. I strongly recommend and thank Taiyyab for recommending. TIP:January's Monthly Special - Discount on Brightening FacialsFebruary's Monthly Special -Discounts on specific Laser Removal (Lasers available for all skin tones)

Cozy little brunch spot located in the quieter part of Midtown East! Atmosphere: cozyyyyy and fun, spunky decor! They've got the ram theme down locked with cute art pieces scattered throughout the restaurant. The exposed brick and wood also add to the warmth. Food: DEELISHHHH. I got the goat cheese omelette and honestly wasn't expecting an omelette to taste so good! It's the perfect combination of savory and spice (with the spiced potatoes on the side) and refreshing salad. We got the teas on the side which were just the pre-packaged tea (a bit overpriced for tea bags but welp you pay for the location). Also got to try the chicken and waffles which were too fried for me but my friend loved them! Cost: decent! you definitely get bang for your buck. we just got the main entrees, no apps and still couldn't finish our food. Service: great and attentive, i never felt like i had to wait to get their attention even though the restaurant was packed with people getting in for that sunday morning brunch. will i be back? for sure! gotta try all their other menu faves!

TL;DR (and a mandate) - I had one of the most delicious meals of 2017 at Root & Bone this past weekend. You MUST go and order the biscuits, the fried chicken, the squash and the collard greens.Your belly will thank you and your taste buds will have a party.- Grandma Daisy's Angel Biscuits: These were soft and buttery on the inside with that crumbly and golden texture on the outside. I am a biscuit fiend, and I could order 3 more dishes of this and go to town. - Squash Salad: Ummm, pickled garlic vinaigrette, lemon AND guajillo pepper? YES PLEASE. This combination is BOMB. Not only do you get that satisfaction you can't get from anything else but garlic, but you also get the spice from the pepper and the acid from the lemon. The squash is such a perfect vehicle to soak up all those juices. I mean, I am salivating over squash here. It is THAT good. - Root & Bone fried chicken: We ordered the half-chicken. It came with one leg, one thigh, one breast and one wing. Absolutely juicy - the long hours of care by that sweet tea brine definitely shows. I was blown away by how all that juicy chicken could be encased in the most perfectly crispy breading. It's more oven-baked than fried, but just as satisfying. I loved the spices in it (lemon and spiked tobasco honey) to give it a tangy, sweet and spicy balance. Korean fried chicken is my favorite type of chicken, but this one actually nudges it out! - Collard Greens with bacon, chipotle & cider vinegar. Yes, you guessed it - best collard greens I have ever had. I usually find collard greens to be one-note and uneventful, but this was a bright dish that complemented every other dish.I plan on returning many times over and bringing my out-of-town guests here for such a delicious meal!FYI - my fiance and I are big foodies and have big appetites, but the above 4 dishes definitely put me in a food coma not long after!

I am delighted to review this place. I have been frequenting Cognac for brunch the past 3 Sundays and have decided to come back as often as possible. This place is superb for it's food, as well as it's service. They treat you like you are the only customer they have (the place is always full.)I have had the Salmon, Scallops, omelette and cheese puffs. Let's say that the hearty cuisine is so amazingly tasty, I have formed a bias about French food. I am beginning to believe it is the best food in the world, if done right. At Cognac, you can't go wrong. Every single dish is carefully prepared to bring out the produce and meats organic flavors. You will savor each bite. Bon appetit!

Bacon Themed // Upscale CasualFriendly Staff // Neighborhood spotThe best bacons, paired with the best local artisanal beers. If you're in the mood for a bacon bloody mary, or have yet to try one then this is a good spot to stop by. Whether you're up for a full meal or just some snacks, Bar Bacon's enthusiastic staff clearly loves the place, and if you searched for bacon, it's likely you'll enjoy this spot too. The bacon flight is great for sharing, salads and portions are substantial. The more you share the more dishes you can try. I would suggest getting an entree to share and some appetizers. It is easy to get bacon'd out in this place but there are hearty and lighter options. The cocktails with bacon infused are subtle, no need to fear! Chef/Owner of the restaurant worked grew up in New York City and worked with Joel Robuchon, David Boule, the Four Season's Hotel among others. Which is clear when you dig into the details. The very approachable menu crafted by a bacon connoisseur clearly wants to cater to the cravings of a bacon fan. Does it? Well, you can be the judge of that. I think when When someone is in the mood for bacon, this is a fun HK spot for an adventure.The Scene: Low Key, Casual, HipDestination Rating: 8Date Rating: 7Hob Nob Potential: 7Strong Suggestion: Try their brunch! Great options. Nice wide windows open on days without rain.

Crave for a bowl of healthy and savory noodles that don't put you to sleep afterwards? Many thanks to talented Chef Simone Tong! Hands down best rice noodle shop in the city, where really nicely flavored rice noodle bowls with hight quality ingredients are served! It's so good that worth a special trip if not couple ;) (no reservation accepted)I have tried grandma Mi Xian, cold duck Mi Xian, and Little Pot Mi Xian so far. All of them are very good. Grandma Mi Xian features the natural and flavorful chicken broth and yummy tea eggs with beautiful flowers decorated on top. Duck Mi Xian is really good too -- broth, flavorful meat with nice texture. And lastly, my fav, Little Pot, the pleasant sourness of marinated cabbage, the sweetness and freshness from the minced pork, flavorful chicken broth and soft rice noodle ... !! Layers and layers of flavors! Really nicely done chef Tong! I can totally see myself a frequenter of this east village gem.

my FAVORITE place ever.This is an institution. If this place ever disappears, the light in my life may as well. Everyone I've recommended this place to loves it, as well (aka some people who have also reviewed this place). I eat here at least once a week, sometimes 3, up to 7 times a week, whether through take-out or sit-down. I've been here alone and with friends. It's crazy how obsessed I am with this place.ALWAYS COME FOR LUNCH. (But they are missing some prime items from the lunch menu.) Always. It's cheaper, you get things for yourself. The portions are a bit smaller. 5 items for $14!!!!!!!!! If you can't, make a reservation. The wait times are ridiculous. My family is Sichuanese, so I am so into the numbing spice. This place is the REAL DEAL. The dry pot is the star, everything else is just a side ho. I never share a pot because I always get super spicy. Always mix the spice on the bottom to get maximum taste. My stomach burns, but it's just too good.My usual suspects (mix and match):Sliced Eye of RoundPork BellySpamFish FilletQuail EggsPotatoBok ChoyCeltuce (it's the same consistency of a celery root AND I HATE CELERY, but it tastes nothing like celery...try it for yourself)Wood EarSweet Potato NoodleGlass NoodlesFried TofuTARO (controversial among my friends)Bamboo shoots (But these are just incomparable to the fresh bamboo shoots you can get in Chengdu, but sometimes you crave, man)NEVER CLOSE. Also please add taro and celtuce to your lunch menu PLEASE. I will keep updating my reviews and adding photos and waxing my poetic love for this place.

I took my first class today and I'm totally a fan. Jen Housek is a super great instructor!Loves:- Instructor = Jen is friendly, provides clear instruction with modifications, and has such positive energy. I have to reiterate how important instruction with modifications is in barre classes given the isolated movements and Jen does a fantastic job of instructing all levels.- Workout = I've taken classes at Pop Physique, Pure Barre, and Bar Method and I honestly think this is the best one. Barre classes work only if you do the sets with the right technique, and once again Jen was great at explaining this.- Facilities = Is this the cleanest studio or what in NYC?! Honestly, it's spotless and feels new even though it's been open for two years already. I was skeptical of carpet at first but I enjoy it better than cheap studio mats.- Amenities = They've thought a lot through with double shower curtains, showers caps, hair brushes, lockers of varying sizes, even a hair straightener. I'm impressed.So yeah... I'm a fan. 10/10 would recommend.

If you want to cradle your face in the sensation of silk, and pamper your senses with luxurious essential oils such as pettigrain and rose, then make certain you try the new skincare line here. I wouldn't have thought that The White Company, known for its high end luxury linens and homeware, could have introduced a skin care line that would marry affordability and performance. But pairing with the powerhouse Deciem, known in the U.K. for its advanced technology in skincare, proved to be a smart investment for The White Company and the consumer. The packaging is simple and clean, with only five items that work for all skin types. Of course not every product is perfect for every type of skin; but as an example, there is certainly one product of the five than can work for even very acneic skin, such as the Eye Revitalize. I'll give a brief review of the items in the five star line. The cleanser is a creamy one that becomes oil as you massage it in, leaving the skin clean without stripping your natural oils. It doubles as a makeup remover too. The aroma is gorgeous, a mix of several essential oils including bergamot, bitter orange oil and rose and vetiver. Inhale deeply, for the fragrance is just faintly evocative enough to tease you to serenity, and not overpowering all. Women and men can embrace this line, without transforming into a heavily perfumed granny from the1920's. The serum is chock full of good stuff, like grape stem cells, amino acids, hyaluronic acids. I smeared this serum over my forehead and could have sworn that my face had an instant facelift; it plumped my forehead up so much the eyebrow area got lifted. Yes, I did use a generous amount, but I hadn't expected to be this pleasantly surprised by the effects. And the plus, you can use this over the eye area too. Want an eye cream but afraid of heavy globs clogging up the under eye area? This eye cream has the consistency of a gel, and penetrates quickly. If your skin is on the drier or normal side, by all means buy the Night Oil. It was one of my faves, the lightest face oil I've ever used, and scented with what I thought was neroli. They told me pettigrain. They're from different part of the same plant, by the way, Citrus Auruntium, or the bitter orange. The pretty scent is also a stress buster. I have dry skin and the oil was so smooth upon application it felt as if my fingers were ice skating over my skin.  I could smell and smooth it on my skin day and night. If your skin is dry, I suggest you do. And lastly is the Advanced Hydration, a moisturizer that rebalances your skin. All the textures are light, as if your fingers are skimming velvet and silk when you apply the products. And the great thing and true surprise about it all? Besides being non animal tested(VERY important to me), and made without parabens, nothing in the line is over $50, if I remember correctly. They source directly, and saving middleman expenses means the consumer saves. They keep the packaging simple, so you're not paying for that expensive container. So nestled in the high end and higher priced products of this company is a well priced skin care line that the average person can afford and should definitely try. I haven't been this excited about a skin care line in a while.The store is absolutely beautiful, with different sections showcasing different bed and bath items like fluffy chenille pillows, robes you want to never take off, other types of clothing, like dresses and cashmere sweaters. Being a tactile person, I restrained myself, but the hand feel of everything here tempts you to touch and squeeze.They have scented candles, body lotions, towels etc. White is the theme here, so you'll find white plates, cups etc. It's called the White Company, folks! White linens are of course what The White Company started out with and you'll find plenty of white sheets, some with delicate grey embroidery you could sigh over. Cover your bed with some of the sheets and duvets and you might never leave it, as you dream of finding your Sugar Daddy or Sugar Momma. If you're already making the big bucks to afford this stuff, call in sick and do a sleepover.  The salespeople here are gracious without being intrusive. They won't stalk you until you buy. I actually spoke to the owner, Chrissie, and Jessica, the manager, both so warm I was inspired to give them a terrific Yelp review after using the products and realizing they work(no Yelpers, I wasn't bribed--not with sheets or what I can't resist, chocolate!) They didn't have packaged samples of the skin care line when I was in, but do have little jars they can pump from the testers to give you. I was told they do Christmas in a big way here, so do come by around for holiday cheer. I'm not expecting to see Baby Jesus swaddled in a down duvet, but perhaps song and mead? It's for certain you can find nice skin care products here, amongst other lovely items! And your presents will not be re-gifted, I guarantee you.

Because I just hit my three year anniversary of practicing at Modo West Village, it's time for an updated review..In almost a decade of practicing, I've never had a yoga studio that I loved so much. Even through years of teaching, I've never met kinder or better guides through my yoga journey.-If you've practiced Bikram and you love the heat but hate the rigidity, come to Modo.-If you want some healing postures and some guidance but not having to fit this perfect idea of how the posture 'should' look, come to Modo.-If you want a yoga home, a safe space filled with loving and joyous people, come to Modo.-If you want sweaty yoga but you can't afford to pay upwards of $200 a month, come to Modo ($115/mo).Teachers to look out for: Michael (check out his Yang Yin or Modo Flow)Sasha (check out his Modo)Siobhan (Freestyle Flow - killer core work, challenging flows)Chandler (Yang Yin. Her classes are challenging and thoughtful)Lawrence (Freestyle, Modo Flow, or Yang Ying - calm voice, hard work, always consistent)Kyle (Freestyle or Hot Yin- his yin classes are to die for, freestyles are wickedly good)Valerie (Modo Flow or Freestyle- such passion in her flows and the words just sound SO much cooler in a Haitian accent! :P)Guillaume (one of the studio owners, Freestyle Flow- so challenging, so divine!).Also Maddy, Katrina, Josh, Zoe....the list could go on & on.The studio assistants at the front desk are so kind and such welcoming people.Do note that Modo has a policy that if you show up as class is starting, you won't be let in. Coming in after the teacher has gone in disturbs the quiet calm of the room and it throws the students off.There are also no cell phones in the room and no leaving early. Yes, this is NYC and some studios allow that kind of stuff but at Modo, they encourage us to have respect for our fellow New Yorkers and yogis. We're all just trying to find some zen in this madhouse of a city.Their facilities are great and although they've upgraded over the time I've been practicing, the bathrooms still aren't as quite as perfect as Williamsburg. The floors in both studios have been upgraded recently and they're so lovely and perfect for practicing. Filtered water is available to fill up your bottles from home and there's juice and tea you can purchase, too. Mat, towel(s), and water bottle rentals are available and cheap.Seriously, for $40 bucks for the first month, there are no excuses *not* to come.

Majorelle is housed in what was formerly the iconic NYC Post Steakhouse at the Lowell Hotel. The entire interior was redone in brightly painted exquisite wooden panels and plenty of marble juxtaposed the wood. The food was outrageously delicious from hors d'oeuvres to the desserts. I was especially partial to the whole roasted chicken, which I hope is on the regular menu. The staff was amazing and I couldn't find fault despite my best effort to do so. I attended a private event and didn't have the opportunity to try the restaurant's normal service I'll be swinging by again soon because my first experience with Majorelle left a positive and lasting impression.

Red Bean, Custard, Matcha, oh my! My crew and I came down here after a huge dinner uptown, in search of something to satisfy our sweet tooth and end our night of gluttony right. I learned of Taiyak through Yelp with their week-long BOGO event and since I've never been lucky enough to try a Croyaki, my intrigue superceded my growing waistline and I decided to make up for my overindulgences the following day in the gym and give into my momentary satisfaction with some custard filled fish-shaped croissants.When we pulled up, I was worried because they were packed but upon closer inspection, realised everyone inside was already enjoying their tasty treats. Upon entry, the very pleasant staff explained how the BOGO deal worked and we each ordered one of each Croyaki, one custard and one red bean. I also indulged in a Red Bean and Matcha Ice Cream for the drive home.All. The. Yums. The Croyaki is warm and crusty on the outside with a creamy pocket of slightly sweet custard inside. It is soooo good! Simple but tasty. My matcha ice cream was creamy also. It tasted just like a green tea kit kat and the strawberry drizzle on top is a perfect addition and then when you've finished the ice cream there's a red bean treat at the bottom of your fish-shaped cone. I loved the mini skewer of gummi candies also. The whole thing is a cute and whimsical treat, worthy of eating ice cream in the winter for. I still have my red bean croyaki I'll be toasting up to nosh later on.Happy to have tried this place and glad to know they're so close to our regular dim sum haunt. Definitely a future after dim sum brunch visit.

I absolutely love love love this little tiny spot on Macdougal. I make it a priority to stop by no matter how many times a week I may be in the neighborhood. Believe me when I say I have never had a bad crepe from here and I have pretty much tried most of them all. Every crepe I have had has always been delicious from the first to the last bite.The staff is very pleasant and they provide speedy service which is a plus. The prices are pretty decent as well. However, it is a little unfortunate that there are only just a few seats (like 4ish). I also pray that one day they will take card because the whole 'cash only' thing gets a little annoying. Most time than others I never have cash on me and usually end up paying for my crepe with all the coins I scrape up from my car and the bottom of my purse.

Possibly the best new Broadway show of the season. The music is haunting, at times enchanting, and the performances captivating and touching. Katrina Lenk, the female lead, is a true talent--gifted. She was wonderful recently in the play "Indecent." (Seems that getting to play the part of a Jewish girl is her regular gig). Her performance of "Omar Sharif" is captivating, elevating the song to a domain beyond the composition itself. There is no dancing in this play, but her body movement is as if it is choreographed. You also get to see Tony Shalhoub, who is endearing (isn't he always?). No one could play his role as well. The stage sets are deceptively simple but clever, and evoke a mood that works well with the narrative. The musical is based on a 2007 Israeli film of the same name. An Egyptian Police Band mistakenly winds up in a small, middle of nowhere, Negev desert village instead of a larger similar sounding town where they were going to perform. With no transportation until the next day, they spend the night with the locals. The Times review says it all: "A Ravishing Musical That Whispers Romance." You would never guess it from the storyline, but it really is about romance. I pick my Broadway shows carefully and I'm glad that I chose to see this one. You'll love the score, the musicians and the other performers are great.

Ugh. Just so delicious.In NYC there are always so many new hyped up restaurants popping up all the time, it's difficult to decipher which ones are actually worth going to. I'm always skeptical of celebrity restaurants because they are generally invariably disappointing. However, I'm a big fan of JG's other restaurants (ABC Kitchen/Cocina, Perry St) and so I wanted to give Public Kitchen a try. We came here for brunch - and I was very pleased! Space is bright, airy and very trendy in the back of a hotel with surrounding gardens. We ordered the basil/corn gyoza, smoked salmon latkes, and the black truffle pizza.Complimentary bread - stiff and flavorless. That's okay though, bread can be a huge plus but is not a dealbreaker for me.Basil/corn gyoza - delish. Usually I am against ordering vegetarian dishes (tbh, I kind of hate vegetables) but this was worth it! Delicious and surprising, the best combination of flavors.Smoked salmon latkes - tasty, but nothing special. Basically, tasted exactly how you might imagine. Given the price, dishes have gotta be at least a little bit special. Would not order again.Black truffle pizza - yes, yes, a thousand times yes! A thick cheesy chewy truffle-y gooey (mm runny egg) type of pizza - so, not for the thin crust purists. Warm and delicious. Perfect for breakfast. Large portion. Reasonably priced for NYC. Reservations needed. Service was quite slow, however - waited a long time for the food to come out, and had to flag waiters down multiple times to get water, the check, etc. Still, given the food, ambiance, and relative value, I would definitely recommend. JG has done it again!

I adore Japanese cheesecakes and the bouncy ones at this modern bakeshop doesn't disappoint. They do indeed bounce, jiggle, boogie woogie to the beat. So success on what they claim to do.We tried the Original Bouncy, done in a steam bath for its signature soft and fluffy texture. It's delicate and crumbles nicely due to its high water content. They don't taste particularly different from others I've had, bearing close resemblance in the Asian stratosphere to Taiwanese cheesecake and/or cotton cheesecake.Keki's is still extremely addictive, and probably just as unforgiving calorically. Don't let its lightness fool you. Like with most things Asian, it's a fat kid at heart.

"Yo what's this place about?"Well this place is a hybrid of a froyo and a burger place. Unlike shake shack, this place always has space and I am able to get a seat so I can enjoy my food.
