They also have outside seating so you can enjoy and take in a glimpse of the hillside riverdale views."Food.... what about the food?"The food overall is good! You can additional change more even a fried egg can go on top of your burger if you are feeling up to it. Now if you did not want a burger they also have a good selection of froyo that you can try before hand. Or if you can always have both I mean if you are truly a savage like that."Overall"This is a family/friends family place. Come with people if you want to get away from the city and you want an amazing view to eat you enjoyable burger

$50 omakase for 12 pieces? SIGN ME UP!!Similar concept as Sushi on Jones, but BETTER! Higher quality of fish, more interaction with sushi chef, and intimate environment. A lot of cocktail, sake options. Favorite pieces were torched toro, botan shrimp, wagyuni (of course) and the handroll add-ons. Overall fish was very very fresh and texture was amazing. No soy sauce needed as the pieces come with appropriate sauces. Our sushi chef was cordial and careful in explaining all the pieces we tried. Dinosaur and I were contemplating whether we should spoil ourselves extra by ordering handrolls and we are SOOO glad we did! We tried the toro and hamachi and both were very good. Definitely would visit again. For the price and quality, you cannot get a better deal especially in the city! Located in the basement of Sanctuary Hotel on 47th street. Accepts reservation by text, only 2 min grace period, so don't be late! This location is right in the heart of Times Square which means lots of traffic and tourists.

I came here with my boyfriend's family last weekend for his birthday. We tried to book online and call ahead on the day of, but they said to just show up.I came in around 1:30 on Sunday and was told a 15-30 minute wait; the guy was kind of vague and apathetic. The place was pretty busy. However, he said we could sit at the bar, which we did once his family arrived 10 minutes later.The bartender was super helpful and explained that we could order our food at the bar and get it moved to our table as long as we closed out there. We put in our seafood orders and started with a round of a dozen and a half happy hour oysters. (Happy hour runs all day on Sunday, and includes dollar oysters!) These are not the most knock-your-socks-off oysters of your life, but they were balanced and juicy. I'm kind of picky about my oysters and I would have kept eating these forever. Big crowd pleasers.Our table was ready after about 15 minutes, so we closed out and switched over. Then we got our bibs and gloves and suited up. Our food came out in about 5 minutes.My boyfriend and I focused on the king crab legs (MP, I think it was $30something a pound) in mild lemon pepper. Awesome. The snow crab legs ($23) and shrimp ($15) were also good, in medium Claw Daddy's Special. Both of them came with potatoes and corn in the bag. We also had a round of clams ($15) that were pretty good, as well as crab cake fritters ($9) that were much better than expected. Garlic noodles ($6) are not what I expect at a Cajun spot, but they were tasty and would be a welcome addition if you're trying to fill up.They warn you about the spice here, but even the medium I tried wasn't very spicy. The king crab was our best choice, as well as the medium Claw Daddy's Special sauce. Do note that they don't serve crawfish in December.The only other seafood boil spot I've been to in New York was Hot n Juicy, which had slightly better sauces. However, the atmosphere is just so far ahead at Claw Daddy's-- you're in a modern, light filled space, and it feels much more fun than being in a basement sports bar. Service was excellent. Bathrooms were clean.If you're looking to eat a lot of seafood, Claw Daddy's is a great choice. Do reserve if you can, and do try to take advantage of the happy hour.

It's easy to overlook writing a review for a staple place I enjoy going to, when the restaurants in NYC seem to be endless. But I have been coming here for years, and was reminded on a night out with my friends why I love coming here so much.I was with a group of 6 girls, so we were a large party, our waiter was superb. Super friendly, and helpful. We ordered family style and helped me to order enough of everything so we could all share every dish. They were great at getting drinks out to everyone consistently, and even brought us complimentary desserts and shots. Every time I have been there though, the food and service is constantly consistent and that's why it deserves 5 stars.

I am in love with Fat Cat. As a person who doesn't party, this place checks off all the boxes for me; it's low key, casual, and an overall pleasure for drinkers and non-drinkers alike. The bar area is filled with eclectic doodads and a nice selection of beers and wines. The majority of the space is filled with a hodgepodge of games that include shuffleboard, pool, and ping pong; on weekdays, games are $6/hour per person (on weekends it is $7/hour per person). Board games go $1 per game. Not only can you have tons of fun, but the cherry on top are no doubt the live music shows. The band area is surrounded by vintage velvety and moody sofas, perfect for chilling with a cool beer. My friends and I had the pleasure of hearing a jazz ensemble on Thursday night and were thoroughly entranced by the ambiance. Pool tables are in fairly good condition, with a select amount of nice cue sticks lined across the walls. Tables are reserved via ticket numbers; I'd highly recommend getting your ticket as soon as you come in, as we ended up waiting a while before our pool table was available. In all, a wonderful place to go for a casual drink and a game of pool or ping pong. I'll definitely be back.

My gfs and I love Mexican food. So for our dinner date a few Fridays ago, we decided to go to this little hidden gem (Btw it's BYOB woohoo).The atmosphere is very intimate and cozyThe food was so fresh and tasty. Everything was made correctly and was simply perfect We started with chips and guacamole which was really good and flavorful.Our entres were: Chicken Quesadilla, Red Sauce Enchilada and Green Sauce Enchilada which came with rice and beans.The red sauce is suppose to be a bit more spicy then the green. However it was not too spicy at all. It had just enough kick to it and I felt was more flavorful then the Green sauce. The Green sauce was also great but a little more on the tangy side.The food here was great, you can tell it was all freshly made and not frozen fast food quality. Overall it was a great night, wine, great food and wonderful service.This was a Mexican Food experience the way it's suppose to be.

I first stumbled into Char Sue several weeks prior, and had the chance to sample an array of their small plates and appetizers - which are ideal for any happy hour get together. I can still remember how flavorful and well-encased in an egg roll shell the Black Pepper Beef Tacos were and the seasoning and spice that were layered in the Five Spice Duck Wings... Needless to say, when the opportunity came to revisit Char Sue for a five course dinner menu, I immediately said yes.The restaurant is conveniently located just steps away from the Delancey-Essex stop in the LES, and is set up for diners and groups of all sizes. Looking to just grab a quick bite? Take a seat at the bar or one of the two tops to the side. Hoping to have a group of friends and family? There's a communal table that'll seat everyone at once as well. It works for almost any occasion, and the food alone is deserving of a special visit.Dinner began with a new menu addition: Monkey Bread served a top a slice of sweet potato in a Thai Green Curry. The bread is a family recipe, compliments of Chef Matty Rojas, and is soft and pillowy with no small amount of butter - perfect for getting that slight crisp at the bottom of the bed. It's the perfect vehicle for scooping up the spicy and creamy curry, and contrasts well with the sweetness of the sweet potato. The following dish isn't, unfortunately, on the permanent menu, but if I had my way - it would be. Tender, succulent slices of octopus were served with charred brussels sprouts and paired with a spicy pennywort vinaigrette. The flavors were reminiscent of the Yu Xiang (鱼香) sauce that I've grown up eating, and was the perfect savory-spicy flavor for the protein.Next up: Crispy. Pork. Belly. No other words are really necessary, but I did my best to savor each of the three pieces that were served; they had a crisp, crunchy crust that yielded to a tender and fatty interior, and was highlighted even more with the side of a garlic-chili dipping sauce. It ties with the Char Sue Duck as my favorite dish of the night, but how can you compare to a plate of decadent dry-aged roast duck coated in a blend of Sichuan spices? A crisp, crackling skin, tender and juicy white meat, all served a top of bed of warm sushi rice... this would easily be my last meal (if I ever had to choose one) and is more than successful as a modern, elevated take on the traditional Peking duck.To finish, a sweet almond pudding with a strawberry jam provided the ideal light finish to the meal... and also cemented my desire to camp outside their kitchens for the remainder of my time. (You think I'm joking. I'm not.)I'm already planning a return visit to Char Sue, and would recommend it to anyone looking for a uniquely NYC restaurant. Here, Asian food is redone and reinvented to even better and more delicious forms, but still stay true to their core flavors and tastes - and truly, you won't find these dishes anywhere else.

Lots of love for Zabar's - although on the East Side, we are allowed to call him Eli.....We were on the UWS and trying to decide what to have for dinner and then we saw Zabar's and problem solved. The shop was buzzing with activity. All sorts of unique foods scattered around. Their cheese selection is crazy big with free samples. Their desserts look really good. The real stand out is their smoked fish. We had their pastrami lox and gravlax with dill sauce. Both were amazing. The bagels were fresh and the Babka was as good as the one we get from Russ and Daughter. The service is at a relaxed pace but I think that is because they take great care in what they are doing.We would definitely come back - and maybe call him Eli.

The Quick: What NYC Bagel Dreams are made of. Incredible customer service. Fresh delicious bagels delivered warm (and on time). Family owned and run. Rainbow bagels and fun cream cheese flavors. I recommend to all my family, friends, and coworkers.The Details: Bagels, pizza, and 24/7 diners are the epitome of the New York food scene for yours truly. I'm a simple woman who enjoys delicious food at reasonable prices where the staff and management is pleasant. Is that so much to ask for? Bagel Boss went above and beyond all my expectations. When ordering for a large corporate group, they helped customize the order to my needs, delivered incredible food on time, still warm, and set up in beautiful baskets for my group. Cannot say enough great things about this spot. From a large corporate event, hungover group bagel order, or a quick bacon egg and cheese after a run-- do yourself a favor and stop at Bagel Boss.Pro Tip: They have RAINBOW BAGELS! They were extremely accommodating for PRIDE orders in June. Any place that is LGBT friendly is a place I want to support.The Damage: Extremely reasonable for all things breakfast and lunch. Extremely large bagels and generous breakfast sandwiches. Go go go!

This tranquil sister museum of the Met is a wonderful standalone gem New Yorkers love to suggest to visiting friends tired of the same old sites.Whether or not you're a fan of medieval art, the gardens alone are worth a visit (suggested donation, people!). There are also some nice vistas from the promontory overlooking the Hudson.The tapestries, murals, and other artifacts are worth a look for sure, perhaps even a leisurely stroll through the galleries.I won't be a jerk by taking a point off for the cafe, but strangely enough that was part of our reason for visiting. For such a cool museum, the options are very sparse and the prices unconscionably high. They did, however, have an "abbey" ale that was perfect for the venue and soon quelled my churlish mutterings.PS: We were with stroller-wielding friends. The museum is not particularly stroller-accessible, but you can get around.

An extremely tall, majestic building, now stands at One World Trade Center (WTC) . Scions of American high society have always represented the downtown wealth infrastructure of the Manhattan landscape, originating from the epitome of Wall Street which began in the 1700s, place of the inauguration of our first President, George Washington, at Federal Hall in 1789.Now it is 2017, in the new trending downtown scene, stylish and trendy Condé Nast has become one of the major tenants at One World Trade, thus making downtown their shiny new headquarters. They publish multiple magazines: Vogue, GQ, Vanity Fair, Allure, Architectural Digest, Ars Technica, Bon Appétit, Brides, Condé Nast Traveler, Details, Epicurious, Glamour, Golf Digest, Golf World, GQ, Lucky, The New Yorker, Self, W and Wired. Condé Nast Entertainment has successfully progressed in film, television and digital video programming industries as well.Anna Wintour, Editor in Chief, at VOGUE, has managed to spread 'chic-ness' to lower downtown and the people have succumbed to dress more fashionably in the Financial District. The landscape indeed has changed with this factor, plus fallen in step with the fancy digs of Brookfield Place across the street. Upscale gentrification has arrived.Expect clusters of bedazzled tourists. This is the site of America's worst tragedy 9/11. We are both amazed and reflective.  Torn but proud.  The new WTC reflects our tenacity to move forward.  God bless America.

We were at Boucherie Sunday evening for dinner. All I can say is WOW! First of all the restaurant itself is gorgeous. Black and white tiles and huge antique mirrors. Really, you could be in Paris. We had reservations and were greeted like long lost friends.The wait staff and hostess were all highly efficient and gracious and they deserve 10 stars. We each had a glass of wine selected by our server and Julie ordered a corpse reviver II after seeing a selection of Absinthe based cocktails. She said it was the best she has had in New York. We just had wines by the glass, but the wine list looked pretty good with lots of bottles under $75.00. Julie had moules as an appetizer. There was a huge pile of them that came prepared with bacon, mushrooms in a very light cream sauce. They had a slightly smoky taste and were fabulous. I had a really nice caesar salad. I know, in such a traditional French restaurant we should have been more adventuresome, but we both couldn't resist the steak frites. See my pictures. The presentation was wonderful and the taste and quality of the steak were fantastic. Our tab for 4-drinks, 2-appetizers, 2-orders of steak frites and an apple tart served with vanilla ice-cream came to just over $200.00 with tax. A really good deal for dinner on a beautiful summer's evening in The West Village. We both loved this place and will return soon.

It took me over a week to get my wits together to write this review because I blacked out after eating the fontina & egg sandwich.The fontina & egg sandwich caused temporary blindness, made me see stars, took my speech, and for a brief moment I couldn't hear anything other than my beating heart, and even that was reduced to what hamster feet sound like on a wheel: tiny, hardly audible rhythms running into endless oblivion.Traditionally served on a toasted roll dusted with sesame seeds, the fontina & egg sandwich is layered with greens, pesto, garlic, and optional bacon (is bacon *truly* optional?). Because I have no time for "greens," I requested they be put directly in the trash. The welcome excess of fontina cheese, a perfectly oozy egg, and homemade pesto on that lightly crisped roll is almost too much to remember in detail because I fear I might pass out from its absence in my life at this moment. Along with this heavensent sandwich were ten fried yukon potatoes the size of grenades that god himself express-shipped to Vic's.To answer all the questions you may have: yes, I can write an entire review about a sandwich. No, I've never had a better breakfast-themed sandwich, ever. Yes, this review is very "extra." No, this review is not hype.

I love this place!!! First at all the owner is there, and he is so friendly. He will make sure you enjoy your food either you eat there or for take out. This was my bowl: Base: white rice; Protein: raw tuna and salmon; Mix in: cucumber, cilantro, hiziki seaweed and edamame; sauce: red poké; toppings: seaweed salad, toasted seaweed and masago; and for the crunchiness I added some almonds, sesame seeds and crispy garlic. And voilá my perfect dish. I must say the sauce I added has wasabi taste, I'm not a big fan of wasabi but good for trying this time.I've tried in other places the Poké bowl but this is one is the winner for me. I like the ambiance (it's very important for me) it's big enough to find a table and enjoy your meal. The product is fresh and the service is fast and friendly.For ordering you have to get the paper and check the ingredients to make your own bowl, even though they have options for you already. Must-go!! Really recommend this place!! You won't regret it.

When it first opened, ñaño was tasty but service was a bit on the slower side. As it's a small restaurant with maybe 5-6 tables total (or less when pushed together), there's really only one person running the ship in the front-of-the-house (which I believe is the owner). As a new restaurant on 9th avenue, I'm sure it needed to find its place, and that it did. I went back to ñaño last week, and the food, drinks, service, the prices, and well, basically everything was outstanding. As a latin restaurant serving what appears to be authentic Ecuadorian cuisine, there is nothing like it around. We tried cocktails made with Ecuadorian Aguardiente aka "firewater," which is a 40% alcohol (80 proof) hard liquor made of up sugar cane. I tried the ***Cholita, which is the Aguardiente, with Naranjilla juice (Naranjilla is a sour fruit grown in the North of Ecuador, kinda tastes like kiwi/passion fruit), triple sec, amaretto, and a berry puree, which I loved! My friend had the ***Galapagos - also made with the Aguardiente, mixed with blueberries, blue caraçao, and a splash of seltzer and lemon juice. Now to the food!For appetizers, we started with: ***Encocado de Camaron: 3 "cups" made of green plantain filled with a shrimp and coconut stew.For entrees, we tried the: ***Seco De Pollo: A spicy and sour chicken marinated in cilantro and the juice of the Naranjilla I mentioned earlier. Usually it is served with yellow rice and sweet plantains, but I subbed for a green salad (which came with red and yellow beets). ***Chaulafan: Pork fried rice sautéed with edamame, Andean corn, soy sauce, scallions and cilantro. It also came with a few sweet plantains on the side. All in all, everything was great! There were so many other options on the menu we wanted to try and I look forward to coming back again soon.

If you have not yet been to DOMODOMO, get your head out of the sand and hop on a train to get downtown, now!! This sushi restaurant is my VERY favorite in all of NYC. It's definitely fun to do an Omokase or a "Domokase", but there's nothing wrong with picking a ton of your favorites from the menu and watching them make each one in front of you. I'm getting a little Pavlovian saliva in my mouth just from thinking about this place! The prawn, uni, uni & wagyu, really there's no pieces that you can go wrong with. I love the uni pasta. I'm a bit of an uni-holic. And this place definitely has some of the freshest uni in all of NYC.  Do you think that paragraph was the most used instances of the word "Uni" on Yelp? I'm going to win an award for talking about uni too much! **Tears roll down face as I accept this award with a giant grin**Anyway, back to the gold, Domodomo!! Not only is the food amazing, and not just your run of the mill average, fresh sushi. It's extremely creative. The ambiance is superb, it feels like a cross between a super trendy spot and a super fancy spot, but with nice comfy prices that don't make you have a heart attack.I think I'm going to make a reservation right now for later this week. Good talk. Thanks.

If you want to know what heaven tastes like, you come here. Don't forget to bring all that money you saved up for a new -insert item you really want here- because it's gonna cost you a pretty penny. Dined in for brunch with my friends because my foodie friend told me this place is to die for. I trust her opinions. We all looked at the menu, astonished because we didn't think we'd be paying $20+ for an Asparagus Omelette. I opted for the Orange Bennett to drink because what brunch is complete without alcohol? And of course the Asparagus Omelette.Before they provide you with your entrees they serve up some bread with butter and olives. I don't know why but that bread was delicious. I'm so glad we asked for more. The Orange Bennett was a bit zesty and the perfect hangover cure. Better than a mimosa, this drink goes down smoothly and most importantly tastes like orange juice. I could have mistaken this for a moscato dupe. HAHAAsparagus Omelette was by far interesting and delicious. It was slightly undercooked inside but tasted like a fluffy egg with some sort of cream in every bite. A definite #musthave Oh and because you can't end a meal without dessert, we opted for the Espresso Chocolate Cake which btw does not have nuts in it. Every bite melted in your mouth. It was the perfect middle between sweet and bitter. Everything from the sponge-like cake texture, soft and moist to the creamy icing made me only wish I could eat it everyday. One of the best brunches I've had this far. Try it for yourself and make reservations.

Riffs on Italian comfort classics & newer joints at this hip, sexy,modern midcenturyish corner spot.A hit from the jump, cause the food is all that!Took a half hour for my food to come out, & I was hungry. No bread type Italian. They are known for the lasagna.Ate;Blackened chicken scarpiello $22Eggplant agrodolce $8A great pairing. The chicken with sausage, capololo & Anaheim chilies was TDF. Went well with the slightly sweet agrodolce. Will encore that chicken. Buonissimo!

Yes. Yes. Yes.For Happy Hours alone, you come sit at this STUNNING bar for a cocktail and dessert. You do not come here for wine or beer, but you let the mixologist do their magic. Things to do:1) Wild mushroom pastas2) Orzo Mac n Cheese 3) Red Wine Braised Duck4) Any of the seasonable veggie offerings5) Smoke Octopus 6) Perfected cooked Cod7) Dessert: Chocolate Cake or the Tartine. Either one will blow your mind. On top of the quality of food, the service is impeccable from start to finish. Impeccable.

The itinerary for the evening was to hog on some ramen at a nearby popular ramen joint and come here to try out this new trending 3-week old dessert place.So glad we came here and tried out the CRUFFS. It's essentially ice cream sandwiched between warm soft glazed donuts. I've tried donut ice-cream sandwiches at another midtown shop before but they didn't feel so soft and fresh! The donuts here are so soft and porous that the melting ice-cream seeps beautifully into them. You'd think that would make the donuts mushy, but it doesn't. We tried the Cruffs with 2 flavors - thai ice tea and lychee with 2 toppings - almonds and mochi. Mochi was a free topping, courtesy Yelp check-in. They also offer milk shakes and ice cream scoops, but coming here and not ordering the cruffs would be blasphemy!

Wow, amazing service from knowledgeable staff is what gives this place five stars!Walked in to get a bottle of single malt before a Thanksgiving party and got expert advice from one of the guys there. Found a terrific whiskey around my price point and it was spot on.Whole transaction was fast and professional and prices are about what you'd expect for the east side.  Plenty of options to get what you want and a dedicated team to make sure you pick the right bottle. Love this place.

Go! Just GO! And so affordable, with such nice service in such a nice restaurant with indoor and outdoor seating. This place is 5 stars all the way for me. I came here for a group dinner and was unfortunately getting a sore throat, but even being sick, the meal blew me away.First off, the service was superb. They were so attentive, so friendly and social in just the perfect amount, not overbearing but provided great insight on what's good and what's great. I started off the with Paid Time Off which was citrusy and fresh. We also received complimentary warm pizza bread and regular bread. The pizza bread was awesome. Had to get two baskets. Then the food arrived!Gnocco Fritto - easy to split between 4 people. AMAZING. A must get if you like fried dough and prosciutto. The fried gnocco was crisp on the outside, chewy and hot on the inside. The prosciutto provided the flavor of soft, melty, salty meat. Loved it. I should have ordered two plates!!Caprese - you can't go wrong with buffalo mozzarella. It was fresh, soft, ooey-gooey. It came with some peppers that were spiccccy. Provided a good amount of surprise heat that normally doesn't come with a caprese. Burrata - Similar to the caprese but more simple. Just the burrata, basil and tomato with some EVOO. Simple, classic.Tagliolini ai funghi - Truffley for sure! This is more of an oil-based sauce pasta with plenty of mushrooms in it. The pasta was plentiful and cooked perfectly al dente. You can tell that all the pastas are freshly made which is the number 1 thing I look for in any legit Italian restaurant. For the price and quantity, the pasta dishes are so worth it. I tried a couple of the other pasta dishes and all were just so fresh and well-flavored. LOVED IT. Ricotta cheesecake - OMG OMG OMG. We weren't going to get it because we were so full after our delicious pastas but the waiter highly highly highly advised it. This cheesecake is reputable across the nation and he talked us into it. Sure, why not? I am sure it will be good. NO! IT WAS AMAZING!! I have never tasted a cheesecake like this. It was the creamiest cheesecake I have ever tasted and the ricotta elevated it to top notch. Have you ever seen the episode in FRIENDS where Chandler and Rachel steal cheesecake from a neighbor and end up eating cheesecake off the floor because it was just too good? That was what popped into my head when I took my first bite. This is the type of cheesecake I would steal and eat off the floor if I had to. Do not pass on this cheesecake! Trust me. Overall, everything was so good. I have to go back. I will go back. Pasta, cheese and three slices of ricotta cheesecake please and thank you!

Boozy Brunch Muy Bueno!Calle Ocho is one of the best brunch spots in NYC especially if you are going with a large group. The prices may seem high at first but it comes with unlimited sangria so it is actually a very good deal!!!When coming into this hotel restaurant it has a nice dimly lit ambience and with a lot of tables. When we sat down we ordered drinks right away and I am not going to review all of them because they are all delicious. The one I will mention is the HAVANA BANANA Coconut Rum, Crème de Banana, Coconut, Lychees this just had so many unique sweet flavors they make it definitely worth getting. The drinks do stop once you stop ordering/eating food so make sure to order a desert for the table at the end ;) to keep them flowing.From a food standpoint I would recommend the Gallitos (serves two)Platter of Traditional Costa Rican Soft Tacos, Scrambled Eggs, Chorizo, lettuce, pico de gallo, avocado salad, Calle Ocho Home Fries. It was all delicious especially the chorizo and this gives you really everything from a food standpoint and solid portion for two people. But all the food here is good you can not go wrong!In short:- Book brunch here now what are you waiting for!- Unlimited Sangria with brunch- Delicious food and drinks- Great waitstaff

The omakase experience at sushi kaito definitely reminded me of the omakase meals I had in Japan. My friend scored a 7pm Sunday seating and the experience from start to finish was amazing. We opted for the 12 piece omakase meal for $75. They also offer a 16 piece omakase meal for $100 if you're feeling hungry for it. Both seatings are 1.5hrs and start exactly on time so don't be late. the master chef was an adorable old man who was very knowledgeable and friendly. Every piece he made was delicious, fresh, and flavorful. It just melts in your mouth and no fishy taste at all! my party was full at the end of the omakase but we opted to order a la carte just to see what else he had. This place is worth a try and the price includes tip and tax.

I'm definitely not a steakhouse connoisseur by any means - I know the greats (Luger's, Wolfgang's, Smith and Wollensky) but that's only because everyone knows those names. I'm pretty sure I couldn't tell you the difference between a prime rib at Capital Grille versus the same cut at Wolfgang's. My boyfriend, on the other hand, loves his meat. There's nothing that lights up his face more than cutting into a bloody slab (absolutely nothing, including me). So for his birthday this year, I picked Keen's. The reviews looked good, the prices were on the margin of affordable for a steakhouse, and the neat New York past spoke to my inner history nerd. Hello, 50,000 clay pipes stacked precariously along the ceilings? The famous mutton chop devoured by Lillie Langtry who took Keen's to court for not admitting women? Yes, please. First, there are several different parts of Keen's. We accidentally came in through the bar entrance and wandered confusedly until we finally came to the main waiting area. There's a first floor, second floor, and third floor. Tables and groups of all sizes. Second, a reservation is definitely a must for weekend dinners. We came on the earlier side and by the time we left there was already a line. Third, everything we ordered was amazing. They give you free bread and crudite/dip: the bread, while not the best house bread, was at least toasted. My boyfriend got the prime rib, I got the lobster salad, and we ordered the creamed spinach, mushrooms, and mashed potatoes to share. Now, let me be clear. That prime rib was heavenly. Even better than my lobster salad. It needed no salt or steak sauce. (While I'm on the topic of salt, Keen's includes a blurb on the menu that says you can ask them to tweak the salt level but only for certain dishes.) It came with a garlic and horseradish sauce but I preferred the meat without. The bliss on my boyfriend's face was over 9,000 at this point. Holy crap, the sides. I was a bit skeptical about the creamed spinach but that was the one I ended up liking the most. Mashed potatoes were fine. Sautéed mushrooms came out a little too oily but I ate embarrassing portions of it nonetheless. Even though we were hurting at this point, we ordered the butterscotch sundae. We practically cleaned the bowl and then waddled out of there, clutching our bellies. Definitely a fantastic meal to combat the Sunday scaries.Our waiter was friendly and knowledgeable and cheerfully promised to bring out a candle with the dessert.

Upon entering the well decorated entryway, you are greeted pleasantly by a smiling hostess surrounded by autumnal hued interiors, flowing into ultra high ceilings, dim lights and exposed brick walls. We were guided to the second dining area that complimented the first, but with white table clothed tables, intimate candle lit settings, rounded out with piped in, smooth jazz type vocals cooing remakes of modern pop tunes. Our server, Joseph, pulled out his patience hat for the evening as he tried on several occasions to get us to order our courses timely. We had so much catching up to do, but finally took a moment to peruse our menus and start with our apps. I had the soup of the day, which was a comfortingly smooth Cauliflower soup. Mercedes's Eggplant Timbale with a thinly veiled béchamel sauce was unexpectedly fragrant and hearty.I followed Mercedes's lead, as I wasn't in the mood for a heavy pasta or meat dish. So I ordered the perfectly seared, medium rare salmon atop spaghetti squash, dotted with lightly seared grape tomatoes. The salmon glistened and had a huge punch of buttery flavors. A Very satisfying and enjoyable meal. If you happen to be meeting up with friends while in the Yonkers area, and looking for a spacious bar lounge with friendly and truly accommodating staff, serving a decent array of modern Italian fare. Zuppa Restaurant and Lounge may have what you need.

Ok I admit I made the reservation 10 days ago at 10am sharp by using the alarm, otherwise I would not be able to secure a spot right at dinner time 6:30. And I was informed as well it was going to be a long-lasting one, so well prepared myself with not too much food consumed at noon.Every dish, as expected, was prepared with delicacy and kindness, and you can directly taste it out using palate. I especially enjoyed the duck and sea bass, which supposed to be their "main" courses. Their special duck confit mixed with lychee was one my most remarkable experiences.Towards the end of meal, they will provide you the menu, so you can remember exactly what was explored at this top notch restaurant!Don't know whether I will come back again here as we have so many choices in the city, yet this is definitely some places you gotta try out if you are someone exotic!

FINALLY THE ANSWER TO MY (FOOD) PRAYERS!Here was my dilemma with Los Tacos No. 1 located in Chelsea Market. On the one hand, it offers one of the best meat tacos I have ever tasted (other being Velvet Taco in Chicago), but the crowds at Chelsea Market are always insane. I prefer to eat in a leisurely fashion and enjoy my food with good company, rather than hunching over one tiny little space as hundreds of people rush past or gawk at you to finish faster so they can grab your space.Now, I know that the pace of this new location might be due to how new it is to the location, but I love the ambiance here! The tacos are just as good (you MUST get the carne asada and adobada), but the pace is much more relaxed. The music is bomb and fun. The sauces just as ample (mild, medium, and spicy). Don't forget to add everything to your tacos (guac, onions, sauce, and cilantro). If you decide to add the spicy sauces to your tacos, you can alleviate the fire bomb in your mouth by drinking their delicious offering horchata.I gorged last time and got 3 tacos (my fiance got 5)! My only regret was that my stomach can't keep up with my appetite. It is just SO good. Trust me, go and thank me later.

As beautiful as the pictures look! Seating is limited but for now it's not a super popular place, so we were able to find seats at 4pm on Sunday. We got the:- Rose latte (light hint of rose, I thought this was just ok)- Lavender latte (I really liked this. Very powerful seeds on top also)- Chocolate and lavender cake (This was good but I'd like to try the other ones. Very light)- Fig chocolate truffle (hint of fig)- Cherry blossom chocolate truffle (good)

Looking for great burgers and don't want to break the budget? This is your place!Food: I got the chicken burger and added cheese (and of course jalapeños ;)). The chicken was perfectly moist and delicious. They also offer lamb burgers which I feel are harder to find and still within a decent price range. I think the best part is that their burger add-ons aren't ridiculously priced. Cheese is 50 cents (wuuuut I know!), caramelized onions are 25 cents, and jalapeños are another 25 cents. Also, if it matters to you, the meat is halal. Cost: sooooo nice to a poor grad student! And the burger leaves you full. Atmosphere: tiny (as is everything in greenwich haha) but cute. I would avoid going at busy hours unless you're planning to pick up. Staff: very nice and efficient. They're quick and manage the high volume very well. Will I be back? For suuuuure. Got my eyes on the lamb burger and truffle fries next!

Lucky is a new bar in the East Village owned by a bartender who has been at it for years and it shows! I was part of an event that was being held here and definitely enjoyed the vibe that was going on. Abby the owner/bartender is engaging and friendly and knows how to pour a good drink. Cara too is just as awesome.The bar area and outdoor patio was clean as well as the bathroom which seems to be something people mention when reviewing this place. The bar itself was decorated nicely and kept dimly lit. One major plus here is their awesome jukebox. The jukebox here has mixes from various famous NYC bars Abby has tended and has a little bit of everything ranging from punk to alternative and everything in between.One thing that will bring me back for sure is the non pretentious attitude here. Nothings worse than a bar that treats you as if you don't belong there. Not here. You feel welcomed as if youve been a long time friend. I'd recommend this place and suggest you stop by.

My husband and I have been coming to this place at least twice a week now, for about 6 months. Why? Because they are really particular about the products they curate. They research and taste-test all the ice cream and chocolates. The items they carry all have a story - history or a charming anecdote. The owner has a diverse knowledge of chocolate. Don't believe me? Ask him. I was blown away from his explanation of virgin chocolate and their ratings on the international market. Wow!We are always so happy to frequent this place. It is a true New York gem, a true neighborhood shop that carries verifiable best of the best. Make sure you step on the red carpet when the place gets busy...as it does often. We earned our badge of honor today...the owner gave us a sample of his finest chocolate in a sealed and "pressed-stamped" bag. Thank you for the beautiful customer service.

Nutrient Dense // Local Organic Gorgeous interior // Vegetarian Friendly"The Best Food" in NYCWhen someone asks where is the best food in NYC? Taste being subjective this question is one I rarely answer. There are about 10 questions that need to take into account. Defining the word best being key. If we include food quality, sourcing, flavors, texture, taste, overall balance of each dish then Ellary's Greens usually comes to mind. Locally sourced, everything here is organic. If you prefer to avoid pesticides and extra hormones, then Ellary's could be your go to for breakfast, lunch and dinner... snacks.Over the summer I had the privilege of meeting the owner, enjoying a tasting, and taking a tour of their incredible clean kitchen. Every dish that we had was delicious! The avocado toast with olive and heirloom tomatoes was such a great appetizer, their bison burger has so much flavor if you want hearty this dish will fill you up! Everything we tasted was something that I would order again. If it looks good in writing when you are reading the menu, it tastes equally as good if not better when you order it.Loved:Avocado Toast Beet Salad Deviled EggsLangoustineBison Burger Bacon & BrusselsAs with each dish, love and care are poured into just about every bit of this place. The interior is comfortable, modern, clean... and has a slick earthy feel to it. Even the ceiling has laser cut details that are delightful. It is wonderful to see a thriving well intended business that offers exactly wha they say they do, good healthful food at a reasonable price.If I were to choose to live in this neighborhood this would be my go to spot.The Scene: Beautiful, Healthy, HipDestination Rating: 8Date Rating: 8Hob Nob Potential: 3Strong Suggestion: You may want to order an extra dish to take home for your next meal. Sooooo good!

Happy Memories of Summer Days and Nights at Playland. I had one of my first teenage kisses in the Tunnel of Love. Classic Memories for a 16 year old. We used to all meet at the recreation center and take the bus. I'd meet a boy from the hood and ride home in his car. I kept my curfew though. I was just spending summers. I wanted to be allowed to return each year. There's a beach. I can't remember swimming there. I enjoyed the rides. The Dragon Coaster and Fun House especially. We always found lots of junk food to eat. It was a highlight of the summer. I couldn't wait to return. I even have photos of my Mother at Playland before she got married. It's great to pass Memories of a historic amusement park down to future generations. My daughter always went when she visited Connecticut in summer. If you get a chance visit this piece of history. Or you might watch the movie BIG with Tom Hanks. You'll see scenes shot there towards the end of the movie. If I remember correctly!

Tldr: This is the real deal. Do yourself a favor and call in advance to get a number--it'll shorten your wait time significantly. Order everything on the menu. Repeat the next day.------------------------------------------------------If you haven't noticed, there's been a seismic shift in the Chinese culinary scene in Manhattan. For years I've had to make a tough choice between pleasing my taste buds or my eyes. When coworkers asked for recommendations I struggled to think of a single name that would score high on all three metrics--authenticity, decor, and service. Alas, we cannot have it all. Or so I thought. Enter mega-wealthy Chinese restaurateurs and investors loaded with cash money. This wealth is not only flooding the investments market but also penetrating the culinary scene. Several new restaurants backed by big names are slated to open in 2017, and these are imports straight from the motherland so are guaranteed to be good. Finally, New Yorkers will discover what Chinese food is actually like in China. All rejoice! Let's take a moment to think about how fat we're gonna get. Ok, good. Now, Sichuan Mountain House has already generated a significant following in Flushing. It made its debut in Saint Mark's Place last week and I just had to see it myself. The Chinese name, which has much more character, references a rather curious nocturnal animal with poor vision but a great sense of smell [1]. I can imagine all the dinners turning into pangolins as soon as they enter, tuning into the deliciously spicy aroma of chili peppers. The owners want to "create an atmosphere that is just like a little house in the Szechuan province." Boy did they do a good job. The interior transports me into an episode of Wu Lin Wai Zhuan. The service is impeccable. As for the food, I don't see a need to elaborate, other than subtly suggesting that your ENTIRE OUTLOOK ON LIFE will be improved.  Out of the 10 or so dishes we tried, these especially stood out:- Sliced pork belly with chili garlic soy: their signature dish. Literal translation: white meat draped over a clothing line. - Steamed crab with sticky rice: the sticky rice was perfectly cooked and having soaked in all the flavors of the crab meat, simply delicious. I could eat three bowls of this. - Fish fillet with pickled mustard green: the broth was reduced to a white, creamy consistency that is making me salivate as I'm thinking about it now. The mushrooms were very fresh. - Fried rice with pineapple: I usually try to stay as far away from fried rice as possible, but this dish cast fried rice in a whole new light. The pineapples were slightly tart and sweet, lighting up the rice and seafood. - A note on the tea: the complimentary tea is seriously good. It's not that moldy three-day old stuff restaurants forget to refresh. Given the aroma I suspect it is Tie Guan Yin. It's cleansing and a perfect foil for all the spicy dishes. Thumbs up on choice of tea.I expect Sichuan Mountain House to go far, and it will be more than deserving of whatever status it achieves. [1] A shortlist of new restaurants slated for 2017 Manhattan openings:- DaDong, the original Beijing roast duck. They announced a November opening and was immediately booked straight through December. Holy. Bananas. - Dalongyi, Sichuan-style hotpot - Dou Lao Fang (The Dolar Shop), Cantonese style hotpot[2] According to Wikipedia, "Pangolins have large, protective keratin scales covering their skin, and they are the only known mammals with this feature. They live in hollow trees or burrows, depending on the species. Pangolins are nocturnal, and their diet consists of mainly ants and termites which they capture using their long tongues. They tend to be solitary animals, meeting only to mate and produce a litter of one to three offspring which are raised for about two years. Pangolins are threatened by hunting (for their meat and scales) and heavy deforestation of their natural habitats, and are the most trafficked mammals in the world." So, no eating pangolins, you animals.

Bep Ga is one of my top choices when it comes to chicken pho. The shop is a hole in the wall place hidden in deep Chinatown. Thanks to my Vietnamese friend who is always looking for food pho, I found this gem.Although the menu has limited items -- basically chicken over rice and chicken pho (Bep Ga means chicken in Vietnamese), both of them are very healthy and flavorful yet light, which is perfect for summer. If you want additional kick, ask for their special lemon based hot sauce. $10 per bowl is very fair price given quality and quantity. Will come back soon!

We found this place accidentally while on a Korean fried chicken crawl. We googled and yelped, but nothing showed up. SUPER PSYCHED, we decided to pull up to the bar as one of the first customers! FYI, this place is in the food court on the 3rd floor.We talked to the manager and found out the grand opening was recent and he gave us some excellent personalized service.We ordered the wings in original flavor without the sauce, some parm fries and a grapefruit hefeweizen.Wings came out piping hot and crunchy. The meat was moist and juicy. We loved the fries! Besides being crispy, the parmesan made the fries more buttery than cheesy, Got to love that buttery tasting fries over peanut or veggie oiled fry. The side of slaw was creamy but wasn't drippy went of dressing. It had a nice crunch also. The cabbage was not in shreds but instead diced. To top off the meal we got a grapefruit hef. Its 50% hef and 50% grapefruit juice. It's both grapefruit refreshing while giving a slight buzz to people who hate beer. You can also get the grapefruit beer as a frozen tropical drink.Excellent find IMO. We will definitely have to come back for the other stickier wings.

NYCID free membership is wicked great. The art is great and things are fairly well laid out. The escalators and elevators plus wide door ways make it easy and accessible for everyone. If you love modern art, it's easy to get lost in here. In between classics and well known artists like Van Gogh, Monet, and Picasso, you also end up with other moving pieces from various artists. They recently added a space that encourages you to use your OWN modern art skills. They have the area stocked with everything you need to sketch your own picture (pencils, colored pencils, paper, erasers, markers, etc). Even though I have zero artistic ability, it's a lot of fun to play...which is the point, of course!Sculpture garden is perfect for spending lunch time soaking up the sun, the culture, and finding some shade and quiet time. The surrounding crowd is a bit better quieter and better than the Central Park ragamuffins ;)Get a membership if you can. After Hours and early morning Quiet Hours that are members only are WORTH IT.Tip- you don't have to pay for admission to go to the sculpture garden!

I love this place! It's very quaint and their coffee packs a good punch. Lots of times, in the morning, the line is literally out the door... and honestly, it's for good reason. The coffee is always delicious and so are their baked goods. My favorite order is to get is the draft latte and a zucchini brownie. The staff here is pretty friendly and the coffee and goods are pretty consistent. I've been to a few locations, but I go to this one the most because it's near where I work. There aren't a lot of tables but you usually are able to find a spot after a short wait.

God damn you, Doughnut Plant. Coming back to NYC, I stayed in LES this time around. You were approximately 8 walking minutes away. Thus, I stopped by to eat here every morning for 5 days. Star Jones would've been proud. Peanut Butter Banana Cream [$4]F*CKING. CRACK. THAT. YEAST. THAT BANANA CREAM. F*CKING CRACK. By far the best doughnut I've ever eaten. ORDER NOW!Apple Cinnamon Yeast [$3.80]Had the right amount of apples to cinnamon, wasn't too overpowering and not overly sweet.Vanilla Bean with Blackberry Jam Yeast [$4]Recommend this one. I thought the blackberry would be too much sugar but Doughnut Plant just knows what they're doing.My suggestions: just get anything WITH YEAST.SKIP: Vietnamese Iced Coffee. This ain't Vietnamese iced coffee. I know my stuff - my ancestors are even upset with this wack attempt. Nonetheless, for the 4 days that followed I continued to get a flat white instead ($3.75). Approved.

With gimmicky dessert shops popping up on every corner, it is easy to roll your eyes as yet another ice cream shop with opens their doors in Lower East Side. HOWEVER, I was blown away with the creativity, presentation and quality of ice cream. I met the young women who recently opened the shop behind the counter. They told me that they were aiming to incorporate their Asian-American culture into the Stax ice cream experience- and they certainly succeeded. Fortunately, the staff was patient enough to cater to my indecisiveness by providing samples of every flavor behind the counter. All of the ice cream was thick and rich with flavor. I was lured in with their range of tea flavored ice cream- earl grey, jasmine milk and of course a bright green matcha. Contrasting to the tea, I loved their truly authentic American flavors such as - 'orange dreamsicle', 'fruity pebbles', 'snickerdoodle', 's'mores', and 'cornflake bourbon'(which was my favorite). I expect to see a surge of young instagrammers 'boomeranging' their signature pressed donut ice cream sandwich. As impressive as the ice cream sandwich is, I am sure this shop will last well beyond the novelty. The very high quality and unique choice of ice cream flavors should bring a consistent crowd to this shop for time to come! I wish Stax best of luck in their opening months.

I came here for a tasting and was truly impressed with the quality of the food as well as the service. It brings me comfort knowing that the food I am eating is organic and made from the freshest ingredients. The decor is classy and has the perfect ambiance for a date or get together with friends. Now onto the food:Fish balls with Tartar Skyronnes- The fish balls were lightly fried and I love the selection of sauces! The chili and mango sauces were particularly good.Nordic Shrimp Salad & Homemade Crispbread- The shimp was delicious and so fresh.Crispy Fish Taco- I love how organic and natural the ingredients were. The tacos were satisfying without being overwhelming greasy.Spelt Battered fish & Crispy Potatoes- The fish was lightly battered and fried to perfection!Creamed Skyr- The dessert was light and satisfying without being overly sweet.Videy Drink- This was both delicious and deadly strong. The dill and lemon flavor was delightful! I cannot rave enough on the high quality of the food here. I will definitely be returning for the Videy Drink and Spelt Battered fish!

Remarkable service!! The small size of this place almost makes it look like a hole in the wall, but the service is A++. The owner and the staff pay solid attention to details and are willing to go the extra mile for you. They will also offer to serve you wine and make you a variety of yogi teas. I came in at the last minute for a pedicure with less than 45 minutes time limit. I was seated right away at the massage chair and the lady did a perfect job right on time with drink offers, mini feet massage and a mini shoulder massage. I was also given a real flip-flop at the end with multiple colors to choose from along with a plastic bag for my shoes. Those who know me knows that I am very particular with the pedicure, which most salons cannot get it right but this one did.Overall, I would say this is the best salon in the neighborhood. Polish still looks fresh after a month. Will be back!

The Met goes out of its way to remain relevant in today's age of instance gratification via the web. Walking though its Egyptian and Persian exhibitions is an experience in time travel and a physical record of our collective human experience preserved intact for posterity. Artifacts are protected for the regressive fads du jour such as the Taliban intentionally destroying ancient Afghani temples and cultural icons. The guards know the museum and become guides that can direct you out of the labyrinth. I hadn't been at The Met in a while but I am glad that I made it a point to go--despite that I've been there dozens of times before.

I try to make a pilgrimage to Katz's at least once a year, and since the last time I'd been here was February of 2016, it was high time to come again.I'm always a little miffed when I hear people knock on Katz's- or a lot of good places more generally- for being a tourist trap, being overpriced, etc etc. The reality of all, truly good places, is that they will inevitably become popular, so long as marginal costs don't exceed marginal revenues. After having existed since 1888, Katz's proves that it can still power on, and even though it gets criticized for being too touristy, it proves that it is indeed something special by virtue of having survived so long.I came in on a Tuesday this year at 9:30, thinking it would be relatively empty- instead I found it was actually quite crowded. I splurged a little bit this time and finally tried the Italian bread (it's $1 extra)You know, considering the prices here, it might actually make sense to lose your ticket. I by myself managed to consume $32 dollars worth of food by myself- just another $18 more to break even (losing your ticket poses a fine of $50). The prices are high, yes, but perhaps not unjustified; it's what people are willing to pay. In a town like New York too, where I think we have relatively good hot pastrami, the market should be quite competitive, so they deserve credit.Pastrami and smoked meats don't have the same elegance or gravitas a lot of Americans like to assign things like Sushi, probably due to all these "Jiro Dreams of Sushi" type things floating around, but to make a pastrami joint as successful as Katz's, you have to be equally dedicated to your craft, especially so since there are so many haters. Momentum and history alone is not enough to keep a business running; we all saw what happened to Carnegie's (it was rightfully deserved).A small note: I think the sweet pickles here are much better than the sour ones.Will be back.

Are you a foodie that appreciates amazing ingredients and crafted chefs meals? Are you in a rush? Then come to Made Nice. As it's been said, the team behind Eleven Madison Park and The Nomad is behind Made Nice. You'll see some similarities such as a "chicken for two" except instead of $80+ it's $22. I haven't had that yet but I have come twice in one week to try: - Cod Provençal - so so yummy, perfect cooked flavorful cod with some kind of pesto (?), Chickpea puree and fennel. It's amazing to have such a meal with care for $15. The crispy chickpeas are the best part of this dish - great texture play. Very filling :)-Chicken rice - again yummy pieces of crispy chicken skin, olives, tomato and juicy and tender dark chicken breast make for an a+ chicken type biriyani type thing. Great flavor. This I had an hour After pick up and it was still tasty - I brought the pork and carrots for my husband - he had it an hour later and considering it's braised pork shoulder (I think) this held just fine. Really good frisée and artisanal carrots. -also tried the delicious garlic rolls which are like parmesan-crusted garlic knots.and only $2!- and finally had the Milk and Honey which was airy and unique -a bit too sweet for me but recognize why so many would love it Staff is polite, and prompt. They're very attentive and. You order quickly and wait time for food is no longer than 5-7 minutes. Seating Space is moderately big and you get to seeThe open kitchen which makes for a good dine in experience. The to go containers look good and I feel, have a filling Portion. Happy to come back try the khao salad and salmon rosti.

Now in my top 3 of favorite NYC ice cream! Along with Grom & Fresco (East Village). Great Italian ice cream with all natural ingredients. Love the pistachio flavor - first time I find it in NYC!DISCLAIMER 1: I'M NOT INTO 'GIMMICKY' ICE CREAM. That is - corn flake soft serve, birthday rainbow sprinkles, potato chip ice cream, waffle tacos, etc. packed with junk food artificial flavors & colors. So don't waste your time reading this if that's your thing. True, they do have ice cream sushi here but that's not what I like about this place. I do eat lots of gimmicky ice cream but except for some of the Asian stuff (Japanese taiyaki, Thai rolled, etc.), I really don't go for the American junk food ideas. DISCLAIMER 2: I LOVE ITALIAN ICE CREAM!Or basically any ice cream with real natural ingredients with flavor. You like rainbow sprinkles that taste like ... a rainbow?!? What the heck is that supposed to have as a flavor anyways? Yes, presentation is great, but taste comes first.All the ice cream here has simple natural ingredients that are often sourced directly from Italy - milk, cream, hazelnuts, pistachios, lemons, etc. The owner is from Turin and most of the key ingredients also come from the same Piemonte region in Italy. So how come farm to table hasn't reached ice cream yet? Seems stuck in a junk food trend rut. Why not compete with Italian ice cream by creating our own fresh unique & local ingredients?!? Like with trendy kale & brussel sprouts - let's do 'local' ice cream flavors like lime, grapefruit, bourbon, mezcal butternut squash, avocado, cranberry, sweet corn, etc. Anyways. Just my 2 cents.

I have walked passed the restaurant countless times and have noticed the cute outdoor seating area. However, it wasn't until yesterday that I had the opportunity to eat at this restaurant when I was invited to come in for a complimentary dinner and see the true charm of the restaurant. (Disclaimer: this review represents my own unbiased opinion)To start off, I had both the Capri Rinha and the Go-To cocktails and they were both strong and delicious.For appetizers, I tried both the Fritto Misto and the Cozze in Padella. The Fritto Misto was comprised of fried calamari as well as two pieces of fried shrimp and two pieces of fried artichoke hearts. They were lightly battered and perfectly fried with no greasy residual left over. The Cozze in Padella (steamed PEI mussels) was plentiful and thoroughly cleaned. Although I'm not a big fan of mussels, I couldn't stop eating because the broth was irresistible. The waitress was even kind enough to offer us more bread when she saw me sharing with my friend.Since their pastas are all homemade, I decided to order the Linguine Nere Alla Sarde for my entree. The squid ink pasta had an abundance of seafood and potatoes. I truly loved this dish. Even my dinner companion who didn't like the squid ink pasta at another restaurant ended up raving about this dish. There were also hints of chili flakes which gave the dish a nice little kick. My friend got the Bistecca Alla Griglia which was a hefty portion of the NY strip steak. I was very surprised at how good this dish was, especially since we were at a Italian restaurant. It was cooked quite nicely and seasoned perfectly. The steak went very well with the arugula salad on the side and fried potatoes. To finish up our meal, we ordered both the tiramisu as well as three scoops of gelato. The gelato was already melting by the time it got to us and the tiramisu was beautifully presented but the taste was disappointing to say the least.Overall, I would highly recommend this restaurant. Our waitress was attentive and very friendly and welcoming. Our drinks, appetizers and entrees were all delicious but I would probably skip the desserts next time!

One of the prettiest and cleanest stations in NYC definitely deserves 5 stars. It's as if the dinosaur fossil impressions on the lower level have scared away the rats. Or perhaps they find better pickings at the nearby Central Park. I suspect that being the main station leading to a top tourist attraction, the Museum of Natural History, has forced MTA to put this station tops on its A list of stations to keep clean. Whatever the reason, this station is a joy to stop in, with the colorful animal mosaics on the top level such a delight for the eyes. Just be prepared for the stampede of tourists and school kids, as they unload from the trains and get ready to visit the museum, so only artwork and not your trodden remains decorate the floors.

Lena just moved in the neighborhood and it is a FANTASTIC spot! Delicious coffee, tasty pastries and freshly baked muffins.High marks for the (gluten free) MUFFINS that are perfectly browned, sweetened and have a slight spongey/cake-like texture, while still being a muffin -- perfection.The decor is modern, open and inviting. Great natural lighting and very spacious with table and couch seating options.The service just couldn't be better either. Pierre (the owner), who also has a Lena location on W 8th near Washington Square Park, made us feel so welcome and served up great coffee and warm muffins (which he baked himself!).Protips: They also serve WINE and BEER and the space is great for events.I love to see local businesses pop up and do well and I'm happy to see Lena bringing such a positive presence to the neighborhood. See you again soon, Pierre!

In a city full of great cafes and restaurants, why is Fiat Cafe the first place I think of when I come back to NYC after being away? It could be that Anna, the daytime server, makes you feel like a returning friend, not just another customer. It might be that I like that the place evokes memories of simple cafes in a Roman neighborhood or some small Italian village. But these things wouldn't matter, if the food did not so consistently exceed expectations. Here's an example. Lunch yesterday (9/22/17). I ordered Avocado Toast with Scrambled Egg Whites (extra $1.50) on Whole Grain Bread. Greens with a touch of vinaigrette came as a side. I put some salt and bit of Tabasco on. The eggs weren't rubbery, like most scrambled. They were light, like a soufflé in texture and like cumulous clouds in appearance. The avocado was copious and warm. The bread was crunchy. Something so simple done well. That kind of sums up what I like about Fiat Cafe.I first came here to have breakfast on weekends while my wife slept late. Since she started coming with me for lunch, it's pretty much our weekend lunch spot. I highly recommend any pasta, the fish soup, any omelette and any desert. The chocolate ganache and panna cotta need to be tasted, they're beyond what words can describe. My original review is below. Time and revisits have only reinforced my original impressions.I basically described it as a funky little cafe on Mott Street, with minimal effort at trendy decor, hardly any kitchen space and where they don't take credit cards. It reminds me of what downtown was like before it got gentrified. I love the place. The most expensive design element here is their neon sign. Come here with no expectations of a culinary masterpiece--so you'll be surprised that some things so uncomplicated can be so good. Sit and enjoy your coffee, wine, beer or prosecco. It's always calm and off the tourist radar--so far. "Prices are reasonable. Service is good since it's only five feet from the kitchen to the tables. It's where I go once a week for a breakfast omelet--which they graciously cook to my specifications. If you look at previous Yelp reviews you can see that people either love it or hate it. As I said, I'm in the former group. But I look at dining/drinking as an experience to be appreciated in context. In this case the atmosphere enhances the experience. I can almost imagine I'm sitting in a run down cafe on a small side hstreet in Trastevere in Rome--almost."

"Noodle cravings:revisited"So after a year of missing this place I was sitting in my house and I'm like "you know what I'm gonna get noodles tonight" this place popped in my head. So I hopped on the train and arrived here. As I walked in I could already smell the flaring heat and the spicy smells of the noodle "baby-making" going on in the kitchen. I realized why I needed to come back here!"Spicy Spicy" I ordered the beef with layman noodles and I told them to make it the spiciest you can possibly make it. Eating into the noodles was a rush of the spicy goodness mixed with the juice bell peppers and chopped tomatoes. It was filled with pure joy as I took each bite. They also have water right next to the kitchen,it's just right for the meal! They also have dumplings, you can not forget about dumplings! "What are your thoughts?"I truly love this place, I will come back here with friends, my family cause this place is a hidden gem in Harlem. So if you happen to be strolling along and in need of a early afternoon or late night noodle pull, then this place will be for you!

Can't believe I got the last cruffin of the morning on opening day - feeling very lucky! I had just missed the lychee croissant. I arrived at 9am after a friend texted me about it at 8am. The line wasn't too crazy, but definitely should get there earlier to get the flavors you want. It sells out really quickly. I think it was sold out by 10am in all of the flavors. I bought 8 out of 11 flavors. I enjoyed the peachy mess twice baked croissant the best. I also really love the boxes. The service was super friendly and fast. I'll definitely come back here again to eat more.

Ive been to this place twice. The first time I came here I came for Sunday brunch after going to morgan library and museum. This place is absolutely beautiful. The decor is amazing. It makes you feel relax and fun. I loved sitting in one of the booths with their lovely decor. I ordered the eggs Benedict and they were great. My friend ordered sliders and fries. I tried those and they were good.The second time I came here I came on at about 4pm on a Saturday. Just like the first time the staff was very friendly. The food was great. This time I tried the appetizer sampler it was two of us and we could not finish it. Things I love:Friendly StaffDrink good and strongFood is great

Review may be biased because I was served by literally the most good looking waiter I'd ever seen. I don't think my friend and I were able to form coherent sentences for a few minutes.Made a reservation for 10:30 breakfast on a holiday weekend, and this place was still packed to the gills, so I'd say a reservation is a must. I'd never come here for a non-dinner meal before, so insisted on getting the famous bread basket to share in addition to main courses. Even has a carboholic, this may have been a mistake. A delicious mistake, but a mistake nonetheless. The bread basket, while pricey on first glance, was huge - way more than two people could ever possibly eat if they wanted to get out of the restaurant alive. It included a full sized (!) sticky bun, croissant, chocolate croissant, brioche, various breads, and I'm sure I'm forgetting at least one - all from their own bakery. Absolutely worth it.My main was the eggs benedict, which come with a side of home fries. I'm not normally a breakfast person, but this was probably the best rendition of the dish I've ever had. Eggs were perfectly poached, hollandaise sauce was as rich as Warren Buffett, and the home fries were on a level I didn't know non-fried potatoes could reach. Balthazar is an NYC institution for a reason (20 years and counting!), and is well worth the advanced planning required to dine here.

I don't have much to add to the many reviews already praising the Ube and black Sesame. In fact, those reviews lead me into choosing those two flavors.I went at a good time since there was no line and there was no pressure to hurry my order. Even though I wanted Ube and Black Sesame, I was offered a tasting of those two flavors before I pulled the trigger. I stuck with my original choice. Stupid me, I should have tried other flavors too, like Coconut and Matcha. LOLI think my ube/black sesame looked awesome and I was able to get a good shot of it in the stand. I would normally give this place 4 stars, but I don't know what it is. Whether it was the perfect weather, my empty belly, having no line to wait on and/or the pretty smiling cashier, I felt this place called for 5 stars.The only thing I could complain about and I'm starting to feel I like to bitch a lot lately, is that the ice cream melted pretty quick and I felt I had to eat it fast to prevent a puddle from forming under me. When I finished, I felt a great satisfaction of having a stomach full of very tasty ice cream. Good day.

12 pieces, 30 minutes, $50. Plain and simple, what's there not to love? True, this place is almost identical to Sushi on Jones, but hey, you don't get Chef David Bouhadana if you go to Sushi on Jones (according to Eater, he is no longer involved with that project)! He's super animated behind the sushi counter and often interacts with his guests, posing for photos and dancing for boomerangs haha. The flavors/garnishes are also a bit different.4 counter seats in total only for Sushi by Bou, and 4 more to the side of it for Sushi by Bae, which is now served up by Oona Tempest (formerly of Tanoshi and Ginza Onodera) for a higher price of $100 per head, 15-18pcs. Text 917-870-1587 for reservations, Josh is super nice! Don't be late, as they give away your seat to walk-in's if you're more than 2 minutes late!Since it's omakase, no need to order, which makes things super simple. He does ask you for allergies or dietary restrictions before your meal starts. Everything was made super well and tasted super fresh. At first glance, I thought the rice looked a bit too loose, but when I picked it up with my hands, it held together quite well. My favorite pieces were the botan shrimp, Toro, Uni, and Scallop - all of these literally melt in your mouth and are bursting with flavor. Though the main show is pretty much always the torching of the wagyu beef and the layering of uni over it, I kinda felt like I preferred them separate / wagyu beef was a little stringy, though it had awesome flavor.If you have more time in your 30 minute slot, you can always order more a la carte, or add a wagyuni handroll for $14.Water/Tea as always is still $3 (water is Fiji), but here, you get complimentary sake!!! They come and refill your cup throughout the meal as well! Not sure if Jones does this now since I went a while ago...but this was a pleasant surprise!Would definitely come here again for some quick and relatively cheap but high quality sushi! Great place to bring a friend to if they're visiting from out of town too.**One worthy thing to note is that he no longer serves his famous Tres Amigos (uni, quail egg, ikura) here!!! Was looking forward to it, but it wasn't on the menu anymore :(.

I had been eyeing Pizzaniste since before they opened. While one may think this is yet another pizzeria being added to the Tremont Ave strip, the floor-to-ceiling windows which made up the exterior led me to think this was something different. Today I had the opportunity to grab lunch here with my brother and found that my suspicions were accurate. Unlike most pizzerias, at Pizzaniste you can choose from a number of individual sized pie creations or you can create your own pizza with custom toppings. I was a fan of the aesthetics. The front walls of the restaurant are able to fully extend out, and as such Pizzaniste has a very open feel to it. It's larger than most pizzerias and has a modern decor with lots of clean lines and a full view of the workstation where you can see your pie being assembled.While you can create your own pie, they have a number of them on the menu that you can choose from as well. I decided to take the latter option, and went with the spinach artichoke pizza. This was a white pizza topped with (guess what) artichokes, spinach, and ricotta. I was a fan - the pies are made to order so it was super fresh; the flavors worked really well together. Service was amazing - everyone was super friendly and eager to help; from the time we walked in we were greeted warmly and it continued up until we left. Aside from the food, it's things like this that set a business apart from others - and I need to commend them for a job well done.Overall, Pizzaniste is a great place - it's not your typical pizzeria, but it's a welcome (and arguably needed) change in this area of the Bronx which is oversaturated with pizza places. The fresh ingredients they use and killer service they provide definitely make them a 5 for me - great job guys!

This was one of the best things I could have done for myself. I called her based on a feeling that I needed some additional clarity in my life, and I was right. From the moment I met Angel, she made me feel confident that I was in the right place and in good hands. She knows what she is talking about and explains things in a way that kept me constantly laughing and really enjoy our time together. She spent a lot of time with me covering everything, and allowed me to record the entire conversation. She also followed-up with an in-depth time line and information about myself. Thank you Angel! I look forward to seeing you again!

My friends and I celebrated our good friend's bachelorette party here. At first I felt a bit hesitant and nervous, as this is not really my kind of thing, but we really enjoyed ourselves. The guys were very respectful, and no physical contact unless you gave consent. We had VIP for our group of 14, which I totally recommend since you'll be more relaxed and comfortable due to expedited entry, guaranteed seating and champagne bottles. Also Staff was very nice and attentive.

We went for brunch Sunday about noon. No reservations, but they were able to seat us at a good table in the main part of the dining room. This place is gorgeous! See my pictures. There is a small swanky bar area to your right and dining room to your left. I would say there is an even mix of locals and tourists due to the fact that the restaurant is in The ultra cool Howard Hotel. We had one drink each. Both very well made with plenty of alcohol. I had the avocado toast , not bad maybe needed a little pepper and a touch more lemon juice, and Julie went for the whole $34.00 poached lobster tail. Julie made the best choice, she gave me a bite, scrumptious. We ordered French press coffee for two. Our bill came to just under $100.00. Not bad for the James Beard award for best new restaurant in the country. Announced last night. We will for sure go back for dinner.

The Whiskey Ward is one of my all time, favorite establishments in the LES. I try not to go to the same place multiple times-- but how can you turn this place down? Especially on the weekends when just about every hot spot in the LES turns into a full fledged disaster zone-- The Whiskey Ward manages to remain pretty chill (most of the time) and retain it's charm. No lines, no nonsense.The whiskey selection is pretty strong-- as you enter and make your way to the bar, you're treated to their menu of whiskeys written in delightfully small chalk (make sure you have your glasses or contacts on...). Fun to experiment. Grab your poison of choice and don't forget to indulge in a bowl of peanuts. Bartenders are cool and do a great job mixing the drinks-- try out their LES Sweet Tea sometime, it's delightfully dangerous. They have cocktails that are available in addition to the straight liquor selection. Zero complaints about service // price here-- these guys definitely do it right.Music in the bar is right up my alley (90s / classic rock) and it's always at the right volume level. No screaming or shouting when trying to communicate to your friends.If you're in the neighborhood, I fully support any decision that involves coming to this place.

What a great addition to FiDi. I never thought that David Cheng will open up one of his restaurants around downtown area. With number of lunch options here but people still complains downtown have limited options, I am so glad they open up Fuku with milk bar next to it. Their fried chicken is definitely one of the best I have ever had. My favorite is their regular fried chicken with radish and fried chicken with sweet and spicy sauce. A little twist to regular fried chicken sandwich. Their chicken bites are amazing with saam sauce.If you decided to go for something healthy:-**Rice bowl!! This is one of my favorite chicken rice bowl! HUGE AND FILLING! Brown rice, with chicken breast, kimchi, veges and some pine nuts are so flavorful that I don't even need to add any dressing. -Their salad is also amazing with fried chickpeas. It's so unique that I never see it in other salad storesDinner Options:-CHIMEK!! You can't get it in other location so grab your friends and order this!! You gotta eat it by wrapping it with the bread and the sauce. It's absolutely one of my favorite.I will be back!!!

It's worth it. I was a bit skeptical at first. Really.. 30 minutes for $50? But yes really, the quality of sushi is great and we had a blast. Reservation is definitely recommended as there are only 6-7 seats. Best for parties of 1-3. Outside seating only. High top chairs with hooks for bags/coats.12 pieces of nigiri (including king salmon, torched chu-toro, wagyu) with really interesting add-ons for extra price. Summer special includes uni with truffle. Double happiness!!They don't skimp out on the fish pieces. Each piece is delicious and the accompanied sushi rice is not too big. My favs were the torched chu-toro and the king salmon. Surprisingly, we were both moderately full after our meal. They do charge you for hot tea $2.50 and bottled water $4. Overall, I am very pleased with our experience. The price tag may seem high for a short meal, but I didn't feel rushed at all. Food was phenomenal and the chefs are interactive. They asked us how we enjoyed each piece and made sure we were happy :)

New Territories is the one stop dessert shop that doesn't necessarily specialize in a single form of dessert, but instead hosts an array of colorful if not fun creations.It's their constant attention to rolling out new desserts that'll keep me coming back for more since their opening in Winter'16. 4.5/5.0I've tried pretty much everything on the menu, starting from their unicorn shake, a fun play on words involving ube drizzle within the milkshake.Their HK Waffle creation,Ube Trippin' with cooks ube into the batter and outfitted with ice cream. They source their ice cream from Van Leeuwen so rest assured that the ice cream will be of high quality.
