While the HK waffle alone may not be the best, it's still an enjoyable dessert.The Affo-THAI-go, Thai tea atop a bed of waffles and ice cream is a smart take on the popularized Italian affogato. The interactivity of this dessert make it a fun choice.As far as presentation goes, they're all very photogenic. Service is swift as can be as far as on-demand desserts go. When the weather hits is stride, I'm sure they'll be super busy so needless to say, go early. Ambiance is fun and light-hearted with obvious neon lighting and giraffe heads to pose pictures with. 4.5/5.0

"Street Taco" sounds like something you'd buy on an arbitrary corner of Manhattan on a day you forgot to pack your lunch, are slammed with meetings, and need something sloppy and delicious from a food cart to forget any/all workplace woes.In reality, Street Taco is a cool restaurant with a well-curated palette of decor ranging from patterned tables reminiscent of The Shining's infamous carpet to walls paneled with oversized rustic tiles à la the remnants of Mexican masonry from the late-1800s.I'm someone who will order everything else on the menu of a Mexican restaurant before I order tacos. For example, I would one-hundred-percent order enchiladas before ordering tacos. I'd order a chimichanga (or a burrito, tamales, quesadillas, fajitas, et al) over tacos. I have absolutely nothing against tacos and my lack of desire for tacos is probably one of the most bizarre things about me.That being said, the Street Tacos tacos I sampled completely satiated my rare desire for tacos. The Gringo (ground beef, pico, crema and Monterey Jack in a hard shell) had a crunch as satisfying as the crunch of a Dorito after you've not had Doritos in years (another random food item that is delicious but--for not even one reason--I never eat). The flavors and juiciness going on in the Gringo taco are impossible to put into words. The Pollo Asado (pico, chipotle salsa, crema, radish and queso fresco) was super fresh and as savory as the Gringo. Street Taco forced me to face my indifference to tacos and realize I need to make taco experiences more frequent!

Delicious Pad Thai, very nice portion size, served beautifully. My friend & I had dinner here a few nights ago. The "Little Mermaid " appetizer was great. ....Marinated shrimp wrapped in thin rice paper, crispy, crunchy perfection in a fabulous house sweet plum sauce. So it was a little hot spicy n sweet. Yum!!!!! Highly recommend it. My Pad Thai is here. If I had it for dinner & Im back to have it 2 days later for lunch--IT IS GREAT!Service is very nice. A is on window for rating. Enjoy!

Holy mother of god the midnight ramen at Takashi is off the charts!!!!!Grandma's Spicy Ramen with Foie Gras: At a hefty ~$36, you can get a bowl of jaw-dropping, lip-smacking, finger-licking beef ramen with melt-in-your-mouth beef belly, crispy intestines, soft boiled egg, and foie gras that you'll be dreaming about for weeks.I know eating late night foods is not healthy for our bodies, but it seems like mental health trumps physical health this time! I am SO happy I can die with no regrets. Definitely the best bowl of ramen in town!Here's some actual useful insights post-rant:Call beforehand to make a reservation as they can only seat ~20 people at a time; there are usually two waves of customers at 12am and 1amThe broth surprisingly is not the usual salt heavy soup bases you get at other ramen placesIf you can take spicy, go for the Grandma - you won't regret it :)

Feeling Miamiish and putting all Peruvian chickens to shame with an organic Amish bird, the food here is first rate and Latin style with salsa playing and a tropical feeling room.There are sandwiches and sides, but with an organic, Amish bird, you should go straight for the bird!Ate: 1/2 rotisserie chicken(white meat) $13Sliced avocado & sea salt $4Lentils with salsa criollo & pickled red onions $6Juicy bird, with mega watt flavor, dipped in the salsas. Yum, with tasty lentils and creamy avocado with olive oil and sea salt. There is great value here and the service couldn't be nicer! Expect to enjoy your food, the music and surroundings!

So I've been banned from coming here by The Husband cause I ogle the waiters too much. I mean what else am I going to do while I wait for the food? The food is hot, the service is hot, the waiters are HOT. As Redemption is to hot waitresses for men, PMF is the equivalent for us ladies ;)Been here twice now and my faves are the mussels w/ that buttered wine garlic broth-- great for dipping all that crusty baguette with and OMG that succulent bone marrow! They gave us a house shot to scoop up the rest of the fatty marrow scrapings with.This place is just one big aphrodisiac. Truly one of my faves.

Brunch staple of NYC!I have been coming to Café Orlin for years and it has always been delectable!This classic brunch spot of the east village offers beautiful sidewalk seating and a large interior that just smells of delicious brunch while seeing cocktails flowing.When you arrive here you will be quick to notice the wait which can be anywhere from 15mins to 1.5hrs but it is well worth it but don't think that when you put your name and number down that means you can walk away and get coffee or a drink somewhere they will seat whatever group is there at the immediate time and the service is slow and not attentive but its still worth it.Once you get seated and see the brunch menu you will be impressed. They always have brunch specials and are absolutely delicious with strong bloody marys. The bloody marys are fresh and the coffee is strong perfect to get you ready for your Saturday.For food last time I was here for brunch I got the potato pancake with lox and poached eggs on top and when you broke those eggs on top of the potato pancake and the yoke spilled out it was blissful and delicious.In short:- Delicious Food- NYC brunch Hot spot- Strong cocktails and coffee- There can be long waits for brunch

Thursday Kitchen in a nutshell: Worth the hype.Part 2 of succinct synopsis: firing on all cylinders. Service, space and ingestibles are all top-notch *and* affordable. No-brainer.Let the record show that Thursday Kitchen does not take reservations. I'm guessing that you already know this, but I want to make note of it before jumping into the meat and potatoes (read: kimchi and kale) of this review. We arrived here at 8pm on a Saturday night, so I was already expecting to be slammed with a pretty significant wait time. Initially 90 minutes, though it ended up being closer to an hour. Thankfully there's a plethora of fantastic bars in the area so it's pretty easy to entertain yourself for that long, contingent on your stomach behaving. Thursday Kitchen is a below-ground mecca of Korean-inspired tapas and drinks that facilitate consuming of said tapas. Fun for a date, even better for a group of friends. It's got a young, energetic vibe with young, energetic staff. Oddly enough, the drinks seemed to take longer to arrive than the food, but I promise they're worth the wait. The beverage program here is as playful and quirky as advertised. Served in luminescent plastic pouches, these cocktails are basically adult Capri Sun Made with soju (clear liquor, rice-based), these drinks are light but lethal. Remember the "adult" qualifier here. Though they may seem indistinguishable from those magical childhood beverages, these do indeed have alcohol in them. They're sweet, too, so do a bit of forecasting and don't catapult yourself into hangover city. It's a very real possibility if you're not careful. In any case, I tried the Ms. Cuteini (soju, cucumbers, bitters) and the Lychee Reach Rich (soju, lychee, mango) and both were sublime. Who needs to wait in line at Death & Co when you have these?Initially, they got our first round order wrong. We ordered three Cuteinis and one Lychee but received the swapped order. The result? Two free drinks. One of them mine. That's a place that wants you having a good time. And our server was fabulous overall. Hilarious, knowledgable and accommodating. You can tell the staff loves working here.Thursday Kitchen recommends 2-3 plates per person. I'd recommend 3--plates are on the smaller side. Because we went as a party of four, it made the most sense to eliminate what we didn't want as opposed to choose what we did. This worked out fabulously. Eats, below:Kale w/ stilton (blue cheese)-daikon vinaigrette, mung bean sprout, brussels sprout: A+Somehow, one of the best dishes of the night. Gotta be that dressing. Light and creamy. The ideal starter.Angry Sweet Potato w/ sriracha goat cheese, chilli pepper: AOnly order these if you like spice. Read carefully: sriracha *and* chili pepper. Delicious. Sriracha goat cheese is a brilliant invention. Avocado w/ greens vinaigrette, pickled radish, yuzu sour crème, shichimi pepper: ASmooth and yummy. Fresh and colorful. Other adjectives. Octopus w/ korean pear, sweet soy-scallion, riesling gellée, mango: BI'm an octo-snob (trademarking that now) so I'm picky when it comes to octopus. The preparation here was interesting but the execution fell flat. The octopus was rubbery and made the whole dish lackluster--especially relative to the rest of our queue for the night.Soft Shell Crab w/ wasabi remoulade, pickeled tomatoes: AOnly got one bite, but it was delicious. Lightly fried and that wasabi remoulade was heavenly. The tomatoes seemed irrelevant, but that's a minor complaint. Kimchi Paella w/ white tiger shrimp, mussels, caramelized kimchi: AOne of our larger (and heavier) orders. The shrimp were tasty, the mussels were just okay. The paella itself was delicious. Hard to believe it was kimchi!Tuna Tataki w/ hummus coulis, sesame vinaigrette, crunchy quinoa, serrano pepper, sumac: ALovely and light--one of our healthier dishes of the night. Varied and interesting both flavor and texture-wise.Steak w/ soy-garlic glaze, feta grits, sautéed kale: A+Probably the simplest plate we ordered both ingredient-wise and aesthetics-wise but man, what a knockout. Grits were the perfect consistency. Steak was cooked to perfection and that soy-garlic glaze made the kale yummy too. Win.Crispy Chicken w/ sweet and spicy sauce, black sesame crumbles: AFun take on fried chicken with an Asian flair. Uber flavorful and not healthy in the slightest.Chicharron w/ conft-style pork belly, cashew crème, white kimchi, lime juice, cilantro: A+Heaven. Pork belly is just decadent. Crispy, rich, flavorful and topped with some creamy/dreamy cashew cream. Fun, creative preparation. Edamame Dumpling w/ steamed, citrus truffle oil, green pepper, parmigiano: A+One of my favorite plates of the night. Hard to go wrong with this combo, but these were total flavor bombs. Truffle Mac and Cheese w/ manila clam, three cheese blend: A+Again, truffle mac was a shoe-in to be a crowd-pleaser. Having some hidden clams in there was a special treat.

I love the food here. I came back two nights in a row. The music is fun and the vibe is pretty good. Didn't have to wait too long each time to be seated. Food:Soft shell crab - super delicious especially with the sauce Wings - delicious Pho - good but way too big; best part was the beef Fried rice - very good Shaved ice dessert - would pass on this one next time

My go to spot for awesome coffee and lattes made by some really cool baristas.Place is cash only!Place is quiet and very chill with small table booths in the back.There's some books on the shelves you can read while you hangout when you're tired from looking at your phone that's giving you too much radiation on a daily basis. They have a menu with tons of good caffeine options and bites.

Loved this brunch spot! It is so close to me - I want to come all the time! It started getting packed around noon, so make sure you have a reservation! Classic breakfast items with bottomless drinks! I would love to come here in a big group - I think it would be great for birthday brunches. The atmosphere is great! Totally rustic and edgy - I love it! I bet for dinner it would be a great dats spot to grab dinner and drinks as well!

Pinch is one of those places that is special not only because of their outstanding food, but also because of the thoughtfulness with which they approach it. The ambiance of the space is pulled together, sophisticated, and artful without being at all stuffy or pretentious. I especially love the viewing window where you can watch their artisan chefs fold all of their dumplings into beautiful shapes. Just a quick glance at their menu shows that they really know and understand their target and are hitting it perfectly. This is elevated, modern Chinese cuisine, with enough confidence to call itself that. While I'm not an expert on Chinese food, the mix of familiar dishes with ones that are harder to find is just enough to keep you from feeling neither under nor overwhelmed. There are both refined flavors and ones that pack a punch, and I wasn't the least bit disappointed with any dish that we tried. In fact, their consistency each time we've gone is one of the most impressive things about the experience. They also throw in some charming quirks, like cocktails named after the lyrics of "Call Me Maybe." (If you like something smoky, I especially recommend the "This is Crazy.") Everything was also very clean, down to their bathrooms, and their staff were all very welcoming and attentive.Seafood + Pork Soup Dumplings: Their dumplings are the star of the show, no way around it. Of course, with their DTF-trained chefs, expectations are high, and they nailed it perfectly. The wrapper on the outside was sturdy with that slight chewiness that I love, and the pork/seafood broth inside is heavenly.Mushroom Dumplings: If you love the earthy flavor of mushrooms and truffles, you absolutely have to order this one. I could eat 50 of these and be perfectly happy with my life choices.Spicy Wontons: Again, the quality of the wrapper is absolutely key, and the flavor of the oils and spices in the sauce just makes you want to discreetly drink it under the table.Marinated Cucumber: Totally the unsung hero of the meal. I am addicted to the cool crunch of the cucumber and the delicately balanced flavors. It seems so simple, but when you taste it, you'll know that a lot of finesse went into this dish.Niman Ranch Cumin Ribs: The flavor on these ribs seriously blew my mind. The meat is tender and comes right off the bone, and the spices on top are phenomenal. I have never had anything like it anywhere else. Even if they didn't have dumplings, I would still come for these ribs.Three Cup Chicken: The chicken itself is properly cooked to just the right doneness, and the sauce is flavorful without making you feel like you're going past your sodium intake limit for the day. I also love the fresh herbs they throw in.Seafood Fried Rice: The rice is amazingly fluffy and punctuated by nice, big pieces of shrimp, scallop, and crab. The flavor is subtle, really relying on the naturally rich flavor of the seafood. I sound like a broken record, but this one is also a must.Overall, you can find cheap Chinese food anywhere, but from what I've seen, you can only find this level of thoughtfully curated aesthetic and experience here at Pinch.

So happy this place opened! While there are a few coffee shops in the area, most don't serve matcha. I was walking by Sunday and decided to check it out the next day. I came around 8:30pm and was told they usually close at 8pm but I was still able to get a matcha latte. The owner (I thought he was at least) was super nice and made a delicious matcha latter. With almond milk it came out to $4.90 which is really good because there's a place down the street that charges $6 which is crazy. They also use my favorite almond milk brand (the barista blend califa one). I saw they have a baked goods shelf/stand but since I was here late I didn't get to try one. Guess I will have to come back!The place has a very cozy environment and I will definitely be hanging out here more!

In loooove! I was looking for a subtle but new cut and after avoiding it for weeks, decided to give it a shot here. I worked with Tara and let me tell ya, this girl made my hair go from drab to fab! Most stylists are overwhelmed with my hair but she handled it so beautifully and always kept what I wanted in mind. She always made sure we had the same vision and worked with me to make sure we were headed in the right direction. She also made sure I was comfortable the entire time- very sweet and professional! She also spent the time to style it afterwards and always answered any hair questions I had in general. Loved my cut so much from Tara, will be returning for my balayage with her later this week and will keep you posted!! **The location is also cute, it's entrance can be a bit tricky but look for the door that reads "Jane & Fox" next to the GNC store.

Is it just me or did the egg tarts used to be a lot cheaper than the current $1 a pop? It's somehow stamped in my memory that, in a bygone era, they were only a quarter each and I would get four in a bag to myself, cradling the waxen paper, each tart still hot from the oven.Sometimes they have the fluorescent green egg tarts but those sell out in a jiffy. The regular egg custards are best when slightly toasted and warm - my favorite part that always ends too soon is the soft eggy middle. Here's what else I've tried (and heartily recommend):- Moon cake with the lotus seed paste and green tea mooncake. - Pineapple bun. These are SO GOOD. My HK friends taught me the traditional way to eat these: slice it in half, toast it, and then stick a thick slab of butter inside. I can't really concentrate after eating one but it's well worth the sacrifice. - Sachima. If you're Chinese, you'll know exactly what this is because chances are that your parents/grandparents/aunties have a few of these individually wrapped cellophane blocks stuck inside an empty blue Royal Dansk butter cookie bin. I basically just summed up your entire childhood. Lung moon's iteration isn't overly sweet and has just enough honey syrup. - Triangle sponge cake. Like angel cake, only fluffier.- Sweet black bean bun and pork bun. You'll want to take a nap after eating this. The only miss was with the cream puffs. I don't know what happened but I got an extremely stale batch.

$75 including tip for 12 piece omakase (I would still tip your sushi chef a little bit at the end) ! What a deal.They are very strict with their time and do not seat late parties. I appreciated this as we were not disturbed at all during our meal. I also thought the little cards with our names were a nice touch. They just opened 6 weeks ago so they are still relatively new. But the sushi is fresh and reminds me of Japan (My rice was falling apart a little for some of the pieces). At the end, we asked the chef to recommend some additional pieces and he was more than happy to show us. The a-la carte pieces were also decently priced.You can now make your reservation easily on opentable. I will definitely be back.

A great addition to the neighborhood. I no longer have to trek to the village for my favorite Indian food. They have the traditional dishes here like the Channa masala, or veg biryani (wirh yogurt but can be made vegan) and some dishes I've never had before. I was ecstatic to see that they have a separate section between veg and vegan items. We had the chilli gobi to start, which is a spicy breaded cauliflower in a sweet and tangy sauce, very spicy. The red pumpkin thoran / curry is simply divine, savoury with a nice coconut flavor. It is perfect with the kadhai bindi, an okra dish, which was crispy and all sorts of yummy. The onion fritters, pakora, are nicely done. I especially enjoyed the combination of the cabbage fry with the dal (yellow lentils). Attentive service, and friendly staff. Plenty of seating, good for groups or a date. Comfy seats and delicious food, I can't ask for more.Overall, we're very pleased with the food and can't wait till our next visit.

Hip Urban // Inspirational Art Walk // Elevated Warm sunshine kisses your face as you stroll along the Highline. A faint breeze greets you as you notice the unique ever changing art. It's clear that the group who preserved this piece of history really are "Friends of the Highline." Inspired by mother nature, and made with Love in NYC all around great experience for just about everyone.Before it's construction in 1934 trains which came directly into what the industrial district had more than a handful of collisions, which led to the construction of elevated train tracks. As an initiative to improve safety the tracks provided a safer way to bring food and agriculture efficiently into lower Manhattan.  As transportation methods changed the Highline became unused in the 80's. Left unattended for 25 years nature had her own design, and when demolition crews were eyeing the structure, friends of the Highline was formed to preserve what we now see today. With over 450 annual public programs, it truly is one of NYC's little gems. Complete with sitting areas, dining, sculptures, changing artwork, and a picture window where you can watch all of the cars zoom by. Make sure your phone is fully charged, you'll want to snap pictures along the 1.45 mile walk.The Scene: Hip, Romantic, Family FriendlyDestination Rating: 9Date Rating: 8Hob Nob Potential: 3Strong Suggestion: If you have kids who are train fanatics the "end" of the Highline should not be missed. 34th street overlooks the train yard for Penn Station, and has a violin installation which has audio that accompanies the trains which are coming and going. Commute hours have the most trains. Pack a snack and sit down and watch. Beautiful sunset views as well.

Delicious! We swung by after viewing photos on Yelp and were really happy that the food was better than what we expected. We didn't have reservations, but there were plenty of spaces as the restaurant is quite spacious. The restaurant was surprisingly not loud although it was crowded. The decor resembles a Western saloon. There is something for everyone here, a romantic indoor patio in the back (reservations highly recommended), a happening bar near the front and a relaxing and open dining area for people like me who just like dining.The food was incredibly good. We had the veal and eggplant, grilled shrimp and all-white salad. I appreciate that they use the best and freshest ingredients for each dish. The sauces and dressing was just sufficient as to not overhelm the dish. I love the huge shrimp they used as they were more than plenty, plump and juicy. It was a wonderful dining experience overall.

I work on the same block as Zio and just started visiting this establishment, but I will tell you they won me over! I almost want to call it love at first sight, just don't tell my husband. One day after work my coworkers and I wanted to grab drinks and decided since our favorite place was rather packed it is a good idea to try something else. Immediately, upon walking into Zio the ambiance had me hooked. It is truly a beautiful space with perfectly dimmed lights, beautiful decor, and an open kitchen as well. There was four of us and the bar was packed but they offered us a table which was perfect.GET THIS! This have happy hour every single day from 4:30-7:30.- $4 Draft Beers- $6 Wine- $10 Specialty CocktailsWhile there I ordered the Fried Zucchine with Calamari and it was the best decision I made all day. The customer service is out of this world as well! I enjoyed myself so much last week I decided to drop in this week to grab a quick drink and dinner at the bar. Once again they knocked it out the park! I had the Ravioli and I am still currently dreaming about it! Also our group had the prosciutto, cheese, and arugula thin crust pizza. LIFE CHANGING! Thank you for becoming my new fav!!!

Returning for the sushi omakase since I really enjoyed the nigiri set my last visit. The meal was very very pleasant. Overall fish quality is above par in the city, very fresh fish and nice variety at seasonable prices.Scallop, squid, eel, totoro, snapper and hokoiddo uni were my favorites. Every piece is fresh, sweet and flavorful with prefect amount of soy sauce/vinegar. Scallop is sweet, fatty and juicy. The squid is sweet with the soft texture like scallop. Smart move to add Yuzu peels to the sweet eel, which balances the flavor really well. Totoro is heaven! Fatty melting and aromatic totoro would simply satisfy all my sushi cravings.... red snapper tastes amzing too (fatty, soft, sweet and flavorful. Literally melts in your mouth. Best I have had of this kind). Hokoiddo uni is surprising juicy (usually drier in texture at most places). It's so juicy and sweet, that I can just drink it like a shot.Overall, very good nigiri, nice pace and good service. Will come back more often.

In the world of doughnuts there's either amazing doughnuts or crappy doughnuts and Dun-Well is AMAZING! I had the blueberry peanut yeast doughnut and was curious at first about the flavor combo but was surprised at how well they worked together. The doughnut itself wasn't too doughy or heavy and not greasy. The flavor was definitely there with the icing not being overly sweet. Freshness is definitely something these guys pay attention to it seems. With about 8 to 12 different flavors there's not 100 hundred donuts laying around all day. Small batches guarantee freshness with any place. Friendly staff. Decent prices. Clean shop.I'd definitely go back!BONUS: They're Vegan!

One of the best museums in the city that never sleeps. Perfect for the whole family, but be aware that kids can ask you funny questions about some of the prehistoric exhibits.In general, it is important to know that the entrance is based on a suggested donation, you don't really have to pay for a whole price ticket. Tourists always get this wrong, it's good that you support the institution though. As long as you give some money they'll be good and you will get your entrance approved.They also have at least two areas for food, if I'm not mistaking. The prices are super high though, a bottle of water is about $5 bucks. Bring your food or pay their price.

This is my favorite Thai place in NYC thus far. Not only is everything from the decor to the food visually beautiful, but it is also delicious. Thai Villa includesHere is what you need to know:1. Reservations recommended.2. Get everything from the special menu. I haven't tried anything that wasn't wonderful.3. Standard Americanized Thai dishes are also available here.4. Cocktails are delicious and strong.5. Service ranges but errs on the side of solid.This is now my go-to Thai place for locals and tourists. I highly recommend coming in here. It easily outranks all other Thai places in Manhattan.

I enjoyed myself immensely here. They offer sake, both sparkling and flat (STRONG) as well as green tea varieties. I had a wonderful night of sake and Japanese comfort food. I ordered their Shrimp Tempura Curry and got hubbs some take-out of Chicken Tonkotsu Curry. The small portions were big enough to have two servings each. Their Fried Gyoza are so banging and I could not stop eating them. So good. The food is great, the service equally so and the staff is just so friendly. It's a blessing they're locates only twenty minutes from my home and less than ten from my job. I can definitely see myself making a few lunch trips here during the week.

Of all the Japanese chains opening in NYC lately, I was most excited to hear about Ikinari Steak's first U.S. location. I expected a line to be out the door on opening day, but was very surprised there wasn't one when I arrived around 11:50 a.m. (They opened at 11.) It was mostly press standing around blocking waitresses that were trying to bring food to customers or pressing against diners trying to eat. There were only few actual diners but more customers started to stroll in by the time I left. I was shown to a standing station right away and was done in 35 min. without scarfing down my food. The menu is small with 3 cuts of wet-aged steak by weight and 1 lunch special, a few sides, and a few drinks including beer and wine. Current prices are 9 cents/gram for ribeye, 8 cents/gram for sirloin, & 11 cents/gram for filet. There are minimum weight orders for the steaks so ribeye starts at 300g ($27), sirloin at 200g ($16), and filet at 200g ($22).How it works:- Instead of going to a counter to order first, an employee will show/direct you to a numbered standing station (Their model is based on standing dining stations but this location has a small number of seats. Ask about seats if you prefer one)- Menus are already at the standing station. A waiter will come over to bring water, a paper apron, & take your order for drinks and sides only.- Then the waiter will walk you or direct you to the back kitchen counter to order your meat (cut of meat and weight). You show/tell the kitchen chef your table number.Even if you order the chuck-eye steak lunch special which is not available by weight, you still have to go tell the kitchen counter your order. A little odd, but I guess this is to make the process consistent for the staff.- After you order your steak, you go back to your station and your food is brought out to you- Forks, knives, napkins & condiments are already at your station. There were no spoons. - A bill is brought to you when your steak is delivered. Keep it so you can pay at the front desk when you leave.I had the $20 chuck-eye steak lunch special because it's a good deal. It comes with soup, salad & white rice. Media reports say the chuck-eye is 14 oz. The lunch menu lists 300g (or 10.6 oz). The soup and salad are very small and basic, but you're really paying for the steak. My steak came out sliced on a sizzling platter with a side of corn. The chuck-eye already had nice color on the outside but was blue rare on the inside. There's even a printed guide on how to enjoy your steak, and they suggest rare.I usually prefer my steak medium or medium rare, but I went rare this time. My chuck-eye was very tender and flavorful from the fat and seasoning. The house hot steak sauce was delicious but didn't cover up the steak. Not sure if the house steak sauce is hot because it's warm and kept in a thermos, or also spicy. If there is spice, I didn't really taste it. But having warm sauce is perfect to help keep the steak warm. There's also Ikinari sauce that is a sweet sauce. It's also tasty but I preferred the house steak sauce. They also sell bottles of the Ikinari sauce.They are a non-tipping restaurant. I walked out full and happy from chuck-eye steak lunch for $21.78 after tax.About that paper apron...it's a good idea to help keep any grease splatter from the sizzling hot plate from getting on your clothes. The standing stations have lots of storage. A shelf where you can place menus after ordering or to store items, a hook to hang a coat or bags, and even foldable stands on the floor that can hold briefcases or bags. The kitchen is open so you do walk out smelling smokey like hibachi or K-BBQ places. The restroom has a fancy Japanese toilet with a dryer option. There's also Listerine if you want to be minty fresh. And if you're so inclined, they have a Niku mileage membership card that you can sign up for to track the weight of meat you eat. The card comes complete with Lady Liberty and has rewards after consuming a certain amount of beef. I'll be back to try other cuts. Definitely recommend trying this place for quality steak at reasonable prices.

A little gem on Macdougal for sure!We all know there is lots to eat on Macdougal but this joint is always on the top of my list. Besides the fact that they make the most delicious golden brown fries they are also what I like to call 'sauce heaven'. Typically when you first walk in you will see a crowd of people standing by the register giving you the impression that the line is long but usually those people are just debating on what sauce(s) to choose. I love condiments and sauces (probably because I'm so extra) and the sauces here are unique, eclectic, and seriously delicious. My favorite sauces are parmesan peppercorn, curry ketchup, and the sweet mango chutney mayo. The staff is always very kind and you can tell they work great together as a team. Upon ordering, the staff offers customers the option of sauce on the fries or the side. I've experienced both options and I prefer to have it on the side because I'm a dip kind of girl.

Nice little cozy Thai restaurant located at 55th Street and 9th Avenue. The ambience is causal and dim with cute wall displays of bowls and plates, representing their yummy dishes. The service is quick and efficient. I really like their pineapple fried rice and sangria. Their pineapple fried rice is sweet and savory...it's like a party in your mouth. Their sangria is pretty unique compared to the other sangrias I had tried...it is just right with a hint of lychee flavor.$10 minimum for credit card.

Very friendly staff all around.Meticulous job on the pedicure, which kudos! The lady used a non sharp toothpick to clean up any kind of polish that ended up on my skin and not on my nail.The shop is cozy, and nicely decorated. When you approach the counter, you chat about what you want, pick your polish color, then are offered a tea (black, green, mint, and 1-2 more). There is a nice happy hour special - $50 for a mani/pedi before 4pm if you pay with cash!

Loved everything about Taco Mahal!From the super sweet and bubbly girl at the front who handles the orders + payments (other reviewers mention her being the owner's daughter), to the BOMBBBB chicken tikka masala taco in a roti shell. It was just filling enough for me to hold me over until dinner and the flavors were all on point! I'll definitely come back to try the other proteins or at least try my steady chicken tikka masala in a naan (apparently 2x the size of a normal taco?!)

My favorite cookie place of all time. So glad they opened this new location, which is literally 4 blocks away from the original location (and the original place is still open). The new location is a lot bigger, brighter, and based on my last visit, has significantly shorter line. Back to the cookie, they maybe the biggest and heaviest cookies you will ever have. Gooey on the inside, a bit crunch on the outside. My favorite is the oatmeal and raisin, although the peanut butter chip one is amazing and so is the chocolate chip walnut one. The double chocolate chip one is the sweetest and I get it the least often. With that said, if you put it in front me right now, I will eat it.

I love it here! It is such a different experience then your typical NYC bar or rooftop.I came on Saturday with my boyfriend and two friends and had drinks and also ordered food. We were lucky enough to not have to wait on a very long line (it moves quickly though) and once we got in we were lucky enough to find a table!!! We started with a pitcher of white sangria ($40) which was tasty. I have had it before from this venue so I knew what we were ordering. Once we finished that we order a bucket of coronas (the bucket is a better deal than a pitcher because you get a beer free and they're in bottles). By the time we ordered the bucket of beer we were starting to get hungry so we order 2 French fries and a burger. They give you a buzzer so you know when your food is ready (nice and organized). Our food came out relatively quickly and it was delicious! Overall, this is a great place to go on a warm day because get to experience the feeling of being on a boat with beautiful views of the city and NJ.

This is THE spot for dessert! My absolute favorite dessert is lava cake, and it is usually what I dedicate my cheat days to and the reason why I run so much. The matcha lava cake here is pretty much perfection. The warmth and the bittersweetness of the matcha lends itself to pair beautifully with the dark chocolate. And that beautiful ooze when you poke at it with your spoon! Ah, nothing is quite so satisfying. The accompanying matcha ice cream provided that cold-to-warm contrast and the cookie crumble offered a satisfying textural contrast in each bite. Pair it with a good cup of black tea, and you have yourself a perfect Sunday afternoon.Also, the service here is fantastic. Our waiter even advised us where to sit (mid-section by the windows) if we want good instagrammable light (haha!), and offered to refill our teas twice.

D.C.-based &pizza finally made it to NYC, and they came in strong with free pizza for the first 212 customers in line at their Flatiron location on West 28th Street. I was number 201 and was thrilled to make the cut, but for only $11 and unlimited toppings, I would have gladly waited in line even had my pizza not been free.I have yet to see another restaurant opening pulled off as flawlessly as this one. They had plenty of &pizza representatives walking around the line with both pizza samples and drinks as well as menus. They were quick to offer their own pizza preferences and answer any questions. Once inside, a DJ was spinning tunes and the servers behind the counter were working quickly to make sure the line moved at a fast pace. Everyone employee I came in contact with was friendly, professional, and had a smile on their face. On a day as hectic as this one probably was for them, they were amazing. The pizza! Wow - I really thought I'd eat just half and save the rest for lunch the following day, but I ate it all. So delicious. $11 for unlimited toppings (meats, cheese, vegetables, sauces, etc) is ridiculous, but I'll happily take advantage of it again.

It's more of a 4.5 for the strange hiccups in restaurant management, but the food is here is very solid, especially with so much ramen competition in the city. I accidentally stumbled upon EAK Ramen after a massage two blocks away and found this place on Yelp. Little did I know it had opened 4 days ago - a chain from Japan specializing in Iekei (E.A.K!) ramen - pork and shoyu broth combo with very thick noodles by, of course, Sun Noodles.We showed up and there seemed to be a lot of people waiting in line so we put our name down on the clipboard, Totto Ramen style. About 15-20 min later we were seated, which was pretty quick in my opinion given this place is brand new, "hyped", and it was Sunday dinner rush hour. We did see a few empty seats at the bar for some reason that they weren't filling for one reason or another. We sat at the bar, right in front of where a lady was washing cups and filling waters the entire time (not really that appetizing to watch). Service was decent - we were kind of served by the cup washer lady and our food was brought to us by other people. It seemed a little disorganized, to say the least and I heard another waitress expressing her frustration several times. I also noticed that the bartender doesn't seem to know how to pour beer - the beers she poured were like at least half foam! Our ramen also came out literally 30 seconds after they gave us our appetizer.... yikes. I hate when that happens because something always ends up getting cold. I'll give them the benefit of the doubt and hope that these new restaurant hiccups will likely get fixed as time passes.However, I came for the food... and not really expecting much of service. The karaage was hot, freshly fried, and very flavorful, unlike some places. They give you the option of choosing not one, but two sauces off their list - we got the garlic chili and sweet chili. I liked the sweet chili the best.The EAK Ramen (original pork/shoyu broth) with thick noodles and the garlic puree and onion really did it for me. It wasn't too salty and not too thick and the noodles were just the right consistency. The egg was absolutely the best egg I've had in the city - YUM. Perfectly cooked and seasoned. The pork left a bit to be desired as it wasn't really "charred" like Totto's is, but still melts in your mouth. An extra side is $3 and they give you a ton. All in all, this dish was quite satisfying and is one of the top 5 ramens I've had in the city for sure.Definitely worth a shot if you're a ramen snob like me. Hopefully they fix the service issues after they've been open longer. The pork/shoyu broth and thicker noodles hit the spot for us!

This place is MY JAM.-They've got a huge screen with stadium style seating for your movie watch/lunch eating enjoyment.(Pro tip: bring Bluetooth headphones to participate in the movie/tv show watching)-Tons of seating along with some more closed off desk space so you can work and do yo thang.-3 floors of books. (With elevators to access all the floors)-Lots of computers to rent or work at.-A play space for babies to run around on the bottom level (it's closed off and the spaces are all lined with padding to keep the tots from breaking their heads).-Clean bathrooms. Seriously, a necessity.-Lovely staff.-Self checkout.-Barstool seating next to all the brand new releases overlooking the movie area (you can't eat there but you can use your computer, read, etc).The design of this NYPL is cool and modern, it will help you beat the heat on the hot, sticky summer days AND it's directly across the street from the MOMA so stop through there when you're finished. Note: lots of baby sitters bring their tiny tots here around lunch and they usually stay around until it's baby's nap time so things can get a little loud depending on where you are in the library between 12-2p. (Usually 6-10 nanny/baby duos during lunch).

If I could give this 6/5 I would! My favorite Indian place in Hell's Kitchen! Super friendly owner, great lunch specials and delicious food. Recently under new management it seems. Much better than a lot of the other Indian places nearby that I've tried. We had the cardamom rice pudding (free with first Yelp check-in) and he was very insistent that next time he let us taste his homemade ice cream. Dine-in veg curry lunch specials are $6.50 but rice or naan is extra at $3. Take-out veg lunch special is $8 - and you get a free side plus rice or bread. Portions are huuge and delicious. We had the okra and eggplant. Okra was slightly better spiced. But if you prefer creamy do the eggplant - plus they give you 3-4 whole roasted mini eggplants!The staff and especially the owner are extremely friendly and polite. Can't wait to come back!

For those looking for the quintessential Parisian bistro experience, look no further than one of the latest newcomers to Manhattan's West Village: Boucherie. The restaurant opened at the end of 2016 to no small amount of acclaim, thanks to the fact that Chef Jerom Dihui (former chef of McNally's now shuttered Pastis) is behind the kitchens. The venue has a sprawling dining room and bar area that gets plenty of sunlight during the earlier hours, as well as a balcony on the second floor - for those looking to impress. Everything about the decor, from the sizeable mirror hung behind the bar, to the marble-patterned tables and tiled floors, is true to form.On a breezy Saturday evening, the restaurant was happily buzzing and unsurprisingly occupied - reservations in advance, especially on busy days, are recommended. We had our pick of seats (I recommend taking a table near the windowed doors or on the patio) and were soon greeted by our server and Paul, the sommelier. When I asked him for a wine recommendation (a white or sparkling, not too dry) he pointed out an effervescent and slightly sweet Brut Rose, which he asked me to taste first to make sure it was to my liking. Pinning down choices from the food menu, however, wasn't quite as easy... So we ending up ordering almost all the dishes that had caught our eyes.For our starters, we had gone with the Escargot and the Foie Gras Mousse. The former were served piping hot and generously drenched in an addictive garlic, butter, and parsley sauce; they were pleasantly toothsome and had none of the aftertaste I've sometimes encountered in dishes that weren't executed to par. Ask for an extra side of bread to soak up the remaining sauce - it's that good. My personal favorite, however, had to be the Foie Gras Mousse. It's beautifully presented with a side of red wine onion compote, frisee, and toasted bread; there are few things more perfectly balanced than a spread of the rich foie gras against the sweet-tartness of the onion compote supported by the firm, slightly crunchy bread. It may appear to be simple, but there's a reason why this dish has stood the test of time.When it came to the entrees, I immediately gravitated to towards the Duck Confit, which is served with a portion of confited duck leg, frisee salad, and a generous serving of black truffle chips. The duck had a delightful crisp skin that yielded to a flavorful dark meat, which paired well with the lighter salad that had the protein interspersed throughout it. I was able to try the Veal Porterhouse as well, which came impressively presented with the bone still in. It was cooked to the requested medium rare and each portion of meat was juicy and tender, pairing well with the red wine-infused veal jus that it was served with. We rounded out our meal with a side of Fries (crispy, hot, and perfectly seasoned) as well as a rustic Ratatouille, made with roasted tomatoes, zucchini, onions, and mushrooms.What makes Boucherie excel, however, is the caliber of service. Our plates were always promptly cleared and our server was always nearby to check on us; when I dropped my knife off the table, she was immediately at my side with a new one. And while I may not be a wine expert, those who do appreciate it will easily get lost in conversation with their Sommelier, Paul; he took a great deal of time to speak with us about his previous experiences (including Le Bernardin) and answered every question we had, from the wines available at Boucherie to the levels of certification as indicated by his Sommerlier pin.I very much look forward to returning now that the weather will allow for dining al fresco - and for those looking for a leisurely and welcoming meal in the city, Boucherie will certainly exceed your expectations.

So fresh and so clean, clean; boasting an ultra minimalist design with large retracting windows. Small coffee table seating towards the front with a small seating area pass the counter towards the back. The Miles Coffee Bar provides inviting options to enjoy a cup of your favorite morning or evening beverage. In addition, the main attraction for me so far, has been the addictive vegan cookie, which had me break out in a Katy Perry song...'I ate a vegan cookie and I liked iittt...', definitely a must try for vegan-phobes. All items, sweet bakery goods or savory sandwiches are baked and made in-house by their onsite baker and available fresh daily; a definitive plus. And to add, just a little further towards the back area, you'll have an opportunity to make use of their patio and enjoy a selection of beer and wine during the warmer days. It is clear, this new establishment was well thought out in all aspects to help break the neighborhood monotony. Indeed, The Miles Coffee Bar is a welcoming and a friendly addition to the area.

Incredible experience for sushi lovers. A lot of good sushi has to do with equal parts craft and equal parts sourcing and you get it all here at Nakazawa. My husband made a reservation for us to eat the omakase at the sushi bar for my birthday - reservations open up 30 days in advance online. You need to reserve right at midnight because it fills up in minutes. There are 3 seating a night- we went to the 930 (think the others are 530 and 730) You also better show up (why wouldn't you - or not be late ) as they will charge you $150 if you don't. Service is really as you'd expect - serene and calm. It was fun watching the chefs work at the bar but it was probably the calmest sushi bar I'd ever seen. Wasn't too much of a show per se. You can I think more easily eat in their lounge but all sushi comes from the bar. Decor is zen and monochrome - simple and clean as the Japanese would have it. Drinks - they have an extensive list of sake, wine (more by the bottle versus glass), beers ( my husband ordered a Japanese red rice ale which was malty and flavorful- very interesting) and I glasses of Sauv Blanc and Gruner. As for dings on service, sometimes it was hard to hear or understand the chefs so I wish that our server did a better job of explaining each course. I guess she was more conversational when it was required - explaining different cuts of fish and demonstrating what was unique about each piece. For instance call me stupid but ginger was given to us on the side and i had to ask what to do with it - it was a palate cleanser in between each meal which honestly should be explained upfront since some people might think it goes with the fish (don't do that). You also shouldn't expect wasabi- that will accompany the piece if the chef feels it goes. They did explain though that you can eat either with your hands or chopsticks. If hands, they give you a little wet napkin to wipe in between.The omakase is 20 pieces and I'm not going to dive into each one because my guess is things change based on what can be flown in. They also ask you what you like and don't like i.e. My husband doesn't like roe. Of course customer service reigns supreme here as we noticed the couple next to us didn't like several of things (sadly) and were quickly given replacements. But, overall the real esoteric Japanese fish were white in nature and ranged from things like Spanish mackerel (can be oily and fishy), to other types of fish which I can't recall since all of the names are in Japanese. Of course there were crowd pleasers like delicious salmon types - one my favorites was one smoked with hay which has an earthy flavor. Others were more subtle. Others were salty based on the type of salmon like an Alaskan sockeye - you get to try all kinds of fish they create sushi from, it's not just from Japan. We also got to try very interesting shellfish sushi - like a citrus squid with yuzu and sea scallop - never really had these raw before. I also enjoyed the square type sushi which we had with crab. Mostly all other types were nigiri - no raw One of my favorites was the 3 piece Tuna trio from most lean to less lean to fatty tuna (everyone's favorite). You get actually pretty educated about different cuts of fish with this meal! For an upsell you can pay $13 for 3 pieces more which I recommend - two types of uni - one from California and one from Japan. Not sure if I actually like uni unless mixed in a pasta but it was incrediblyFresh. Perhaps the real killer piece of this upsell is the waygu beef. It was grade a something - but trust me it's worth the upsell for this!! Barely cooked and rare done, I don't usually eat beef this raw but it was so clean and fresh and flavorful and perfect pairing with the rice (which mind you was incredible- vinegary and flavorful). Absolutely yum with a hint of soy. They also had a tasty hand roll with tuna towards the end of the meal which was salty, and had good crunch from the Nori. For dessert, you end the meal with a delicious house made tea which was so warming. I forget the flavor but it was very good. And then an egg sushi- forget the name but the steamed egg is also pretty to look at and sweet and light in taste. And best yet, a scoop of lychee sorbet. Yum!A really awesome experience on all fronts so definitely go for a special occasion. Dinner for 2 was about $500 ish all in.

Super cute spot, albeit a little out of the way in alphabet city. From what I saw and tasted, this place is the real deal! Even all the employees there are Italian with heavy accents :)Pretty short and sweet menu, divided into appetizers, pastas (all made fresh in-house!), and meats. At the beginning of your meal, you get complimentary bread, and they also come by with a basket full of wines for you to choose from if you're in the mood for a glass! Note that they don't really have fancy cocktails unless you want the classics like a martini.This place does classic and simple really well. The 4 of us shared the following:Burrata E Pomodorini $15Clean and simple - just fresh burrata cheese and grape tomato, but it tasted extra freshhhh with the tomatoes chilled beforehand. Good start.Crostone "Fagiolino" $16Chicken liver, prosciutto cotto, mushroomsBEST dish of the night for sure. We at first got one order, which came with 3 crostinis. Since we had 4 people, we decided to ask them to add one more which we would pay for. Probably some language barriers/miscommunication but we ended up getting another order of it. Except this time, it came with 2 larger pieces of crostini haha. It was so good we didn't mind getting more of it :) Everything on there is so light, yet so flavorful. The prosciutto is delicate enough where you don't tug everything off the crostini in one bite, and the raw mushrooms shaved on top really lift the whole dish up. MUST GETTTT.Tagliatelle Bolognese $16Yummmm tagliatelle with beef ragout, this pasta was the perfect al dente! Spaghetticon Bottarga $22This was an interesting dish...when he described it, i honestly thought it was going to be like spaghetti with a shaving of bonito haha. I guess it IS pretty much like that, but with a finer dusting of bottarga mullet. The pasta is like a thinner and squiggly-er version of spaghetti, al dente to perfection, but i couldn't quite taste the bottarga. Would probably not get this again.Polpette al Sugo $20Yet another simple dish, meatballs in tomato sauce. Probably a little aggressive in charging $20 for this dish (6 meatballs), but they were good. I'd probably get more pastas instead of this dish if I ever went back.SpecialWe also got the special pasta of the day but I can't remember what it was called. I'll upload a picture so look there, but it looked like 5 perfectly plump and fat dumplings. The filling tasted like a spinach based filling, and it was fantastic. If i remember correctly, it came with a simple sage butter sauce.Everything was pretty delicious, and the restaurant is as cute as a button. Not as mom and pop-y as Bianca, but I think this is a pretty good alternative (I still miss Bianca though...!!!).

What can beat $12 wine flights during happy hour?! You can pick from a variety of whites and reds - 3 glasses for just $12. It's basically free in my eyes. Amélie is a great date spot, super intimate and cozy. It can get really dark, and although I hate the lighting, the food makes up for it. There are about 10 seats at the bar and 15-20 tables. It gets extremely busy so call really ahead of time to ensure a table. The wait staff are extremely nice! They all have great accents; I wish they can speak to me all day long, if possible. MUST GET GOAT CHEESE BALL. If you're a fan of cheese, please try this! They serve this with an unlimited amount of bread, so just spread it on your bread and eat, eat, eat. Then, order another one, and eat some more. It's super flavorful and creamy. You won't be disappointed.For some reason, I always end up getting octopus at a French restaurant. Try the Grilled Octopus Salad. The octopus is tender and the salad makes you think you're eating healthy!I have also tried the escargot, which wasn't too impressive, you can go without.If you haven't had enough cheese, order a charcuterie and cheese board. If you're like me and have no idea how to pair meats and cheese, ask the servers for help! You can never go wrong with a charcuterie board. I'm so glad I found this cute little place. I'll be back very soon!

Make a reservation. Sit at the sushi bar. Look over the list of sushi available for today; check off your favorites and shudder at the fact that you may be paying $10 for ONE piece of sushi. Or get Omakase if you're okay with letting go of control once in awhile. Drink the Matcha tea. Smile a wide smile at the newly assembled sushi that the chef has delicately placed in front of you. Put the sushi in your mouth and happy-cry a little (okay, a lot) at how every component is perfectly executed: from the light squeeze of fresh lemon on the oyster to the coarse sea salt on the white eel. Repeat as often as possible. Some tips:1. It's called Sushi Yasuda, not Sashimi Yasuda. Carbs are good for your spirit and you don't want to miss the rice here. Go for the sushi.2. You do not necessarily have to get Omakase for the best experience here if you know what you like. Must-order pieces for me are the east coast uni, oyster, three different types of eels, and toro scallion hand roll.3. The Sushi Matsu is a great way to taste 12 different types of sushi and half a roll at a lower price point ($44.50)! You can order some more premium pieces to finish. 4. It's acceptable to eat with your hands. So ditch the chopsticks; or god forbid, ditch the fork. You know who you are.

Walking down the block after leaving the restaurant, feeling euphoric, walking past Gramercy Tavern a few doors down, I just came to the realization that this is THE PLACE TO BE in 2017. There is nothing like this in NYC and makes other NYC institutions feel so 10 years ago... Having eaten at two of the restaurants owned by the same chef in Tel Aviv a number of years ago, totally blown away, I couldn't wait when I heard he was going to open his first restaurant in the US. It has a casual yet refined, and lively atmosphere. With much anticipation the two of us went a bit overboard and ordered: - Date donuts - excellent, absolute must have- Smoked eggplant caviar - extremely creative, utterly speechless, must have- Palestinian tartar - interesting tartar, very good- Foie gras - generous, tender and creamy grilled foie gras with crunchy condiments, perhaps the best and most creative foie gras I've ever had, absolute must have- Sea bass - tender, perfectly cooked, served with eggplant cream, must have- Octopus - extremely tender and beautifully presented, very good but a tad rich All dishes have a generous portion and are meant to be shared, and I totally agree. Even if your date or friend is not a big sharer, I would strongly encourage to share at least 3 main dishes, following the date donuts. They do not serve a free bread basket so we ordered kubaneh which was like a combination of brioche and croissant. I'm not usually a big fan of kubaneh but this was excellent. I also saw other tables eating Jerusalem sesame bagel which looked delicious. The cocktails were also outstanding. The manager told us that the cocktail menu was developed by a well known mixologist who worked at Eleven Madison and other institutions. Consistent with the food, the cocktails were extremely innovative yet refined. Of the 6 we tried, my favorites were Nur York Harvest (bourbon, must have), Clore Park Swizzle (arak, must have), and Old Fashioned (very good). The space is casual but sophisticated. I think it's good for dates, friends, or for business, or just drinks at the bar. I'm sure it's going to become extremely popular and hard to get a table, but for now it's a hidden gem which will surely impress whoever you want to impress...

My friend recommended Unfade to me, as she got her hair colored by Roy. Roy being the boss man, had limited availability and also a higher price tag, so I took a look at Yelp to see which other stylists I could consider. Leo got great reviews, and I was impressed by his work on his instagram, so I decided on him. I wanted to turn my (mostly) virgin Asian black hair into a rooty dusty pink cloud. Leo was fantastic - we had a half hour long consult, and he explained very thoroughly what I could or could not expect and what my options were.Leo was definitely very knowledgeable about color theory and has a great eye for colors that work together. I enjoyed how articulate he was about the technical aspect of hair coloring - it made communication a breeze since I enjoyed being equally technical. He recommended blending my hair with a purple into the dusty pink, and the end result is even better than I expected. The whole thing (about 2-3 rounds of bleaching, I can't remember, and a color melt), set me back about $400. Well worth the 6 hours he put in and the beautiful result!

This is what i imagine Disneyland to be like if it only sold food.A burger? -Go to Hard times Sundaes- ---Get Double Burger With Cheese ($9.50). MUST be a DOUBLEDon't skimp on it; unless you like eating like you're in "hard times." Trust me it's worth it.Too greasy?-Go to Mayhem and Stout---Get The dragon- Braised Pulled Pork w / Dragon Sauce (Signature Asian BBQ) & Spicy SlawThis is so good. You'll love it so much, you'll be "dragon" all your friends here so they can see what the "mayhem" is all about.Eating only white meat? -Go to Delaney Chicken---Get the Original Fried Chicken Sandwich (8$)Grow up and stop winging it. Come here. Wanna at least try to be healthy? -Go to Liquiteria- here are my favorites---Green" Monster-blueberries, strawberries, bananas, apple cider, super green food & vegan protein---Mean Green-kale, spinach, mango, bananas, golden pineapple & fresh golden pineapple juiceSo good, it's got Popeye saying "what the kale" and giving up his canned spinach for this.Stop lying to yourself.-Go to DoughEverything here is Delicious. Really "dough," I "donut" kid about dessert.

After having drinks around the block my friend mentioned we had to come here for some food she said it was a must try! Long line but moves rather quickly easy to choose menu items. We had the Adobada & Chicken tacos with everything. Lord all mighty what is going on here? It was like a flavor party in my mouth with the Adobada which is pork so good nice tasting meat great with the extras on top .. Guacamole, cheese, tomatoes etc wow amazing. Chicken tacos not far behind also delicious great tasting meat add all the extra's & even better. Located inside the Chelsea market this place is basically a small food stand. Only thing that surprised me here are their hours of operations u would think that with some many drinking choices in the area this place would be open a little later. Hard for me to believe I didn't know about this place sooner. glad I do now wow delicious tacos, quick service & cheap prices just can't go wrong.

Jiggly cakes! 'Cake' can be misleading because it's more like a fluffy bread custard. Made throughout the day, so definitely fresh. Cheese Souffle Cake is hands down the best. Has traces amount of cream-cheese kind of taste in the middle of the cake. Super moist and heavenly. I can imagine having this with coffee in the morning. Whole cake is about $13. I love their brown cardboard packaging that keeps the jiggly cake un-crushed through the busy streets of Chinatown. Great for gifts too!Matcha is a bit dry, regular is alright. These are bit cheaper $9.

This place was great! I was here with my fiancé and a few friends on a Friday. Even after several drinks and quite a lot of food the bill was extremely reasonable. The pernil tacos were probably the best I've ever had. Authentic but with their own delicious twist, tons of flavor! We kept ordering more. I can't wait to go back ASAP. The owner was very hands-on walking around making sure everything was running smoothly. Each booth had its own tv screen as well which was pretty cool. Great place all around :)

Let me start this off by saying I'm a fiercely loyal believer in the statute "New Jersey Pizza Is Superior To All Other Pizza."Little Italy makes me question my core beliefs.The chicken ricotta pizza is mind-numbing. I have fever dreams about the chicken ricotta pizza. The chicken ricotta pizza has changed the timeline of my life multiple times, especially the time my friend and I waltzed in there at 2am and gavoned several slices. If Little Italy is church, the chicken ricotta pizza is its god. If you're out of your mind and don't get the chicken ricotta pizza, the plain pizza gives all other plain pizzas a marathon run for their money. I can't personally vouch for the Grandma's pizza but my dad who's been named Top Connoisseur Of All Grandma's Pizza Pies In Northern New Jersey says Little Italy's is among the best he's had.The delivery service is alarmingly quick so you don't have to pace across your living room for too long while you wait for the pie of your dreams to knock at your door. There's an old saying about pizza that goes something along the lines of: "When pizza is THAT good, surrender your life to it." Little Italy should have this quote painted into a phantasmagoric mural on their wall.

One of my favorite places for ice cream in the city. Fun and unique flavors. The earl grey tea and honeycomb are two of my absolute favorites. PLUS, lots of vegan flavors. The west village location is small, so it's perfect in the summer time to come for a scoop and an iced coffee to-go to walk around with.

Excited for Wowfulls' first brick and mortar! Perhaps most experienced in tenure in churning out waffles day after day at events, Smorg. This iteration seals the deal. On offer are coconut, chocolate, and coffee waffles with their usual selection of ice cream to keep the lines moving smoothly.I picked the a home Sweet Home. Taste is as good as I've remembered it at Smorg waiting in the lines, however they've tweaked, perhaps even perfected the taste of their regular waffle. Crisp, puffy, and only mildly sweet, allowing for the toppings and ice cream to do the rest of the work as sweeteners.An amazing experience even if I have to wait for them to churn out waffles 4-5mins at a time each. The staff is really upbeat and I remember them all from Smorg.The decor is really sleek. Honeycomb shaped woodword adorn one wall, and a whole hearts art wall adorn the other. A very fun place to be. Of course the only tip I have to leave for you is to go early during there grand opening mode.

I've recently been on a Mexican crave, and was so happy to find a brand new Choza that just opened inside the Gotham West Market! I got the 3 tacos with chicken, carnitas pork, and steak + corn elote on the side.The tacos aren't huge - in fact they're very cute size (about 3 inches across) - but they're packed with flavor and the meats are very well braised and marinated. Like most soft shell places, the tortillas are double layered which I find a bit unnecessary (I just eat one layer), but the key is in the mix of meats, cheeses, salsas, and toppings. Perfect balance and blend of spices. What really stood out was actually the corn. Most taco joints don't have corn on the cob, and the mix of sprinkled cheese and sauce on sweet corn made it high addicting and unique!Glad to have a taco joint near my apartment!

Ube soft serve?!?! Say no more!!!!! Soft swerve is a trendy new ice cream establishment with creamy ice cream, bold flavors and quality ingredients. After sampling all of the flavors, I thought the Ube was very unique. It tasted slightly like taro but I can definitely see this being their top seller! I was told that it is made with actual chunks of ube in it. You should definitely order this with the toasted coconut. Although all of the flavors were delicious, matcha turned out to be my absolute favorite!Their Black sesame ice cream had a very strong black sesame flavor, which I love. I will no longer have to go all the way to Mitsuwa for the rich flavor. I also love their custom made chocolate cones! You can taste the chocolate but it is not a overwhelming flavor. The cone is crispy but not too sweet. Perfect to go with any flavor of ice cream that they offer! My friend ordered the strawberry shortcake! It looks very presentable and the added crunch makes this a recommended item. This reminds me of a better version of the strawberry sundaes that we used to enjoy as a kid. It has a vanilla base, dried strawberries, crushed golden Oreos and strawberry drizzle. I will be back again soon!

I tried the banana pudding and it was delightful. The pudding was tasty and they crumbled banana bread and blobs of caramel into the pudding. The chocolate chip pretzel cookies was also delicious... Very hardy. Great taste complementing the sweet with salty. Also Sarah is a doll..she's so lovely.

An amazing time and experience at The Clocktower, which went much better than anticipated. I made a reservation a month before for my boyfriend's birthday, and I was so glad I made the choice of Clocktower. The food was absolutely delicious, atmosphere was perfect for a celebratory occasion, and service was attentive and unpretentious. Five stars/bonus point that my boyfriend had a really great time and very much enjoyed his birthday dinner, and who doesn't want to try to impress their loved one on their birthday.For those of you like myself who have limited exposure with a very basic understanding of British food, this is a place to try. Or rather, it is a must try. The menu looked outstanding upon reading, but note it all comes at a bit of a steep but all worth it price. I wanted to find a place that was somewhat fancy but without the necessites of a particular dress code. You can come and be yourself. It borders between casual but high end enough for any special occasion. There are three rooms plus the main bar. We sat in the middle room, or what I call the Hollywood room, with framed pictures upon pictures of well known celebrities. The lighting is nice and dim at night for what felt like a mostly intimate but comfortably spacious space for two people to converse. Meanwhile, food and drink -- I personally thought A-mazing. Cocktails are a worthwhile try ($16), all of which were expert mixtures and a lovely complement to our meals. Give Peas A Chance was our favorite of the night, a mixture of Bombay gin, Yellow chartreuse, Salted pea cordial, Lemon juice, Fresh mint, Butterfly absinthe, and Egg white. The Los Pollos Hermanos (ode to Breaking Bad perhaps) was refreshing as well. We ordered some appetizers -- 1/2 doz bucket of oysters bits and bobs and quail frumenty scotch egg with wild mushrooms, tea, liver parfait. For main, I had the Colorado lamb (spiced pistachio crust, mixed grains, caramelized yogurt, artichokes). My bf had the Berkshire pork chop (piccalilli, black pudding, crackling, apple sauce). We loved our dishes. I tried some of his pork chop, which was succulent and tender. My lamb chop was real tender and slid easily right off the bone. I would get this again, but I would also be curious to try one of their seafood dishes, like the sole or halibut. We ended our meals with a bit of dessert, but 'a bit' might be an understatement. The Pink Lady apple tarte tatin for two, Madagascar vanilla ice cream could have fed 4 people easily. But I would go for this in a heartbeat again. It was a truly sweet end to our meal. Overall, a really pleasant experience at The Clocktower and a successful birthday dinner for the two of us. I would recommend it for a special occasion, if you are looking for this sort of experience/food. It's not over the top but fancy enough to satisfy a more celebratory occasion. Otherwise, I would definitely return for brunch or lunch and see their offerings during the day. The dinner was exceptional, and I was very happy with The Clocktower in its entirety. Hopefully your experience will speak the same on your first visit because I highly recommend.

Cafe Bari has saved my ass too many times. I work in SoHo, which is very very far from where I live. Though I tend to make coffee at home before work, I will occasionally need a second (or third or fourth) cup due to the nature of my job. Some use nicotine as a stimulant, some use caffeine. I happen to like my lungs clear and healthy, so I choose the latter. Cafe Bari, along with being comically convenient, has fabulous coffee served by fabulous folks in fabulously fast time. Can't ask for much more than that in a neighborhood coffeeshop. Convenient you ask? Cafe Bari is both subway-convenient and office-convenient, in my very specific case. You can pretty much step right off the subway platform at Canal Street and right into Cafe Bari. I also happen to work on East Broadway, which is a wasteland when it comes to to-go options. Bari is just steps from my office, so round-trip plus ordering/waiting is about five minutes. There's a Starbucks equidistant from my office but I virtually never go there now that I've discovered Bari.I'm from Philly (hold the boos, please), so I grew up being taken to La Colombe in Manayunk. My parents are big coffee-drinkers as well, so I started young. My coffee knowledge is slightly above remedial, but I can at least tell the difference between Dunkin Donuts, Starbucks, Coffee Bean (or what used to be Coffee Bean) and a more artisan place like Bari. Namely, that Bari is head and shoulders (like, Shaq's head and shoulders) any of that chain crap. When I heard that Bari served La Colombe coffee, I ran over there within the hour. Even better than I remembered, probably because I'm a working adult now and not a teenager wanting to get into coffee because my parents made it seem cool (I told you, this could've just as easily been cigarettes and thank god it's not). Bari has your standard offerings as far as cafes go. Like a lot of these hipster places, they only have two sizes. The large is about the size of a Starbucks grande, if you need a reference point. My go-to drink there is a large almond milk cappucino, which is $5. If you're worried about quantity, I suppose you should go corporate, but I promise you that quality over quantity is a particularly salient argument in this case. They've got that awesome almond milk there that's specifically made for coffee, which makes a huge difference. Add in one of those lovely steamed milk hearts atop each drink and now you've got coffee *and* a smile. Ah, yes, a smile. A *genuine* smile. Not a routine, get-out-of-my-face-so-I-can-get-to-the-next-customer-and-I'm-really-exasperated kind of smile. The staff/baristas at Cafe Bari are fabulous. Everyone's nice, everyone's friendly, and they've got awesome taste in music. Today I walked in and they were blasting Britney, then NSYNC, then Spice Girls. A magical TBT. Service is fast, product is top-notch. Though I can't speak to the abundance of pastries here, I can report that my coworker comes in with a chocolate croissant from Cafe Bari every morning and devours it. So I can directly say they're delicious, I suppose. Pretty sure everything that comes out of this small-but-mighty shop is a slam dunk.

A more suited named for this delightfully delicious confectionary shop should be hidden cakes as it is located on 18th street down the staircase in the basement of a brownstone building. These are the types of shops you love for their uniqueness. As you walk in assuming down the stair case not sure what to expect you find your self in a cramped hallway infront of the entrance door. As you open the door you are greeted by the joyous bakers in the shop who are working on their next masterpiece. When you get to the counter you see all the cookies and cupcakes that all look scrumdidlyumptous! I selected the nuetella macadamian nut half pound cookie and the snicker doodle half pound cookie. They were both just as good as they looked. The texture to flavor it was just cooked to perfection. Though I must say the Nutella cookie was better.In short:- scrumdidlyumptous half pound cookies- friendly bakers- hard to find - basement shop

2nd Ave & East 70th Street, near -around corner from Lenox Hill Post Office.Excellent service from Robyn--he was AWESOME!! My friend & I showed our appreciation with a nice $$$$ tip. Hardworking Robyn was wonderful.Now, the food: DELICIOUS!!! My friend had a blue cheese burger--he loved it. I had the special DOLLY BURGER, & it was really yummy, delicious!! It's a tie-in with the Broadway play HELLO DOLLY, starting Bette Midler. So every 100th Dolly Burger served here, has Bette serving this & she came out of the kitchen....the place went wild!!!! Nah, I'm just kidding you, but the burger was really, really, delicious!! This is in high contrast to my one other 5 Napkin Burger several years ago ON NINTH AVE IN THE West 50's. Service was non-existent literally. I was at a table, starving, & I kid you not, I counted 5 servers, standing & glancing at my table from several feet away. No one came to take my order. After about 15 minutes, I spoke with the hostess. Apparently my server was in the bathroom. Alright, it happens, but, please take my order. At end of meal, I was offered comp dessert, & a coffee, but I said politely, no thank you. I needed Pepcid AC after the burger, maybe it was the carmelized onions...probably, although tasty. After that experience I couldn't go back until last night--different location & AWESOME SERVICE BY ROBYN! We wonder if he is an owner. Yep, that's how awesome! 2nd Ave & East 70th Street--YES!!!! Delicious burgers. Neither of us had fries, but they looked great!!

Wine 30 is a restaurant I have walked passed numerous times. Never entertaining the thought of eating here. What a hidden gem in the heart of midtown. I Arrived at 5:00pm my reservations were for 5:15pm. staff was very polite sat us promptly. We had requested to sit in the back. the requests were made. the bill was over $200 for 3 people and worth it! The menu is not that big. But i like that. The attention to detail was noticeable. The food and wine tasted amazing. the ingredents were fresh and some local. the wine list was very extensive. I was very impressed by the food.Both me dad travel quite a bit and eat out frequently. My dad said the scallops with asparagus resoto was the best he has ever had. I tried some and ordered seconds. it was sooo good. they had light music playing in the background. i was the youngest person inside but the music was good. billy joel elton john cat stevent the who the rolling stones all playing good variety. There was a candle on every table to set the mood. I would definatly bring a date to Wine 30 the mood is fantastic. there was hardly anyone in the resturant when we arrived. by the time we left the place was filled. as i was leaveing other people who were eating were saying good bye to me. atmousphere was very friendly! This is a place i have walked past a bunch of times and never thought of stopping into. im glad i did. I will 100% be back to wine 30. I would walk from uptown to come here and recommend anyone who is looking for a great meal in midtown to give it a try. You will not be disappointed

I received a xmas gift for a thermal bath, aromatherapy & 60 min massage. I didn't want to go by myself so I also purchased the same package for my mom & sister for xmas. $213 each. Oh my.... one of the best massages I've ever had with the exception of the Balinese massage I got in Bali. When we arrived, we were given complimentary teas while we waited in the lobby. We were given a private changing room for the 3 of us. Then we were escorted to the massage room that overlooked the thermal baths. We had the private room to ourselves. All three of us got our massages side by side with a curtain separation. It felt very luxurious! We all agreed that the massages were superb & super relaxing. The massage therapists were excellent! The best massage in the city for sure! 5 stars!!!After the 60 min massage we then enjoyed all the thermal baths, aromatherapy steam room & the complimentary teas. Died and went to heaven! Amazing! The thermal baths were inside this underground super luxurious space. I felt like I was in a greek or roman baths from back in the days. Loved the salt water pool & jet bath. All the stress & aches in my body melted away. The entire experience was 135 min. 60 min massage + 75 min thermal baths.
