After the we finished the thermal baths, we then went to a spa shower where we were treated with Loccitane shampoo/conditioner & body wash. They had a large vanity with hair dryers & lotions. Highly recommended! Fantastic Luxurious Spa experience!!!

Polpette, we finally met. I have walked by many days, thought the menu looked amazing, and kept forgetting about it when it came to dinner. My mistake was I didn't bookmark it on Yelp. As a seasoned Yelper, I made a rookie mistake.I called to make a reservation since most of the reviews state that there tends to be a wait. They only take reservations for 4 or more that are made 24 hours in advance. They have a small bar if you do have to wait. The bartender seemed very friendly with everyone seated at the bar. The lemon martini is excellent. It's $12, which is fair for a good martini. We snagged the last table for 2, so no wait for us around 7 on a Saturday. In general I like this spot a lot because his prices are reasonable for quality food and drinks. I hope he keeps it this way because his model is definitely working. To begin they serve a delicious basket of bread with oil. The bread had a seasoning in it that I like, I think it was rosemary. We ordered the meatball sliders and a caesar salad. We noticed most people did try the meatballs since they state on their menu that it's their item they are well known for. The meatballs were tender and bursting with flavor. There was just enough sauce on the meatball so all the flavors could be enjoyed. It comes with a tasty salad. Once again, impressive that for $12 the sliders were served with a salad. The salad had a light flavorful dressing, which made me think next time I'd try another salad other than caesar. The dressing tasted homemade. My hunny really enjoyed the caesar salad too. I ordered the lobster ravioli with shrimp in a vodka sauce for $20. It typically comes with a white cream sauce, but I'm all about vodka sauce so the waiter was more than happy to swap it. The portion was excellent-I managed to eat it all! It was so delicious, I couldn't stop eating. The vodka sauce was creamy. I think it had cabbage sprinkled on top which added a nice crunch and presented well. The two shrimp on it were large and fresh. The ravioli were overflowing with lobster and cheese. I was impressed by their large selection of homemade pasta dishes. I'm a huge fan of homemade pasta. I'll be back for the squid ink linguini. The staff were all very friendly, attentive and knowledgeable. I feel that it's rare to find such good service with reasonable prices in Manhattan. I'm scared to hit save on this review because I really want our table for 2 to waiting for us! My hunny and I agreed we found our new neighborhood spot, finally!

Text 917-270-1815 for reservation. There are only 4 spots at the sushi bar (winter time)- there's heater lamps and blankets. You have 30 minutes to eat the omakase. Intimate place- located on 3rd and bowery. I did feel a bit rushed but it was because I was rushing myself. I kept thinking" oh no only 30 minutes". The service was wonderful and super friendly!!! Our group had a lot of questions and they were really nice about everything. We were a little over the 30 minutes and not once did they rush us. I think there's about 12 pieces- some of my favorites include the waygu beef, uni, salmon, yellowtail. I paid the extra 8 for a piece of toro- WORTH IT!!!! SO FRESH! I also paid 12 for a wagyu x uni hand roll- OMG BEST THIS EVER!!! MUST TRY!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! IT IS SO GOOD!WAGYU x UNI- FAVORITE!!!!!!! I could keep eating this, the texture and flavor is amazing.! words cannot describe how good this was! Two of my all time favorite things in the world. They take credit cards- they can split the bill however you want. Telling all my friends!

Not your typical hole in the wall viet place. Madame Vo is super modern with its decor and hip hop music bumpin in the background. The quality of the food is really good though and the best viet place I've found in the city so far.Came with a group of 5 so we ordered a bunch of dishes to make it family style.Banh xeo - love getting this at viet places! Egg crepe with prawns, pork, and sprouts. This one had a bit of a sweeter taste to it, but good nonetheless Madame pho w/ short rib - really good pho as in the broth and noodles were made really well. The short rib is huge and tender!Garlic noodles - really really good! All I need to saySpring rolls - classic, can't go wrongFried squid - the batter they use to fry it is amazing because the chunks of fried squid were so light and crispyGiant $35 platter - hefty amount of food, great for sharing. We probably ordered too much, but it was all so good!Not the cheapest food you'll find in NYC, but definitely worth it.

Don't judge a book by its cover is the perfect idiom for Shu Jiao Fu Zhou. I was confused upon arriving at the restaurant by whether or not I've actually found it. Think the sign outside isn't of its full name. Even as I stepped inside, I wasn't fully convinced I was at the right place. It's a frugal, no fluff hole-in-the-wall.But oh boy, can they cook! The dumplings, wheat noodles, rice balls, and fish balls are excellent and so so cheap. 5 entrees came out to be ~$15. We left a generous tip because of the price and how friendly the staff was. Turns out you can definitely eat well in New York with 5 bucks or less. The only thing I didn't really care for was the beef tripe soup. Everything else was authentic and top notch.Do I foresee a Michelin star in its future???:))))

Fantastic dining experience at The Gander on a weekday evening with a group of 5 girls. Upon arriving we were warmly greeted and then led to a round, family style table in the back. Personally I am a huge fan of round tables with a large party since it makes it easier to share dishes, which is exactly what we did.We tried a mix of appetizers and entrees, with plenty of drinks to go around. Everything from the Parmesan butter bread, to the brisket tots, to the selected cheese plate was spot on and ideal for sharing. I particularly LOVED and will come back for the warm lentil appetizer with the gooey poached egg. So not something I would normally order, but so worth every bite. Will I be back? For sure. But I think The Gander is ideally the type of spot for a large group so you can sample a variety of options given they are all so unique. It'd be cool to see an mixed appetizer sampling given the many varied (and delicious!) dishes.

Kingsbridge Social Club (or as I have decided to call it, KBS) opened recently in the Bronx. It's a great addition to the neighborhood! While the Bronx obviously has no shortage of pizzerias, KBS is so much more than that. Wood-fired specialty pizzas with toppings ranging from quail eggs to meatballs, plus sandwiches, salads, and unique appetizers. We ordered the House Pie (10) & one of their daily specials, a pie with herbed chicken, flor di latte, and sweet peppers. We also got the meatballs (9) as an appetizer. Meatballs were really delicious. The sauce they were in was also amazing, even though I believe it was a simple homemade marinara. The bread that came with it was also warm & delicious. The pies were both great as well.Now, usually, I don't condone the use of all caps (ahem, Mr. Trump, if you're reading, take note). However, what I'm about to say requires it. THEY HAVE PROSECCO ON TAP. And red wine. I'm not even sure what makes this so exciting except that I didn't know it was possible. We actually stuck with beers last night, but next time, rest assured I will be tapping that (pun intended). Beer offerings are good, I wish they would clarify a little better which are draft, can & bottle. It was a little confusing. Also, in case someone from the restaurant is reading, I'll fully forgive it for now since they're so new, but the waiter definitely needs some additional training on beer styles & appearances.The physical space is small but cute, the decor is interesting. Dave (the owner? manager?) was available and friendly, pitching in where needed & making sure everyone was happy. All in all, I really enjoyed my experience and I can't wait to go back, try some more pies, and get my Prosecco on!

Italian Tacos // Fancy Sandwich PocketsMouthwatering Roman Street Food // Quick Bites Imagine all of those savory Italian dishes, that are not so portable being more portable! That's exactly what Italian Chef Stefano Callegari did, and it's good!Came to meet a friend, and was not hungry or in the mood for a sandwich. Tried a couple bites of their braised pork with rosemary and fennel pollen, and the rice-ball of the day. Both were delicious! No doubt I will be back.The pork was hearty, the flavor was rich. The bread was tender with just the right amount of crisp, it was hollowed out not too thick. So if you are shy about the carbs it's good, this feels like a warm crust with the center dug out. The savory flavors inside will remind you of a home cooked meal. I can see why this was such a hit in Rome.The price seems reasonable for a snack, considering the ingredients. However, if you are hungry you may end up buying a couple of sandwiches. Think... pizza slice, or an Italian tacos.The sitting area is relatively small. You can push tables together if you are a large group. However, as this is a quick bites type of place it is doubtful you will have a large group in tow. If you're walking through the neighborhood definitely stop by!The Scene: Casual, Quickbites, HeartyDestination Rating: 6Date Rating: 2Hob Nob Potential: 1Strong Suggestion: Come here if you're hungry and in a hurry.

My favorite spot for gelato! Not only is the presentation beautiful, Amorino's gelato is creamy and luscious. Absolutely delicious. There are so many flavors to choose from and you get to pick as many flavors as you want, just have to pick the size - small, medium, or large. Each flavor becomes a petal and forms gorgeously into a flower shape - looks like a rose. You can also top it with a macaroon like we did :pI believe Amorino's originally from France. I remember when the first store in NYC opened near NYU on University Pl. years back and that was a big deal. Now there's a Amorino on UWS as well as the Theater District and here in Chelsea! I was quite excited when I found this location last weekend.

THIS PLACE IS AWESOME!! Best bang for your buck near times square, in my opinion. How it works is, you pick one base (pita, hummus bowl, salad, rice) and then a protein. The rest is an unlimited one-time toppings bar. Sort of like a chipotle for mediterranean food but you put the toppings on yourself!Food: yummy and fresh! I loved that they had sooooo many options and all vegetarian. They have beets, chickpeas, radish, cabbage, and plenty of sauces to choose from. This place a veggie haven! Also, serving size is big enough to eat for two meals. Cost: Decent. There are a few toppings that you can choose to add on to your base that are extra, but I'd say skip that and just bulk up on the free toppings ;D It costs about $8-12 depending on what base and protein you decide to get. Service: Very friendly staff! It was my first time trying it and I was confused as to how things work and the staff was very accommodating and friendly to explain. They also made me fresh chicken shawarma since the other was sitting out for a while. Will be back? It's in a prime location (although that can cause a bit of a hold up during busy lunch hours), prices are decent, staff is friendly....I'll definitely be back.

Popped in here totally out of the blue and boy were we glad to have found this hidden gem. The cocktails were unique and strong - but beware of the Hot Buttered Rum, this little guy is buttery-rich AF it might clog your arteries if you haven't been working out. I was secretly glad it was my bf who ordered it and not me because I wouldn't have been able to finish it. I also tried the Flawless Victory and Midnight Society and had a sip of bf's Untold Story - all excellent. Bartender was super friendly as well. Ambience was dark and intimate, good for a date spot. We didn't order any food but it sure smelled delicious whatever it was. Will definitely return if I'm ever in the area again and looking for a good cocktail.

I recently heard word about this modern Israeli spot in EV and decided to dine here as my latest 'treat yoself' meal. Not sure about you, but I find most of the spots I have saved up to visit are all 'new' American / Italian cuisine whereas Mediterranean/Israeli spots are usually on the casual side, so found this mid-price and classy spot as a great change of pace. Timna is located just slightly below ground and has a quaint but polished atmosphere and an amazing staff who is eager to suggest their favorite dishes. The bartender I interacted with was straight from Israel, and the only one in his family in America and suggested a few amazing Israeli wines for me to try and they were excellent, who knew Israel has the good juice?I ordered the cauliflower dish as a starter along with the "must order" bread that comes in a clay pot. While I enjoyed the bread, the flavors in the cauliflower dish and accompanying sauce were outstanding, vegetarian or not. For my main I went with the roasted carrots on farro, again accompanied with two masterfully paired sauces.While most people (me included) would expect some upscale hummus, falafel, hell maybe even a kick-ass tabbouleh from this place, Timna goes above and beyond these basic dishes to create new, creative and flavorful dishes.

I've lived in this city for close to 3 years but with the exception of my local bodega, I have yet to become a regular at any one particular spot. I've gone to great bars, restaurants, and cafes but because I love trying somewhere new, I'll almost always opt for an unfamiliar place over a familiar one. Chochin is one of the few places that I will work very hard to be a regular at. At first, I was quite surprised to find a homey hole in the wall serving up Japanese home-style cooking in the middle of Yorkville, given that most of the Japanese places around here are generic sushi takeout spots. Well, East Village's loss is my gain because as soon as we stepped outside after our meal, we made plans to come back the following weekend to try more dishes. When we first came in at around 6, right when it opened, I had a brief moment of panic that this place wouldn't survive the lack of foot traffic around this Second Avenue-adjacent neck of the woods. Then the place filled up to capacity within minutes. So definitely come here right when it opens, especially if your group is more than 2 people. The menu is in English but everything else may as well have been imported from Japan. There's one guy in the very back making all the food. The waitress manning the former sushi counter was very sweet and explained each dish as she brought it out but she didn't know things like BYOB or leaving a party's name down while they wait. Which is completely fine because the home-cooked food more than makes up for it. Lately, I've been fiending hard for Japanese-style comfort dishes and Chochin ("lantern") handily delivers. This is what we ordered (ranked in order of how much I loved it):(1) Spicy tuna don. My stars. This was as far away from the gunky, spicy mayo-slathered mess that other places tend to serve. If there was any mayo (which I absolutely loathe) in this dish, I could barely taste it. The rice was cooked to perfection: buttery soft with a hint of vinegar. (2) Whole tomato soup. Perfect for a freezing winter night. It comes as a tomato sitting in a lake of cheese. Inside the tomato is the softest-boiled egg you ever did see. It sounds like a children's tale but it's really the best thing I've eaten all week. (3) The miso soup that came as a side to my spicy tuna rice bowl. This one tasted like it was brewed from scratch and didn't have that immediate umami bomb that other places' soup delivers but still tasted wonderfully hearty. (4) The hamburger appetizer. It tasted more like meatloaf than your usual burger patty. (5) Daikon salad. Eat some veggies, yo. (6) Fried oysters. I don't really like oysters in general and I'm trying to wean myself off fried stuff in time for the summer months so this was doomed from the get-go in my book but my boyfriend liked it. CASH ONLY. Place is tight, so tight that if you come here with even the barest hint of a cold, you'll drive away your neighbors in disgust (i.e., don't come here when you're sick and nursing a tub of Robitussin!). I'll be back in a few days!

Man, oh man, it's probably been a good 2 weeks or so since I ate at Post, yet here I am still dreaming about their Avocado Biscuit with Chicken Sausage. Seriously, guys, this place has without a doubt one of the best damn biscuits I've ever eaten in my entire life and let me tell ya, my carb-loving ass has eaten a lotttt of biscuits over the years. It's moist (giggity), thick (giggity giggity), ridiculously flavorful and I want at least a half dozen of them delivered to me right now. The chicken sausage I added on was also such a great idea because it was also so flavorful and it just made my biscuit *that* much better and meatier. This little gem just opened up a few weeks ago, so there is currently only bar seating, but don't let that deter you. In fact, I would actually highly recommend high-tailing your asses there ASAP so you can get one or two or ten of those biscuits before this place really blows up and the lines become insane. Or, actually, wait, maybe don't, so I can have all of that biscuit goodness to myself. Yeah, let's go with that. Find your own dang biscuit place, guys :)

I literally wanted to eat everything here. So many choices and great prices! My friend and I got noodles and crab XLB (soup dumplings) and the total was $26! Each of our noodles came with a side of broth which was clean and perfect to wash down the noodles and their XLB were nice too - thin wrapper with just the right amount of broth inside.Service was quick and attentive and I loved that the food wasn't super oily. Their congee looked great - it's a perfect place to get a bunch a dishes and share family style. Will be back for sure!

So I think it is safe to say Thai Villa has given some of my favorite Thai spots in NYC a run for their money. They are reasonably priced, the decor is beautiful, and the food is amazing. I have been eyeing this bookmark I have saved forever mostly due to that beautiful "New & Hot" tag. First time I dined with them was for pick up for lunch since I work close by. Their lunch prices range in the 10-15 dollar range which I think is reasonable due to the excellent portion sizes it comes with two sides as well. The second time I decided to dine with them it was for lunch but I did nab a seat at the bar for lunch with a friend. She is a Yelp Eliter and was blown away by the decor once arriving and then the food wowed her as well. Once getting back to the office we were immediately planning our next lunch at this spot. The bartender definitely added to the experience by being personable.In terms of the food, my favorite is the Pad Kra Prow with chicken. They will ask if you want it spicy and I don't recommend getting "spicy" if you cannot deal with heat, and I would recommend stating you would like it "mild". This is a great place for a date, large parties, or if you happen to be in the Flatiron/Chelsea area and want great quality Thai.I normally post pictures of food when I go out to dine but EACH TIME I GO I JUST DIVE INTO MY FOOD. Bookmark this place and make sure you go.

My favorite Japanese bakery & quick lunch spot in TriBeCa. They make their pastries and sandwiches fresh each day without any preservatives. The bake goods are so fresh and warm if you come early in the morning. They have tables and chairs if you want to dine in. Green Tea (Matcha) Crepe - A must try if you are visiting; it is soft and creamy with red bean filling. Matcha Latte - tastes a bit like the matcha latte from Starbucks but a little less sweet. The price for the medium and the large size is the same.Tuna Tataki Salad - I really like this salad. It is seared ahi tuna with some snow peas, shredded carrots, a few blueberries, banana peppers, and a piece or two of broccoli in the mixed greens with wasabi vinaigrette dressing on the side.Spicy Tuna Bread - A savoy pastry. It is crispy on the outside and warm on the inside. The tuna used for this pastry is cooked.Matcha Croissant - I liked it. It has creamy matcha filling in the center.Spicy Salmon Avocado Sandwich with Cucumber - This is really good.Smoked Salmon Sandwich with Lettuce, Cream Cheese, Cucumber & Red Onion - This is also really good. Kind of reminded me of smoked salmon bagel. Tuna Avocado Sandwich with Lettuce - This is tasty.Egg Salad Sandwich with Tomatoes - Creamy and delicious Mochi an Pan - Personally I don't like this one because I found it heavy. Matcha Roll Cake - Green tea flavored cake with red bean filling. The green part is kind of dry and the red bean filling have an orange zest flavor. Sweet Cheese Puff - I like it. The cheese is light and a bit sweet.They accept credit cards except for American Express.

Two words: Grandpa Pizza. So good. We ordered from Addeo's twice and both times we got that pizza. It's a fresh, thin crust Sicilian pie topped with actual tomatoes and basil. I want to say that there's 8 slices in all. We definitely had leftovers the next day. It's a hefty $23 but it's worth it for the quality.We've only had experience with this business via delivery but have not been disappointed. I'm very happy with their quality, delivery time and courtesy of the drivers and people who've taken our orders over the phone.

Memories from the Corner of my Mind.....Rainy Day Memories... My morning snack was a piece of NY Style Cheesecake from Two Little Red Hens. I can't tell you how happy I am that this great little bakery has survived the 2nd Avenue Subway construction! I had no problem at 10-10:15 AM getting a seat so I could enjoy my cheesecake. I am a Cheesecake Factory Fanatic but I have to say this is the best NY Cheesecake in the city! I enjoyed looking at all the goodies before I made my decision. There are scones, cookies, cupcakes, pies, and cherry cheesecake too. The service was very fast and pleasant employees. The place is clean and well stocked with napkins and anything else you need to enjoy your desert. If it wasn't for my health I'd be here every day for a different treat. I do plan to return soon for the Peanut Butter Cupcake. They were huge! You definitely owe it to yourself to stop by for a treat when you're in the neighborhood!

Tenth Avenue in Hell's Kitchen has long been a "no man's land" when it comes to the restaurant scene. The only mainstays over the last several years have been Pio Pio, 44 & X, and 44 1/2. A few years ago, along came farm-to-table The Marshal, bringing with it a new ambiance and cuisine to the area. It is the success of The Marshal that allowed the introduction of Dianne & Elisabeth by the same owner just down the block, a quaint wine bar that also includes fresh produce and eclectic mains and various varietals of wine you can't get just anywhere. Having visited Dianne & Elisabeth a few times now, I can say the service, the food and drink and the ambiance is consistently exceptional. My favorite wine on the menu, which I recommend very highly, is the Counoise, a red varietal that is medium-bodied and not too sweet, yet not bitter. And it is a perfect, reasonably-priced wine. In fact, ...it's the only wine I choose to order here. On to the menu: Spicy Marinated Pineapple ($5) - Huge pieces of pineapple seasoned nicely Langostino Poppers ($12-small, $18-large) - beer battered langostinos, lemon garlic thyme aioli. So far, this is the best plate I've tried on the menu - each "popper" is verrry meaty, and only lightly battered. Beet, Apple, & Fennel salad ($12-small, $18-large), with blue cheese, caraway, and a red wine honey vinaigrette. This was the perfect balance of the sweetness of the apple with the bitterness of the beets, presented beautifully. Croquettes ($12-small, $18-large) - pork lardon swiss cheese, smoked paprika cream. I'm generally not a fan of dishes on the creamier and cheesier side (only a personal preference), but these are definitely worthwhile if you are. So far, I've only been for wine and apps, but the rest of the menu looks awesome. Hopefully I'll get the opportunity to go back again soon and try more. When it comes to ambiance and service, I must say George the bartender, and Emilio the service have been nothing but kind and professional. Plus, sitting at the bar having a glass of wine - you never know who you'll meet in the neighborhood. It's one of those very inviting, cozy, and warm atmospheres that is great addition to the neighborhood - plus it's a great date spot, too (although, for now, it's only open for dinner) .

Wonderful night at Folwer and Wells, a new restaurant by celerity chef Tom Colicchio. Located in the retro and classic Beckman hotel, it has fantastic interior--chandeliers, colorful glass windows, high ceiling and huge wall windows facing the street. Staff is friendly and helpful at recommending drinks to pair with our dishes.We ordered hamachi with sea urchin, roasted Jerusalem artichokes, black bass, and baked Alaska. Everything was excellent. The sauce in hamachi and sea urchin is slightly sour and nutty which matches the fat hamachi and nutty sea urchin perfectly well. Black bass: one of my freshest and most delicious seafood dish of the year. Highly recommend. Jerusalem artichokes: (the root of artichokes, very starchy like potatoes) the artichokes are nicely baked and flavored--slightly fruity sweet taste, yet has more details as you chew along. A hint of fiber-ish texture and veggie/fruity ish flavor. Excellent sauce.Baked Alaska: surprise ice cream hidden inside! Yummy as how pretty it is!Highly recommend. Tasting menu also available at 135pp.

I ate alot of spaghetti in college.I think the only things I could cook were mashed potatoes, scrambled eggs, boil spaghetti and make cereal.  It was a bachelor nightmare.Maybe that's why my mind went a little blank at my plate of wonderful spaghetti at spaghetti incident. The room was handsome. Dimly lit, with a brick wall, mirrors with cute planters underneath. It felt like a little Italian home, miles away from the lower East side poser scene.An adroit young man, with a new bass voice, who couldn't have been 20 had the grace and poise of the best waiter I ever had.  He checked on me just enough, was warm with enough distance, and quickly recommended his favorite dishes with descriptions, and without hesitation. The kitchen is open, and I could smell my spaghetti with salsciccia cooking with garlic, pork and white wine. The pasta is house made and al dente, a treasure, confirmed by the happy Italians dining next to me.Glasses for montepulciano were a breezy and generous $7.  I opted for a second glass over the panna cotta, a not so easy decision, but the place is cash only, so I wanted to have enough to leave a generous tip.This cozy bistro is a little gem if you love spaghetti, and if you don't, you should come for the small plates and desserts and drink wine, which I'll do in the very near future. Atmosphere - cozy and wonderfulFood - clean, fresh, simple and homemade.

As a skeptic of any cha siu place that isn't a hole in the wall, I was blown away by the deliciousness & quality of the food here, in addition to the atmosphere, cleanliness and friendliness of the waiters. Crispy roast duck in the mantou sandwich was super flavorful, and I highly recommend it. I was expecting a small mantou with a little bit of duck for a pricey $8 but boy I was wrong! Huge mantou with a bit of that duck fat grease, and enough pieces of duck that you'd see on an entree. Prepare for this to be messy to eat, naturally. Just pick up the duck pieces that fall out with your fork and add some of their heavenly chili sauce to it. The five spice short rib plate with egg noodles was surprisingly tasty as well. Short rib is fall off the bone, except they make it even easier and take out the bones already, topped with a bunch of garlicky, saucy garnishes including braised daikon. It was super delicious. My only feedback is that the egg noodles were a tad soggy and a tiny bit bland (though that might have been bc I didn't mix some parts of it well, as everything else was bursting with flavor), but this was entirely made up for when sprinkling some of their garlic chili flakes and oil. Admittedly an entire mantou sandwich and egg noodles plate was too much for one person, but I'm glad I tried both and was pleasantly surprised at the big portion sizes! I'll be back again for that crispy roast duck.

TL:DR for those who are confused about MSB's family-style option and whether you should come with a large group (or whether it's worth it to come with a small dining party) - YES, the food is delicious. But your dining experience will be quite different. I came here for dinner with a friend, and we ordered the fried duck dumplings, steamed pork buns (not on the menu), fried brussels sprouts, and seared pork ribs.The steamed pork buns were excellent. The buns were pillowy soft but just firm enough to hold up to tender braised pork. And boy, was the kitchen generous with the pork! The accompanying pickled cucumbers provided a nice acidity and textural contrast. This was served with ssam sauce, which tasted like a lighter gochujang sauce (Korean chili paste). Honestly, the pork buns are pretty much perfect as is - I think adding the ssam sauce is a disservice. The fried brussels sprouts were yummmmmy. The fish sauce was not overpowering as it was balanced by an herb mixture that made it more of an assertive vinaigrette to coat the perfectly fried brussels sprouts. The duck in the duck dumplings was just ok. I couldn't really discern the taste of the duck itself, but I thought the crispy wanton (with a sea salt crust?) and the mint sauce were excellent. The seared pork ribs were succulent. They were marinated in gochu sauce and then seared. Somehow, I thought the glaze on top was more teriyaki then gochu, but I loved the smokey, umami flavor as well as the toasted sesame seeds and the spice from the scallions. It was quite tender and fell off the bone that we could eat the ribs with silverware.HOWEVER, I think this dish is improperly labeled under "ssam". Ssam means lettuce wrap in Korean. So I thought the ribs would be accompanied by lettuce or some kind of veggies, but the dish was just five giant pieces of ribs. Our waitress was gracious enough to bring over some lettuce when I asked, but I don't think it makes sense for the main entree to be just hunks of meat without any veggies. Regardless, I saw that the grilled porgy comes with tortillas for you to make fish tacos with at the table so I think the label is appropriate depending on what you order. But don't expect all of the "ssam" courses to come out in the lettuce wrap style like you would for the family-style option. We finished the meal with the creme brulee, which is highly recommended. The custard is matcha, infused with thai basil. The perfume of that and the brulee on top are HEAVENLY. My God, I can have this all to myself and I would still want more. I can't wait to come back to try their seafood donabe, as the table next to me ordered it and it looked delectable with so much seafood. I'd order all of the above dishes again in a heartbeat except for the duck dumplings!

Nothing man produces, in my opinion, could ever surpass the beauty found in nature. But in some instances, man's genius comes close. Coming on the heels of the spectacular orchid exhibit here is another stunner, the Dale Chihuly Exhibit. This artist has managed, with hand blown, colored glass, to mold creations that evoke images of flamingoes, stars, sea anemones and other fantastical forms. Some are huge impressive structures as tall as trees, with squiggly, swirly extensions that fascinate and capture the eye. Others resemble ordinary objects, like balls, only dazzling in their color combinations. All are intriguing. This is a stellar exhibit that I recommend seeing in various lights, on a cloudy day, during a sunny day, and during extended evening hours when they are lit up. Even if you see it only once, the exhibit will impress. And of course the gardens themselves are always magnificent any time.Note: The Dale Chihuly Exhibit is on until October. If you go now, you get the lovely cherry and lilac trees in bloom to enjoy while you stroll through the rest of the park.Extra treat at the gardens: Birders should know that there is a pair of nesting Great Horned Owls at the gardens now. You won't be able to photograph them without a tripod and a long, long telephoto. Bring your binoculars unless you care to stare at the façade of a building to see...nothing.

"Let's Visit the sky"So I had the chance go take a bunch of my co-workers to experience happy hour at this place you start of walking in the dim lit hallway leading to a pleasant elevator temple guard dude. The security guard was very pleasant and answer questions on how to get to the roof level."Elevator city"Can I said just say this... literally in the elevator... "SKYLAR" is its own floor! its a huge button you just push and the elevator zooms up. as your waiting for the music choice, they have in the elevator is actually legit. I almost felt like I was at a cookout with all the old school music, pure enjoyment I tell you!"View like whoa"Upon entering, they had a complimentary coat check, a pool room (if you made reservations) and a wonderful spacious bar. the drinks are certain prices, so come prepare to spend more than usual. The food menu was actually legit I feeling full, they have really fancy things here."Overall"The food was epic, the experience was really good, the views were super amazing I would go back there with my camera for sure!

Photorealism:'A genre of art...encompassing extremely realistic painting, drawing and other graphic media...in which the artwork is based entirely on a photograph.'After reading fellow Yelper Helen's review I couldn't resist. I took a mental note that I had to put this on my list of things to do. After a very early morning great experience at The Metropolitan Museum of Art, I made my way over to the Bernarducci Meisel Gallery. I entered the gallery and stood and pondered in front of many of the arts on display, mesmerized and amazed by the artistry. Upon first glance, your eyes immediately see a photograph and then as you step closer the realization dawns on you that they are actually either a painting or drawing...unbelievable. For a long moment, I stood and imagined myself seated with a glass of champagne, continuing to listen to the mellow smooth jazz playing in the background and staring at these pieces. That's how much I wanted to stay and immerse myself further. A thank you goes to Kimberly who kindly answered all of my many questions and also allowing me to catch a glimpse of their resident puppy while venturing farther throughout the gallery. The arts of Raphaella Spence and Emily Copeland, who I have now deemed among my favorites are on display with Ester Curini and others. This current exhibit will end April 1st, 2017 and is a must see for those who can appreciate the arts. Current Exhibit pricing: $3K and upUpcoming Exhibit: Size Doesn't Matter; 50 plus artists to participate April 6th - 29th, 2017Reception: 5:00pm - 7:00pmGallery located on 3rd floor

Came here on a breezy abnormally warm Monday evening with a girl friend and I loved every minute of my dinner at Boucherie!I had noticed Boucherie a month or so earlier while walking through the area. I loved their open seating and bistro vibe of the joint and made a mental note to swing by on a warm night. We were greeted warmly by our servers, Jose and Niko - and ordered a bunch of things to try out. We had:Steak Tartare (small portion): omg, so good! And such a healthy size too. We finished it but totally doable to share among a group of 3-4! They use the ends of their tenderloin steaks so this is top notch quality meat!French Onion Soup: a last minute add on but man - such a good call. Delicious, just the right amount of salt, and the perf melty cheese. Duck Confit: the quintessential French dish so I just had to try it. The smell of the truffle potatoes were intoxicating. The greens were a little overly salted in some areas but I just made sure to mix well before eating. Hefty portion of duck as well! Ordered medium but I may go even below that next time as it was slightly tough. Lamb Shank: huuuuumongous portion. Couscous was perfectly cooked and for someone who isn't a fan of gamey meats, I thought it was quite good!We also had to order a side of fries after seeing the table next to us indulge in some. Best. Decision. Ever. I'd go back just for the fries (and some of that Tartare). We also ordered two Old Fashions which were okay - was expecting something more from their drinks. Perhaps I'd try some of the wines next time. And there will definitely be a next time. Between the great food, superb ambiance, amazing service (and open kitchen to boot!), I am a super fan. Felt like I was transported back to Par-ee! ;)

I love Augustine! Came here with my family on an early Sunday evening to celebrate my Mom's birthday, and as one might expect at Keith McNally restaurant during opening week, the restaurant was packed. Moody lighting, antiquey accents, and that overall glamorous brasserie feel make this one beautiful restaurant. I think it's also great to have such a great name down in the financial district/Seaport area which is constantly and thankfully getting upgraded in terms of food options. The service was warm, professional and honestly... there. The restaurant was well staffed, considering it's not even a huge space (much smaller than Balthazar).  We had: - Delicious amuse bouche of puffs with caviar- a delicious bread basket (not joking) - with seasoned olive oil, and butter - mixture of white and wheat bread- the Waldorf salad, classic- The foie gras - The avocado/crab saladAll the salads were super fresh. As far the mains, we all tried different things. From the burger, to the leg of lamb, to the halibut, special pork chop, and uni pasta. I had one bite of this and it was satisfying - breadcrumb, uni, crab... very good flavor and texture. The dishes was very classic, simple and just tasty.I myself was torn between the duck l'orange, which I wish I had gotten now and the steak frite. I got the latter. The steak frite is so so delicious - au poivre style with serious peppercorns and a sweet ish sauce. The frites, as they are at all of their restaurants, are delicous. I didn't try my hubby's lamb since he was across the table but he said it was really well done and enjoyed the beans. In the end, we got two desserts - the seasonal apple tartin (delicious) and a Napolean type of dessert. Both were so fresh, and tasty. I really thought the food here again was spot-on, re: flavor and fresh ingredients. It's not the most experimental but the food is good and the space is beautiful so definitely worth visitng for dinner or drinks.

I would love to get myself grounded here. The entire time I was reading a book in a fresh green backyard. Free wifi. Super nice barista. Tea pots and coffee cups. A tall bookshelf. One red velvet sofa. Extra metal seats. Leafy plants with quirky Chinese statues. Wall art for sales. This coffee shop is almost like a West Village thrift shop - most items are unrelated, but when assembled together, they easily become part of the architecture. Writers and designers work better in an unorganized environment anyway. Your eyes shouldn't be bored in here. The overall color is green, but like a game of hidden objects, the closer you look, the more visual toys you find.

Outstanding experience Saturday night at Jimmy's NYC. This is a must for anyone who was a fan of the Bronx original, or other Jimmy Rodriguez establishments. If you love Don Coqui, Sofrito, Sazon, or the Bronx institution, you will love Jimmy's NYC.First things first: come DRESSED TO IMPRESS and nothing less. I was wearing jeans and Uggs and knew immediately I'd made the wrong choice. Women are wearing heels and dresses. Men are wearing jackets. Wear the flyest thing you've got. You'll feel a lot more confident.Onto the food, which is INCREDIBLE. Pete and I loveeeee Puerto Rican food and big fans of all JR's restaurants. Jimmy's NYC has all the delicious specialities - carne frita, the obligatory fried calamari, chicharonnes, peril, and my favorite - mofongo. The service was excellent. Our waiter was professional, as were the other servers. The cocktails are priced commensurate with the area. I would come here just for the cocktails and the loungey, classy, welcoming atmosphere. I look forward to returning soon and often.Pro Tips: - happy hour M-F until 8pm.- best nights are Friday and Saturday. Come ready to party!

Worth the wait and definitely not just a gimmick of standing while you eat. One of the best (and cheapest) steaks I've had. I was surprised to see such a long line but it moved very quickly - there was about 20-30 people in front of me, but I was able to get "seated" in an hour. The smell when you walk in is heavenly. The system works like a well-oiled machine - you would think that a bunch of diners standing around would make things chaotic, but the staff (who are some of the friendliest I've encountered in NYC) swiftly took our drink and side orders before directing us to the "Cut to Order" station to pick out our steaks. TIP - if dining for just two, I highly recommend asking for the total grams of steak (i.e. 600g) and then having it cut in half - that way, you get a thicker cut of steak which will be much juicier and tastier vs. asking for two separate 300g cuts. There are plenty of helpful signs and staff around to help out if you're unsure of which type (ribeye, filet or sirloin) or weight to get (there are also ounce conversions). The 300g was plenty for me, and I went with the ribeye. And yes, you should get rare or - at worst - medium rare. Anything further is just downright disrespectful.The food came out pretty quickly, about 10 minutes, on sizzling plates. It was DIVINE. The steaks come with corn topping but you can replace with a variety of other veggies or add extras for $1 each. I highly recommend the Ikinari sauce on your steak - it doesn't take away from the flavor but rather enhances it. The quality and taste of the meat was so good, and an amazing value considering the price. DO NOT PASS ON THE GARLIC RICE!!! One of the most delicious side dishes ever - mixed with more corn, crispy garlic, bits of steak, and pepper. A divine combination. The standing while eating concept was a great experience. I didn't mind it at all - it was fun, casual, and made people eat a "power dinner" which must have contributed to the line moving quickly. A huge kudos again to the amazing staff who were so attentive - even though Ikinari is marked as a non-tipping establishment. I will DEFINITELY be back!!

One of the best pasta establishments I have eaten at. This place was packed out when I came here. If you expect to eat something else beside pasta, this is not the place for you. They only serve pasta. Not only the food taste great, the price for the dishes is incredibly cheap! I spent less than $15 for a meal and drink. I don't think you can ever find a place this cheap in the area! Will definitely be coming back to this spot.If you're looking for a recommendation, I got the sausage & broccoli rabe. I don't remember what kind of pasta I got as these names are all foreign to me. I'm not Italian!

If I ever swear anything to you all, it's this: if I could give every star I've ever given to just one solitary location there is no doubt in my sugar rushed head that this would be the one. I walked in looking line a post apocalyptic scavenger, however the owner (son) / employee / server / messiah to all my yummy dreams greeted me with a fist bump and amped me up to get ready for a "one way trip to Flavortown".He was helping a couple people ahead of me so I went browsing about the racks and saw several things I wanted to dive right in and start licking, but I remarkably abstained from doing so. When it became my turn, I asked what they had that was vegan, and seeing as how it was hot outside I opted for a hot fudge covered ice cream sundae and omg y'all seriously it's like the best thing in the world. Like, THE WHOLE WORLD. If ever there were a hidden treasure trove of everything you could ever want, it would be packed in this classic style candy and sweets shop. The only thing sweeter than what's on the shelves is the owner and staff who apparently fist bump random strangers even when they look homeless.I love everything about this place, and I know you will, too.

I came here on a first date and boy was it the best freaking first date EVER!!!!!Now while the food was impressive, our table happened to be next to the ONE AND ONLY, BONO himself! So that kind of made our night. What date? Ha!We shared whiskey shots, champagne and wine for almost 4 hours. Just another Thursday night in NYC.epic night. so epic.Now to the food. It's pretty incredible! The burger is definitely one of the best I've had considering how "simple" it really is. I had it medium. But to be honest, the cheese did over empower the burger sometimes. Nonetheless, still love the burger. But what do I love more than the burger? THE SHOESTRING FRIES!!!!!! I would come here for drunk fries any night if that was an option. I could eat a whole side of that by myself. And a side of that Dijon mustard that they have, two sides please.We also had a few of their apps. Deviled eggs are fabulous. Also had the Chicken liver toast and Roll mops. The toast was definitely a heavier appetizer (for me) but I really liked it considering I hadn't had that before. The roll mops were new to me too.All in all, great first visit to spotted pig. Fabulous food, great company, amazingly attentive staff!Can't wait to come back!

I arrived to Annisa with Anita Lo (my gf) only to find that Anita Lo (the chef) was not there that night. Though it was the sous chef Katie who would be running the kitchen, the concepts are developed by Anita Lo just like the concept for a dinner date tonight was developed by Anita Lo.Anita Lo was great and the other Anita Lo was well behaved. We ordered the pakora fried oysters which spiciness Anita Lo informed me could be considered slow. Anita Lo prepared a masterful blend of textures on the plate. The focus of the dish was the oyster itself: crispy on the outside and so unbelievably soft on the inside. It sat upon a cucumber pedestal. The pickled fennels also sat on the dish with fennel oil anointed to the side. Right across the middle of the plate was a brush of yogurt which looked like the carefully crafted stroke of an oil painting.For the entree, Anita Lo ordered the Sea Bass by Anita Lo while I ordered the Duck by Anita Lo. Hers was perfectly seared sitting atop a piece of broccoli which alluded to Asian flavors. The other sea bass was part of the fatty belly which rested on a bed of apples. A perfect fusion of Asian and French.Similarly not only was my duck amazing, it also came with a small serving of a foie gras and some Japanese egg custard that was slightly acidic.We didn't order any dessert, but Anita Lo's restaurant provided us with some pineapple popsicles, candied ginger, and a mint chocolate.Anita Lo's ideas were awesome and Anita Lo's concepts were exquisite.

SO MUCH YES. I'm initially skeptical of places that take another cuisine into the taco realm - something usually gets lost in the translation. But at Taco Mahal, everything is just amazing.Here is what you need to know:1. Roti tacos are smaller than naan. I enjoy both so just gauge how hungry you are.2. You can sub normal naan with GARLIC naan. Do it.3. All the protein options are awesome. You cannot go wrong.4. The place is small. For winter, expect to be cramped in there. For spring and summer, getting food to go is probably the best option. 5. Service is awesome. The staff are patient and ready to walk you to find the best delicious meal options.This is definitely worth checking out - it doesn't matter if you're a local grabbing a quick bite in West Village or a tourist needed a quick stop. Taco Mahal makes a memorable meal.

Note that there are TWO locations of &Hair Lounge - make sure you go to the right one! Overall ambience is cozy, hip, but chic at the same time. Most, if not all, the employees here are Chinese. The clientele seemed to be mostly Asian as well. The receptionists are not the most bubbly of people, but they get you where you need to go quickly. If you have to wait, there's plenty of seating in the front.The hairwashing station was actually comfortable, which I can't say for a lot of places. It usually hurts my neck like hell, but this one was extra comfortable. The guy that washed my hair gave me a great scalp massage, too.This review is for KELVIN - he's a lesser known barber here because he's only been there two whole months, but he deserves some loving too! My thin, Asian, hair can be a struggle sometimes, but he cut it to perfection. He even told me my last barber gave me an incredibly uneven haircut... good thing that person is nowhere near New York City. He was friendly, offered plenty of suggestions, and listened to my concerns with having flat, boring hair and offered ways to fix it. I wanted my hair quite shorter than it currently was at the time, but not too short. Some places have always cut my hair too short, but he understood what I wanted and gave me exactly the length I was thinking of. He spent over an hour on my cut and almost 30 minutes on the styling itself. That's a lot of love to give to a single customer! Very much satisfied with my haircut as it is a very flattering length with layers that complement my face.He gave me blow out and the day after, I washed my hair and inspected it while straight, which is usually how I wear my hair since I'm so lazy to do anything to it and I must say, I love it! Looks and feels great. As reference, I cut at least 3 inches off my lengthI also looked around and saw a lot of people with nicely balayaged/ombre'd hair. I might have to come back to get my hair colored after it fully grows out.Cut was $60 base with shampoo and (a lot) of styling. Overall time spent in salon was about 1.5 hours. Will definitely be back.

I love love love this place! When Dinosaur visited LA, he wasn't a fan of the city, but he was a BIG FAN of KazuNori. KazuNori is the sister restaurant of Sugarfish (located on 20th street). KazuNori specializes in handrolls.The interior is modern and chic. Good ambiance for casual date nights or even a quick lunch break by yourself. Self-seated establishment - grab a menu and an open seat. Quick turnover, so don't be discouraged by the line. The concept is simple - fish on rice, wrapped in crispy nori. What sets KazuNori apart from other restaurants is their Nori. The nori is unreal and I wish I knew the secret from keeping them so dry and crispy. He got the 6 roll combo (salmon, lobster, crab, bay scallop, yellow tail, toro), 5 roll combo for me. Super filling, don't underestimate these hand rolls. My fav are the bay scallop and crab! Service is on point! They make the hand rolls in front of you and place them on your 'serving paper' **TIP: eat them as soon as they are made, before the nori gets soggy!** Can't get enough of these simple, but amazing hand rolls.Welcome to NYC, KazuNori!

FINALLY! I've been working in the area for over 7 years now and I've always said we needed a place like this! I'm so excited Burger Heights is expanding. I've been to their first location further uptown but they are not getting the proper exposure up there. This location is walking distance from New York Presbyterian/Columbia Med Center. I went during lunchtime and noticed they have a growing clientele. There was a line and most tables were occupied. They have specialty burgers at decent prices. I spent around $11 for a burger and sweet potatoes fries. The place resembles Shake Shack which is not a bad thing. They serve wine and beer as well. I can't wait to return ASAP. Thumbs way up! :)

What else can be said about St Patti's that hasn't been said before? Recently renovated St Patrick's really is an amazing building nice tall pillars inside, beautiful glass windows.After it's renovation it looks brand new something that was way over due for this amazing building which sits in the mist of this busy city. Because of its location it attracts a lot of tourist of course but both locals & tourists can enjoy this beautiful church. Just like many other places of worship masses are held here on a daily basis along with plenty of special occasion as we have all seem. My most recent visit brought me here for mass on Ash Wednesday, lovely service. Being a New Yorker sometimes we can easily forget that we have beautiful places like this in our backyard & tend to end up not paying any attention to it local or tourist this amazing church is definitely worth the visit.

Anyone who lives in the Bronx knows it's a bitch to get from the east side to the west side of the borough (and vice versa). No train lines run east-west, and there are few roads that connect as well. However, I was in the mood for sushi tonight, and Yelp searching "sushi Bronx" brought Aoyu up as the top result - it had a high review average and 100+ reviews, so I decided to make the trek to Riverdale and try it. Aoyu is small and narrow, like most other sushi bars I've been to. The color scheme is mostly white with splashes of dark woods and black - a very clean look which makes the dining room look very open. The seats were nice and comfortable, even the chopsticks had a finished look to them - almost metallic, not the normal wooden ones. As soon as we were seated, a server brought us hot towels to wash our hands, a really nice surprise. The menu has a selection of rolls, ramen, and other dishes. We started with garlic broccoli, basically just steamed broccoli tossed with garlic - it was so simple yet so tasty - full of flavor. For my main I chose two rolls - they have a classic roll section of the menu as well as a specialty roll section. I went with a king crab California roll (from the regular roll selection) and the American Dream roll (from the specialty roll selection - ooh!). The American Dream had shrimp tempura and spicy tuna in it, covered with a sauce which made it super tasty. Both rolls were fresh and delicious. Service was very good - everyone was friendly and attentive. I was very impressed with Aoyu, I'll definitely be back.

If you're in town, head up Madison Avenue to 76th Street by foot or taxi in order to experience a NYC icon in the Carlyle Hotel--Bemelmans Bar. Hollywood set designers could not have imagined a bar that evokes the mid 20th Century classic elegance of NYC better than does Bemelmans Bar (so named because it is decorated with murals by Ludwig Bemelmans). The lighting, the intimate size, the patina, the bartenders and the people watching opportunity all combine to make this a must stop during your visit to Manhattan.If you stay until the jazz group starts to play, expect to pay a $15 cover charge.Great cocktail menu, but drinks are pricey: Cocktails and wine run $20 and up, beer $8 and up. Nuts and chips are generously refilled, and of course they make you thirsty, so you order another drink

Who am I kidding? I don't, just, like this place. I LOVE THIS PLACE. Yes, it's that good. I love the people they hire, I love the decor, it is superbly clean, there is live music, when there isn't live music: there is an awesome honorary DJ who plays all of the right music. Maison is where I love to fall in love with myself. Maison helps me feed my soul. Signed, sealed and delivered. They do, what they do well. Is it possible to gush more about it? Well, I'm. Working. On. It. (Seriously.)They price the good Malbec at a reasonable point. The food is solid, the experience is always an amazing time: whether sharing in conversation with the bartender or making a Maison friend. Is it possible to not have a good time here???

This was my first Broadway musical ever. Setting the bar quite high, am I right?I acquired tickets through an AmEx pre-sale back in June 2016, and saw the show beginning of February 2017. Face-value seats in the back of the Orchestra center section ended up being about $210 apiece. Currently, the lowest price you can find on third-party sites is about $500 per ticket, and that's for the back of the mezzanine seating. Curse you, third-party sites and high demand. The Hamilton show lottery currently releases 46 seats for $10 each (max 2 tickets per person), but as tens of thousands people enter this lottery, the tickets are hard to come by. Hopefully soon, demand goes down, and therefore, prices will go down too? Who knows, though? Nonetheless, just keep scouring the internet and do what you can to get a ticket at a (relatively) reasonable price. It might be physically and emotionally draining, but just save your strength and stay alive.Richard Rodgers Theater: Perhaps not the best possible venue, but the good thing is that there really don't seem to be any terrible seats, and the capacity ain't half bad. As previously mentioned, we were seated in the very back of the orchestra center section, and we had a pretty great view of the stage. On the other hand, the seats themselves were a little cramped, and the crowds can get a little out of hand pre-show and during the 15-minute intermission. Nonetheless, given how good Hamilton is, you will more than willingly brave these conditions for this particular show.Hamilton The Musical: Lives up to the massive hype, and is certainly not at all overrated, as one orange-toned man may have previously declared. I hadn't listened to any of the songs, or read any Wikipedia articles, so as to go into the show with a relatively unadulterated view. Anyways, I was worried that some of the rap dialogue might be hard to follow, but it turned out to be fine since all the actors and actresses enunciate exceptionally well, and the singing and stage directing was (obviously) top notch. Javier Muñoz, Brandon Victor Dixon, Lexi Lawson, and Mandy Gonzalez were all great in their respective roles of Hamilton, Burr, and the Schuyler sisters, and Taran Killam was super funny as King George. After the show, I bought the original Broadway cast soundtrack, and have yet to stop listening to it. During the show, I, for some reason, felt super proud being the son of 2 immigrants who worked their tails off to make it in America, and the show does a good job not only telling the story of Alexander Hamilton, but honoring those who sacrifice all to be part of the American narrative. Not only that, there are some bomb-a$$ rap battles! *air horn sounds*Anxiously waiting for them to release a live video recording of the show, or waiting to see if I can somehow get tickets again. If you haven't seen it, you definitely need to. But you didn't need me to tell you that. You want to be in the room where it happens.

Turkish fresh food fast. Happy Addition to the Chelsea foodscape. Close to the Joyce, NY Gyro brings two gyros made with quality ingredients and non GMO meats with automated meat machines that look sci-fi with beef and pork or chicken souvlaki. Ate: chicken gyro over greensLentil soupThe platter included beets, onions, tomatoes and I added on babaganousch. The lentil soup was superb. Nice seating and toilet. Super sauces and good Turkish bread.. Value and Turkish Flavors bring zing to Chelsea.

Hill & Dale provides one of the best bar experiences yet you would find this to be one of the most unsuspecting bars in the area. I first learned of Hill & Dale at an elite event few years back. My second visit was for my birthday party last year. I was taking a bit of a gamble on this one, a venue I have been only once. Though I was so glad I did. It was perhaps one of the best venues I hosted a birthday. No hassle whatsoever and with drinks and food a flowing. I can say if they can cater so well to a large party, regular service must only equate or exceed.I was looking for a classy cocktail bar venue that accomodated at least 20 people throughout a Friday evening with a fair priced menu of food and drink. Not easy to find in the city at all without a large price tag to come along with it. With a bit of handy internet research though, Hill & Dale proved the best option, and suspicious at first -- 2 hours open bar of beer and wine for $20/per person plus an entire room reserved only for us, without an extra charge. A minimum number of guests was the only main requirement (15-20ppl~). A bright colored wristband was distributed to each of my guests who participated in the bar special, so it was easy to spot. We sat and stood around a nicely adorned space of exposed brick by a non functioning fireplace conveniently adjacent to the bar, so ordering drinks was never an issue. The beer menu included craft and was not limited to your typical Sam Adams or Bud Lite. There was a choice of different wines. The food menu was their regular menu of bar fare. Couches and sofas were in our comfortably cozy area, so seating was never an issue. A waitress came by several times to ask if we needed food and cleaned our tables throughout the two hours. Tater tots anyone? Can't beat a bar that serves tater tots. Food was delicious aside all things. Music was great and not an obnoxious playlist of your typical mainstream pop songs. Not bad at all Hill & Dale. Not bad at all. In fact, it was all so much better than I was expecting.I was completely astonished by the great service and hospitality provided that Friday evening for such a large group of people, but not limited to just us. The bar was bustling with customers as the night went on, but things were running very smoothly for myself and my guests. My friends were asking how I found this place. A few friends left more than just a little happy. For this amazing birthday experience, Hill & Dale remains somewhere on top of the list. I speak highly of their service for a large birthday party. With that in mind, I feel strongly that normal service can only go the same way. Last note, beer and wine is an option always, but definitely try the cocktails. Hill & Dale is built on a reputation of some delicious mixed drinks of quality ingredients. All in all, I find little to no reason to complain about this place and hopefully all types of occasions will be as wonderful as I had experienced.

$50 omakase for 12 pieces of sushi and you need to eat it in 30 min in an outdoor shack like setting. Somehow none of these seem to go together, yet it was a great experience and I was actually full after.Came in on 12/21/16 for 2pm lunch (rsvp the day before around 4pm via texting that number). We actually arrived a few minutes before our reservation, and were seated while another couple finished up. There are 4 seats facing the chefs and 2 on the side (but I don't think those are for the omakase, more for the people waiting for their takeout). There was a toasty heat lamp above our seats so if you're in the middle you'll be fine. My fiance was sitting on the edge so his left arm was a little chilled by the end of our meal. The chairs are also covered with thick, fuzzy scarves so that kept my butt from freezing on the metal chairs. Food:Some repeats (tuna, wagyu, and salmon) but they were two different types of tuna and one wagyu was combined w/ uni. Each piece is made in front of you and the flaming of the tuna and wagyu is so exciting. I was slow and had to feed my camera before I ate, but the chefs would wait patiently until I finished each piece before placing the next one for my fiance and me. They never rushed you and they would tell you what each piece is as it is placed on your plate. They also put in a bit of wasabi under each piece of fish. Everything is so flavorful already so you don't even need the extra soy saucy they offer. There is an optional wagyu and uni handroll for a $12 supplement at the end of the meal. Somehow these two went really well together. Overall, this is a great place for a quick splurge lunch or with a SO/friend. The experience is and great fish is absolutely worth it.

East 34th Street location, close to Empire State Building. This was my FIRST VISIT to any of the very popular & beloved Xi'an Famous restaurants. Fresh food, spicy & DELISH. Next time, I must order the home made noodles; I'll probably have the Lamb Noodles next time. Tonight, I enjoyed a "Spicy Lamb Burger"-GREAT! FRESH INGREDIENTS!  I also had the "Spicy Tofu"--I asked for mild spicy. Both delicious!Clean location, fresh, flavorful food & friendly staff. See my photos. Worth a visit! ATTENTION VISITORS TO THE EMPIRE STATE BUILDING--this location is about a block away. On 34th street, between Fifth & Madison...just walk EAST on 34th Street.

Amazing Argentine food, wonderful service, and upbeat ambiance make for a wonderful dining experience. I've been here a handful of times, a couple for wine at the bar and a couple for dinner, and have never been disappointed w food, ambiance and service.Food. Steak and Meat lovers must come here for their mixed grill for two. Amazing! All incredible w the tender mouthwatering short ribs, steak, chicken breast, chorizo. Noticed they did not give sweetbreads mentioned on the menu but also included a small mixed green salad and creamy, delicious mashed potatoes (or french fries).The traditional chocolate filled crepe dessert was divine. Creamy chocolate inside and a slightly crisped crepe with ice cream on top. Amazing!Drinks. Extensive drink menu, but I wasn't thrilled w the first one I ordered. My fault as I failed to notice all the ingredients on the one I ordered which was bitter, sour, not sweet . They nicely accommodated and made an amazing sweet old fashioned instead - wonderful. Red Wines I've had here have also been good.Ambiance. Lively feeling often with a full house, tables a little close for me but I haven't minded here as I usually would. Grill of the kitchen somewhat open so you can see and smell the amazing food and steak cooking.Great music playing in the background I noticed as the crowd cleared and my mood turned from not a great one earlier to wanting to dance. Thanks to the great vibe, music and drinks.A few years ago I was here for A low key but very nice New Years Eve. They offered a champagne toast and just enough cheer without being over the top. Service. Servers at the bar and tables always attentive and friendly, knowledgable about specials and menu items, water always filled.Definitely recommend for dates friends and family dinners.

Her Name is Han is a dream come true if you're like me: a fan of delicious Korean food and a sucker for rustic/industrial decor. Everything about this place is on point, from the unique Korean dishes not typically found in other K-Town spots to the beautiful plating that is both appetizing and photo-friendly. I love coming during the daytime the most, since the crowd is a lot smaller and their lunch menu offers a wide variety of main and side dishes. Perfect for those who want to have a little bit of everything! Did I mention that the lunch options are also extremely affordable? I know it's tempting to just settle for one of the many Korean spots on 32nd, but Her Name is Han is definitely worth checking out! Everyone I've recommended to come here has fallen in love with the place as much as I had. If you have extra time (and extra space in your stomach), I'd highly suggest going to their sister store Cup & Cup next door after your meal to enjoy a nice cup of green tea latte (in a cute bear design, no less!).P.S. I met the owner and asked if her name is Han. Unfortunately, it's not.

DON'T COME HERE! There is nothing to see here, I swear. Just move along, collect your $200, pass "Go". I repeat: DON'T COME HERE!!!If you do, I will no longer be able to laugh at all the people who unknowingly pass by Little Branch's unremarkable entrance while I sip gorgeous, delicious cocktails served by gorgeous, delicious staff. I'll have to fight for my sexy table in my dark corner. I'll need to wait longer than 10 min to imbibe libations that contain nutmeg, almond and egg white. That's just--ugh--distressing. So for the love of me, don't come here! Unless you're with me.

This is a fantastic restaurant all around. It's ultra romantic, so a perfect date spot, but good for lots of other occasions as well. They have a lovely bar, and a nice cocktail selection. The actual dining area is cozy and beautiful, and the atmosphere is amazing. For whatever reason, the décor makes me feel like this is a perfect Fall/Winter restaurant. Probably because they have a big fireplace that makes it feel cozy and rustic inside. The service was excellent, and the sommelier selected a fantastic bottle of wine for us. Wish I could remember the name. We tried several items off the menu from each category. Everything was delicious and I'm pretty sure you can't go wrong with any of it. The menu is great, and quality of the food is excellent. They have some of your standard Spanish tapas options, but the selection leans more heavily toward a Mediterranean influence, which was a refreshing change. It is somewhat pricey, but worth every penny. I can't wait to return.

Wow what a great find! This small ice cream shop has an assortment of interesting flavored ice creams that you don't normally encounter. My friend and I split the odd pocket, which is basically an ice cream sandwich in between a brioche bun. It is ridiculously delicious. The hot and cold combination of warmed toasted bread with ice cream has me hooked. Made me wish I had a whole odd pocket to myself! Props

I love reviews that write themselves, don't you?Abiko turns out some mean Japanese curry. If you like it hot, they'll deliver[1]. Inevitably, I'll be asked if Abiko is better than Go Go Curry. They're similar, but I find Abiko tastier. (To GGC: I still love you. I'll see you next week!)Last I was here, I sprung for the vegetable curry (base price $8.99; credit accepted), and asked for their hottest "level of spiciness". The waiter talked me down a notch - to level three - and I'm thankful. They weren't kidding, their spicy is a damn good one, with a burn that sneaks up on you, bear hugs you, and doesn't let go until you remember your safeword.When I ran out of rice, I had to stop eating. I got everything to go, and my mouth's watering just thinking about the leftovers.Obviously I'm no vegetarian. To my curry I added the complimentary green onions and garlic flakes, then a raw egg, then a huge piece of "premium" sausage[2], then a side of natto. When my dish arrived, there was miso soup (yum) and pickled kimchi radish too. Because Koreatown?Go to Abiko now, and say Dave sent you. I guarantee they'll be confused.This review is dedicated to Jerome T., because he reminded me to finish it.[1] I have no idea if they actually deliver food.[2] Funny because I didn't see a "regular" sausage offered anywhere.

I think I've been on a roll with 5-star reviews. Perhaps I might be too generous in handing out those stars. But it was really TOUGH for me to find anything critical at this hole-in-the-wall. The eatery is meant best for takeaway service or a quick bite. There's very limited seating and not even enough room to stand. The kitchen/staff area takes up roughly half the space in what was formerly a Chinatown floral shop. But I think that's the charm. It's to recreate in these tiny conditions the comforts of a Malaysian coffee shop (kopi tiam) or a house, while giving the customer extensive transparency in seeing how the food is prepared.The food is cheap. Nothing on the menu goes near the $10 mark. A good portion of it is devoted to pastries (kuih), but there are also mini-meals such as nasi lemak (coconut rice with anchovies and a boiled egg for $5.50) or the chilled spicy noodles. I have had the pleasure after seeing this place open near me to visit a couple of times. After eating nasi lemak at least three times, I decided to try the spicy noodles.I enjoyed both a lot. The nasi lemak comes with a generous dollop of coconut rice. The coconut flavor is not that strong. Most of the flavor eventually comes from the anchovies and the sambal spicy sauce. Condiments such as cucumber give a refreshing taste, especially after eating the sambal. I'm not Malaysian so I might be unorthodox for doing this: I usually mix the rice with the sambal and the anchovies, counter to my usual OCD ways. The spicy noodles are served at room temperature with cucumber and a boiled egg. I asked the owner to swap the egg for cucumber. The cucumber again gives a cool and refreshing taste and the soup came to surprise. One would hardly associate something served room temperature with something spicy. It was an interesting combination that I think they pulled off well.At my most recent visit, I had the opportunity to learn more about the owner when she gave her story. She's very nice and is a very sociable person. Her parents owned a restaurant in Malaysia and she compared the experiences of her owning her own place. She described how she imported the bowls were imported from Malaysia. The owner's chatty and relaxed vibe matches what would be expected from a coffee house or someone's house. A slower pace, a break from the hustle and bustle of the city, some place to really warm up and talk to someone, all while sipping on quality coffee and eating some of the dishes for cheap.I find it near impossible to criticize any aspect of the place. Perhaps one might say that I was too generous with my 5-star rating, but I stand by with what I said.

Time for an update!!So "H Bakeshop" moved to 54th Street and its now named Hauscar & Co. Although they have moved a few blocks away the recipes are all the same and are basically the best you could find in the area. I'm not joking, this place is truly amazing. Its small but packs a serious punch.The display isn't a mile long which is a good thing because small batches mean everything fresh and never days old. You could taste the difference in ingredients that Huascar uses in his unique cupcakes, they're different in a good way. Gianduja, Guiness, Cayenne. Next level cupcake action. Move over crumbs.On my last visit I had the mini oreo cheesecake. First off they come in mason jars, who doesn't like mason jars?! The cheesecake was just right, not too airy but not too heavy. It was topped with whipped cream and a layer of chocolate ganache which was tasty. I suggest everything here.The new space is bright and clean and you could peek into the kitchen where you'll see Hauscar baking away. He even comes out to chat!I'd highly recommend this place if you craving something sweet!

Warning to all that love to crunch on nuts. I had no idea that almonds are one of the hardest nuts to chew. I know now! I can't remember the last time I had a cavity. I floss and brush after each meal. I'm a fanatic! Well, I still lost a tooth from crunching hard almonds and other nuts for the past few years. Eating lunch I felt a crack in my molar. Split that tooth in half down the middle! No pain but very uncomfortable to eat. You never let a cracked tooth go or bacteria gets in. Very serious. The next day I went to the dentist to see if my tooth could be saved. The answer was no! Their in home oral surgeon was not available for a week and a half. Knowing how sick I've been recently I asked if they could recommend someone I might be able to see sooner. They referred me to Doctor Tuchman and even made the appointment. He saw me the next morning at 9am! Unheard of typically for me. By the time I arrived home from the dentist I had an email confirming my appointment and instructions to complete the patient Medical Questionaire on line. I did so with ease and was amazed at the high tech process. Excellent! I immediately received a conformation from the office. The young lady I had spoken to on the phone earlier handled everything for Doctor Tuchman. Also included in the email were the detailed instructions pre oral surgery and my options for anesthesia! Plus steps for post surgery care of the extraction site. Next morning I arrived at the office. Very comfortable and clean. I didn't even have the opportunity to sit and the young lady I had been communicating with came over introduced herself and handled my introduction to the dental assistant. Very nice assistant took me to my chair and explained a few things prepping me for surgery. In a couple minutes Doctor Tuchman arrived. He took his time explaining in detail all of my options and very patiently answering my questions. I naturally selected local anesthetic. No ones putting me to sleep at my age! I failed to tell him I'm very susceptible to drugs. He over did it with three shots. I was numb for seven hours or more! I must say either I'm nerve dead or he is super good at extractions. I did not have any pain after. The jaw was a little swollen. I used ice packs which they provide and they provided gause for bleeding. I turned down prescription for pain reliever. I get very sick from those. I may have taken a couple Tylenol. As I said I never had any pain. The following day Doctor Tuchman called and we also emailed back and forth with any questions or concerns I had. The extraction was on a Wednesday. On Friday he contacted me by phone one last time to see how I was doing. He reassured me I could email if needed him over the weekend or the following week. I received Wonderful Caring Treatment throughout the whole process. I would highly recommend Doctor Tuchman. I know if I'm still living in Manhattan and need oral surgery I will go to Doctor Tuchman. Since I don't have dental insurance it set me back a couple months of my monthly budget allowance! Manhattan prices are a killer! If you want the best care bring a fat wallet! Or excellent credit!Just remember avoid hard nuts. When I did some research on line there's been a recent epidemic of broken and split teeth from almonds. Don't let this happen to you!

I have to say, I was fairly impressed with this place and will give it a 5 stars rating. After reading all the yelp reviews, I decided to come here. Best to make reservations. I made a reservation for 2 for 5:30pm since the popular times were all taken up, especially counter seats of course. This is omakase style sushi, which is what I was looking for. There were 5 options I believe. Think it was a 12, 13, 15, 18, or 20 piece sushi + sashimi. We opted for the 20 piece + sashimi omakase ($180 pp). They give you a couple of appetizers which were all pretty good. There was a soup and ice cream mochi for dessert in this set. The sashimi that came with this course were really good. Fish was fresh of course. Wouldn't have expected anything less if I'm paying $180 pp. I thought the sashimi was very little for the price. I think the 18 piece sushi with no sashimi was $150pp. So for an extra $30, I only had like 6 pieces of fish, 3 different kinds (tuna, clam and red snapper). Nonetheless, it was really good, no regrets. The red snapper was my favorite of them all. Although I don't remember a lot of the fishes I tried, I really enjoyed the Hokkaido uni compared with the Santa Barbara uni. He was nice enough to let me try the Hokkaido one...wow.
