Probably the best uni I've ever had to be honest. I really enjoyed this place because they gave such a huge variety of different fish selections so I never got bored. I've been to some omakase places in NY where they do not give as many different selections. They will use the same types of fishes and just serve it a different way. This restaurant is very small, very intimate. I also liked that they had a small cup with a wet towel for people who wanted to eat the sushi with their hands instead of chopsticks. That was something small, but new to me. The fish was so good and fresh that eating it with soy sauce would be completely wrong. You just put each whole piece in your mouth as is, no soy sauce (not like the American way of eating "sushi.") Don't come here expecting dragon rolls or California rolls. This is the real sushi/sashimi stuff. If you want dragons rolls and all that, stick to your "Japanese" restaurants owned by Chinese people lol. Great experience here. I would def come back some day. Expensive, but great quality fish.

This has been on my wishlist for over a year. We were overly-ambitious that night, as we had had a few drinks and appetizers somewhere else before wandering in to O Ya out of the cold. O Ya definitely deserves to be THE star of the night, so we won't make that mistake again. It was a Wednesday night, and we had a reservation for around 9:15pm. The staff welcomed us kindly though we were a bit late. The ambience was lovely, the lightning warm, the decor charming. The tiny "chopsticks rests" were adorable, some were in the shapes of cute animals and we loved the whale and kitty ones. The server humorously mentioned that they used to have panda-shaped ones, but they "disappeared" to new homes, haha. Though the omakase was tempting as always, I'm glad we kept it to a few a la carte choices. The presentation was stellar, and everything tasted heavenly. Lots of delicious truffle choices. We had some lovely champagne to start, because you know, bubbly goes with everything in life. The bluefin chutoro with the herb sauce was one of the stars, as was the scallop truffle. I do believe the truffle scented uni nigiri was possible the best uni I've ever put in my mouth. Ever. I mean, I'm not saying I've had a lot of uni but still. Really. Everything just melted in our mouths, felt like heaven really. I kept wondering if I really was still alive, I might have pinched myself once or twice. For one of the only times in my life ever, I would have skipped the dessert, though the mochi donuts were interesting. It's just that everything else was too good. It's perhaps too extravagant to wish to come back for the 24-course, but. It's Christmas, and a girl can dream.

Since their soft opening few weeks ago, we have been going to this lovely café almost every weekend. Instead of having so many updates, I decided to combine the last several visits into one. It has constantly being really busy, with its fun theme, good food and coffee. The only time it was not full was the day of snow storm. When most businesses and schools were closed for the day due to the severe weather, Rue La Rue Café was open! Thank you for being a dedicated café...!We have been there for several Saturdays now, and it is constantly busy. Also, they have had musicians there on every Saturdays so far, which is really cool. They always have a pianist, and one accompanying string musician like a cellist or a guitarist. Nice to have a live music while you are enjoying a brunch.They have some glasses with Golden Girls design in gold (of course), I believe for sale. I don't think they serve their coffee or any drinks in it, since I haven't seen it used inside the café for customers. it would be fun, yes, but it probably is more cost effective to NOT use fancy glasses like that, as the design can fade faster in a commercial grade, powerful dish washer.So, over the last several visits, we had Adult Mac & Cheese, Betty White Cake, Blanche's Raspberry Cheesecake, Chocolate Cheesecake, Mrs. Naugatuck's Curry Chicken Sandwich, Sophia's Amaretto Cheesecake, Strawberry Cheesecake, Tomato Mishmash in a Bread Bowl, and a Waffle with Strawberry Butter. Jealous? I know, I would be too...We have not come across anything that we didn't like. Everything was tasty, and I can see that they are all crafted with care. This also means that food does not come out right away, but I prefer them to make the food to order, and with love. I saw a customer who was so impatient and kind of rude, because they ordered a hot dish and it didn't come out within few minutes... If it came out so fast, that meant it was already made, and sitting there for a while. Here, the food might take a bit longer you'd like, but you are getting something that is made for you, and only you. So, please come with a little more patience.The staffs here are nice, not all "friendly" but most of them are very nice and attentive. One of the staffs took a really good care of the demanding customers I mentioned above, with great patience and poise. The owner, Micheal is there all the time, greeting customers with smile, making everything feels special. Thank you for being a friend!One last note, they have extended their hours to 7:30AM to 7:30PM, so now you can visit them in the evenings if you can't make it during the day time!

Doughnuts are at the top of the list of items I would blissfully stuff my face with if things like health and money were of no concern. One of my most cherished childhood memories is journeying out to Long Island to my family friend's Dunkin Donuts and devouring a jelly glazed doughnut with a sweet milk. Doughnut Plant is Dunkin Donuts on crack: softer, fluffier, with less of the sugary sweet aftertaste. I still felt like I needed a kale salad and a green juice after eating but it was one of the few much-hyped, Instagrammed food that is absolutely worth it. My office ordered a few boxes of donuts for a holiday party and I unabashedly stuck a few in my bag to take home for my boyfriend to try, they were just that unbelievably good. Still moist even after sitting in my bag too. The standouts were: 1) the peanut butter and banana combo (why isn't this a more common combination?) and 2) the Christmas tree donut (mint and chocolate). There was some other chocolate flavor but the only one I returned for seconds and thirds for was the pb and banana. Must come back for the creme brûlée donut. After all, if it's good enough for Hillary Clinton to be bad about, it's good enough for me.

One of the nicest meals in NoLita. Fully digitized you can order your food at a kiosk, use your credit card, and get your order picked up at the counter. Lot's of counter and bench space to eat your meal. It's a simple interior but the large windows provide lots of great natural light to come in. My go to favorites here are the shrimp hai gow. Large shrimp very flavorful and fresh. The fried rice which had ample ingredients and vegetables was very satisfying. The shrimp dumplings with snow peas was also delicious. What really stayed in my mind over time that i can go back to get everytime is the Steamed ribs with char siu glaze. Tender, porky, and full of chinese bbq flavor. Very satisfying. I'll definitely be back for sure.

Quality, creative subs with inventive, bold flavors. Staff was extremely helpful and remembered my name the whole time I was there. I went with the roasted chicken Sammy with date and apple slaw. The ciabatta had a great crunch and was a huge fan of the slaw. Can't think of a better sub shop experience to date, I'll be back forsure!

It's very hard not to like a place where the first thing that greets you when you enter is a fresh wall of apples and a lovely person wanting to help you with your coat. I have wanted to come to Bouley for many many years- finally I, very luckily got to come here recently, not once, but twice for lunch! The whole restaurant is just simply stunning. From the entrance and wall of apples (it smells so amazing btw), lush waiting area, to the upstairs dining and also private dining room downstairs- the visual experience is already very stimulating, all before you have even received your first course. The first time I lunched here, we were seated in the downstairs private room. It was like being taken to a European library- very charming and quaint and my second time here, we were seated in the upstairs main dining room. Both are beautiful in their own ways and you will not be disappointed in either dining areas. The whole restaurant has accents and furniture imported from a French Monastery. While you await your order to arrive, they have a wonderful bread cart. I don't even like bread but I tried a few different fresh breads- my favorite has black currant in it. I started with the porcini flan, made with Golden princess and Alaskan dungeness crab, black truffle dashihad. It was filing and also very tasty. For my main entree, I ordered the organic duck which had Organic Maine einkorn grain and young sprouts,with New York State foie gras braised in red Burgundy duck which I highly recommend. To finish up the meal with dessert, I recommend the chocolate cake- it delightfully oozes with fudge or avocat- ananas which is Pineapple-wasabi sorbet, fresh avocado, miso sponge cake, sesame tuile. For a light martini, if you enjoy apples (I mean, they have a lot of apples here..) I loved la pomme. Overall, both meals here were excellent as was the impeccable service. As expected, both meals were delightful and it only makes me sad that they are set to shutter in early 2017. P.S. for the ladies, don't forget your gift with the hostess at the end of the meal! The delicious lemon pound cake is a great way to enjoy a little bit of Bouley at home. Michelin *

I was super impressed with Eatsa! I was excited to try it, but since it's their first few days open in this location I had expected there might be a few issues, but there weren't. So the basic concept is that you go in and order from an iPad (or you can order from their app) and once it's ready you go pick it up from a little cubby. It's also relatively healthy with all the bowls being either quinoa or salad based, and there doesn't appear to be any meat on the menu (FYI), and pretty inexpensive. I had downloaded the app and previewed the menu and options, but I actually wanted to go in and see what it was like. The only human interaction with people working there was them guiding you to the iPad and asking you to move over while you wait. You don't even really need any help since it's so simple. You can choose a bowl, and then customize it to your liking, or just customize a bowl from scratch. I went with the smoke house salad, and was able to take out the things I didn't want and add in the things I did. Super easy! And I really don't even think I had to wait 5 minutes for it to be ready. There was a small crowd of people, nothing really too crazy, but all the food seemed to come out really fast. There was a small area, high counter, for eating, but I took it back to my office to eat. Everything in it seemed really fresh, and it was so good! I'm happy this opened down the block from my office. Hopefully it won't get too crazy when more people discover it, but I'll definitely be back!

Craftbar was always a winner in our experience. A casual but refined relaxing atmosphere just below Madison Square park, with dark walls, bar dining and booths, which became the mantra of many of the hipster joints one sees in Brooklyn these days. Reliable, though elevated, with comfort food menu items i.e. Buttermilk fried chicken, Louisiana shrimp and grits,Veal ricotta meatballs, Short ribs etc.Sadly, due to a 50% rent increase raising it to $60k per month, Craftbar will be closing its doors April 15, 2017.  *We look forward to visiting Tom Colicchio's latest restaurant in the Beekman Hotel further downtown in the Financial District, named Fowler & Wells. Hopefully the rent will not be as astronomical.*

It was serendipitous that we stumbled upon this very good coffee shop in the Bowery while looking for a quick coffee. The space is small with limited seating, maybe just a few counter perches and only a few stools. There is also a bench outside.Cute scruffy hipster baristas with black blocky glasses, dyed blue hair and throw on out of bed wardrobes blast out deep rich joe. We had black thick creamy Americanos for $3 each, and found them to be of European quality. The wall space is bare, zen like, and the crowds are large.  Its true simple good coffee - like gasoline.PSIts kinda hidden in an alley.Drink and go. No food that I saw, but you never know. We were super content with our outta space black cups.

One of the few places I ever expected to find myself at was Le Bernardin. Why? Well, as a child growing up, I abhorred seafood and fish of any kind; it was partially derived from being exposed to a limited number of dishes, but mostly due to my stubborn nature - but I digress [1]. But for those looking to truly find some of the best seafood in New York City, Le Bernardin should be at the top of the list. The accolades are numerous, including a consistent string of 3 Michelin stars, four NYT stars, and a near-perfect Zagat score, and Chef Eric Ripert is considered by many to be one of the best chefs of his time. His philosophy is printed clearly on each of the menus at the restaurant: "The fish is the star of the plate."The dining options at Le Bernardin are also quite generous, with options available for lunch and dinner, and allow diners to choose between a number of prix fixe menus and a la carte dishes. While it's certainly possible to have a fairly extravagant meal, we opted to come in the middle of the day for a slightly more scaled back but nonetheless comprehensive experience. Reservations were made a month in advance as well, although the availability of tables during lunch seem to be better than at dinner. Regardless, tit's best to come prepared as it's far from just a casual dining experience.The meal will start diners off with a choice of bread from their bread tray, as well as an amuse bouche; we were treated to a generous salmon rillette paired with the buttery thin toast points. From the three course prix fixe, I opted for the Seafood Truffle Pasta and was presented with one of most beautiful (and fragrant) pasta dishes I have yet to find. The tagliatelle pasta was cooked to just the right texture and bite, but played second fiddle to the tender pieces of crab, lobster, and scallop that highlighted the dish. All the components were lightly coated in a black truffle emulsion that imparted a distinct flavor in the sauce but held back from overpowering the entire dish. For those looking for something a little lighter and brighter, the Langoustine and Sea Urchin was a similarly gorgeous dish, featuring a thin langoustine "carpaccio" studded with generous servings of sea urchin, all balanced out with a sweet and tart nori-apple vinaigrette.Originally for my main, I had decided on the Pan Roasted Cod, which was served with a Coq au Vin sauce. Upon my first bite into the dish, however, I was taken aback at the acidity in the sauce which wasn't balanced out by anything else in the dish. Our server, upon noting my hesitation at the dish, immediately inquired if everything was all right, and I told him that I found the sauce too sharp for my tastes; he immediately had the dish sent back to the kitchen (informing me that the red wine in the coq au vin sauce could be sometimes overwhelming) and offered a suggestion for an alternative, the Black Bass "Surf and Turf". The latter option was, I'm happy to say, one of the best seafood dishes I've yet to have, which paired a perfectly cooked filet of black bass with braised veal cheek. The dish was dotted with several portions of a creamy, light parsnip emulsion and an aromatic broth that featured ginger and a five spice reduction. I can still recall how perfectly crisp and thin the skin on the bass was, how tender the veal was to cut into, and how beautifully the parsnip paired with the lightly spiced broth... While I can't speak to the entire menu at Le Bernardin, it's impossible to go wrong with this dish, and it's one I'm glad I did wind up with.As for dessert, I ended up going with the Black Walnut, a beautifully plated dish that featured a cylinder of Baba au Scotch cake (traditionally cooked with rum, but traditions are meant to be broken), caramelized banana, and a quennelle of black walnut ice cream. It was surprisingly balanced, with the darker, nuttier flavors contrasting well with the coolness and lightness of the ice cream. I think my preference may lie with the Slow-Roasted Pear, however, which took a perfectly poached pear and uniquely elevated it with a "beurre noisette" tuile and a frozen pear parfait. It was a truly refreshing, perfectly sweet dessert that featured the pear in numerous forms and textures.I don't think I need to touch too much on the elegance and refinement of the dining room, and the professionalism and attentiveness of the service at Le Bernardin. In actuality, this review is probably more redundant than anything else - but if there is one takeaway from it, let it be this: Go. There is good reason that Le Bernardin stands the test of time and continues to be seen by many as one of the best restaurants in the city, if not the world. It is a fitting 500th review (at least in my opinion) and I can only hope to return one day to experience the full dinner service.--[1] Rest assured that since moving to NYC, this has been nearly completely rectified.

I'm so glad this place is here!Corvo has been open for about a month now, and in that time, they've had a promotion where EVERY item on their menu is $2. Every. Single. Item. That includes all their coffee products as well as their pastries, breakfast sandwiches, and other goodies. I keep going every day, thinking the promotion will end soon, but it's been a solid month and prices are still the same. So not only are the prices great, but get this: the coffee is too. They use La Colombe beans and turn out solid lattes, regular coffee, flat whites, or anything you're in the mood for. Best of all, the service is friendly and efficient. I occasionally ask for mochas or flavored lattes with very little syrup, and they have always been happy to accommodate. I've never been disappointed with either my drink or the service. Part of me hopes that Corvo will stay a secret, but part of me is happy to see more people discover it!

If wine enthusiasts ask "Bordeaux or Burgundy?," Pho enthusiasts similarly ask "Northern or Southern Style?" My answer to the latter is always "Northern" (Pho Bac). Hanoi House is the only NYC representative, so far, that makes Pho Bac. (---- I must mention that this review is a long, but personally special one to me. Because I am finally writing a review about Pho as a Vietnamese! To create a certain credibility of this review, I need to mention my background. I am not the Vietnamese who grew up with Orange County's cuisine, but the Vietnamese who spent the entire childhood in Vietnam, where I often had Pho Bac (Northern-Style-Pho) made by people from the North. Basically what I am trying to say is - I know what I'm talking about. ----)Back to the opening question - "Northern or Southern?" Why is it so crucial for this review? It is because the majority (or may I dare saying "all") of Pho in NYC is the Southern-Style-Pho. The kind of Pho videos you see on Youtube by Zagat, Munchies, even Asians like Fung Bros are videos about Southern-Style-Pho! The only popular video-documented Northern-Style-Pho appeared on Anthony Bourdain's show. There is nothing wrong about your choice of style, but if I liked Bordeaux and you served only Burgundy, there's a less chance that I'd come back, right?-------Here are some main differences--------- Northern (Pho Bac): traditional Noodles: flat, soft / Soup: clear, cooked from cow bones / Taste: mildly sweet (bland) + a hint of black pepper and ginger / Meat: chicken or fat beef to compromise with the soup / Addition to serving: Chinese cruller + pickled garlic / Portion: medium bowl + lots of scallions / Location: local Northern Vietnam-- Southern (Pho Nam): Noodles: chewy / Soup: cloudy, cooked from cow, chicken bones, and sometimes dried seafood / Taste: sweet + rich / Meat: doesn't matter lean or fat (the dish is highly fat anyway) / Addition to serving: sriracha + hoisin + side veggies / Portion: humongous bowl + sprinkled scallions / Location: anywhere in the world but local Northern VietnamHanoi House's Pho is not perfectly authentically Northern (Hanoi). The most distinctive difference of the 2 styles is the noodles. The noodles Hanoi House use are absolutely not Northern, but considering the Northern noodles are handmade and no restaurant wants to pioneer, I probably shouldn't demand. The soup, on the other hand, is the r-e-a-l d-e-a-l. A very important point to mention here is their price points. Some people really (really?) need to complain about spending $13 for a Pho. My total combo of a Pho + bone marrow + chinese cruller + tip were $20. If you can pay $13 for a ramen or a pasta, what's so wrong about a $13 Pho?! Preached about your health then demanded less than $13 for an MSG meal. Only idiots would expect a less-than-$13 dinner in a neat, top-service restaurant in East Village.

This review is primarily for the galette des rois! Yes, every year around January 6th French people enjoy the galette des rois tradition. Even after January 6th many bakeries keep the cakes, often even until the end of January when Valentine's stuff starts coming in. So go out and get some galette!!I personally always find it a bit annoying when people say stuff like, "This Italian place is legit, because my mom's Italian and the pasta sauce is the same!", etc. Well, sorry, I'm from France and I highly recommend this place. Does this mean somehow that my opinion trumps those of other just 'regular' Americans even if they've personally eaten like 2 bazillion croissants more than me? Well, duh, yes I'm better than you! haha, no just joking. But yes French people can be snobby.This is the best galette I've eaten in a long time. Crunchy and flaky and buttery and light on the outside (as it should, it's puff pastry similar to a croissant) and warm & rich & gooey & almondy on the inside (typical frangipane, same often found in almond croissants). Plus the top design is really nice and the price at $25 (6 person size, $40 for 10 person size) is spot on. Kayser only had a 8 person size and it was $35. Really didn't like the last 2 cakes I bought at Kayser so was very delighted with Mille-Feuille this time.Don't be shy, enjoy the tradition with us! They even sell individual slices. Its basically a giant pie shaped almond croissant, so good!! Oh, if you don't know the tradition involves sharing the pie with friends and the person who finds the 'fève' (bean, usually a figurine) gets the crown and is the king or queen. And if you lose, well just keep buying more galettes until you win the crown like I do!!! lolTo finish off, I've tried other galettes at Kayser, Pain Quotidien, Financier and this is my favorite. Financier is good but basic, Mille-Feuille really kicks it up a notch.As for their other offerings, they are also very good. They have croissants (they even offer private classes, super pricey if you ask me), their namesake mille-feuille, and other standard cakes and viennoiseries. Oh, and yes they have CUPS so make sure you get the CUPS app to get cheaper coffee!I really like Mille-Feuille, so I definitely won't hesitate next time say to buy a bûche de noel from here - yes, another French tradition that Americans really ought to experience and one you guys just missed! Btw, don't buy from Kayser, over-priced and mediocre bûches. I have really really enjoyed other bûches though from Dominique Ansel and Restaurant Benoit (they do special orders). Ceci cela normally is another favorite but their bûches normally don't look very nice.

GUYS. Super Foodtown is the best thing to happen to the neighborhood in quite some time. Finally, a grocery store with a big selection of fresh produce and a meat section where the meat isn't half-spoiled and all dripping meat juices on itself (looking at you, Key Foods). And the prices don't make you want to straight up punch someone (looking at you, Gristedes).  They even have some bougie staples, like stations for you to grind your own peanut butter and coffee, and a sprawling selection of cheeses. After you've stuffed yourself with cheese and peanut butter, you might be looking to shave some calories, and BOOM -- a wall full of Halo Top ice cream.  You start feeling bad for eating the semi-franken food that is Halo Top, and lo and behold -- another wall full of nourishing Bob's Red Mill products.  You decide you don't actually feel that bad about eating franken-food, and HEY-O -- aisles of fun snack foods (have you ever tried coconut jerky? I hadn't either before discovering it at this wonderful gem of a grocery store). My point is, you can find everything you need, and also everything you don't need but will thoroughly enjoy, right here on 160th St. The service is great and the manager (who I swear is always working) has a frankly admirable amount of hustle in his heart. Your groceries will be bagged in no time flat.The best news of all? FREE DELIVERY. In a country run by a despotic monster, in the midst of the cold and dreary winter, let Food Town be the salve your weary soul craves.

This is it. This is my favorite coffee place in the world. It's a bougie, slightly hipster place but if you want an incredible, unique coffee experience go to Coffee Project New York.Here is what you need to know:1. THE HAPPY DRINK IS EVERYTHING. I actually feel happier after I order it. It's delicious, creamy, refreshing, and the coffee is well done. You have to get it. No matter what the weather, this is the drink to get.2. The deconstructed latte is worth a try at least once. So much thought is put into it and the flavor profiles are really apparent.3. Service is top notch. Everyone is friendly and coffee loving.4. This is more of a sit down and enjoy your coffee and the vibes place. But you can take coffee to go.5. The coffee is absolutely worth the higher price tag.CPNW is the number one spot for coffee. Whether you're visiting NYC or a local, you absolutely must come here. And you will come back.

This Israeli Bakery has many yummy carbs that will have you coming back for more! From breads to cakes to cookies to tarts, there's no telling where to start and end with your purchases.They also have multiple sitting areas where you can sit and chatt it up. At the back of the store is an area where you can order drinks hot or cold. They also have multiple pastries you can choose from as you order your drink.The staff is all so friendly and interestingly enough they say they work out to avoid putting on weight from working there. I couldn't agree more.

I have taken quite a few classes at this studio for like 10 years. I haven't been consistent. So unfortunately I can't grace a stage anytime soon. But I thought of reporting my experience here.This school is super organized. You can tell that they've been doing this for a while. Their classes are posted online. They offer amazing specials via Groupon, LivingSocial, and other sites. They even have an unlimited class monthly special.Their teachers are amazing. I love Jose for the Beginner Salsa classes because he breaks things down and he's super funny. I prefer Joe for the Advanced ones because he teaches with speed and efficiency which is what Intermediates and Advancers need. We don't have time to review the basics, so thanks for skipping it. I firmly believe that this school can teach anyone with the worst case of 2 left feet. Best of all, they offer a ton of classes -- from Bachata to Zumba. So, that unlimited class special can replace any gym membership if you're a class aficionado like me.

From the moment you walk in, the golden decorations of the restaurant is absolutely breathtaking and their food completely reflects the beauty of decor. For a party of 6 that made no reservations, we waited about 40min, which is good for a Friday night at 730pm. As for their beverages, I highly recommend their jasmine tea (one pot gives your about 6 cups of tea) because it offers a refreshing taste when paired with your appetizer or entree. For the appetizer, we got both their papaya salad and Mieng Kum. Their Mieng Kum (shrimp leaf-wrapped bite-size) was a fun way to start the meal with your friends, where they give you 5 bite sized portions served on top of shot glasses. Not only is the dish visually appealing, but the bite sized portions offer a great burst of authentic Thai flavors such as ginger fresh red onions, shrimp, and coconut. For the entree, I hands down recommend their Ped Ron (crispy five spice duck). Upon receiving the dish, you could immediately tell how delicious and expertly plated the dish was. The duck was cooked to perfection, with the tender duck simply falling apart in your mouth upon biting it. The dish is paired with a sweet honey-soy dressing, which I found to be pleasant but not necessary to enjoy the taste of the duck. Overall, the beauty of the restaurant and dishes alone should be enough to draw you in for a meal. I would highly recommend Thai Villa for a special event or an intimate date night.

Jane of ViewBeau eyelashes is really, really a gem. I have been seeing her for years, and have been following her around throughout each location she has been to. It seems like this one might be more permanent, and it is very convenient - right on 34th and Park in the middle of everything. She and her colleague work hard, do a perfect job, and are so accommodating as they are happy to text to make appointments and are so flexible on timings. Before I came to Jane, I saw the bigger places in K-town like Ebenezar and I just feel like the work doesn't compare. Jane is meticulous, detailed-oriented and she is very personable- whenever I have her lashes; with good care they last as long as 3-4 weeks! She has all different lengths, curl types, thin/thick and will advise you on what's best for you. She is skilled at mixing different types of lashes, and the lashes never hurt or feel tight.  She will personalize whatever look you want! She is really so sweet and her demeanor is so relaxing that I always somehow fall asleep...;). Definitely go to ViewBeau - they have loyal cards to and trust me, you won't regret it. Typically I do 70 lashes per eye but she can also put on more for special occasions. Attaching a photo of the incredible lashes she did on my wedding day! (My natural lashes are thin and go down.. these make a HUGE difference)

This place is amazing. Come here to sweat out toxins, detox, burn calories, utilize light therapy, and just zone out. I feel so much better after an hour session, albeit I last maybe 45 minutes in there- but it makes a difference. The first time I went I think it took some getting used to, but the more I have gone, the longer I can last. And I absolutely notice a difference. I get a glow that I normally only get from a good facial, I sweat out toxins, and it definitely relieves muscle and joint pain. Highly recommend coming here. Also if you come while the Alchemist Kitchen is open, grab something to drink after.

Spice has officially taken over!!! I've been here a few times, including last night, so I think a review is finally in order. There is definitely a reason why Spice has successfully opened many locations in different areas of the city. They have created the perfect equation of delicious food, friendly service, beautiful decor and affordable prices. I mean, really, what more can you ask for? My friends and I each had an appetizer: Siam buns (my fave!), calamari and chicken wings. Then we had entrees, of course: black noodles, pad Thai, and something with fried rice (I forgot the name, sorry). Everything was phenomenal though, which is typical for Spice! And the service was amazing, as usual. So you literally can never wrong with any Spice location. Chances are there's one near you, so check it out; you'll be glad you did.

This review is solely on their Happy Hour (4 PM - 7 PM), which is freaking fantastic. $4 for STRONG vodkas with a variety of flavors to choose from. I forget what the price of wells was, but $4 drafts as well.Food options are available as well, but as I'm ignorant to the fare, I declined ordering anything. The bartender is super friendly. There wasn't any entertainment when I went in at 4 PM, but I enjoyed catching up with a friend so I didn't mind the quiet. As we were leaving around 6, the place was definitely starting to get full. So the earlier the better, my happy hour peeps.If I get drunk on $13 in Midtown, you get 5 stars!

One of the relatively new dessert places that's unique, which is tough to say in Chinatown. This one is worth your time. As many know, Taiyaki is a cake shaped into a fish, served up with soft serve. To make it fun, they pair it with trendy new ice cream flavors that you're familiar with, some filling (custard/red bean), and toppings. They all come together in a half piping hot and ice cold artwork that holds up, which is perfect for photos. Not only are they photogenic, they taste great too. Since their grand opening earlier this year, I've already had the green tea, vanilla and most recently pumpkin spice. They all taste pretty damn good, which is a testament as to why they have continuous lines straight out through now (winter). The store is perfectly located with steps of Canal St. despite being on Baxter as a street. Service is exceptional, accommodating and upbeat, and i've never had a single issue every time I've ordered. They're the ones to watch as they're best situated to come out with new colorful and tasty combinations in the winter soon that's sure to turn heads.

I do a taco cleanse about once a week. Sometimes you have to reboot and get illusions of how fantastic life will be when you're 96 years old right out of your system.To me, Al Pastor makes the most sense. AP wakes up my immune system and reminds it to keep running, or else.Every few weeks, I like to switch it up. A carnitas burrito and margarita cleanse do wonders for your face, like making it look more trustworthy, and other such traits. I discovered the carnitas benedict recently and -- let me tell ya -- it left my taste buds more balanced and focused.One side benefit of going burrito between taco cleanses is that it elevates my mood with these simple, crispy sweet potato fries. Maybe it's the cojito or lime, I'm not exactly sure tbh.All of us are exposed to some environmental toxins. The bottomless brunch & happy hour lime margaritas can keep those toxins company, and maybe fight them cell-to-cell, depending on your body.The effects of Cascabel's churros are impressive. It relieves inflammation of the soul, and the dark chocolate dip facilitates this process nicely.Finally, I've found several taco cleanse enthusiasts here, of different ages and species, and it's a neat community. Dogs chill out on the patio. Lots of kids learn their common core math and tipping etiquette on receipts here. There was one eight year-old kid who just ordered a plate of meat and sweet potato fries because he was getting in shape to shoot a commercial. He looked like a young Rocky, so this stuff obviously works. It was 105°F last time I was here, there were fans but no air-conditioner, and a server brought over a bunch of ice to play with.Def recommend.-----Happy Hour Tips:- Skip: wings- Get: veggie tamale, house margarita (strong)

Five Senses is my new favorite restaurant in Koreatown - hands down. The line is extremely intimidating as it's usually out the door every night, but don't worry - they move quick here. I would not recommend coming here in groups of more than 4... it's an optimal if you have a party of 2 and they can seat you quicker. Our wait for 2 on a Saturday evening was around 15-20 minutes, which is amazing.The atmosphere reminds me of a restaurant in Chinatown or something - they want you out as fast as possible to serve other people, so service is a little rushed and frantic. I wouldn't come here expecting too much out of service, but they still get the job done. I don't mind... that just means I get seated faster! Overall service is acceptable, but could be better. The restaurant is loud and bustling, but not so much to the point where you feel the need to scream over the table to talk. The music is top-40 which is interesting for a restaurant on this street.I've eaten here a couple times now and each time, the food has been amazing. I love me some soups and stews and Five Senses has a ton to choose from. Their Seolleongtang (ox bone broth), mul naengmyeon (cold noodles in broth), and yukgaejang (spicy beef stew) were all very flavorful and some of the best I've had, especially the cold noodles. They are a little pricier than their competitors, but I guess you pay for the quality and the servings are pretty large. I have also had the spicy double fried chicken and it's comparable, if not better, than your usual Kyochon or Bonchon - the outside is very, very crispy and it packs a lot more heat than it looks.Come for the food, ignore the dodgy service (I gave them the benefit of the doubt), and keep returning, because this stuff's the real deal.

Service 9/10They got a little antsy near the end of our dinner, but there was still an hr before they closed. Don't rush me when i'm eating :I But otherwise, everything else about service was excellentFood:Quail eggs- 10/10Delicious Blue crab & shrimp dumpling- 6/10Could have done without. Was very blah. Yellow fin spicy tuna tartare- 11/10This was so good. Best thing we ordered. My dining companion usually is skeptical about tartare or anything thats not cooked (he's very uncultured), but he too, could not deny this masterpiece of food. Pan seared duck breast green curry- 10/10Perfectly cooked. I almost gobbled up the whole thing.Pad Thai jumbo tiger prawn- 10/10Yumm

I was reading an article about Colbert becoming the new host of the Late Show, and they mentioned interviewing Jon Stewart while he was at Chalk Point Kitchen drinking a Red Stripe. So obviously we had to go and check it out (stalk) for ourselves. We didn't find Jon Stewart there, but we did find ourselves a great new restaurant.I'll quickly cover the non-food items first to get that stuff out of the way. I was a fan of the overall aesthetic of the restaurant, even if it might be a bit too urban farmhouse kitschy for some. Service was exceptional as judged by the ice water never less than half full test. I also got some excellent recommendations from our waiter which I'll cover now.Market Heirloom Tomatoes & Lioni's Old Fashioned Ricotta - As described. This isn't anything fancy, but it certainly was a very good representation of the farm-to-table concept being sold by the restaurant. Sometimes just fresh, high-quality ingredients speak for themselves.Maine Uni Crudo - Uni is the new bacon apparently! If you see an item on the menu with uni, you just order it. Icelandic Arctic Char - AWESOME. This was my entree. The fish was prepared perfectly tender with the white miso sauce balanced nicely against the radishes and grapefruit. I normally like to explore the menu a bit when I revisit a place, but I'm fairly certain I'll just order this again the next time I'm here.New York State Grass-Fed Lamb Loin Chops - My very pregnant wife had this and cleaned her plate as well. I had a couple of bites, and the lamb seemed quite tasty, with none of the gamey taste you sometimes get with lamb. Butterscotch Pudding - Scotchy scotch scotch! Yum!Overall, I was impressed not only with the great food, but also with the fact that they didn't seem to have any of the usual struggles a new restaurant has during their first few weeks. It probably helped that we were one of the first diners there when they opened at 6pm, but we'll definitely be back again.

One of the best weekday Midtown lunches I've ever had, bar none. DB was not on my list or anything, but Yelp had a hand in leading me here. When a work buddy and I got the hankering for Korean, we naturally made a beeline to K-Town. None of the joints on West 32nd were calling out to us. We whipped out our magic devices and voila, Don's was only another block's walk.DB is a classy joint, with an upmarket decor perfect for business lunch. The restaurant is spacious and larger than the storefront would suggest. We were led to the back area, which was a tad more casual. The seating is interesting: they have these tatami-like seats with cushions that kind of look subterranean, with your lower limbs disappearing into the floor. Actually, it's quite a snug fit in there.As in other Korean eateries, service was brisk. We got the banchan as soon as we ordered, munching on wonderful nibbles like sauteed spinach, several pickled veggies, and even dry fish flakes (at least that's what I think it was). The lunch specials are excellent, ranging from $12-$16 with a choice of stew (more of a soup). I opted for the DON special (pork belly with stew and rice) accompanied by Haemul-sundubu (spicy seafood and tofu broth). We ordered a couple of Cass lagers (Friday afternoon!) and had a leisurely lunch. I came away very happy. Don's is good eating and stands out from an already very good pack of K-Town restaurants.

Breakfast review. The French love their oeuf's and it's done right at this star of Stephen Starr's restaurant empire. Located in the Blond Hotel(really) this is a glam spot with sumptuous velvet banquettes and velvet baked chairs. Modern chandeliers hang over the space. Fancy French country open kitchen.Ate:Pain au chocolatOeuf's specialCafeThe pain au chocolat arrives warm, made in house. The poached eggs with choron sauce (bernaise with tomato) are perfect served over pomme Darphin- perfectly crisped French hash browns. La Colombe coffee made this a rock star breakfast.

Sweetest bartender, Dania! This is such a cozy bar nestled in the Lower East Side... Perfect for date night at this place. Ended up ordering two munchies off the menu. - Spicy Crispy Chicken Wings: So Delicious. Its spicy but just enough spice if that makes sense. The moment I took a bite out of this, I thought of someone that I wanted to bring but then I remember this weirdo doesn't eat chicken. (teheh)- Fries: Crunchy and just addictive to munch on.I can't really say much about the cocktail list. I ordered my usual Jameson&Ginger and then a Jack&Coke. Surely, I'll be back to munch on the rest of the other items on the menu!

It's been sometime since I've been to a lounge with a DJ that really DJ's. I've been to many in the past, but the DJ at bOb doesn't try squeezing in portions of 12-18 songs within 3.5 minutes. DJ Mika, though seemingly a bit shy, throws a punch with her playlist. I did a teeny bit of DJing and hung out with DJ's back in the day so I know how I like it done. She mixed things up and included some non-commercial radio, hardcore hip-hop from back in the day. It was a breath of fresh air not hearing the same ol' commercial hip hop standards and I have a feeling if she could, she would go deeper into her list of hardcore hits. As most have mentioned, bOb is small, but wasn't too small for us, we took advantage of the space early before the masses headed in and the a/c was pumping providing ample ventilation. Bathroom's are cute as cute goes, set-up has the one sink placed on the outside of the toilet areas, more as a necessity as space is limited. Bartending and busser service was great for us, but certain as the evening progresses things no doubt will get less ventilated, with less room to dance and slower service. But no matter, this is a great spot with a very diverse crowd to dance and dance and dance. Miss Evelin and I finally made it here and we will be back; all are welcome to join if schedules allow. I know my dancing feet are quite happy and will be shuffling my way back to bOb Bar. Happy Hour from 7:00pm-10:00pm$5.00 cover after 10:00pm

I need to quit coming here every week... but damn it's so hard. It's an actual restaurant with sitting areas, it's almost never crowded and you definitely get more options than at the cart vendor. PLUS you can take your meal over to Central Park and have an impromptu picnic!I always get myself small gyro platter with extra meat- no rice ("trying" to be low carb about things) and loads of white sauce. I am always surprised at how generous and filling the portion is! They don't really have the sauce bottles out there for abuse but they really do put on the right amount of sauces - unless you're the type of guy to gorge down a whole bottle of sauce, then this isn't the place for you. They do offer packets of hot sauce for an extra fee, but good lord those are so hot. At least there's also a soda fountain to quench the heat. Sometimes the pay line gets backed up because some patrons either order a large amount or pay in pennies or something. Most times it's a fairly quiet, in and out sort of thing. Either way, beats the long cart line any day.

New and very nice, very cozy gem of an Irish restaurant. While cozy like an Irish pub, it is way too nice and has too much charm and character to fall into a pub category.A fabulous find just away from the hustle and bustle of Times Square and away from the edge of the heart of Hells Kitchen. Fantastic cozy find for family, friends, anyone.Newly renovated, new owners of a previous place. The original closed, was renovated with fabulous taste by new owners, then closed again shortly after for a short period and now is reopened- about 6 weeks ago -- with new enthusiastic owners. Here they are, definitely a fabulous find.Ambiance. Walked in to the warm cozy spot with brick, wood tables, character in the details and a comfortable cozy living room set up in the back with a sofa, comfortable chairs and fresh orchids. Great music playing and 10 tv screens downstairs alone show games, videos, and the entertaining presidential debates entertaining about 70 people last time. A large screen tv upstairs as well.Food and drink. Happy hour Shiraz was good, and I couldn't resist trying the shepards pie potato skins - creative twist on the original and fantastic . Service. Friendly and fantastic service. Irish Irish Irish. The accommodating and friendly bartender Irish and new, the cute friendly waitress just came in from Ireland a couple weeks ago to work there and still staying w friends while she finds a place. The very nice, friendly Irish owner who was a bartender for 17 years turned owner and enthusiastic to share all the details . Definitely recommend and I will definitely go back if and when I'm in the area. If I lived close by, this would definitely be a neighborhood goto spot.

Where to start???? For one, 5 STARS!!!!! So you really don't even need to read this review anymore. But go go go!The cast is amazing and embodied Gloria Estefan and Emilio Estefan amazingly well. She literally looked just like young Gloria Estefan. The plot was a little bit of everything- love, music, happiness, tears, laughter, emotions!The theatre itself is nice, clean and well kept. The seats are incredibly close together and if anyone leaves their seat, everyone they pass have to stand. So only little downside but otherwise great. No food is served, just drinks in cute take home souvenir sippy cups hahaThe cast is interactive and upbeat! A great energy and a great show for a date or girls night. I wouldn't recommend it for kids because the costumes are everyday costumes - not much pizazz so might be tough to keep a kid still through it. But otherwise- go go go! Amazing show!!!!

Having lived in NYC for over 7 years now, there's been a noticeable 'good' dim sum drought - so much so that as a Cantonese person, I would wait for trips back home to California, Vancouver, or Hong Kong to fulfill my cravings. Tim Ho Wan, the well known Michelin starred dim sum chain from Hong Kong, was my renewed hope to change that.Today, December 16, is the soft opening, which will last with staggered hours (10am-3pm; 5pm-10pm) until its grand opening date of January 18. I arrived a little after 12pm and was unfortunately told 40 min later that the the couple in front of me would be the last people that would be seated for lunch. I was devastated but the couple in front of me graciously offered to give me their spot in line because they had to go back to work. This was a recurring theme considering I didn't get seated until around 3:30pm so plan accordingly. They do have a name/cell phone service when you check in that will text you when a table is closer to opening up. It seemed to be having issues today but when things calm down, this would be a great help so you don't have to wait around the entire time, and can do some shopping or get a drink nearby.The space isn't the biggest but it feels bright and comfortable. I believe it only seats 60, with tables and booths optimized for 2-4, so no huge round tables here for you and your extended family. I've been to one of the Tim Ho Wan locations in Hong Kong several times and it was also on the smaller side.Despite the craziness of opening day, the staff remained friendly and calm. Front of staff June and Christina were great, along with our server whose name I didn't get but looked like a young Ming Tsai. More surprisingly was how calm the kitchen staff was (viewable through an open kitchen concept). They were focused like a well-oiled machine, and food came out consistently without large waits. I loved the beautiful marble lazy susan that the kitchen staff and wait staff use to exchange food. We did wait a bit for one dish but I think that was due to it not being put in, which has always happened in general at dim sum places with the checklist/tallying order method.Like any dim sum place, you come for what's good and unique to that specific place. The highlight and namesake was of course their Baked BBQ Pork Buns. They came out hot and fresh out of the oven, and were made more delicious because we were so cold and hungry from waiting outside and it was the first thing that arrived at our table. The topping was crisp and lightly sweet and the inside was perfectly seasoned being both sweet and savory like a good char siu. I also noticed some umami / seaweed / dashi flavor at one point. From what I remember, I think the buns here were even better than the ones I had at Tim Ho Wan's HK location.Other highlights were the Shrimp Dumplings (Har Gow) and the Shrimp and Chives in Rice Roll (Har Cherng). The shrimp were really fresh, sweet, and plump. Again these were served super warm and fresh. I generally prefer the Shrimp Rice Rolls to the pork ones, and this was the case here as well since the BBQ Pork Rice Rolls were a bit forgettable and the pork pieces were cut in large chunks that felt out of place in the dish. Also if you have an aversion to cilantro, don't order the BBQ Pork Rice Rolls. It's common for the meat rice rolls at dim sum places to have cilantro and it exists here as well.Fried Turnip Cakes - these were good too. Not the best I've had but decently seared and the ratio of daikon to flour was good and not overly doughy or plasticy at all.Deep Fried Dumplings with Pork and Shrimp - these have always been a favorite of mine. I generally describe these as meat mochi footballs. These don't reheat well so I'd recommend eating them here instead of taking them home.Vegetable Spring Rolls - really good with lots of mushroom flavor. Only downside was these were on the oily side. Could fry these better or let the oil soak out a bit more.Another unique thing here was the French Toast with Custard. It tastes like a fried souffle sandwich filled with custard.I was really impressed overall, especially given that it was the first day of its soft opening. I could feel how much work was put into the desire for this place to be successful - from the food to the service. I went into this experience just hoping to have a solid dim sum place finally in NYC, but somehow I left feeling happier than I expected. I wasn't expecting to have a sense of camaraderie in line with fellow diners, or that I would feel a sense of warmth from all of the staff especially with how crazy busy today was (you know what I mean when you're accustomed to Chinese or dim sum restaurants where attitude and annoyance is the norm). But it reminded me that the essence of dim sum really is a place to rest, gather with loved ones, and warm your heart (and belly).

Delicious food with impeccable service!The restaurant is a no-tip restaurant, however, the service is better than most of the restaurants that actually mandates tips. How funny! The service definitely makes a huge difference to the entire dining experience. The waiter was so helpful and I really appreciated his help. I loved the seafood tower, absolutely fresh and delicious! Yum!! That's probably the highlight of meal. The saragli (baklava) was so special too. Normally, they are sickly sweet.. Here, they are hand rolled and delicious, not as sweet.

AB-SO-LUTELY. YUP!I am extremely picky with high-end Michelin-type restaurants. I eat at about 3 per week and am mostly unimpressed. I was told that GK was a game changer and quite good. I figured that I had to check it out!First of all, the presentation was amazing. I was blown away. I have eaten at Alinea (in Chicago) where they give you a helium balloon made of apple for dessert and everything is extremely well presented. In NYC I've eaten at almost all of the 3 Michelin starred restaurants and a huge handful of the 1 & 2 starred.GK for NYC takes the cake. In my opinion, it's better than 11 Madison Park, absolutely.I had a cocktail with watermelon and basil which was so light and refreshing. It started my evening off on the most positive note. I have a stomach issue and have extreme reactions especially to acidic drinks, so it was awesome to be able to choose from a menu with an extensive selection of juices and cocktails to choose from.The staff was great. There was one hiccup where a course was swapped (I received the wrong plate and had to switch), but I didn't mind it one bit. Other than that, everything was perfect from start to finish. The waiter had great recommendations and was very accommodating to my stomach issue. It's refreshing because even in some of the very high-end establishments, waiters are not briefed on what allergies mean what (for instance, a lot of the times when I say I have a stomach sensitivity to acid, they bring me a drink with grapefruit or OJ in it which are both extremely acidic). Awesome to know we were in good hands!Now on to the food+ Cured Tasmanian Ocean Trout with sweet peas * parma prosciutto * dill - MUST ORDER. Absolutely heavenly. I tried some of the other starters and this was by far the best.+ FOIE GRAS - Perfectly seared and heavenly. I'm a HUGE fan. + Grilled Maine Lobster - Also heavenly.+ Awakening * Strawberry Rhubarb with poached rhubarb * buttermilk panna cotta * strawberry sorbet - Again, perfect.There were some little things that the waiter brought out (for instance, palate cleansers) which were extremely well presented and tasty. I almost don't even want to post pictures to ruin the surprise. For a special occasion, business dinner, business lunch, any type of lunch/dinner, romantic dinner, or just simply the want to embark on a culinary journey, Gabriel Kreuther is your place!

Absolute favorite bakery in all of Chinatown. They open up extremely early in the morning and work fast getting you what you need.I've only ever had the honey lemon water here and I can honestly say I have not tried any place better. At 2$ for their drink it is cheaper than most of Chinatown by 50 cents and tastes more refreshing. The baked goods here are also delicious as it ranges from .60 cents+.The ladies here always remember their regular and are super sweet as well. Definitely come try this bakery out as even their chicken in lotus leaf is amazing.

What can I say about sushi nakazawa? It is an absolutely amazing experience. Before i make this TLDR, I want to start with the tips. How do I make reservation? You can reserve 30 days in advance online on opentable. MAKE SURE YOU GET ONLINE AT 12:00AM (midnight) 30 days in advance if you want sushi bar experience. Sushi bar or dining room table? I HIGHLY suggest sushi bar experience. Chef Nakazawa interacts directly with those at the sushi bar telling us history behind the different types of sushi and we can take pictures of the entire experience. Also - you can watch all the sous chefs prepping and how they work in tandem. At an extra 30 dollars - it's worth it especially for those who like to take pictures!Designated Times for Sushi Bar - 5pm and 9:30pm. whichever one you decide, make sure to get there 5-10 minutes early as you want to get the center seat right in front of chef nakazawa. Get used to eating with your hand - if you didn't know already - each item is offered one at a time with the correct amount of wasabi in it already and you pick it up with your fingers. i repeat - eat with your fingers. The chopsticks are offered to pick up a slice of ginger to cleanse the palate and prep yourself for the next piece. Don't worry for germ lovers - a finger napkin is provided to wipe your fingers after each sushi piece. Sushi Bar Experience When you walk in - you find the place stunning and it lives up to it's 4 money signs. The place is immaculate. All staff is super cordial. They slide all chairs in/out for you. All staff are wearing business professional (aka suits) and well groomed. The staff is just on point with everything in terms of refilling waters, coming by and asking if we need anything else. The omakase is a 21 piece SUSHI (sorry - need to eat rice for those non-carb eaters). The items are offered one at a time. Chef Nakazawa does an amazing job explaining what type of fish each one he is offering us and tends to interact with the sushi bar really well. He does a good job walking back and forth so everyone can have a fair shot and see what he is pointing at. The sushi is just immaculate. The fish is indescribable. 60% of the fish is from Japan and are changed seasonally based on Japan's weather and depending on what's fresh out there. The other 40% is domestic. I don't know how much I can rave if you have read this far but the craftsmanship by Chef Nakazawa and his staff are absolute artist when it comes to the sushi. Each piece is amazingly laid out. My favorite piece was teh egg custard sushi. This is probably what he is known best for. For those who watched Jiro Dreams of SUshi - Chef Nakazawa was the guy who practiced for 6 years on how to make the egg custard sushi every day. I can absolutely say he perfected it. Price150 dollars/per person for sushi bar experience and 120 for dining room experience. Sake pairing an additional 45 dollars. For those who want the full experience - expect to drop AT LEAST 600 for two people including tip/tax/alcohol.

Having never done one of these escape rooms I sort of had pre-conceived notions; a mix of the movie Saw and a cheesy office room space with a few locks to open.. well that wasn't the case here. From the very beginning when you enter the first door to the "Maze of Hakaina"to get the backstory you are immersed in their world. The basic jist is that you are to enter a Japanese maze to both escape and rescue a boy who got lost in it. Along the way you encounter demons and must solve clues to get from the starting point until the very end (through various rooms). I enjoyed the dim lighting and that the clues were very creative, and went beyond what you may have initially thought. Being in a group of 4 was nice as we worked together and different people pieced together different riddles/clues. I did enjoy the hints that were given, they were good at putting you on the right track. The space itself was very well put together with impressive Japanese artifacts and letters decorating the walls and some very fun props that totally fit the mood. We completed the missions with 30 seconds to spare! Afterward, I enjoyed speaking with the staff on our opinions on what to improve and what we liked, but from my friends who had been to make quest rooms like this, they said this was amongst their favorite. This would be a great team-building activity, fun for a group of friends, or anyone that wants to escape from their phones and reality for 1 hr to get caught up in an adventure. I would surely try some of their other room experiences around NYC.

I confess that a part of me doesn't really want to write this review, because a slightly empty rooftop bar at 8 pm on a Thursday is the equivalent of a $1500 one-bedroom Manhattan apartment or $1 avocados - rare unicorns that must be protected against all disclosure. Skylark has ridiculous views, especially if you can make a reservation and score a table. I love how they turn down the music to just the right level so you don't need to shriek like a banshee in order to have a normal conversation with your friends. I love how the rooftop area isn't ridiculously crowded (in no part because it's still relatively unknown). I love how they were patient enough with the frequent changes in my reservation, and how they kept my table even when my party was 20 minutes late.The food and drinks are pricey but you're definitely paying for the views and the opportunity to lounge on a comfy couch while enjoying said views. From one side, you have an unblocked view of the Hudson. The prickly pear margarita is a godsend on humid August nights. As for food, we tried the $20 Skylark sliders (not worth it IMO for only three sliders), the Peking duck wontons (this was definitely worth it), the guacamole, and the burrata pizzette.For rooftop bars in general, I think it's better to get a dinner beforehand and just come for drinks. Now, please don't tell anyone else.

Rudy's is a quintessential dive bar, so as long as you don't go here expecting anything else, you'll have a great time. The seats are upholstered with red duct tape, there is limited seating, the entire place smells like spilled beer, and the service isn't exactly lavish. The nice thing about Rudy's is that it doesn't pretend to be something it's not. It is unapologetically dirty and crowded, but the drinks are dirt cheap, the vibe is friendly, and you get a free hot dog with every drink. Favorites include the house blonde ale (only $8 for a whole pitcher) and the "beer and a shot" deals (there are a few, including one called the "Mexican hat dance"- for only $5). They have some good beers in bottles and in drafts, too, including the Lagunitas IPA (one of my favorite beers) for a mere $5. You have to ask for the hot dog, but make no mistake- they're totally free. And while they weren't exactly gourmet, they hit the spot and were great with a beer. I've been wanting to check this place out for a long time, and it did not disappoint. Oh, tip: they have a back door to Rudy's "back yard" that allows you to drink your cheap beers in a more open, outdoor location. Really nice during the warm months.

Let me start off by saying YAAAAAAAAAASSSSSSSSSSSSSSSS!I have been living in Harlem a little more than two years, and I didn't make my way to Ricardo's Steak House until yesterday for the first time. My friend and I got there around 8ish on a Tuesday night. There was security outside that was asking if we had a reservation. Kind of bizarre because I thought that was something I would speak with the hostess stand regarding. Anywho we opted to sit at the bar area v.s a table because that is what we prefer. The bar set up contains about 6-8 seats and it is kind of an awkward set up due to half of the bar facing part of the open kitchen and shelving blocking your view, and then the other half of the bar you view is obstructed by large jars of sangria. I believe it is more of a service bar if anything...so don't expect to really know your bartender. I will say the good thing about sitting next to an open kitchen is seeing and watching the food being prepared.For drinks we started off with the Roja Sangria in a carafe which was about $34 and we each got about 2 full glasses out of it. What I loved and appreciated about the Sangria carafe is they did not put ice in the carafe and only in your glass. I hate when I order a carafe from other places and the ice waters down the drink. Smart on your part Ricardo's Steakhouse...well played! Since we were sitting next to the kitchen we got to see ALOT of dishes prepared. At Ricardo's you can really tell not only the servers BUT ALSO the kitchen takes pride in their work. The presentation or plating of the food is out of this world!After drooling over all of the food I decided to get the Shrimp Alfredo penne pasta. Shrimp Alfredo is such a simple dish you can find at any restaurant BUT HONEY THEY KNOCKED IT OUT OF THE PARK! It was well seasoned and the sauce was not thin, but thicker and creamy. I loved every minute of the entree! You ever eat food and get to the last bite and instantly become sad? That happen with me last night. My friend ordered Salmon Al Vodka pasta and she said it would be worth commuting from Brooklyn to Harlem for again.As far as the ambiance it was pretty rockin on a Tuesday evening. Their playlist is awesome from Biggie to Mint Condition to Solange! I think there were 5 people there celebrating their birthday, and each time they would bring out a cake with sparklers on it to some hip hop birthday inspired song ( Rihanna "Cake", Trey Songz "Say Ahh", or 2 Chainz "Birthday Song"). I loved every minute of my experience at Ricardo's Steakhouse. The only thing that is a bummer is there is only one bathroom! Other than that I plan on spending my birthday dinner at Ricardo's SOON!!

We need to talk about Han Sushi.I know what you're thinking - "But Jenn, all delivery sushi places are the same. They're overpriced (or extremely cheap and the sushi is sketchy at best), the food is subpar, and they probably didn't exactly nail your order". NOT HAN, THOUGH. Not Han!I discovered Han Sushi one day on Seamless when I accidentally searched for sushi instead of using their cuisine type feature. Pricing was extremely reasonable, reviews were great, and I hadn't tried it before. Why not? I placed an order. Estimated wait time was 40 minutes or so. Not 20 minutes later, my doorbell rings. That can't be the sushi, right? WRONG. The delivery man RUNS up four flights of stairs to my apartment and hands me the bag. What?Not only that, but the food was outstanding as far as delivery goes. "This must be a fluke" I tell myself as I stuff my face with a tuna roll. "This was a one time thing".I now have ordered from this place 30+ times and only ONCE did anything deviate from the exact situation described above (sushi guy running up the stairs and all- that guys is awesome and you will love him). One time, my food was late. And by late I mean MAYBE 15 minutes late. I am not exaggerating, the delivery man apologized to me three times. The same guy who never judges me for ordering enough food for 5 people even though he clearly sees it's just for me. Fast, fresh, and NEVER forgets my extra side of ginger dressing. "A" for Han Sushi... And A+ for awesome delivery man.

Having patronized this restaurant growing up in the LES, I have gone through about four different closures/rebranding of this restaurant to its current iteration. Good Cantonese food in Chinatown is becoming more and more of a relic in recent years, but Wu's remain one of the best that the Manhattan has to offer. Solid selection of noodle soups, rice plates, stir-fried dishes, and dim sum will forever allow this spot to be a popular fixture for locals. The new renovations are a welcomed upgrade as brightness and cleanliness appear to be focal points. Prices have certainly gone up a bit, but value at Wu's will still be as good as it gets even in Chinatown.

As a huge ice cream lover, I am so blessed to get a birthday ice cream cake from Sundaes and Cones!!! Thank you Elaine!! Not gonna to lie - This cute one coming in hazelnut and chocolate flavors will be so hard to beat! It's dense and yummy - with strong hazelnut aroma (guys prepare a real knife so you can cut it easier). How good it really is?--We all agreed that we can finish a quarter of the 6 inches cake on our owns! Thank you S&C for the wonderful cake!

Depending on what area of town you're in - independent coffeeshops can be a warm and fuzzy haven. Grumpy is no exception... and other than the logo, no one here is actually, well, grumpy. If you work in midtown, the café is a respite from your office, and from the noisy streets of Times Square and Herald Square surrounding it. Grumpy truly serves a fantastic espresso - I usually get a soy latte (and yes, they've got almond milk, too). Though, keep in mind ICED lattes are 50 cents extra. They roast their own beans and every cup packs a punch. I come here on a regular basis, and personally speaking, of Grumpy's seven locations, this one has the best energy and overall fun baristas. Grumpy also has many carb-heavy pastries. And, as it is with many of their cafés, this Grumpy is laptop-free. While many may see this as a negative, it keeps the tables open for the midtown latte aficionados and there is usually a place to sit if you want to chill for a bit.

I walked up and down 125th Street looking for 4 lb. tub of Mizani relaxer. I know the trend is natural, but this is sheer laziness on my part. Yes, laziness. Natural hair takes time and the kind of skill I just don't have, or salon money I don't have either. So Creamy Crack it is. At $27.99 for a tub that will last me until next year, it's the best value around. Those $40 dusty tubs the other stores had... ha! It was the same story with the neutralizing shampoo. $20 to Feel's $16. Get out of here! Sure I'd love someone else to do my hair, but at $60+ before tipping the stylist and the shampooer... nah, I'll just Vaseline my hairline and go to town on myself.By the by, all the Mizani isn't together. It's usually in a section by the cashier because that brand is rife with high shrinkage items. This tub was with the other tubs in the aisle. Just ask the really tall, really friendly guy working the floor.

Surprisingly good! It's amazing how this shop has not gotten the buzz and food sites write ups. It should be on everyone's list! The price points on each dish is great. Affordable for the fresh seafood and/or curry dishes. Service was wonderful and you could see it's family owned vibe.I went with the ahi tuna bowl with brown rice. All ingredients were fresh and the tuna was seared perfectly with a large portion of tuna. The accompanying ingredients all matched well for the bowl such as the garlic chips, asago, seaweed salad, and pickled vegetables. Filling and satisfying for a meal. Small spot with a long table and a table for two with most folks either taking our or eating quickly.I'll definitely be back and will go for the curry katsu next.

I'll just start off by saying this place is great! For anyone that doesn't know Dinnertable is like a reverse speakeasy of sorts. There is a bar in the front, and then there is a curtain in the back that hides a little restaurant. There's no real signage or anything for it, so if you don't know it's there, you probably would never guess. My friend and I talked about going Saturday night. We weren't really sure what the wait would be like, so we decided to get there around 8, since we assumed there would be some sort of a wait, and we could just put our names down and grab a drink out front at the Garrett. So we showed up about ten to 8:00 and were actually seated right away. The place is pretty small. There's one long communal table, maybe 2 or 3 two-top tables, and then some seating at the bar which faces the open kitchen where you can see them cooking. The place wasn't too crowded at 8:00, but as the night went on the place filled up. Our waiter came over to ask about our water preference, and explaind the menu a bit. It was mostly smaller plates, with a few big ones. He suggested we get two little plates, two big plates, and share everything. We browsed through the menu, and decided to get the lasagna bolo for two as our main to share, the short rib tartare, and the shrimp crudo dish. I am generally not a fan of meat that is tartare or carpaccio (aka raw) but my friend wanted to try the short rib tartare, so I thought I'd give it a try. No regrets! It was really good. It was 4 crackers/toasts with a generous portion of the short rib on top. It says there was horseradish in it, but the taste was not that strong, which I liked. The shrimp crudo was also really good, a nice refreshing dish. Then the lasagna bolo came out, which was amazing! It was so cute; it came out in a dish with about 5 rolled up lasagnas, and plenty of ricotta cheese. Seriously, so good! After all that food we were stuffed, and couldn't possibly eat dessert. Overall everything was great! The food was top notch, as well as the service. I will say the drink selection compared to the bar it's attached to was slim, but I went with a glass of Rose so that wasn't an issue for me. Since the menu isn't huge, I might wait a bit for them to change it up, but I would definitely go back!

The Oculus is a truly majestic creation,15 years and $4 billion dollars later. Definitely a "must see" amongst all of the glory of the new architectural landscape of downtown Manhattan. There are many shops and eateries in the plans. Right now, one can walk within the World Trade Center across from Broadway completely underground straight through to Brookfield Place on the far west side. All major train connections are there (2, 3, 4, 5, A,C,J, Z, E,N,R) including the PATH to NJ. The Oculus is our welcome downtown version of Grand Central and Penn Station.

Staff were so nice and friendly!!! I went for the Rad Thai, nice sesame flavored dressing. With tons of big pieces of shrimp. Very filling. Some might say it's expensive but for the size and quality I think it's great. But what I liked most actually were the drinks! Tried the cucumber lime ginger fresca and it was delicious. All the drinks are housemade and sugar free.

I am absolutely LIVING for The Dead Rabbit! What an amazing spot with such excellent, gracious staff! I had been many times to the first floor, which is very fun but always crowded. It's so crowded it detracts from amazing drinks and excellent service from the bartenders.At our most recent trip, the bouncer made small talk with us as he was checking our IDs. Prolly cuz Pete and I are old AF and he didn't have to look that hard. He lead us to a MUCH different room upstairs - not at all crowded, classy seating, same great drinks and gracious bartenders. The drinks here are $16 each which is more than I spend on most whole bottles of wine. I don't care. Get a delicious drink here. It is so worth it. My drink had like 90 ingredients including Aperol. The bartender gave us complimentary sparkling water, which was a nice touch.The bill came to more than what we had recently spent on dinner and it was worth every cent. I'll be back and I'll be grateful for the experience.

Oh my god. For every dessert person, this place is the definition of heaven. I saw the high rating and was a bit skeptical because although the taste, texture and everything about this dessert was amazing; it is not the most photogenic and looks very average. But I can tell you for sure, the making of this dessert and everything about the ingredients taste very very refined. This is an art, and to make the merveilleux looks extremely difficult even for the best of pastry chefs. I got the chocolate one, ate it in the corner and came back to try the coffee one as well after 5 minutes. It is just absolutely amazingly light, crumbles in the right way and sweet enough to melt anyones troubles away. The chocolate tastes alike to the quality of the best chocolatiers and meringue just shattered in the most fragile way. I also got the chocolate chip brioche, which was a miracle in itself. The star of the show was the meringue but the brioche was also amazingly fluffy and buttery and the chocolate was amazing. Tasted fresh out of the oven. One of the best bakeries to check out in the city. This is after having been to the most hyped up places and I can tell you for sure, this is one of the most impressive dessert shops I have had the pleasure of frequenting in the city. I would give them more than 5 stars if I could. Not even speaking of the great service as the cashier who worked there threw in an extra mini brioche bc she saw how I was eyeing the pastries. I thoroughly enjoyed my experience here and can rave about this place for ages if needed. Amazing experience

I'm so happy there's a cat cafe in New York. It basically saves me a trip to Japan. Except, in Japan those cat cafes don't charge hourly but alas the money is going to a good cause. I came in late afternoon on Tuesday and this place was empty. Great for me because that means all the cats are mine. When you walk in they tell you it's $6 per half hour (a dollar more than when they opened), you pay at the end, and they warned me when my half hour was almost done (although, I don't think they warn you normally. So, keep a watch on your clock). You then sign a waiver, take off your shoes, sanitize, and play with all the cats you desire. You can also order drinks and snacks and the people will deliver it to you. They provide you toys that you can use to play with the cats and an array of seats and tables you can sit at to watch all the cats you want. I was reading some of the other reviews and one of the reasons why people wouldn't rate it so low is because the cats are asleep and not as enthusiastic when they see people. I wonder why that is. Oh, it's because they're cats. Not dogs. Cat's have all different personalities some can be very trusting and loving and others need time to warm up to you. So, you might need some patience but the workers there are knowledgeable to tell you which cats are more willing to play with you, which cats you can pick up, and which cats are more of a lone wolf. They know each cat and the story of how they got to the shelter and they're all up for a forever home! This is an amazing place and I'm going to bring all my friends here who need a furry little friend! I mean who wouldn't benefit from a cat in their life?

Super excited to write this review and post pictures! Located in Seaport, this ipic theater took over the old market place where Gap used to be. This is by far the best theater I've been to. The closest experience I've ever had is with AMC dine in theater and that doesn't really compare with this one. Of course here, I'm paying $29 pp and kind of expect this to be better than AMCs dine in. Reserved seatings here as well so you don't need to rush to get good seats. You walk in and what's great about this is the ticket kiosk. Sure they now have these in different theaters, but their machine looked really new and fancy. Not only does it print out your ticket, but if you purchased the premium + seats (waiter, reclining seats, unlimited popcorn), the kiosk will print out a "complimentary popcorn" ticket which means unlimited popcorn. If you bought the premium + seats, they automatically bring you popcorn anyways so technically you don't need that popcorn ticket. Going up the escalators: Wow, such pretty designs and artwork.
