The theater corridor was so pretty and there were waiters standing in front of each theater room professionally waiting to serve customers. Now we are in the theater: A couples pod with 2 seats that recline. You get a pillow and blankie :) very awesome since we all know theaters can get chilly...way to cozy up. Only thing is that the arm rest in between the 2 seats do not go up so fellas, there's no snuggling up with the gals :P You have a cup holder next to the seats, a swiveling table to share. All of these things mentioned are the premium + seats. The waiter service that comes with these seats were great. They were friendly, pretty quick with responsiveness when you hit the service light, and efficient. No complaints here. 2 minor things: I wish they had utensils, but most of the food items on the menu were finger foods and I wish they didn't run out of certain foods on the menu because I wanted to try everything. Food was really good even though most were finger foods. The sauces that came with the items were really good and unique (pictures posted). All the orange seats are the premium + seats. There is one row of orange seats in front of the pods that are also premium + where a larger group can all sit together. Only difference between that and the pods is that the row has no cup holders, but whatever. The tan seats are all the way up front, called premium seats. They are cheaper of course because the chairs don't recline, there's no waiter, no popcorn, no pillow, no blankie and of course, too close to the screen so basically aren't really worth sitting at to be honest. If I had to choose those seats, I'd rather do a regular theater. If you are going to come to ipic, then go hard or go home lol. Dont be cheapy cheapy lol. After the movie or even before, go upstairs to the bar on the 3rd floor (also where bathrooms are located). This theater is the perfect place to bring a date. Eat dinner while watching a movie, then head upstairs for drinks right after. Overall, I would definitely come back to enjoy a great big popular film, but wouldn't do this for every movie. It was a wonderful experience and hopefully it wouldn't be too hard to get tickets in the future.

So check out my review for Fox & Jane UWS, because I followed my amazing stylist, Jackie to the LES location. My first review for her is as true as ever. She is amazing with color and cuts. I haven't always had colorists who I think are the best at cutting my hair and have had to go to a couple of different people to achieve the look I want. Not with Jackie, she colors and cuts perfectly. Plus her blowouts are the best. I never leave there thinking I have to go home and style it differently. I just wish I could have her blowout my hair every 2 days. That's how awesome she is. Always look forward to my appointments with her!

Let me set the scene for you: you're strolling through Chelsea Market, you pass by this long line and see it's for Los Tacos No.1. You roll your eyes and wonder if it's worth it.... let me tell you. IT IS.I am a California native that spent five years in the LA taco scene. I know my way around a taco. I know what's real. And... LTN1... it's amazing. This is hands down on of the few real tacos in NYC. If tacos are what you want, LTN1 is where you get them. And they will be filling and delicious.This is what you need to know:1. Be prepared to wait. It'll happen. Just plot what you want to get.2. Quesadillas here are basically more taco than anything.3. The carne. Always yes.4. You want chips and guac. Why deny yourself the finer things?5. Horchata game is pretty strong.6. $10 credit card minimum.7. Just do it.

I am a SUCKER for that little "hot and new" symbol on Yelp... that's how I ended up at Thai Villa. Was having drinks with real-life friend and fellow Yelper Desi M. at Wined Up when we decided to come here for food.I called ahead to secure a table, and we were seated right away. The place was bustling, and it felt a little like walking into a sexy thai lair, with gold leaves dangling from the ceiling and cozy harem-like booths lining the walls.We both had glasses of wine. The chef was sending out an amuse bouche to all tables - Ma Hor, a little pineapple segment with a thai meatball on top. It was sweet and savory and soft and firm and a nice introduction to the meal and to the restaurant. We also got complimentary taro chips, which helped take the spicy edge off of some of the food later! The menu is cool, opening from the middle with three sections. Despite the cool look, I was unfortunately unclear on what each of the sections meant. There is "Preferred, Signature, and Classic." I was clear that Classic is "regular shit for your stupid American palates" but not on the difference between Preferred and Signature. Is one better? I want to order from the better one! Our server (Lin?) was super cute and friendly. We started off with the chicken in pandan leaves. I don't know what that is, but I know it means the chicken was SUPER moist and yummy from being cooked while all wrapped up. We also had the spicy chicken wings, solid. For our entree, we shared the Kaeng Run Juan, which our server recommended. It was spicy and lemongrassy and perfect. We did not have room for dessert, and after dinner plus happy hour, I was drunk off my ass. But I HIGHLY recommend Thai Villa and look forward to returning soon!

I was absolutely blown away by the level of service here. Sat at the bar for Happy Hour, which runs from 5-7, and had a great experience with both drinks and service.What drew us here was the attractively priced Happy Hour, but I'd definitely return to try the food. Plates kept passing us that looked and smelled amazing, and the fare goes well beyond your typical offerings. Yucca dishes, feijoada, shrimp...they really have a great variety.CAIPIRINHAS ($7 on HH):We came for the $7 caipirinhas and did not leave disappointed. Caipirinhas are hard to come by in general, let alone on happy hour menus, and that made Samba stand out among all the other HH's in Hell's Kitchen. For the uninitiated (and believe me, you want to be initiated), these simple drinks are made with cachaca (Brazilian sugarcane rum), sugar, and lime. Think of them as a more intense variant on mojitos. Samba offers their caipirinhas in a couple different flavors: currently they have coconut, passion fruit, strawberry, and lime. I can't recommend the coconut one highly enough. If you're a fan of creamy drinks, this one's for you. They use coconut milk rather than just flavoring it with a coconut syrup, and this gives it a fantastic consistency and rich taste.Last but not least, I have to sing the praises of the husband-wife duo that run Samba and man the bar. Not only are they genuinely sweet, but they're highly skilled and provide excellent service. They truly make guests feel at home. Bertha was wonderful to speak with as we sat at the bar for almost 2 hours. When we were curious about a couple drinks (the passion fruit caipirinha and cashew juice), she even offered us samples! Just wonderful, wonderful service, the kind that certainly does not go unnoticed and will bring them many loyal customers. Overall, I'm so happy you're in the neighborhood Samba! Can't wait to be back.

Love this Japanese izakaya spot. Located on top of Nitecap, this place can easily come across as a speakeasy where the entrance looks like an entrance to an apartment building. You need to buzz in to enter the restaurant. The space is dim and very cozy with meditative music (Japanese style) playing in the background. The food was excellent, however quite small in portion. Our server was very professional and attentive. We stayed past closing and he didn't even say anything nor tried to kick us out. Would definitely come back again. Spicy Cod Roe - they shaped it to look like sausages. It tasted like sausage too.Ika no Uni Ae (Squid sashimi mixed with uni) - So creamy and yummy with rich uni flavor. Absolutely love this dish. Uni sashimi - Only 3-4 pieces but the flavor is just right. Love it!!Kinoko Toban Yaki - Warm and yummy. Love the texture and flavor. Uni over rice cake - I'm not a rice cake fan so it was okay. Mackerel sashimi - By far the best Mackerel I ever had. The pieces are so tiny but the flavor and texture are so good. Saki pudding - There's a few gold flakes on it but love the flavor...it goes from the bitterness of the saki to the sweetness of the pudding.Almond pudding - I really like the creaminess of the almond milk on the pudding. You eat it by putting the pudding on your dish and pour the creamy almond milk over it and add the strawberriesP.S.: Some seats have a large cabinet where you can store your stuff while dinning in. Overall 4.5 stars...minus 0.5 stars because the portions are so tiny.

I booked for a mani and pedi. It's $30 (really reasonable for the area!) and special nail polishes cost extra. They have a decently wide range of OPI and Essie options, gels, and Essie "longer lasting" options (for $3 extra). It's a tiny shop with only 3 massage/pedicure chairs, but Nam is very warm and so are the other manicurists, and my new nails look awesome. The chairs have a variety of charging cables for your apple devices. The topper is when I was about to walk out with the cheap temporary foam flip flops, and they stopped me. They gave me a pair of real flip flops... $3 they say. I had only put $40 in the front pocket of my purse for the mani/pedi+tip and I started to rummage through my purse for $3. They stopped me again... "No you'll ruin your nails. Next time." You bet I'll be back for next time! Not only do I love supporting smaller shops, but I really enjoy their customer service.

If you are into ramen then Mososan is your Mecca. The broth is on the thicker and soupier side than your typical ramen joint. Thicker in this case translates into more flavor. Momosan's high-point is that their noodles maintain their texture and do not become soggy. Apparently--and per the educational menu--there's a term for this but I don't remember what is that term. Best gyozas ever! I typically burn the roof of my mouth because I don't have the patience to wait for the gyozas to cool down once they arrive (served in a rectangular sizzling-hot cast-iron plate). Staff is great!. What sucks about Momosan are the long queues. If it weren't for the wait Momoson would be elevated to ramen Utopia from ramen Mecca. You know what they say: all good things to those who wait.

Pocion is a tide-bringer in the area of Washington Heights; a neighborhood one would not normally find synonymous with such terms as "high end lounge", "premium cocktails" or "expertly crafted and presented dishes" let alone the dreaded V-word (vegan, of course!)When I had first heard about Pocion opening up, Uptown's first all vegan-fare restaurant I was beyond excited. When I found out it would be tapas and cocktails that excitement went to the power of ^10 and I could barely contain myself.Fast forward a couple months since their debut, and I am totally smitten with this small eatery in the heart of WaHi. The owners spared no expense going to the nines with the decor and this place is popping! Walking distance from NYP hospital where I work,it has become "the spot" on the occasions I work evenings (usually I work overnight shift) and being nearby my house in Hamilton Heights / W Harlem it is a no-brainer. They even usually have live music or even a DJ!The fresh cold pressed juice cocktails are to die for and they make a heavy pour with some good hooch that blends splendidly with the flavors of real fruit juice, instead of some gross reconstituted fruit syrup flavoring with HFCS and other flavorings that is known only by god and Monsanto.I've had pretty much every dish here and none of them fail to disappoint. Like, seriously, everything is amazing^10. Another reviewer mentioned that they are pricey but it's actually pretty standard prices for tapas, if not even a little less. Dude, omg get the creme brulee and thank me later.f

This place has become my favorite ice cream spot in Chinatown! Their menu is both unique and inventive - my personal favorite is the straight outta Japan. The matcha pairs perfectly with the black sesame!! Neither flavor is too over powering in my opinion. The staff is also super friendly and easy to talk to. They were all great at explaining what Taiyaki is and what their favorite combinations are. I've never seen a dessert restaurant like this, and I will definitely be coming back! The hype is pretty intense right now, so expect long lines. Management made the grand opening worth it with BOGO deals and free soft serve during the wait. Overall, I had the best experience at Taiyaki and I would highly recommend checking it out!!!

So I've done Kamayan here 4x and the rest of my visits were for the usual menu. I'll split my review between the two.Kamayan:   Kamayan is done on Wednesday and Thursday nights for parties of 4 or more, for $55/pp, and on any other night for parties of 10 or more, for $65/pp. The prices include tax and tip, but not drinks. On my most recent Kamayan it was $92/pp on a Sunday for 13 ppl with everyone having one drink each. Kamayan reservations are ONLY done through email. Whoever is doing the organizing will be the one who emails them with the information of date, time, and number of people in the party. From there they will email you back with their availability, if it is the exact time or very close to it, then they will also email you the information on pre-ordering your dinner. They usually allow a good 24hrs to get it all in order, as you also must place a credit card in. So if you're the one coordinating the dinner, then it is best that you know of any dietary restrictions ahead of time. When most of the party arrives, they usually start setting up the table at this point, and will be one of the longest 20-30mins ever since you can smell and sometimes see all the amazing food being set up, but you can't touch it yet. The table will be fully set up with all the hot food you pre-ordered, DON'T FORGET TO TAKE PICTURES at this point, if you want them. Once everyone is seated the servers will come around with wet towels to wipe your hands with, and to keep so that you may use them to wipe your fingers with throughout the dinner. The servers will also gladly do a demo for you on the correct way to eat, and if you aren't sure, maybe checkout YouTube or ask a fellow Filipino friend to show you =P. Just remember to, one, clean your nails as well, so if you have cracked polish or etc, then it is best to "take care" of all that before coming to the Kamayan; and two, your fingers should never touch your lips/go in your mouth/be licked. The food is ALL being shared, so be courteous and try not to put your saliva everywhere. After everyone is done with the hot food they will pass out to-go containers for anyone who wants to take home any leftover food there may be. Then they give out halo-halo for dessert. The dinner itself is quite expensive just taking into consideration the amount of food you are getting and etc, however what you are also paying for is the experience, and this is why I've done Kamayan so many times.Usual Menu:   Jeepney has a nice backyard area where you can also enjoy your meal, and feels great on those cool Fall days/nights. We usually prefer to sit in the back if trying to have a good conversation amongst the group as it can get really loud inside. The bar is very lively, and not much elbow room if trying to have a meal. Their usual menu is filled with delicious Filipino dishes and nothing has yet to disappoint. The restaurant is actually quite small, so be prepared for a wait if you do not have reservations.The only downside I can think of is the fact that they aren't open late so I can get a -silog fix after a late night of being out/drinking. Jeepney, you should consider just being 24hrs ;)

Yanza Shoe Repair is located on 9th ave between 57 and 58 and if you blink, you'll miss it. It's a no-frills nothing-like-Leather-Spa type of place, but you definitely get your bang for your buck.For $25 (even, if you pay cash, but including tax if you pay with a credit card), I got the soles and heel of my Chanel ballerina flats replaced in 2 days. They also used Vibram rubber, which I'm sure if that was supposed to cost extra since I specifically asked when I dropped them off and they said it did. I got it anyways!Great quality and craftmanship - my Chanels looked brand new after they finished shining the leather. The scuff marks that were on the patent leather part on the toe completely vanished!It's really a no frills place like I said - you're in, you get quoted, you leave your shoes, and you pick them up in a couple days. That's that. However for the price and quality, this place is top notch and I will be bringing my other shoes to them.

Lots to choose from at Madison Square Eats--many yummy options. Yesterday I finally tried one scoop of amazing ice cream from ICE & VICE. I had one scoop of "MILK MONEY" ice cream in a cup. $5. Absolutely delicious because you can taste the richness of the flavors. This was a creamy, rich vanilla base with a very rich, deep chocolate gianduja swirled thru. EXCELLENT!! SEE MY PHOTOS.I was sorry that I was too late to try the original "Food Baby NYC Ice Cream"---it was a limited time only. It looked so darn good in the photo reviews. FoodBabyNYC is on Instagram, and is also one of the VERY popular reviewers on YELP. I'm a fan of his reviews. Well, maybe Ice & Vice will bring back FoodBaby Ice Cream for a longer, limited time, so I may have a chance to try it, with my wacky work schedule. IT IS SUMMERTIME NOW, AFTER ALL. Ice & Vice, can you please bring it back??

Ah Sweetgreen, I want to make sweet.... well let's not get too crazy here! Seriously, Chopt and Just Salad there is a new sheriff in town and his name is Sweetgreen! This place is AHHMAZING! They have the typical create your own salad along with their signature salads and bowls but where they stand out is that they list the farm where every ingredient is sourced from. Now to some, where your food is sourced from may not be important and may appear to be upper east side mom elitism at its best. My answer to that is Hell Yes!! I want to know where my family's food is coming from! Back to the salads! We had:Chicken Kale Caesar Salad - Delicious!Apple Cheddar Kale Salad - Delicious!The multi grain bread included with the salads was terrific. They also have a wide array of healthy beverages - iced teas and lemonades.There is a small seating area but be warned, this place gets super busy at lunchtime due to all the hospitals in walking distance. The lines don't get that crazy because the staff is extremely efficient and keeps a good pace filling orders. The bathroom is also extremely clean.Sweetgreen, I think this is the start of a beautiful friendship!

Literally so cute. The food is delicious and service was great. We had a little corner table and few glasses of wine with our meal and thoroughly enjoyed everything. You kind of feel like you're in a little Parisian bistro!It's not a huge space so I'm assuming a reservation is recommended if you're going during prime time. Those who complain about portion size must not understand that French cuisine is more about the taste and presentation than it is about filling your stomach. Will most definitely be returning.

Sometimes I walk out of here feeling so powerful and strong. And other times, I walk out, smelling like crap, and my clothes are drenched like I just got stuck in a thunderstorm from all the sweat that comes off of me. I am not a runner, and it scares me that my short legs are like a corgi on a treadmill, while I have all these super sexy hot people with long legs making running look like walking, (also baring it all in the locker room, which hey- go you, if you got a nicer ass than jlo I would walk around naked everywhere). Kid you not, I've never sweated so much in a span of 50 minutes, and that's why I keep running (crawling) back.The instructors give you a range of speed which the whole class will follow. I've caught myself going on the slower end compared to most people, so for those who aren't runners like me--the room divides and there's a hidden corner where you can run (or cry)...spot 24/25 are the best to hide!The lights are also very dim, so there's a part of me I like how no one can watch my face cringe with my tongue sticking out and my facial expressions of running like I'm giving birth. And the other part of me felt like I was running in a dream, and I was on molly with these red lights and loud music.Also, I never leave without having my Plain Jane Chocolate protein shake. The best shake I've ever had, and it has the least amount of calories and it's also so so addicting. Sometimes when I'm in the neighborhood, or I'm at another workout class, I'll walk over to Barry's and get me a PJC, reasonably priced as well.And thank you kind workout fellow friends, I dropped my Gucci glasses in the women's locker room, and someone was kind enough not to snatch it, and they brought it up to the front desk. So bless your honest heart, where kind, happy, endorphin-filled people come and hang out.

Who: Flatiron residents, tinder dates & Gansevoort guestsWhat: Food- Contemporary Italian food, food comes in manageable portions (you do NOT eat until you hurt as you would at The Palm)Drinks - Nice selection of wine and cocktails. Bar seating full of tipsy tinder dates. When: I went here for dinner, but I could see this being a great place to grab happy hour drinks or come to lunchWhere: East side of 28th street (outdoor seating caters nicely to those who like to people watch)Why: Simple Italian food in a very contemporary setting. The noise level is low.

This place is tiny (it seats 9 people), and you'll most certainly bump elbows with those next to you while using your knife, but the food and atmosphere are very worth it. The focus seems to be more on take-out and delivery, but the quirky atmosphere and eclectic music (from xylophone music to jazz), is not to be missed. We came here around 7pm on a Thursday, and were seated immediately. The menu is simple--choose a main, a sauce, and two sides. The actual food presented on adorable partitioned plates, though, is anything but simple. Everything is well-executed and I'm hoping to come back soon to try more combinations. You can also opt to order as many of the sides a la carte, if you'd like. Mains: - Rotisserie chicken: I opted for the Romesco sauce to complement this crispy-on-the-outside-but-insanely-juicy-on-the-inside main. No part was dry, and the nutty-sweet sauce added another dimension and some necessary texture. I was surprised with how many pieces of chicken were on my plate, and loved that one of the chicken bones had a paper handle.  - Swedish meatballs: These already come with a creamy, thin gravy, so there was no need to order extra sauce. The meatballs were already flavorful on their own, with sweet browned bits and a juicy center. Seven meatballs came on a plate.Sides:  - Soup: The soup was one of the best gazpachos I've ever had. There was a hint of rose, and a hint of mint which resulted in a refreshing, developed soup that never once bored my taste buds. It wasn't as strained as I would have liked, but the flavor was on-point.  - Pasta: Ricotta gnocchi with crème fraîche. No complaints here given the combination.   - Pickled beets: These came with herbed goat cheese and candied walnuts. Solid.  - Pattypan squash parm: First of all, I learned about a new squash variety. Second of all, the size and shape made it perfect for a small parm side. Warm and homey. We had the root beer float for dessert because we are children. - - -Likelihood of another visit:Very likely. I hope it doesn't get too popular too soon!

New Fun , Funkadelic addition to the upper east side. Nothing like this upper east with a 70's inspired theme, movies playing and a funky disco type ball and lights creatively lighting up the back area of the bar and small dance floor. A downtown type bar brought uptown.The owners' objective was to make a fun neighborhood feeling bar, where everyone feels welcome: that they've done with their fantastic, friendly service and incredibly rad red 70's theme and decor. The layout is great: Tables along the side and a long amazingly decorated bar are great for sitting and having conversation, disco type dance area in back, and (a little later in the night) entertainers dancing in the front bar area. Also tables outside if you're more into people watching.They are developing a lineup of entertainment many days of the week including dancers some nights, comedians one night a week, and a gay inspired night Mondays. Two Gogo dancers came on around 9 dancing in two designated spots one visible from an open window facing 2nd avenue as passers by snapped photos - entertaining without being over the top or distracting since they stayed in one spot. The managers really are impressively passionate and excited about Ethyl's: friendly, present, so eager to talk about the thought that went into the decor and bringing this downtown type spot uptown. Adam in particular was extremely enthusiastic and even dances thru the bar while mingling and checking in on customers. I had a Hotpants Punch off the menu - very good and I'm eager to try the Mezcel drink they're putting on the menu.They also have a solid food menu with a born and raised New Yorker Chef (Paul Gerard) who has anImpressive list of experience and drove much of the concept of Ethyl's and its 70's based theme and decor . This visit we just had a cocktail, and I'm looking forward to going back for food another time.Highly recommend as a fun spot that's definitely unique to the upper east side.

Hot new spot down on the LES. Love it!private sauna // infra red treatmentsWant to Lose weight & Relax??Relieve Aches & Pains??Make your way through the Alchemist Kitchen and as you walk downstairs you'll find an pleasant new surprise... A Higher Dose of detox!Full spectrum infra red.If you google benefits for infra red sauna and read the results there is no doubt you'll want to stop by and try it out.Detox is something every New Yorker could use, and what better way than being your own DJ in a private room, relaxing, and quite possibly meditating for 30 minutes to an hour?Or maybe an infra red wrap treatment for two.There was incredible the amount of sweat which came out during my treatment, and at the same time I could breathe, and didn't feel too hot. I left feeling better than when I came! Will definitely be back perhaps a package is in my future.Would be nice if there were more locations, a girl can dream right?The Scene: Hip & HealthyDestination Rating: 10Date Rating: 8Hob Nob Potential: 3Strong Suggestion: leave some extra time to explore the alchemists kitchen, they have some great stuff.

Christina Tosi (of Milkbar fame) and Andrew Rudolf (of Per Se fame) recently opened this little slice of heaven.The concept here is Kellogg's cereals with newfangled creations from Christina. Pick your pleasure: do you want Rice Krispies with strawberries and green tea powder. Frosted Mini Wheats with raspberries and ground coffee, Corn Pops with blueberry jam, lemon and salt? All of that is served with a jug of Five Acre Farms Milk. Concerned about your inability to digest dairy? Don't sweat, they have soy for $1 extra. Maybe you want something a little bit crazier, in which case you want a dessertier option. The Life in Color was thebomb.com. Froot Loops, lime zest, marshmallows, passion fruit jam served with Blue Marble soft serve ice cream. Unreal! The Peppermint Patty with chocolate Mini Wheats, cocoa powder, and fresh mint was also divine. Or, for the adventurous ones, you can customize your own bowl with all the different Kellogg's cereals, fruit, nuts, and toppings.After you place your order, you're given a buzzer. When your food is ready, a number is displayed on the buzzer. You go to the red lockers and open the one that corresponds to the number on your buzzer (a deacon is there to assist). Plenty of cute seating too. The staff is beyond friendly. Special shout out to today's deacon, who was the friendliest, nicest and funniest! What are you waiting for? This place is serially good (see what I did there?).

Oh. My. God.Those ice cream cones are everything.I ate the delicious waffle cone dipped in marshmallow and Froot Loops. They have tons of options in toppings on the ones but the Froot Loops was delish.The vanilla ice cream. Perfect consistency, fabulous flavor. Small store that lacks a plethora of seating but who he hell cares? Give me ALL the cones and ice cream.

Using up characters by saying I'm going to run out of characters. The eternal struggle. That's the only negativity you'll hear from me in this review, though. Yerba Buena has been on my list for ages before I finally dined here on Thursday night. So my expectations were very high. Usually that doesn't work out so well for me, but not the case here. The cocktails were superb, the food was even better, and the service was on another level. This place is all kinds of fabulous.YB is located in one of the hotter areas of the city--straddles the LES and the East Village in the most platonic way. A friend and I made reservations because the space itself, though lovely, is pretty small. Though the place was filled with parties of friends on this particular night, I'd say it's just as viable for a date spot--especially if you decide to dine tapas-style. Despite YB being a smaller restaurant, they happily accommodate larger groups. We were very surprised to find a group of maybe 12 guys celebrating someone's birthday. Surprising, because how many guys do you know that can successfully rally ALL of the troops for a birthday dinner at a fun restaurant? Maybe I'm ignorant, but my friend was just as intrigued as I was. Anyway.Though the prices at YB are pretty typical for Spanish spots, the hospitality and decor here are that of a much nicer restaurant. Everything is beautifully polished and refined, which was a pleasant surprise. Being the twentysomethings that we are, we were totally floored when several members of the waitstaff promptly offered to remove our jackets as we sat down. Not mad at it. As it turns out, we got double the love, because we had to switch tables soon after getting settled at our table. The host told us that he needed our space for a party of four but that he'd seat us in a booth right away. As we swapped, he told us that we shouldn't worry, for he'd personally take care of us for the rest of the night. And this didn't seem forced or overkill or anything like that. The dude was just all kinds of classy. When words like "decorum" and "etiquette" are thrown around, well, this was that.Onto the drinks. I had the Poquito Picante (gin + jalapeño + cilantro + cucumber + combier + fresh lemon juice) and the Desert Rose (rose infused gin + prickly pear purée + lemon juice). The Poquito Picante, though not as aesthetically pleasing as the Desert Rose, is my ideal cocktail. If you've read my other cocktail reviews, you know that spicy cocktails are my jam (do people still say that?). This drink is thoughtful, creative, well-balanced and supremely satisfying. It's apparently their most popular drink, which doesn't surprise me one bit (sorry, I think I've used that word a lot in this review). The Desert Rose pretty much tastes like you're drinking a posh English garden, minus the dirt. It's not bad, but I'd pass on it if I got a do-over. Still appreciate the creativity though.Our food damage was as follows:Hojas de Salmon (black truffle vinaigrette, quinoa, green onion-jalapeño salsa, yuzu): AThe black truffle vinaigrette sold us. This was the perfect dish to start off our meal. Light but plenty flavorful, texturally interesting and more conducive to sharing than some of the over options. Chicharron de Calamar (blue corn meal-crusted calamari, sweet plantains, tamarind vinaigrette): A+I don't order calamari when I'm out unless there's some kind of twist. In my opinion, there's always something more interesting to order. Whoever decided to experiment with ways to bread calamari hit the jackpot with this one. The blue corn meal added fantastic flavor and texture which made for one of the best calamari dishes I've ever had. Both the calamari and the plantains are dressed in equally tasty tamarind vinaigrette. For those wary about trying ceviche but are craving seafood, this is your baby.Brisket tacos (chipotle braised brisket, corn tortillas, avocado, chipotle salsa): A+What could be bad? Look at the ingredients and it's pretty damn obvious how drool-worthy these babies are. Sure, it's not the most creative dish on the menu, but who needs creative when you have perfectly-braised brisket, avo AND all the chipotle. Come on friends, make the right move.Toro Taquitos (tuna tartar, peanut butter aioli, chile de arbol, cilantro chimichurri): A+For whatever reason, I didn't expect these to come in "taco" form, despite the name. If you're hesitant to order to ceviche dishes, this is nothing like any ceviche you've have before. You get three thin, crispy tacos filled with all the fixin's here. They pair peanut butter and tuna in two dishes here, a venture I'm in full support of. Somehow it works. These are fresh, rich, herbaceous and satisfying. Seriously yum.$100 bill. Standard for tapas in NYC.As we were in the process of paying, the host approached us with two champagne flutes and poured us each a glass for a complimentary toast."I told you I'd take care of you," he said. Mic drop.

Ahhhh this place was amazing! Everything from the bar area to the food to the decor to the service- definitely want to go back!Atmosphere: super romantic and fancy, I loved it. The design was eastern Asian and had this mysterious feel with the dramatic lighting and gorgeous chandeliers. Every corner of this place made a statement. Food: perfect. The serving sizes aren't massive so I thought it was the perfect amount of food. We didn't have any leftovers and enjoyed everything to the fullest. The lamb chops were perfectly made. The spring rolls came with the yummiest sauce. The shrimp noodles were a delicious touch to our entrees. And the chicken breast was too fried for me but delicious nonetheless!Service: suuuuuper great! Our waitress was a gem. She really knew the menu inside and out. She also made suggestions on how much to order and was spot on. Price: it's a bit pricy but I personally thought it was worth it. Definitely a lot cheaper than other places I've been to. Will I be back? Do I even have to answer haha - YESYESYESYESSSS

Rory's. I have been going to Rory Dolan's way before my Yelping days existed. Located on McLean Ave., this traditional Irish pub has been around since 1994 and boasts an inviting exterior that slightly resembles a castle with just as an inviting interior. The venue is large and well laidout, and like most Irish pubs I've encountered they have beautiful Waterford Crystals displayed in lit, glassed in wood armoires throughout, which aides in the homey, warm atmosphere. Upon entering, the first thing you see is a large rectangular bar, surrounded by plenty of booths, a few high-top tables, plus a raised dining area towards the back of the restaurant. There are also well placed flat screen tv's and projection screens spread throughout the restaurant to catch all the events of the day plus your local games. Aside from their well stocked bar, like most pubs, food offerings are available through a diverse menu covering all Irish, American and Italian-American food staples. In my opinion, Rory's food is not overwhelmingly the best, but you can't go wrong with a burger, salad, or some type of veggie+protein+carb entree to satiate and soak up your adult beverage. Rory's has hostessed many a good time of birthday parties, opportunites of meeting new people, mingled and jigged at many St. Patty's Days parties. Plus there's also the obligatory Friday night move all the dinner tables towards the back of the restaurant and set-up the DJ for that evenings dance party leading to many, upon many good times. -Very friendly and welcoming service-Outdoor sidewalk seating available -Party Room for special occasions-Metered street and Valet parking available-Happy Hour on Friday's; 4:00pm-6:00pm only-DJ on Friday and Saturday nightsCome into Rory Dolan's solo or with a crew, you are bound to find most of what you need and have a good time.

I was hooked from the moment I tasted some of their Poké on the Yelp cruise this year. On that faithful night, I vowed to try them in person and took the task serious enough as to challenge a fellow Yelper to see who would try them first. I won. Go fig. Sorry G. G.!! #sorrynotsorry  First thing's first, know what you want. Walking in here was more intimidating than that of facing the curving line of Chipotle customers, leering at you while you find you way to the end of the line. You're super uncomfortably close to fellow patrons and you're pretty much yelling out your order over people's heads. So upon entering, either have the menu pulled up on your phone or grab one from the cashier counter or you'll be the bain of everyone's existence with a large helping of continuous side eye from those who can tell you're a nube a mile away. Not to mention that it seemed as though the closer they got to closing, the more people filed in. It took almost thirty minutes to get my food and it was most certainly worth it. I'm one who eats for the love of taste and food so while that doesn't help my waistline, I am most happy, trying various items as opposed to have a set of courses. I love tapas restaurants and places where you're able to "build your own" menu item. It's a semi-adult way to play with your food and allows for a taste of as much or as little as you'd like. So while they offer their "Signature Works" items, I went with the Poké Your Way (build your own).You have a choice of the bowl, the "burrito" which is really just a burrito-sized Maki roll or the salad. After you pick which item you want, you pick your proteins. Some are raw like the salmon and tuna but they also have items prepared sous vide, which is basically sealing a seasoned protein in an airtight plastic bag and slow cooking in a temperature-regulated water bath. They prep the chicken, scallops and shrimp sous vide. Organic tofu is the vegan op. I ordered a Poké Bowl w/Quinoa, Ahi and Salmon.Next, you choose your mix-ins. They offer a couple types of seaweed, cucumber slices and even diced mango but I went with the edamame, cilantro and shiso leaves. For the flavor option, you're supposed to only choose one but being me, I asked for the sriracha aioli AND the spicy ginger and I'm glad I did. They also have the fresh, citrus-y ponzu, sweet chili gochu, wasabi aioli and a few others. The last two options are for adding additional toppings and some crunch for texture. I asked for avocado on the side since it was take out and had them add some pickled ginger as well as masago, with which they were generous. They also have other toppings including furikake, crab salad and wasabi. For crunch, I went simple with some sesame seeds but you can get crazy with macadamia nuts, onion crisps and then some.The miso soup was good for the price. They fill up your cup with seaweed, scallion and tofu and you fill the cup, yourself, from the miso soup dispenser on the counter! I love miso. The price isn't too bad considering a lot of the items are included. It's just a matter of how many you want to order. They're a little skimpy on the protein servings but again, you can offset that by ordering a crapload of add-ins to get your money's worth. The fish is super fresh and I could seriously live on this forever.

YUMMMMMMMM. I wasn't sure what to expect because it had so many well-rated reviews and my expectations were a bit high. I am so happy that all the praises are justified. I came here for a roommate dinner and it was the perfect set up for catching up with friends. The wait staff was super friendly, very attentive in refilling our water and ensuring we were having a good time. They have wine and beer which was exactly what we were looking for. As for the food, it was delicious.My roommate and I started with the pizza bread and meatball trio. Both were hits for me. I would go back just to eat the appetizers. The pizza bread was so good and huge in portions. Six thick cut pieces of heaven. The bread was crisp and crunchy on the outside but super fluffy, airy and soft on the inside. It was strong to hold the tomato sauce and melted mozzarella well. Add some parmesan cheese and red hot chili flakes and it became glorious. Loved every bite. The meatball trio were three large balls of awesome meat. The meat itself was seasoned very well and the tomato sauce was creamy with great hits of basil and olive oil. Both were plenty to share between two people. I was already kind of full by the time the pasta came but of course I devoured that as well. We shared the Spaghetti and white clam sauce and again, another top notch dish. There was plenty to share between two people. The spaghetti was cooked perfectly al dente and the white wine sauce was seasoned beautifully and tasted almost buttery with the spaghetti. There were also plenty of clams in the dish. Like a delicious surplus of it which is great because it balanced well with the pasta and made every bite worth it.Overall, a delicious meal. Given the quality and execution of the dishes, I would highly recommend it for a good casual dinner with a date or friends. Man that pizza bread was just addicting. Also the prices don't break the bank which is even better!

Meow.? Katz delicatessen has been here for ages and ages now. Been here a handful of times.. Always a fun drunken, not so sober, kind of pit stop after an outing.. Came here with my guy friend after dinner and drinks and drinks... Amazing. Pastrami. Pastrami. Pastrami.Pricey but portion is large. Even though the large portion doesn't compare to the price. But worth it. The experience is a must. CLASSIC!This place reels all types of people... its really funny when you start having random conversation with people. You know their the best random conversations when you know you have absolutely no filter and they don't get offended.

Great Coffee for a Great CauseGo figure Hugh Jackman (yes, the actor) owns this place and not only is the coffee amazing it's fair priced and fair trade so it's helping the good people of other countries and helping their business grow.This location is inside the US mercantile exchange building so walking into a bit of history here. Now there have not been traders in this building for sometime now but it is still cool to think this is were millions of dollars traded hands back in the day. In addition to that it is across from the ferry and water which boasts beautiful views of the hudson. Back to the reason you come here Amazing coffee! They are known for their flate white coffee which is very good but not my favorite I go for the ice coffee black with simple syrup and it is literally the best ice coffee I have ever had!!!!! Seriously get this and you will see. In addition to coffee they have a vast array of pastries and goodies. In the end if you work in the area or are visiting this is the coffee shop to go to!

This place has everything I want in a upscale- casual dinner. I'm not sure if we went on a slow night but there was no wait around 7pm. It was one of the first nice days we had in New York this year so we decided to sit outside. The garden is very cute. It is closed off and surrounded by a bunch of flowers and herbs. We ordered two drinks to start. The volver ($14) which is tequila based with mezcal, green chartreuse, lime, ginger, agave, basil, and grapefruit bitters. It was good but I liked the duchess ($14) better which had gin, plum, early grey tea, blackberries, lemon, and agave. Luckily my boyfriend liked the tequila one better so we switched. To start we shared the burrata $16 which was so good. You really can't go wrong with cheese. We also got the roasted golden beets which were good but I wouldn't order it again. For the main courses they had two fish entrees and we got both. Mine was a red snapper $29 with green peas, fiddlehead ferns, and morels. It was super delicious but a little on the well done side. Next time I would specify on how I want it. I really enjoyed the other fish as well I just can't remember what it is. Regardless, the fish options change but I would highly recommend them as both were great. Our waitress was also helpful when we ordered wine and the service was great. The atmosphere is cute, intimate, and laid back but also nice enough where you could dress up a little more. I would highly recommend it here. It was one of the better restaurant experiences we had as we have been on a search and stumbled into many mediocre places recently.

Have you ever gone to bed after a meal and literally dreamt about the entire food and experience for the whole night? No? Well - I have. This seriously happened to me after dining at Blue Hill. I'm not kidding. It was one of the most amazing culinary experiences I have had. To date, there is no other restaurant, food, or service that I find to be even somewhat comparable.I probably cannot add much more to what has already been said. But I'll provide a few bits of info that were specific to me.The service was amazing from beginning to end. I dined alone and opted to eat at a table, instead of at the bar. I chose the daily menu. I discussed my preferences with the server, along with some dietary restrictions that were making it difficult for me to choose one option from each course. She said that she would speak with the chef about other options we could do. I was hesitant because I did not want to modify the beauty and flavors already created by the chef for each serving. But the server assured me that they want me to have a great experience and that they are very happy to accommodate almost any dietary restriction or request.The chef then suggested two items from the first course (in lieu of one from the second course as I could not eat anything from the second course). The chef also swapped out some of the items I could not eat with items that I could. I cannot possibly explain the food nirvana as I bit in each and every piece of the meal. I felt like I was in a culinary utopia, with the most creative, fresh, and delicious vegetables and food ever.They also created a dessert for me which was gluten free, as the standard dessert had gluten. My dessert was teeny, tiny cubes of cantaloupe on a bed of Stone Barns honey and with some ginger. They also brought out halves of various seasonal plums on the same honey. I really cannot adequately describe how beautiful it is to taste fresh fruits and vegetables that are prepared in a loving way to bring out the best in each.In addition to the food, the patrons are truly very cool. I was lucky enough to have a couple sit to my left that have been coming to the restaurant every single week since it opened in 2000! That is dedication - and after having my first experience at Blue Hill, I can only say I envy them for being able to do so financially. They were both lovely and I enjoyed hearing their experiences as being long-time diners. On my right, a beautiful mother and son arrived during my dessert course and we started chatting almost immediately. The clientele probably clearly reflects Dan Barber's philosophy of farm-to-table, as the diners all seemed to have their feet planted firmly in the ground, but aware of all the beauty going on around them and sharing it with those nearby.I will try to make this a regular spot for me as they change their menu regularly with the season.

Welcome to your new go-to restaurant for Korean comfort food. That's right, I said it. Korean Comfort Food. Think creamy, cheesy and fried!Thursday Kitchen has created tapa style Korean dishes that are a real bang for your buck when shared among others. I recommend sharing four or five plates between two.  I tried the following:Pork Belly Taco Bursting with flavors, the pork within that is slightly crispy on the inside is so tender in the center, it'll melt away in your mouth. It's topped with corn, a kick of salsa, sour cream, red onion and guacamole. Crispy Chicken If you'ever ever tried Korean fried chicken, you'll love this! Bite size chicken pieces glazed and topped with black sesame provides sweet and savory in every bite! Truffle Mac and Cheese There isn't a single person I know that doesn't rave over truffle oil. This mac & cheese dish has taken truffle to a new creamy, cheesy level adding a hint of truffle that you won't be able to refuse when placed in front of you. Kimchi Paella Kimchi fried rice meet paella. Creamy kimchi with a dash of black pepper and who-knows-what-else has you scraping every last bite. Pure Jeremy The alcoholic fruit punch drink with a glowing ball is not only aesthetically pleasing but equally tasty! Pureed strawberries with what tastes like soju is that fruity cocktail you'd refuse because it's too girly but secretly down when no one is looking. Matcha Bread Pudding Matcha bread pudding reminded me of my grandma's homemade rice cakes. It's served with homemade vanilla gelato and bourbon sauce that tastes like sweet caramel. These dishes are highly concentrated with must-eat attitude. You'll need to try this place, ASAP! Unfortunately, no reservations are taken here so be prepared to wait in an hour long line.

We need to make books cool again.If you go home with somebody and they don't have books,don't fuck them.- John WatersWell he's got books alright. Mountain of textbooks. And tort law.But I didn't fuck himAfter date night he brought me back to his 100 sqft dorm and said,"Missy, just give me a minute. I need to finish my readings."To which I exclaimed,"Jewish lawyer bf, are you fucking serious?!"Moments later, I somehow ended up at the Strand.Cuz its proximity to NYU and Joe's pizza.My salvation.So I'm hauling an armful of books back to my apartment.Cuz who needs boys when you got the Strand

One of the best Omakase in the city (The other top two are Sushi Zo and Ichimura, haven't tried masa, but soon!) and certainly one of my best meals in 2016! I'm a HUGE uni lover so Soto to me is Michael phelps's champion defense to 200m butterfly in Rio. It is supposed to be that good and it even breaks my record for best Omakase. I just can't think of why the average Yelp review is 3.5 for this amazing place. To me, it surely deserves the two Michelin stars if not more!Without hesitation, my friend and I went with Omakase (Omakase means "I'll leave it to you" in Japanese. Used in Japanese cuisines, simply means tasting menu that you leave the chef to decide what to present in the whole course with creativity). Omakase includes 12 dishes + 13 pieces of sushi + Mochi ice cream in assorted flavors. We also informed our waitress that we are both big uni lovers so they slightly customized the menu for us. The first half of the meal was full of wonders leaving us wordless to describe it. The uni presented in different dishes taste so divinely uni-y! The texture is creamy, silk-like smooth, a bit custard-like and wet. Upon biting it, the luxurious, nutty, and sweet taste bursts on my palate! Uni is also presented is fine delicate differences in each dish - fatter, creamier and nuttier in uni cocktail, more custard-like and stronger in the botan Ebi tar tare, creamier and sweeter in the uni/quail egg/squid dish. While uni dishes are mind-blowing, other non-sushi dishes were also outstanding. (Basically I loved everything I had there!) 1) The white and black tofu is the most soft and creamiest I have ever had not to mention the heavenly good sesame aroma. 2) Tuna tartar is OMG-good - soft and smooth like tofu, with the creamy layer of avocado and refreshing note from the scallions. 3) I'm not huge fan of tempera, but the scallop tempera is simply excellent - flavor well presented and not heavy at all!The second half - sushi part was no less amazing than the first part. The most memorable one to me is the sea scallop (5+/5) - absolutely delicious! It's so sweet and succulent with a touch of refreshing sourness from the ponzu sauce. While the sweet shrimp didn't deliver the succulence and sweetness I was looking for.The meal ended with 5 home-made Mochi ice cream balls. The skin is thick, soft and chewy and the taste is very natural!My highest recommendation. Bring your special ones here to cherish the love towards amazing japanese food together - life is perfect. For ppl less fond of uni - inform the waitress when ordering. Only negative I could think of is that it is louder than an average sushi bar. Our waitress was very efficient and attentive. Will come back soon.

I'm giving them the tops. Five stars for having all the flavors and cakes ready for purchase. This location is very busy. They get a lot of tourists. People leaving saying they'll come back later. Ha! By afternoon it is really crazy. I was helped promptly this am and found my spot at the counter. I inhaled the Peanut Butter and Jelly Cupcake. It was sooooo good!Here's the drill: One line is to order in front of the display case. After your order is ready you take it and step to the right side into another line. There you wait to be called to the check out. If you use a credit card it appears you're served faster. I use credit card now especially since there's no minimum purchase required. I think PB and Jelly is tied with German Chocolate Cupcake for favorite. It was very good as usual. The price is comparable to other bakeries. Lots of jelly inside and the peanut butter tastes like actual peanut butter!! I did see some of my other favorite Magnolia treats. I'll return soon for a slice of cake. I know how to ask for what I want now. They remember me and converse. It's fun to be welcomed. The best time to go is early am. See you there! I'll be the one standing at the counter stuffing my face!

I love it here -- although I have to admit that, because I am a buffoon, I laughed inward whenever I walked by here the first dozen times or so... B&D, bondage & domination, sadomasochism, get it?It's definitely steamy from all the buffet tables, so I wish they would cut a hole in the wall to make a window because the only other relief from the heat is a regular sized-door, while in addition to the gigantic buffet tables there are also always at least a couple dozen people in here merrily eating and relaxing (and adding to the ambient warmth). Even if the food weren't so good, I would still love it because it's so fresh: there are always lots of people eating so the staff are continually refilling, and, also, it has been my experience that they round down in pricing. Like me, they like even numbers. If your plate is 1.10 pounds, they ask for $6 for vegetables or $7 for meats. This is something that makes all the difference in the world to me. Little gestures of generosity are giant.I don't bother looking at the food labels, which really don't give you more information than your own powers of observation, "tomato," "peas," "okra," etc., but apparently I really love their vegetable heavy soups and stews, because after a few visits now, I am just realizing that I really haven't had any chunks of meat. Not that I have been avoiding the meat, just that there are always long lines of guys waiting to get at them, and I'm perfectly fine exploring all the other stuff. And all the other stuff is really really good. The atmosphere here is the opposite of intimidating and also the opposite of welcoming, it's almost anonymous, which I honestly like most of all, nobody bothers you and you don't bother anybody, how this behemoth city of ours should be, lots of people packed into a small space all taking care of themselves and having fun.

Okay, I just love this place. This was my 3rd time here, and it does not disappoint! Also, side note - the waiters are all so cute with their denim button downs and William Sonoma striped aprons. Had to say it.I came here for dinner this time at 7:30pm on Saturday. Everything was so good!!FOOD:-Garlic bread: comes on a large, thick toasted piece of bread, covered in butter/oil with garlic. Man this was good! Get this to start for the table. It is very flavorful.-Crispy Sweet Onions: I got this the last time I was here with friends, and decided to get it again. It's bite sized pieces of onion that are lightly breaded/cripsy. They definitely feel much more healthy and lighter than onion rings, but you can compare it to that to get an idea. Comes topped with fresh parm, and a dipping sauce that is very good and creamy. Get this!-Tomato Pizza: this was good to share as well. Thicker crust, tomato, pecorino cheese, and pieces of basil. -Cacio e Pepe: I got this last time I was here as well, and got it again! I really do love it. It's so good, and I would get it again. All the cheesy and peppery goodness.-Borsa "Little Purse" Pasta: I adore this pasta (my sister and I split the Cacio e Pepe and this pasta). They look like little dumplings, and are filled with ricotta cheese. The menu says hazelnut and lemon, but thinking back, I feel like there is a truffle flavor? Whatever it was, it was unreal. It's also great to split since the dumplings are so rich in flavor.DRINKS:-Honey Fashioned: Get this if you like Old Fashioneds. Love it!SERVICE:-Very good and attentive. And like I said, cute uniforms.

Perfection. I've not had the perfect combination of comfort, sight lines, intimacy, and sound until Stage 1 of Manhattan Theatre Club. I saw Incognito starring Geneva Carr, Charlie Cox, Heather Lind, & Morgan Spector (Separate show review upcoming). The actors aren't mic'd (at least I don't think they were, it was very directional) and the sound was excellent from my seat at stage left, E6. Stage 1 is the larger of the two and in the basement. It seats 300 or so people, so it still qualifies as intimate. The couple next to me moved over but I don't think any of the sight lines are actually bad. Row E was the perfect distance from the stage for me. But if you are front row center, there's a couple of moments when the actors are almost in your lap (Hyperbole!). Very high risers so nothing obstructs the stage. Also very comfortable seats with tons of leg room. So comfortable that sitting through an 1 hour 25 min. show with no intermission, you won't enter the stage I call "Butt Fatigue". There's a bar and if I'm not mistaken, two coat checks. Fully ADA Compliant, with listening devices. What I think I love the most... Stage 1 is a total cellphone dead zone.Like I said, perfect.

Situated in midtown in the prime location of Penn Station and MSG. This quant food hall will get great foot traffic for a quick meal for commuters, folks attending a event at MSG, or for the corporate crowd for a lunch. Clean and has ample tables and seats to sit for your lunch with large windows to see outside. The food hall hosts 5 food stalls and a large bar area in the back. The bar area is great for after work happy hours and the food hall is great as a central place to meet up with people and to hang out with groups. Highlights for me are the pat la frieda stall serving steak sandwiches, the mario stall serving sandwich and soup, cinamon snail with their assortment of baked goods and vegans meals, and the lobster press for a wonderful pressed lobster sandwich.I'll be back, it's a great spot for a work lunch.

Came in here frantically needing 2 shirts steamed (intern duties, don't ask). The owner, I forget his name, greeted me, asked my name and told me he was super busy. There were customers waiting before me so he took me in the back room, taught me to use his professional steamer and went back to help his other customers.Once he was done helping the customers before me he came back and finished steaming my shirts for me. The whole time he was so patient, kind and kept calling me by my name making the experience really personal. Then he *kindly* shoved me out the front door so I wouldn't offer to pay. Seriously such a sweet man and great business. I could tell the other customers were loyal customers as he knew them all my their first name. Whenever I need something hemmed or dry cleaned in the future I'll be sure to stop here. THANK YOU DRYCLEANING JESUS!!!!

I should have listened to Youngest Sis when she recommended this bakery to me. She had the street cred. After 9/11, she delivered to me 3 batches of biscotti, beauties made from that divine chocolate, Valrhona. I ate 47 of them in one weekend. Following are a few reasons I have to apologize to sis and make up for lost time:S'Mores Danish-this is another masterpiece, seemingly so simple to put together and yet complex when you eat it. Bittersweet chocolate is smartly paired to cut the cloying sweetness of toasted marshmallow, the taste of the two balanced. The pleasant surprise is the crunch that comes after your teeth pass the marshmallow, then the chocolate, and meet the layers of laminated dough, right before the buttery pastry. I wondered how Gural made this. If he baked the pastry first, and layered the chocolate and marshmallow after, he magically managed to keep the crispness in the exterior. I pondered the technique after one bite, then promptly devoured it. Some lucky customers have eaten it hot out of the oven. The first time I went, I was told a customer cleaned them out and bought forty. Easy to understand why. I could eat a tray of this myself. I gave one to Oldest Sis. She sent me two emails, saying she liked it. In Older Sis code, it means, "Get more".Chocolate Bread-I can already tell after eating this that Arcade's breads are going to be dangerous. Arcade Bakery's pastries are too rich for me to eat more than one(well, maybe two) in a day. But the bread, I can eat that for breakfast, lunch and dinner. This bread packs a few delightful surprises. The crust is soft, not hard and crispy as in many chocolate breads. The doughy inside is like the baguette, tender, moist and with that same airy quality. Another wondrous touch were the diced orange peels in this bread. I dug out one of the minute pieces; it was only slightly sweet, seemed more preserved than candied. Then I dug out one of the small pieces of chocolate. A smooth, dark chocolate, without a strong smell and not in large chunks. The almonds are whole, toasted, fresh and crunchy. I put my nose to the velvety bread and smelled yeast, not the cocoa I expected, or the expresso powder I was sniffing for. Gural loves his bread so much, he does not let any added ingredient dominate the taste of his bread. But he has mastered baking alchemy, along with matchmaking ingredients. When I ate the bread as the sum of all its parts, the orange and almonds accentuated the cocoa and chocolate and a wonderfully addictive chocolate bread emerged. I almost ate half the loaf in one sitting. My bff showed more restraint, but raved about this bread too.Almond chocolate croissant: Another rich creation. The layers crackle not as sharply as with the almond croissant, perhaps because the filling was a wetter paste, a mix of the almonds and sugar and melted chocolate and whatever goodness Gural bakes in. I expected a more intense chocolate flavor. This one tasted more like an almond cream with chocolate flavor. A lovely breakfast pastry, but the plain almond one I thought surpassed it in texture and taste. But don't shie from buying this. It is delicious.Caramel apple brioche: A pretty ring of brioche with apple pieces on top, this pastry caught my eye at the first encounter. Gural, I realize, doesn't permit one ingredient to overpower another but understands how well they complement each other. First, I like to nibble on his ingredients separately to taste them. Tasted singly, each piece of the brioche was good, not remarkable. But when the browned apples(caramelized in sugar and browned butter?) is eaten with the bread portion of the brioche, transformation into wonderful occurs with each bite. I also loved that there wasn't even a hint of cinnamon in it.Lemon sugar brioche- I didn't try this but bought it for Oldest Sis, who said it tasted like an overpriced lemon danish. But sis, you must understand, likes an artisanal pastries as well as a cheap, processed supermarket pie. If it's like the other products from Arcade, I am sure it is very excellent.I know I love this place after writing a super long review that I had to put out in three parts. Live your life without regret. Visit this bakery pronto.

Came here yesterday for the Lincoln Center's Festival 2016 series! This great theater is just steps from the foot of Central Park and under one of the main subway hubs of midtown. The Kanze Noh Theater was presenting some of the oldest and most visually stimulating renditions, "Okina" and "Shkkyo". While other very famous, "Shkkyo" is particularly wonderful because of the beautiful lion dances. The theater itself has great seating in the 1st tier and 2nd.Be on time. They do not offer late seating. Also ladies the theater is very cold, so bring a scarf to drape over your shoulders, even in 90+ weather outside!

Que rico mami! Mi encantan tus helados! Solo un peso?!? One dollar!? Es loco :-)I've seen this older couple sit on the corner of 6th and B every summer for years now. Summer isn't here, until the Puerto Rican ice cream cart has arrived! They're smart, they take the key spot right in front of the school entrance. So every day between 3-4 pm, the kids swarm the cart. The cart usually arrives for the warm weather before school lets out. But they stay the whole summer since there seem to be a lot of kids summer school camps.Love practicing my spanish. Er, spanglish. Tried the mango, not a big fan. But the coco is pretty solid. Reminds me so much of my trips to the Caribbean and Central America! Damn, one dollar? Crazy, can't beat that. Pretty sure even in Puerto Rico "un peso" is pretty hard to beat!This place is refreshing in an age of sophisticated foodies (cold brew, locavores, farm to table, craft beer, organic), this brings it all back home. Simple and no frills here!

I wanted to hate this place. I mean, it really has all the right ingredients to bring out my ire. It is ultra hip. There is an old record player. It screams "this is a hip downtown place" The intentionality looks off the chart.I went in sporting my "I'm too good for this shit" sneer. Irving Farms coffee. Hmmm ok. Well, that's a nice touch, but I am undeterred in my readiness to hate this place. Well, a small menu of nice little sandwiches and a quiche that was really tasty. Nope! I am going to hate this place damn it.Friendly service. Oh no, you are not fooling me! I came in here to hate. Really nice seating. Ok, well, that's kind of cool. Oh, and a full bar. Hmmm....no, no, I refuse to like this....wait, is that bob dylan's tangled up in blue playing...no, I will hate it. Look at this sign. No wifi after 5 pm and on weekends. Let me ask what that is all about.Oh, it's about giving people a chance to get out of their insulated internet tunnel and have some social interaction. Wow. Ok good answer. Shit. Ok. Fine. This place is like totally awesome. Everything about it is right. I already want to go back. You win DTUT, you win.

NY Frost Factory's grand opening is tomorrow, Monday 8/8/16, and I was lucky enough to stumble in on their soft opening just before. Before I start on the delicious melt in your mouth dessert itself - I've got to give it to the staff. The owners and employees are incredibly patient and helpful, and off the chart friendly. Now onto the product itself..They serve delicious quality shaved ice! Finally, a place that sells shaved ice cream with the perfect fluffy consistency and texture that does not melt into liquid in an instant. My matcha shaved ice stayed nice and cold in the 90 degree heat. Their base price is $6.25 for an order of shaved ice+boba on top. Additional toppings start at 50 cents each. These guys are GENEROUS! You definitely get your money's worth, trust me. My matcha had the perfect amount of green tea flavor. Not too much that it was bitter, and not too little unlike some stingy establishments. My friends ordered the passion fruit, and lychee flavors. All three of us had the same verdict - YUMMY. Passion fruit wins hands down for me though! It was the perfect combo of tart&sweet and did not taste artificial at all. Toppings are also well kept behind the counter and everything was very sanitary. Fruits are fresh, and toppings such as the boba, mochi, etc. are not stale. If their soft opening is already this successful, I can only wonder what NY Frost Factory will have in store for foodies like myself. Excited to visit them again and try out all the other flavors they have to offer!

As New Yorkers, we can all boast and brag about going to the coolest / hippest / divey - yet - most awesome restaurants. (Why else would I choose to continue to write reviews on Yelp? *wink*) Still, there are those dining experiences that transcend any of the aforementioned. It's not often that I have had a well-curated five-course meal in a private chef's abode. Scratch that...I never have, until recently.I was lucky enough to be invited to a private residence in the city to experience the fine cooking of Chef Shuchi, the brains behind 29 Calories. In this particular brunch, she made small servings of some of the breakfasts she remembers from her childhood, but re-imagined and improved upon. She served a story with each dish, and we noshed on various dishes with oats, vegetables, meats, eggs, coffee, and cake, each with a truly unique Indian influence within them. Her hospitality and warmth is pretty unparalleled, and she was very open when we had questions about the food, the spices she used, her background in cooking, et al. The two hours I spent at this brunch was too short! I can only hope to be lucky enough to be able to eat some of her dishes again! It was all exquisite! I doubt I'll ever have such a unique brunch ever again! What a day, and what a memory to have. Thanks so much, Shuchi!

From the moment I walked in and heard the old Chinese music floating through the air, I knew this place would be authentic. From the wooden bowls that the food comes in to the hot water thermos sitting around, everything here reminded me of home. There were even classic Chinese phrases painted on the wall that exactly resembled those I see everywhere in China. The atmosphere hit me with so much nostalgia, I could not wait to try the food. Food: We ordered the Husband and Wife beef appetizer which is one of my favorite Szhechuan appetizers ever. The dish was the perfect amount of spicy to numbing and a great way to wake up the palate. For the main event, the mala xiang guo, I ordered some lamb, beef round, spam, pork belly, wood ear, shiitake mushrooms, squid, fish ball (get the one with meat inside), fish cake, lotus root, celtuce, bean curd sheet, tofu pocket and glass noodles. It was difficult to narrow down all the choices since they all sounded so good! The selection is exactly what I would expect if I went to a Mala xianguo place in China. They have a great selection of offals too that I will for sure try next time. I ordered the Spicy level which was perfect. Just spicy enough to feel that sweet, sweet burn but not enough where I couldn't enjoy the food. The Wang Wang milk drink is key to cooling down the spice also. Overall, what an amazing trip down memory lane with some amazing food. I can't believe such a place exist in East Village and not in Chinatown! I will for sure be back soon and maybe even order delivery a few times.

If you're going to go to Balthazar (quoting my BFF) "Go big or go home!".. That being said the Le Balthazar seafood tower is Le BOMB! BOOM!! That and a nice bottle of bubbles and you're in Paris ;-). $175 will get you a giant tower of beautiful shellfish.. Luxurious perfectly prepared shellfish... OMG YAASSS! Worth the splurge. My party of 4 were stuffed and happy. We also shared an order of pom frites (yum-o) and poached eggs with avocado and jalepeno salsa on toast (brunch menu). In the past have had steak frites, steak au poivre, Balthazar burger, eggs benedict.. all delicious. Ohhhh, and let me not forget the french onion soup.. soooo good. The cool thing about Balthazar is that you are not rushed out. You're meal is an event, a long luxurious event ;-).. I get "dragged" to Balthazar any time my SF bestie visits. As a native NY-er this place is super touristy but it's kinda great and I always enjoy myself :-).Tip - Reservations are a MUST. Unless you like waiting a LONG time for a table. Request a table away from the bar.

The poke craze has definitely hit NYC, and Wisefish is leading the pack in terms of quality.I was both dreading and looking forward to the day when poke would make it big here. Sure enough, the second a video was made about New York's "trendiest new food" at Pokeworks, lines went out the door and hype was blown out of proportion. Nothing gets people going like a viral video about sushi burritos. In hopes of avoiding crowds, I went to Chelsea's Wisefish on a Sunday morning.Having had both Pokeworks and Wisefish, my vote goes to Wisefish. Pokeworks is good, don't get me wrong, but Wisefish is better. You can taste the difference in fish quality and feel the difference in friendliness. Both places are similar in terms of setup, which consists of Chipotle-style BYO-bowls and pre-set options, as well as ingredients and prices. A regular bowl at either will run you about $11. Not cheap, but it'll fill you up.POKE:Wisefish keeps it simple with protein choices between tuna, salmon, and tofu. Beyond brown and white rice, you also have the option to get zucchini noodles as a base. I got them out of curiosity along with rice and was pleasantly surprised. I think of the zucchini more as a topping since it complemented the fish so well, and IMO rice is a must with poke. You then have your choice of toppings, which range from scallions to avocado cream to fried onion. Finish it off with a sauce. You can go with a spicy option like wasabi shoyu or spicy citrus shoyu or keep it classic with soy sauce and sesame oil. My suggestion for poke is to always go simple rather than complicated. Too many toppings make it flavor-overload, and poke should be all about the fish.ATMOSPHERE:I think my favorite thing about Wisefish was not the food, but the people. The girl checking me out was friendly and very informative, telling me how they make an effort to locally source their fish and keep it authentic. I really appreciated the enthusiasm and genuine interest in her store. On that note, the store itself is nicely set up, with a long table down the middle and a couple of window seats below hanging lights. Overall, I'd love to come back. The next time I'm craving poke in the city, I'll be here.

Excellent New York classic for smoked fish. The smoked/cured salmon come in all varieties, Scottish, Norwegian, Irish, Nova Scotia, Gravlax, Pastrami salmon, you name it. Plus Sturgeon, White fish, smoked trout, chopped liver. My favorite is the Smoked Sable. However, in mid-June do come for the Holland Herring first catch! Like buttah! Young fresh delicate herring fillets are smooth, sweet from the sea with a sashimi-like quality. Try only if you are familiar with herring. They have an abundance of cream cheese, with lox, or scallion, plain, vegetable, horseradish, with caviar and tofu cream cheese for the lactose-intolerant. Plus all types of Bagels, bialys. If you are a fan of caviar, you can get Osetra, Siberian, Hackleback, Paddlefish, and orange salmon roe, or green Wasabi roe. Pricey, good knowledgeable, friendly service. **Get your bagels at Ess-A-Bagel**   **Get all of your fish delicacies here****Old school. Founded 1914**

I love this CoCo so much solely because of its location. This place has saved me from snacking and given me a boost of caffeine throughout some long days. Another big plus is that there is no credit card min spend limit here like the CoCo in midtown, so I can always swipe my card for just one bubble tea. I also personally like this better than the nearby Vivi, maybe all the pink there hurts my eye or something... and plus, they close a lot earlier than CoCo I believe.

The hummus is very good, but it's not worlds better than what you can get elsewhere.What *is* better: the pita. I watched a chef make the pitas fresh, putting them one by one in the wood burning oven, letting them rise, then swooshing them out with her big pita spatula, and letting them cool just until they were ready to serve. They were transcendent. I would come back for the pitas alone. You cannot get pita this good anywhere else that I know of. I can think of an Arab bakery in Paterson, NJ, that once made me a pita this good (and whole wheat, no less) and I can think of other very good pitas to be had around the city, but this stuff here stands apart.Other stuff:* The salatim (little side dishes of salad) are a mixed bunch and change frequently. Based on what I had on just one visit, they're nice but not essential. If you stuck to the Israeli salad that came with the hummus and maybe some pickles & onion, you'd be fine.* They serve shakshuka for breakfast, through 11:30am. I didn't have it but saw others having it: imagine a cast iron skillet filled with tomato and eggs, baked in a wood burning oven. I'd try it.* Don't skip the limonana. Limon means lemon in Hebrew. Nana: mint. These two things, they go together.

Love Jivamukti yoga!! The space seems very authentic. The two things I noticed about the facility are the clean floors and the high quality of their mats. Not only are the mats complimentary for members and drop ins, but they are also cleaned right after each use with their laundry machines. The term 'Jivamukti' means individual liberation. Jivamukti Yoga School embraces the philosophy of Ahimsa, Bhakti yoga, Raja yoga, Karma yoga, Nada Yoga, Dhyana and Chanting. The instructors here are very professional and they make sure each student receives a hands on adjustment while the breaths are also counted for awareness.I love the Spiritual Warrior class. It is an hour long and unlike most practices, it starts off with an inversion and a backbend...it's different but it works. The mats are lined up against the wall and the flows are simple but the way they sequenced it does work a sweat. Jivamukti Open is an hour and 35 minutes long that starts off with 3 oms, a chant and a philosophical speech before the physical asanas begin. Unlike the Spiritual Warrior class, the inversions and the backbends are saved toward the later part of the class when the heats are built. The practice ends with a seated meditation follow by savasana. On the downside, there's only one shower and no mirror in the changing room. And the lockers are really really small and it's for rental only...if you have a large bag, it wouldn't fit. They also have a gluten free vegan café attached. It's cute but some items are overpriced like $13 to $16 for a quesadilla.Overall for someone who must have her inversions and backbends to call it a full practice, you can't go wrong with Jivamukti. However it would be amazing if we can have hanumansana and gong savasana added :) 4.5 stars.P.S: They also have MySore Ashtanga

Wanted to get here for a while. Finally, today, after work--worked holiday--I made it to ICE & VICE--THE STORE/SHOP on East Broadway.
