I wanted to try Mike C's (great Yelp reviewer) FoodBaby Ice Cream creation. Mike C, & Ice & Vice, I applaud you! Delicious creation. The scoop looks like a strawberry color ice cream, BUT, it is/says it's a Concord grape, donut soil, rainbow sprinkles, & raspberry coulis(sauce) all blended in, but not overly blended, so you get a GREAT CRUNCH FROM THE RAINBOW SPRINKLES, you simply have cartwheeling tastebuds from the fantastic flavors of grape, raspberry, & rainbow sprinkles crunch. YUM TIMES TEN!!! Mike, you rock!!! ICE & VICE, you rock, too ! EXCELLENT, rich, dense, flavorful ice cream. I had the chocolates rich flavor called SHADE, as my 2nd scoop, but I requested that be placed in the cup first, since I had to taste FoodBaby ice cream on its own--so FoodBaby was on top or kind of side by side. Both were delicious. FoodBaby--creative creation & so yummy good.I tried MilkMoney at Madison Square Eats & it was great. A vanilla rich, dense flavor with a fab swirl of rich, deep dark chocolate ganache. Excellent!! Overall : EXCELLENT! Visiting NYC:A MUST TO TRY THIS ICE CREAM & worth the bit of a schlep. YES FOR SURE!! If you are in Chinatown or Little Italy, you are Close!!Soho, you're close too! Enjoy!I look forward to trying the rest of the creative flavors this summer...starting today!!

There aren't too many places in the City that have a burger that can stand against Salvation Burger's "Salvation Burger." Think steak on a bun, like Peter Lugers and Minetta Tavern... this burger belongs on that list.For those that don't know, after winning 2 separate Michelin stars at two previous restaurants (Spotted Pig and The Breslin) primarily for the burger offered at each, James Beard winning chef April Bloomfield decided to open a joint in Midtown dedicated to the burger, and it does not disappoint.Bloomfield selected her cattle ranch and slaughterhouse personally upstate, uses only locally sourced ingredients, has a few butchers in the basement, all in the name of having complete control over the burger and its contents. The meat on the burger is expertly cut and ground in-house, with a high fat ratio that is tough to get right from distributor or store bought meat.The burger patty was about the diameter of a hockey puck, and about 50% thicker. We had 6 in our party, and ordered 6 Salvation Burgers, all medium rare. They all came out hot and fresh, all cooked to medium rare perfectly, all topped with the same crispy onions and perfectly toasted sesame bun, top and bottom. The flavor of the meat shone through, seasoned minimally with salt and pepper, and maybe a few other undistinguishable items, but focused solely on bringing out the flavor of the meat.Bloomfield cooks all of the meat over a wood-fired grill. That is unheard of for a restaurant of this size, that is pumping out this many burgers. It added a tiny bit of smokiness that complimented well with the onions.Aside from the burgers, the McDonald's inspired thin shoestring fries were spot on, and the shakes -- OMFG the shakes --were amazing. I highly recommend the Toasted Marshmallow shake which captures the caramelized marshmallow taste in a cup lined with caramel sauce and thick vanilla ice cream.Everything was perfect, but there were some bad points on our trip. The server lost our name in the app used to track tables. When we went back 2hrs after dropping our name to check, they looked it up and twas nowhere to be found. They did end up hooking us up with a table immediately, but what if we never came back to check and just waited for the text?The place is pricey, with the Salvation Burger a whopping $25. I think it was worth it, being in the upper echelon of burgers in the City, but damn good burgers can be found for much less in the City elsewhere.The ambiance of the place (at least at night) is a little dark for my taste, more nightclubby than fancy burger joint. Pop some candles in there or something, people want to see each other, and this amazing burger.Staff was well trained and helpful, despite only being open for 2 weeks at the time of my visit.Overall, 4.5 stars which rounds up to a rare 5-star from me for Salvation Burger. I hope you get another Michelin star Chef Bloomfield, you definitely deserve it on this one.

I'd been looking for a way to vary my workout routine once I felt like I'd reached a plateau. For some time now, women all around me have been raving and going crazy about Pure Barre. I'm here to join the crazy train and support ALL of the hype about this form of exercise. To be fair, you could find a cheaper barre class at another gym/franchise that isn't trademarked like Pure Barre/Pure Body, Vixen, CrossFit, Zumba....but I went with Pure Barre and signed up for their New Client Special for $99, which grants you access to unlimited classes for one month. Then you're required to either pay for individual classes to the tune of $27, or sign up for a real membership, which I have not yet looked into. That said, I LOVE PURE BARRE BRONXVILLE. I would recommend going to a "Breaking Down the Barre" workshop, which I had the pleasure of doing with Mariellen. This workshop is great for those of you who haven't yet taken a barre class, so that the instructor can really take the time to demonstrate the proper form and technique. I say this because, classes are fast-paced and expensive, so you definitely don't want to waste your time and money being too far behind the other people in your class. You'll walk in, take off your shoes and be greeted warmly by one of many women with a friendly smile. Classes are done without shoes (and in socks), so you can buy your handy pure barre socks with foot grips for $14/pair in any studio. Yes, it's another expensive thing, and you probably can get through your classes with your normal gym socks, but I find that the grips help. Yes, I could buy my own grippy, Spiderwoman socks, but I just bought a bunch at Pure Barre and called it a day. Classes are CHALLENGING! But that's why you came here, right? You want to earn those muscle shakes when you're on the bar. Come into your seat, now lift and tuck, and squeeze and tuck. I'm actually obsessed with this program. You might think that nothing is being accomplished by moving parts of your body just an inch, but you are really working. I dare anyone who thinks they are in prime shape to take these classes and not feel like they're working muscles they've been neglecting. So far I've had class with Mariellen, Erica, Jill P, Stacey, and Sian. All of these ladies have been wonderfully helpful to a beginner like me, and have taken the time to answer my questions thoughtfully. I feel like I'm really getting my money and time's worth, and I love the environment. I'm sure there are larger Pure Barre locations in more densely populated areas, but the Pure Barre Bronxville has only one studio, and that seems to be sufficient. Downloading the app makes it super easy to sign up for classes, which you must do, if you expect to participate. Walk-ins are allowed (but not for Platform) but it's more likely than not, that you won't find space in the walk-in of your choice because there's usually a wait list before that. As I mentioned, Pure Barre is trendy and everybody wants to get in there to feel the burn and build that lean muscle. I have no regrets besides not starting this program sooner. I feel that it's a challenging supplement to my usual routine and I noticed an additional 3 lb drop in my weight after alternating Pure Barre with my cardio and lifting routine. I intend to continue that and really push myself. Pure Barre instructors will help to push their clients, too. One of my favorite things I've ever heard in class was, "Don't let your body decide when you give up!" It's all about trying to get yourself to a point where you can mentally push past the pain and the muscle spasms. Once you do, you're gold!My cousin's wife came with me the other day and we had a blast! No, I'm lying we both were dying and having uncontrollable leg spasms, but dammit it was worth it! Seriously, I plan to be a Pure Barre junkie some day and can't wait until I can call myself a member of the 100+ club. This studio is clean, located right in town and you'll leave every class feeling great about you. What more can you ask for?

Aside from being very convenient for me (literally right across the street), I've only been to Starbucks once, and it's because the hours here are shorter on weekends. Having said that, I wanted to wait to write a review since I knew I'd be coming here frequently if worth it. I got the matcha a couple times, and although the craze of taking pictures of this green drink has swept Instagram recently, I was never compelled to try it. I saw a couple weeks ago how matcha actually has a good amount of caffeine but there are more health benefits than coffee, and there's no crash. So I tried it and it's not bad! However I don't have any other place to compare this one to. The cappuccino and flat white were also good. Another place within the past two weeks that I found that doesn't need sugar. That's how you know it's good coffee. Even Howard Stern has said, you don't like coffee if you have to add sugar. And it's so true. I've never been a big fan, and always ordered vanilla lattes or mochas to mask the taste. The avocado smash is also a recent "hot item" to order for brunch all over the city. Why now? I'm not sure. I've been eating avocados forever... It's pretty much the only green thing I eat. But it is nice to not prepare it yourself. How lazy do I sound? Price wise, I understand it doesn't make sense to spend however much it costs since I've been putting avocado on toast myself for years. But.... They do make it well. So if you're lazy, or in a rush, order it! This is my new coffee place.

It is about time that I updated my almost-year-old review. I have been visiting the den fairly regularly and I continue to support the Murray-Murray ticket in the upcoming elections (Bethany and John can figure out who gets to be the POTUS). Five reasons why:- The den is doubling down on its commitment to my neighborhood, Tribeca. Taking over the second floor and expanding the space on the third floor!- The medley of instructors continues to get stronger. Don't believe me? Try the 'slow burn' with Terri, or yin it with Braxton, or sweat it with Brooke!- The community keeps growing (formulaically, that is the % visiting over 10x a month times the % of time they spend bonding with each other times 10^4)- Den mascot Josie and sidekick Murphy can give Bo and Sunny a run for their money. Just ask Josie to demonstrate a few asanas to you- The Sunday noon class with Queen B is the most cathartic ninety-minute session ahead of your work week--Monday mornings are easy in comparisonSo exercise your suffrage and vote for the Murrays with a membership to the Den. Make yourself great again!

This place rocks.Any place that serves legit, easy, delicious Kellogg's cereal is good in my book. And Kellogg's NYC makes it FUN to enjoy your cereal.It's a bit hidden amongst other, flashy places but it's not crowded once you make it in. Since they're new, I don't expect they'll be this way for long but it's so refreshing after fighting my tourist crowds to get here.My favorite thing to get? Some 'plain jane' Frosted Flakes cereal. It reminds me of the way my mama 'made' it for me when I was a kid. Whole milk from local farms makes it THAT much better.Dress your cereal up or keep it plain, add a small bit of fun with fruit and toppings or go all out with sugar on sugar on sugar.The choice is yours, my friends. Choose wisely!

Covina. So hot right now. Covina.This place is blowing up, and it's blowing up fast. Get your reservations in now before you start the futile fight with OpenTable. It's already reaching that level, and it's only been open a couple of weeks. Came here on a Tuesday night at 8:15 and the place was absolutely packed. Foodies all think the same, it seems. As other reviewers have mentioned, there's an odd little cafe in the front which is very casual and seemingly out of place. But saunter on down to hostess post (new band name?) and you'll start to see the grandeur that is Covina. Expansive bar and an absolutely massive dining area. So while it *was* packed, the feng shui made it such that it didn't feel claustrophobic/cramped in any way. It's upscale, but approachable-upscale. And despite the size, there's a lovely warmth to this place. It's intimate but in a totally platonic way. Everyone present - staff included - just seemed particularly joyous. Before I jump into food, I'll make a few notes about their cocktail program. It's...different. Not bad different. Just different. When anything seems original and inventive, I'm going to take note and I'll likely think of it fondly. So before dinner, you get - you guessed it - the "before dinner" drinks menu. Like all cocktails here, they don't tell you the whole story on the menu. Don't give it up to soon. Make 'em wait. Leave something to be desired. Play hard to get (but not with me, I'm too old for mind games). Anyway, I love that approach when it comes to food - so why not drinks? Before dinner, I went with Covina's take on a Lemon Drop and chose gin over vodka as my base (I always opt for gin if I can). Impeccably done, complete with a generously sugared rim. My dining companion went with the Boulevardier, which was fantastic as well. One of my favorite classics. Remember that part about leaving something to be desired? They did that with the *actual* drink menu. We knew the "before dinner" list couldn't be it. For whatever reason, we didn't get that menu initially, but our bubbly, wonderful waitress fixed that promptly. From this menu, I tried the Rose Hill Sour (ice pictured - made w/ "rosey-cucumbery gin, mezcal-rose cordial, lemon juice and cucumber ice) which was dynamite. Refreshing and well-balanced. And that green ice cube! I then tried the "Pass That Dutch" (pop that pop that jiggle that fat...hail to KWEEN MISSY), which is gin-based (Dutch Genver) w/ apricot and amaro dell'erborista. Rich and boozy. Perfect nightcap.[Text here raving about the service, me trying to find adjectives to do everyone justice, failing miserably, moving onto the food.]Fresh Sardines w/ pickled roasted red pepper and fennel: A-/AThis was all kinds of fresh. And a very inventive preparation. I'm not sure I've ever had sardines, but regardless I've never seen them presented in this way. They are very very fishy so if you don't like that...steer clear. But the pickled roasted red pepper added a great flavor antidote to the saltiness of the sardines, so my full bite rating remains high.Hungarian Fry Bread w/ smoked salmon, kefir ranch, herbs: A++The star. THE STAR. I felt like I needed to call every single one of my family members after each bite of this dish. My mom would remark: "I'm kvelling!". My grandmother would call the flavor "mashugana" and would demand to meet the balabusta who created this divine dish. My dad would try to pretend he knows Yiddish and say some phrase involving the word "schlep". The point: this is one of the best things I've eaten in a very long time. I'm not sure what went into making the kefir ranch, but that hands-down made the dish. Yogurt/dill/caper semen of the gods (the Jewish god, obviously). And the bread was unbelievable as well - slightly crispy but perfectly spongy. Ugh. Wood-Grilled Gulf Shrimp w/ red flint florani polenta, smoked Oaxacan pasilla chile sauce, cilantro: A+I think I'm on record as saying I don't like polenta. But this wasn't your average polenta. It was quite grainy, which I adored. I'm a sucker for texture - I like chunky peanut butter, pulpy orange juice, cookies and cream ice cream and coarse grain mustard. So this was right up my alley. The shrimp were grilled to perfection, and I expected nothing less. But the confluence of flavors in the polenta/chile sauce combo was seriously something. As far as execution goes, this baby wins.Housemade Salsicia Pizza w/ roasted red peppers, house fior de latte, mozzarella, tomato: AI first need to say that this pizza was my 4th choice. I would have preferred the funghi or the fontina/brussels sprout (my dream combo), but my company hates brussels sprouts and is allergic to pine nuts. So our options were limited. THIS ALL SAID I still seriously enjoyed this pizza. The sausage was everything that homemade sausage should be, the mozzarella was fluffy, plentiful and heavenly. I've probably had better pizza in my life, but this was as well-done as I've seen.

Yum yum! Ambience: cute. It's a basic pizza shop but cute rustic feel to it with intimate seating......a bit too intimate at times when the place is full. We practically had dinner with our neighbors which was sorta semi awkward lol but it's what you get in Manhattan. staff: loved our waitress! We ordered individual slices but she made a suggestion that saved us money with the entire pie and for seating, she tried her best to get us, a group of 7, seated. Although the wait was about 1 hour on a Saturday night. Food: yummmmm and so filling. One slice is enough in my opinion. We got the classic spinach artichoke pie which they are famous for and was not disappointed. Perfect crust- none of that pizza falling apart in your hand nonsense. The crust was well baked and could handle the heavy sauce and toppings. It wasn't too oily and was perfectly fresh when we got it. Price: the entire pie is $32 and we split it so ended up being about $5 a person. Talk about a steal!! No dollar slice pizza but I'd rather pay $5 for this pizza than $1 for an overly oily street slice with sloppy crust. Will I be back? Yes because.....pizza.

How could this be anything but five stars? The inside space is immense and the filtered light is majestic! I knew the space was open and we asked one of the traffic cops where to enter. At this time, because the outside entrances aren't finished, we had to enter on Liberty Street south of the station and take an escalator down a few flights. Once you are in, all you have to do is follow the signs to The Oculus. It's worth it. The entire development is still far from being finished, however the raw marble clad space is terrific. Once all the stores and restaurants are open it may be too crowded to appreciate. Currently you can walk all the way through the station and passageways, under the highway and up into Brookfield Place without paying for a train ticket.

I was introduced to my very first ramen and pork belly bun experience at Ippudo NY in the East Village over five years ago. I had no idea what to expect then and now years later, here I am a self-proclaimed pro...well not really. I had some time to kill and wanted to eat something before a Yelp Off-Broadway event, so I searched my Yelp app for Asian cuisines nearby and noticed this spot was a mere two blocks away. I arrived to this Westside location a few minutes before 6:00pm and there at the empty entryway were two patrons who at that exact moment were being directed to their table by the hostess, perfect timing. The efficient hostess returned promptly and immediately guided me to the last seat at the modern looking communal counter. Little did I realize I lucked out getting seated so quickly. Just like the East Village location, every single customer is greeted with a Japanese welcome, which thank goodness isn't as loud and intrusive here on the Westside considering its more intimate and warm atmosphere. I was tempted to order an appetizer, but I know ramen servings are always plentiful. So I chose to have ramen only; the Drum Heart Ramen. The listed ingredients looked like a perfect combination that I knew I would enjoy. As I waited for my meal, I looked around the counter and it seemed as though I may have been the only one ordering this soup, and now I started thinking that I may have made the wrong choice. But once my order arrived and I took my first taste of this soup the umami jumped right out of that spoon offering hot, spicy, sweet, sour, salty, earthy, fragrant, rich, bold, unctuousnesses...oh my goodness...oh my goodness! It was a titillating palate dancer of flavors, which consisted of fresh herbs, pork belly, cilantro, and all others including the largest perfectly poached egg I have ever seen. All of these surrounded in a broth that had this look of charcoal and look of deep dark chocolate, which looked scary and intriguing all at the same time. All of my senses were engaged in this ramen experience. I never finish an entire bowl of ramen, but for this I had to. I will say that I am glad I came in not reading any prior reviews that may have swayed me to try what the masses had been ordering, my decision turned out to be a very good one indeed. For an impromptu visit, I was happy with everything. The impeccable service of the waiters, hostess, bussers, chefs, all efficient and friendly and run this operation like a well oiled machine. An experience I would love time and time again. My last note. Upon leaving a little less than an hour later, I could barely get out of the restaurant as the previously empty entryway was now hella crowded with patrons waiting to be seated...Ippudo Westside, well worth the wait.

The food here is consistently great and cheap! My go to is the duck with rice and the Chang fen with fish balls. Ah writing this is making me want the food. The man packs each lunch box to the brim with food so you definitely get your money's worth! The roast pork is delicious as well. You can get an amazing meal for about $5 or less! There is a long line always for the duck but I believe you can skip and just ask for Chang fen if you want? I haven't tried that but that's what my friend says.

When I moved to New York from California (San Francisco) my family thought I was crazy. How will you survive the winter... They said. Will you live in a safe neighborhood? Won't you miss your friends?Do you have health insurance?My short story begins when I am sitting at home in my new apartment in Chelsea about 2 weeks after my move. Hmm... You know what sounds good?! Mexican!!! I text my new NYC friends... Where can I get good Mexican?!? Cafe Cubano, Horchata, Pedro's Tacos they say... )Tacombi would not disappoint... I was assured. I cannot express my disappointment when I tried these places. These places are not authentic Mexican and they lack in the flavor department. I never would have thought the real reason why I would consider moving back home to the Bay Area would be lack of real, tasty Mexican food in New York.I'm so glad I found Los Tacos! I will wait in line until they close just to get real tacos. I don't care what it takes. The salsa is on point and is actually spicy! My favorite are the pork tacos and I always get a side of guacamole. Thank you taco gods.

What a breath of fresh air! A vegan restaurant without any soy protein in sight, purely focusing on plant-based foods and making them absolutely delicious. For 2, we shared 2 toasts, 1 cold dish, and 2 hot dishes. The carrot toast and fennel hummus toast were both very tasty, great flavor and texture combinations. The salt baked sweet potato was like a hearty potato salad, quite a substantial dish and so pretty to look at! The Maitake Mushrooms was my favorite - it's easy to love these mushrooms. Great sear, meaty interior, with a few bits and pieces of other vegetables to pair bites with. The basmati rice is a good option if you're looking for something more filling. It's similar to a risotto, and again the presentation was gorgeous. Make a reservation (since it's so easy to) because the space is pretty small, and request a seat at the bar so you can watch all the cooking in action. Service could've been more attentive, but everyone was nice including the chefs. Perfect if you want a lighter meal especially for spring/summer, and of course perfect excuse to grab ice cream afterwards (could not resist Big Gay Ice Cream across the street).

*Brunch*It all started a few decades back, on a small farm in Southern Ireland. A black rooster sat motionless on a fence for years, until one day it flew across a kitchen window and startled an Irishwoman. "LOOK AT THE BLACK FLYING COCK!" she yelled. Her young son astonished by his mother's reaction, opened this restaurant in honor of her memory. Who: NYC professional brunch crowdWhat: $15 bottomless mimosa, bloody marys and bellinis. The alcohol is flowing without a question and frequently and generously refilled into pitchers. The 90 minute limit is more of an effort to keep you alive than to kick you out of the restaurant. The brunch menu caters to those seeking creative breakfast options as well as those who are ready to jump to lunch. When: The brunch crowd thrives from 12-4 Where: Murray HillWhy: If you looking to mask the "Sunday Scaries" with a strong bellini-buzz while you eat fantastic food, this is the spot. The menu has something for everyone and the service is fantastic. They do not take reservations, but they encourage you to start your bottomless at the bar while you wait for a table. For $30 you can enjoy several beverages and a great meal. After this meal, I'll never go back to 'The Smith' or 'Sarabeths' again. Overall, this place deserves a strong recommendation.

Organic. FARM-TO-TABLE. Local sourced ingredients. Korean Food! *Chandler's voice* "Can it GET any better than this?!?" My friend and I came at lunch time around 2pm on a Monday. There were a 3-4 other tables occupied, there was more enough seating. It's pretty spacious for restaurant in Manhattan! For now, the LUNCH service is CASH ONLY! FOOD:What we ordered- Lunch Special: Uni Bibimbap ($9) with optional (+$3) Nutty Salad and Vegetable Dumplings-Kalbi Dumplings -Tofu and Kimchi Uni BibimbapI'm incredibly in love w/ UNI. There's a lot of different textures going on in your mouth: The soft buttery-ness of uni, the crunchiness of the quinoa, three different types of sweet and salty masago (fish eggs) that pop in your mouth, comes all over a bed of white rice. It also includes a side of chopped up kimchi, Korean-style pickled cucumber, lettuce and spring greens. It's recommended to mix it all up, I like to keep it a little separated so you can experience the flavors of the ingredients individually and your mouth doesn't get too bored. But it's far far from boring!It came with a side of slightly spicy miso soup w/ green onions, Nutty mixed green salad, kimchi, and 2 Vegetable Dumplings.Vegetable DumplingsI didn't even realized there was no meat in there. It's lightly fried, sprinkled with sesame seeds and seasoning and 100% YUM. Kalbi Dumplings According to my friend, the Kalbi Dumplings, tasted like real Kalbi, but now instead of get big serving size you can get it in dumpling form! Comes with 3 pieces. Tofu and Kimchi The tofu were little fried nuggets of deliciousness with a side of wilted kimchi. The kimchi was aged perfectly and had the right texture that complimented the bite size tofu! All my plates were clean and empty! A sign of a good meal! SERVICE: It's so awesome when restaurants leave a bottle of water at your leisure whenever your glass get empty. When our vintage "milk" water bottle was empty, it was quickly replaced by the server. The staff didn't rush us at the end! I love that! DECOR:LOVE IT! Feels upscale, Hipster-esque, Metal Chairs, wooden tables, wooden trays, Wooden Walls, Wood everything! Very sustainable! My friend and I joked about how the big moon in the middle is actually representative of a big radish.  TIP: -Free Cocktail Soju w/ Check In (Saving it for a Rainy Day)

I first came here around 2 years ago, so was overdue a return visit.Now I'm a resident of Manhattan, what seemed 'cramped' now becomes 'cosy'.What seemed 'noisy' now becomes 'atmospheric' and thus so it was with Palma, it was significantly better than I remembered it to be, simple and superb Italian food in 'cosy' and 'atmospheric' surroundings.My advice, keep it simple here and the quality of the ingredients and cooking comes to the fore...simply delicious pasta.I won't be leaving it 2yrs to my next visit.

This place reminds me of little house on the prairie for some reason. Walking in, place is narrow, railroad like kind of restaurant. Country looking. From the front looking and walking in. It looked like seatings where limited. But they had a secluded like section seating towards the back and a little outdoor patio! The patio is so cute! We were seated right away in the back. Party of 5. This place does not take reservations. So first come first serve. Drinks:- Half a pitcher of Bellini Brunch Menu:- Benedict Royal Brunch served w/ Smoked Salmon- Egg, Cheese Sandwich w/ Fries - Mussels - Chicken & WaffleDessert:- Brownie Hazelnut w/ Vanilla IceHonestly and surprisingly everything was delicious! I was surprised that they served mussels on the kid's menu and did not have that on the brunch menu. We adults love them more than the kids. So we ordered 2x of the mussels. The portion and the size of the mussels were quite appetizing. Where as other places served pea sized mussels. **Kids menu they eat free during dinner hours, I believe if I read correctly. Service was great and attentive.Will definitely be back.

This is the perfect spot to have breakfast, lunch or a coffee date. The whole family were running around the city and while we waited for my husband, my son and I stopped in for some brekkie. Based on the Yelp ratings, I had a good feeling about the place, plus the food pics were appetizing. It's a cozy café but they made use of every corner to allow for ample seating; it's way bigger than it looks upon entry. We chose a sunny table at the front entrance and the employee taking care of the counter did double duty and came to get our orders. They have a large tea selection that I couldn't choose from, so I went with the fresh squeezed red grapefruit juice. My son had one of their Tropical smoothies, made with coconut water. We both ordered the Nuotatore Sandwich, which had a little cream cheese, smoked salmon, tomatoes and spring greens. It was served with a small, lightly dressed salad and was really good. It was just enough food to satisfy us while in the city but I wish we would've ordered one of those sandwiches and a quiche so we could've had the opportunity to try a couple of items. Hindsight is 20/20.They have a small menu and food is prepared well and if ever in the area again, I would definitely have to stop in.

The last time I saw the Rockettes live, I was a kid. We had an opportunity to see it on July 4th and I grabbed at the chance. My BF hasn't seen the Rockettes either in many many years. Let's just say I got really excited at the first scene when the Rockettes came out. I love the way they dance in unison. There must be about 50 of them. The costumes that the Rockettes were wearing in each scene were really nice too. They are mesmerizing to watch with their perfect formations and perfectly unison kicks and choreography. I love how NY the Rockettes are. The story plot is pretty light, it's about a family visiting NYC on vacation and the two kids get separated from the parents in Grand Central subway station. So we follow the kids as they go through a NYC adventure as they try to find their parents again. We follow the kids to some pretty iconic NYC sites such as the MET, Wall Street and the bull, NYC Public Library Main Branch with the 2 lions, Central Park and the Alice and the Wonderland statue, Statue of Liberty/Ellis Island, Empire State Building, Grand Central Station, and of course the Rockettes. The famous statues all over NYC come alive to help the kids reunite with their parents. I felt like I visited everywhere in NYC without leaving my seat. That was pretty awesome. This show is a tribute to everything that is NYC. The special effects, lighting, visual stage design, costumes, puppetry, choreography, etc were all awe inspiring. The Egytian scene was cool, the rain on stage looked fun, the couture costumes. Everything was top notch in this show. It's definitely worth the money. A lot of the numbers and scenes just wow'ed me. I never realized how big the stage was until I saw it from the Mezzanine. To fully see the wonderful Rockettes kick line and multiple dance formations, the best seats are from the front center mezzanine. To also see the special effects that light up the entire theatre, the front mezzanine is the best seat. If you sat in the orchestra, you'll miss how the Rockettes dance formations look like from the top and you would totally miss the action happening on the sides of the theatre that are eye level with the mezzanine. There is also no way to see from the orchestra the special effects and lighting of the entire theatre in a lot of the different scenes which all were very impressive. There is definitely more special effects and lighting design in this production than the majority of the shows on Broadway. I would totally recommend this show over others on Broadway if you are looking for flash or pizzazz. It was definitely a really fun show.

This is my go-to supermarket whenever I am in the Chinatown area. I think I am very partial to it because it was here where I was able to accomplish one of my life goals: walk into the middle of a top chef filming when they run through the grocery store to prepare for their next challenge! It was during top chef all-stars which was even better because I recognized everyone running around. Now I am digressing.Back to the supermarket. This place has a plethora of Asian sauces, snacks, vegetables, fruit, dry noodles, and meats...just to name a few things. I think what they are most well-known for is their cheap good sushi. You can get a full salmon roll for less than $5 and the quality is not bad at all. Overall, a good, reliable supermarket where one can get a wide variety of Asian goodies.

I lived in LA for five years before moving to NYC. This place has this comforting feeling and the best tacos in New York City. And trust me, I have been on the hunt for a good taco for a year now.Here's what you need to know:1. Guac + tacos + marg = LESS THAN $20 IN NEW YORK2. Lengua tacos. LENGUA TACOS. You need to get them. 3. The margs are real and they be real strong.4. The menu makes me laugh. Damn right they don't got fajitas. 5. LA teams are featured here. As an avid Bay Area supporter, I only state this to establish the environment of the establishment.6. I may or may not dream of the guac cause I'm so far from CA.In terms of the turn up, this is a restaurant/bar with more emphasis of the restaurant. If you want a bar vibe, this probably isn't the spot for you.When it comes to deals versus quality of food versus vibes, this is easily one of the top places in NYC. I highly recommend this spot if you're in EV. It's a local hangout with some of the best Mexican food you can find in the city.

Five Stars for service, Five stars for taste, five stars for making us feel welcome and special. Portion size five stars and selections five stars. It is hard to find anything wrong with tonight's meal. I won't sleep tonight I'm so full! I've got a couple more photos on my daughters camera. There were so many courses I can't remember all the names. They asked up front about my allergies. I feel comfortable knowing my food was prepared with my health in mind. They even have a little stool to put your handbag on instead of on the floor! Lovely atmosphere not overly gaudy. I'm definitely not a food review writer. This was a once in a lifetime experience for me!!Thanks to everyone involved for a memorable evening. My photos will have to tell the story.....

I think it is safe to say I fell in love with wonderful establishment at first sight. I have seen a couple of blogs and press releases written up about this amazing space and it has everything needed to breathe life in to this part of Harlem. I think it was a number of things won me over such as the ambiance, decor, service, drinks, and bar menu. I went on a Saturday around 5ish because I was just meeting up with a group of friends for a drink of two. It was rather quiet and mostly that is because they were probably switching over from brunch to dinner time. The mixologist (Cyllan) was inviting and very informed...let's make this clear ...he has his craft down to an art AND HE IS SERIOUS ABOUT IT. Drinks are about 14-15 bucks a piece, but I consider worthy of forking over my hard earned dollars. After several drinks I decided to try a dish off their bar menu and the cod fritters sounded great after having a drink or two. It was a great appetizers and definitely had me wanted to come back to try the dinner menu.Around 6 or 7 ish it picked up and almost every table was full with patrons along with the bar. My advice to you my fellow Yelpers is GET RESERVATIONS. This is a place you want to bring your lady or male friend to leave a lasting impressions, grab casual drinks, or have a fab ladies night out. I look forward to coming back soon!

Ah the glory of Gotham. There aren't too many places like this left. From the imposing entrance at the corner of the block to the stout, yet friendly security team that seamlessly lurk in the dark corners this place screams, in a muted whisper, the grandeur of all things vintage and charming. The mystique of watching this place transform for each event is a luxury afforded to it's employees only. Even if you happen to be hosting, they will allow you entry only after the basic accommodations have been met. Akin to an opera singer prior to a show, no secrets must be revealed. I love that they can do so based on their expert attention to detail and professional staff. The staff is both professional, yet approachable. Despite the large crowd that this venue can hold in the main room and in the multiple alcoves/rooms, there is never a worry as the space is ample (think fairytale ballroom). It goes without saying that the place is immaculate, carpets are rich and plush, and the floor is heel/stiletto friendly.Catering is also well executed. All of the items in the four course dinner were delectable and service was well timed. (Sadly, there are no food pictures because in this environment it is just uncouth). Bar service was efficient, quick and courteous. I can honestly say I enjoyed every aspect of the evening and if forced to sum it up in one word: superb.Old school charm that makes the hustle and bustle of the City disappear must be acknowledged. I would recommend for any special event/occasion and I cannot wait to return.

I thought this place was better than West Malaysia and Nyona. It's such a hole in the wall and I never knew this fusion restaurant existed until my sister mentioned it to me. Their roti was at least $1.50 cheaper than many other places which is a steal and the pancake was such an interesting texture + taste which I enjoyed plenty. The chicken wings stuffed with sticky rice was also interesting, it was really crispy and tasty.My sister had ordered a tofu + chicken and rice dish and the sauce they had smelled amazing and it was a good amount of serving and delicious. I had the hainese chicken and their chicken serving was generous. What really amazed me was that they served their hainese chicken with hainese flavored rice, every other Malaysian location I went to serves hainese chicken with basic white rice.The steps are a bit steep so I wouldn't come here if you're drunk as you might roll down the stairs but do try this place as they have great service, are never busy and in my opinion serve up some delicious malaysian/indonesian food.

About a month ago at my work I noticed one of my coworker's beautiful knives after he removed it from it's wooden sheath. Being that I'd only experienced those crapping plastic bland guards, I was immediately in awe of this new set up. After a few uses of this Togiharu petty knife, I was sold. I had to have one.To my great surprise, my wonderful mother took action before I could, and purchased a Togiharu petty and santoku knife set for me. Thanks ma!!! :-D To make sure the knives would stay as magnificent as they were on the day I received them, I traveled to Korin to purchase proper wooden sheaths and ask about sharpening stones. All I can say is I received the most educational and pleasant help I've ever received when shopping for knives or their accessories. The attendants are so knowledgeable and friendly. From the moment you get there, they greet you and guide you through the store, answering all your questions and giving you all the information you need to pick the right knives and accessories. Truly A+ service.After a few weeks of working with my new Togiharus, I'm so thankful to have come across them. What absolutely amazing knives. They're relatively lightweight, have a handle which fits comfortably in my tiny-winy hand, and have a slightly thinner bland then European style knives; thus allowing them to be more easily sharpened, and allowing you to perform precision cuts with ease, butcher meat and fish like nobodies business (hot knife through butter!), and not crack root vegetables when cutting. Just be sure to not leave this knives wet or exposed to acid for too long. They will rust and discolor!My advice to you: if you are a culinary professional, take the time to travel to this playland. You'll be there for longer than you think, and leave with a lighter wallet, but you'll have a blast. If you're a home culinary enthusiast, still pay Korin a visit. You'll find flatware that will be perfect for your next extravagant dinner party, learn a ton about knives and how to care for them, and maybe even get a show from their in-house sharpener working his magic on the giant stone. This place is so awesome.

Peter is definitely the man with the hands. On Chloe C's review and recommendation I came here after a massage therapist I like was too sick to work on me. I like my massages the way I love chocolate. Better not to have a massage than a bad one. But I was in severe pain. I usually pass on these cheap Asaian spas because I feel like I am taking advantage of an overworked, underpaid drone and end up tipping 50-60 percent for what has always been a mediocre session. Luckily, my tip was not out of pity. He has more feeling in his hands than many massage therapists I know, and is professional and accommodating. If you are open to a different style than Swedish you can have your knots worked out here. They end with a few minutes of hot stone. Picky person that I am, I bring my own lotion and you can too. The place is definitely no frills, with tables with a hole for your face. The tables are harder than at a posh spa but if you want deep tissue, it's better for that work anyway. The rooms are stalls with curtains for a door so if you want quiet, come at off hours. It is clean. It's a win win if you plan it right. The price is cheap enough at $48 an hour so you can leave a generous tip(I always hand it to them directly btw) for an underpaid, talented worker and you leave feeling better, body wise and karma wise.

"Goodies for cheap" If your looking for some snack and candies glore but your looking for an upper classy feel then you would want to come here! Literally I come to this location for all my pocky needs (Japanese candy sticks). They value at only $1.30 per pack which is not bad at all especially because of the fact it's considered an import. Five below is also known for having some rare candies such as those bottle pops, pop rocks, and those flavored jelly beans just to name a few. They each value at roughly $1 each so you can go stacking up and turning your own home into an old school candy store!"Other notable items"They have phone cases (usually worth $5) and selfie sticks to take that candid shot of your entire group! They carry spots things if your looking for something quick to throw around at the park and you don't want to pay to much at places like sports authority or modells. "Overall"Come down here and get yourself some candy and cheap juices!

Yeahhh this is probably the best boba spot in all of NYC. They have a wide variety of teas matched by a quality selection of bobas including almond jelly and classic tapioca pearls. As many people on here attest, the green tea and matcha latte are both excellent choices, but I would also recommend you venture into the black tea/thai iced teas as well.There really isn't much to say here other than that there isn't a ton of seating, you will have to fight armies of hipsters to make it to the counter, the tea is a little pricey but worth it, and try to experiment if you can. Oh, and don't feel like you have to get milk in everything. Like every pic on here has a tea with milk but I got mine without (it was a jasmine green I think) and it was absolutely delicious. So, don't feel like you are missing out if you go milk free. Anyway, cows' milk is kind of on the wane right now and, I am not a vegan or anything, but when you think about what it is it does become kind of baffling why people drink it at all. Moooooo.

The Quick: French, beautiful, and girlie little macaroon shop where the treats are as sweet as the store. Tiny, with not much seating, but this little shop is just perfection. The Details: Some places live up to the hype, and for me this tiny Parisian shop is one of them. The macaroons are small and $2.80 each but they are the perfect texture and very flavorful. The decorations and boxes are perfect down to the last detail (the bow!) If you're in the upper Eastside, it's worth stopping in for a treat. The Damage: $2.80 each, you can order individuals or a box of six. Either way, make sure to ask for a bag as they are beautiful!

When I was growing up, my mother used to make me sandwiches for lunch. She was a very hard working woman who did her best to put a roof over the kids heads and made sure we were never hungry. Being as busy as she was, she didn't always have the time to make the fanciest sandwiches or come up with a diverse meal plan for us. We were on a budget. Lunch for school was often simply ham and cheese in between two slices of white bread.I ate that for years. Or at least I tried to. Unless I was extremely hungry, sometimes I would just throw the sandwich away. I'm not sure what type of ham she would get for these sandwiches, but eventually, I just couldn't eat ham anymore. I think I told my mother to stop making these sandwiches for me and she never did again. I was a very unappreciative kid. To this year, I've never willfully ordered ham of any kind (bacon, pork belly, and the kind are a different story).Fast forward 12-13 years later, and I'm told about one of the best bakeries in New York City--Arcade. Deciding on what sandwich to get, I wanted something on their famous baguettes. But when I read the menu, I saw the ingredients in the sandwich... cheese, butter, and... ham.Not wanting any other type of bread for my sandwich, I swallowed my old hatred for ham. After snapping pictures of this plain looking sandwich, I delve in. A big bite for this crunchy-on-the-outside, slightly-chewy-on-the-inside baguette. My teeth sunk in getting into each layer. First into the subtle butter. Then into the cheese and the HAM simultaneously...The harmony of all four simple ingredients in my mouth had me wondering what I was eating. Was this how sandwiches were supposed to taste.. with HAM??? This could possibly be the only ham sandwich I can ever eat again.Now, I understand what my mother had to do to feed three children at the same time while holding down a full-time job, working overtime, and trying to get her degree at the same time... This sandwich made me appreciate that. It brought back memories of sandwiches I ate for years and threw away for years.Thank you, Mom, for all your sacrifice and thank you Arcade Bakery for helping me appreciate her.

We've been back here at least four more times, and we love it every time. The service is always so warm and friendly, and now they take online reservations?! Yall need to get on that!!Since our first visit, we've tried the sweetened nuts (like praline nuts, but honestly, the Nuts2nuts cart is better), and the kale dip with assorted breads (would be better warm, but the breads are fun).The pineapple and pancetta flatbread is crispy, light and delicious - it reminded me of the rectangle pizza I used to get in grade school with the cubed pepperoni, but far tastier. The boy adores the peppercorn burger, but my heart remains with the Benson burger. Beets + beef = life.It's a shame not more people seem to know about the churro ice cream sandwich, which has swirls of fried cinnamon sugared disks with vanilla ice cream and honey drizzle. Somehow light (least it felt that way because we inhaled it), and oh so satisfying!Benson, we love you. Will be back soon!

I put off getting a haircut because I'm living off student loans and couldn't afford one. However, my ends were getting atrocious, and it was either spend the money or cut it myself. I think I'll spend the money.I made the appointment about three hours before. No problem.Tapping into my precious loans was well worth it! The shampoo was not rushed at all. It was very relaxing and felt great. Their shampooing stations are extraordinarily comfortable. It didn't hurt my neck like most places.The man who cut my hair (Lam) did an incredible job as well. He radiated confidence. I gave him minimal directions and let him do his thing. What was most impressive for me is that he styled my hair with only a brush and blowdryer, virtually no product (that I remember). I've never seen a stylist do this before, and I've never seen my hair cooperate so well. Furthermore, this is the first time that I've gotten bangs and not hated them. I love 'em!And perhaps most importantly, NO SMALL TALK. Lam let me sit in comfortable silence with my own happy thoughts and didn't force me to have a conversation. It's an introvert's paradise. :DOverall, my cut was $39 before tip. I will definitely be back.

How to survive a Tone House workout:1. Wear long pants that cover your knees, unless you don't mind having your knees slide over the astroturf.2. Come 10 min early, so you can stretch. The warm up is tough here, and you will be sprinting like crazy, so stretch beforehand.3. Its about TEAM. Its all about TEAMWORK. You cheer everyone on, you cheer till the last person touches that finish line. 4. Show up. Workout hard (drop dead in between then get up again, then drop dead, then get up again). Finish strong. Finish proud. Go home and sit on couch. Other useful tips:1. There are cubby holes for your bags and hooks for your coats. 2. There is a unisex bathroom but no showers.3. You are provided with a towel and a bottle of water. There is also a water fountain.4. First timers get a special rate of $20.5. You can sign up for classes online.6. Tone House is on the second floor.Tone House is the hardest workout in New York. I take all sorts of classes at Equinox, run marathons, but Tone House was like "random hard workout class" x4. Its like your usual bootcamp class but on crack. To be honest, I was so nervous coming here, I already felt like puking in my Uber. I don't even feel that nervous going for a job interview. I got there early and started stretching. I didn't know anybody going there obviously, there were some others who showed up with their friends. But the camaraderie and team spirit is so great that everyone will cheer for you, that you will feel as if the whole team is your friend. My coach was Tamara and she was excellent. Half of my class happened to be newbies aka first timers, so I felt a little less intimidated.Well, as I mentioned above, the warm up isn't some simple stretching. The warm up is tough. According to Tamara, if you can survive the work out, you can survive the class. We spent the first 10 min sprinting over these blocks with the faster people going first and the slower people behind. The faster people will catch up with the slower people so you better keep running. You will have to jump over the hurdles, and also jump over them sideways. You will even do push ups in between those hurdles. After the first 10 min, I was pouring in sweat and panting. Now for the real work out. We did lots of bear crawls. We also got into a plank position, put sliders under both feet, and dragged ourselves from one end of the room to the other with our arms. Tamara also divided us into little groups of 3-4 people and each group would take turns doing certain exercises (putting the gliders under your hands and pushing them with your legs, getting down on all 4s and hoping forward with your legs, then moving your hand forwards, then hopping again till the end of the room etc). While doing these, the rest of the class would cheer you on. I wasn't the fastest at moving around on gliders under my feet while holding a plank position and trying to pull myself forward. In fact, I had to take lots of breaks on my knees (which is why you should wear long pants that cover your knees), and ended up being the slowest of my group. I must have been with ultra fit D1 athletes or something. What got me through doing 3 laps was the wonderful team cheering me on, Tamara even came beside me and did it with me and helped me get to the finish line. I still remember standing up with sweat dripping down my red face, and everyone was clapping for me, telling me I had done a good job. There was one girl in my group who hid in the toilet at times, because she was scared to do the exercises. My philosophy is to suck it up and do it, and finish strong. It doesn't matter how old you are, or how fat/ thin you are, just do it, mind over matter. However, I would strongly recommend being in decent shape, if not, you will probably end up puking. We also did push ups with gliders under our hands. The last set of exercises that we did was lunging back, and to the side, followed by jumping lunges. I have fairly strong legs, I can run marathons, however Tone House had me burnt out. I realized my quads were so exhausted that I could barely jump. My jumps were getting lower and lower haha. I was actually shocked that my legs were this tired.Finally, we got into a circle and did all sorts exercises like burpees, push ups, running in place etc. You feel like a hero when you are done. I was so tired I had to outside and sit somewhere just to catch my breath. I felt as if I was still panting and sweating 25 min later. Yes, its that hard of a work out. Its no joke. I came home and sat on the couch for another 30 min.Tone House takes working out to a whole new level. You might want to cancel partying plans after Tone House, because sitting on the couch after that with a bottle of wine and some cheese (Trader Joe's is nearby) is the way to do it.

LuAnne's Wild Ginger All-Asian Vegan provides tasty, healthy dishes at reasonable prices in a relaxing atmosphere, and the service is great, too.I've been here several times, and I usually start with the spring rolls and the agedashi-tofu, which have been yummy every time. Recently, I tried the crispy soy protein and the stuffed wontons, which tasted great.Seriously, I have not had a bad meal here.I have not tried the desserts yet, but from the happy faces of other patrons and the great Yelp reviews, I look forward to coming to LuAnne's restaurant the next time that I have sweet tooth.YUM!

Man this place is eerie at first...like dusty Victorian meets the porn music from 8MM. Walk through an art gallery and open the narrow door in the back left corner, and you'll find a cool secret oasis of cocktails and comfy furniture that immediately reminded me of Ranstead Room in Philadelphia. The cocktails here are fantastic. Vanishing Point and Midnight in Paris were both fantastic, and for $13 apiece, they were well worth it. Bartenders are friendly yet professional, and the experimental/trip hop music lends to a curious ambiance that'll have you coming back for certain.

I normally don't review bodegas/delis but I'll make this place the exception because I am impressed. I also just really wanted upload a picture of my awesome *$3.50* salad. Unreal outside of Chinatown. Super affordable prices, quality meats by the pound, chicken that is actually quality chicken breast rather than "chicken breast," and $2.50 base salads! I hope this place never changes. One suggestion: please update your seamless menu with more options (e.g., specific ice cream flavors and snacks like clif bars) for those of us who are truly too lazy to cook and/or are hungry at 2am in the morning.

"Patience and Fortitude conquer all things." - Ralph Waldo Emerson (and/or Fiorello LaGuardia) Five stars. Hot new bar in LES.Came here on a Friday night (2/19), not realizing they'd just opened the night before! I read an article written in the fall about the bar, but guess the opening had been delayed a bit. It was so nice to experience the place when it's less crazy, because I know in a few weeks it'll be impossible to get in. Also, when I visited, Giuseppe Gonzalez himself was the bartender! ("The very handsome half-Italian half-Puerto Rican" as Pablo the server described him.)To drink: The Tough Room - guinness and whiskey sour. "Tastes bright and foamy, but unmistakably guinness." - Marissa L., my adventurous companion Trinidad Sour - rye, lemon, orgeat, angostura. If drinks/flavors could have shapes, this drink would taste round. Like a perfect circle. It's sweet but not. Deep but not. Heavy but light. And in a weird way, tasted like a chocolate covered orange. (Please don't let that description read too specifically and turn you off. That's just the only other flavor combination that made me feel similarly!)The Twin Lion - rye, lemon, sugar, egg white, wine. Pretty drink with four visible layers. Frothy and foamy on top with the egg white, then silky, then the hit of wine. Very fun. Czarine - vodka, dry vermouth, apricot liquor, bitter. "Mmm, tasty!" - Marissa again. To eat: Thai Chili Wings. These were perfect. Right amount of crisp on the skin but soft from the meat. Served not too hot (as wing often are). And the thai chili flavor was sweet and tangy without being too thick or syrupy sweet, again how these wings usually are. I think there were 10 wings. They come with a sauce that tastes sour creamy-y, and an onion-y slaw. I didn't love either accoutrement alone, but the trio of chicken, sauce, and slaw was divine. Shrimp Cocktail. Thick big shrimp (5) served on an asian-y carrot slaw. The cocktail sauce was BOMB. Thick, chunky, spicy, and red. Lol. Again, I really enjoyed the shrimp, sauce, and slaw all together. Short Rib Buns. Order comes with two. The short rib is good, if a little salty. Dish comes together nicely with a fresh mango slaw on top. (Lots of slaws here...ever write a word so much you start to question if it's a real word and if you're spelling it correctly? Yeah. Slaw.) Just be careful with these because the paper they're served in stuck to the buns, which aided in their disintegration. Music was a loud but cool mix of 2000s alternative rock (I think) - just imagine lots of The Killers. Two servers were working together, the aforementioned Pablo and a very nice girl named Caitlin. ("Girl" seems diminutive, but "lady" seems aging. Le sigh.) Caitlin was super excited about all the cocktails and did a great job of explaining them and aiding in our decisions. I hope to see her behind the bar soon! When we were done, I kindof elbowed my way up to the bar. Giuseppe looked up quickly and said, "I'll be right with you!" "Oh that's okay, I just wanted to say thank you." His face lit up, and I could see his pride and excitement pouring through with his ear to ear smile. Finally, super cool: the two lions on the logo are Patience and Fortitude, from the NYPL main branch. Apparently when Giuseppe was a kid during NYC's dark days, he wasn't allowed to go anywhere after school except the library. Swoon. TL;DR - get here soon so you can say you went before it was famous. And yes I'll go with you.

Holy caffeine Batman! This Armenian coffee tastes just like Greek coffee or Turkish. There's really no better way in my mind to top off a fantastic Mediterranean/Middle Eastern meal than with the traditional boiled ground coffee bean concoction. But first... Almayass is absolutely my favorite restaurant in Manhattan. They are going to be huge. You are going to be amazed. I tell you it's terrific. I know food. Nobody eats food better than me (sorry just finished watching the Sunday morning political shows). But seriously. Everything that we ordered was in itself an exemplary culinary experience. Perhaps the best lamb chops I've ever had and they were even enjoyed by my guests who aren't lamb meat lovers. The list of things we ordered includes over two-thirds of the appetizers so I'm not going to list them. For the main we begrudgingly (because we were so full) consumed the mixed grill. Ultra highlights of the mixed grill were the lamb chops and the chicken. They entertained all my absurdities. For instance, I insisted they bring me a whole lemon and they did: on a plate with a knife to cut it myself--precisely as I had demanded. They are going to become really sick of me!

My friends know I like to spin. I like to spin a lot. In fact if you are one of those cool kids who follow me here then you know I am a complete cyclepath. So when I was asked to take a ride up to test out a new spin studio on ClassPass, I said ":Absolutely, let's do it!" I get somewhat complacent in my class grove with my classpass routine so I love when people recommend a new place. Admittedly, I haven't ventured up to Harlem for anything besides Dinosaur BBQ, but this was worth the trip and I was down for an exploration. It is conveniently located right by the 2/3 so if coming up from midtown or UWS it is pretty easy. Seriously, don't be lazy, explore your city. .The studio reminds me of a former beauty salon or barbershop ... just without the mirrors and salon chairs everywhere. You will see what I mean. You walk downstairs into a reception area where an extremely friendly front desk girl checks you in. From there you walk into the spin room where there are cubbies for your things as well as bathrooms in the back to change. The bikes are all brand new. They have baskets for those wearing sneakers and clips for any pros with their SPD shoes.  I love that they have the monitors on them so I can think in terms of RPM while I spin. It makes for a much more efficient workout. Harder to slack off. Your bike comes prepared with water and a towel for you. I love that personal touch. The studio is also extremely clean. I understand you are there to sweat but the last thing I want it to grip onto a bike and have to worry about the sweat residue of the person before you. You won't have that worry here at all. The class I took was a reggae themed ride. What is that you may ask? Well you are spinning out to reggae music. Do I know much about reggae? No, but who cares, it was dope. If you are new to spin, that's totally cool, this place is probably perfect for you. I love themed rides and reggae made for great spin music due to its controlled nature. Specifically it was awesome for climbing. The instructor did a great job of getting new riders set up and comfortable on their bikes before walking them through the different hand positions. With no mirrors it is a judgement free zone in here. You focus on yourself, the music, and the spinning. It was a tough class, but definitely a good kind of tough. I walked out of there with some happy jello legs. It felt great.After class the owner Tameca, greeted everyone with a nice little surprise of bananas, energy bars, and coconut water. Such a nice treat. Not sure if that is standard but definitely unique to other classes I have taken. Also the reason I didn't collapse before dinner later. Thanks again. Loved the class.

BESFREN is located within/behind the Korean ginseng store on the corner of 32nd and 5th. Blink and you could miss it.Seriously, this is some of the best Asian dessert EVER. After a meal at Her Name is Han around the corner, my friends and I dashed real quick around the corner to make it 2 minutes before they close at 8pm on Sunday. This place serves all sorts of baked goods and sweets from truffles to canelle to petit fours. They also sell gelato by il laboratorio del gelato. However, the piece de resistance - the roll cakes in multiple flavors and the chiffon donuts. So many things, so little room in my stomach.I had bites of my friend's roll cakes and oh my goodness gracious I was wishing I had gotten those. The jasmine green tea is different because it actually tastes like jasmine tea, not just the normal hardly flavored matcha flavor. The salted caramel is the perfect marriage of salty and sweet. The cream for both are not too sweet, a very fresh milky flavor, and filled with vanilla beans which are my favorite! I will most definitely have every single flavor of these the next time I stop by this dessert shop.For myself, I ordered the Jasmine Green Tea chiffon donut, which was unique... kind of. It's nothing like a donut at all, really... more like an Asian pound cake. It tastes like the honey cakes you can get at the Asian supermarket and is a little moist with some sort of honey or sugary sap. The green tea flavor isn't as pronounced in this cake, but it's still very delicious though sweeter than the roll cakes. The white chocolate on top makes the "donut" a little hard to eat since its hard on top, but nevertheless it's a great dessert. I just prefer the outstanding roll cakes more.Not much seating inside, so I'd suggest this as a take out dessert place. They've also got a nice array of interesting hot and cold drinks on their menu also, ranging from ginseng lattes to grapefruit yuzu tea.Will definitely be back.

While this reservation is incredibly difficult to secure, the food and dining experience are unforgettable. My grandfather knew someone who knew people that could get a table, and as a birthday gift brought my family to dine there.The first thing I was taken aback by was that a waiter came out and started asking what we wanted to eat and spouted Italian options that ran the gamut from seafood salad with lobster, shrimp, crab, and calamari to all sorts of pastas, veal, chicken, meatballs, sausage, clams, a basil and breadcrumb coated fried mozzarella and paired with a simple tomato sauce to create a "caprese" and other dishes I did not recognize or forgot in the deluge of options. They did this in a way that was very charming. Although it was overwhelming to have these options thrown at you rapid fire, it made you feel like they wanted to get to know you as a diner and prepare the meal specifically for you. As we were a party of 7, the spread that they eventually presented was incredible and had all of the above mentioned items.All of these things were cooked beautifully and you could taste the time and energy that painstakingly went into producing every slow simmered sauce and accompanying item, and the proteins were all succulent. As someone who is fairly well-versed on food, but certainly not an expert on all available Italian dishes, I would say that if you're open to a wide variety of options to ask what the waiter recommends, or ask other diners what they've enjoyed (if you feel so audacious), as I guarantee it will be unique, made to order, and absolutely delicious.If you can get a table here cancel any other plans you may have had, this is an experience that simply cannot be replicated elsewhere.

Delicious & artfully prepared healthy food. Everything is flavorful, beautiful and yummy good. Even kids will enjoy their veggies at Beyond Sushi. There is a lunch special that includes a small soup. There are filling & delicious hand rolls, such as Nutty Buddy--it has buckwheat noodles, cashews, carrots, cilantro, tofu, avocado, peanut butter & a drizzle of flavorful sauce. This is a yummy, filling, hand roll. The Spicy Mango roll is a big favorite--it has black rice, avocado, mango, English cucumber, spicy veggies, & sauce. Sweet Tree has sweet potato, 6-grain rice, avocado , alfalfa sprouts & a yummy sauce. And there is LOTS MORE TO SELECT FROM. It's all great!

Barney's is in a league unto itself. Very different from the 2 other "Big B's" (Bloomingdale's & Bergdorf). The store windows are usually decorated with avant guard fashion (as you can see from the pictures).The first floor is a wonderland of high end, non-traditional department store handbags and accessories (Celine, Goyard). The bags aren't locked inside glass cases, if you want to touch one, look inside or venture close to a mirror to see how one looks with your ensemble, you are free to do so. They also have a beautiful display of jewelry from less well known (but extremely expensive) designers. Their fine jewelry department is also breathtaking! This is the only store in Manhattan that carries Hermes, outside of, well, Hermes. The selection isn't huge but the fact that Barney's has it, is pretty amazing.Downstairs is the Beauty Level which definitely rivals the one in Bergdorf (Bloomingdale's doesn't even come close). It is a wonderland of high-end cosmetics - don't come here looking for MAC, Clinque or Estee Lauder. Lila-B, Serge Lutens' & Cle de Peau Beaute will laugh at you! All kidding aside, the sales staff is super friendly and accommodating. Be mindful, when purchasing perfume, the sales staff defers to the larger sized bottle without asking - you have been warned!The clothing is beautiful and wearable - unfortunately, not affordable. Then again, what do you expect from Barney's??

After having dinner in the area we decided to stop here for a drink. After making our way down the stairs, we made our way inside and there was a guy waiting there ready to sit us. They had the option of a table or at the bar. I would've loved to sit at the bar, but because it was really full, we went for a table near the entrance. The bar itself is one large room with the bar closer to the bathrooms, which are all the way in the back of the establishment.After being seated and given menus, about two or so minutes later we were approached by our server. He took a seat, as he could tell we were still going over the menu and maybe needed some guidance. He asked me what alcohol I preferred, taste, etc and gave me his suggestions -- which I took, and were great.The entire place is very dim, but it gave off a romantic feel, IMO. They also had some food on the menu, which I did want to try but because we just ate I just wasn't going to be able to fit much more into my stomach -- it came down to deciding between more food or alcohol ....... I chose alcohol =X.For me, this place is really just great. Great location, great ambiance, great service, great drinks, great quality all around. I will definitely back over and over again.

WOW. No wonder it's always crowded and the wait is long. I was hoping to eat there again a lot sooner but when I'm hungry I want food like... Now. So waiting almost an hour was a little frustrating. When I walked in I was handed one of those buzzers like the ones from shake shack to let me know when there was a table available. There were two chairs available at the bar, so my friend and I had a couple drinks while we waited. The bar tenders were really nice. We almost ordered food at the bar but our buzzer went off so we went upstairs where the seating is. Every table was taken. So we sat down and went over the menu and I wanted to order almost everything. However, I already knew I had to order the pork belly sliders. They were amazing. We also had the chicken pot pie... Also really good. I forgot what else we ordered but everything was above average. I was so hungry and excited about the food I didn't take pictures.Also, their cocktail list is extensive and unique. Other than the long wait and crammed seating, this place should appeal to almost anyone

Modern // RusticFarm-to-TableWhether you're dining casual at the bar or slightly more dressed up this spacious neighborhood spot is a welcomed addition to the Upper West Side. Meat eaters welcome, fish lovers too. Delicious but limited options for vegans or vegetarians. This is one of those restaurants you could come to regularly without getting bored of the menu. An appetizer and a main and not be overwhelming the portion sizes are just right. There are both light and hearty options available. Loved the octopus, beet salad, hamachi tartare, rabbit pappardelle, pork chop, chicken... the list goes on. Have yet to have a bad dish here everything has been delicious. Whether you're on a date, have a group of friends, are with co-workers, or you're dining at the bar. A solid choice for any occasion. Definitely worth visiting the neighborhood if you are elsewhere. The Scene: Upscale, Modern, RusticDestination Rating: 8Date Rating: 9Hob Nob Potential: 5 Note: bring a friend who thinks they're a foodie.

I don't care that it will take me over an hour to get here - this is the best nail salon I have EVER been to and I will be coming here every 2 weeks to do my nails!Most nail salons make me feel awkward and uncomfortable - either the manicurist will silently do my nails while avoiding eye contact or try to engage in awkward small talk. Fresh was not at all like that! Sabrina was friendly from the moment I walked in the door and fun to talk to - in addition, the other girls in the salon were all striking up conversation as well. THAT is how a nail salon should be!I came in with a photo of Mardi Gras inspired nails and asked Sabrina if she could do it. Together we picked out colors and discussed how to execute the design and she made it come out even better than the photo! I have never gotten glitter on my nails but I am absolutely OBSESSED and will be getting glittery nails every 2 weeks now!I came in for the $38 mani + massage combo (but of course paid more for the designs), and the massage was great.I can't wait to come back in a couple weeks for my next fun nail design. Thank you Sabrina!!

I love this place. Love. This. Place.It's one of the ONLY places you can go in this area that isn't overrun with tourists. The lunch/loud rush is at 1pm but if you get there before then, you can find ample seating, quick service, and a quiet space.They rock good music and their employees are friendly.The panna cotta is to die for. Try the Earl Grey tea flavor. Noms to the fullest extent.Being a non-coffee drinker, I always get their hot chocolate. Yum! DEFINITELY get the homemade marshmallows. Holy. Moly. So much delicious fluffiness. So necessary.

The easy review is to say, "If you loved the Chapelle Show, you'll love 3 Mics!" But it's deeper than that. The hip-hop that greets you as you enter the theater makes me wish they had cocktail service at the Lynn Redgrave. The vibe is definitely comedy club lounge. But again, it's more than that. The titular mics and stools are it as far as staging. Sorry. I've been dying for an excuse to use "titular" in a sentence for a week now. The third mic gets a great workout. Neal Brennan delivers solid, straight up comedy club material. Wicked funny, with a cross cultural sensibility that only a white guy who wrote shoulder to shoulder with Dave Chapelle can bring. The first mic... not so much. The bits are very funny, don't get me wrong, but it seems a bit tacked on because calling it "2 Mics" just doesn't have the proper symmetry. I was all about the 2nd Mic though. Brennan got all up in my feelings. We are close in age and creepily close in life experiences. No, I'm not a successful comedian, writer, producer, director. But when he described his experiences with depression and an emotionally unavailable parent.... Bam. And yes, dude. Henry Rollins is a piece of shit. I'm currently Benjamin Buttoning my way through life as well, just not nearly on Brennan's level. So to the 28 year-old guy in the audience who said he felt old... Yeah, just wait. Your midlife crisis is going to be spectacular! This is one of the better shows I've ever seen. The best one-man show by far. These types of shows live or die on their pacing and the writing. There's nothing else to distract you. Neal Brennan is a talented writer. Simple as that. He's got you fam. His comedy game is bananas.

We went there for brunch on Saturday about noon. There was close to an hour wait for tables, but we spotted a place at the bar. No wait at all! We split a bottle of rose', cost a whopping $28.00 and was not bad at all. We ordered the avocado toast to split. It's a bagel cut in half covered with very good avocado with a warmed tomato slice on each half each topped with a poached egg. fantastic!I got the fish tacos, made with large pieces of black cod. They were the best I have had. Julie got the kale salad with substantial amounts of mackerel cooked to perfection.We like eating at the bar, because you can make friends with the bartender and get "inside" info on what to order and other interesting info. There is also a never ending show featuring mixology and witty rapport. But i digress. We had a great time at Seamore's friendly food and terrific service. We will, for sure, be back.

Aye, I got myself in trouble with this one. I was at the spa next door and I was looking up places to get something quick, and I don't know why I chose to walk in here because I have been working out so hard and eating so healthy and I will probably gain 50 million pounds after this place.Cute, charming, and small...a simple menu, designed to make it easy to order, which of course you can still make your own sammy, but I chose to order from their array. If you don't like proscuitto, then I hate you. I mean, don't come here. Most of their sandwiches consists of it. If you don't like mozzarella or burrata, then you need to die. I meant, don't come here. They make their own and it's simple and fresh, and added to a lot of their menu items. Anyways, their proscuitto was sliced like tissue thin, not paper thin, but thinner! So light, not too salty, probably the best proscuitto I can think of. I got it on a baguette, with the burrata, dripping out of the sides, ooey and gooey, with just some tomato and arugula (mainly for color? jk). I devoured it. I didn't even give it a chance to look pretty, and I still regret giving a piece to my friend who said "that's f*cking retarded" because that's how good it was. I really still am bitter about it.And the service was nice, both pretty ladies genuinely smiling. Oh and you get a free drink with your order, and also the prices are way off online!! It's way cheaper when you go there. Including their truffle and burrata sandwiches.

SO. GOOD.Although the location is a little out of the way, I'll come here any time, any day to get my hands on this amazing chicken sandwich. I haven't tried any of the other sandwiches, but I'm sure they are just as good!The chicken sandwich is fried white meat (still super juicy and flavorful) with purple cabbage coleslaw and gravy in a super fresh, buttery, just-the-right-texture biscuit.A must-try sandwich in NYC!

I've never wanted a place to stay a secret this much. I'd be doing a huge disservice to Dinnertable/the world if I didn't report on my sublime experience here, but in a few weeks time this place is is going to be utterly impossible to get into. So man, am I glad I got here this early in the game. I've had a number of fantastic meals in my life, but my experience here was just special.First things first: Dinnertable is what they call a "reverse speakeasy". It may be the only place of its kind in the city.
