Nestled behind a curtain and a fun little door, your only way to this teeny tiny space (15-20 seats max w/ one communal tables and a few smaller tables around the perimeter) is by navigating through the Garret East--which is a pseudo-speakeasy itself. Though I'm not head-over-heels in love with the Garret, it's a damn good place to get a drink while you wait for dinner. And regardless of how good their drinks are, their profits are going to quadruple/quintuple/and beyond thanks to Dinnertable and the waits that will ensue (though according to the friend I went here with, they're all part of the same ownership group, so it's one in the same).One more note: for fans of Quality Italian, Dinnertable is brought to you by the same husband-wife team. Even better, you can watch them work! Not only is this one of the tiniest restaurants I've ever been to, but there's also no kitchen here. Or no separate kitchen, at least. Behind the "bar", the dynamic duo is working away--and are very social while doing so. Like I said, my experience here was its own kind of special. Before I go right into the magical wonderland that is the food here, I will warn you about time. When I arrived at 8pm (on a Friday night), there was no wait here. I was floored. Well, my friend showed up about five minutes later and we made what would ultimately be a very dumb decision, that being to have one drink at the Garret before heading into Dinnertable. 20 minutes later, we were slapped across our proverbial faces with a 40 minute wait. Serious ouch. But we weren't going to miss this. Given that Dinnertable is a small plates venue, we shared everything. 4 plates, 2 drinks, $80. It felt like a total steal. The major redundancy of the night: FLAVOR.Eggplant carpaccio w/ Farro, Spicy Peanuts, Mint: AIdeal dish to start off with. Though I'd said this was my "least favorite", citing the world "relative" has never been more important. This plate was fantastic...the rest were just more fantastic. The preparation was light yet rich, the peanuts added a lovely crunch to what would have otherwise been a soft texture profile and the farro added a good dose of heartiness.Smoked Short Rib Tartare w/ Horseradish, Marble Rye: A+Any variation of beef tartare paired with horseradish is going to get rave reviews from me. A combination for the ages. This plate nearly made me cry, because I wanted this dish x4 and we only got it, well, x1. Unbelievably flavorful, smoky, rich, subtly spicy. And all atop a perfectly-toasted piece of bread.Baked Mussels w/ Pepperoni Rice: A++What a brililant, creative preparation. I've had some pretty unique mussels preparations due to my mussels obsession, but nothing quite like this. Some might say the fact that these are "baked" takes away from the flavor of the mussels, but I didn't mind one bit. More on that flavor--you get pretty much everything here. Briny, salty, some spice--incredibly well-rounded. The picture doesn't do these justice. THE Dumplings w/ potato & pecorino: A++++ to infinity and beyondThese are called "The Dumplings" for a reason. The pomp is so warranted, I assure you. This is coming from someone who never eats this particular type of food. These are buttery and creamy and carb-y in all the right/wrong ways, depending on who you are. Though they're not posted online, Dinnertable offers a few cocktails of their own as well. Pictured is the bourbon/chile/strawberry/mint concoction, which was honestly better than most of the drinks I've had at the Garret. I'm a whiskey girl and a huge fan of anything spicy, so this was--and is--my ideal drink.

Its all about the lunch lunch lunch.7 days a week 3 course lunch for 38 bucks sounds too good be true but it's the real deal. The service is tip top and food is fantastic.I woukd definitely recommend the duck confit or sea bass with cauliflower as entree and finish with the infamous chocolate molten cake.Even though its prix fix there are plenty of options and healthy portions.I can't wait to come back and do it all again.

To those who have yet to experience the joy that is raclette, I ask you this. Why the hell not?To put it simply, raclette is freshly melted cheese poured over some potatoes, cornichon pickles, and cured meats. It may not sound delicious in words, but trust me on this, you have to try it first. Raclette is the size of a broom closet (only a slight exaggeration), seating around 12 people only, but the size of the cheese wheels and the hospitality of the servers is not to be underestimated. Orders of the raclette come with a "refill" of cheese which the server pours straight onto your plate from the hot cheese wheel which sits under heat lamps in between servings. Each time the server comes around with the wheel you can't help but stare and admire the chemistry that went into putting this yellow gooey deliciousness on your plate.Here is my recommendation for diners at Raclette: make a reservation (did I mention this place is small?), grab up to seven friends, bring a couple bottles of wine, and simply enjoy.

LOVE. UWS speakeasy, a gem, with fantastic old school ambiance, outstanding service and the best custom cocktails. We were led up a back stairwell from Burke and Wills, the Australian restaurant downstairs, an added bonus of dining there, very cool. Otherwise there's another entrance. Ambiance: Old school class, cricket club inspired, comfortable leather sofas and chairs, dark wood, bookshelves with old books that if you take a close peek have the vintage feel and smell. Somewhat dimly lit with small candles on the table.Not crowded, and seating is wonderfully arranged in personal cozy sections so whether a couple or group you will feel you have your own semi private seating area. Service: outstanding. Our server April had a tasteful 1920-ish period look with her hair and attire . She was incredible, attending to the tables with confidence and a serving style that showed enthusiasm of a new employee but knowledge and confidence of an experienced server. Assessing what each person liked to get their best drinks. Witty, friendly, attentive and so on with her recommendations.Recommended thee perfect heavenly drink creation I can't wait to have again. I was asking about their drinks, a list of interesting cocktails with creative and amusing names, but not sure what to get... She asked about my likes: I said I love Mezcel and I love chocolate : bam, she said I have the perfect drink for you with both . Hmm, interesting . Wow wow . Chocolate and Mezcel heaven with the mixologists' addition of some Mexican spices; apparently they have herbs and spices selected and changed regularly for the mixologists.Huge five stars for the amazing service - server and and mixologist (Jason I believe was the name she gave working at the bar last night) for the perfect custom and off the menu cocktails we had as well as above and beyond outstanding service. Highly recommend coming here with friends, a date, anyone actually. This is a fantastic UWS gem that won't disappoint.

My girlfriends and I (a long overdue reunion) decided on this centrally located restaurant (2 blocks from the 72nd St. 1,2,3 stop). I am not normally in this part of town as I work and live below 14th St., but this place was excellent! Cozy ambiance, helpful waitstaff, and delicious healthy Mediterranean food. We also used a Groupon here ($27 for two people which included 2 beer or wine, 1 appetizer, and 2 entrees). I ordered a Brooklyn dark lager ($6) and my friend had the white wine sangria ($6), she said the sangria was tasty. One of my friends and I shared a cauliflower ($5.50) mezze (which basically means tapa or appetizer for Groupon purposes). The cauliflower was one big hunk, not exactly what we were both expecting. It was decent, but I would not get this the next time around. I would suggest the eggplant or falafel or another more traditional Mediterranean mezze. For entrees, I had the veggie patties platter served w/ lentils and rice ($15) and my friend ordered the shakshuka minus the optional halumi or feta cheese ($12). Both of our entrees were a good size. My dish was excellent and the veggie patties were so flavorful (didn't need any of the accompanied sauces) but the waiter was nice enough to give me both the tomato and tzatziki sauce on the side to try. I was pretty hungry as I hadn't eaten much all day and biked from LES to this location, so I polished off my dish and was very satiated. My friend finished half her entree and took the rest home. Our friends got a combo of mezzes (3 for $15) and a small Mediterranean pizza ($7). They both said their meal was tasty and satisfying.For dessert, they were out of the vegan carrot cake, bummer. We then decided on baklava ($7) and malabi ($5). Baklava were three wee small pieces (very adorable presentation), but the flavor was a bit lacking, I would pass on this dessert. Our friends that had the malabi enjoyed it quite a bit, so I would recommend ordering that if dairy is OK with you. And with the Groupon, plus the dessert, taxes, and tip (should tip the waiter off the original food price), we ended up paying $47 in total. Not a bad deal really. This is a conveniently located pro-veggie Mediterranean style restaurant with a cozy and welcoming atmosphere (tucked in a lower level). Service was good and food was solid. I don't think you really save that much with the Groupon, but it's an option. I definitely will be back and will also visit the West Village location.

This place is perfection for me! Not only is it a few block from home but their drinks, food, and service is amazing. We've been here 4 or 5 times now and every time it's a solid experience. Some of my favorite drinks here are the classic sazerac and pin up girl, they're a must try. I would describe their food as good 'ol cajun cooking with an upscale twist. In other words its damn good hearty food with a kick. My ultimate favorite is their roast beef po' boy, it's soooo flavorful it will leave you wanting more. Their fried chicken is cooked to perfection! It's moist and crispy and they give you dark meat! Also their braised collards are the best I've ever had you got to get them.Everything I've ever ordered here wether it was a cocktail or a meal I've loved. The restaurant itself has a very relaxed vibe but it's stylish and cool. They also have a great happy hour M-F from 12-7pm on drinks and food. All their staff is so friendly they go out of the way to make you feel at home. This has definitely become one of my favorite places in the UES.

The Pennsy is a delightful new edition to the mediocrity that is Midtown. Food choices around this area leaves one to be lack lustered, yes there are enough food chains or carts around the area, those who need not be named TGIF I'm looking at you. The layout of this upscale food court is easily navigable, after all if your on a lunch break you'd want to be in and out as fast as possible #whatshesaid. The space is brightly lit, with modern décor of cafeteria style dining. Thus this is easily a great location to bring a group of friends and sample different foods from each vendor. By sample, I mean eat till your stomach's content. They have numerous restaurants, including coffee/bar in the back, the most notable being the Cinnamon Snail. Frankly it's what brought me to the Pennsy in the first place. The staff could not be any better, from the greeters who actually seem to care, to the bussers who are consistently on the job keeping the space tidy. PS The Cinnamon Snail is a beast on it's own, although their menu has seen a downgrade, it stills hold a prominent place in my vegan heart. After all the food here is nothing short of exceptional. The beast mode burger made it to the new menu and is still one of my favorites (mac & cheese, coconut bacon, and seitan patty on a pretzel bun who could ask for more).PSS I think my boo might kill me when he finds out I got the beast mode burger without him hahah I'm sure the maple bacon donut will make up for it, yep lol

It's tough to get tickets (I got mine because of a great standby ticket number), but if you get in, it's fantastic.Online - you have to have your device ready to select the tickets at the exact time he announces on Twitter. Even that isn't a solid bet, unfortunately. For standby, you'll have to wait under the NBC marquee at a ridiculous hour, but usually the top 10 tickets have a great shot of getting into the show. Expect more for a major storm - I think there was a major snowstorm in upstate NY on the day that I got in along with 20 others. Sorry for you, happy for me?I honestly can't remember who the guests were when I saw the show, but I didn't even care. Jimmy Fallon is entertaining & funny all on his own. He probably could've invited a 2x4 and I would've loved it.No cell phones, no bathroom breaks, no food or drink.. think about it - when you watch TV, do you ever see anyone in the audience enjoying a snack, or texting, or doing the awkward "scuse-me-while-I-crawl-literally-on-top-of-you-to-make-it-to-the-aisle-to-go-to-the-bathoom" shuffle? Nope, they're all there to enjoy the show! :)I don't know if I'll ever crack the code of online ticketing & standby was pretty exhausting... but if I don't get into the audience for this again, I'm thrilled with the experience that I did have!

Do you like your noodles hand pulled in front of you and dropped into a hot pot of amazing spicy biang biang broth- well I do! New to Chelsea Market, this Central Chinese style soup will rock your world. I went with Mock Duck. Sichuan peppers steaming in a mushroom vegan broth with veg, like bok choy, mustard greens and those hand pulled wheat noodles. Hot, spicy and vegan to boot, delish $12 Lamb and beef also available.

Wow this place meets the hype. Clearly, as a long time Stephen Starr restaurant Buddakan NYC has real staying power. While I feel it is a touristy destination, it is also well regarded with the locals. The ambiance is sexy, and the size makes it great for groups, and cocktails are good. I had the Truce (cucumber/gin based- very, refreshing).  I came here for a pre fixe dinner for a friend's birthday party of 15 or so, and we had SO much food so they were generous. Service was overall good- decent with water refllls but there was a big lag between the apps and the mains.. I guess it's a big group so Idk. But anyway, the food was for the most part, very excellent. (Better than Tao for sure)To start, we all shared the below family style:Cantonese Spring Rolls - Good, but you know hard to mess this up, fried spring rolls. The chicken vs. shrimp was sort of indisguinishableEdamame Dumplings - As good as people say, really unique, it's like edamame plus some kind of mash which made them so flavorful ad uniquePork Potstickers- Meh, sad I wasted calories on eating two of these. With two different dip sauces.Peking Duck Salad - This was ok to good, duck was a bit tough. The greens and poached egg were good.Chili Rock Shrimp - Who doesn't love shrimp tempura? Their is pretty good- not overly saucy or done, perfectly crispy. For the mains, we had:Chilled Udon Noodles- I think they brought this because it was vegetarian but these were not my fave by any means, kind of lacking in flavor.. they have better options. Also had a weird sorbet on top.Lobster Fried Rice- very good. Could use more lobster flavor but overall, very buttery, good fried rice. Kind of had a Thai twang to itChinese sauteed broccoli - such an underrated dish as a side but it was really, really tasty - loved the toasted/fried garlic atopBlack Pepper Beef- Unfortunately did not love this, it was a bit overcooked in my opinion so the beef was rubbery. It was also too saucy...Sizzling Short Rib- very good, well done maybe a bit chewy? But I enjoyed it Salt & Pepper Bass - very very delicious; I loved, loved this- it was well cooked, delicious I think we had the Black Dragon Chicken - crispy, chicken, I think tea smoked? Anyway not sure which it was but it was a well seared, crispy chicken. The mains were definitely mostly better than the starters- except the edamame dumpling. Dessert was banging, and some were just as good as the mains. We had the famous Crying Chocolate- a molten lava cake not to be missed with really good coffee ice cream (which normally I do not like!) The almond bread pudding - not my cup of team; too sweet. The pear sorbet - eh, uninteresting but I guess good if you want something fruity and light. We all had champagne to end the night - a nice toast. Any way, long story short...Buddakan rules, I don't care what people say!! Go here and make it a special occasion.

Fresh Coffee & Great PricesThe Porto Rico coffee company is exactly what you want from a coffee shop. The amazing smell of fresh coffee beans that you can smell and see before you purchase them.When you walk into this tiny shop you will notice that it is packed with people but there are more than enough attentive staff to get you all your coffee needs.I typical come here to pick up a few pounds of coffee and get a fresh cup of one of the four flavors they are brewing which cost less than $2. The pound of coffee changes by the kind you want and they have an awesome variety including organic coffee.If you are looking for a great cup of coffee for a great price with an extremely friendly staff come here. In addition there is a bench outside to sip on your coffee.In short:-Great coffee-Fair prices-Friendly staff

Yea for new juicery to open next to my hood: Pressed Juicery- Get Back To Your Roots! Although expensive for juice, the hype is real! Cold-Pressed, unpasteurized, 100% non-GMO ingredients that are pressed, mixed, and bottled in their New Jersey factory, then shipped sameday to their storefront every morning. Be advised, these 16 fl oz juice bottle will not keep for more than 3 days, but after first taste, you will certainly guzzle this down in 3 seconds!The juices are a smart blend of greens, roots, citrus, nuts, fruits, or all 5 together so even those who can't stand the taste of certain green and/or root juices will be amazed. There are so many options available which can usually be overwhelming, however they are well organized and you will be guaranteed to leave with something you like. With friendly helpful staff, they will take you through a journey of all the different tastes and fan favorites as you can sample any and all their juices. They even offer a premade juice cleanse package that comes with 6 different juices (greens, citrus, root, protein, everything) in each of their 3 options (Cleanse 1 for the first timer, Cleanse 2 our most popular, Cleanse 3 for the experienced).I tried juices in each of the major categories with my notes as follows: My first try was Citrus #3 and I immediately fell in love! A refreshing mix of grapefruit and a hint of mint will remind you of a lovely warm summer afternoon sitting by a lake. Next was the Greens #3, which is exactly the same as Greens #2 plus a hint of ginger. This mix is a bit much if you're not used to the slow ginger burn down your throat. At the same time it has all the health benefits of those highly antioxidant greens: kale, spinach, and romaine; sweetness of apple, undertone bursts from: celery, cucumber, and parsley, with a twist of lemon and ginger. You will easily get used to this mix and crave more.Then the Roots #1 which is under the "low sugar" icon: the key is the beet juice, which is a great add for health. It is by the far the most nutritious of the root selections. Finally I got a shot of their Signature Blend of Brazil Nut. The kale, spinach, romaine, brazil nuts, vanilla bean, dates, and sea salt blended together to make a rich, thicker juice that tasted more like a smoothy.The bottom line, you should definitely check this place out if you're nearby! Sample to your heart's desire. I'm going back to try their seasonal blends hearing raving review from others at this soft opening.

It's been months in the works - but, finally, Kahve's second location on 47th and 10th is finally open! If you've been to Kahve on 52nd and 9th, you'll recognize the same amazing coffee and pastries, and you're also in for a few surprises!Even on their opening day, they are fully supplied for all of your favorite coffees and espresso drinks. Just like their 9th avenue location, fast wifi, electrical outlets, recycled materials and reclaimed wood in various components around the coffeeshop where possible, and friendly smiling faces. The new location is much larger, with plenty of seating, electrical outlets are everywhere, including fast charging USB stations at almost every chair. And still to come, later hours (likely til midnight) and various beers on tap and wines to add to their awesome coffee and espresso drinks. My favorite drink here is the Cafe Miel - it's a espresso drink with honey topped off with a sprig of mint! So good! The croissants are so flaky and they practically melt in your mouth! Definitely will continue to come back again and again! If this is opening day, I'm truly looking forward to see how Kahve On 10th continues to evolve! Congrats guys on an awesome first day!

Whoever said $1 pizza is the ultimate drunk food... I beg to differ. There's honestly nothing better when you're drunk (or just super hungry) at 2am than tacos (with chips, salsa, guacamole and probably more tacos)This place is open until 4am and also delivers. I've had their regular tacos as well as the grilled fish tacos. I love the grilled fish ones the best. I have also made the mistake of getting a grilled fish burrito once... it was delicious but honestly no one needs that amount of food at such late hours). The salsa is super spicy and they give you a lot for the order, more than most places give, which also comes with a large box of chips.

200th review on Yelp and it just happens to be on of my fav places in the city to grab a quick bite. Why you as ask? They are ALWAYS CONSISTENT!!! I order from them pretty often because I work in Soho and regardless if I do pickup or delivery via GrubHub I always receive it on time and food is always correct. When I say always, I mean always. The food always taste fresh and well seasoned. Lunch time is definitely their busiest time of the day and along with late nights as well.My favorite food at this fine establishment:- Chicken Tortilla Soup- Any of the tacos- Chicken sandwichPick any of those three and you will be a believer and lover of La Esquina. During the spring and summer they have outside seating if you are lucky and there is seating inside but it is extremely limited. If you come during lunch without calling ahead you will be waiting a good 15-30 minutes to get food. BUT TRUST ME IT IS WELL WORTH THE WAIT.I have been to the lounge downstairs twice and I have thoroughly enjoyed myself on both occasions. It is rumored that is one of Beyonce's favorite spots. The menu is alot larger then they have upstairs. The corn is to die for! The selection of Mezcals and Tequilas is out of this world! STOP READING THIS REVIEW AND JUST GO!!! You will thank me later!

When you are craving pizza in the big, bad city, and don't want to brave the black ice and the crowded trains (winter coats add volume to the commuting population) to take you to Di Fara in faraway Brooklyn, you will find a contemporary pizzeria in Marta in the Madison Square Park area.Marta boasts of Danny Meyer pedigree and is an "ecosystem" that also includes the Martha Washington Hotel and a sizeable bar, that doubles up as a waiting area for the restaurant. Just the other day, I went with a good friend and former colleague who lives in the area. And the experience was flawless.High ceilings, a communal feel, great service and especially good crackly-crusted pizza. What more can you ask for? The mezzanine area lent itself to quiet conversation. We discussed work, gossiped about common friends, plotted a few clever moves, and then agreed to catch up again soon. I consumed a pizza and a half, and most of the ricotta-hazelnut appetizer.I will return to Marta soon. Not so much to experience the diversity of the menu, as to simply indulge in what I like most--great thin-crust pizza. Hopefully I will have equally delightful company for my future trips!

Every body tries. Every body fails. This is it. The location. Don't go anywhere else looking for a shorter line or a similar experience. You won't get it. It's like thinking you know what it's like to be Steph Curry because you can make one three. No. Stop. Don't.This is it. 3am. NYC. Maybe 4. Maybe 5. Who cares. Who knows. Is the sun rising? Not yet. You aren't asleep, and your alcohol infused body craves food. You want the white sauce. I swear it's infused with crack. You can't forget it. You can't imitate it. Bring cash. Bring your face. Stuff it here. Chicken over rice. Drench the white sauce. Go easy on the red sauce unless you're looking to sit on the toilet bowl for hours the next day. Scarf it down. Be in ecstasy. The location. The city. The food. The hours. Somebody who traveled in a time machine must have started this location, because they know how to print money like a drug dealer in a legal way. Be happy. Go. Please.

We often say love cannot last forever and yet, what is forever to us? There isn't a single aspect of our lives that exists in perpetuity, not ourselves, not our homes, not even the art we create, which will likely disappear long before the sun swallows the earth.I personally think it isn't the great cathedrals or statues or gods that are eternal for us; rather it is the most fleeting things: that kiss you will always remember, the look on your son's face you think of every day, an accident you wish you could change.It is these infinitely small, transient things that are the true monuments of life. That stay with us always. So, if you are sitting here with someone you care about, sipping an espresso for a few minutes, know that you are making a greater and more true history than anything read in any book. And honestly, the espresso pulled here, which is some of the best on the UWS, is well worth making these kinds of moments. I often think how sad and sorry a thing like a government, or even an entire city is, compared to two people sitting in the corner of some coffee shop sharing the briefest of kisses.

This place is basically a little haven for sushi deliciousness. No frills when it comes to the exterior, and upstairs it is very simple and clean, with impeccable service. Chef is always impressive. He is masterful in his craft and it shows. Do the omakase and let him showcase his talent. Everything is beyond fresh here. They might as well have just brought it in from the ocean before you sat down. Also, always love the sake here.

It's a rarity to find a lunch spot in Midtown where you can actually eat fresh and healthy food. If healthy and delicious is what you're looking for, then you should check this place out - but don't come here too often because I don't want to stand in a long line ;)I think the name "Between the Bread" is an oxymoron because most of their menu focuse on salads and bowls and not sandwiches. You choose your protein and then pick two sides. The proteins include grilled or herb-grilled chicken, salmon, catch of the day or shrimp. The salmon looked great, but on this particular day I chose the catch of the day, which was a beautifully cooked white fish. Sides include roasted pumpkin, brussels sprouts, fire roasted cauliflower, beet salad and kale. Grains include wild rice, couscous or quinoa. I went with the kale and beet salad. Both were delicious and healthy. Portions are not too large, but just enough. Prices are not bad either, I'd happily pay more to eat healthy everyday. Very little seating here, so most likely you'll have to do take out.

Overall, an outstanding dining experience.I wanted to do something special for the lady to celebrate the holidays. We have dined at many upscale restaurants in NYC and Per Se was next on my list. I called the reservationist two months in advance to ensure a table at a reasonable hour given the restaurant's longstanding reputation and high accolades. You are required to provide a credit card to secure a reservation, and their cancellation fee is $175 per guest if you do not notify the restaurant within 3 days of your reservation date. They also enforce a dress code, which requires jackets, long pants (no jeans), and no tennis shoes for men and no shorts or tennis shoes for women. We dined at the restaurant last night, and I wore a suit while my girlfriend wore a dress - we were not overdressed.The restaurant was elegant. Walk through the large blue doors on the fourth floor of the Time Warner Center to find the hosts and a classy salon. We were greeted promptly and escorted to the dining room, which was beautiful. The décor and table arrangements were upscale, and the room featured a fireplace and unobstructed views of Columbus Circle and Central Park.The service was excellent. All of our servers were approachable. We appreciated their willingness to accommodate any of our requests. They were extremely knowledgeable of the menus, and they even took the time to get to know us on a more personal level. The presentation of our drinks and food courses was professional.The drinks were great. The restaurant's wine, cocktail, alcoholic, and non-alcoholic menu is roughly 155 pages. They also allow guests to bring wines that are not represented on their list for a fee of $150 per bottle. My girlfriend ordered their version of a gin & tonic, which she found to be refreshing. I started with a "blood and sand," including a mixture of Johnnie Walker Blue, Cherry Heering, and Carpano Sweet Vermouth, which was very tasteful. I capped the meal with a single malt scotch, which was a 30-year Glenrothes from The MacPhail's Collection. This was served with a small and single cube thanks to the recommendation from our waiter, and it was outstanding.The food was delicious. They offer two daily menus, which are a vegetable tasting menu and the chef's tasting menu. We both ordered the chef's tasting menu without any supplements. This included two starter courses, seven menu courses, and an assortment of desserts. We enjoyed every course with the oysters and pearls, fillet of Mediterranean lubina, Maine sea scallop, and Pekin duck breast as some of our favorites. Another notable course was the beef short rib, which was braised for 48 hours. Their description of, "an assortment of desserts" is an understatement. We were served at least four different desserts, including a box of truffles that were made onsite, which my girlfriend's sweet tooth thoroughly appreciated.We had a great time and concurred that this was one of our more enjoyable fine dining experiences. We look forward to coming back again soon!

Ok, this is where the big boys (and girls) eat.As good as it gets for experience, ambience and food.The bar and dining room are perfectly lit, the staff are just 'there' but not overly fussy and food aside this place feels special, on a higher level to pretty much else anything else I've tried in New York.The fact that the food is simply delicious, mouth wateringly so, cements an 'easy' 5 star review.I normally wait 24hrs before posting a review to see how I felt about an experience 'on reflection' .....no need here, The Greek is quite simply the nicest overall dining experience I've had in New York City.Take a step of those TriBeCa cobbled streets and get inside, I can honestly promise you will not regret it, fantastic.

The Quick: From start to finish, a five star, very expensive and noteworthy, experience. The service is amazing, the atmosphere is casual and inviting, and the sushi with sake pairing is what dreams are made of.The Details: I wish I could afford sushi Nakazawa regularly, because I fear I am ruined for all other sushi. The food was out of this world. It's roughly 20 courses with all different types of fish hand curated perfectly for consumption. Even the homemade pickled ginger it was delicious. No soy sauce or extra wasabi needed. The meal really was an experience, interacting with the chefs; the whole evening was sort of like a show. You MUST sit at the sushi bar or it's not worth the expense. Note the staff is extremely fancy but patrons can wear jeans, it's a nice mix. Pro Tip: If you're a couple, I recommend 2 people splitting the sake pairing. The pours were very generous, and one person would likely leave wasted (if that's your goal, by all means live your life). The Damage: $150/ person for omakase, with the sake pairing the bill was ~$400 before tip. And we already want to go back!

Some friends and I recently went to have a wonderful feast on a Thursday evening. At about 7:30 on a cold night right off a cobble stone street in the Meatpacking District I arrived to a warm welcome at Bagatelle. Before I even reached the bar to wait for the rest of my party to arrive I encountered five different employees, all greeting me with huge beautiful bright smiles.The restaurant that happened to be the setting for our evening was what might be considered the birth child of when classy got with hip. Or perhaps a better description, it was the result of when a bunch of undercover hip people, including the staff, showed up at a classy restaurant. This all became very evident, reaching the point of being unmistakable, as soon as I laid eyes on the cool suggestive artwork donned by the walls. Then again, the restaurant might have described itself best, "...the chic St. Tropez meets Paris." This place is legendary for its epic party-like brunches, but now can also be touted for its great food with the masterpieces from Chef Sébastien.Once my entire party of 7 arrived we commenced with our communal style meal with appetizers and wine at about 8 pm. We started with salad, grilled octopus, homemade gnocchi, black truffle pizza, ahi tuna tartar, king crab leg, and main diver scallops. Like myself, the entire group enjoyed everything, but I also had a few personal favorites of my own.Grilled Octopus, aka Poulpe Grillé à la Plancha(white bean hummus, crispy Yukon gold, Kalamata olives aioli)...was juicy, tender and flavorful. Suddenly I don't know if I can ever look at Ursula off the Little Mermaid the same way again. Where you may see evil, I see potential, a lot of delicious potential. Whoever thought octopus could taste this good?Homemade Gnocchi, aka Gnocchi Truffés à la Parisienne de Nicolas(black truffle pesto filling, truffle sauce)...was perfectly cooked with an excellent texture and by far the best I have ever had. Thought to originate in the Middle East, whomever first created gnocchi would be very pleased with what has come of it, at least the gnocchi I had.Black Truffle Pizza, aka Pizza à la Truffle Noire(black truffle, flat bread, crème fraiche, scamoza)...was extremely flavorful, decadent in a good way, but also well balanced. To even call something that taste so unique, but still so good 'pizza' seems blasphemous. Yeah, I was lucky enough to have two slices due to everyone else's efforts to King Crab Leg, aka Ceviche de Crabe d'Alaska(king crab leg, habanero & citrus "leche de tigre", smoked trout roe)...was remarkable as the sweet flavors of crab danced with acidic citrus and lightly spicy habanero. This was a threesome I am fully willing to stand behind anytime if it looks like this.After our light and not so light apps the more hearty heavy hitters came out. We had whole-truffle chicken, center cut beef tenderloin, and pan seared marinated Hudson Valley duck breast. Of the three I enjoyed the Châteaubriand - Pour Deux best (24 oz center cut beef tenderloin, truffle potato purée, red wine and peppercorn sauce - for two). The truffle potato purée might have been the best mashed potatoes I've ever had. They were thick and richly flavorful. Not really sure what else I should say about them. I will just add this though. Immediately I formed a gripe towards every other establishment I've ever had truffle anything from. Every single thing Chef Sébastien put truffles in or on that we ate was simple amazing. Hell, I didn't even think I cared that much for truffles before Bagatelle. Up until this point I've been cheated of great truffle experiences and someone owes me answers!Next came the desserts. We had Italian meringue crisp, white chocolate tart, dark chocolate mousse, and caramelized hazelnut mini choux puff....drops spoon!!!! The Chouchou Caramel though! Wow! ...caramelized hazelnut mini choux puff and milk chocolate caramel sauce, was incredible! On your visit you should tell your server Sheldon sent you, then ask for it because it isn't on the menu. Okay, that will most likely increase your chances of getting the Chouchou by 0%, but it sounded good. HaHaCenturies after spices and food from around the world was made available to the rest of the world, a mad scientist figured out how to pair these ingredients together perfectly. Chef Sébastien is an evil genius with a life goal of dooming everyone who is fortunate enough to partake in his delicious creations. He wants to doom us to eternal gluttony! I'm convinced of it and can't wait to partake again.

So, who grew up the Bronx and DIDN'T take a school trip here? Probably no one (okay maybe someone), but odds are if you live in NYC or the surrounding areas you've been here at least once. The Bronx Zoo is deeply intertwined with the history of the borough itself. Opened in 1899, the zoo is owned by the Wildlife Conservation Society. WCS does work all around the world, and they also own/operate four other NYC parks (Central Park Zoo, Queens Zoo, Prospect Park Zoo, and the New York Aquarium). At 265 acres, the Bronx Zoo is the largest park WCS runs and is also the location of their headquarters. There's a lot to see and do, you definitely get your money's worth with the amount of animals you'll see; they have a good representation of most types of wildlife. Some of my favorite exhibits are Jungle World, Congo Gorilla Forest, the sea lion pool, and the Sea Bird Aviary. It's a lot of walking so wear comfortable shoes, though they have a shuttle that goes from one side of the zoo to the other (which I believe they charge for). Food options are okay; there are concession stands throughout the park and a large counter service eatery called The Dancing Crane Cafe located in the center of the zoo. For something less run-of-the-mill I would bring my own food/snacks. There's also a large gift shop in the center of the park where you can pick up your Bronx Zoo memorabilia and a stuffed snake. The zoo is pretty accessible - there are four entrances and four parking lots (they charge for parking). Additionally, it's not a far walk from the subways, Metro North, and city buses. Wednesday is suggested donation (aka free) day; though you may be tempted, the crowds are crazy so I would avoid it. Admission isn't exactly cheap, but it's worth it. The Bronx Zoo is definitely a place to visit at least once, definitely makes other zoos pale in comparison.

**Reservation recommended, unless you want to wait 1-2 hours!!**Probably my new favorite place for AYCE hot pot, but the wait here, as with most hot pot places, is absolutely ridiculous. However, if you're like me, and the craving for hot pot is just so real and you called and they already had 0 reservations left, a 1.5 hour (!!!) wait is worth it. Was it worth it? Verdict: yes.After the crazy long wait, we were finally seated at our 4-person table (but we only had 3). You have the choice of having 1 large pot (split into 2 or 3) to share among the table, but we decided to each get our own individual pots instead (free of charge). You can choose from original, herbal, spicy, curry, or tom yum soup bases.Of course, I went with the spicy soup base as I do with all hot pot places. It was just I expected - spicy, but not too bad and actually not ridiculously greasy like some places have it. There were plenty of numbing herbs and whole garlic cloves as well.The ingredients at Hometown seem very fresh, from the watercress to the seafood to the meat. I highly recommend the lamb - it was really good here and I usually don't eat that much meat when I eat hot pot. Watercress is my absolute favorite. No comment on the rest of the ingredients, it's just really what you prefer to eat or not eat - just know that it's fresh.Service is much, much better than that of 99 favor - our waiter was all smiles and really nice. I also liked that there seems to be much more space to move around here and not feel like you're eating in a box with a million other people sitting too close to you. The decor is modern and quite comfortable both upstairs and downstairs.Current ranking of Chinatown hot pot spots:1 Hometown2. 99 Favor3. Hou yiThey charge $13.99 a pound for uneaten food, but I'm not sure it's really enforced.Ventilation is not that great in the downstairs area - beware, you WILL smell after leaving the restaurantGood for groups as they have massive tables downstairs, but definitely make a reservation.

I have a long history with Scarpetta. When I was a young deer in headlights at 18 years old, a little baby fawn in my first year of ever living in Manhattan, I came here for dinner with some friends. There is no sign in front of the restaurant and I completely forgot the name/where this restaurant was. I always did remember it as the best spaghetti I ever had.Fast forward to when I moved to Miami and dined at Scarpetta where this glorious spaghetti again touched my mouth. I instantly remembered the flavors as being from the same restaurant in NYC. I finally realized that it was Scarpetta that I had dined with that lovely evening.Ever since then, I have been to the Scarpetta in LA, Vegas, Miami, and back in NYC. I have never had a negative experience at all in this restaurant, ever. That is pretty hard to pull off! The food is extremely consistent and absolutely delicious.+ Raw yellowtail - Light and refreshing although I wish there was some ponzu sauce or a bit more flavor to it (that's just my opinion, a lot of people like it the more traditional way with less sauces)+++ Chilled corn soup - I was never a fan of cold soup until having this dish at Scarpetta. It changed the game and now I love chilled soups. It has the perfect texture and flavor. It's not too heavy but not too light either. + Scallops - Amazing but you only get 2 so be prepared it is a smaller dish. ++++++++++++ SPAGHETTI +++++++++++++++ TO. DIE. FOR. PERIOD.+ Duck & Foie gras ravioli - Awesome dish but very very rich. Heavenly! There's nothing else I can really say about Scarpetta other than consuming all the carbs here is actually worth it and I don't say that about many Italian restaurants. YUM!

Dropped in on Ramen Lab last Friday and as you know, they consistently host a cadre of formidable talent from Japan that take up residency at this famed, yet tiny establishment to showcase different styles of ramen. They've got our 4.8/5.0 in the bag and here's why.Quality ramen in the U.S. supplied by Sun Noodles, goes pretty much hand in hand with every great establishment in New York. It's no secret that Ramen Lab would lead the forefront of this charge from when they first opened with Chef Jack Nakamura operating and setting the tone for others to follow.I met up with three others around 7pm, as there's no reservations, you write your name down on a board by the door entrance (within the vestibule). The wait time lasted for no more than a half hour, decent given the time we showed up. If you arrived an hour earlier, there's probably little to no wait at all. Their choices are listed on the wall and there's little in the way of ambiguity of decision-making, which makes order-taking simple, efficient, and straightforward. That part happens when they call your name to enter. It's standing room only, as can be expected, and cash only.This season, Ramen Tetsuya from Sapporo, Japan holds residency, the same Tetsuya Brothers Ramen known to specialize in Shoyu. Oddly, they offered miso tonkotsu here and serve it particularly well. I was not decidedly hungry so I ordered a regular, my friend ordered one with the seasoned egg.The ramen arrived lightning fast (well, within 5 minutes of entering) and we were able to snap photos, yet still have steaming hot ramen awaiting us after ten minutes of photo-snapping obnoxious fun.There were a couple pieces of decent sized chashu sitting above the broth, but the broth is what made the meal, in addition to the nice chew from the ramen noodles. I nearly finished the broth. It was that good! It's no secret that other restaurants may offer an extra side of noodles so you can finish it along with the broth, but that is not an option here.As the staff here were very professional and worked quickly, there were no complaints to be had other than the familiar waiting period and that there were no seats to be found except a couple of makeshift ones outside by the vestibule. Beyond that they've earned their stars. 4.8/5.0

Dinner was absolutely fantastic. Made a reservation for a Thursday night about a week early and had no problem getting a table. I love the ambiance of the place, you can tell it's been around for a long time. The wait staff is extremely nice and attentive. The oysters were delicious and fresh. The steak au poivre was perfection. I got it cooked medium rare and it was spot on. The peppercorn crust and sauce give it an incredible flavor. The spinach and fries that come with it are also delicious. The lamb was tasty and cooked perfectly but could've used a little more flavor. The profiteroles were insane - you have to get these. They look dense but they're light and airy and the chocolate sauce is insane. I found myself eating it straight from the gravy boat. This isn't a cheap place for dinner but for a celebration (as was mine), it's a great spot that everyone will enjoy.

The best thing about having friends visit from out of town is taking them to all of the places I normally wouldn't make it to (er, other than seeing the friends themselves). Levain was at the top of my list, because unlike other New York heavyweights (looking at you, Shake Shack and Momofuku), they haven't felt the need to spawn and spread themselves too thin. Having seen the crazy lines at the 74th location, I decided to chance the Fredrick Douglass one ... and there was a line. Yep. I was stuffed from a winner winner chicken lunch at Pio Pio a few hours before, but after watching my friend wolf down the chocolate chip walnut cookie, I knew I was in for a treat. The cookie was still gooey and chewy even after sitting out on the counter for a few hours - so good, I'd even be willing to try the oatmeal raisin version. Shaped like a scone, a little dome of nuts/chips at the top, a perfectly crunchy ring, and, best of the best, the molten middle. I have to confess, I don't understand most of the food that people go insane for. 3 hours for ramen? Waking up early for a cronut? Paying out of the nose for avocado toast with some chili flakes, feta, and pumpkin seeds? Guilty (and I've been making my own avocado toast since). But this cookie deserves the hype. NEXT TIME: dark chocolate and pb cookie. I love peanut butter in any kind of dessert form, so I'm a little terrified at how gross I will look eating it, but it's a sacrifice that I'm willing to make.

Found my new fave dinner spot! Came here for "mistress Valentine's" (a joke by the hubby) because we couldn't get a table for actual Valentine's day so we opted for a substitute celebration. Whatever, Valentine's Schmalentines. Hate to ascribe to it. It had been awhile for us in Manhattan where everything from taste, quality, service synced beautifully together to create that perfect dining experience, but it happened here. Service was phenomenal from the minute we stepped into this place til the moment we left. The set menus, plating and ambiance really made us feel like we were truly dining in Japan. Also, was great seeing a lot of Japanese people dining here as well. To me, that is the true mark of awesome Japanese fare.We started with the handmade soba noodles with dipping sauces to start and it was just perfect. Sooo good! I forced the hubby-- okay gently directed him-- to order the kaisen don set, which he didn't really like but that uni, yes it is as sweet and umami-tasting as everyone has described. I would order that separately but that's just me. My katsu toji (katsu fried pork loin in salty sweet soy broth) was definitely the star of the meal. My hubby couldn't keep his chopsticks away from it. With the set, it comes with pickled vegetables (ok), pork and vegetable miso broth (hubby really loves this), steamed egg custard (yummy! Unless you're like my hubs who actually thought he was getting ice cream custard!) and yes, that heaping bowl of rice. There's also the option of ordering soba and add-ons for an extra price which had we known, would've done that instead of getting the soba as a starter. Even though we were both STUFFED midway into our meal, we just had to finish off with dessert. Ordered the strawberry parfait which contained buttermilk (mmmm!!!) and strawberry ice cream with a powdered sugar cone, strawberry sauce and marshmallows (these really kinda took away from it all if you ask me). Paired all this with hot yuzu sake and a pitcher of Sapporo, which we realized was just excessive at this point given how much food they give you! I haven't been able to stop thinking about this place and can't wait to come back again. All in all, a great traditional Japanese spot with options of getting sashimi/sushi, yakitori, dinner sets or churashi. I highly, highly recommend this place!

I'll up it to 5 for the extra friendly service!Got one dark peanut butter cup with sea salt for $2.25. It was absolutely delicious.. like melted peanut butter inside and the sea salt really added to the flavor.Great hot chocolate! Not soupy or too rich like City Bakery, and definitely better than La Maison's (for 10 bucks).. At 4 bucks, definitely one I would return for...and one of their small chocolates!

4.5/4.75. A few small issues, but rounding up because the food and wine were out of this world. Like actually, I'm not sure if these things were created by earthlings. Order 40 of the spicy tuna plates. And maybe 30 of the beef tartares. Okay maybe just come here for dinner every night and deal with the whole going broke thing later. Sound reasoning, no?Came here around 7:30 on a Thursday night. As others have reported, there's going to be a pretty substantial wait if you don't come between 6-6:30 (NO RESERVATIONS). The hostess was incredibly scattered, which was one of the minor issues we experienced during our visit. I'm not sure if she was overwhelmed or what, but there seemed to be no organization whatsoever when it came to seating people efficiently. So while our first impression wasn't good, we were determined to stick it out - thank god we did! The wait ended up being about 45 minutes (they told us 30), but we were rewarded for good behavior, being sat right in front of the kitchen! Some might prefer a table, but my fellow foodie friend and I were thrilled.Just to clarify - when I say foodie, I'm not one of those voracious Times/Eater/Grub Street/Infatuation readers who knows everything about every restaurant opened by "this team" or "that team" or "the brainchild of the creators of so and so...". What I did know going into it was this: I had been wanting to try the tasting menu at Contra for quite some time, and when I heard that Wildair was the more causal - wait for it - BRAINCHILD of the Contra folks, and a la carte to boot, it shot up to the top of my list. First: Wine. I know cocktails very well, beer pretty well, and wine not well at all. So when I'm confronted with a wine list such as the colossal display at Wildair, I get really intimidated. Thankfully, there were plenty of servers around to help guide us in the right direction, and all of them were quite patient with our amateur-ism. I ended up trying two different reds which were both fantastic. We both opted for wine by the glass, so we were able to give our prospective options a taste before deciding. The wine here - along with being overwhelmingly diverse - is natural/organic/biodynamic, so like the food, the feel is very clean and refined. FOOD! The way that everything is listed on the menu, you'd think the food here is oddly minimalist. This is not the case. They list the key players in each dish, but the subtleties are left a mystery. I'm a fan. -Bread and Olive Oil (A)Paying for bread seems silly to me. But they're known for making some standout bread in-house here, and the rumors are true. The only thing silly here would be NOT to order it. Not much more to say - you gotta experience it yourself. -Beef Tartare, Smoked Cheddar, Chestnuts (A+)I don't eat red meat too often but after perusing the Yelp and the Google for a bit before coming here, it seemed pretty unanimous that ordering the beef tartare at Wildair might be the best decision you make all day. Again, the hype was warranted. The texture and flavor profiles of this dish were sublime. The tuna was my favorite dish of the meal, but my inner foodie knows this baby was by far the most inventive and beautifully-executed plate we had. Apparently, beef can be made light and fluffy - thank you Wildair for enlightening me. Just a note - this plate is slightly spicy thanks to the addition of some horseradish. This made the dish for me.-Georgia White Shrimp, Celery, Cilantro (A)You're encouraged to eat the skin. It's not necessary, but it made the dish for me. I wasn't head over heels in love with the shrimp honestly, but it was masterfully prepared, as everything here seems to be. -Spicy Tuna, Scallion, Tomatoes (A+++)Served on toast. Party in your mouth good. I suppose it's not as "refined" as some of the other dishes here and certainly not as complex, but the resounding flavor is incredibly powerful. The tomato and tuna blend together in the sweetest of harmonies. Now that's what I call a power couple.-Chocolate Hazelnut Tart (A++) I basically don't eat desserts because consuming food high in sugar does really weird stuff to my chemistry. That said, I caved and had a couple bites of the tart after hearing nothing but squeals of glee from my equally adventurous dining companion. They were warranted, I assure you. The tart looks quite simple. Deceptively simple. I don't know how they make this little piece of heaven taste so damn good (the salt on top doesn't hurt), but whatever they do, they better keep doing it. Sweet, rich, creamy but not too heavy.

Hale and Hearty please open a store in the Bronx. No, not just in the Bronx, but specifically in Throggs Neck, okay?!?!I confess, I am a soup lover. I kid you not, I could have soup 212 days a year, but only with one caveat, there has to be a multitude of varieties and that's what Hale and Hearty provides, a multitude of varieties. Aside from soups, Hale and Hearty offers a choice of pre-made sandwiches, plus an option to create-your-own salad. Eh, for me, I'd rather just have my soup, thank you very much. Thank you Executive Chef Bruce Rogers for bringing your philosophy of 'If you liked it as a kid, you'll like it as a soup.' Basically it seems his thought process is any knife and fork meal could be basically turned into a soup and did so by creating 500 different varieties that are constantly rotating on the menu board.To help you choose there's a dietary breakdown showing either V=Vegetarian, L=Low-Fat or D=Dairy. Plus samples are offered to also narrow down your decision. Samples have helped me expand my favorites to: Curried Eggplant & Lentil, Ginger Butternut Squash, Chicken Pot Pie, Tomato Cheddar...yummm Tomato Cheddar, Lobster Bisque, Vegetarian Split pea, Green & Yellow Split Pea with Smoked Bacon, Morrocan Chicken, and so many more. This location, during lunch hours, can have lines out the door but the employees at the soup counter and the register are good at what they do and get you in and out quick fast and in a hurry. Upon checkout don't forget to get your Green Bean card stamped so you can cash-in on a free soup after a bunch of visits. Soup is good food!

After seeing these guys at countless pop up food festivals (Madison Square Eats, Broadway Bites, etc.), how fortunate we were to have them open up their only permanent storefront literally right across the street from us!As much as you may want to customize, your best bet is to stick with their pre-arranged signature options. My favorites are the Banh Mi (braised pulled pork or chicken w / spicy aioli, vinegar slaw, fried shallots & cilantro) sandwich, and the buffalo mac & cheese side! If you're indecisive, you're better off getting two half sandwiches over a full one. You'll pay an extra buck or two overall...not only can you pick out two varieties, but you'll actually end up with something more substantial in size/filling than a full sandwich.

It isn't often you get to say that you had a restaurant experience that was perfect from beginning to end, but my experience at Ocean Prime was one of them. I was meeting a group for a birthday dinner but I arrived early. This allowed me to spend some time at the bar enjoying a couple drinks beforehand. The hostess was immediately welcoming and after a quick coat check I hung out at the bar to enjoy my cocktail. I had the Whiskey Clover, described on the menu as "Gentleman Jack Whiskey, Hennessy VS, Honey Water,Hand-Squeezed Lemon & Orange". You'd think with a description like that the drink would've been overly sweet, but instead it was just the right balance of citrus sweetness and whiskey flavor. I really enjoyed it.As I sat at the bar I looked around the bar area which includes several comfortable, circular booths and tall tables. The bar area alone could accommodate a party. The decor manages the hat trick of looking sophisticated but not pretentious. The combination of dark wood, white counters, medium tone furniture and dim lighting creates a comfortable atmosphere that feels rich, but not in an off putting manner. The environment lends itself to everything from after work drinks with colleagues to a date.Eventually my friends began to arrive and we all got to talking - so much so we didn't realize that it was taking a rather long time to get to our table (we had a reservation - I highly recommend you make one). The manager came up to us and was very gracious, offering us the use of the private dining room near the bar area (dubbed the "Rockefeller Room") since they had made us wait so long. We of course accepted and happily sat down for a very different experience than we had expected!The Rockefeller Room could easily accommodate a small office party of about 10-12 people. There is a large, round table with a huge lazy susan in the middle. There is a flat screen TV mounted on the wall and tasteful decor is the order of the day in the brightly lit room. Our waiter was absolutely professional and on point the entire night. It wasn't just a matter of making sure our glasses were full of water. His manner and event he way he addressed us spoke volumes about the training the staff had gone through. We were all very impressed.Okay, enough talk about the room and bar etc. What did I eat? Here's a list of what I got to have:FILET MIGNONNot wanting to be a complete glutton, I went with the 8oz filet mignon, medium rare. The steak was cooked and seasoned perfectly. While you can order items on top of the steak such as black truffle butter, I wanted it straight to taste it in its most pure form. I'm really glad I did. When I cut the meat it was like butter and it was perfectly tender. There was just the right amount of seasoning to make your taste buds happy but not overwhelm them. It was also truly medium rare with pink in the middle.JALAPENO AU GRATINA side dish, this comes in a rather large bowl and there was enough that all six people at the dinner were able to get a couple forkfuls of this spicy dish. Jalapenos generally can go two ways: either there is a kick or there isn't. In this dish there definitely was along with some savory flavor.PARMESAN TRUFFLE FRIESOther restaurants have this and I've had it many times. Most of the time they are shoestring fries and there's not a lot of substance to them. Not so here! These fries were *huge* and the cheese layer was obvious from several feet away. These were absolutely addicting. Be warned, you can't just eat a couple!CREAMED SPINACHWhat could have been a typical creamed spinach is elevated by a smokey element inside the dish. Most of us agreed it was likely bacon, but there were no bacon bits to be found. Whatever the case may be, this was a very uncommon creamed spinach that was full of flavor.BLACK TRUFFLE MAC N' CHEESEI only got to have one bite of this, but it was full of flavor. The cheese was creamy and salty and the truffle flavor was definitely assertive. TEN LAYER CARROT CAKEA signature dessert, this cake was *truly* 10 layers. It was a literal tower of goodness. The cake was so moist that you could push a fork through all ten layers and it didn't tip over. It tasted delicious and surprisingly had no raisins in it.CHOCOLATE PEANUT BUTTER PIEPeanut Butter Mousse and Bittersweet Chocolate Ganache come together to make one of the most delicious desserts I've had in ages. The mousse is perfectly delicate but full of flavor while the ganache gives just the right amount of sweetness to balance the savory mousse. Special shout out to the coffee and bread basket - both of which could easily be overlooked in any restaurant, but here they were exceptional. The bread basket had amazing pretzel sticks (fresh baked!) and the coffee was french pressed!I really enjoyed my experience at Ocean Prime and I can't wait to go back!

I thought I should wait a bit to go here, but I wanted to see what all the hype was about. Also my friend lives right down the block, so I figured if we had a long wait we could at least wait there. I went yesterday (Wednesday) and got there around 6:10. The line was to the corner of 22nd and 8th, so not that bad. They opens at 6, so they were seating people slowly and then when they were filled they would take names. Luckily both my friend and I were there and we were seated when we got up to the front. It was probably overall a 20 min wait. The place is a good size. We were seated in the front at one of the low communal tables. There are 6 seats at each of those tables and we were sat in the middle across from each other. It was close, you could hear everyone's conversation around you, but I didn't feel like they were eating right on top of me. The place was noisy though, so it was a little hard to carry on a conversation. The waitress came over and took our drink orders. I just went with a glass of the house white. It was sweeter than I thought it would be, but it was still good. My friend had ordered the limoncello slushi, but they came back and told us it wasn't ready yet, so he went with the blood orange daquiri. We had looked over the food menu and thought about what we had wanted. We also heard a few recommendations from the waitress, and then made our decisions. We decided to go with 5 small plates and no entrée, and it proved to be a good idea. We ordered the sirloin crudo. I've never been a big fan of tartare, or carpaccio (I like my fish raw, not my meat) but my friend wanted to try it and it was a suggested plate to get, so we did. It was pretty good, and I had some, but I let my friend finish it. If you like raw meat, I think you'd like it. We didn't add on truffles to anything because I HATE them, but for an additional price you could add it this and the chicken and dumplings soup. We got the shaved winter vegetables, which are pickeled and served in a beef broth. I liked it, the presentation was pretty and it was light and refreshing. Another one from the appetizer section we got was the tofu. I really liked this one! The tofu was so smooth and creamy! The trout roe on top was really fishy tasting, but I liked it. I finished that one off while my friend finished off the crudo. Win-win! Next up was the ceci e pepe, which was probably one of my favorites. The pasta was so good, and chickpea hozon (whatever that it) was amazing. I'm not a huge black pepper person, but I even enjoyed that on top too. Last up we got the chicken and dumplings. I really liked this as well. My friend wasn't as big of a fan. It was served in a thick broth with chicken, thick noodles and mushrooms (which I did not eat) and had a bit of a spicy kick to it. We thought about dessert, but we were both stuffed, so maybe next time. Overall I really enjoyed Nishi! Everything we ordered was really good. My friend doesn't love fish, so there were a few dishes I'd like to go back another time and try. Service was good, everyone seemed very friendly and attentive - clearing plates and making sure everything was ok. Pricewise I didn't think it was too bad either. For a drink and a satisfying meal it came to about $70 per person (no tipping it's all included), which isn't crazy for a nice meal in NYC. I definitely plan to go back at some point!

Just opened yesterday. Best meatballs that even Beat Bobby Flay's in a meatball throw down / challenge aired on the Food Network; and possibly even more impressive, liked and devoured by my pickiest ever son. :DVery unique concept- Grandma Maroni's meatballs and other Italian dishes/ meals served in a small, medium or large sized cool looking red pot... That you can have delivered or take home with you. The meatballs - wonderful! My very picky and healthy son thinks he wants to be vegan - not ok for a young, growing child ... so I need to use creative negotiation to get him to eat meat or chicken... Zombie tv for protein and iron? Whatever works ... When I walked into this new little restaurant, I was brave ordering takeout/ meatballs for my son... Hm. What tv show should I use... would it work ? My son hated the last meatballs at The Meatball Shop ... So I wasn't sure if he would even try let alone eat them ... Well, huge thumbs up. "I will try a bite" even without any bad tv incentive turned into his eating and loving ALL the meatballs . Success and a thank you to Grandma Maroni... Even a want to be vegan can't resist the Maroni meatballs! Amazing Pop's pizza bread which my son couldn't stop smelling and looking at before we ate, amused I think by its ginormous size and unique look. Delicious.Raw salad with arugula and Parmesan also super with a great tasting, light dressing.The decor is really cute with red pots hanging from the walls... A t-shirt hanging inside and sign outside says "Our pot is legal." Cute.They have one location in Northport, and brought this one to NYC- a unique concept and fantastic addition to the upper east side!The manager Marizio and employees Jennifer and Mike were really friendly; and Mike's knowledge and pride in the business - wow. I was asking about the business, and he shared all the facts in this post with me. Highly recommend whenever you're craving Grandma's meatballs or other Italian creations -- Dinner served in the pots for 2, 4 or 8 people would be an amazing, fun idea if you're having guests for dinner.

This is by far, one of the best Indian restaurants I've visited, time and time again. They never disappoint, whether we come for the lunch buffet or a la carte. The staff is always pleasant and attentive, the bathrooms are always clean and we've never had a problem getting a table. The lunch buffet has a wonderful selection of various curry dishes, vegetable dishes and tandoori. The price is right at $12 on weekdays (noon-2:30p) and $16 on weekends (noon-3p). They usually have one or two desserts, my favourites being the Halwa (carrot pudding), Gulab Jamun (sweet dumplings) and the Kheer (rice pudding). Every time we visit, we leave full and satisfied. Their Samosas have gotten much better since I last remember. The dough is way lighter so you can actually enjoy the whole thing without becoming overly full. Their Naan is always good; it's soft and warm and I love getting the garlic variety. Every meal comes with Papadum (thin baked bread crisp) and a few condiments of tamarind sauce, onions and a cilantro sauce. I love their curries, both Phaal and Vindaloo are my favourites and I usually pick either Lamb, Goat or Shrimp as my protein. They're extremely spicy but an order of Raita will help cool it down. The Biriyani is top notch, as is their Tandoori Chicken, unbelievably juicy. If you're feeling adventurous, try some of their Hot Pickle condiment which is basically spicy pickled lime. Just writing about it makes my mouth water. I would suggest that you take advantage of their buffet if you haven't visited before so you get the opportunity to try a variety of items. Weekdays are less crowded bit get there early because there tends to be a steady flow of people throughout their lunch rush. Also, make sure to fill out a comment card so that you stay alert with their events and specials.

So in love with this place! Probably one of the best dining experiences I've had since moving to NYC. Everything about this restaurant is perfection, from the quaint decor/atmosphere, most delicious food, beyond gracious and helpful staff, and how could we forget BYOB!!!We came on a weekday, it was not very busy so we were seated right away (they also take reservations). They have an amazing BYOB policy, first bottle no charge thereafter $10 corkage fee. The restaurant has a relaxing casual feel and is very clean.We ordered the pork spare ribs which were a good size for the price and it was served in a bed of shredded lettuce. These are by far the BEST spare ribs I've ever had in my life! They were succulent and packed with flavor, you must get them.For my entrée I had the duck panang curry...words can't even describe how good this dish was. The duck was cooked to perfection! Moist and tender in the inside and perfectly crispy on the outside. The panang sauce was so good I wanted to drink it. We also had the kee mao noodles which were delicious!Our waiter was very helpful and knowledgeable. He guided us through the menu and all his recommendations were on point. I can't wait to come back here. Im totally in love with this place and their delicious food!

For every 100 fast sushi places in NYC, there is a Sushi Yasaka. It's not that any one detail is worth its own entry in NY Mag--rather, care and a careful eye are given to everything here.The values look like other places, but don't let $12 for three maki rolls, miso soup, and salad lull you into low expectations. I already told you, everything is better than you expect. Feel free to hope for friendly service, quick water refills, fresh hot tea, and high-grade fish in those rolls. Unsurprisingly, Sushi Yasaka is also pretty busy. But they manage their wait times efficiently, even on packed weekday lunchtimes.

This place lives up to the hype and Dominique Ansel is a pure genius. The only thing that annoys me is that things like the cronut and the cookie shot are served at certain times but that's probably better for the diabetes epidemic. I had a friend come in for a day and I decided this was the most touristy things to do and I have never been here. The bakery itself is very narrow and long so make sure not to bring something big with you. There were some people that came with suitcases which made it a pain to walk around. In the back there's a beautiful garden and on the way to the garden you can see the employees baking and like 100 sticks of butter. I have never seen so much butter in my life. Since I didn't know the cronut was a morning thing, we ordered the DKA. The DKA was delicious and was perfectly caramelized outer crust and was puffy and layered that bounced back after I bit into it. Loved it. I was kinda mad that I forgot that they sold frozen smores which would have been to cool to get with my friend in town. We then hung around till 3 to get on the cookie shot line. The line wasn't that bad for a Friday. We prob waited like 7 mins max, a few people go in at a time as to not crowd the bakery. OMG the cookie shot. It is pure perfection. We couldn't talk for like 5 mins after and kept rubbing our bellies. It was amazing. The cookie was dense and chewy just the way I like it. Writing this review is making crave carbs really bad and want to pre-order like 50 million cronuts so I'm gonna stop now...

We walked to Mamacita Bar & Grill due to high Yelp reviews and they were on the money! This was some of the best, freshest Mexican food we've had in NYC, certainly in Hells Kitchen. A neighborhood you-know-what, so get on over there.Once we were seated, the manager/owner came over and basically became our friend. He is rightfully proud that everything is made from scratch, with no lard, animal fats or MSG. There's a page specifically for Vegetarians too. Menu prices are a bit higher than a typical family style Mexican place, but the quality is worth the extra cost.The complimentary chips and spicy salsa were a good start. The nachos with guacamole was delicious. My Carne Asada en Salsa Ranchera came bright, colorful, fresh and tasty with grilled rib-eye, jalapeño, onions and vegetables. We all enjoyed our entrees. The owner gave us a complimentary dessert, delicious Tres Leches with real whipped cream.With a whole page of margarita specials to select from, both frozen and on-the-rocks, it takes awhile to read. The frozen drinks look like fantasy art pieces. My Gran Gold Margarita with Herradura and Grand Marnier on the rocks was awesome and strong! Choose the 16 oz goblets...so much better than that Dallas joint. Kudos to bartender Anthony! We ended up wired, hugged the manager, thanked the friendly service staff and stumbled out into the night. A great jump on the weekend.

American Cut Is the real deal!I went to this steakhouse for a friends birthday having high expectations because it is owned by Iron Chef Marc Forgione and it did not disappoint.When you walk in there is a large bar/lounge area which is nice while you wait for the rest of your party to arrive.After moving out of the bar area into the dinning area the ambiance complete changes and playing some old school music classic. There was six of us and it was a birthday so we went all out getting the surf and turf as well as the 52 day age steak (which is not on the menu), stuffed potatoes, fries, and the Cesar salad because we figured we need to eat some greens with all the meat we are about to get.Before we got our salads we got these everything biscuits which were amazing and made fresh. These biscuits let you know the food is only going to get better. When the salad arrived it was cut up right infront of us along with making fresh Cesar salad. Which was one of the best Cesar salads I have ever had.Now all we needed was the main course but I'm the mean time we were sipping on our bourbon. When the main course arrived it came in fashion. Out on a push cart with a hot top where they made a fresh dressing for the steak which you can see in the video. Everything was absolutely amazing it was tender, juicy, full of flavor. I couldn't have ask for a better dinner. After finishing the meal we got a Cracker Jack Popcorn Sundae for our friends birthday so he could blow out a candle. This was nice sweet touch to end the night and is must if you come here.In the end this has been one of the best steakhouses I have ever been to because of the friendly staff amazing food and great service.

I'm looking at an empty bag of Porto Rico Importing Co. coffee. French roasted Costa Rican. ::silent tear runs down face::I was walking in the Greenwich Village, head down, minding my own business, when all of a sudden I smell the best coffee of my life. It was like a Bugs Bunny cartoon the way I followed the aroma right into their door. I'm no aficionado. I will murder a cup of joe with too much half-and-half and sugar. But the coffee at Porto Rico Importing makes me want to be a better person. A person with the $126.75 Cuisinart DGB-700BC Grind-and-Brew 12-Cup Automatic Coffeemaker, Brushed Chrome/Black, that's going onto her Amazon Wish List immediately. There was a sign that requested that you not take photos while I was there. I don't know how everyone else got away with it. Y'all are special. But there really was no need to visually capture what is best experienced through scent. ::opens empty bag... inhales forlornly:: The only reason I'm out now is that this place is absolutely near none of my normal haunts. But I'm quite willing to get out my Metrocard for a special trip.

"You can find magic wherever you look. Sit back, relax, all you need is a book." --Dr. SeussI love books and really enjoy reading. Dr. Seuss taught me mostly everything I needed to know about this world...This location is pretty convenient for me and today I came here to hang around a bit. Yippee! I felt like a kid in a candy store.I have a Queens and Brooklyn library card, but today with my NYC ID card, I registered to be a Manhattan library user. Now, I have all three boros covered. Have you ever wondered why all the boros are not linked? I am guessing because there are over 8 million New Yorkers and having one library system would probably be a cluster...This branch is open until 8pm from Mon-Thurs. It is closed on Sunday (bummer). The first floor is for adults/teens with new nonfiction/fiction displayed and DVD selections in English and other languages (mainly Chinese). There are also computer terminals on the first floor. I also spent some time looking at the bulletin boards about book clubs, where to compost, language groups, morning teas, and upcoming events (very cool).Second floor is the children's section and third floor is for adults again. On the third floor you will find more computer terminals and adult nonfiction/fiction, periodicals, reference, newspapers, etc. Many tables available for studying or reading and the place was quiet as a mouse! Printing cost 15 cents/sheet and currently the only way to retrieve your printed items is to pay on the 1st floor and then your documents will be released. This location does not have self-checkout so you may have to wait in line to check out. This branch definitely caters to the community and you find many books and videos in Chinese and Spanish language. They also offer quite a selection for those wanting to learn English. The staff were friendly here and the building was toasty and well heated. I love libraries and when I came here, I fell in love all over again. How wonderful it is to fall in love over and over again!"The more you read, the more things you will know. The more that you learn, the more places you'll go." --Dr. Seuss

Great new bar where the mediocre Neely's BBQ used to be. Terrific beer list, cocktails, ambiance, food, ping pong tables, pinball machines, popcorn machine, and flat screens all around. Holy cow - a working fireplace too!Plenty of seating along the bar, high tops with stools, and heavy picnic benches that seats couples or groups.Varied menu with a little something on it for everyone. Brats, sandwiches, finger foods, salads, and some main course entrees. I found the prices fair for the area, and for the type of craft beers curated on their list, but may seem a bit pricey for some.20 rotating draught craft beers and ciders, and a selection in bottles, cask beer, and hand crafted artisanal cocktails so there is a lot to choose from. Hot damn! A few of us enjoyed a terrific Smoked Chipotle & Cherry Milk Porter, while I decided on a refreshing IPA and Pilsner.
