So much beer love!The cigar bar is still downstairs on the level below so if you want a puff on a stogie after a few brews the option is close by. Bathroom is down on that level too.Oh yeah - Get the monster sized pretzel! Huge, soft, hot, sexy. You're welcome.Loved the look and feel of this bar, as there is nothing else like it in the area. Fun vibe and friendly staff. Wonderful new spot on the UES to get your brews on!

Harlem Public is to Adam Levine as At the Wallace is to the Quirky-But-Still-Attractive Maroon 5 Bass Player.By that I mean, At the Wallace is cool. It's cheap. It's still as fun as its partner bar, but there's a lot more room for everyone & a lot of character. Giant Jenga? Whiteboard Bathrooms? Maybe it's a dive bar, but I'll swim here! I can get a can of Purple Haze for $6, and that's pretty awesome.I've never tried the food here - the menu is much smaller than Harlem Public - but, according to these other reviews, I must!So happy to have you, At the Wallace!

Another excellent display of just how much the Bronx has changed! This time we are going to take a look at this wonderful hotel called "umbrella" hotel! I'll break down in a few parts to just why this hotel stands out from the rest in the Bronx!"The grounds" - this hotel is located in the melrose section of the bronx, it truly stands tall and proud displaying wonderful inviting lights wanting for people to try this place that's what attracted this to me as I was trying to find a suitable hotel for my friends who were in town for a few days. So I decided to check-in (like any yelp pro would do) and snoop around this place."The inside"- as I walked inside I was quickly acknowledged and greeted with respect, I gotta say I was almost taken back by the the wonderful gesture, it was as almost i wasn't in the Bronx. It was a simple "hello welcome to umbrella hotel how may I help you today! " and of course with a smile! that had me sold on putting my friends in here for the next day. So I wanted to check out the rooms before I made any decisions so I decided to do my "investigation" of the area and I must say I was true impressed on everything I saw."Floor by floor" -literally I peeked into a few finished rooms and I noticed the tvs were huge!! (55inch tvs),Kings size beds with lavish bedding to accommodate along with it! Even the bathrooms were in excellent condition! (I judge harshly on bathrooms being a certain way but I was impressed)Overall: I ended up recommending my friends from out of town stayed here, not only they saved month from not going to the city, they were able to have that luxurious feel and be in the Bronx. So to umbrella way to represent and show the Bronx is making statements!

Moving is such a drag*. It takes weeks, makes you ask a ton of your friends (and of your relationship with your significant other), and for what? Well, I guess for a place like this; in this particular case my move (however painful - miss you already Brooklyn), paid me back with a few perks. When I first heard that we would be seeing a place next to Central Park, I figured it would be nice (who doesn't love a walk in the park), but nothing overly insane. I mean a park is a park right? Wrong, oh so very wrong of an assumption. Some parks are, well, better than others and the conservatory is amazing. Walking through Vanderbilt gate (a guy actually unlocks this in the morning - I want to see what the key looks like), you find yourself transported to a park hidden inside a park. With flowing fountains and groomed walking paths, the park is sculptured with angles and elevations that are laid out so spectacularly that they make this oasis in Manhattan feel truly grand; this place would do very well in Paris, no doubt about it. The best part of this park for me, is that it takes you out of the craziness of the city to a more tranquil place. You can truly relax here, and forget about your surroundings or the stress of the day. If you've never had a chance to check this place out, and happened to find yourself in the north side of the park, absolutely stop in._____________________________________*Side note; it's good to be back; new lab is up and running, apartment is coming together and I actually have a few minutes to write a review (hurray!)

I'll keep this short and simple so you can save time reading my review and get that rear-end in gear on over to Om. The dishes are superb, they have a separate part of the menu for vegetarian and most things can be made vegan if not already. Although they serve wine and beer in-house, they still offer BYOB (with *NO* corkage fee) including bottle service from Mon-Thurs only - so note Friday - Sunday there's a fee. Still the best deal since sliced bread.Near major transportation, prices are cheap and service is outstanding.They did not bat an eye when Jennifer spilled two glasses of wine and water all over the table and floor. Nor did they mind when she spilled food on the floor at the new table. (What did I get myself into here?) They remained courteous and polite offering outstanding service despite Thrilla's best attempts to violently overthrow the establishment in a food-fight-frenzy.

Haha yeah the chicken sandwich here is amazing. I mean, I ate at fuku+ literally 48hrs ago and I liked the one here slightly more. And yeah you have to put in some time waiting for your bird, but once it finally comes you will see that it is pretty excellent.Just before being placed into the sandwich the fried chicken is slathered in this spicy vinegary dip that gives it this really unique, tangy flavor. It is also slightly spicier than most chicken sandwiches currently in nyc but not overwhelming. However, the spicy dip also dampens the skin a bit so just be aware of that. But with the pickles, crazy southern mayo, and straight up normcore bun it is a pretty insane sandwich and probably one of the top fried chicken sandwiches in NYC right now.I also found the fried chicken here to be both comically large and quite excellent. I like the shatteringly thin, puffy golden skin as well as the extremely moist meat and ever so slightly spicy taste. I also tried the potato salad, which was really herbaceous and enjoyable.As for all the people giving 1 star because they had to wait 20 mins, guys, welcome to NYC.

I can't love this place more. Unfortunately, it has turned me away from regular ol' store-bought yogurt and taken a huge bite out of my wallet recently. Like any other yogurt-lovin' gal, I was all about the FAGE until I discovered the delicious fresh-made $7 (!) yogurt at Greecologies.You get two yogurt options: strained or traditional. While strained is more similar to your typical Greek yogurt, I prefer the traditional. It has a thin layer of whey on top, and I like that it's less thick, but just as creamy. To me, the traditional has a bit more flavor and is much less tart. If you go with the rose petal preserves, be prepared to try NOTHING ELSE FOR AS LONG AS YOU LIVE. I thought I would be adventurous with the menu each time I walk in, but I've not been able to wean myself off the rose petal preserves. Just do it. It's a magical combination, and best of all, you can buy a jar of the rose petals to add to your own yogurt at home.There are plenty of savory items on the menu. I've had the Greek salad, which is superb. All of their ingredients taste great and look like they belong on a blog. The service is top-notch, and the space is big and comfortable. There's a garden in the back and plenty of seats. Because of the price point, you usually don't find this place packed with tourists like everywhere else in Nolita/SoHo. Nice place to duck into after some shopping for a healthy, delicious treat.

How do I love thee? Let me count thy ways:+ This is basically Indian Chipotle, you guys. INDIAN CHIPOTLE. + I love how flavorful all the bean and entree options are WITHOUT just being overwhelmingly oniony. I hate onion overkill. + unlimited chutneys and sauces! I highly recommend mango and coconut. + So many vegetarian and vegan options. The corn and avocado curry is brilliant, as is the kale and cauliflower. + I love the size options. The petite size is perfect. + Can choose between white and brown rice.+ The prices are very affordable. + Everything is constantly being freshly prepared and refilled. Nothing has ever tasted old or like it has been sitting out forever. + Everything is REALLY DELICIOUS. No complaints here. I love everything about this place.

This has quickly become one of my favorite spots in lower Manhattan. Created by the same geniuses who brought us, Public and Saxon + Parole, Genuine Superette is a nice treat at the border of Little Italy/ Chinatown and Nolita. It has a very laid back and retro ambiance, with a vintage tape deck on the wall. There is also a window and you can see it's a partial open kitchen. If you're lucky, you can watch the chefs cooking your meal- we got to watch them make our ice cream sandwiches one day! Overall, the staff here is friendly and they make great suggestions- just ask for what their suggestions are! My typical meal here consists of:1. Fried chicken sandwich2. A glass of Pot Of Gold3. Vanilla Bean Ice Cream SandwichMy boyfriend and I love this place and since it's been open, we've already been here more than a handful of times, making this our new favorite. We have also brought a handful of friends, all who have also enjoyed their meals here. Although the portions are a tad smaller, when you taste the food you surely will be content with the flavors and satisifed after your meal.

People you should take here:1. Your Irish dad visiting from out of town 2. Beer lovers3. A small group of friends looking to "grab a Beer" (standing)4. When someone asks "where next? What's around here?"5. A first date where being tipsy is appropriate / not offensive 6. A serious date when you order based on high alcohol content (shown on wall) And get halal food from the truck outside afterwards 7. A self organized beer club8. When looking for a "straight bar" in Hell's Kitchen 9. If you like craft beer and a big selection to choose from10. If you don't mind small spaces and standing

Boba Guys, taking over the USA, one shop at a time.I can't say enough great things about Boba Guys. I remember when I first ventured into one of their SF shops last year, I knew the east coast could use some boba improvement. 12 months later, I'm happily sipping on their amazing drinks right in the heart of New York.I've pretty much sampled every item on their menu and my all-time favorite is definitely their coffee milk tea. A balanced combination of smokey coffee and fragrant black tea, it's the perfect afternoon drink. Please make it a permanent item on the menu!My other favorites include the jasmine milk tea and the thai milk tea. I hate it when boba shops use too much milk powder because it makes the drink taste chalky. Because Boba Guys uses real milk, it really allows the tea flavors to blossom, making it more refreshing as a whole.Their boba is one of the best kept secrets. Soaking in a mysterious mixture of brown sugar and honey, among other unknown ingredients, it's the perfect QQ consistency. If you're not a fan of firmer balls, be warned that these boba balls will bounce back with every bite (but in the most fun, delicate, cute way).Can't wait to see the Boba Guys brand grow in the city!

Yum. Step 1: you choose a size. The smallest size was more than enough for your first attempt.$6.00Step 2: choose a flavor. The coconut is the only vegan option. The others have dairy. The coconut is very coconutty.Step 3: free drizzle. I went with salted caramel. There are a ton of options like condensed milk, chocolate syrup, honey.Step 4: Toppings. 50 cent each. I opted for almonds and strawberries but there are a ton of way more delicious ones like Oreos, waffle come, nilla wafers, and lucky charms.Yum yum yum. I have convinced myself this is healthy. Not so sure about that. Definitely coming back! Oh and the spoon changes colors, how cool!

One of the best sushi restaurants in town! Tasty, clean, kind and fast service, and now - super pretty too!I have lived one block away from Miyabi sushi for over 10 years. That's about the same time they were in the previous location until they moved to the new one, just across the road. The new place is absolutely beautiful, and a must go to in Greenwich village! The owner is super friendly, I always see him when I'm there and he is always making sure everything is going well - and it does.

It's one of the best gelato's i've ever had in NYC. Period. Situated in the Lower East Side and close to Katz's. It's the perfect snack or dessert if you are coming from the salty pickled meats of Katz's deli. Not too many sit down or tables but having your ice cream isn't really a sit down experience. Wonderful service as the folks behind the counter are open to explaining each flavor and giving a taste. The gelato is creamy and full of flavor. Definitely gives you a punch and you are carried away to the flavor you picked. My favorites are the salted caramel, buttery with that burnt caramel flavor and the salt takes it up a notch. Also a fan of the hazzlenut as you get that roasted hazzlenut taste with bits of nuts in the gelato. All very refreshing, well made, and satisfying.

This place does everything you could ask for from a winebar right. Intimate setting, limited seating (so that it doesn't become an exercise in screaming and leaning), and reasonably priced, well-executed food that actually shares well. And the fact that you can drink any bottle on the list by the glass, so long as you get at least two glasses? Patently ridiculous. The list is easy to navigate (organized geographically, then by varietal, then by price, and while the variety of reds on offer is impressive (Negoska from Greece? Strong.), in my opinion, the whites are where it's at, particularly if you're down with Chenin Blanc from France (and if you aren't, you're probably a scrub). To sweeten the deal even more, there are featured bottles at happy hour for $28, which is often borderline retail price.The greatest positive, however, is likely the staff, who are in a league of their own. Winebars typically hire either the blasé, well-coiffed jagoffs who pour you the wrong wine while staring wistfully at the equally disentranced 'models' at the other end of the bar, or the over-eager, pseudo-wonkish types who refuse to believe that you have no interest in a magnum of Screaming Eagle cabernet. The vintenders here are genuinely attentive, warm-hearted people. They truly love wine, but don't snigger at the less educated or invested. They're happy to answer questions on any level, whether it's their favorite Kabinett on the list, or what goes best with the Gypsy Salami. None of this is to say that they don't have nice hair, of course. They just aren't dead behind the eyes. If you like wine, you owe it to yourself to make a visit. And even if the dude (or lady) you've dragged out here for your requisite bi-monthly date night doesn't like fermented grape juice, they've got some pretty dope beers. (Just get him a Pretty Things "Baby Tree" and enjoy your Paolo Bea in awkward, silent contentment. You're welcome.)

I knew there had to be something better than Barry's Boot Camp, because jogging to death under a blaring speaker in a shoddy facsimile of a crowded Miami nightclub isn't for everyone. BFX Chelsea is much bigger than it appears at first glance. Great when you're talking floor space. Not so great if you're talking about someone you met on the Internet.They cater to a variety of workouts. They have a spin class I choose to ignore. I took the Build class, in the same room where they also have classes called Burn, Barre and Boxing. Clearly, all the classes that take place in this room must start with B.Build uses kettle bells, dumbbells and TRX to build muscle. Burn focuses on cardio and I imagine it looks like that scene in Flashdance where the lady is getting all splashy with the chair. Barre is like ballet and it's for women, no matter what anyone says. Boxing is pretty obvious. Marvelous Marvin Hagler yelled at me when I was a teen busboy, so I hate to generalize but boxers can kind of go to hell. I have taken three Build classes so far and hope to build mass and be beefy like The Mountain and have women wink at me and hand me their room keys in hotel bars. So far it's not going that well because I have a hard time making eye contact. It's a shame because I really want to see what my wife would say if I came home with a gym lady.This was my first exposure to the TRX system. If you're unfamiliar with the TRX system, it's an $8 strap that retails for $200. TRX absolutely destroyed me. I was sore for days. It's the good kind of sore that allows you to build unwarranted self-confidence by telling everyone that you're sore from the gym.

This restaurant unexpectedly exceeded my expectations! First, I just have to point out that the service here is exceptional! The waitresses were so nice and friendly and explained everything to us in detail. They brought us out vinegar and taro chips. The waitress explained that we can dip a lot of our dishes in here. She also gave us a bottle of calamansi that we can add to our food or the vinegar.Baked Oysters: These breaded oysters were so delicious. It was flavorful and crispy on the outside and juicy on the inside. Even better with a little bit of lemon on top.Spam Fries: This is exactly what you'd expect. Battered and fried spam. Tasty, but a little too heavy and salty for me. It came with a side of banana ketchup. Very interesting!Grilled Octopus: Wow this dish was exploding with flavor. First of all, the octopus was soooo tender! And eating it with the mango and the sauce was the perfect complement. So good!Sizzling Sisig: I always love sisig, but the sisig here is so good. All the meat is tender and even melts in your mouth. It's bursting with flavor and goes so well with the garlic rice. Fried Chicken with Purple Yam Waffle: The fried chicken was good, but the waffles!!! I'm usually not a fan of waffles but these... so good. It was crispy but moist and a bit denser than regular waffles. The anchovy compound butter and caramelized macapuno syrup was the perfect combination! You must try this if you come here.Duck Breast: Duck was tender, but the skin part was a bit chewy. It came sliced on a bed of veggies and a side of grilled apple and eggplant. This dish was good, but it was a bit on the sweet side for me.Mango Cheesecake: This was a bit too sweet for me, but definitely tasted the mango in it! If you like cheesecake and mango, then you'd like this dessert.Coconut pudding (not sure of the name of this dish): Yum, this was creamy, smooth, and had little pieces of dried coconut in it. Not too sweet and topped off my meal perfectly.

It's excessive and it's damn good. Look, this place has over 1,000 reviews, a fixed menu and 3 Stars flying over its Michelin constellation so I'll skip the jibber jabber and make three solid points. 1) If the white truffle risotto (add on $175) is in season just suck it up and get it. However, you'll only need 1 per table of four or per couple if you wanna throw down the sexy time card. It's just too rich and decadent for one person. Being as self-centered as I am I got one all for myself and regretted it as about half way through my tongue went dumb and nose closed it's door 2) Allocate a good 4 hours for the meal. Plus or minus 15 min for the kitchen tour upon request. 3) I really wished I pocketed all the left over chocolate truffles and macaroons. You won't be able to finish them all by the 3rd round of desserts. 1st generation Asian guilt mom conscience would have scolded me for leaving food on the table. In fact let's not tell my mom I went here at all. ( insert dollar signs and bulging eyes emojis)Also you can't tell me that the amuse-bouche does not look like a penis.

A handroll bar!Had my birthday dinner here a few nights ago - they were very accommodating with my extreme tardiness. I would recommend making a reservation here ahead of time, though it seemed like they weren't as crowded as I thought they would and should be on a Saturday night. Not even a line or anything!In my opinion, DOMODOMO is underrated and is a gem of a place that doesn't seem to be too hyped up by the foodie crowd yet. The prices are reasonable, quality of food is excellent, and the service is impeccable.We were seated at the counter and served by at least three people working there. Their Japanese beer is amazing - and I don't even really like beer. The cool yuzu-smelling self-expanding hand towel thing is an added part of the whole experience.To start, we got the duck udon, which at $10, is actually very, very well priced. The duck was tender, not overcooked, and had so much flavor in it. The broth was flavorful, too. The udon noodles were of perfect consistency - overall a 10/10 for this dish. I would say however, ordering this alone would not make you full.For the rest of our meal, we got the handroll sampler ($30). We started with a mini black truffle chawanmushi that was just absolutely delicious. The black truffle was there, but wasn't overpowering like you might think it would be. So good! The rest of the hand rolls - fatty tuna, salmon, unagi, and crab were all so good and so fresh. Even the seaweed was good! I liked the hand rolls versus a roll of sushi because it seems like you get much more fish in your roll and can control how big of a bite you want. Somehow it's just... different. The guy serving us waited until we finished each one and continued to serve us, kind of like omakase-style.To finish, we had the squid ink pasta with uni, caviar, and cheddar dashi. It reminded me of a very high class mac and cheese, only because of the cheddar dashi. The squid ink pasta was probably the best textured pasta I've ever had - beyond perfectly cooked. The only complaint I have with this dish is that it could have had more uni and I'm not sure how I felt about the cheddar being thrown into the mix - very unconventional.Overall, very happy with DOMODOMO and I'm glad I chose this lesser known place for my birthday dinner!

This is such a cute place. I am so glad my friend (a regular of this spot) showed me this gorgeous restaurant!CASH ONLY. FOOD:-my friend ordered tapas: the crispy potato, the grilled octopus, and the mushrooms. The mushrooms were surprisingly flavorful. The potatoes were good but not amazing. The octopus was very fresh. My favorite might be the mushrooms out of the trio. -I ordered the lobster paella. Holy moly was this a GIANT portion! I think it was meant to serve two but I will neither confirm nor deny that I ate most of it, took the rest to go, then ate it around 1 am that night. Yes it's that good. The lobster was a bit measly but the other seafood in it was generously portioned. Giant scallops, fresh mussels, etc. MUSIC/ATMOSPHERE: there's usually live music but we went on a Friday and there was just a really cool playlist. Good for date night, tons of string lights, sangrias, rustic wooden dining tables, and cute wooden bar tables for more casual diners. SERVICE: we stayed from 7:40 to midnight and didn't keep ordering drinks after the first set and they never tried to oust us! Instead they refilled our water glass numerous times. This pushed the place from a 4 star to a 5 star!

The Quick: Great delivery experience. Authentic Italian food with a flair enhanced by healthy salad options and an outrageous Nutella pizza pie. Good portions and quick delivery. New go to lunch spot in midtown east. The Details: Nutella. Pizza. Enough said. Sweet and chocolatey, on a heavenly pizza crust. If you're trying to be less gluttonous, (I'm always trying to lose 5 lbs) I suggest the Mediterranean salad loaded with goat cheese, or the quinoa salad which was a huge hit with my group. We ordered an array of different items and absolutely devoured everything. The other favorite was the lasagna which had a sweet yet savory flavor to their sauce-- very interesting and addicting. The portion looked average but was very filling and easy to share. The delivery was quick and our delivery guy was so friendly- it's the little things in life. I would order again for a team lunch or salad for myself. Recommend. The Damage: Since it was a big group order, it's hard to say. Looking at the website, everything is very reasonable especially for Midtown. Go try!instagram.com/SkinnyGirl…

Warnings: TAKE-OUT and CASH ONLY! and part of this review may require translation for some of you. This is a literal hole-in-the-wall, so don't think you're coming here to sit down, unless you and your friend grab two of the stools by the window. Speaking as a Jamaican whose family is blessed with several outstanding cooks, it can be really difficult to find a Jamaican take-out place that delivers like my aunts and cousins and father, et. al. Island Taste is some serious Jamaican food! You won't be eating quality like this on a regular basis unless you're making it yourself, or your family is. And it's great to know that I can get stew peas a la my papa, or curry goat a la my Aunt B. I've been making the journey here for several years--and so has my family when they're too tired to cook-- because it's worth it. A lot of the other spots in The Bronx that have great food, are constantly changing cooks/chefs, quickly going out of business, or having other unsavory events take place. I've never been disappointed and have tried almost every lunch/dinner item on the menu. They also serve breakfast, but I loathe porridge (I know, wtf? Jamaica, please don't disown me!), and haven't been able to try the ackee, saltfish, or cook food. Prices are pretty standard for similar spots depending on your meat. SOUP every day. Chicken soup is excellent and Mannish Wata is nice. Island Taste is bringing us the following amazing reasons to travel to 241 St:1. Consistency and food like ongle mi pupa couldah mek2. Dis food is TAP A DI TAP! Belly full! Unuh cyaan get dis nuh weh, so unuh muss come yah!3. Dem even fling likkle country peppa inna mi stew peas! (usually have to do this myself, at home) 4. dem open mawning, noon, and all 'til miggle night and all fruits ripe, and everyting (literally) cook an curry!If you're in the Bronx, if you want to trek for some authentic, bangin' breakfast, lunch or dinner...Hop on the 2 train. One love, bredren. More pics to come...

Wow...Excellent food, excellent service, excellent ambiance and excellent wine list, all at a price less than what you'd pay at a comparable Michelin-Star (1) rated restaurant (Blue Hill, Gotham, NoMad, etc.). Plus, when you do the tasting menu, you have several options to choose from for your courses, as opposed to a set menu of courses like other fine dining restaurants. And the wine list has many options of great wines, especially Red Burgundy, at only a 2x markup vs. a 3-4x markup at other fine dining restaurants...I'm a Sommelier for fun, so this is an area of importance for me. The Sommelier (Brook) was very helpful and her service was impeccable, decanting our wine without me even asking...which I would have. For wine and dinner, we had the:Champagne - R.Pouillon, grower-champagne (small producer): amazing, and at a great price Red Burgundy (French pinot noir): Gavinet, Nuits-Saint-Georges, another amazing wineRosemary-Rye Rolls & Butter: both excellent and loved the French butter Amuse-Bouche:Ricotta Tart: tasty, but almost too small1st Course:Beef Tartare: the best I've ever had, melted in your mouth with a savory black peppery flavor Lobster Salad: very light & fresh, but enjoyed the tartare more2nd Course:Red Snapper: such a perfect combination of flavors with a sherry sauce that even non-seafood eaters would enjoy Pork Loin & Belly: perfectly cooked and accompanying mustard sauce was to die forTrou Normand (palate cleanser)...American-Mexican style:Strawberry soda with a splash of Agave Tequila: very tasty and could've drank ten of them...why don't they serve this shot at bars? hahaDessert:Goat Cheesecake with a cherry compote: so rich and delicious, and the whole cherries matched well with the goat cheese-based cakeChocolate layer cake with raspberry sauce & salted caramel yogurt: decadent and paired well with our red wine, but preferred the goat cheesecakeCoconut Cream Merengue Birthday Cake: complimentary, so moist and flavorful and the merengue wasn't too hard or chewy, perfect Long Island Late Harvest Riesling: was recommended and thought it would suck as its from LI, but definitely did not, was delicious Mignardise/Petit Fours:Almond Cake rolls & Dark Chocolate filled with raspberry: both very good, but the chocolate/raspberry combo was amazing Complimentary-Take-Home Cinnamon Brown Sugar Muffin: amazingly delicious, even the day after the mealOverall, this place is a wonderful experience with impeccable service, amazing food and beautiful wines. Can't go wrong here. 5-stars for sure!!

Truffle chicken nuggets: so good that we paused in the middle of the first order to get a second round. Even before the pink slime fiasco, I wasn't too crazy about McDonald's' chicken nuggets, but how could anyone not love these beauties? Deep fried to a deep brown crisp and accompanied by a garlicky ranch dressing, totally worth the hike up Second Avenue in all its current stages of utter demolition. I suppose if you had to, you could lump The Milton's vittles into pub food, but everything we ordered went above your average limp mozzarella sticks and potato skins. The coconut chicken pot pie came with a little hat of flaky, croissant-like bread. I sampled some of my friend's cottage pie - braised short ribs, mashed potato, cheese, otherwise known as winter hibernation food. But my boyfriend's burger took the cake: as I was eating it, I kept thinking to myself how, in a true fit of gluttony, I would not be above taking the French fries, er, chips, and mashing them inside the burger. I also ate most of the Knickerbocker glory, even though I never thought the combination of strawberry marmalade and ice cream would pair so well. NEXT TIME: more of the fizzy pear drink, more of the chicken nuggets, more of the burger, and maybe the Milton kale salad because, you know, "health."

My birthday fell on a Monday. I don't mind Mondays for a birthday. No one else usually goes out so it is slower, more relaxed, etc. My boyfriend planned a lovely, fancy night that ended at Amelie. The place was packed. Yes, on a Monday, it was packed. Thankfully, we had reservations and were seated immediately. I just adore everything about this restaurant. The staff are incredibly friendly and (from what I could tell) all spoke french. We easily settled in for a long and savory night. First we obviously had to get a bottle of wine. The menus are fixed to old records which was a fun touch. Most bottles were priced $30-50 which is to be expected. Next on the to-do list was to decide on what charcuterie to get. They were able to accommodate our questions about the meats and cheeses (my favorite things to eat, surprisingly cheap at only $18 for three choices). The dish was served with grapes, honey, jam, mustard, apple cider red slaw, and of course mustard and butter. It was a dream. We ended up getting prosciutto, a creamy french cheese and blue cheese. Everything tasted just as it should if not better.Now seeing as how it was my birthday, I needed to end the night with steak and frites. The steak was delicious as I got it (medium rare). It came with a scalloped potato and greens cooked with garlic and butter. I loved it. The frites were very crispy. My boyfriend thought the soup could have been better (salty and the cheese didn't seem right) but still enjoyed it.They provided a banana creme brulee dish at the end for my birthday which was a sweet, but not toooo sweet way to end the night. When leaving, the lovely staff all wished me a lovely birthday and my boyfriend and I decided to digest with a long walk to a farther subway stop. Top notch place. I'll definitely be back!

Just go.Where do I begin for a review of Queen of the Night? Just imagine doing coke off a unicorn's back. (Assuming you haven't already.)I'd say QotN is combo Cirque du Soleil[1], combo bacchanalian feast, combo speed dating event. If you're not an extrovert, you might want to learn to be for the evening. You (and/or your party) will be seated at one of several tables, where you will partake in communal wine, and whatever the heck the kitchen brings out to you (if it's the brisket - THAT BRISKET - or lobster, you're in for a culinary treat). Want something from another table? Haggle with your fellow diners, usually with a simple exchange of food. Though, if you're feeling particularly feisty, I'm sure you could make out with someone to get a lobster.Watch out when they clear your tables, they're kind of eager and might take your drink.[1] it's natural I draw this comparison - speaking to performers after the show, turns out many were trained in Montreal.

I love this bar.A buddy of mine recently invited me to The Tippler for his birthday. Considering I frequent the West Village I was surprised I hadn't heard of it. Little did I know, it's a bit of an underground gem AKA a SPEAKEASY BITCH. Sorry, I didn't mean to call you that.ANYWAY, The Tippler is underneath the Chelsea Market and it's quite large. Like really large. What's interesting about the Tippler is you could easily miss it. The entrance is inconspicuous (DUH, IT'S A SPEAKEASY BRO) and once inside, you have to go down two sets of stairs to get to the bar.The inside is great. It's on the darker side, but the low key lighting, rugs and optional tables on the side give it a really chill, almost apartment like vibe (despite the fact that it's so large). Obviously, the size of this joint is a huge bonus because I've never gone and felt uncomfortably crowded and there's always somewhere you can escape if you want to have a more intimate conversation with friends or if you're trying to woo a lovely lady (or in my case, getting horribly rejected).The drinks are a tad pricey (it's the West Village after all), but they are fantastic, unique and tasty. Personally, I'm like a chick when it comes to drinks and I often find myself annoyed that drinks are over poured with booze as opposed to well crafted. Thankfully, The Tippler makes strong, delicious cocktails. For example, I love the Derek Smalls:It consists of Zubrówka bison grass vodka, cucumber, grapefruit, anise, mint. I don't know what the hell bison grass vodka even means, but I do know this drink basically tastes like an alcoholic green smoothie and you better believe the chick in me was loving this drink.LASTLY and although insignificant to my friends, I LOVE, LOVE, LOVE (yes three loves, no shame people) that The Tippler offers self serve spa water (infused with lime, cucumber or something spa like). After a heavy night of drinking, this was SO clutch as I progressively drank water throughout the night and woke up the next day sans a hangover. Not to mention, it provided fodder for a series of jokes like, "Alright bro, hit me with one more for the road, but that's the last one" as we pretended to be grizzled truckers taking shots of water. CLEARLY, my friends and I are a cool bunch.ONE THING, I would keep in mind with The Tippler IS there's something depressing about how dark and underground it is. NOW, I say that having come to The Tippler in the middle of the summer and summertime in NY is all about outdoor drinking. SO, I think this is the absolutely PERFECT winter bar and I'll will undoubtedly be frequenting this place come the colder weather.FINAL NOTE: I left my credit card at The Tippler for over two weeks due PURELY to laziness. When I reached out, not only were they friendly and accommodating, but they had taken good care of the ol' girl (the "ol' girl" being my credit card of course).5 stars all around for Tippler and once winter comes, a bar that will be apart of my consistent rotation.

Man, what a great experience! I didn't know what to expect and this exceeded any expectation I could have had. We picked up our tickets upstairs, but the theater was downstairs. We went downstairs to a theater where any seat is a great seat. The stage was set for a nursing home. One door they opened looked like a real bathroom inside. Their window looked like actual sun was shining through. The set changed a few times. One time the characters had a massive screen behind them so it appeared as if they were sky diving. There weren't many actors/actresses in the play, but they were all good. The two older women were hilarious!!!! I laughed throughout the entire play. The cranky lady's humor were those one liners I wish I could always think of that pack a big punch in only a few words.I'd absolutely recommend this play to people. I wish them a lot of success because it was a wonderful way to spend a Friday night.

This is one of those places that I have bookmarked for when I accidentally stumble upon a pile of unclaimed ca$h money that mysteriously regrows itself. It's archived for some future Utopia where first world issues like health insurance, prudent retirement planning, and Alzheimers don't exist. Because ZZ's is nothing but pure indulgence, and possibly the greatest threat to your financial bottom line since Obamacare.Like many before me, my mind was blown from beginning to end throughout the three-hour rendezvous with ZZ. The drinks menu is overwhelming only because the options all look equally enticing. After some deliberation I went with the Buddha, because who could resist magical potion in a Buddha belly?! I can't even remember what was in it, only that it put me in a deep state of bliss. Several heavenly uni toasts, scallops, and yellowtails later, I was drunk with love. I recalled the fledgling days of my youth, the nascent buds of young love, the first time I laid naked eyes on my untamed ChildManLover, gliding over the sinusoidal waves of his ginger peaks and valleys. And then the grandmother of all dishes. Layers upon layers of Chianina Beef Carpaccio spread generously, interspersed with sea urchin and topped with caviar. The carpaccio yielded to my tongue without resistance. The sea urchin was as delicate as a lover's touch, and the caviar a product of their love. The holy trinity of sea treasures, together in one place. An explosion of culinary chemistry. I let myself succumb to it willingly, casting away all my worldly worries to be simply and utterly awash in this sea of joy.Rising cost of tuition? Looming water crisis? Such trivialities. Pick up all the litter from your humdrum life and stuff it in the back of your closet. Put on your best suit and head to ZZ's because sometimes, unchecked indulgence is just what you need.

Oh my goodness gracious. I was going to not write a review at first because I assumed all Ethiopian restaurants in NY were about this level amazing, but after a recent bad dining experience elsewhere, I've decided to give Injera the great review it deserves because it is my favorite Ethiopian restaurant in the city. The ambiance here is so cute and romantic. The service is AMAZING. They are so friendly and take the time to explain each dish and make sure that you have everything you need. But I know you guys just care about the food, so let me get to that. The Yetimatim Fitfit (diced tomato, red onion, tomatoes, avocado, green chilies & pieces of injera with olive oil lemon dressing) has been the best Ethiopian appetizer I've ever had. It's such a great take on the usual Ethiopian salad. My roommate and I had the Vegetarian Combination for Two and we were in heaven. Usually the vegetarian dishes at other Ethiopian restaurants aren't so flavorful, but this was the most flavor-filled dish I've had in a long time. I don't know why anyone would complain about small portions. I eat like a truck and even I was like rolling out the door by the end of dinner. I didn't even have room for ice cream which is unheard of! Anyways, I highly suggest anyone who loves flavor and spices to go go go to Injera!

I'M LITERALLY GOING TO HAVE A PANIC ATTACK DUE TO THE FACT THAT THE MARK IS ONLY 3.5 STARS ON YELP. It's times like these I wish I could give a Yelp seminar on what makes a great restaurant. If someone were to ask me what my favorite restaurant is in Manhattan (I eat out LITERALLY every single day and most days, twice a day, usually at top notch restaurants) I would say The Mark. Why you ask? Well let me explain...ATMOSPHEREUpper east side traditional with a modern twist. The crowd is definitely the movers and shakers of the Upper East Side. The restaurant oozes modern luxury (the hotel does as well).SERVICEThe service is always great. Sure maybe there are a few hiccups here and there but honestly nothing to get upset about or notice. The first time I ever came here my friend made a joke about it being a special night or something and the waitress brought over a complementary dessert. It's that small touch that brought me back here a second time with my family and friends.FOODHere. We. Go!I really don't enjoy eating at "fusion places" which blend different styles of food together or places that have large menu's. I feel like a restaurant should pick one thing and just be very good at that. Well, 1- The Mark has a HUGE menu. HUGE. HUGE. HUGE. The Mark has everything from sushi to fresh seafood to steak to pizza, pasta, cheeseburgers, veal, lamb, chicken... do I really have to continue?! You will feel anxiety just reading the menu as the choices are honestly endless.2- Definitely has a fusion of many different types of cuisine all on one menu. Yet all surprisingly well executed.+ Seafood platter (small portion) - Absolutely delicious and was an amazing thing for 4 of us to share. I think it's honestly priced lower than it should be for a seafood platter of that size so take advantage of this!+++ Lobster - ABSOLUTELY the best thing on the menu that I have eaten thus far. While it was plated differently the two times that I dined at The Mark, the flavor was still the same.+ Lamb - My friend stated that this was one of the best lamb's he has ever had.+ Crispy sushi - Really great. I was cautious with this dish as I eat sushi as some of the best sushi counters in the world and am extremely picky with raw fish but this was not bad. For a place with such a big menu, I was very surprised at how good this dish was. + Char grilled octopus - DelishI can't remember the other dishes that I had but those were the ones that really stood out to me.DESSERTI'm actually not a big sweets person. I used to be and then thankfully grew out of that stage (thankfully as in calories-wise). +++++ BUTTERSCOTCH PUDDING - Salty, sweet, butterscotchy. Dear Lord! One of the best desserts that I have ever consumed in my entire life. I absolutely adored this.+ Angel food cake - Delish but not as good as my butterscotch pudding ^+ Vanilla ice-cream with chocolate sauce - Sounds very simple but this dish had a lot of flavor actually. It comes very nicely presented as well. + Selection of sorbets - Also very well plated and tasty.I am a HUGE fan and will definitely make this a regular spot.

So I'm at the bodega and Mario (the hardest working man in Two Bridges), while slicing my Boar's Head Honey Turkey, tells me that a new bar has opened up the block. Now, anywhere else in Manhattan another bar opening would be about as newsworthy as another Cosby accuser coming forward (actually, I guess that is still newsworthy...but you get the point). If you are at all familiar with my personal Chinese shtetl, and particularly the immediate surrounding streets where rats dine on the finest fish guts this side of the Yangtze, you would understand my intrigue upon hearing this news. Several days later while walking my gf's dog we passed by and went in to take a look. We both were kinda shocked to see what they had done inside this former nondescript storefront on the most random block in the city (maybe Mechanics Alley is the new poor man's Freeman Alley?). So, yeah, the bar looked great, not a dumpy dive bar, but nothing pretentious or artificial either...just right. Since it had just opened and it was mid-afternoon, we were the only customers there. After scoping out the inside I went to see what they had on tap and met the bartender and part owner Aisa (class act). As my adoring 17 yelp fans are well aware, the only thing I really care about is if a bar has perfectly carbonated ice cold Coors Light on tap (go ahead, roll your uppity eyes and judge me, but I won't apologize for enjoying the best domestic beer ever made). Imagine my delight upon learning that they have Coors Banquet on tap ( business.time.com/2013/1… ). Just as Coors is considered the prototypical uncool beer, Mr. Fong's location is equally uncool, or maybe so uncool it is cool (I suspect this is their angle). After having a beer and one of their signature cocktails, we checked out the jukebox which was also impressive. I have not been back since that first time, but have passed by several times and it was crowded! Who the hell are these people and where did they come from?! I get the feeling more and more that in a couple years I'm not going to recognize my neighborhood (and since it is such a dump, I'm fine with that...sorry, I meant I will fight gentrification and organize the community to keep the streets smelling like fish guts). Seriously, I'm happy to see that Mr. Fong's is doing well and hope to return soon.

Sakagura is where we had our second date.*Where we had responsibly shared a single carafe of wine on our first date, this time, we got ridiculously, aggressively, comically, drunk.So anyway, we met in front of Sakagura. It's in a very ugh part of town, midtown east. I remember approaching the spot and seeing him leaning against the streetlight in his white polo shirt and khaki shorts like some sort of preppy pied piper.I was wearing black leather combat boots, grey acid-washed jeans, an oversized asymmetrical hoodie, and my school backpack.We were like two enemy chess pieces, meeting covertly off-the-board to discuss a possible armistice despite our bloodthirsty generals.We go in and order some sake. I'd furtively eaten a cream cheese bagel on a park bench right before, because we were meeting for "drinks" at dinner time and I'm the rare bird on this island that actually likes to eat three meals a day.Anyway, the conversation went like this:him: So, how's school?me: It's ok.him: So, how's life?me: It's ok.Hehe. I don't know. Then I grabbed the mic and started asking the questions. Because I was never socialized properly into society, my questions went like this:me: Do you want to die by fire or drowning or buried alive?him: Drowning.me: Lame.me: Would you move to the jungle if it had great wifi?him: I guess so...me: Wrong, the insects would kill you.It continued like this until he got drunk to escape me, a trend that has carried on to this very day. I didn't think I was drunk until I caught myself leering at my reflection in the mirror with a knowing smile when I was washing my hands in the washroom. That's when I knew I was a little sauced up too.We played a little "guess what those people over there are about" but it was not too stimulating. Everyone there was obviously a 37-year-old office worker relaxing over drinks with co-workers before taking a commuter train home.After a few rounds of drinks, he said, "Want to order food?"I said I was not hungry.The other thing is that I had planned to go to a Danish house party later that night. Our first date had been short, so I'd assumed this date would be short, too.But I realized that I liked how he took my questions seriously, mulled over them respectfully, so I invited him to come to the Danish house party with me.Outside on the sidewalk, we were shy and formal again. We hopped into a cab and sped towards the East Village.It was our first time in a motor vehicle together. I pointed out my favorite street meat vendor spots. He blanched at "street meat" but that's what I still call it to this day. It is meat that you eat in the street: street meat.Anyway, before we went to the Danish house party, we decided to get some more drinks at DGBG first. I don't recall how that came to be. To wash down the sake?I had a martini. He had a martini.Next, I remember walking against traffic up Bowery. There's that soft spring wind that swirls around at night like you're being caressed by ghosts. My boots stomping with unnecessary assertiveness. Maneuvering around orange plastic construction pylons and drunks gathering their things in the backseat of impatient cabs, ready to pick up new fare.I'm leading the way. He's behind me. Or maybe it's the other way around. Doesn't matter. We are equal partners in crime snaking through all the lovely detritus of a warm Friday night.And even though there is no mirror in front of me this time, I catch myself smiling again.*If you want to start at the beginning, go here: yelp.com/biz/bar-jamón-n…

Pizza is one of my favorite foods. It had gotten me through some rough times in life. So while browsing the Internet, I came upon this tour and thought "why not?" The best thing about Scott's pizza tour is Scott himself. He is so knowledgable about pizza. I learned so much from our tour. His excitement about pizza and the history of the New York pizza landscape is impressive. I love that he has these little gadgets like his temperature gun and his tiny pizza wheel. You get a goodie bag that is awesome! My favorite thing in it were the gummies that looked like pizza. The tour I went on was the original walking tour (I forgot the actual name of it). The pizza was fantastic. We went to lombardi's, rubirosa, and prince st pizza. All very good and worth a trip down to soho. Oh and in case you're curious, Scott does not eat drunk 99cent pizza.

I booked a couples massage with my girlfriend. She got there earlier than me and texted me while waiting downstairs, saying that it seemed sketchy.I arrived a few minutes late and we walked up the stairs into a nice little spa. And no, it was not sketchy, they were really professional.The couples massage room is 2 fights up, we had to wait a little because they were behind schedule. This place is small but clean. The rooms are separated by curtains. The best part is that there is a sign on the wall saying "no hanky panky" and to not take off your underwear. I read the no hanky panky part but did not read the rest and took off everything by mistake.The massage was good, if you check in with yelp, you get an extra 10min for free. $36 for 70 min of massage? Hell yes. They even used hot stones on your back.If you pay with cash, there is no tax. They do accept credit cards too.

When deciding where to eat tonight with friends, this restaurant name resonated with us so we decided to give it a try. We arrived around 7:30 on a Saturday night - they don't take reservations for parties smaller than six so we were expecting a wait. Surprisingly, we were seated pretty quickly - 5 to 7 minute wait at most. The restaurant is small and bustling - the dining room is decorated simply with an impressive bar upon entry and a huge golden pizza oven in the back. We decided to share everything ; we started with the beets which came with pickled red onion, pistachios, and ricotta salata and the kale which came with garlic, chili flakes, and ricotta salata. Both were great, but I especially liked the kale; it was seasoned well and I was in heaven with those bulbs of roasted garlic. We then shared the gemelli pasta which was served in a pesto sauce and topped with stracciatella cheese. The pasta was good - it was cooked al dente and the stracciatella was a nice touch. We couldn't leave without trying the pizza, so we decided to split two of them. As the name of the restaurant suggests, the pizzas are wood fired. They're meant to be individual-sized and have a rustic look to them with charred edges and an overall irregular shape. We went with the goat cheese and the J. Sexton. Both were great - the flavors worked well with each other and the wood-firing technique really showed. Service was awesome; everyone from the hostess who greeted us to chef Chas Anderson himself did a really great job - super impressed! I had a great experience overall - definitely a place I would return.

See my last review for more details if you'd like, but I feel obligated to bump up my rating to 5 stars. I came here this past weekend for the first time in a month or so, and have nothing but positive things to say. The crowd is boisterous but not obnoxiously so, the bartenders are downright awesome, and obviously, the beer list is expansive, creative and diverse. And tasty. Can't forget tasty.Even when this place is packed as it was this past weekend, I'm always aware of how full of good vibes it is. Lots of chill people with a passion for beer, just looking to have a more low-key night. Something about Arts and Crafts being below street level makes it like a cozy little nook. I love it. If you didn't get that already.I felt the need to update my review because on this past trip, I conquered a flight of 12 beers with a friend. We're both very into craft beer and are interested in sampling as much as we can (responsibly, of course), so we were very much up for the challenge. A flight of 12 (1/2 board) is 45 bucks. If you're splitting that between two people, it's a really really good deal. That's 25ish per person if you're including tip, which is basically 1.5 cocktails at a speakeasy. If you check out my picture, you'll see that they give you good-sized glasses, so don't get too overzealous or you WILL get blackout. I can't see how you wouldn't. When we asked the bartender about the full flight (24), he said "well, it's possible....". But the two of us wanted to find our way home that night, so we did the responsible thing.First things first - you'll get a paper and pencil to list your choices. They were actually out of a few beers we had listed, but fortunately that meant that a number of beers on their "coming soon" list was coming...right then and there. So voila, more beers to choose from - if there weren't enough already! They give you your flight based on the order of the beers you've chosen. I'm not sure if all racks are circular (I'm guessing they are), but you're encouraged to go clockwise. The first beer you pick will be at 1 o'clock (I mean, technically you can make it whatever o' clock you want but you get the point), and then you just rotate around. Simple enough. If you're with someone who's as interested in broadening their craft beer horizons as you are, I'd highly recommend this option. They've got such an impressive draft list and for someone who's addicted to trying new things, the flight option is really the only option.
Don't. Speak. Poorly. Of. My. City. If. You. Don't. Like. It. Here. Pls. Take. Your. Ass. Else. Where.Born: CaliHail: AtlR.I.P.: NYC

I've been to HandCraft kitchen and cocktails primarily for their fantastic beer selection, but I got to try a tasting menu the other night and they exceeded my expectations! Come here for the drinks, but stay here for the food! Here are some of the highlights of the evening!For starters, we had the Louisiana Gumbo that had some nice heat to eat without it being overpowering. Perfect for the cool weather we've been experiencing. I also loved their Baltimore Crab Cakes which is paired perfectly with their lime Aioli. For fans of deviled eggs, you've got to try their Buffalo Deviled eggs with chicken and blue cheese.Their salad course was a Kale Salad served with Farro, quinoa and roasted corn in a delicious burnt lime vinagrette. The salad was very hearty and I could definitely go for an entree size. For their pasta course, we were treated with an excellent version of Mac and Cheese which was farfalle served with gruyere, asiago, bacon, and bechamel with garlic bread crumbs.For their entrees, I highly recommend their Wilde Game Meatloaf served with bison, wild boar and duck in a homemade bourbon bbq ketchup. Also try their Bison Burger with avocado, bacon, manchego and chipotle aioli. They also served seared salmon on a wasabi mash! WASABI MASH! Wow!Thankfully, their dessert course was a light vanilla panna cotta with wild berry sauce. The perfect way to end a large meal!For drinks, you can't go wrong with any of Alex's creations! I love the Berry Lemonade which he makes with a black and blueberry strawb, a drinking vinegar. Trust me, it tastes delicious. The Red Wagon Wheel uses house made ginger beer and fernet branca. If you want a traditional whiskey sour made right, Alex is your man. But if you really want something special, order the Fiery Porch. It has both a spicy and alcoholic kick that will keep you coming back for more!Thanks HandCraft Kitchen and Cocktail for a wonderful experience. I came for the drinks, but I'll keep coming back for the food!

I hardly do any yoga any more. In fact, I have skipped yoga for several years now. Truth be told, I have barely been working out lately. So it was with considerable skepticism that I signed up for a class at Lyons Den, a brisk five-minute Eastward walk from where I live.The venue has had some interesting uses for it previously. But the makeover to being a yoga studio is impressive. It has a very East Village vibe to it--casual and inviting--but a distinct Tribeca feel when you factor in the loftier setting and the older crowd relative to the college kids flocking along St. Mark's Place.The owners--Bethany and John--are very friendly and engaging. Bethany seems to be a unique talent who is motivating, mindfully merciless with the intensity of the flow, and has great command over what goes on in her class. The other instructors seem very effective as well--Annie, Meg and Brooke to name a few. The power flow yoga classes operate at a brisk pace, and are sure to leave you sweating and well exercised. Is Lyons Den at an early stage of its evolution and growth when everything is brand-new and everyone is friendly and accessible? I sure hope not. While I can't see how the business could grow in its current location, I suspect new locations could spring up over time. Hopefully not at the expense of diluting Bethany's and the other teachers' commitment to this Tribeca gem.

I am so happy that this place is in the 'hood. And today I got to try it with some friends visiting from out of town. I stopped in about 2 weeks ago and asked some questions to the friendly handsome bald bartender. He was very friendly and told me this place is the sister restaurant of fogetmenot, how cool! The ambiance is intimate, airy, and open. I showed up a few minutes before my friends arrived at at noon, this place was just starting their day. I had a choice of any table in the house. Sweet. My friends showed up and we started salivating over the menu. One of my friends and I decided to order a half carafe of house rose. Good amount of alcohol to share and all wines from Greece. This place does a very decent job showcasing Greek food (I am a fan). Too bad they were out of the octopus, because that is what I really wanted to try. My friends and I decided on a few plates to share including spanakopita ($10), taramosalata ($6), fave beans dip ($6), sauteed shrimp ($11), zucchini chips with mustard dip ($8), and roasted potatoes ($6). Everything was very tasty and flavorful, and came with unlimited amounts of homemade grilled toast with olive oil. The standouts would have to be the taramosalata and the zucchini chips. Great to have a new place in the hood to hang out with friends. So happy you guys are here in LES/Chinatown. Yippee!

This is review #300. I had saved it for a special place and mŏkbar fits that bill.They say true geniusoften strikes in the pale moments between awake and asleep. I must have been sleepwalking all these years because I haven't truly had Korean-style ramen until today and the experience I had, by definition, was a culinary eye-opener. This brings us to why we feel mŏkbar is deserving of 4.8/5.0mŏkbar, the brainchild of NJ-native Esther Choi, began operating in Chelsea Market in May of 2014, billed as the first Korean-style ramen in the city. (They're situated across from Los Tacos #1 which I'm not a fan of... you can read my review on that.) Riding on a wave of high acclaim from media outlets, Esther's Food Network appearance on Beat Bobby Flay (aired Sept 4, 2014, in case you're interested) catapulted the restaurant into the cross hairs of the masses for better or worse. Having cut her teeth with experience at ilili, and La Esquina also helped hone her craft from training at Institute of Culinary Education (ICE).When I first visited one afternoon, months earlier, I had the classic ramen, my mistake- it didn't set my palate on fire. I returned to rectify this on a Thursday Chelsea gallery opening night, ordering dishes until I bursted with fruit-flavor.FOODFor small plates or as it should be called, anju, we ordered Ho'Cakes, Japchae dumplings, tteokbokki, and spicy Mok wings. Anju is typically accompanied by alcohol so we simply had to have the soju sampler (where each glass come flavored by a different fruit or inspiration- sorry, I can't remember them all) The Ho'cakes, otherwise known as hotteok, are every bit as amazing as I've heard about these savory stuffed pancakes of pork. Every morsel with satisfying chew, it was probably not meant to be shared, because it will fall apart if you try to cut into one of the halves! hahaha. The japchae dumplings, although true to the dish that it draws inspiration from, I prefer my japchae served up on a plate, not so much in the form of a dumpling (just my preference), however the dumpling had a nice crisp to them and the glass noodles danced around inside my mouth with the accompanying sauce being spot-on. The tteokbokki was a nice surprise because I've made them at home with gochujang and so I know that the rice cakes are typically huge logs with satisfying chew. Their take is a fantastic departure in that they're the size of penne with crisp, chew, and heat all in the same bite! This would ideally go great with beer in any case. They were still crispy even while marinating in the sauces. Impressive! Finally, the Mok wings, which we ordered spicy were marinated in gochujang, the right amount of kick without overpowering the flavor of the wings. Simply fun to eat, much like the tteokbokki.For my entree, I ordered the kimchi ramen along with porkbelly and extra noodles because you can never have enough. I enjoy these soups that're served hot, and also packing sufficient heat despite the summer months. The presentation is all there, Sun Noodles, as ever-present in commercially produced ramen, is also nice to see. The porky soup broth provides the requisite kick and flavor from the kimchi, as expected. The cabbage itself provides all the veggies I'd like to eat for the night. All-in-all, I love it without the egg. Definitely on-par with all the ramen heavy-hitters in the city.SERVICEService is as quick and attentive as you'd expect from a standalone restaurant, making sure your table never runs out of water, getting small plates to the table first, getting entrees out altogether, checking on your experience- basically all the little things which always ends up mattering so much.ETCVegan ramen is offered, and this means miso-based. (This is huge) A restaurant offering a menu set of this size is remarkable considering the space/kitchen they have to work with. They have seating by the kitchen counter and in the back, away from the prying eyes and those seat-vultures in Chelsea Market. (Yes, like you, I am one too) The only drawback I find with mŏkbar is that it's set within the busy energy that is Chelsea Market, amidst the hustle and bustle of shoppers, stragglers, lunch-goers, foodies, I've heard my fair share of ignoramus commentary while waiting a few minutes for my table like "What kind of Chinese is this??" and so I also don't especially welcome the prying eyes burning into the back of my skull, nor the onlookers with the look of bemusement, gazing at the "bizarre foods" that I'm savoring.SUMMARYmŏkbar is a solid, casual dining option among various non-competing choices in Chelsea Market, catering to both tourists and worker-bees alike from around the area (e.g. Google), the only Korean eatery within the Chelsea/MePa districts, offering ramen and gastropub (anju) fare. I can see Esther take the mŏkbar concept into it's own standalone restaurant, as it truly deserve a home to call it's own. 4.8/5.0

Lawrence and David are my shit. Alyssa kills it, too. Katharine is great and so is Siobhan.This yoga studio was hard for me to find. I visited at least five other studios in my search of 'the one'. My journey ended when I found Modo. Hot, sweaty classes with great facilities and conscious teachers. It's a beautiful thing.Start off with the traditional 'Modo' class if your even somewhat new to yoga and especially to Modo. Even if it's just one, take it and get comfortable with it. It's always the same postures every single class so you know what to expect. They have different time lengths 90, 75, and 60. Next, try Modo Flow. Similar to Modo in that it's the same postures every class BUT it's more challenging. You get in numerous chatarungas and it's very similar to a typical vinyasa flow but always consistent. Again, they offer different lengths of time in the classes.Then, grab a freestyle flow. Vinyasa class with ever changing postures and sometimes (depending on what it says on the schedule) they have music playing in the background. These teachers don't mess around...come ready to sweat and flow.Then my favorite....Yin Yang. Get your flow on for the first half of class (think freestyle flow) then slow it down and get into the yin portion. You will walk in there thinking it's not that hot and that you absolutely will not be sweaty and then just wait. This class will kick your butt and stretch you out in the most delicious ways. Lawrence is my favorite teacher for this style of class. They offer 60 minute versions but try the 75 minute. It doesn't get any better, really.One other thing that reeeally turned me on to Modo is the locker rooms. Clean showers but best of all, lockers that lock. Out of all the NY studios I visited before Modo, NONE had lockers I could lock. I've had my debit card and ID stolen at a studio before so that's a huge priority to me. Just because we're all looking for enlightenment doesn't mean someone won't snatch up your purse during/after class.

BNO with the guys was quite a feast here as some classy gents such as my buds Dan C and Dave H joined me to partake in an evening of manly men steak consumption.Put on that suit and tie, grab a cocktail at the bar, sit down and order a steak, throw down the credit card, and enjoy life. The only thing missing was a good cigar. We did it right here and they took care of us. Great service, the food was on point, and atmosphere was sophisticated but not overly upscale and fussy. Nice scene at the bar with an affable bartender and cool tunes playing.Don't heed the haters here, as it seems many of them would also whine about their burgers at White Castle not being good enough.Is it pricey? You bet! That's what a steakhouse goes for in NYC. Deal with it and eat. That's why you throw down the plastic and have at it.What can I say other then we picked out some great wines, my filet mignon was perfectly prepared, the sides such as grilled aparagus, mushroom caps, and mashed potatoes were just right, and the manager even came over to say hello and had some extra appetizers sent to our table complimentary. Now that's what I call an epic meal.Great food, great conversation, great company, great fun. That's what a BNO is all about. To eat loads of meat and talk about manly things without our gals being around for a night.Dat popover served up first tho. Dayum!

Delicious! Had my eye on Oiji for a while given all its' rave and write-ups in food blogs galore. Luckily, it lived up to its' hype!I made a ressie about 3 weeks out and was only able to nab a 6:15 pm reservation on a Wednesday so make sure you book early! Ressies were made quickly via OpenTable. My parents and I walked in and were seated right away. The space itself is pretty darn small - mostly 2-4 seater tables with a handful of bar seats. We saw some walk-ins throughout the evening that were able to eat at the bar so perhaps you will have luck with that sans ressies!For the three of us, we ordered the following:Fried Chicken $12 - YUMMM. Can't go wrong with fried chicken. This is basically a cutlet split up into 7 or so pieces. The batter on this was perf and the dipping sauce delish.Jang-Jo-Rim $10 - This was recommended by the waiter to round out our meal. It was SO good. The butter on this was amazing.Truffle Seafood $18 - I could have done without this dish. Hard to taste the truffle and while there was a decent amt of seafood, I don't believe it justified the $18 price tag.Ssam Platter $29 - So fun to make this! We all had a blast making our own lettuce wraps and the sticky rice with the PB sauce combo is amaze! Slow Cooked Oxtail $20 - Absolute 200% winner of the evening! It came with 2-3 LARGE pieces of fall off the bone oxtail. SO YUMZ.Honey Butter Chips $4 - Nice way to round off our meal! Be aware that the sticky sauce is SUPER syrupy and you're likely to get it all over your clothes if you're unlucky/a slob/basically me.They recommend about 2 dishes per person and we were nicely stuffed by the end of the meal. Everything tasted homey and flavorful! We did not order any alcoholic drinks as I noted to our waiter that I wasn't feeling that great/had a sore throat. He came back with hot water w. lemon - and even refilled it for me! Super good service :)

The Dive Bar Lounge or DBL as we fondly call it, is the new gay bar addition to the Hell's Kitchen area. This place has been transformed numerous times, but I'm sensing this time it will stick around for a while. We love coming over here during happy hour, $5 frozen margarita on a hot spring days. $3 draft beer and well drinks.On a nice day you can sit at outside tables. This is really a great place to start a night.

yeah i'm a product guy. big shock since i am in the branding, marketing, etc. game. what's worse is my big weakness: well-merchandised items. while i remain brand loyal, i recently decided to switch things up and start buying my skin, face, & shower stuff from Kiehls!i know i know: late to the Kiehl's game...not really. i was with Kiehls then left, then came back several times...it's like a marriage i can't let go of...makes me look good but at a price! "the struggle" -- least there's no alimony or child support.this third avenue store occupies the 13th street corner. there are typically a couple of benches outside during warmer weather for folks pause from the hustle and bustle. it's a nice touch and nod to the former neighborhood-y ways of NYC.the store gives its nods to old-school apothecaries and still manages a seamless flow to the modern day. the transition from exposed brick and off-white walls, then floored with light modern woods...creates a nice clean visual flow as the space is broken up by modern and old-school product metal displays/racks/bins with a mix of eclectic decor items like the skeletons (a nod to Kiehl's roots in medicine and science) and motorcycles (something for guys who don't want product, but are shopping with their gfs and wives). the store employs the clean aisle/display concept--merchandise is concentrated in spaces with wide lanes of travel as opposed to having the space broken up by retail displays and tons/varieties of product.the staff here are clad in lab coats/apothecary gear. they act not only as sales people and brand ambassadors but most importantly as folks who can speak intelligently to the products in the store by assessing your hair, skin, etc. needs and suggesting the items that will give you that rounded edge approach. i find the the Kiehl-sters really pleasant, always saying hello to you, and pretty helpful. i only shop when one Kiehl's staffer is there as he knows what i normally buy, can suggest stuff to complement, and give me the heads-up about products that i'd want. also i feel like using only one particular staffer every time i'm there shopping gets me free samples that i want or are open to using. so choose your staffer wisely! AND don't forget to sign up for the KIEHL's REWARDS program: you earn points for free items, get a free item on your birthday, and get mailers on specials, etc. the products themselves are great. the quality of them for the most part are miles ahead of what you get at your local supermarket, drug store, convenience store, mid-tier dept. stores, etc. however prices can be steep on items, but quality over quantity as your Kiehl's items tend to last longer bc you don't need to use of tons of it to see / feel the benefits at work as opposed to cheaper products which need to be slathered on multiple times.packaging is simple: either black on white or a simple primary color. much like the store itself or the ingredients list of the merch...Kiehl's employs the "less is more" by using high quality over quantity. and it stands behind this by its generous sampling policy. from a store, product and retail experience--there's not much to critique except that they don't have beard products for dudes yet, but they are in development. drops mic because i need both hands for my face and moisturizing regimen! i out!zzz

I know that there are three different hand-rolled ice cream locations in NYC, but I have so far only been to two, and of those, I would strongly recommend choosing this location, I-CE-NY (not sure why all those hyphens are there, but who cares, I'm here to judge the food, not the name). My gf is a huge Instagram food blogger (check out HungryNYC if you ever get a chance) and was invited over by the owners to come check them out. She brought me along and we came here on a Saturday afternoon to put the taste to the test.We arrived at 12 when it opened, but it was still closed. I gave them a call and they apologized that they forgot to flip the sign outside. We entered soon after and told them that we were there from the Instagram page. The guy at the counter (Danny... or Dani. Sorry, I asked how to spell your name and I already forgot) smiled and explained to us the origins of the hand-rolled ice cream and handed each of us a menu. The gf wanted to split an ice cream (NEVERRR) but I acquiesced and decided on the Thai Iced Tea flavor with lychee (part of the set-ice creams on the back of the menu). Then we watched one of the servers make the ice cream.The whole liquid nitrogen technique is really awesome. I saw it once at 10 Below, but it was cool to see the little differences here. 10 Below usually rolls 4 larger logs for one bowl, but I-CE-NY makes around 7-8 smaller ones, so it actually looks more presentable. We sat down with our ice cream and immediately dug in (no we did not... my gf took 5 minutes taking photos, during which the ice cream started inevitably melting). The ice cream texture was a bit rubbery because of the mixed in lychees, so that was odd. However, the flavors were all there and it had a nice, strong, complex taste that I think puts it far above its competitor. The only thing was that I didn't think that the pocky sticks it came with added to the taste - it's cute and fun, but flavor-wise didn't do much for me. The servers probably noticed me feeling very sad about the lack of my own ice cream, so they made one just for me! It was the strawberry cheesecake one with strawberry puree and cheesecake bits on top. This one had a more subtle flavor, but the presentation was nicer. The gf had a field day doing the photoshoot. Overall, I think the Thai Iced Tea had a better flavor and was more delicious. Both are AMAZING though. We 100% want to return to try the other flavors. This is the best new ice cream shop for both flavor and service!*EDIT* We came back exactly a week later because we couldn't resist staying away. Tried the Green Tea with condensed milk, mocha, and poppers. BEST ONE SO FAR. Also got the banana chocolate. Delicious as well! I'm not a banana person, but I still gulped the whole thing down.

"This is the changing point of the heights" I gotta say I was very impressed walking past this newly built hotel!walking across the street this hotel caught my eye and I was actually waiting around to go to a yelp event (cause I didn't really want to truck it back to the Bronx just to wait) so I decided, with the amount of time I had left to walk in and see what this place was about!"The lobby"It was extremely hot that day and I already had a button up shirt and a tie so coming into the lobby the AC hit my entire body instantly as the doors opened up! I noticed the front desked people were up front, they greeted me upon me walking in and I asked if I could have some water (I was dehydrated so I thought I asked) and they actually gave me a bottle of water! So that in itself was a awesome gesture in my book. So I took a seat the front lobby seats were colorful and literally so comfortable I was dozing off lol "The bathroom" So of course I wanted to do some sight-seeing so I walked around and found their bathroom and it was so clean and fresh I was more than happy to use it."Rooms,rooms,rooms"From walking from floor to floor (cause I was walking around looking in the building) I noticed the rooms (thanks the cleaning lady) being finished and it was a descent size room with a king size bed, with a huge TV and the bathroom from what I saw was very upscale was very impressive!"The results/overall"I'd would love to throw events here! I noticed that they were more space for things to be done so in curious to see what in stores for this hotel.This place just opened and already they choose to open in the heights which could be a hit or miss but already they are making a excellent name for themselves here in the heights! I wish them all but the best and I will be back to try this place out!

I love dim sum!Buddha Bodai is an excellent choice for get-togethers, whether it's an intimate dinner or brunch with a group of friends, as they offer an array of Chinese dishes that is sure to please omnivores and vegans alike. The dim sum, offered throughout the week till 3:30 pm, is served hk style which ensures that each dish is freshly made and not sitting around all day unlike the carts in other dim sum establishments. Their vegan "spare ribs" which has a firm texture and sweet marinade, taste even better than what you would get at a non-vegan restaurant. The crullers wrapped with rice paper are quite addicting! The steamed veggie dumplings were also very good. As per the regular menu I had the mushroom and bok choy with black pepper sauce: the sauce was light and the dish was a large portion, enough to share between two people.I'm definitely a fan of the Buddha, I think if you give them a try you would be too.Happy Eats....

I might be a little biased writing this review, because after all, I just so happened to propose to my girlfriend of two years at the top of this magnificent skyscraper, but all that goodness aside, we had a fantastic visit from start to finish!First and foremost, the impeccable level of customer service here deserves a serious shoutout.
