Only three employees knew my secret plans to propose here, but everyone treated us like royalty anyway, from the entry process to the elevator ride, to the CityPulse demonstrations, even the gift shop. As someone who frequents Yankee Stadium (also managed by Legends Hospitality) you really can't put a price on good service - well actually, maybe that's what those $10 stadium hot dogs are all about - I digress.The friendly folks in One Mix restaurant (the "middle" of the three tiers of dining options) who were aware of the proposal plans really went above and beyond. The hostess secured us a beautiful window seat facing north towards Midtown, and the manager offered to record video using my iPhone. He offered us a round of champagne complements of the house, with a nice little sugary "congratulations" decoration bearing the "One World Observatory" logo - a really nice touch! Our server, Fatima, was terrific and gave us both a hug, and let us really enjoy the moment and the view during our meal.Here's a quick 90-second video of our visit & the proposal: facebook.com/Rfisk83/vid…With 360-degree sweeping views of all five boroughs and beyond, One World Observatory is definitely worth the visit. If I were to pick one area for improvement though, there are FAR TOO MANY people sitting on the windowsill just doing nothing. Signs should either be put up, or some benches should be provided so people can take a quick break as they're taking in the beautiful views. I'm sure that by keeping everyone standing, that encourages people to look around and leave, but again, tourists are still sitting down, except now they're on the windowsill, getting in the way of the views and photos!

Turning up on a Tuesday!I preordered cronuts, which I highly recommend. I was in and out within 5 minutes, which included time I spent drooling over other goodies. Yes, I waited 3 weeks to get mine, but you won't catch me in a line at 7am with no guarantee!The Cronut itself was bergamot and earl grey and the flavors definitely complemented each other. The first bite was bliss. Crispy, flaky, light, sugary, so f-ing good. When I opened my eyes I noticed the earl grey cream oozing out. So so so good.Next time I go, I'll definitely try the Paris - NY, which is a take on the amazing Paris - Brest. Anything with chocolate, caramel, and peanut... Yeah buddy I'm in there.

We were so pleasantly surprised by izakaya! Due to a poorly-planned Sunday evening nap time, we ended up dinnerless at 10 p.m. Our usual go-to was closed, so we turned to yelp for suggestions. 4.5 stars is a good sign anywhere, so we came here. It's an unassuming little hole-in-the-wall near alphabet city, sunken into a small stretch of lane peppered with other small foodie joints. To be honest, we expected to eat well but nothing fancy. The photocopied menu doesn't say much about the amazing fare available. You're best off asking the waitstaff for their top recommendation or what people order the most often - their obvious enthusiasm and intimate familiarity with the menu was very refreshing and got us very excited about our food!We had the cold tofu, the beef sashimi, the omelet and the chicken nanban as well as the Kagua blanc beer. We were the only ones in the restaurant, so everything came out at the perfect pace - not too quick, not too slow. The tofu is dry-aged for two days, so it has a custardy texture (the aging process allows the whey to naturally drain out). They top it with a sharp-flavored leafy garnish in addition to fresh scallions with homemade dashi soy sauce. Mmm! The dashi was a little bit salty but it helped with the creamy tofu texture. I just dipped sparingly - no big deal. As the waiter passionately explained, the raw beef (washu, I believe?) is a hybrid between Kobe and Angus cattle for a medium-marbled fatty texture that isn't too heavy afterward. It was scrumptious and didn't even require any of the dipping sauce to taste delicious. I wrapped mine around some of the green scallions and left out the wasabi to enjoy the full beef flavor on my tongue. Mmm. The chicken nanban was the juiciest bite of fried goodness I've ever had. It tastes like the chicken is marinated in the same salad dressing it comes with, and then lightly battered and fried. The ranchy-tartare sauce was a little overwhelming for my personal taste, but you can easily scrape off any excess if you so choose. The salad was very fresh and light - the perfect complement to the chicken. As for the kagua beer, it was very light with some unique piquant notes to it. My beer palate isn't very refined so I can't tell you from taste how it stood out; I'll just rely on the waiter's description of it being a Japanese-flavored beer made in Belgium that sold out in Japan in two weeks - special water used for the brewing process, and some special Japanese ingredients (I believe yuzu citrus and a Japanese chili pepper?). Delicious and well worth the $12. The little details, like very high-quality disposable chopsticks, are what make this place a five-star experience. Again, very pleasantly impressed - my expectations weren't high based on appearances!

One of the most iconic and famous museums in Manhattan, the Met has something for everyone. For you Gossip Girl lovers, sit on the steps of the entrance to live out your Serena / Blair moment. You can also get in for a suggested donation. Most recently, I came to the Met to see the China Through The Looking Glass exhibit. I really enjoyed it and it was one of the most talked about exhibits since McQueen's- which the fashionista in me very much enjoyed. I'm glad I made it there after work before the exhibit ended, and it wasn't too crowded at night.If fashion isn't quite your thing, then there are plenty of sections for you to check out about ancient cultures! There are also various events throughout the year that are worth checking out, so keep your calendar updated! This is by far one of my favorite museums in Manhattan and I enjoy coming here a few times a year.

Snowdays is a heavenly place for shaved ice/snow lovers. I went gaga over the myriad yummy toppings. I decided to be totally unoriginal and go with Made in Taiwan, which I'm sure every other Asian girl orders. It had everything I wanted--matcha snow, mochi, grass jelly, condensed milk--everything except... red beans! So for 50 cents I added the red bean topping and it was BOMB. I love the matcha flavor. It was not too sweet and had that familiar grassy taste I love (but it wasn't overwhelming!). Maybe, just maybe, if I scrutinize the flavor, it could be a little less sweet (I felt a sticky, sweet aftertaste in my mouth but that could be from the condensed milk). Overall, great flavor!For the uninitiated, the Made in Taiwan combo is VERY traditional Taiwanese/Japanese. Once you try it, you will know exactly why matcha + mochi + grass jelly + condensed milk (AND RED BEAN) always go hand in hand! They also have a variety of interesting flavors like yeti tracks.... and you can be like a kid and add fun things to your snow like pocky sticks, rainbow sprinkles, peanut butter sauce etc. etc.

I was really surprised to find such a high quality tea shop a couple streets down from Columbia! I just moved here and was frantically Yelping bubble tea/boba places near campus, since I'm used to having 5-6 near me at all times in California. Although Culture Tea Bar was highly rated, it didn't seem like as many people knew about it or went there. This made me question how good it really was, but I decided to give it a try. What a treat!I ordered an iced osmanthus oolong milk tea with less sugar ($3.50), and though it was slightly sweeter than I would have preferred, the tea flavor was distinct and fragrant. I was very impressed to learn that they brew each tea to order with loose-leaf tea leaves (using a tea brewing machine that looks similar to an espresso maker). It was refreshing to see that they had actual tea variations like Fuji Apple Black Tea, Cherry Blossom Green Tea, and Blended Black Tea rather than flavors (caramel, taro, etc.) that rely heavily on powders and syrups.They do take credit card, but remember that there's a $3.50 minimum. Since there's wifi and some limited seating, it would be a nice place for studying when it's not too crowded. However, the tiny space can get quite cramped, so I'd recommend getting a drink to-go. Will definitely be returning!

Ladies and gentlemen, I present to you one of the best bars I've ever been to. I went here on a Sunday night around 9:30pm with three other fabulous ladies. The atmosphere is amazing - cozy and familiar, yet trendy and modern. It felt like a bite out of Williamsburg. There was a fantastic singer singing in the front and there was a crowd gathered near him. I think his name was John Shmidt - this man was the star of the night! He had us dancing and singing along to it all, from Sheryl Crowe to Bill Withers to Bruno Mars to Billy Joel to Boys 2 Men. He really made our night!!! Was told this place is known for their gin and tonics, and my Winslow VIP friend recommended the Dorothy Parker gin and tonic (isn't on the menu). Tried hers and it was delicious so had to get one for myself. At just $10, it was worth it. In short, awesome atmosphere, fast and friendly waiter holding down the fort, great live music, and good drinks. Go here; you won't be disappointed!

Ruggy J's review was like Pavlov ringing the bell for me and Yelp pointing the direction to Davey's. As a person who one summer made 2 quarts of ice cream a week, I can attest to Davey's superiority in the homemade ice cream niche. Good ice cream is expensive and I can tell when good ice cream is made from expensive ingredients because that's what I used.The chocolate chocolate here was an explosion of deep cocoa flavor and cream, smooth, and so rich you know your tongue will never tire of licking this stuff up. The strawberry had a strong taste of the berry in that same smooth cream. Repetition may ensure you get bored with your cone and cup but the flashing lightbulb in your tongue and tummy will tell you then to lick the ice cream off some sweet someone. Because fellow Yelpers, even if you have the same flavor over and over again, this ice cream you won't tire of. It is really good. My friend had the pistachio, the creaminess of the ice cream offset by the graininess of pistachio bits. We both knew quality when we tasted it. Elation in a cone.

Friday 09/18/15: I was really in the mood for Sammy's Downtown Bistro, but had never been to Rosie's Bistro Italiano (just up the block from Sammy's) and my aunt told me that I would not be disappointed. She was 100 percent correct! I would probably give the overall experience a 4 stars, but the risotto served with my entree bumps it up to a solid 5! This is a cute Italian restaurant in downtown Bronxville, located near the train station, pharmacies, grocery store and other restaurants. I stopped in for an early dinner on Friday and was sad to hear that this place does NOT do happy hour. No sweat, though. I was greeted by the hostess, who walked my aunt and I to our booth. Our server was Kristen, who listed the specials for the evening and was very friendly and helped to answer my questions--5 stars for service. She was quick and made sure to check in between courses, and ask how everything was. 1. Arugula, pear, gorgonzola salad with pecans and cranberries--absolutely delicious! Lightly dressed to perfection. I'm not a huge gorgonzola fan, but do enjoy this combination in a salad.2. Pasta Di Bosco--linguine, wild mushrooms, artichokes, pancetta and garlic tossed in white truffle oil. This wasn't my dish, but it was outstanding and had quite a bit of truffle, not just a hint--one of my least favorite things to encounter when promised this divine treat. This was a really satisfying dish, although I would have enjoyed a bit more pancetta. Seemed a bit scarce.3. Pan-Seared Chilean Sea Bass in a tomato white wine sauce. This was topped with toasted pignolis and served with a parmesan risotto, plus two negligible asparagus stalks. The risotto stole the show! This cheesy, truffle-hinted, veggie-speckled rice was creamy, smooth and needed no additional help to brighten up my hectic week! I actually, exercised incredible restraint by only eating half of and leaving the remainder for my leftovers the next day. MMMMM. The sea bass was flaky and had a nice thin crust on the outer layer. This dish was one of the specials for the evening and I wasn't originally certain that this was what I wanted for dinner, but the risotto and our server's very positive attitude about it made me curious. I stand by my choice. 4. After feeling that there was no way on earth we could possibly make room for another morsel of food, we decided to consider that the dessert menu might feel left out if we didn't at least give it a peek. Choc-a-holic that I am, (and considering the medicated cookie dough that was a prequel to dinner), I suggested to my aunt that there was no harm in SPLITTING the chocolate souffle with vanilla bean gelato. The gelato was decent, but nowhere near the best I'd had, and the souffle could have been a touch warmer. It was served with one lonely strawberry and s sprig of fresh mint. It was a 4-star dessert. I would love to give this place a second try and see if the peach/blueberry cobbler is as amazing as it sounds. I'd recommend to anyone who wants a taste of great Italian food.

This is the kind of coffee place I don't want to tell my friends about because it's SO good and I want to keep it ALL to myself. The space is charming, lots of seats, free wi-fi, and dapper dressed baristas. The decor sets the perfect ambiance to write, read, or meet a good friend. I'm obsessed with their chai lattes (iced or hot). I haven't tried the food yet but I've seen photos of it and it looks mouth-watering. If I wasn't fairly low in funds at the moment I would find myself there every day!

Tanoshi has long been on my list of omakase places to try. Despite all of the good things that have been said about it and the high grade fish, the restaurant itself is unassuming and low key. The sushi bar seats 10 people and there are three sushi chefs, one for each corner of the bar. This was on the side we were on (they have 2 storefronts). The omakase is $65 per person and it includes 10 pieces of nigiri, one handroll and 3 small sushi rolls. While the omakase itself may be reasonably priced - there are a lot of items available for a la carte that can rack up your bill. There are two lists on the wall of the appetizers and the add on pieces and a hand drawn map of where all the fish is sourced from. We ordered the Chawanmushi, the Ikura Uni and Ankimo. The Chawanmushi was delectable - the texture was silky smooth and there were pieces of chicken, shrimp and peas inside. The Ikura Uni was basically a sandwich composed of salmon, squid and Uni and boy was it a generous helping. In fact, I think there were more parts of Uni than salmon. The ankimo, or monk fish liver, is a must have. The texture can take some getting used to but it is definitely one of my favorites. The omakase began with fluke. The fluke was delicately sliced with an interwoven technique and it was the perfect size. Next, we had the Alaskan king salmon, seared in propane for a few seconds. Salmon is one of my favorites, so this was very enjoyable. One of the more exciting pieces was the Amber jack fish topped with a cherry blossom leaf. The leaf was edible and extremely fragrant. I also really enjoyed the firefly squid - something I've never tried before. While the rest of the pieces were delicious, I think it's important to discuss the add ons. The normal sea urchin that Tanoshi uses is from Maine. It is absolutely satisfying but for sea urchin connoisseurs, you will want to order the Japanese Uni - which is from Hokkaido. Another must try piece is the Triple X - salmon roe, sea urchin and quail egg. This piece is absolutely exquisite. My friend tried the ice fish. This is poached - which we did not know beforehand. There was a novelty about this but we probably wouldn't order this again. Instead, I would have tried the crab brain. Shout out to Geronimo who really made our meal! We talked to him throughout our meal and he was very knowledgeable about all the pieces.

"Fancy" was made to be played here. Paintbox is like a pink unicorn -- glittery and girly, fancy and fun, lavish and luxurious. Definitely not your average, neighborhood nail salon -- it's a treat. I had a gel manicure with design yesterday, and was super impressed with everything from the moment I walked in to the moment I walked out.I suppose I'll start with the staff -- they're all sweethearts. Both receptionists and Yolanda, my nail technician, were friendly, welcoming and genuinely sweet girls. Even though it was my first time here, I walked out feeling as if I had been coming here for years. Also, one of the receptionists -- unfortunately, I can't remember her name -- refilled my champagne glass every fifteen minutes -- thank you! (...I was loving the champagne almost as much as the manicure!)The actual service -- my manicure -- was amazing! Like, really, really, amazeballs amazing. I loved Yolanda, she was the perfect combination of talkative/quiet -- like, you don't want to be sitting in silence, but you want to chill out and relax. It's a fine line, if you know what I mean. I had the Electric Feel from the Spring/Summer 2015 Collection. I love, love, love it -- it's my first time with foils and, it's safe to say, I'm foil-obsessed. They're just so pretty -- I can't stop looking at my nails! I was also very impressed with the nail preparation -- I'm (very!) picky when it comes to my nails and she did everything perfectly (i.e. shaped, buffed, clipped, etc.)Price-wise, it's not too expensive, but of course, that depends on who you ask. For me, someone who regularly gets a gel manicure with design, it's "normal." But, like I said, it's for when you want to treat yo' self -- have a glass(es) of champagne, lounge and remember to do the mani cam!

I have nothing but big gay love for this place. The ice cream creations are so much fun. The unicorn on the wall really makes me happy. Beware of coming here on summer weekends because there will be a line around the corner and this location is a hole on the wall... a very lively hole on the wall. I love the Monday Sundae with some rainbow sprinkles. The American Globs is my second favorite and I usually get the cone lined with Nutella. Don't eat the Bea Arthur on a windy day, specially if you like what you are wearing, because the Nilla wafers will take over your body like glitter does to a drag queen's. Worth it, tho a layer of Nilla wafer crumbs won't look nearly as glamourous as a layer of glitter. You should get the Salty Pimp if it is your first time here. The Salty Pimp will make a believer out of you. Don't forget to get a punch card, because you will come back and getting FREE ice cream once after 10-12? hundredth? times lol is such a glorious thing. Always check and try the seasonal soft-serve flavors like coffee, nutella, coconut, cinnamon toast crunch & etc.

THE DENNIS SYSTEMD- Demonstrate Interest. Make sure to get to Parisi somewhat early in the lunch time so they don't run out of cutlets or bread!E- Engage Physically-Once you've ordered and have The Dennis in your hand, you gotta get your mouth around this bad boy. There's three chicken cutlets, balsamic vinagrette, Mozzarella, Prosciutto, and Tomatoes, and sandwiched between two amazing slices of bread. Parisi's bread is used at other places across the city, because it really is phenomenal. N- Nurture DependencyYou're going to need to nurture this bad boy for a while, as it's a HUGE sandwich. It's the size of my forearm, and I'm a pretty beefy guy. N- Neglect Emotionally.By this, I mean you need to neglect the fullness that you feel when you've only finished half. There's still a ton more sandwich to go, and you need to neglect that feelings of insecurity and self doubt that one naturally gets when faced with sandwich this 'tootin delicious.I- Inspire Hope.Believe in yourself. You can eat this other half. S- Separate Entirely, Go to the nearby park to eat it, or possibly eat the other half later. The sandwich is big enough for two meals.

In a sea of sushi spots, Mocu Mocu provides a much-needed shot of fresh Japanese flavors in Hell's Kitchen. Coffee and bento boxes? Yes, please. Did I mention they've got booze and sweets? That's a winning combo I haven't seen in the neighborhood since Kyotofu[1].Their menu isn't complicated, but the way the menu's presented at the counter can be. If you're a first-timer, the choices can be a intimidating. Ask questions, and the welcome staff will steer you in the right direction.Their baked okonomiyaki makes for a satisfying lunch. I went for the pork belly, which went well with the oshinko pickles. The accompanying white bean and pork sausage miso soup was my fave, hearty, with light spices. On the side salad was a citrus-y vinaigrette that I couldn't get enough of.Stop by the library next door, grab a book, then swing by Mocu Mocu for a latte and snack[2]. Bring a friend, bring a date, or bring your family.[1] Anyone else remember them?[2] Use common sense and don't loiter for hours.

What can I say that everyone else hasn't already said?I'm a foodie. Like, I live, breathe, and dream of food. I go out to eat every single day and sometimes twice or three times a day. My guilty pleasures include: (you guessed it) food.A friend of mine had suggested that we go to 11 Madison Park for quite some time. Alas, just a few short days after they were named the 5th best restaurant in the world, we decided to make a reservation and go all out.I will start off by saying that I truly enjoy food "experiences". I love 5+ hour meals, tasting menu's, cocktail and wine pairings, you name it! I feel that this is lost in the modern age of dining as usually people want to get in and get out. Not me and not 11 Madison Park. Don't come here if you want a quick meal or really anything less than 3 hours. Don't rush. Don't panic. Relax. Woooooosa. It's okay. Sitting down for a great length of time and trying out heavenly dishes isn't so bad, trust me!DECOR & AMBIANCEArt deco/former bank. To be honest, I'm not really a fan of art deco or bank "decor". I would just say that this isn't my style. However, a great deal of people LOVE the decor here so it's really just a matter of preference. The ambiance is great as it just oozes elegance. Everyone is dressed from head to toe in pure perfection. One word: Classic.SERVICETop-notch. Would you expect anything less? The service was absolutely perfect (and usually poor service is my greatest pet peeve at restaurants). Bravo!FOODWhile I've had some truly exceptional meals in my lifetime, this one was definitely in the rankings. Every dish was obviously very tasty and delicious but I was particularly surprised by the creativity behind each dish. At the very end of the meal, chocolates were presented with a little guessing game. Many different flavors were presented and one would have to match the unknown flavors to their names. Later, someone brought a cheat sheet and provided the correct answers. I really liked this as it just seemed like a really fun way to end the evening.Will I be back? Yes. I want to come back and try their lunch actually. MMM MMMMMM MMM!Come here expecting not just a meal but an experience.+ Also make sure you ask for a tour of the kitchen! It's immaculate!

I really bask in any opportunity to be pretentious and feel socially superior while sipping on expensive cocktails surrounded by waiters wearing sleeve garters working in an astounding event space lined with sumptuous mahogany holding up shelves of unread leather-sleeved books.That's actually my ideal bar.Having to face the bitter reality of walking outside to the concrete cityscape and going home to my apartment which features significantly less mahogany and an illusory number of ritzy bartenders ready to get loose was an all-too-necessary reminder that I should leave the NoMad to special occasions.

I was informed of this place last year, but it was the one in Williamsburg. Not being a fan of the boroughs, I never really made it out there. Luckily for me, anything in the boroughs can be found in one form or another in Manhattan.After a trek through Chinatown, I stumbled across this place.For starters, it had air conditioning on a really muggy day, so that was a huge plus. The bowl of bacon was what sparked my interest in the first place and I finally got to try it. They serve it with maple syrup... it was DIVINE!Drinks are well priced and the bartender was very friendly.Best part about this place is the clientele. You'll see everything from lawyers to college kids, to old Chinese men, to tourists looking to get away from Canal street. The location is very strange since it is a very white establishment in the middle of Chinatown. Highly recommend it and next time I'm there, I may stop in for more bacon to go with my bubble tea!

I am obsessed with LYFE Kitchen. I've been going here at least once a week. The food is delicious, fresh, and healthy. I love that the calorie counts are listed for all dishes (and drinks). My favorites are: Art's Unfried Chicken--the sauce on the brussels sprouts and squash is finger licking good (i actually want to lick the plate clean...) and the breaded chicken is juicy and flavorful and the goat cheese and mushroom pizza is also excellent--the crust is superb. The space is quite spacious and inviting; however, this seems to lead to the entire restaurant being nearly empty every time I visit. I'm concerned that they're not doing enough business to stay solvent. People really need to find out about this place because it is an awesome fast casual option where you don't need to feel as guilty about enjoying a delicious meal.

People get so excited about ramen, but I never really understood the appeal until I went to Totto Ramen. A few years ago, I went to Ippudo and thought, OK, Ramen can be very good, but was not blown away. A couple of weeks ago, after a play, we tried Totto. I was in shock how insanely delicious the soup was...hands-down this was one of the most delicious soups I have ever tried. The service was great too. The music was beyond horrible; it was almost as if the owner was making fun of us by demonstrating that he could play the worst music ever, and yet we would still wait on line to eat his soup. Part of me felt like a detainee at Guantanamo Bay being exposed to enhanced interrogation techniques (I did not break). I was going to leave 4 stars because they would not give us a container to take home the unfinished portion of soup, but I just can't...the soup was that good.

Total yoga n00b here. Didn't even Google positions or watch videos before taking my first class. Loved all 90 minutes of it!I signed up via Classpass - which is a godsent for indecisive people like me. It was a Basic class with Erin Teufel on a Sunday afternoon. I had ZERO yoga experience and had to look around the entire time to avoid looking the part. The class was well-paced for beginners, with Erin focusing her attention on everyone getting into the correct positions. In a way, it felt like a private yoga class in a room of 20 people practicing downward dog!I loved the class so much, I quickly booked my second visit! If you're hasty about joining in because of inexperience - give it a go one Sunday afternoon. You won't regret it...even on Monday when you're sore.

After three different feasts here, I've gotta weigh in. I'm pretty shocked that a place sitting on the infamous St. Marks gauntlet can be so authentically executed. Every staff member I've encountered there has been extremely professional and respectful. The decor is cute without being cliche, and yet still classy. Even with people clustered around the door waiting for tables, they somehow manage to keep the atmosphere cozy and not too crowded/loud. This in itself is a huge feat for this area of the East Village. I originally stopped in to try the xiao long bao (soup dumplings). I've now tried all variations- crab, wasabi, super spicy, and kung fu (regular). They are all delicious, but be prepared to have your entire mouth on fire with the super spicy. I have never met my match in spiciness until I put those in my mouth. Don't get so distracted by the xiao long bao that you don't try other things. Some musts: pork knuckle soup (amazing), the leek with pork, spicy eggplant, peashoots, wood ear, and mapo tofu. There is some controversy amongst my dining friends about the mapo tofu- The Bao decided to make it vegetarian, and some people insist that it would just be so much better with pork. Let's be real, most things are, but I still think it's pretty delicious. This is one of the few Chinese places that I feel like I could visit again and again and still discover new delicious things. Also, you can tell they don't "cheapen" the dishes by just adding MSG or corn starch. You leave the table feeling satisfied but not sick, heavy, or comatose.Bao down, b*tches, East Village vicious!

I'm a big fan of their original restaurant Malatesta, so I was really excited to hear they were opening a sister restaurant closer to home.Spaghetti Incident does not disappoint. We had two arancini, a naked woman salad, the carbonara and the salmon & aparagi pastas. Everything was delicious, but the salad was fan-fucking-tastic!It's super small inside - I counted 30 seats. It's going to be hard to get a table here once people find out about it.I probably shouldn't post this review...

"I have something important to tell you," I said. I cowardly turned away and concentrated on the glass of water in front of me. "What is it?" he asked. I stayed silent. The place hummed with murmurs and clinks, but the weight of my confession-to-be dampened those sounds. "What is it?" he repeated. "Is there someone else?" he pressed on. I couldn't look at him. A drop of water dripped down the side of the glass at an impossibly slow rate. "I may have to leave you for this smoked Arctic char." I felt his stare."It's okay. I was considering leaving you for the roasted duck."The droplet rolled onto the cool white tablecloth and vanished. -----------------------This was one of the best dining experiences of our lives. Even though the executive chef is moving to the Whitney, I'm sure both the food's quality and the service will stay the same with the passing of each season.Likelihood of another visit:Duh.

I really love Earl's Beer and Cheese; it's such a great spot for this area. Straddling the Upper East Side and East Harlem, Earl's gets bonus points in my book for its proximity to the Metro North underground/above ground transition. Transit nerd pro-tip: If you wait to watch a southbound train go by, you can wave to the conductor, and he'll most likely wave back! I was way too excited about this interchange.So the latest big news is that they have EXPANDED! This tremendously popular place is no longer the size of a thimble. There is now an open back room with I think 5 more large tables, so I no longer have to restrict my visits to summer off-hours.I've tried a few things on the creative menu, but have settled on the mac and cheese, which always allures with its creamy decadence and sprinkles of rosemary. I also like Earl's Taco, which combines slow cooked meat with flecks of Mexican cheese, a cabbage slaw, and a delicious hot sauce. The taco comes on a scallion pancake, which I think is brilliant, and lends a uniquely satisfying texture and thickness to the dish.There are a lot of faux-hipster/creative/foodie restaurants (Supply House, I'm looking at you) on the Upper East Side that don't deliver, and are merely trying to cash in on a trend, but Earl's Beer and Cheese is the real deal.

Such a nice, cozy place for drinks and dinner. Decorated like a speakeasy, this place has loads of charm...chandeliers and sconces, black and gold wall paper, leather booths, black and white photos on the walls. Great beer selection here, but also good fruity cocktails too. I had the Ommegang Belgian and it was delicious. The food was surprisingly good too. The eggplant and BBQ chicken flatbreads were delish, everyone at the table loved it. The pepper appetizer, crab cake and the tagliatelle were all really good. We came early so we got spoiled in the beginning, having every server serve our table. Good and friendly service. Check out the Jack and Jill bathrooms. Overall, I really enjoyed my experience here and would highly recommend.

I have to tell you, after the trying experience I had at another establishment this week, tonight was a breath of fresh air. Hubby and I made reservations for my girlfriend's birthday weekend. We were late, as per usual but Angel, the manager, greeted us and accepted us in with open arms. From the moment we walked in, we felt welcomed and my girlfriend and her boo were already at the bar sampling some of their amazing cocktails. The dining area is intimate and the decor is sexy. This is a perfect date night spot. They sat us at our table and we were overwhelmed by the menu items. We ordered the Calamari, Short Rib Arepas and Hamachi Ceviche for our apps. Let me tell you that I've never had calamari with maduras (sweet plaintains) but OMG they were amazeballs! The arepas were bomb as was the hamachi dish. My girlfriend and her love ordered the Parillada to share, which included Ribeye, Chorizo, Morcilla Arepas, Short Rib and Bone Marrow...yes. Bone Marrow. Hubby had the Arroz con Pollo and I went with the Paella de Mar. Everything was spectacular. While we ate, the table next to us was also having a birthday celebratory dinner but the birthday boy went to the bathroom right before they arrived at the table with his dessert and sparklers. When the staff realized what happened, they quickly grabbed everything, went back to the kitchen and presented the birthday boy again. They kicked butt in the customer service department. The wine list is a perfect size. They have a nice selection. We went with an Albariño and enjoyed every last drop. When it was time to surprise my girlfriend with her birthday dessert, they also hooked us up with comped champagne. I have to tell you that they made us feel like regulars, despite the fact that we've never stepped foot through their door before tonight. The night was a total success and we had a very special, intimate, tasty and wonderful meal.Thank you, SO MUCH to Angel, José and the rest of the Yerba Buena Ave A staff! You guys did an AMAZING job and made our night the best #YerbaBuenaNYC

A bonafide, awesome cocktail bar in the East Village, Dead Drop is a must-try on the cocktails bar list. This is probably one of my new favorite speakeasy spots, next to places like Angel's Share and Little Branch. Admittedly, I would hate to reveal too much. It is a spot to check out though if you want quality service and very well made drinks, a low-key, sexy yet simultaneously casual atmosphere. I will say in short that there is very little to dislike.Located inside the North River restaurant in the East Village, go down the small set of stairs upon entrance. A button on the wall will call for the hostess, who should open the door promptly. It is first-come, first-serve basis, so obviously you will want to come earlier than later if you want to avoid the wait. Not a very large place, but accommodates just the right amount of people for a good night's crowd without being obnoxious. I love the red walls and the dark, intimate, and super cozy atmosphere it creates. Two bartenders man the tiny bar at the front, but this tiny bar has a lot to offer. What is great is the breakdown of their menu, which displays 'Yet To Be Classified', 'Recently Classified', to 'From the Archives'. Under these categories is the classification of 'Lethal' and 'Lively'. Lethal, is of course, the stronger of the cocktails. Lively is the refreshing/lighter ones. I started off with a lethal Red Orchestra (Gin, Kumaru, Maraschino, Cherry Brandy, and Celery Bitters). This was an excellent stiff cocktail yet not peaty and smooth to the last drop. Second drink was the classic yet lethal Martinez from the archives (Old Tom Gin, Sweet Vermouth, Maraschino, Boker's, and Orange Bitters). Again, while it was a lethal martini, it was very tasty and easy to take down with each sip. Service was excellent too, as one of the bartenders/servers was very helpful in providing input. I will definitely be returning to Dead Drop soon. Bring a friend or two, a date, and you should not be disappointed. Do not be shy going for the lethal cocktails either. They are all tasty and will be worth it in the end.

Steve Cohen must be a smart cookie. He has a degree from Cornell, sports rimless glasses and a three-piece suit, and his expression exudes intensity. But I will remember him most as a gifted magician who captured my full attention during his amazing 90 minute show at the Waldorf last year.I didn't expect the show would be at a fancy suite in the hotel. And I didn't expect I could watch him at such close quarters. While I managed to snag front-row seats, the performance conjures up the intimate setting of 19th century parlor magic regardless of where you are seated.  Steve's portfolio of tricks included Think-A-Drink--a tea kettle that produced five different drinks, all at the audience's request, and also mind reading (really?), and cards. If you are not averse to spending almost $100 a ticket on a magic show (note: I have a great interest in magic), I would strongly urge you to experience Steve's show at the Waldorf. It is money well spent!

This place is literally 3 days old. I stopped in tonight to check out the Hester Nights that is at the Klimpton Hotel and well this stand caught my eye. Ever since I went to Hawaii, I am always on the prowl for a good poke. Sadly, in New York, those places are hard to find. The next big food craze hopefully is Poke on the East Coast. The owner was really nice and he told me that he used to hang out a lot in Hawaii and he would surf and well eat poke. Cool! I am glad he brought this to NYC. The poke bowl I had tonight was made from yellow tail tuna and it is from Fulton Market up in the Bronx. Did you know that the Fulton Fish Market is the second biggest fish market behind Japan? Good to know.So I had the tuna with shoyu, it comes with some flakes of seaweed, spring onions, and pickled onions. I also asked for additional topping of masago (roe) and toppings are additional 50 cents. You can also get jalapenos, kale, avocado($1) added on top. Oh and there is a choice of shoyu vs. aioli sauce, white or brown rice. And for $9.50, I walked away with a very delicious, healthy bowl of poke! Let's make this place famous and a staple to NYC good eats!

Edward will take care of you. He's a shoe surgeon. I have these hot pumps with metal heels. It was starting to unscrew and the heel stub that needed cobbling continued to come off. He took the shoe apart and repaired it from the inside out!. My sexy Nordstrom pump was repaired, renewed. It experienced a rebirth. Thanks Edward!

$1 pizza in NYC are for those people who are too lazy to microwave their own frozen supermarket pizza. If you notice, they all pretty much taste and smell the same- all days, everyday, when ever you pass by them.I definitely can't say that here! Just walking in; the scent of fresh baking pizza fills the rustic decor of this tiny pizza establishment. And MOST importantly, the pizza here is like eating a fresh out of the oven Lombardi's pie! This is New York style pizza at its finest!Lovely fresh tangy tomato sauce, perfect crispy thin crust, and gooie tasty cheese! There is seriously something different about this $1 slice that made me do a triple take in one seating! I recommend just a plain slice and avoid the toppings- their greatness resides with the basics- crust, sauce, cheese!The owner reminds me of the soup Natzi: but he's truly sweet at heart. He knows lots of the regulars by name and has a strong following. All I got to say, I am so glad I live far from Percy's Pizza, otherwise I would be eating here every day!Now stop reading and just grab another slice! You will thank me later!!!

WOW! This place really impressed me. I work a short walk from this fast healthy restaurant but since its not on the way of my commute this was the first time I passed it as I was going to another store. The Taco Tuesday with Tacos $2.50, Beer $2, Wine $4 I was sold on it because with those prices I gotta check this place out.When I walked in you can tell it has a very family friendly trendy ambiance going on. You walk all the way to the back where someone prepares the food fresh in front of you. The ingredients they use is really fresh as you can see from my photos and they prepare it very quickly as well. I got a Chicken taco and an El Pastor taco which we so delicious and exploded with flavor! After it was prepared I payed at the register where I got two $2 beers which were Smuttynose IPA and Sierra Nevada IPA now don't get too excited they were smaller glasses but still a great deal.My co-worker and I took our food and ate upstairs and thought about how awesome this place was and we boggled why there weren't any people coming in after work for drinks and tacos. We will definitely be back with more people.I think the owner can make a few updates as well with advertising on the taco Tuesday sign outside by explaining that these are specialty tacos and that the beer isn't cheap bud light it is craft beer.

This place is definitely no secret but the restaurant is hidden like one. Sakagura is located in the basement of a building. Once you walk into Sakagura it crazy how the restaurant went from 0 to 100. It feel like you are walking into a restaurant that located in Japan. The quality of all the fish is amazing and the portion is definitely enough for someone to get full off of. From looking at the picture we had to order the Sakagura: Lunch Tasting Course. We decided that the Sakagura: Lunch tasting course will be out appetizer. Then we also ordered the Una Don($17.00) and Higawari Set ($11.50). Sakagura: Lunch Tasting Course start off with a appetizer with 5 kinds of sashimi. Then came the main course of assortment tempura (shrimp, white fish and vegetable), Grilled Fish, Beef Fillet Steak, and Cold Handmade Soba. (Cost: $33) The freshest and best tasting sashimi that I have had in NYC. The beef fillet steak was really amazing and something I would just order by itself next time. The shrimp inside the shrimp tempura was huge and not just tempura. I think that the Sakagura: Lunch Tasting Course makes a great appetizer for two so that you can try a large assortment of food. The Una Don was huge! This is probably the first time that I was unable to finish my food at a sushi restaurant. For lunch the Una Don came with a full serving of Eel in a large bowl of rice. The rice and eel was both covered in eel sauce which was amazing and tasty. We also ordered the Higawari Set which was a part of the valentine week special that Sakagura was offering. The service is amazing. The waiter was very attentive and was on point with refilling water and tea. The waiter also informed us on what part of the the sakagura lunch tasting course was placed on the table. I highly recommend this restaurant and I can not wait to come back!

Holland Bar is narrow, crowded with random but interesting customers, old, not very pretty, with cheap, good drinks served by charismatic bartenders. In other words, it's the perfect dive bar.Don't expect to find a seat, bring cash, stand, drink, converse, and enjoy the juke box.Holland Bar keeps it simple, just the way I like it! :-)

Finally I made it out to Seven Grams Caffe after hearing about it long ago and not making it into the Elite Event prior. Seven Grams is actually pretty close to my apartment, but I've yet to make it out here during times that are reasonable to drink coffee and not be awake til 3am unable to sleep.Faced with either cold brew or iced coffee for my cold coffee choices, I went with just a regular iced coffee because I always get scared about cold brews - I've had far too many cold brews where the coffee is just sour. Bleh. The barista also told me if I wanted a less acidic taste that I should go with iced coffee. The decision was a good one - some of the freshest, not so bold, yet not too watery iced coffee I've had for a while. I'm usually a fan of Gregory's Coffee iced coffee and this one comes out even or even tops it. I also like that they offer simple syrup - a small little thing I wish other coffee shops would do... the worst thing is getting all the granulated sugar at the bottom of your iced coffee.Will definitely be returning.

Well. Talk about a completely different experience.I first visited the Gowanus Dinosaur BBQ. Read my review... I wasn't particularly pleased. And to be honest, I really wasn't willing to try again even though I said I would. It's a schlep. But when I got a last minute notice that The Jewbadours were going to be at this location in Harlem.... I jumped out of bed and rushed over about 1/2 hour after the start of the show. I figured what the heck, if they're done, at least I can get something to eat. I'm so glad I did. Yo, seriously Halem Dinosaur... you need to talk to your sister Gowanus. She's making y'all look bad. Everything I had a problem with there, was perfect here. Dinosaur's greens are always great. Exactly like homemade. No stems, great spice, only thing missing is pieces of ham hock. The Chicken (dark meat)/Ribs Combo was perfect. Came from the kitchen hot enough to still be warm while I was too busy recording the Jewbadours playing. And the Mac & Cheese! How could it be so different from the one in Gowanus??? The best one I've had in a long time. I had some hiccups with service, but since I'm proactive and not a person who complains all the time (really... I don't!) the thing that tipped the experience over to 5 stars was the Jewbadours. I live for live music. Live for it. So the fact that there's a little stage over by the bar with regular live music will definitely get me to come back. Even if it's just for drinks (if the pina colada machine is working next time I will be ecstatic. See... I don't complain...).The two ladies next to me were ready to throw their heyzelekh at the stage. They were killing all the Blue-eyed Soul standards of the 70s. All of them! Hopefully Yelp will actually upload my video this time, but it doesn't do them justice. They're pretty much touring the Dinosaur BBQs in the city, but I'm coming back to the Harlem one if they play here again. Are you listening Harlem Dinosaur? Harlem loves "Sara Smile" and "Baker Street". Harlem wants "Steal Away" & "What a Fool Believes". Harlem needs it. Keep up the good work!

This is one of the best deals in the city, hands down. My go to is the shawarma chicken in either a wrap (which they make right before your eyes) or a pita, with fresh hummus (no extra charge!), carrots and corn. They have a ton of sides/veggies to add to your salad, wrap, pita, or plate, and I've never been disappointed. For less than $10, you have a protein packed lunch or dinner that's filling and delicious. Everything is made fresh, and you're in and out in about 5-10 minutes.

The evening was coming to an end. And some nights, you wish could just last forever. Enter Rin Thai as we debated calling it an early night. However, sometimes one has to feed an insatiable hunger before calling it quits.Walking in 15 minutes just before the kitchen close was of no consequence. Our waiter was courteous, friendly and attentive without being intrusive. We enjoyed the comforts of the Talay fried rice and the Tamarind chicken. Not being a huge fan of Thai food, I must admit that I was actually shocked at how well both dishes were executed along with their presentation. The Talay fried rice contained a delicate balance of seafood which was tender, well seasoned and only slightly spicy. I quite gladly bypassed their drinks to savor all of the complex flavors. With hesitation I contemplated trying my company's Tamarind chicken. I was afraid to throw off the wonderful balance from my palate. But I am glad I didn't pass up the chance to sneak a bite of that crispy, savory-sweet tamarind chicken. The bathroom was spotless and beautifully decorated, along with the rest of the space with a serene Zen theme. I would recommend Rin Thai for small groups or an intimate date.

Let me tell you about my only vice, ice cream.The ice cream here is so good it gets 5 stars even though literally the entire menu board says "Coming Soon" (Sundae, Soda Float, Ice Cream Sandwich, Cold Brew, Cone, Topping).Normally this would be extremely frustrating, but what they do have more than makes up for it: 11 flavors of top quality, inventive, unique, fun ice cream, served by two of the most pleasant, genuine, and friendly ice cream shop owners in existence.I've tried Ice & Vice a handful of times over the past few years at places like the Astoria Flea and other events around Queens, and have been eagerly awaiting the opening of this new shop in Chinatown (which, by the way, is really looking up now along with Mission Chinese Food and Pies-N-Thighs right nearby). I was actually excited to find out that they also just started selling their product out of the Little Muenster stall in Hudson Eats, which is another major win for the extremely ice cream deprived neighborhood of Battery Park City.The abundance of flavors makes up for the lack of cones or other vehicles for trying them, as they are so complex and fun to try, that it works in just a cup. Milk Money and Basic B are two of their most incredible flavors, which I had the pleasure of getting from Little Muenster last week, so on this initial visit to the shop I had to try 6 other flavors (I know, I have a problem). Look at how unique the ingredients are in some of these:- Shade (Smoked Dark Chocolate, Caramelized White Chocolate Ganache)- 9AM (Vietnamese Coffee, Donut Truffle)- Movie Night (Buttered Popcorn, Toasted Raisin, Dark Chocolate Flakes)- Nuts of Wrath (Marcona Almond, Grape Kool-Aid Jam)- Three Little Pigs (Salted Caramel, Bacon Butter, Bacon Praline)- Mahjong (Jasmine Tea Leaf, White Peach, Peach Lambic)Those first 3 flavors blew me away. Each was more incredible than the other, and I couldn't decide which was the best of the batch. The last 3 were much more of an acquired taste. You really need to like bacon to enjoy the Three Little Pigs, as it super bacon-y, and you really need to like the taste of alcohol in your ice cream to enjoy the Mahjong. I'm not the biggest fan of these two concepts in ice cream, but they were still delicious actually.This is an amazing addition to the neighborhood, and fills a major ice cream void as well (all we really had previously was Chinatown Ice Cream Factory a little further north, and maybe Mo II Gelato for another good option). This is definitely my new go to in this area, and I am excited to see all of the stuff coming soon.

i'm hardly thirsty cuz i know the benefits of staying hydrated. and i ain't no scholar, despite my leagues of green ivy strollzzzzzzz.any/s/ways....the Scholar is a chill bar that isn't divey but has that divey charm and an air of non-pretentiousness. the Scholar does three things well: low prices, great service and cool environment.the key to any good time there is taking advantage of the above three and bringing non-entitled fun people there...it's that simple.i've been here a bunch as i am a ghost (just not pale yo) within the East Village. the bartenders are good with the banter and conversation--and superfriendly. they pour mean stiff drinks and generally have various beers at a great price. buybacks are NOT dead here! they occur fairly regularly here if you are nice, well-behaved, and not a dick...which mean means i never get buybacks (doesn't matter...i steal my friends drinks. zzzzz.). the happy hour special here can be a fairly generous one for the EV. and i believe they buy pizza around 6 or so for bar patrons and then it's a free for all for those saucy cheesy carbs. this is a good group hang place. after work. post-drunk-brunch conduit. or a place to hang with your bestie/gf/bf/etc. the decor and layout is open space. dimly lit. copper bar top. exposed brick. lowkey decorations. there's flatscreen/s for game watching. it's a good place to fade to the shadowy drunk recesses of your mind. hadropkicks mic so i can two fist these PBR tallboys that my friend bought (i mean i stole from them). smoooooth criminali out.

Freemans was one of the first and most memorable places I visited in NYC right before moving there a couple months later. I was looking for a place to have brunch with my family for my birthday and was drawn to this place in particular because of the lovely rustic decor and the fact that it was "hidden" and off the beaten path. I will never forget turning a corner and walking down that very unassuming urban alley that leads to a tiny rustic entryway. One minute I was in New York and the next I was somewhere much more remote. The interior is stunning. I am a sucker for atmosphere and this place really did a great job in that department. There is lot of warmth, wood, flora, and taxidermy. It's simple, rustic, and reminiscent of an old world hunting lodge or farm house. The menu is great and offers a nice variety of simple, hearty, American fare. Downstairs was a little more tightly packed, but we were seated upstairs, which was less busy and had more room to spread out since we were a larger group. The food was fantastic and everyone enjoyed their meal, adults and kids alike. The brunch cocktails were great as well, and the prices were very reasonable. I've returned one other time just for drinks downstairs. Unfortunately, that time the service was not very good because our bartender was not very nice, but I won't hold that against them since my last experience was excellent all around. I would recommend Freemans for a variety of occasions. It's great for brunch with friends, but at night I would imagine it is super romantic and, therefore, would probably make for a great date night spot. I can't wait to come back for dinner!

So good, so good! The sweet milk cream had us so excited after we finished our large bowl that we promptly went back for a green tea round of seconds. Will definitely be back. Would love to have egg pudding as a topping option!

Saeed's food is AMAZINGLY good and really complex! Plus I love how he cares so deeply about his food. I haven't had a chance to dine-in bu bf rode his Citi Bike down to the shop to get us some Persian goodies. We had the famous thick winter veggie soup, which was so fresh and wonderfully home-made. It had a lot of flavors going on but all came together nicely: spinach, dill, noodles, crispy garlic (especially this, yum!) and then some. We also split the stew of the day which was an awesome shredded chicken dish with very royal rice and sour cherries. I love how the menu changes often because I believe any kind of experimentation coming from this joint is a good one. $20 for both items and healthy portion sizes, too. There is something special going on here for sure.

Best place for new dim summers! I've been coming here for about 20 years and have brought many new comers along the way. I promise you that it will impress! The place is massive with a big escalator bringing you to the large banquet hall, which is actually used as an event space and sectioned off for weddings and such. It's size, atmosphere, and food are all very impressive!When you are seated, you will receive a card for your table that servers will stamp when you order a dish that is small, medium, or large. As the servers push the carts by, you will see an array of mainly southern Cantonese style small dishes. You will point out which you want, they give you the dish, and stamp your card. Easy as that! When you are stuffed and cannot eat anymore, take that card and head to the cashier by the escalators to pay your bill. Tip is left on the table. Food! here are the staples that we can't dim sum without:-ha gao: (shrimp dumpling)-Sui mai: (pork dumpling)-cheong fun: shrimp in think rice noodle)-(spare ribs on thick rice noodle)-wu gok: (fried taro)-cha Siu bao: (roast pork bun)-lo Mai gai: (sticky rice)-Dan tat: (egg custard tart) for dessertFew other quick tips:- Cantonese call dim sum "yum cha" which means to drink tea. So when your tea runs low, take the top of the teapot and tilt it. That will let your servers know it's time for a refill!- there is a buffet style setup along the long wall that will have your more interesting food items. We're talking snails, stomach, fish balls, and also some killer veggies- get here before 11:00 to avoid the rush!!!my only complaint is that they recently started trying to jump in on the NYC boozy brunch scene by offering a bar cart with mimosas served by Americans. Don't get me wrong, I'm all about the boozy brunch, but it unfortunately makes this place a tad less authentic

Maple Bacon cookie? Yes please! Red Velvet cookie? Yup!Green Tea cookie? Hell Yes.Cookies & Cream cookie? That's a given.Chocolate Duet cookie? Duhhh.Chocolate Chip? I think I'm going to need another box...The cookies here are amazing. They're freshly made, soft, and super decadent. Indulge those taste buds and practice your willpower. I apparently have none. More cookies for me!

F irst of all: blown away by the whiskey selection!L ovely collection displayed beautifully along the wallsA nd really the entire interior really well decoratedT he overall feel is old fashioned, classy, and funI ntimate seating and more open area both availableR eally impressed by their knowledgeable, friendly serviceO ur waitress totally knew her ish, and was awesomeN o question went unanswered with her, and we had lots!R ather happy with my 'World Tour' flight of 6 whiskiesO rdered cocktails as well, which were perfectionO verall, could not have had a better parlor experienceM ost definitely coming back; already made a reservation!

I'm almost torn to write this as I'd love to keep this hidden gem all to myself lest it become the next hot commodity that takes 2 months of planning to get a reservation at.Domodomo is probably my favorite discovery of 2015. I'm always on the lookout for great Japanese spots and am surprised that the opening here didn't get more fanfare. In addition to being able to order a la carte, Domodomo offers what is probably one of THE most reasonably priced tasting menus in New York: 1. 6 courses for $302. 8 courses for $45 3. domokase 10 courses (+5 sushi pieces) for $68I got the last option,which I thought was just a little too much food, but as always my eyes were bigger than my stomach. Highlights included the truffle chawanmushu, jumbo oyster, eel and katsuo sashimi (comes with an awesome mango salsa). The one noticeable item that isn't on any of the set menu's is the uni pasta, so next time I think I'll go with the middle option and pasta to share.One of my main gripes with Asian restaurants in general is that dessert is often forgotten about, and every restaurant will offer some sort of green tea ice cream or cake and call it a night. So I was pleasantly surprised with the hojicha pudding, which had just a hint of sweetness and a great smoky flavor.Edit: they now also offer a sushi course! It comes with edamame to start, 8 pieces of sushi, a crab handroll, an eel handroll and dessert for $55

What a wonderful wonderful place to go to for brunch!I have to admit, I'm not big into going out for brunch, because most places I have been to have just been a disaster, and it was just cheap and disappointing. But off a drunk late night whim a.k.a. great idea when you're drunk but terrible idea to try to wake up sober/hungover....it was definitely something memorable!I made reservations (drunk the night before) for 4, and a 5th person decided to join us last minute, which they were able to accommodate for about 12:30.There was a good crowd still, and yet it seemed like the service was fully concentrated on our table, and only our table.The food was impeccable, the trout hollandaise was the most perfect combination of crispy, creamy, salty, that I have had. It sounded so good that 3 out of 5 of us ended up getting it. YUMMMM!!The escargot were piping hot, perfectly seasoned, not overly salty. Perfect accommodation to the bread basket that they kept on bringing. The oysters, unfortunately were out of a few types but we ended up trying other types that were fresh and delicious as well.The bloody mary's were made with love, garnished with pretty lemon, lime, celery, and even olives. And they weren't stingy with the alcohol, definitely hangover cure! I even tried my cousins mimosa and is was made with fresh juice as well.And I guess my cousin has been there before where she said hi to the owner, and he must've overheard that it's her birthday brunch, so he sent us over free dessert and coffee as well.Just a wonderful experience and even though this was about a month ago, it was such a great time that I remembered it just like it was yesterday! HIGHLY HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!

The Quick: A fantastic hole in the wall spot for roast pork over rice with cabbage for $3.50 which is so tasty. If you don't trust me, trust the line down the block at all times (moves quickly).The Details: As with all my favorite hole in the wall restaurants, I like to be very upfront right away. There are no chairs in this restaurant, it is take out only. This is actually a good thing because the line is always down the block (full of locals) and yet it moves quickly. We just walk to the park near by to enjoy our meal outside comfortably. As far as I know there's only one or two options on the menu, and the staff speaks very little English. Just get whatever everyone else is getting because it's cheap, it's greasy, and it's delicious.This place deserves its 5 star rating based on quality of food for the price. It cannot compete in venue, atmosphere, or presentation to a more expensive restaurant. However the food is extremely good and the flavor profile is different than your average meal. In this price range it's a great alternative to a fast food chain and more filling than a slice of pizza. My boyfriend and I split the roast pork and the 5 dumplings from Prosperity Dumpling for $1 (see my other review) and felt very satisfied for a late lunch. The Damage: Under $4 for a full meal for one.

Who is the Duke of Luke's Lobster? Well I am the Duke and I enjoyed every last step that brought me to this point. There are a lot of choices. Actually there are a lot of great choices. I'm an economist, and therefore concerned with the cheapest way to get the most diverse flavors in my mouth at one time.....'A Taste of Maine!' Give me a half of all of your three rolls and then throw some extra stuff in! That's how you take a visit to Maine in a NY second. The lightly toasted buttered roll buns grace the nicely chilled lobster, shrimp, and crabmeat, all of which is in itself buttered with a delicious garlic dressing soaked throughout. The texture of the meat isn't rubbery, but fresh also.Well Luke decided all that wasn't enough. So he added in a couple claws for a couple more dollars because he's that type of guy.(sigh) To be frank, that description isn't really doing the best job of describing what Luke is selling. How do you describe 'love' to a person who has never experienced it? See what I mean? So that brings me to my suggestion/solution.TAKE YOUR TAIL OVER TO LUKE'S LOBSTER AND GRAB A ROLL, OR TWO, OR THREE. Then again, just going for a visit to Maine isn't a bad idea. And if you're rolling as a duet, and not solo, make it a Noah's Ark (A Taste of Maine x2 w/ a $2 discount). HaHa

Iconic. A "must" when you're in New York. I'll keep it short because I know you'll visit. Katz's is good at any time of the day. Whether it's leftovers for breakfast, lunch or dinner, Katz's is amazing. I used to take the F train all the way from Jamaica, Queens (sometimes by myself #fatgirlproblems) just to get a sandwich from here. It's that good. Some of my favorites: Pastrami, Katz's Cheesesteak, Katz's Cold Sub, the macaroni salad, and the knishes. Order any of these (or all) and you'll be super happy.

Very nice. Came here with my boss and got the Crunchy Tuna after he recommended it. Service is really quick and efficient here and they're also very kind! Food is unbelievably fresh and I can definitely see why they're busy around lunch hour. It's located in the basement of The Atrium for those who cannot find it. Although I loved the tuna, the bread was a little hard to eat in my opinion. Perhaps it's because I just suck at biting bread but if it were on a panini or something easier to bite, it would be my all time favorite sandwich. The tuna is perfectly mixed with veggies like carrots and peas giving it that "crunch". It helps to break up that tuna-y taste that sometimes gets old pretty quickly. Portion is also pretty filling and it's $8.75 for fresh ingredients. What else could you ask for?? Try this place now!!

I've had many of special moments at this place. You can't go wrong on anything they offer. But the cookies are the best, and I may or may not have had tasted all of them. ALL OF THEM, in one single sitting....Tip #1: Come super late, and if you're lucky--they give you free desserts. Doubt this is part of their policy, but most definately has me coming back at the wee hours of the evening. Not even sure if this counts as real tip. *shrugs*P.S. I especially enjoy the fact that I can come here at any hr of the day since they're open so late. So late night after drink cravings are always satisfied. =)

I recently took advantage of the opportunity to see One World Observatory prior to its actual opening. I was excited from the second I chose my tour time. Everything here is very organized, the entrance is separate from the employee entrance (which is smart) and there is staff EVERYWHERE to help you along the way. I promise you cannot and will not get lost. Once you're inside, you go down the escalator, they check your ticket, and you go through TSA-type security. Be prepared to take off your belts and empty your pockets!Once you're through security, you wait for the elevator that everyone has been talking about. It's no joke. You get to the 102nd floor in a matter of seconds and on the way up you see the city being built from farmland to what it is today. Your ears will also pop at the end. The 102nd floor has a small theater where you watch a quick visual of NY today and there is a little surprise at the end (I won't give that away). You eventually make your way down to the 100th floor which has 360 views, meaning you can see the city, Brooklyn, Staten Island, Lady Liberty, etc etc. Tons of photo ops on all the floors! Even though it was overcast when we went, you could still see pretty far out.There is also the Sky Portal which you can walk on. It looks like you could fall through at any moment so it's a bit of a mind f*ck but it's awesome nonetheless. There is also a restaurant and a gift shop (which I disagree with but whatever). If you want to see a beautiful building and experience pretty much all of NYC, you should definitely come here once it opens on May 29th. Also the video in the elevators going down IS totally different and if you typically experience motion sickness, this might not be for you. Overall, a fantastic way to spend an hour or two.

I have passed Yuca bar many times and never really looked at the menu until my brother pointed it out once. This place is ALWAYS packed on the weekends and for a good reason. My first experience here was on a Tuesday where for $34 the two of us ate way more than we can handle. They have half off tapas but the tapas are larger than what you would expect. We got two orders of guacamole ($4.50 on tues) which has about a cup guacamole, a cup of salsa, and a huge basket of chips... So all that times two, calamari ($5) which was HUGE-- looked like two orders at any other restaurant, yuca fries ($5) which are AMAZING but are not on the half off menu, Latina salad ($8) which was also not on the half off menu but it was a really good portion, and a diet coke & a tea which was A LOT of food for the price.The second experience I had here was MUCH better even though the first visit was still good (and a really good deal). I came here with a couple of friends on a Saturday night around 7:45. We got drinks at the bar ($7 for tequila on the rocks) while we waited for only about 5 minutes for our table. We got guacamole ($9), taquitos de pescado ($13), salmon ceviche ($12), and pulpo ala plancha ($12). The high lights were the Taquitos and the ceviche. I definitely like the dinner menu a lot better here and you can still get the happy hour discount since it goes until 8pm. It is usually packed but there are a lot of table and you can always get a few drinks at the bar while you wait.

1st time coming here was recently on a Friday around 5pm. As soon as I walked in I fell in love with this establishment. I sat at the bar because I was meeting with friends for drinks. My bartender was extremely sweet and attentive. I never had to track him down to order a drink. He was ALWAYS on top of it. I believe his name is Jamison but don't quote me on that. I ordered the shrimp dumplings which were great. I love dumplings so anytime I see them on the menu I have to order them. This place fills up fast after 5pm. This a great spot to grab a drink after work if you work in the Flatiron district. I would consider it a chic or trendy bar. Upstairs this establishment has a wine bar that I did not get to check out BUT WILL upon my next visit.

I actually didn't try any soba here! But their yakitori and other food here is surprisingly good.Yakitori: I tried the liver, shishito peppers, gizzard, chicken skin, and all were cooked really well! They could've just a pinch more of salt, though. Smoked mackerel: SO GOOD. I've always loved this dish but it's really good here. The fish is juicy and fatty and full of smoky salty goodness. Had to get another order.Zaru Tofu: I really like this, but some people might find this a waste of money. It's light and creamy and comes with ginger and salt, but I like it plain.Grilled Squid: Nicely cooked, not overdone, and tender.Takowasa: The takowasa at Hagi was always my favorite but this one tops it! It has a ton of flavor and just the right amount of wasabi (I like it spicy). I liked the radish mixed into the octopus. Also, the octopus was fresh.I love the ambiance here. It's not super crowded like other yakitori places and the service is attentive. I'd say it's a little more high end here compared to others.

I'm here every other week. I am a museum person, and let me tell you something: no other museum in the world compares to this.Everything is organized chronologically. Everything is organized neatly and symmetrically. Everything is taken care of with utter diligence. There is a department for everything, even for lighting. This is my favorite place in the world. Go up the grand stairs. Make sure to don't miss out on the Egyptian and Roman wings. Look at the wonderful Van Gogh paintings; they are thoughtfully placed with the Gauguin ones. Enjoy the Picassos and the Monets too. Don't ignore the period rooms. make sure to visit the American Wing, but don't ignore the Tiffany fountain or the Tiffany Arches. Take it all in, there's something for everybody. It is a public museum for those who didn't know, you can request to see a piece of art they have in storage and they will show it to you. It is also suggested donation put always add a buck or two from what you were initially planning to give it takes a lot to keep such an institution running. Have you ever seen a Da Vinci sketch, up close? The museum will be open late until 9 (they say) on Friday and Saturday, but they will start closing the galleries and guiding people out earlier, so let's call it 8:40ish. There will be live music and the Great Hall bar will be open. They have a good selection of wine and cocktails. They offer wine flights for $18. The rooftop bar is open, but it's a weird ambiance with the fake grass and overpriced meh drinks. The views are great.

Summary: Siggy's is a terrific spot for comfort food with gourmet flare, smoothies and juices, and a menu that offers something for everyone but that'll make vegans and vegetarians especially happy. If you've been to Siggy's original Brooklyn location, the menu here mostly overlaps with the one there, but the space here is maybe two or three times bigger and more stylish. Though the original location is cozy and a swell space to eat in, the new Siggy's feels more refined, somehow more like a restaurant. You could come here with friends or family, but it'd work for casual dates too. All the produce used is organic and, maybe more importantly, all the meat is sourced well (e.g. the beef is pastured). Infinite plus points.Misc details:* The macaroni n' cheese is excellent. The whole wheat pasta has more body and feels more substantial than plain pasta, and the cream & cheese sauce turns your mouth into a gooey wonderland. My friends and I split this four ways and had it as an appetizer.* The soup--black-eyed peas, tomatoes, and celery--was equally great. It's a daily special, but if you like hearty vegetable soups and this is available, you'll like this.* Salmon burger w/ feta on brioche--solid. They were two sizeable patties side by side, and they paired well with the feta, smeared onto the toasted bun. I liked this but I hear the turkey burger here is phenomenal, and the beef burger is all pastured-beef (as is all the beef served here), and I was left wishing I'd maybe tried one of those.* The raspberry tart! As with the BK location, this is the best dessert. It's crispy, tart, sweet, and leaves you impressed that it's vegan. It's not huge, but big enough to split two ways easy, or even three or four ways, if you want more of an amuse-bouche-y dessert.* Siggy's has a small selection of organic beers--the Pinkus wheat lager is sweeter than most beers, but if you're okay with that it's a very good hefeweizen.* It's also the sort of place that has theme-appropriate political flyers up in the bathrooms. Did you know that Monsanto is suing Vermont because Vermont passed a law mandating all G.M.O. foods be labeled as such? I did not know this but I do now. Now, you might not worry about genetics and crops, reasoning that it's silly to worry about any such thing when we're all doomed anyway, what with the seas rising and the advent of the AI overlords nearly upon us! So you might just go to Siggy's to enjoy wholesome food before that happens. And that's okay. The politics don't get in the way of the eating.

On Thai Avenue, how do you differentiate yourself?First of all, hire a SWAT team that can deal with regulars and troublemakers alike, and empower them to entertain and excel - Jesse and Mai work at their bar and always remember me, even though all asians look alike.Second, focus on your distinctive characteristics. At Viv, northern Thai dishes were the exception rather than the rule, but with recent revisions to their menu, Viv is expanding into an area that isn't well represented in Hell's Kitchen.For best results, get anything on their menu preceded by their tom pakard jew - it's so savory it's not funny.

There is literally no pho place in the area and i was soooo happy when they finally opened one, bc as an asian, i eat pho:- when i'm sick- when i'm cold- when i'm dieting - when i'm craving warm soup- when i'm hungry in generalThe pho here is actually soooo good (noodles slightly undercooked the way i like it, and soup is cinnamony, fragrant, and savory), and the even better part is, the food here other than pho is good as well!!! I just got back from visiting Vietnam and was on a Pho Ga eating binge, and this place opened right in time for me! woohoooo~

If you read ONE review of this place, this has to be it.One word: Omakase.Listen up white people! Take a seat and take notes.I couldn't believe what I saw when I walked into Neta. My friend advised me that Neta was an amazing sushi spot to go for Omakase and so after my 4-day juice cleanse was over, I ventured on over to Neta.I walked in and saw all white people! WHAT? I looked at my friend and asked if he was sure that it was that good! Not just white people...white people eating rolls. Rolls?! WTF. Likely they were freakin' California rolls! I was definitely not confident that it would be a great meal. I'm white and listen, there's nothing wrong with white people eating at awesome sushi spots but I was just taken aback as usually when I go to "authentic" sushi spots, there are not many white people at all (like 1-2 max).I was also surprised to see a mixologist behind the sushi counter in this small little bar area. He made me a great cocktail with soju vodka, yuzu juice, peychaud bitters, and simple syrup. It was quite strong and different but very tasty. We ordered the omakase (chefs choice) that had 8-ish prepared/cooked dishes to start (can't remember), followed by 10-ish courses of omakase sushi. I forgot the exact numbers but whatever, you get the point.Are you ready to start this magical journey with me?Prepared dishes:+ Leek soup - This was like straight out of a 3-Michelin starred restaurant. It was so well presented that I felt terrible actually eating it. Honestly (see attached photos) it was ridiculously good.+ Toro Tartare with caviar + White asparagus salad with miso tofu, scallion purée, quinoa, and pickled radish+ Miso glazed seabass+ Raw fish kara age+ Wok fried lobster with miso and lotus root********+ Wagyu beef with king mushrooms - I swear I almost damn near fell off my chair when I ate this. BEST PIECE OF MEAT I HAVE EVER CONSUMED IN MY ENTIRE LIFE. Do I need to repeat this? Make bold letters and stars when you are taking notes about this. Legit, the best. It melted in my mouth.*******+ Mochi rice (risotto) with uni and truffles - Is this for real?! Seriously. Come on guys, you can stop trying now. The sushi pieces were quite heavenly as well. Very fresh and VERY good.We ended with the peanut butter ice-cream (THEY MUST HAVE KNOWN THAT I AM OBSESSED WITH ALL THINGS HAVING TO DO WITH PEANUT BUTTER) and I can definitely say that I was in heaven. For a good 2 hours, I was sitting in heaven.Neta definitely ranks within the top 2 sushi restaurants in NYC in my book and I have been to pretty much all of the top sushi restaurants in the city. YOU MUST GO and also make sure that you sit at the counter and get the omakase. Trust me, it's worth every penny!

Threw my big 30th birthday bash at The Winslow and I couldn't be happier with how it turned out! Pros:* One of the nicer bar lounges on 14th street with an elegant, warm, and unpretentious atmosphere. * Winslow is perfect for large parties- I reserved the semi-private room in the back that can hold up to 35 people max. When 65 people ended up coming, the room obviously became super cramped so many ventured out into the main bar space, which was totally fine. If I were to do this again with the same number of people, I would reserve the 1-2 additional tables right next to the semi-private room. * The best part about The Winslow was the excellent service.
