Unlike similar lounges like Stanton Social or Verlaine's, The Winslow is one of the few, if not only, slightly higher-end Manhattan bars that do not require an initial deposit, a crazy minimum charge, and one or limited tabs for parties. They also offer open bar specials, but I decided to go with the easier cash/credit bar! * Keiran, one of the managers, was so nice and easy to work with. He always replied to my emails promptly whenever I had any questions. When he mistakenly informed me the Happy Hour ended at 8PM (when it was 7PM), he still kept his promise for my group. They were so easy-going that they let me re-arrange the furniture in the semi-private space. Rory was sweet and friendly, and all my friends were happy with how quickly he came back with our drink orders, especially when he was our only server. Throughout the night, both Kieran and Rory made sure to ask me how my friends and I were doing. * The food here is delicious! I ordered several party platters (which you order 2 days before your event), which my friends loved! The winning hors d'oeuvres that night were the Pigs in a blanket, Goat cheese and fruit compote, Deviled eggs with crispy bacon, Grilled cheddar and tomato sandwiches, and Smoked Salmon Crumpets. * The Winslow is known more for their gin cocktails. I gravitate towards fruitier and sweeter drinks, so I loved the Garden of Eden $11 (Gin, St. Germaine, Lime/Lemon). Happy Hour Specials:Cocktail of the day - $7Gin and Tonic of the day - $7Draft beer - $5Wine - $5Post-Happy Hour:Cocktails - $10-$12Beers - $5-$8Wines - $8-12* During busy nights Fri-Sat- they had DJ sessions starting around 10PM. The electronic music was fun and not over-the-top brash like dubstep. * My GF surprised me with a birthday cake, and without any extra charge The Winslow added big sparkers on top and brought out plates and cutlery for everyone. Kieran and Rory, thank you so much for making my 30th birthday so fun and easy!!

I am a HUGE fan of Brooklyn Industries! Their clothes are comfortable, hold up in the wash, look great, and are decently priced. I have a few really great pieces from them that I pair with pretty much everything in my closet. Their sales are pretty awesome right now: buy 1 get one 50% off. I was able to get 2 jackets for the spring and some comfy spring/early summer cardigans and sweatshirts.By the way, I got my boyfriend a jacket, a button down shirt, and a sweater from here for Christmas, he's been hooked on them since then as well!

Holy moly, I need a bigger stomach for my trips to this neighborhood because goa tacos is added to my must-eat list!Paratha tacos are so smart! It's a large, buttery, flakey and chewy shell encompassing all the good qualities of naan, Chinese scallion pancake (minus the scallion), and phyllo dough. It's crunchy on the outside, yet chewy enough to sop up all the delicious juices without falling apart.I got the lamb shoulder, which comes with tzatziki sauce and eggplant salsa. It was total perfection: the shredded lamb was tender, juicy, and flavorful (garlic baby!!), while the sauce gave it a decadent, creamy component and the salsa a fresh crunch. Although it was a single taco, I was quite satisfied after finishing it. If I didn't have upcoming dinner plans I would've wanted to try all the other tacos!My tastebuds are still salivating from the taco as I write this review. Go there before it gets too packed!!

Japanese-style crêpes are still very much alive, kicking, and trending. It's Spicebox Crêpes's balance of quality, price and location that gives them the nod for our overall rating of 4.5/5.0This crêpe concept first landed in L.A. around 2005, and made it's way to NYC in 2013. Spicebox opened on Pell St., in the heart of Chinatown in October 2014, so they're still relatively new to the neighborhood. They have (reportedly) 5 locations including 3 in Guangzhou (China), 1 in Guangdong (China) and this new NYC outpost.One can't help but draw comparisons to other Japanese-style crêperies, (Eight Turn, T-Swirl, little known Big Bear) and traditional French crêperies. The timely conical shape preparation, while not all that difficult to execute is still an art and thus difficult to master. Savory or sweet, there's sure to be something for everyone either for breakfast, lunch, or snack to be shared. Made to order on-premises, the price point is comparably in the $7-10 range.I ordered the "Tokyo in a Bite" (Strawberries, red bean, green tea ice cream, pocky sticks, yogurt, chocolate sauce) which was easily my favorite of the whole menu, and "Piece of New York" (Blueberries, cheesecake, jam, whipped yogurt, house Nutella) and while these are different in their own right, they're just as tasty and fresh as their counterparts they're named after. They're Light, flavorful, and portable with their own handheld, tear off cardboard container to consume it in. The ingredients are fresh and complement each other well within the crêpe.I've also ordered a cappuccino or two and know that they offer a perfectly acceptable blend of standard coffee. This is actually a great place for me to duck into to get my caffeine fix while everyone else queues up at the other cafes. By the way, the cup and matching polar bear sleeve are ridiculously adorable!The space is fun and inviting, with colorful adornments throughout, and detailed hexagonal floor-tiling. A chalkboard menu keeps the menu dynamic, and the wall of crêpes adorning the window is a nod to the Japanese fake food motif.I'd like to see if they add to the menu as the weather gets warmer. Parfait and frozen yogurt sound good to me but hopefully something unique, original, and insanely Instagram-worthy.Spicebox may be an underdog in this space, but they're the ones to watch, as I expect they may be adding delivery and catering options to weather the seasonality of their product and target small businesses, too. As I don't enjoy venturing into neighboring NoLIta, their location within Chinatown is perfect for me, and ought to help them capitalize on tourist and local traffic. Overall rating 4.5/5.0

Woke up one morning and felt like my right ear was stuffed and could not hear so well, no other symptoms. Being your above average neurotic, I went to google and read about sudden sensorineural hearing loss (basically, sudden deafness that comes out of the blue). Then spent an hour watching youtube clips of doctors removing bugs and other unpleasant things from ears. After a day or so, with no change, I decided that I should probably seek the help of an ENT. Went to Castle Connolly (see my yelp review) and started calling doctors.  Luckily, I was able to get an appointment with Dr. Rothstein the next day (he accepts many different types of insurance). After booking the appointment I starting reading patient reviews and was happy to see that they were practically all glowing. I thought to myself, what are the chances of being able to get a next day appointment with a CC listed doc who accepts my insurance and has universally excellent reviews?!Went to see the doc the next day. Great modern/clean office located at the NYU Langone Medical Center. Turned out, no bugs, just a little impacted wax that he gently removed (no pain at all). I will be the first to admit, I'm a bit of a doctor snob; stellar credentials and a decent bedside manner mean a lot to me. I also like to see doctors that have been PRACTICING medicine for a long time (but not too long). Dr. Rothstein exceeded my expectations in every respect. Not only does he have a good professional reputation, he is a heimishe guy who made me feel very much at ease. I highly recommend him if you are in need of an ENT.PS: The entire consultation I was thinking of this scene:  youtu.be/dwswnuTvSMIPPS: It is a great feeling to be able to hear perfectly out of both my ears again. This whole incident has made me appreciate and marvel at how our ears work.

This place! I grabbed a few magazines and an egg cream here. It was worth every penny, even if I did have to buy a chocolate bar to meet the CC minimum. The service has always been great, the egg creams satisfying. I've brought along other NY transplants who couldn't comprehend the idea of mixing milk and soda water. Now they are true believers!

Aire Ancient Baths...I am so thrilled I stumbled upon this place. Upon first walking in, we thought "wow, we are out of our element." The fancy lighting and interior design was beautiful but much more than we are used to. We checked-in and were given wrist bands that magically opens a locker. Lockers hold a bathrobe, towel and slippers so all you need is your bathing suit! What stood out immediately was how friendly, helpful and welcoming the staff was. There were women working in the locker room making sure we all knew what to do and they brought us down to the pools when we were ready. We thought it would be relatively empty as our time slot was 9-11 pm (!!) on a Tuesday night but it was full!Oh my dear lord...the pools. A salt water pool, a very hot pool (102 degrees), a freezing cold pool with ice chunks (53 degrees), a jet whirl pool, a pool in back that we called the "grotto" because it was hidden and dark and cave-like. And then the steam room - the most incredible steam room I've ever encountered, enclosed in a glass room with aromatherapy.We tried each pool quickly to figure out which we liked best. And then we had TWO HOURS to relax, float, and breathe deeply. Yes, as others have said, most people here are couples and people did seem to get very touchy feely, which might make some uncomfortable. I just ignored them and enjoyed myself. We had also booked 15 minute massages, which were wonderful and much too short, although I'm glad because that gave us more time to spend in the wonderful pools (massage time is included in your two-hour time slot).This is the perfect romantic date or special occasion celebration. It is very expensive so it's perfect for a treat. I had the best time and would recommend it to everyone I know. Book far in advance as they get quite busy!

In Parerga und Paralipomena, Arthur Schopenhauer relates a parable of porcupines huddling together in winter for warmth, inevitably pricking each other in the process. After several instances of this, the porcupines finally settle on a distance wherein their collective heat remains a resource (albeit less than ideally), but without the fear of being jabbed by one another's quills. This behavioral framework eventually became known as the 'Hedgehog's Dilemma' and a quote within the parable came to be known as an early reference to man's tendency toward isolationism. "A man who has some heat in himself prefers to remain outside, where he will neither prick other people nor get pricked himself."Rebelle and Pearl & Ash are sister restaurants, and, on first glance at least, should by the above parable be inextricably intertwined in their respective bloodstained quills. Yet somehow, in a separation of but a few feet, and while sharing a theme, the two restaurants remain distinct, and each serves to strengthen the other. Rebelle, on its conceptual surface, is the sort of inchoate culinary rebellion that entices talented chefs who tire of classical haute cuisine. It is not a renouncement of necessary skill, but, rather, a recognition of the creative possibility (and risk) of a greater degree of freedom. Serious food in a more casual setting. While some may roll their eyes at the idea of yet another Per Se expat using moderately larger tweezers to arrange moderately smaller plates, that isn't the sort of apostasy Rebelle incites or contributes to. Rebelle is instead the closest place to a New Wave Parisian bistro outside of, well, Paris. Bistros in Paris have gradually come to be reclaimed by a young generation of prodigious talents, seeking to deal less in faste, and more in fantasque. The man chosen to head the kitchen of Rebelle, Daniel Eddy, formerly the chef at Spring (in Paris), was unsurprisingly a figure of that movement. It should come as no shock then that a good number of the dishes are cleverly altered renditions of French culinary history and technique. Beets Bourguignon retain the earthy savoriness of the requisite mushrooms and subtle sweetness of the equally obligatory carrots, but treads on an altogether lighter plane, and rather than mentally prepare you for a long winter, it leaves you contemplating the approaching luminance of summer. In a nod to the almost fanatical precondition of acceptance of a bistro's quality, the pork headcheese is a showcase in charcuterie skills. Of the desserts, not ordering the cherry clafoutis would be a mistake. (Yes, they're done by a Per Se expat. No, you shouldn't roll your eyes.)Wine, much as at Pearl & Ash, is unimpeachable. As should be expected, the list at Rebelle skews slightly more French than its predecessor, in keeping with the theme. That said, the sheer breadth of obscurity, affordability, and amazing finds - French or otherwise - leave the list at either restaurant as unparalleled in the city. The by the glass offerings are reasonably priced and serve as a suitable lens through which to view the list, often featuring wines that don't normally see that sort of exposure. The sommeliers are much more well-versed in the 81 page tome than is reasonable, and like Patrick himself, are more invested in leading you to what you want to drink than in pushing trends. Rebelle, like its sister before it, is the epitome of what 'small plates' restaurants were envisioned capable of - cool, exciting, satisfying, and most of all, damned good fun. Vive la résistance.

Finally. Inwood has grown up, gentrified and gotten itself a good bar/pub. Stand aside, Inwood Local and Piper's Kilt. We now have a bar with good beer, a great atmosphere, great food, great service and more room than you could possibly want. My favorite draught beer: Dyckman Brew...a pilsner with some great flavor and a great glass to be served in.Don't miss Inwood's newest and best burger: the Truffle Burger. It will knock you out with flavor. Piper's Kilt needs to take down their "best burger in Manhattan" sign. They've been ousted. After a bunch of misses with new bars opening up (um...District 12 on Broadway), I'm so happy that there is a great place to call my own, just a few blocks from my apartment and way too close to the A train. I'll be here often.

For my 400th review, I can say Rainbow Room is sufficiently worth reviewing. After a five year renovation closing, Rainbow Room reopens offering a Sunday brunch buffet ($95) and Monday night a la carte dining with live entertainment. In regards to brunch, it was certainly one of the most fanciful, yet fun white tablecloth brunch buffets I have experienced. Although I can't take credit for setting one, a reservation will prove a bit of a challenge (taken 60 days in advance, with few openings in between).Foremost, the space is simply captivating. Located on the 65th floor of 30 Rock, you are surrounded by breathtaking views of the city. An adjoining room provides the views alone. Take this opportunity for many photos. Vintage chandeliers, mirrored walls, crystal curtains, a circular dance floor, plus a live band, adorn and surround a large, impressive space that resonates a slight touch of contemporary with predominantly classic. Soft, grey colored walls provide a neutral palette for the decorative elements of tastefully done glitz and glamour. On to the dining, there is simply too much that can be covered in words when it comes to their buffet. A 360 degree buffet, labeled and separated into sections, provides an immense variety. You should be here for a good few hours, trying a little bit of every thing they offer. The buffet consists of, but is not limited to, a raw bar, sushi bar, a meat carving station, charcuterie of cheese and salumi, breads, pasta dishes, Asian-inspired dishes, pate varieties, and truffle and grits. There is also a crepes and desserts station to the other side. They nearly cover all types of food. Some dishes were admittedly better than others. My favorites -- the crepes, risotto, meat carving station, truffle and grits, and pate section. We managed to try a lot, yet not all, within a span of 3 hours. Seated around 2PM, we were officially stuffed by 5:30PM. Note: Take your time. No one will rush you. Soak in as much of the experience, and try as much of their food. You might not get this chance too often.Rainbow Room is a truly landmark, classy establishment with much to offer when it comes to dining and atmosphere. Do not neglect to dress to impress. Hardly pretentious at all, as some may think. All in all, superb time at the Rainbow Room. I would undoubtedly return and recommend others to try.

Voilà is to chocolate what Yankee stadium is to baseball. The best chocolate comes here to be tempered and transformed, in many cases with your help, as part of an experience that is both unique and educational.Voilà is premium on all fronts--the venue is contemporary and features modern furniture, the chefs are well-pedigreed and know their chocolate, and the ingredients and utensils are all sourced with care. The brain behind Voilà is Peter, who (not playfully) has anointed himself with the title of 'chief cocoa nut'.You can choose to make chocolate bark, truffles, lollipops or bars. The chefs will adeptly guide you through the process and help package the end product. I duly consumed the two boxes of chocolate bark I made the last time I visited Voilà. Alternatively, you can simply buy their pre-made chocolate or visit the store to try their hot chocolate. Voilà also hosts corporate events. One cautionary note--try not to make nicer-looking chocolate than your boss.Do not miss this retail concept if you are visiting the Upper West Side, or if you live within a 100-mile radius of Voilà!

Already love this place. It's so spacious, and the plants and decor make it feel like more than just a coffee shop. It's definitely a great place to not only work, but also hang out and unwind. Even during the worst and coldest month in New York City, walking into this place makes me forget that it's even winter time. I was also enamored with the fact that they currently exclusively feature Cake Thieves Bakery's amazing vegan treats. Lauren of Cake Thieves is a sweetheart and I can't wait to try more of her baked goods - it's so hard to decide because everything looks phenomenal. The staff is enthusiastic and helpful. They offer premium oolong tea in addition to the great espresso, so there is definitely something for everyone. Say hello to Herb, which is the name of the plant on the end of the coffee bar.

Buddha Bodai is a vegan dim sum place with food so good you'll want to passive-aggressively slap yo' momma (vegans are typically non-violent). I normally come here with groups of 8+, and they are more than happy to accommodate us. Last time, for about 12 people and ridiculous amounts of food the total per person (incl tip) came out to 11$ each, and we had pretty much everything on the menu 2-3 times over.My two favorite things here are (in order):1) BBQ "meat" - tastes just like BBQ pork, even my meat eating friends since discovery come here without me and always order this. Trust me. Order. This.2) Croeller Noodle - Some sticky flat noodle thing around a semi-crunchy dough thing. What this dish lacks in description it makes up for in flavor.Buddha Bodai is a spot you should give a try once. I promise you you'll be back.

Finally after all these years I've found my people! As a Vietnamese-American used to having endless options in Houston, the lack of authentic Vietnamese restaurants was one of the things that made fully loving New York so difficult for me. In an admittedly diva-esque move, I literally left the last "Vietnamese" restaurant my friend suggested because it was way too Chinese (I couldn't even read the menu, the Vietnamese names for dishes were printed as some sort of subtext/translation to the Chinese name) and THANK GOODNESS I DID BECAUSE I FOUND THIS PLACE. For the first time since I moved to the city, I heard the waitstaff speaking my mother tongue. MUSIC TO MY EARS. We had the grilled pork summer roll (Goi Cuon Thit Heo Nuong) to start with. That's something I feel like you don't see on menus enough. The meat inside was actually warm like they had just grilled it right then. Then I had a Pho Tái, which was nothing mind-blowing (but still good, especially for these brutal NY winters). Their Chè Ba Màu is off the chain--shaved ice, beans, green jelly, and coconut milk, all topped with peanuts? What more could you want for a light, refreshing dessert? Best of all, THEY SERVE AVOCADO BOBA Y'ALL! Gosh Da Nang-it, why isn't this brilliant Southeast Asian move to make avocado sweet not available wherever tapioca balls are sold? I would say the only thing that isn't traditionally Vietnamese about this place is that the waitstaff is actually super friendly and the decor is great. There's really nothing bad about it. Now if only we could do something about the black ice and the summer smells, then I'd wholeheartedly love NY!

If you are into dressing up in vintage attire and fancy escaping into another world and era; time periods you may sometimes wondering about: "How would it been like living in Berlin or Paris in the 1920's ? When these two Cities were the metropolis of the world.....Being entertained by Anita Berber: Weimar Berlin's Priestess of Debauchery, or Marlene Dietrich singing to you at the Blue Angel. What a night out !!!Well just come and indulge in Ziegfeld's Midnight Frolic, and I promise you these fantastic performers will dazzle and travel with you in this time machine.Just make sure you will explore the whole venue, show and all the different stories which are going on several floors and rooms.For example in the interval go one floor up and behind the stage, there you will find Paris, where mayhem and mystery is waiting for you. I met Diana who carries roses spiked with wannabe cocaine, in Weimar times it was real in our time its baby powder....... we can't even smoke on the street..... BUT "the divine signature cocktails" created at the Paris bar will compensate you; the names alone for each cocktail deserves an oscar: naming a drink syphilis, that is naughty !!! All cocktails are made with fresh herbs, flowers and seductive ingredients. You must try one !!!Be prepared to walk around get involved and be curious! Simply don't be shy.Because you are walking around the fun as well is meeting other people in the audience, which you cannot do in an ordinary show where you are bound to your seat from start to finish."Ziegfeld is a big party of decadence."You will have so much fun, and so you must as the tickets are ranging from $80 to $280; the $280 ticket is VIP which includes reception, VIP balcony, dinner, drinks and this stimulating seductive show. It may sound pricy but it is not at all as it is an unforgettable experience and totally justifies the entrance fee.I soooooo recommend this show for special occasions like birthdays, engagement parties, double/single dates, group of friends, dressing up peeps, vintage lovers and just anyone who appreciates quality time.Sorry guys no pictures for this review, just go and see it for yourself...... I don't want to spoil your fun.

Quality Italian indeed has quality Italian!Gone three times now to this Midtown restaurant and every time I am reminded why I love this place more and more with each visit. My favorites are listed below but everything I've had has tasted spectacular! -Yellowtail Crudo $17 (Shishito Peperonata, Lemon): so fresh and delicious! The shishito pepper gives it a tiny oomph and the fish just melts in your mouth with the simple lemon dressing. -Dry-Aged Porterhouse Agnolotti $24: tender pieces of juicy steak wrapped up in house made macaroni. Probably my favorite pasta on the menu so far but I haven't had their lobster fra diavolo yet... Duhn duhn DUHNNNNN! -QI Baked Clams $16: probably the best variation of baked clams oreganata I have ever had. On each clam they broil on some pieces of capellini so they give the clams a tiny bit of crunchy texture. And to make things even more orgasmic, they drizzle on a delicious butter-lemon reduction sauce table side. Talk about a taste explosion! You know that amazing garlic bread they give you at the beginning? Save yourself a piece of this and use it to mop of the reduction sauce from this clam dish. You'll thank me later.Quality Italian Chicken Parmigiana (For Two) $29pp: think of it as a giant pizza pie-shaped chicken parm dish served with fresh arugula greens and honey with chili flakes on the side. Phenomenal. If you come with a group I highly recommend sharing this so you can all have a slice without dying from massive food coma.My favorite dessert option is the Cannoli Cart which is prepared tableside with tubes of fresh cannoli cream and freshly baked pastry shells. Every cannoli should be given to me this way! I also love the zagbaglione cream with fresh berries. Simple yet so good.Besides having delicious variations of your more traditional dishes, this place offers exceptional service. I love their wait staff! They are always so congenial and actually seem to enjoy talking to you about the menu and recommend dishes.If you missed my declaration at the beginning, I absolutely love this place.

I've been to Scarpetta at least 5 times during the last couple of years, and while I have certainly eaten at more inventive restaurants, I am compelled to give it 5 stars largely due to its consistency and the fact that I find myself back here time and time again. I have come here on a date, with friends, and with out of towners and parents. Reservations are not hard to come by if you are flexible with a 630PM or 930PM seating, and the location is in an easily accessible part of town.First off, the bread is not something to gloss over here. While at other places bread almost seems like a formality, at Scarpetta, bread is the first course. Their famed complimentary Stromboli, is served warm and with generous chunks of salami and mozzarella. I do not remember a single time when I did not ask for seconds and I admit I have gone to Scarpetta with precisely the intent of showing my dining companions how great it is.Appetizers are solid as well but if you are getting just one then it would have to be the Polenta. It is unbelievably creamy and the mushrooms add a great flavor to the dish. Scallops are seared well, but expensive at $21 for two small ones, and you are better off getting the Braised Short Ribs. Scott Conant is most famed for his simple spaghetti dish, which I tried on my first visit, but not again. Not to say it wasn't good, but I prefer the richness of the Duck and Foie Gras Ravioli, or the sweetness of the Short Rib and Bone Marrow Agnolotti. My boyfriend and I took my mom and her friend here two weeks ago, so we shared several pasta dishes, which I thought was the perfect way to try a bit of everything. The Foie Gras Ravioli in particular was well received by everyone.Mains are less exciting than the pastas but the Prime Sirloin of Beef is done very well and a good one to share. The Black Cod is not to be missed either.If you've left room for dessert, the Ganache Bar and Warm Banana Bread are both personal favorites. Service is attentive without being intrusive, and ambiance is beautiful. I definitely will be continuing to visit Scarpetta in the years to come.

I came here last night on a first date to meet up with for coffee. Sadly she was a little late and i had a chance to speak to the staff. Here's what i ascertained: - This wonderful little coffee shop is brand new at only a month or two old.- They make all their sandwich meats in house which means roasting the roast beef and all the chicken and what not - they're not using some boars head stuff - they do it all there so freshness is never an issue.- The coffee/latte's/hot chocolates are all amazing (i can attest i had the hot chocolate it was probably the best hot chocolate i had in a long time)Here's what i noticed:- This place is a somewhat of a hidden gem - with several large tables and a few small ones, it's good for hanging out for a few hours or just grab and go. - The tables are large comfortable - the smaller tables are for a pair or so.- It's nice and warm inside and pretty comfortable, although maybe i'd like them to have a little more comfortable seating. Ideally i'd like to come back, bring my laptop, do some work and look like a hipster in this coffee/sandwich shop. I intend to do that in the near future while working on whatever i need to do on my laptop when i have free time and need to get away from my apartment. I just wonder how the staff will take it. Plus i don't know if they have wi-fi and mind if you sit there and just buy a coffee and hang out.

Came for brunch and was going to come here again to really decide if I wanted to give it a 5. I thought about it and you know what? Yes.Everything here hit the nail for me (price, interior, food and service). $10 add on for bottomless mimosas, FRESHLY made pasta for $9. $9..for fresh pasta?! Yes, it surprised me. I found their lunch menu more interesting. You could also customize the pasta type. We ordered the Brussels sprouts, wild boar ragu with pappardelle, sausage and pepper with garganelli and eggs Benedict and of course, the bottomless mimosas. The Brussels sprouts were crispy and the pancetta, pecorino and fuji apples paired well. I probably could have ate 4 more plates of it! Next, was the wild boar ragu. The pappardelle was thinner than other ones I have had, but I actually liked it more like this. The wild boar also was not gamey at all, which was my initial fear when ordering it. It was similar to pulled pork in texture and delicious. My boyfriend ordered the sausage and pepper pasta which was also good, but actually, I don't like bell peppers. If you really love bell peppers, get that dish. I did not get to try the eggs Benedict, but it did look good haha...Service was excellent. They were very friendly and made sure to fill up our mimosas like water! Even after we paid, they encouraged us to stay and drink some more. Awesome.The only downside of this place is the portions aren't too big and their dishes are so yummy that you might end up eating two entrees! That's how they get you with the nice prices I guess.. I don't eat too much so it was the perfect amount for me, but I can see it being a problem to people with big appetites. If anything, get more appetizers..Yay!

*Credit cards accepted!My roommate and I were literally the first people in the new Xi'an at 11am this morning when they officially opened for business (with free noodles!). We're both ecstatic and mortified (there goes our diet) that this location is so close to home! Xi'an noodles every day!This location, compared to some of the older locations of Xi'an, is huge. The downstairs area hosts an open kitchen where you pick up your food, and at least 10 counter/bar seats to eat. This location even has an upstairs eating area complete with natural lighting through skylights (I've since learned that this area is closed unless the downstairs has run out of seating). There's plenty of space for everyone to enjoy their food and you won't have to hound people while they're eating to get a seat like the St. Marks, Midtown, or Chinatown locations. The ventilation here is also good and you won't smell like food for the rest of the day after eating here. Also, side note, this place isn't full of Xi'an propaganda, newspaper articles, and tv re-runs as the other places are.As with the other Xi'ans, my go-tos are"A1: Liang Pi - cold spicy noodles with gluen chunks - if you take it to go, make sure you ask for the sauce on the sideNS2: Spicy and tingly beef noodles in soupNS3: Mt. Qi pork noodle soup - diced pork with a sour/star anise soup baseNS4: Spicy pork noodles in soup**and anything in soup, really. The non-soup versions (same order number but without the "s") is good, but I always favor noodle soups!The hand-pulled (watch them make it!) noodles here are legit and it's hard to find this kind of al dente pulled noodle anywhere else in the city.PS: Take-out Xi'an never tastes as good as when you eat it in the restaurant. Except for the cold noodles.Cheers to Xi'an! This will definitely be my new go-to spot when I'm lazy to cook.

Hell's Kitchen is a new Mexican restaurant in the Hell's Kitchen, Midtown Manhattan (hence the name). The Mexican Sugar Skull art theme sets a trendy ambiance throughout the restaurant.We had large frozen margaritas with trio of guacamole to start; Avocado, Grilled Pineapple and Habanero Chile and Mint flavors served with tri color Crispy Corn Tortillas. It was a perfect appetizer to start the dinner with.We shared the Quesadilla Braised Pork with Jack and Cheddar cheeses, Cilantro and Salsa in homemade flour tortilla. We ordered two Tacos the Braised Short Ribs with Pumpkin Seed Guacamole and the Grilled Tuna with Romesco sauce and Almonds served with homemade corn tortillas with pickled radish garnishes.This place is great, with the right choices of background music and good custumer service. A bit pricey for what it is, but we will definitely come back for a date night!

I forgot to write a review for this new location since it first opened a few weeks ago because I can't stop coming here and eating doughnuts any time I am within a 1-2 mile radius of it.I eat a lot of doughnuts. I am pretty sure I have tried every doughnut shop in New York. After much research, these are without a doubt, the best in the entire city.After several stops at their stand at the Smorgasburg locations and at their original storefront in Bed Stuy, I have tried all of the many different flavors. They still seem to come up with new ones all the time though - I most recently discovered the filled Nutella doughnut for the first time here, and it blew my mind. This one and the other filled ones they have are smaller than the regular giant yeast ones, but pack even more flavor.You can't go wrong with any of these, but the Cafe Au Lait and Dulce de Leche are up there as the best of the bunch. If you love chocolate, then you will love my favorite ones, the Salted Chocolate Caramel or the Mocha with Crushed Almonds, which are so incredibly rich and chocolatey and gooey that you need to take a bath after eating them.You used to have to go line up at Smorgasburg or go to the remote shop in Bed Stuy to get your hands on these beauties, but now not only are they available at this much more accessible location, but are also showing up in nearly every coffee shop throughout both Manhattan and especially Brooklyn. They always seem a bit fresher from one of the storefront locations, but no matter where you get your hands on these, there's no denying how incredible they are.

The staff here is so wonderful. I came here on a Saturday afternoon, looking for a comfortable, non-pretentious place to drink some coffee (and, let's not lie, a mimosa or two); bum some free Wifi and work on a little blogging project; and hang out. I got everything I wanted and was tempted by some waffles along the way as well.At one point, I realized I'd had enough caffeine so switched to decaf refills. No problem. Then I ran out of battery juice and needed to plug in my laptop at the bar. No problem. Then when reaching for my mimosa, I knocked over the champagne flute and broke it, spilling the rest of my drink all over the bar. No problem. They were so nice, even with all of my bloopers. They'll be getting a nice tip and lots of return business from me, since I live right around the corner.

Always a treat. I grew up a couple blocks away and practically lived here during high school. I've seen many different things here, and the other night I saw a Lord of the Rings symphony while the movie played on a big screen above and behind the orchestra. It was so nice to be able to watch the movie and have the music played live. This is one of my top 10 favorite movies, and I'm so glad it was done justice by this performance. Every time I've been here though, whether it was for ballet or opera, I've always enjoyed the atmosphere and crowd. My one and only "complaint" is that you can't bring a drink inside unless it has a cap that you bought at the bar. So I had to chug my mimosa before going in and during intermission.

What have you done to me Dominique...I can't stop coming back for more. Ever since your cronut I couldn't stop thinking about it for 26 hours.I got a bit curious and had your other items, as always it gets my tastebuds excited. Your perfect little egg sandwich squirted all over my mouth and your frozen s'mores - I was licking every bit of cream off my lips. Your madeleines had me reminiscing Hong Kong egg waffles but they're 10x better. I ate every last little crumb, even the powdered sugar. I wanted to see what your DKA could do to me. It almost brought me to the edge but cronut will always be the one who takes it home. You always leave me wanting more and licking my fingers from your delectable desserts.You might be the worst thing to ever happen to my waistline. I can't deny it, I love it when you sugar me up. Next time lets do cookie shots together. Till we taste again. Delightfully yours, Virginia

With Totto Ramen right next door- no like literally RIGHT next door, this place has some major competition. Truthfully, I only noticed it because I was going to Totto Ramen and almost walked into the wrong place. I scoffed at the cahones of this place. Trying to compete with the infamous Totto Ramen? Pshh.. I felt sorry for this little fishAs a self diagnosed Ramen addict, I felt a duty to try Hide-Chan to see how it stacked against the rest, despite my allegiance to Totto. And you know what? It's now my favorite Ramen place in the city. First off, there's real seating here unlike Totto Ramen. I could have a real conversation with my co-worker, and didn't spend all my time trying not to fall of a stool. Ok, but in reality, those are minor details. I'd eat outside in the cold for a great bowl of Ramen. So onto the important stuff- first off, you have the choice of wavy or staight, extra firm, firm, medium or soft.Extra firm, wavy, spicy ramen with corn. Totto who? I had a new lover and his name was Chan, Hide-Chan that is. The meat was tender, the broth was rich, the noddles were cooked to perfection & the heat was just enough. Oh, and the wooden ladle is just fun to eat with. Bye Totto, Hello Chan.

I am highly impressed with how much pride these makeup artists take in their work! I was at the Yelp Holiday Hangover cruise last night and Pucker was doing touchups for free so of course I decided to sign up.I did not expect anything more than a 5 minute touchup - maybe some eyeshadow and quick foundation. Instead, I got a full-blown 25-30 minute session with Julio who took his TIME with me. He painstakingly made sure that I looked my best and didn't overlook any detail. I seriously felt like he was a true artist who wanted to create the best work possible. After he was done, I was blown away at the results. He made sure the makeup looked natural and even with my super dry skin, nothing looked cakey! I was so happy, I was compelled to give him a huge hug afterwards. Because of the phenomenal service I received, I will be most certainly coming to the studio to get my makeup done for my engagement shoot. I took a look at their website and they had very reasonable prices, PLUS complimentary access to a dressing room and shower! Oh, and did I mention they donate 2% of their sales to charity? Totally in LOVE with this place!

I barely give 5 star reviews for clubs. Just because there's always something to complain about when you're packed into a sardine can or the bathrooms are dirty or there's some gross guy trying to grind on you all night no matter how much you try to get away and there's no where to go. But I freakin love this place lol. The music is what gets me. The stuff you grew up listening to where they got the whole club turnt up singing that old school biggie song that everyone knows the lyrics to. Then they got that reggae stuff like mr vegas and every girl is droppin it down low and they don't care if you bump them cuz you drop it lower than them too. I didn't hear one song all night that I didn't love. Whoever the dj was is awesome!! And the drinks we're 9 bucks for well drinks. $10 for stolis. I was expecting 15 bucks to be honest. But the pictures make it seem like this place is huge! It's not at all. But who cares! I love the music!

When I moved to work for a new company, I lost my daily dose of Brits... but thankfully, Jones Wood Foundry is close by! This has become one of my favorite UES bars because it has great (albeit a bit pricey) British staples, a great selection of beers, and the friendliest and most engaging bartenders you can find. I haven't ventured further into JWF than the bar, so I can't (and won't) provide insight on the vibe/space of the dining area... but the bar is where you want to be, as it allows you to interact with not only the bartenders but regulars who frequent this watering hole.I've had the burger and the fish & chips and may I say, both are solid choices that are well worth the price. The (HEFTY) burger was juicy, well-seasoned, and cooked to a perfect medium, while the fish & chips was perfectly light and crispy. By far, the best burger and fish & chips I've had in NYC to date. Note that they give you malt vinegar to eat with your fries; my boyfriend asked for (and was denied) ketchup... JWF keeps it reaaaal British!Overall, a great neighborhood spot that has tasty food to be enjoyed in a friendly and relaxed atmosphere. JWF will see plenty of me in days to come!* Will update review with my British ex-coworkers' take on JWF pubfare, if/when that happens

J ust a tiny walk-in shop with a counterO nly a few seats, barely any standing roomL ove Stumptown's 'Hair Bender' blendL atte and mocha were both superb~Y ou can see what care he takes in each orderG onna be back here for sureO bviously pricier than Sbux/Bean, but worth it!A nd good selection of baked goods tooT hanks for the great service!

So I uh, met my significant other here for our first date. [Looks over at significant other sitting on the other end of the couch, his face bathed in blue laptop glow.]It went so poorly that there almost wasn't a date #2.[Stops smiling so he won't know that I'm up to no good on the internet again.]It all started at Bar Jamon.I arrive and see him sitting on a bench outside. Elbows resting on knees. Loose linen shirt billowing slightly in the breeze. Khaki shorts. Those ubiquitous fratbro Adidas slides. Not how I usually order my enchiladas, but hey.He springs up when he sees me. This is the second time I've ever spoken to him and the air is tinged with "first meeting" static, making even the people around us anxious and nervous.This is how we greet each other:Him: Hey!Me: Hey!Him: How are you!Me: Good! How are you?Him: How are you!i let his extra "how are you" linger in the autumnal air as we step inside the bar. The ambiance at Bar Jamon is what I call, "euro-fresh," because i'm an ugly fat-fingered American who lumps all the European countries together. It is lively but not uncomfortably packed, and service is easy and smooth. I like this place.We stand by the wall for no more than a minute, waiting for seats to open. Suddenly, an entire bottle of wine falls off its place on the wall and lands beside my plastic-shoed date.The bottle shatters, bleeds out on the floor, wet shards of dark glass blinking up at us.A server swoops in and cleans up the gruesome sight with nary a word of blame or disdain. Euro-fresh is the best kind of fresh!We are seated at a slim counter and order a responsible ("aka, meagre!" -21yo me) amount of wine. Red as a bodega macintosh.Polite conversation is had. No one is buzzed. Just two grown-ups living the euro-fresh life.We finish our wine and step out into the slightly frenetic fuzz that befalls Union Square at rush-hour.Bathed in the flattering halo of magic hour, we circle the block --my high-heeled boots syncopating with the flip-flap of his polymer slides.When we talk about this walk in the future, I will claim to barely remember it, and he will argue that it was the most shocking part of the date. According to him, without warning or provocation, I'd suddenly turned to him and said "Wanna see my fake tooth?" Then, before he could assert himself and say no, I allegedly reached into my mouth and pulled out one of my front teeth, glistening with saliva in the setting sun. He allegedly recoiled. I allegedly smiled proudly like a gap-toothed jack-o-lantern or a grizzled uncle returning from the Vietnam War.We circle back to the subway entrance at the bottom of Best Buy. As commuters stream past us like tiny slivers of fish, we solemnly recite the usual litany of declarations that conclude first dates."Well, I better go. Got class tomorrow!""This was fun, we should do it again!""Yeah!"We shake hands like businessmen, and I descend the stairs to the underground train that courses through this city, our city, bloody, unstoppable, veinous.A few days later, he sends me an email with a single attachment: a pdf of a New York Times article about dental health. I do not respond to this strange document production.And we do not see each other again for a long time.Autumn degrades into winter.Fools gather in Times Square to carry the year's disappointments into the next, counting down in unison to the slow and steady descent of a crystal ball.Winter loosens its grip on our throats and in its place, spring, summer's ugly sister.Pastel mannequins cheer on pedestrians as they lean into the rain with black umbrellas shuddering in the wind.Pant hems creep up two precise inches.And slumbering college students awaken to the sound of birdplay.It isn't until May that we meet again, in a parking garage in midtown east.[To be continued in my review of the location of our 2nd date...!]

IN SHORT: In a space along a street in Midtown that has undergone many a transformation in its lifetime, one can only pray that Betony, with its Michelin star food and service that makes you feel like you're sitting down for a meal in your living room, is here to stay for a while.THE STORY: In a world that seems to increasingly seek and embrace the singular superlative title of "the best thing I ever ate," Betony slips quietly into the scene with its purely extraordinary piece of roasted chicken. This chicken is undoubtedly the best piece of chicken in New York. Sliced in a slender triangle and draped with seasonal vegetables like celery root sitting over a decadent jus, the chicken is impossibly soft and tender, like none I have ever had before, managing to occupy a buttery chicken flavor so perfectly fresh and pure. At my most recent meal here, all four members of our party ordered the chicken, and all four cleaned the plate so completely you would have thought it had never seen food.While a taste of this signature dish should not be missed, several other appetizers and small snacks deserve almost equal praise. At the top of this list is the hot foie gras, served next to pork belly in a hot ham broth. True to the rest of Betony's style, this piece of foie gras seems so simply executed at first, yet the purity of flavors does not belie a handsomely silky, rich, and perfectly textured bite. The Radicchio Tardivo, with beets and robiola bosina is another creamy yet light addition to the meal. With entrees ranging from $29-$43 and appetizers from $11-30, Betony is fitting for a superbly special meal that doesn't have to break the bank like a tasting menu easily could.Service is incredibly knowledgeable and calmly prepared to please to perfection. For our bread course, the pastry chef even prepared a phenomenal piece of gluten-free bread for our resident allergy-ridden guest, and our server was able to tell us the preparation of every dish to astonishing depth. It's the kind of subtle hospitality that makes a delicious meal even that much more rewarding.Although it stretches across 3 levels, with the main dining spaces on the first and upper levels and a private room downstairs, the 80-seat space still manages to feel like an intimate private dining experience in one's own parlour. The two-tops and four-tops are larger than normal and spaced a good deal apart, giving each diner room to both spread out and cozy up in the plush, purple velvet banquettes and admire the ornate molded ceiling panels. It's a space that feels both personal and fantastically regal all at once.

The Quick: It's just so much fun! Prepare to get tipsy and bond with your new 30 best friends, while you laugh, participate, and do something different. The Details: We had the BEST time at Drunk Shakespeare last night and already bought tickets for another production the group puts on. You walk into this awesome room with walls lined with books and a giant thrones, completely transporting you into part of the skit. They immediately start you with a delicious shot, and from there the booze keeps flowing. It's a little pricey ($40/ bottle of wine) but worth it-- booze makes everything more fun. I suggest a light pregames to set the mood. The actors are talented and hysterical, honestly people you'd want to hang out with. If possible try to sit on the ground level because you participate more in the show and everyone becomes best friends. Be warned though you might be part of some ridiculous shenanigans that might not be great for a first date or for the prude at heart.It's a mix of modern pop culture, shakespeare, and all things ridiculous. It's something different to do in NYC, I highly recommend. The Damage: there is currently a deal on Yelp! For $35, I've also seen deals on groupon and I believe living social/ gilt. For a fun night out this seems like a good price to me.

Proud to be a Chinese-American: Before the rise in popularity of iconic modern day NYC restaurants like Union Square Cafe, Daniel, Bouley, and Peter Luger, Chinatown NY defined East Coast Chinese cuisine. Now if we discount San Francisco in the "Nation of California, " the 24 hour restaurants on Mott Street began to inspire the theme for the Tribeca Film Festival documentary: "The Search for General Tso." Asian cuisines have evolved as fast as social media in the USA, arguably becoming more American, and long-lasting than McDonalds. Certainly, the meteoric rise of Asian cuisines I would argue has defined the "Yelp Phenomenon." Anyway, as I have always said it is all about the food. With all due respect to my Asian friends, who prefer the many different Asian cuisines, my culinary tastes were defined by my parents of Toisan descent. While, I love the spicy influence of Thai, Szechuan, Hunan dishes, etc. my favorites have always been the old school Cantonese dishes. Hop Kee really defines the Chinatown Cantonese experience. It may not be as well known as Shun Lee, or even the more Chinese-American Wo Hop, however on Chinese New Year it does not get any better than finding the back room in Hop Kee's basement restaurant. Now, on Chinese New Year, Hop Kee's back room is always hopping with the chants of "Gong Hay Fat Choy." It is not the pictures of Anthony Bourdain, and all the famous guests, the waitors who look like your Chinese Grandfather, the one button cash register, or the metal containers that create the experience. However, on Chinese New Year (The Year of the Goat/Sheep) Hop Kee has a wonderful special menu of their famous Pork Chop, Clams with Black Bean sauce, Long LIfe Noodles and many others. However, my all-time favorite dish is Hop Kee's Crab Cantonese--A large plate of perfectly cracked blue crab with sizzling Cantonese sauce made with black bean, egg, ground pork, ginger & scallion. The eggs and shell on a piping hot plate with a medium bowl of perfectly steamed white rice constitute what I want to have one day for my last meal. Having the world's best egg roll to start the meal perfectly cooked in a deep fryer is an All-Madden meal at a higher level. Like a Peter Luger porterhouse, this is something you cannot make at home. I love the crab egg, and the fact that I do not even need a mallet or crab cracker to open the perfectly prepared claws, and backfin blue crabmeat--eat your heart out my fellow Marylanders. When I die "Take my body back to Georgetown, but give me a Crab Cantonese Chinese New Year meal at Hop Kee below Mott Street."    I was not born in Asia, but on this Chinese New Year, I could not be more proud than to be Chinese and born in the United States. I dedicate this review to two of my grandparents: Thomas Wong my paternal grandfather, and Lee Ngon Win Chin my maternal grandmother who like many Toisanese made it possbile for more recent immigrants to come to this country. Lastly, thanks to Hop Kee for making Chinese New Year Special. I will argue with any of my Asian friends, that Hop Kee's Crab Cantonese is an Asian meal beyond compare. Old School Chinese Baby!Gong Hay Fat Choy!Dr. Thomas A. WongGeorgetown DoubleHoyaProud to be a Chinese-American

Came here a few months ago when it was juuuuust a tad bit warmer out and I wish I could close my eyes right now and reappear on this amazing rooftop bar. I feel like The Roof was the underdog of the summer. Located inside The Viceroy Hotel, you walk inside this beautiful hotel and go up an elevator to the top, get out and you feel as though you are walking into a cloud above Central Park. Amazing... Breathtaking views of Central Park, NY skyline and plenty of space to either sit and get cozy or stand by the ledge and dream. I found this spot to not be as pretentious as some of the other well known rooftop bars (such as 230 Fifth). Bartenders were chill, complimentary pretzel bites at the bar, decent prices for Lambrusco/champagne. Love their matchbook design ... Great spot that I can't wait to return to. Til next summer ...

*** The super-short review ***Lives up to the hype. Eat here.*** The medium-length, summary review ***Pig & Khao is fantastic, and I couldn't even eat their signature dishes because I usually stay away from pork. I mean I had to cut the Pig out of Pig & Khao, and they still impressed. That's pretty great. To boot, I came here with a proper citizen of the Philippines, and P&K got her thumbs up, with one exception, the Chicken Inasal, which underwhelmed the both of us. I'd definitely come back, I'd recommend this to out-of-towners, to friends, for dates, for lunches, for brunches, for dinners, for winners, and I suppose for losers too--they can sit in the sad little heated patio out back and stuff mantou buns (not Filipino, but perfect in about every way) in their mouths till their sorrow is forgotten or drowned by dough.BEWARE the menu labeling. Their "small plates" aren't small. The khao soi could easily be most people's main plate. Even some of the sides--the chop suey, which was $%@&ing delicious, by the way--would have made for a pretty great minimalist main, in and of itself. My partner and I, deceived by the menu's willy-nilly categorization, over-ordered, and while I was delighted by this in the moment, I felt ill shortly thereafter, as my dear stomach battled for my very life against the mantou buns, which were trying to burst my insides with their doughy, assiduous expansion.*** Dish by Dish ***Side-dishes and appetizers:* Chop Suey. Allegedly a side-dish, in actuality also candidate for a very light main or appetizer. Terrific. Would have again. Not Filipino, but served there often according to my dinner partner, who said P&K's version is way better, lighter, fresher, and not drenched in sauce so the crispiness and flavor of the vegetables comes out.* Mantou buns. Side dish. Also not Filipino. Four buns a bit bigger than a doughnut hole, and like doughnuts but denser and only very lightly sweet. They were perfect. I have never had mantou before, and I don't know what their ideal is, but if their ideal is not this, then, it either ought to be, or I ought to be eating it right now, and every day, forever, and then buried with some of them, because they were so good. (Be careful with these--I think they do the thing where they expand in your stomach and threaten you with slow, pressured death, if you eat too many.)* Khao soi. Allegedly a small plate, in actuality a not-huge main. This was the best khao soi I've had outside Thailand, and also the only khao soi I've had that seemed as good as what I remember having there. To my palate, this dish was also perfectly spiced--there was enough in there to give heat, but not enough to overwhelm the flavor or to hurt. Everything above was not just excellent, but it was perfect. Which is why the main dish was so disappointing.Main dish:Chicken Inasal. It was... chicken. Just plain old chicken. I mean, they did *something* to prep it, its skin was colored and has some flavor to it, but not to any great effect. And my dinner partner mentioned it wasn't as good as what she'd sometimes get from the chicken chains of the Philippines, where it would not only be super cheap, but also come loaded with garlic rice. In this chicken's defense, I have to note it tasted better the next day as leftovers, perhaps because it didn't have to compete on my palate with all the other stuff.Dessert:Halo halo. The best iteration of this dessert I've had! The ice was a proper slush, not big tooth-chipping chips, and while it was loaded with the mix-mix of sweetness you'd expect (red yam ice cream, rice crispies, condensed milk, and cubes of flan and candied banana), it didn't feel overloaded. Drinks:I didn't try the cocktails, but I have important beer notes for you: The Lucky Buddha, a Chinese beer, is flavorless effluence poured into a lovely, jolly-Buddha-shaped bottle. Avoid. The San Miguel Pilsner, however, is a pretty good, flavorful pilsner. It seems the Philippines escaped the trap of exporting only their most generic lager beer.

What I love about this place:1. FREE POOL!2. The BEST Cosmo in all of NYC. Go on Friday, Saturday, and Sunday evenings because that is when the bartender who makes them works. Yes, I asked him what his shifts are.3. Swanky leather couches, swanky atmosphere, swanky overall. Makes me want to puff on a cigar while I wait for my wife to give birth in the next room.4. The waitress was super nice, constantly checking up on us for drink refills. She gave us complimentary shots at the end of the night (whatever whiskey we wanted).5. It's right by the NQR train on Central Park South. For the location, the price isn't too bad!6. Did I mention FREE POOL?7. The pool table was well maintained, unlike the one in Dumbo that looked and felt like it was about to disintegrate. No missing balls, table was tilted in anyway (making it impossible to sink any shot), and the stick were not on the wrong side of crappy. Highly recommend! Will be frequenting here after work on Fridays from now on! FREE POOL!

Sake Bar Hagi is one of my dependable standbys. I've been coming here for years: low-key dates, catching up with friends, and even solo dining, this bar has always got me covered.Reasonable prices, service is always on point, and if you go early (or laaaate) enough, you won't have to deal with a wait.Their menu covers the gamut of what you'd expect at a Japanese bar, light bites galore. The tofu agedashi is a good warm up, and then you can move onto skewers. Who doesn't like yakitori? And if you have a hankering for ramen late nights - yes, they've got ramen - they'll save you a walk to a specialty noodle shop (most which will be closed by then) and it'll fill you up.There's a TV (if you're into that), and plenty of alcohol (if you're into that), and seating for a decent group, so you'll never be bored.

Easily one of the top beer shops in all of NYC. Huge variety of beer in every price range, style, origin you can think of. Warehouse style place. You can mix and match 6 packs, buy as many or few bottles as you want of each beer. Bottles are priced individually so you can pick and choose. They also have a small selection of taps. Its a bit out of the way, so make a day trip out of it and hit some good restaurants and shops in the area. Staff were very helpful. Large selection of local and regional beers from all around the US. Lots of stuff I had never heard of, and lots I was very familiar with. Great selection of IPAs, Farmhouses, Saisons, Hefs, lagers, ales, etc. Small selection of sours as well. You pay at the window, which isnt quite traditional but it works. Came here and spent about $40 on a large selection of beer. Even got some advice from two guys who were shoppers and looking at some similar beers. Nice folks. I will definitely be coming here again next time im in the area or have a hankering for some unusual beers.

As a guy, Id rate new clothing shopping slightly above going in for a dental cleaning (which im overdue for...), so after a large shopping spree at Macys on 34th I found myself with two pairs of new Jeans. Unfortunately for me, god did not make me a length that agrees with most traditional Jean sizes, leaving me in the precarious position of needing to get them hemmed. Dating back to my days living in North Jersey it was relatively cheap and easy to find a place to get this done. Every town had a few laundromats or tailors.Hey, I know its New York City. There are plenty of places to get your jeans hemmed. However, the prices shocked me during my initial local search. In my neighborhood Greenwich village they wanted to charge me $17-20 dollars per pair, the horror!I decided to take matters into my own hands and went on yelp and found this little East Village gem. I called in advance and found out with their coupon on here and by checking in you can get original stitched jeans hemmed for $5 dollars. No its not a typo, these are old-school New York City prices. I arrived there on a chilly Wednesday after walking more than a mile (the lengths we go to save $25 dollars in Manhattan) and chuckled as i saw they posted a list of peoples faces via video surveillance who had shop lifted as a way to shame them, bad.... very bad people who did that! I digress, after entering the large store with rows of clothes and large lights reminiscent of a fashion runway I was greeted by Air, a very friendly receptionist who explained to me the different types of hemming available (didn't know there was more than one before!) and also suggested to me using the yelp coupon code on my phone app, which was very nice of her. I had her put pins on the bottom of the jeans as they were boot-cut, and needed to be cut just enough to not scrape the ground. She told me they would be ready in 5 days, and even suggested me a coffee spot down the street (I reviewed it too, yay!) .  After 5 days she called and told me they were ready so I strolled back before heading to a yelp event (also reviewed it, I'm on a roll here!!) and i went back in and tried the newly hemmed jeans on. They were cut to exactly where I'd have wanted, not so long that they were touching the bottom of my shoes, but not so short that you'd see my socks if I sat down. In other words, they were hemmed to hit that magical sweet spot that so few hemmed jeans ever reach. And the original stitching was still in place, successful plastic surgery of my jeans was completed. I thanked air, switched my frumpy pants for one of the newly hemmed jeans and headed out, feeling great. Suffice to say, I would recommend other Yelpers come here for any of their hemming or tailoring needs as this store is simply cut from a different cloth, :).

Ducked in from the cold for a quick brunch yesterday and ended up having the most amazing meal I've had in quite some time. I don't even know where to begin!? Disclaimer: I came with a group of gals who love to eat and are the harshest of the harsh in terms of food critics...Bright, clean, modern design and a casual yet trendy atmosphere. Lively crowd on a Saturday afternoon. Friendly staff. The KALE SALAD is to die for. Perfectly dressed with a delicious lemon-y vinaigrette. Shredded Kale (my favorite) with the ideal amount of candied pecans, croutons, pancetta, apple, and pecorino cheese. Can I use the word flawless to describe this kale salad? Yep. Just when I think it can't get any better...enter: Buttermilk Fried Chicken. Good lord almighty it was delicious. Impeccably battered and seasoned. Crispy but not overcooked. Served over small pieces of cauliflower, pomegranate seeds and a delicious puree of some sort. Just get it. I promise you'll thank me. Avocado toast is on point. Can you ever go wrong with avocado toast? Phenomenal bloody mary. Ok and maybe we had some french fries. Loved them. Andddd the pancakes for "dessert." Fluffy, sweet, oh-so-perfect pancakes. The orange infused butter on top should be illegal...it's that delicious.You won me over, Upsider. Hands down the best brunch experience I've had in the city in quite some time. I'll be back soon...

This place is like the Great Gatsby movie on steroids. What? This type of bar/lounge/club whatever exists in real life?????! I have had an intense love affair with NYC for 7 years and I just recently came to this glorious nightlife establishment NOW?! Oh heavens.2 of my friends and I do our ritual dinner/drinks/club night like mmm once every few weeks. We wanted to try some place new that all of us have never been to. The top of the standard (or boom boom room as it was formerly known) got thrown around in conversation and while I tried to get the "hook-up" from some of my promoter friends aka GET US A TABLE STAT, they were unable to do so (even though we were willing to shell out thousands of dollars). Hmm. Impressive.Finally, a friend of a friend (you know the drill) knew someone and alas, we reserved a table. The hostesses are dressed in...wait for it...wait for it...like something out of the Great Gatsby movie. You walk in to this SUPER swanky gorgeous nightclub where it isn't so packed that you can feel the sweat dripping off of the person next to you. No. No no no no. We had our own little table and it was only appropriate to order Dom. Like, literally, it would be a shame to drink something regular. This is not a regular place. Be prepared for a luxurious evening where good service actually exists in a nightclub and people around you actually smile. No one will spill a drink on you and you will not wake up in the morning smelling like you bathed in cigarettes. Wow. Definitely had a lovely evening and want to return ASAP.-I think they may be a little too strict at the door as this place has so much potential to be like THE "it" club but they make it very hard to get in to. When they say "guest list" only. They MEAN it. No BS. It's hard to reserve a table here but honestly, it's worth all the trouble if you can actually get a reso.-This review was for the club experience (after 12am)

My review used to say I come here every Tuesday and Thursday, but a few people (as well as my scale) brought it to my attention that I am here almost every day. I try to restrain from the sweets and walk to the back where the coffee bar is. They do not have almond milk but they do have soymilk so soy cappucino it is. The walk back is the hardest part because by that time, you are completely surround by the delicious smell of pastries and chocolate and you have to walk past all the delicious offerings and I give in 99% of the time. My favorite thing here is the chocolate rugelach. It is flakey and the perfect sweetness. I grew up in Israel, where rugelach are extremely common so naturally I have had some amazing ones, but this is one of the best ones I have tasted. You can get one... Or you can get 2 and it is a better price or something but honestly I would still buy these if they were $10 a piece. The breads here are delicious too. I bought two focaccia breads; seeded and roasted vegetable. I like the seeded much better because it has a nice crunch to it but both were really delicious. The rolls (sesame or poppy) are really soft on the inside and only $1.50. The Jerusalem baguette reminds me of the ones I used to get in Israel but with higher quality ingredients. The babka ($12) is AMAZING as well and I would highly recommend buying one, though you can only buy it as a whole which for someone like myself is extremely dangerous because I am more than able to finish a whole loaf. Honestly anything chocolate here is mind blowing. The almond croissant is also a really good choice if you are craving sweets. It kind of reminds me of a cronut in the sense that it is really crunch on the edges but super soft inside. It also has marzipan inside which is one of my favorite things in the world. It is super filling so I would recommend sharing it. The potato burekas are also good but that was my favorite thing as a kid and it feels like a sin to eat them anywhere else except Roladin (a bakery in Israel). The spinach feta are the best ones here in my opinion.I recently tried three of the hamantashens, the vanilla chocolate chip, chocolate nutella, and poppy seed. My favorite of the three is the vanilla chocolate chip. The vanilla is almost like a pudding/custard texture which I really enjoy. The poppy seed is also really good but there is A LOT of poppy filling so if that is not something you like, try the vanilla. The chocolate was a little too chocolatey for me which surprised me because I thought it would be my favorite. This place is a little pricey, they give student discounts if you are a student but everything I have tried here was amazing and it is 100% worth it.

Seriously, you MUST try this place! It was spectacular. Aside from having a cozy atmosphere, the food and service were phenomenal. My friend and I opted to order and split the bibimbap with spicy chicken ($18) and the le grand bulgolgi ($36). I probably liked the le grand bulgogi a bit more, but the bibimbap was tasty as well. The bulgogi is Chef's cut prime beef rib-eye marinated in Korean barbecue sauce, grilled on open fire served with kimchi and brussels sprouts. The barbecue sauce has a nice mesquite flavor. The steak should be eaten completely together with the kimchi and brussels sprouts for an absolute perfect bite. The bulgogi, which we ordered medium rare, was tender, melt in your mouth perfection. The bibimbap with spicy chicken was served with a bowl of rice with bean sprouts, zucchini, shiitake mushroom, julienned carrots, seaweed chips, gochujang (a red chili sauce) and a fried egg. You mix everything together yourself for a really nice portion of bibimbap. It was a nice blend of flavors. For dessert, we opted for the green tea pudding ($8). If you like the flavor of green tea ice cream, you'll definitely enjoy this. It's served in a shooter and topped with house made whipped cream and a cookie crumble. The pudding is not too heavy or sweet, so I left feeling like I could still fit in my clothes. Just a note: Although our dishes came out at the same time, at the tables to the left and right of us, their food was served at different times. It would be nice if the restaurant could address this issue. Either way, don't let that deter you from coming here.

Went on a Friday night around 8:30ish. I had read an article about this restaurant and been meaning to try it out. The dining area seats over 300 hundred and the wait time for a table was only about 5-10 minutes When you first come in you will notice the huge tank which hold exceptionally large lobsters. I AM TALKING 7-10 POUND LOBSTERS. Insane. You also notice the huge beautiful bar. They literally had at least 7 bartenders. I knew I could truly appreciate this establishment because it is properly staff. As soon as we were seated we were introduced to our server. I ordered a glass of wine to go along with my dinner as well.There menu has three things -whole lobster (steamed or grilled)-lobster roll -burger Each comes with fries and a salad. This is not a place you bring your vegan friend to. LolOur food came out in less than 20 minutes and was delivered on a silver platter. I ordered the grilled whole lobster with lemon butter. My husband order steamed. I think the grilled lobster is better and less messy in terms of the tomalley of the lobster. I am not a fan of the tomalley and that is why I order it grilled. The lobster tasted great, the salad was pretty basic, & the fries are pretty addicting.I WILL DEFINITELY BE REVISITING THIS ESTABLISHMENT SOON. Its is a great deal for the amount and quality of food you receive.

12 Corner's latest outpost extends into Chinatown, replacing the outgoing beleaguered Orange Teahouse. Time will tell how they fare against the glut of Chinese coffee shops and bakeries in Chinatown but one thing is clear, service and premium coffee drinks you've come to expect from the sister shop on East Broadway are here as well.As you may well know, the younger demographic (20 & 30-somethings) will be right at home here as they do at the E. Broadway location for which I've grown fond of since their opening.They have free WiFi and a few seats to enjoy a cup of coffee with a friend, though much like the E. Broadway location... It too is quite a tight space. I ordered a cappuccino and did some work on the counter space and sure enough, customers are already coming through. That's coffee for ya!If you enjoy premium brews besides Starbucks and you happen to be in Chinatown, make this yours.

Veselka is forever a horoshayie*memory in my mind.First time I've stepped into the NY streets, I stayed at a couple's apartment arranged through AirBnB. Completely new to the city and hungry after a 6 hour flight, I asked them for a suggestion for late lunch."Go to Veselka, it's just down a few blocks. We go there with friends often. Great Ukrainian diner.."With this advice from mere strangers, I waltzed down the street picturing myself as a petite Carrie. (The things watching too much SaTC before flying out will do to ya..) The corner diner was packed, but as I had arrived alone, I decided to sit at the bar overlooking the kitchen. I ordered blintzes with the works, my hunger mixed with happiness of being in the city didn't register that it would be too much food. It was delicious. I think I drank a cup of coffee as well. Which is a must for any diner visit for me. The service was quick, the food delicious!When my mom (who was born in Ukraine) visited, we went here on a whim. Again, we sat at the bar, this time we ordered pierogi and borsht and a few other things. As someone who has Russian blood, but has never made borsht from scratch, I sure am picky. I actually judge Ukrainian/Russian restaurants by their quality of this hot staple. The red beet soup flavored with beef with a dollop of sour cream on top. Oh yeah..It was a bowl of deliciousness that I couldn't get enough of. In fact I swore I'd visit again (and again and again...) in the winter months to be warmed by the goodness! Can't wait to be back! LOVE this place!* (Rus) - good

Remember that time I almost burned down the bar by catching the paper napkin on fire? Yeah, me either.But seriously, minus that little snafu I love everything about this place. I been a couple of times and have had fabulous service every time. Whether I'm sitting at the bar or with a large party at a table the service has been way above par. All of the cocktails I've had are fresh and delicious, their happy hour is great, and can you really go wrong with a solid (cheap) burger and wings? Nope! Great new addition to the neighborhood.

DA-LISH.So I have been in a bit of a foodie funk lately. Everything seems mediocre. Everything. It's pretty upsetting. Enter Maysville on a Friday night. I was meeting my friend Lea for drinks and we chose Maysville for the location and the intense bourbon selection we had read about. I met her right at 6:30 on the dot and my word was it crowded. There was absolutely nowhere to sit at the bar. Nowhere to stand, either. So we decided to order an appetizer or two and snag a table. We were seated at a super tight little table in the actual bar area, which I didn't love. After our first drink arrived though, it was all good, baby. I had the Noreaster (whiskey, ginger beer, maple syrup, lime). My stomach had been a bit upset that day, so I thought the ginger beer would really help a sister out. Booze logic! Hot damn. This was one bangin-ass drink. For realsies. Come here just for this alone. Delicious. We looked over the menu a few times and had a hard time choosing what to have. My friend doesn't eat pork (why she agreed to go there I will never understand) and most of the dishes are based around glorious, delectable pork. Anyway, I'm not one for wallowing and we were already there so....Shrimp Toasts (celery and ginger aioli) were excellent. I was especially glad these came before any other dishes. They were robust but also....delicate? I just don't think they would have been as good after some of the heavier dishes. Grilled Flatbread (brussel sprouts, buttermilk, sheep's milk cheese and crispy pig ear) so good. I mean it was likely one of the healthiest dishes (hahah JOKE) on the menu, and it was really good. The brussel sprouts were all shaved and drizzled in cheese, the flatbread was a nice balance between soft and crispy and we had the crispy pig ear on the side, to accommodate my friend. But there was no way I was going to give that ish up. It looked like teeny tiny slices of chicken cutlet. It was salty and delicious. I especially liked the flavor of the ear with the brussel sprouts. Don't let the fact that it's pig ear scare you. It doesn't look like an ear, and if that's what ear tastes like, bring me more. We also went with the Mushroom Tart (whipped ricotta cheese and pickled apple) which was honestly just okay. But you don't come to Maysville for their mushrooms, now do you? I think not. Best part of the whole meal? The cornbread they serve in lieu of a bread basket. For the two of us, we recieved four slices of steaming hot cornbread with soft butter, which obviously melted all over the bread before the entire thing melted in my mouth. We even had seconds. Yes, seconds on the bread basket. Bring me thirds. As for the space itself, it was really gorgeous. It walked a fine line between being too girly or too masculine, with somehow striking the perfect balance between the two. Massive photographs of horses on the walls, a carrera marble bar and warm lighting throughout, including a wall of whiskey and bourbon, all softly back-lit to catch your attention, but not take away from your dinner companion. Even the wallpaper has a golden glow, which balances nicely with the wood and steel barstools. You know I am a sucker for a nice space. Anyway, have you been? No? Well, that's a tremendous mistake. Get thee to Maysville. Have the pork and bourbon.

Crush is up there with Flatiron Wine and Astor Wines as one of the best wine shops in the entire city. This is the place you go when you need to find a bottle for a BYOB birthday at Peking Duck House (a sick vintage of Spätlese from a strong producer, duh). This is the place you go to when you want minimalist, gorgeous glassware (Zalto) so you can pretend to be an adult when you have friends over and open a bottle (as an aside, damn you Aldo Sohm for tripling the popularity of these. Now we have to wait for Ryan Sutton to make some eager comment about them so they stop being cool with the tools again.). But this is also the place you go when you want some Savennières or Chablis but don't want to break the bank.
