For in spite of the fact that at the high end (grand cru Burgundy, cult Champagnes) Crush crushes it, they also thoughtfully curate at the $20 - $25 level. From Beaujolais to the eccentric Jura, Crush is also a wine shop where you can feel comfortable asking the staff for help or recommendations without feeling like 1) they don't actually know very much themselves or 2) that they know too much to translate for some plebian - aka you. I've come and simply asked for a Vouvray, no other context given, and was guided to a wonderful wine through thoughtful, genuine questions. I've also had a ten minute discussion about whether a particular Crémant d'Alsace would be more citrus or orchard fruit forward (Pinot Blanc blends are straight tricky) and it didn't feel forced, or pretentious, or even as absurd as it probably was from any objective perspective.So, expand your horizons here. Better yet, it's the holidays: expand the horizons of others. Have a friend who, mystifyingly, still finds it funny to scream "I am NOT drinking any fucking Merlot!" yet you feel obligated to remain friends with? Get them some Château Pétrus and let them put that in their pipe and smoke it.Bonus points: Their website is fantastic. The search options are sufficiently nerdy, and the landing page is surprisingly helpful, highlighting recent acquisitions, special sales, and generally interesting news in the world of wine. You don't have to be a cork-dork to like Crush, but don't be too surprised if you start to become one.

I had the shrimp and grits and loved it. It was so thick and creamy. It also came with a buttermilk buscuit which was to die for. My friend had a catfish plate with grits and biscuit. It looked and tasted heavenly. The owner are Carlos n Joy! They are so sweet and kind. The interior is so quaint and cozy. Be sure to look at the celling. Ive been twice and the food taste consistent. Be sure and make reservations.You gotta check out this place!

The selection of food and drinks is first rate, which the highlight being their appetizers and mac & cheese. They have 9 varieties of mac and cheese and the Shroom was AMAZING! We had a group of stellar appetizers as well, and the main courses were all d'lish. Our server didn't rush us, and we were able to have a nice, leisurely meal on a busy Friday night.

I don't eat Chinese food too often as my taste buds don't have a liking for this cuisine. But, wait, before you call me an Asian hater, I can explain. I am not one of those Chinese Americans that's too snobby for my own people's food, that's hardly the case. It's more like I am a health nut, and well, Chinese food is basically heart attack on a platter. But after an extremely grueling Bikram class right upstairs, me and my homegirls needed desperately to restart our engines. Bikram yoga will kill you, but you will appreciate it later. So all the glowing reviews for this place is for the Cracklin chicken and well if you eat birds of the fowl family, you have got to get this dish. It comes with about 5 to 6 pieces of LARGE chicken pieces fried to perfection. The pieces are seriously as big as a small bird. On top of that, it comes with fried rice, soup of your choice and salad. And all this food is for $16. Since I don't eat meat, I got the Tofu Szechuan style, served with a side of fried rice, an order of plantains and soup of your choice. And all this for $16. My other friend got the General Tso Shrimp, with side of yellow rice. This was $17. I'll have to tell you, when the waiters brought out a dish of egg noodle chips with a side of duck sauce, I just couldn't stop smiling. It just brought back so many good memories of when I was a child and going out to eat with my family. Those were some of my happiest moments. We ladies enjoyed our meals, chatted about life, catching up and enjoying our adventure into a time warp. The restaurant looks like it's right out of the 80s, with a diner top in the front of the restaurant with the coolest stools (that's right, Hipster is in), and they have a few tables with booth seating, and of course, very tacky wall art. That is a quintessential Chinese restaurant ambiance, which I took in with fondness. The waiters were very nice, smiling all the time, and speaking three different languages while working quickly to serve everyone. We came in at 10pm and despite them closing at 11pm, they allowed us to enjoy a most relaxing meal and the waiters never rushed us and let us take our time. I will definitely come back again for other Tofu dishes served with plantains. This is my go-to now after a crazy-ass Bikram class. Never mind that I also thought the waiters were exceptionally cute and adorable, wink wink.

My first and special bronx review! I have to say it's special because..... I LIVE HERE! So I'll be breaking down this apartment complex as much as I can with the best style I know how! PROS and CONS! Pros-This area is in the Kingsbridge sections of the bronx aka the upper north west side of the Bronx. Your. About 10 mins away from yonkers which is the first city technically being "upstate". -The community itself is very diverse with lots of people from all walks of life and backrounds. from old Irish tradition to hip hip/jazzy vibes you have a little bit of everything here in this location-Kingsbridge arms is a co-op apartment complex with a full blown community room (100 dollars to reserve for the day up to 2am), full laundry mat with numerous of washers and dryers (closes 9pm daily)-Has 9 floors and each floors has its own garbage room so if your too lazy you can always throw your trash in that room.-this place also has a intercom system with security guards so you need to know what apart your going to and they each all know who lives in each apartment they each have their way of making themselves known to the tenants here! -again..... I LIVE here lol -walls are very thick do you cant here people business unless they are yelling or physically doing something loud! So you will feel comfortable sleeping at night.- did I forget to mention that I have a BALCONY!! -I live in a 3 bedroom apartment so it's a lot of room for a descent price! They offer 1br,-3br in this complex.-the workers here really do a helpful job fixing things and help situates your concerns quicklyCons -I have neighbors ~_~OverallI love being in this apartment, it's quiet, people are respectful and nice and my apartment is more than enough for me to live my life.

This place is the bomb. There was literally one other couple when I got here (4 pm on a Sunday). The place is small and spotless, and the waitress took our order quickly. I ordered the dancing spicy ramen and my boyfriend ordered the california ramen. I actually thought the california ramen wasn't so great, but he really liked it. It's got this weird tomato broth that's kind of refreshing, if you're into that kind of thing.I wanted thick, creamy, garlicy ramen, which is exactly what I got. The calamari was delicious and fit in surprisingly well, even though I thought it was an odd choice when I ordered it. The broth was filling, perfectly salty, super savory...I definitely want to come back and try a few other things on the menu. They have an awesome lunch special that I missed - I believe it comes with a free side and salad. This is a great, inexpensive alternative to Ippudo and Totto that can get you in and out in 45 minutes!

Don't be misled by the unmarked, apartment door entrance. If you're still not sure, look for the window with the "A." But you are in the right place. Once you knock on the door, they will buzz you in. (He kicked the door a few times because we thought it was jammed. Oops. They have a video feed inside too so don't do anything embarrassing like us haha.)Chill, intimate, and narrow with a row of eight bar stools in front and several booths in the back, Attaboy is the perfect place for a date or a long catch-up session. And you must acknowledge Sam Ross (known for coming up with the now ubiquitous "Penicillin") & Michael McIlroy, two longtime Milk and Honey alums, for successfully holding down the fort (this is where Milk and Honey used to be) and making it their own. That's a big name to live up to; I'm impressed.The best part?NO shouting needed to talk to your friends. (Only light background music.)NO immensely long lines if you come in a small group (2 or 3 is ideal).NO drunk yuppies wandering in after happy hour.NO menu = no reason to "settle" on a drink from a drab menu, drink to your mood.YES to knowledgeable barmen.YES to unique, well-crafted cocktails for $16. Credit cards are accepted.YES to a huge selection of bourbon.I didn't have a chance to talk to the barman as much as I wanted to because we were quite engrossed in our conversation (& beyond satisfied with our amazing drinks), but I will most certainly be back soon.Save a seat for me at the bar!Notes:- Attaboy is named after a vintage store in Belfast (McIIroy's hometown).- Hours are 6:45PM-4AM daily.- No reservations, just first come first serve.- Wine starts at $12, beer starts at $9.- No food yet! Word on the street is that charcuterie is a possibility in the future.- More natural light in front (window installed) and larger bar than M&H. Also has a small standing area.- If you tell them how many drinks you'll have, they'll design a series of "courses" for you!Update 12/14/13: Dan Greenbaum, formerly of the Beagle in the East Village, is also manning the bar now!

Whoever decided to open up this Bubble Tea Shop in Hells Kitchen I am now your most loyal customer...Midtown West has been yearning for a good bubble tea place for some time...THANK YOU ViVi!The ViVi at this location offers better food than the other locations. My favorite is the Taiwanese Salt Pepper Popcorn Chicken. Absolutely yummy and only costs about $4! They also offer ramen as well. My favorite Boba Tea here is Yellow Black WOW Milk...even tho I am lactose intolerant...I still must have it! No pain no gain right? To all Boba lovers come check this place out when you get the chance!

Words can't even begin to explain how much I loved my dining experience at The Musket Room. I heard from a friend that they had an amazing 6-course tasting menu for an affordable price ($75) and they were able to snag a Michelin Star within the first year of opening. All these accolades are EXACTLY on point!To start, the service here is impeccable! When we arrived at our reservation, our hostess was very apologetic about making us wait and she offered to buy us drinks. We opted for the Smoky Kiss and The Queen's Punch. Among the two, the Queen's Punch was the better drink, with a little less of an alcoholic aftertaste.When we were finally seated, we chose the 6-course tasting menu. While we were waiting, our server gave us a choice of a couple different breads: sourdough, bacon and cheddar brioche, and rye. Like any starving individual, I stopped listening when our server said bacon and ordered the brioche immediately. AMAZINGGGGG. We asked for seconds and thirds throughout the night and our server happily obliged. The sourdough was pretty good as well, but no contest for the brioche.Our dishes were paced perfectly and in this order:- Broccoli soup | oxtail | parsley: The oxtail croquette was SO DELICIOUS. Be sure to savor this one! The broccoli soup was a great appetizer for a cold night. It was thick and had great texture without being too heavy.- Cold smoked scallops | cucumbers | black garlic | pears | sea beans: This dish had the best presentation. It was served with smoke bubbling underneath a glass cover and when the server lifted the glass, the smoke dissipated into the air, drawing the attention of other patrons sitting near us. The rolls of pickled cucumber here were my favorite. Everything on this dish complemented each other perfectly. - Quail | blackberries | bread sauce | roasted onions: I haven't had quail too many times before this, but I really enjoyed this one. The bread sauce was very unique and tasted great with the tender quail, which fell right off the bone. I only wish there was more meat!- New Zealand red deer | flavors of gin: This was my favorite dish of the night. The red deer was cooked perfectly and did not have a gamey taste to it at all. The portions looked small at first, but as I was eating this one, it didn't feel that way at all. I think it was just the right portion to satiate an appetite without being overwhelming.- Grape | ginger: This was a really interesting palate cleanser. I liked how at certain parts it tasted somewhat like a peanut butter jelly sandwich. It was bright and sweet without being too overly saccharine.- Chocolate mousse cake | pear | almond: I wasn't a huge fan of this dessert, but it was still pretty good. I'm big on textures so I really appreciated the medley of flavors and combination of textures on this plate.This is probably one of my best dining experiences in NYC and I will definitely recommend this to anyone and everyone! The Musket Room has definitely set a high bar for New Zealand cuisine in my book!

I'm sure the 1000+ reviews speak for themselves about how great this place is. But what I do want to share is that, despite the receipts you see on here, Yasuda has one of the best deals around for high quality sushi.Especially after spending 2 weeks eating my way through Japan this summer, I realized how lucky I was to be able to find similar quality sushi at my doorstep.While you can opt to get the omakase (which don't get me wrong is fantastic), if you don't want to spend $150+ you can also do the following (assuming splitting between 2 people):- 2 orders of Sushi Matsu: 12 pieces of sushi and half a roll each for $44 per person- Sashimi Take: 5 varieties of sashimi (you can order 1 extra piece so that you get 3 pieces each) for $27.50- order a few special pieces that aren't on the "set" menu. I always like to get an addition piece (or two...) of uniAnd that brings you to just under $75 per person!Tip: do try and get a counter seat if you can regardless of if you're doing omakase or a la carte. It lets you talk to the chef about your likes and dislikes and he can adjust the pieces as you go. I'm often unfamiliar with half the fish on the menu, so I tell the chef to surprise me

With so many Thai restaurants sprouting all over NYC like mushrooms, it is always amazing to stumble upon the ones that stand out.Somtum Der offers a fantastic Thai Isan cuisine (northern part-spicy). The long communal tables and the Sai (fish traps) hanging on the ceiling speak truly of a Thai ambiance.Since it's family style dining, we started with Pad Thai Mun Poo; it's a special Pad Thai made with crab meat and crab paste with home style sauce. its so delicious and it disappeared on our table with a blink of an eye. Next was the Papaya Salad (Tum Poo-Plara) it is Isan salad with fermented fish sauce and field crabs. Unfortunately, the taste was too pungent for our Americanized palate. The waiter incidentally over heard us and was kind enough to offer to replace with another salad called Tum Thai Kai Kem (spicy salad with salted egg). +1 star for that!The fried Isan sausages (Sai Krok Isan) were simply epicurean. the grilled coconut marinated beef skewer (Moo Ping Kati Sod) with sticky rice on the side made our dinner sumptuous.With top notch customer service and its inexpensiveness the competitors near by should really be worried.

Never mind the pies and the thighs - these doughnuts are insane.Actually the pies and thighs are pretty awesome too. But make sure you also get every doughnut. Especially the Butter Crunch. But especially the Chocolate. But especially the new Sourdough ($3).Also, this location is way better than the tiny original in Williamsburg. Still the elementary school chairs, but there's a lot more room now, as well as a counter.

Yes, the Cronut is good. But their other pastries, and even their lunch items are just as good, if not better. The only Cronut variety i've tried was their pumpkin chai ($5.00). It was good, and I only had to wait in line for about an hour. But it really doesn't live up to the insane hype. Their current seasonal menu offers a Gingerbread Croissant ($4.00), which is far superior. It's perfectly flaky, and comes cut in half, having been stuffed with toasted pecans, a caramel coulant, and topped with marshmallows and powdered sugar. It's seriously good, and requires no wait!I've also had a few of their savory menu items as well. The Perfect Little Egg Sandwich ($5.00) is just that. Perfect, fluffy, and delicious. It's served on a warm fresh brioche bun, and comes with gruyere cheese. It's an awesome snack, and a great pairing if you're looking for something to offset the sugar coma. For a more heavier savory option, their Mustard Braised Cabbage & Burrata Panini is also a decent vegetarian choice. Although the egg sandwich is better. The secret is their soup though. The Parsnip and Cauliflower Soup ($5.50) is delicious, and it's served with homemade Cheese Gougère, one of the best breads my tastebuds have ever encountered. Just get the soup, you won't regret it. Unfortunately, this place is super touristy, and can get really crowded but they have ample amount of seating with a back patio garden. There is always a line, but it moves pretty quick, and somehow the employees stay pretty nice despite the daily insanity. Venture out from the cronut! There's more to this great little bakery!

City Bakery brings its popular offshoot, Birdbath, to Midtown East. Here you have a bakery that is dedicated to fresh, organic ingredients for its salads, sandwiches, and soups. With that comes a relatively steeper price point for most breakfast and lunch seekers who are not picky. It will annoy some who notice that prices are not listed anywhere. An average meal can set you back $10+. For others who appreciate the concept of an eco-friendly eatery, Birdbath has everything going for it. The salads and soups taste very fresh and flavorful leaving you not feeling overdosed in oil or sodium by the end of consumption. If you are allowed one bad eat for comfort, then their mac-n-cheese will surely hit that spot. The vegan chocolate chip cookies are excellent without being "oversugared", and the amazing City Bakery hot chocolate (with giant marshmallows) can be found here as well. The enormous Baker's Muffin alone, with its crusted top sprinkled with powdered sugar and soft interior loaded with raisins and walnuts, makes it worth giving Birdbath a visit!

I don't need frills. I couldn't care less about scented candles or waterfalls. Whether the oils are "essential" or a watered down Vaseline in a pretty jar is irrelevant, and who needs English? The pain from my stiff neck, tight back, and arthritic feet needs no translation. A damn good massage is a damn good massage. Renewing Spa hits the spot. Literally - all of 'em (well, almost all...not that kind of place, kids.) I haven't wanted to write this review for some time, because I saw what happened to Shun Fa in the West Village - I haven't been able to get squeezed in there for months. Shun Fa-ck that.If you can get yourself past the buzzer at the barred from door off 8th Ave and up the dark staircase to the second floor, you're in for a transportive, super relaxing experience. Walking through the door, you'll be a bit surprised just how peaceful and pleasant the space is. The front desk staff is incredibly warm, friendly, and accommodating, and the masseuses are nothing short of talented, skilled, and remarkably effective. (Hailey is my girl.) I leave here walking on air (which is difficult to do with double bunions and crepitus, believe me.) Gentle frou-frou, it's not; therapeutic ecstasy, it is.Now, for the clincher: It's 39 freakin' dollars TOTAL for 75 minutes of massage (which I usually divide between back and feet).I selfishly, shamelessly beg you: please book your appointments from 9 am-5 pm, M-F. And don't tell too many people about this place. Thank you.

I've passed by here after church so so so many times over the years and have always wanted to come in. Finally, one Friday night my friends and I came in after a Tango class we took near by. We were in good moods already and wanted to keep the evening going, it was after all, a beautiful Friday evening in Manhattan.We walked in and immediately noticed the really cool decor and ambiance. It's homey, chic and a little rustic. The food is really good here, but you will have to order a lot if you want to be stuffed, which is great because you get to try a lot of different things! Jon had the paella, I had the arepas and I must say that the guac is definitely on point and is a great snack to have with evening drinks. Even though anything you pick will be a delicious choice, I would definitely suggest coming here especially for the drinks. They are simply amazing and will blow your mind. I had the Spicy Coconut Mojito and I really wish I had ordered more than one (I switched to another drink which was also a really great choice, but I am still thinking about how crazy amazing the mojito was). Another nice surprise were the napkins. Where else can you grab a drink and learn different pick up lines in Spanish?What you'll find here is very good service, a super nice & chill vibe, and drinks that will make this place your usual drinking spot. It's a perfect spot for an intimate date, or to come and chill with friends. Since coming only once, I've already raved to all my drinking buddies (I mean come on, who in Manhattan doesn't drink a lot) that we will be coming here to enjoy some specialty cocktails. I am very happy that I finally came by and absolutely will be back again soon! Cheers!

Flat Rate is the absolute best! They truly made our moving experience seamless. After a last minute decision to move, we called a few places for quotes. Although Flat Rate was a little higher of the quotes, I was assured that we wouldn't be paying more than quoted.Man were they right. The movers came early, asked the right questions, and let us go grab breakfast while the loaded the truck. When we came back, they were almost done and i couldn't believe how fast they moved out! The 2 boxes and small items that I didn't count for in my quote were included at no additional cost.Moving in was a piece of cake too! 5 flights of stairs is NOT EASY, but I didn't hear them complain once! They didn't break or damage anything and put my furniture exactly where I asked.For any future moves, I'll be using Flat Rate! Thanks, guys!!!

Collaborative food markets are having a moment in this past year. From Gotham West Market, to Hudson Eats, food hall or food court style spaces are housing some great talent all under one roof. The most recent to join this trend is Gansevoort Market in the Meatpacking District.Once occupied by a club, this open space now has an array of food offering with a seating section underneath an incredible skylight and wrapped up in branches and bits of nature. Below are a list of all the vendors, in no particular order: Dojo Sushi is serving authentic Japanese cuisine and sushi.Tacombi serves Mexican street food and tacos.Champion Coffee serves coffee.Heermance Farm Purveyors has organic produce from the Hudson Valley.Luzzo's has coal oven pizza.The Bruffin Cafe serves a muffin-brioche-like pastry filled with quality ingredients.Pig Guy NYC serves BBQ.Yiaourti has a Greek yogurt bar with sheep's milk yogurt.Crêpe Sucre is a French crêpe bar.Ed's Lobster Bar serves New England seafood.Gansevoort Bakery is a Greek bakery.Cappone's is an authentic Italian specialties and sandwich shop.Our True Roots makes beverages and snacks from tiger nuts.Dana's Bakery makes French macarons.Lov Organic has organic teas.Feel Food has organic juice and highly nutritious food.Donostia serves Spanish tapas.Flower Girl has whimsical flower arrangements.

On 11/4/14 my friend convinced me to sign up for the $39 for 30 day deal & attend my very first yoga class EVER; bikram yoga. A short background on myself: I HATE heat, have asthma & heart conditions/issues, & I dislike sweating. So with that you could fairly assume that I would've walked into the studio & turned right around to walk out, but I didn't. I kept going after my very 1st day & I finished their 30 DAY CHALLENGE, which is THIRTY classes in THIRTY days. #dedication ;p (whoo-hoo)Studio Lobby:You can either take the stairs or take the elevator to the 3rd floor. When you get upstairs you remove your shoes & place them in one of the cubbies provided. You then check in at the counter & there you can rent/buy items; e.g. coconut water, smart water, yoga clothing, mats, towels, etc.Locker Room:The women's locker room is kept pretty clean. There are a lot of lockers & definitely enough for the # of students that would be attending the class. Don't forget to bring your own lock, even a small luggage one would do. The locker room is very narrow so can/will get crowded when classes are coming/going. They provide some toiletries for everyone; e.g. soap, shampoo/conditioner, q-tips, etc. They even supply blow dryers, brushes, etc. There are 4 showers & they are limited to 3mins.Studio:The studio is on the 4th floor; you can take the elevator or the stairs. Be careful when taking the stairs as there can be a good amount of sweat, so use those handrails. There is also a little outside area where students can hang out before/after a class (but usually after). Everyone falls in line outside the studio to wait to be let in. An employee usually comes to "turn" the room in between classes ~15mins before the next class is to begin & that is when the next class can start entering to claim their spot. The studio gets super-crazy-ridiculously hot, but that's the point. The room is carpet, as bikram yoga is supposed to be so not sure why some of the other reviewers were complaining about it, but I do see the concern w/the sweat. This is very true & you can definitely see/feel the sweat in the carpet, but it really isn't that bad IMO -- or maybe it's just me. I will say that they do need to vacuum a bit more as there can be a good amount of debris on the carpet. The classes fit 39 people & you can sign up through their app/website or at the studio.Bikram Yoga:The class itself is rough & definitely something you need to keep working on. Though you do the same postures in each class, you realize you can always get better & go into each posture more -- in my case I'm still trying to learn how to do all of them correctly or just get into them in general. I've met people who have said they've been doing yoga for over 40 years & they still need to take breaks in class. I applaud them & hope to keep it up myself. Also the instructors always remind you to only look at yourself, so there is no competition here, you are only there to better yourself.Instructors:Here are the list of instructors I've taken in the last 32 consecutive days, the # of times I had them, & the order I had them = Patrick O'Keefe (1x)Omri Kleinbeger (5x)Melissa Ritz (8x)Eddie Marco (3x)Justine Gartner (3x)Patrick Lynch (1x)Yvette Velasquez (2x)Maayan Yefet (2x)Luke Strandquist (1x)Natalia Maldonado (1x)Charly Seamon (2x)Lesly Klose (1x)Summer Saunders (1X)Emily Faurholt (1x)They all have their own ways of teaching, but the foundation is all the same. Some instructors like the class more humid, some w/more heat, & some w/a good balance of both. Also some instructors teach more "military" style & others are a bit more laid back. But something that goes across the board w/ALL of them is that they are all INCREDIBLY SUPPORTIVE. Like seriously, so supportive of you, your needs, your practice, & everything in between. They are such positive beings & as I continue to practice I am trying to get it to rub off on me. As you continue to go you'll begin to have your favorite instructors, I know I have mine. I just don't feel it is fair to post mine as everyone is different & you should come & try a few classes out for yourself to see what fits.After finishing the challenge not only has my physical health improved but so has my mental health. I am much more patient, kind, & encouraging to the people around me. Also I've learned how to "brush off" a lot of the things that would normally get to me. There were/are some days where my cardiac/asthma issues are getting the best of me, but I still attend class. When people doubt my decision I explain to them how I would not go if the instructors weren't as encouraging/supportive as they are, or if it were a competition with the other students. I go at my own pace, and the instructors respect/support/encourage that. When in the room I feel detached from my life & any other stresses; I am there to just focus on myself for 90mins -- & that alone feels refreshing.

Pros: awesome food, awesome view overlooking columbus circle, awrsome service, souvenirs to take home (a print out of your menu with some personalized phrases like happy 1st anniversary lindsey and daniel, their cookies in cute little tin boxes with per se logo on top, and a tour of the kitchen)Cons: getting the reservation is a bit trickySo I came here for my 1 yr anniversary dinner and I had an amazing experience... this was exactly why we chose this as our 1st anniversary dinner place. :) We opted for one tasting menu without incurring additional costs and one with all of the additional options added and added one red and one rose: the whole meal came to 1500 including 100 dollar tip for the waiter. (Btw, the tasting menu price is inclusive of the taxes and tips. No need to tip. We just did because he shaved extra truffles for our pasta. Hehe)It's useless to talk about the menu itself since they change everyday. One thing they don't change is the oyster pearls, which is a classic here. After one bite, I understood why this is the un changing dish at per se. Waiting service is impeccable. The waiter was very attentive and actually offered to shave off a very generous portion of extra truffle on our pasta dish. It was beautiful to see piles and piles of shaved truffles a mounting on top of my pasta. :) The whole experience took us about 3 hrs and while we were eating, we watched the sun goes down the columbus circle. Very romantic. :)Oh, btw, if you ask them for a tour in the kitchen, they gladly show you around and we got a chance to say hi to the chef! :) it was so much fun! This place is just once in a lifetime experience. :)

So we're sitting in his car after my brunch shift, and he was like, "I want foie gras. And escargot." What are the odds that a restaurant that offers both was in walking distance? Only in New York City... Voila, Amelie! Also the name of my favorite movie. I had walked past this restaurant many times in my old days of living in Manhattan. So we stopped in, and it was PACKED. The staff all spoke lovely French, and added to the authentic flair of this modern French restaurant. They worked hard to seat people as quickly and efficiently as possible in such a tiny space. The wine selection was amazing, and they had excellent happy hour specials. The lighting was dim and the atmosphere intimate. We tried the escargot, and it was shockingly nice. Also, sopping up the delicious garlic parsley sauce with the fresh bread was half of the fun. I had the smoked salmon/avocado salad (I couldn't have anything heavy that day for some reason), and he had the duck confit. Both were excellent, and the wine pairings were on POINT. In my crazed hastiness to get some bread from the bread basket (ok fine, I had also had a bit of wine), I accidentally knocked over my wine glass and it shattered. The waiters were so sweet about the accident- "Was there wine in it?" "No, I drank it all." "Oh good, that's the important part." I offered to clean up the mess, since I am a server at another restaurant. Of course they did not allow me to, but at the end of our meal, the waiter ran over and gave me a dollar tip. "For your services," he grinned.  Ah. I'm in love. Je vais revenir!

One imaginary teardrop rolls slowly down my right cheek! (sniffs) It is a joy experienced while simultaneously reflecting on the triumph over hardship. I'm aiming to give a glimpse of the feeling I had when I learned Patacon Pisao had finally opened in LES.The struggle:Typing 'p' 'a' 't' on my browser is automatically completed by pataconpisaonyc.com. I've gone to that site countless times with wishes not to see the neon red "Coming Soon" sign. It never happened. Then what? Feeling more adventurous and hoping I was being deceived by the website not being updated also led to me randomly jumping on CitiBikes to make the small trek to Essex, first to see where renovation was on the property, and then in hopes the place would surprise me and be open. I have no idea how many times I've made that trip with the sole purpose of grabbing a cachapa. It's a good thing I have an annual CitiBike membership. The temperature was hot, tepid, cool, cold, frigid, brisk, warm, and sweltering again. I remember doing google searches for any article that might shed some light on the magical opening date that changed over and over again. I remember peering in and seeing the long wooden bench on the side of one wall, and stainless steal metal seats on the other to match the stainless steel tabletops. I remember seeing the sign, being excited and posting a storefront picture on Yelp. I remember being equally thrilled when I saw the sign saying, "we are hiring." ...all just toying with my emotions. (sniffs again) This is bitter sweet! After over a year the time had finally come.Ahhhhhh...., it was delightful to sit in the energetic contemporarily decorated small restaurant on Essex as the nice cool breeze rushed in through the retractable front windows the other night. It's a friendly relaxed casual hip space.The staff was attentive, sociable, appreciative, pleasant, enthusiastic, and helpful with recommendations for customers (clearly I knew what I was getting).I had my fav, the La Gorda Cachapa and a ginger beer; a friend had a Shredded Beef Patacon and Jarritos, while we both shared some tequenos (cheese wrapped in dough).As expected, everything was great just as I recalled it always being on all my other visits to Patacon Pisao in Inwood and Elmhurst. Both, the Shredded Beef Patacon and La Gourda Cachapa, were certified by my Colombian friend who has eaten both on many occasions while visiting Colombia (Colombian names differ). I think that lends more cred to the food at Patacon Pisao than I can, considering I was just recently introduced to Colombian and Venezuelan food.Cachapas: sweet corn bread like cake sandwichesPatacons: hardened and flattened green plantain sandwichesArepas: white corn meal patties...lots of flavor regardless!The tequenos are extremely popular at the Inwood location and should be tried with the lightly spiced pink sauce. They also have several ethnic flavored drinks to go along with the experience.The neighborhood spot has great tasting food not found anywhere else in the area and should be a hit. You would be doing yourself a huge favor to go check them out. Lastly, please read the warning below.Disclaimer: I am not held responsible for unwanted weight gain and irresponsible consumption of frequent large amounts of food from 139 Essex.

I HAVE FOUND MY CHEAP ASIAN FOOD OPTION!! :)great lunch specials at $8 for appetizer AND entree 12-4p daily. happy hour- sapporo $3, cocktails $8, wine $5. portions are very generous if not the same as the regular hour menu. imagine my surprise when all the food came out.i usually don't care for asian fusion - or asian combo whatever. however, obao proved me wrong. we came here with his family and since it was packed, we decided to sit at the bar. to order:pad thai!!!!!!!!!!!! :) i love pad thai, don't fault me. it comes with shrimp!! pho bo - light broth w/ tons of fresh beef. amazing portions. singapore lak sa - delicious, unique, a little spicy. creamy w/o being overwhelming. great portion of shrimpmixed veggies - nicely sauteed and a good mix w/ all the other orders as a palate cleanser. again, meal comes w an appetizer (i have to stress this.. $8 for an entree and app!!) .. grilled japanese eggplant - lightly grilled w/ bright flavors while retaining eggplant textureobao salad - peanut sauce is delicioussteamed dumplings tofu... this was a GREAT meal .. great price. the bartender smiled at us and said, "great deal for lunch huh?" when we left... YES OF COURSE! will be back!

Please do not visit On the Rocks. Please don't find yourself walking into this tiny hole-in-the-wall and have your jaw drop at their overwhelmingly, mind-numbingly, ridiculously long list of whiskeys, scotches, bourbons, rye and other spirits of all forms. Please also don't find yourself speechless when you realize that dozens upon dozens of (bottled) beers are also available at this establishment but ignore it completely because just attempting to fathom such a comprehensive selection of alcohol would make your brain explode.Please don't open up their Odyssean liquor menu and begin to salivate as your eyes dart through the list, taking you on a mental world tour of whiskey. Please don't, after much careful deliberation, choose your beverage and please don't patiently await as it's poured for you. Please don't clink your glass with your fellow patrons before taking a swig at the sweet nectar of the gods as you savor every moment while it passes through your lips and down your throat. Please don't enjoy that pure and simple, timeless pleasure at On the Rocks.Please don't engage in conversation with the bartenders and ask them for recommendations with a little help from their encyclopedic knowledge of spirits. Please don't hear about their favorite selections on shelf and certainly don't order one so you can try it out for yourself. And please don't begin to plan your next visit back here from the very moment you step outside (or just wish you never left to begin with).And finally, please don't let this place become anything other than the quintessential "hidden gem" and the gold standard that all whiskey bars should strive to in terms of drink selection, low-key atmosphere, and knowledgeable bartenders. Please do all these things that I ask - nay, implore - from you so my next visit to On the Rocks is just as fantastic as my last.

AT LAST! I've seriously stalked Beauty & Essex for months before visiting. I knew this would be the perfect place for my birthday. It started out as a bookmark back in January, then I obsessively came back to yelp to read updated reviews. I'd ask everybody I came across if they've visited, and I went as far as visiting weeks before my reservation. Yep, it was that real.But I loved EVERY minute of my experience here. When I passed the pawn shop area and I walked into the venue, my initial thought was: Fancy. It's absolutely beautiful, I can't begin to describe the decor. It's just something you have to go and see for yourself. I will say, the woman's bathroom is it's own little lounge. Comfortable seating, a powder mirror, and champagne bar makes for the "Best Public Restroom Award." (Yelp should let us vote for these type of awards).As for the food, of course it was delicious. I like that it's a tapas kind of place. Our waitress told us the small plates are meant to be shared, but we both wanted different orders. I ordered the grilled cheese and tomato soup dumplings, lobster mac & cheese and a Beauty Elixir. I planned on ordering more, but I was way too stuffed. My boyfriend ordered their fancy schmancy burger with bbq dusted fries. Everything was on point.I already saved the date to come back. But this time I will brunch it out.

first and foremost...loved the service!the decor - beautiful...sleek and simple...and next to Central Park..what more do you want?It was my boyfriend who wanted to come here and i am not a big seafood fan and this is obviously one...i was bit pissed...lol duh....we ended up choosing a 4 course meal...sorta? I got Appetizer - Grilled Octopus Pasta - Calamari Risotto with eggplantMain Course - Seared scallops with mushroom pureeDessert - AffogatoGrilled Octopus - lightly seasoned, slightly burnt outside but JUST A BIT soft raw inside...perfect texture of the bounce and tender. i have to admit...it was not a sight to look at! it was black and the potatoes didnt help! but the sauce...great balance for the the burntnessrisotto - not one of my favorite...the risotto was cooked right but i think it lacked just a bit of seasoning and maybe im not used to that rich of risotto...didnt find much of the calamari and the eggplant gave it a weird taste (thats just me)scallops - They were delicious!!! cooked just right and melted like butter!! salted but not to the point i needed a starch to balance it out...the mushroom puree was a bit oversalted. The scallops were big piece and i was full after for sure!dessert - if you had to choose one from the dessert...choose this! sweet and bitter...a great way to end a meal that was all about balance! boyfriend had choose a fruit dessert and he tried to steal mine!overall, the whole experience was great...service was great (our server recommended a great white wine for me since they didnt have the type i like) and the meal was great....definitely need to set 2-3 hours aside for this dining experience

Great little corner spot with EVERY magazine known to man. Reasonably priced. Now serving breakfast and lunch (bagels etc). Sodas, beer, snacks, coffee. I continue to come here for necessities because a) the location is convenient and b) the men working there are so gosh darn friendly! They keep the "cozy neighborhood deli/bodega feel" in check.

Okay people, take a seat and listen up! I am like a little kid going to the dentist when it comes to hair salons. Finding new salons scare the pants off of me.1-Because I have a black streak birthmark in my hair (that literally every hair stylist says to me they have never seen before) which can turn orange or break off easily so the color that one uses must be top of the line2-Colorists tend to never know EXACTLY what you want. It doesn't matter how many pictures or explanations you give them, they always tend to mess it up. Fact.3-I hate getting my hair done and on the phone hear the dreadful "____$ and UP" and then you get done with your hair and it's like 4x the amount you thought it would be and you just had a not-so-great experience at the salon but leave spending like...rent money there.I just moved back to NYC from Miami, where, the salons weren't exactly "the best". I did find one or two that I "liked" but didn't LOOOOOOOOOVE. I haven't had an "oh wow my hair looks da bomb" moment in many many many many many x1000 years.I did my research extensively online. I tend to stick with Aveda salons because the color works great for my hair. However, I wanted to get my hair done Saturday morning and all Aveda salons were booked. I did some googling and found an article on Racked about Whistle. Then I came to my trusted Yelp to verify this article and alas, saw the heavenly Yelp reviews. I called exactly when they opened at 10:00 am on Saturday morning and asked to get an appointment for a half a head of highlights and a blow-dry. She said "$100 AND UP". The dreadful words. I was like ughhhh, fine. I'll go in and try it.Eric was my colorist and even though I read on the website he is an apprentice or something (which made me so skeptical because of my previous experiences), I still decided to be brave and give it a shot. I explained to him that countless times before I have told colorists I want my hair "blonde blonde" only to be left with ashy dirty blonde hair. He said he would make me golden and he would definitely do his best.UMMMMMMMMMM drum roll please...this freakin' salon rocks. Like, what? My hair came out the best it's EVER looked. My blonde goldy locks look PERFECT. I was like staring in the mirror today trying to find SOMETHING...ANYTHING wrong with my hair and I can't.find.anything.wrong. This is DEFINITELY going to be my go-to spot. He did a ridiculous job and how much was it for the "$100 AND UP" service you ask? Half a head of highlights + included blow-dry?$100.Go.To.Them.Now!

**Dinner tasting menu review, FALL 2014*I had a friend come into town and of course, he wanted to try a Daniel Boulud restaurant. With only a couple days ahead of time, we were able to secure a spot for two at Cafe Boulud, thankfully, at 9:30pm. At 9:30pm, this place is still very bustling! Our table had a 45+ min delay which was one of the few downsides, so we hung out at Bar Pleiades next door.We were seated side by side by the wall, allowing us to people watch while we ate our dinner. We were probably the youngest people there. Decor of the restaurant is lovely, but I will say that towards the end of the night, the very powerful heater kicked on and I was literally sweating just sitting still because it was so hot and uncomfortable. Not enjoyable at all, but by that point at least we were ready to leave.We did the $125/pp tasting menu with a few drinks in between as recommended by the waiter. Best decision ever. I LOVED the fact that instead of bringing us both the same dishes every course, we each got a different one. Essentially, a 7 course tasting menu turned into 10+ and I was beyond ecstatic. I'm not sure if this is always the case, so I would check with the waiter first.I'm not going to go into detail about each dish, but they were all tasteful and well worth the price, especially since you basically get to taste the menu if you go as two. Notables:- Olive bread - you get to choose out of multple kinds on tray, but the olive bread is for sure the tastiest.- Amuse bouche - everything was delicious - chef's choice of 3- NZ Venison - never had anything like this before and the oats/seasoning on this is just absolutely amazing- Chestnut veloute - oh my god.- Dessert - all of it.Service was of course amazing and the waiter made sure to explain each and every dish we got and even stuck around to chit chat when we had questions about the food or wine. Staff is quite knowledgable on the dishes and drinks.If I return to Cafe Boulud and do a la carte, my go-tos would be the foie gras, chestnut veloute, vension, and Marrakesh delight (seasonal dessert, but the thyme creme brulee was good as well).

Like Lorey Y., I've been entrusting my styling and hair health to Ray for years. I've stayed with him through various high-end boutique salons, and will happily follow him wherever he goes.Why? Because I have notoriously hard-to-cut hair....and can count on one hand how many stylists have done my head justice throughout my entire lifetime. I'm also getting older....and thinner on top.Not only did Ray bring my hair to health, he has kept it there all these years, and has made adjustments to help compliment me as I age. I always leave feeling and looking more youthful, very refreshed, and have a grand time laughing and chatting through every sitting. And, man oh man, can this gent give one grand head massage!I've also sent various managers from my office to him. All have different hair types, and all were thoroughly pleased. The most impressive was a female manager who received a horrid cut & dye job. Ray saved her! She looked stunning after he was done working his magic, with people complimenting her left and right.You'll be in good hands, folks.

Beads of sweat are rolling down your cheek. Thoughts of panic are racing through your mind. You hastily run through the items from a mental checklist you've swiftly strung together. First, remember to add the garnish. Second, wipe off the excess drops of sauce that eagerly dripped from your ladle and splashed onto the barren white plate that is your canvas. Time is quickly running out and before you know it, you're down to the last few seconds of the clock. Boom. Time is up.Clearly, if you can crank out amazing dishes under intense pressure, you can only begin to imagine the quality plates Top Chef Season 1 winner Harold Dieterle can assemble under ample time. Shortly after his win, he opened Perilla located in the West Side. Despite its rampant growth in popularity, Perilla has remained modest. The decor strays from opulence and is instead enhanced with tasteful simplicity. The lighting is resplendent and brilliantly golden. Altogether, Perilla presents a very charismatic and handsome atmosphere. Perilla has a menu full of fine, fresh American fare. The ingredients are heavily dependent on what is locally available and thus, the menu seasonally changes. The menu clearly reflects Dieterle's love affair with Asian ingredients. The menu is embellished with vibrant asian notes: basil, kimchi, black sesame, and bok choy. A separate menu was created for New York Restaurant Week 2014. Steamed Mussels are the perfect appetite primer. They are steamed and tossed in rings of sautéed yellow onions. The mussels are topped with a coarse mixture of garlic bread crumbs for a satisfying texture and bathed in a creamy stock. Minuscule pieces of tasso ham are also sprinkled onto the dish for a smoky flavor. This was swiftly followed by the Roasted All Natural Chicken (26). This features a thick slab of chicken breast served over a bed of pearl barley. The skin was perfectly salted and crispy, the breast was oozing with au jus. This entree playfully incorporates the flavors of roasted peaches, coriander, cumin and fresh chilies. All desserts are designed by Laura Jackson. The Panna Cotta unites an eclectic combination of flavors: lime, jalapeños, and gooey melted caramel. It is adorned with cereal-like puffs of amaranth for a delightful crunch. My favorite element of the dessert was the sweet sorbet that was transformed from watermelon juice. Perilla's wine list is extensive! I ordered a glass of sherry, Valdespino Contrabandista Amontillado ($10). It has a deep nutty flavor with strong accents of plum. I definitely recommend this for people who enjoy fruity, concentrated, and medium dry wine.Some Pro Tips: Cards are accepted. Restrooms are a little small but well-kept. Perilla features booths that are appropriate for larger parties. There is a bar large enough to seat 10 comfortably in the first half of the restaurant. The staff was extremely welcoming and the service was spotless throughout the night.

The other night was my birthday so I reserved a table of 15 (which just also is the biggest table they have) for a big and fun Chinese AYCE (all you can eat) hot pot. A handful of my coworkers and some friends from around the neighborhood swung by for the 7:30 reservation (yes they take reservations). With that said - they do take reservations - and if you book early enough you can book out all 4 semi private rooms that can each hold about 10-15 comfortably. So think of a party of like 60 can be seated and hanging out all having a good time.Also - it's BYOB. They don't have a liquor license yet so they aren't serving alcohol - but if you feel like you want to drink - you can bring your own. Not sure if there are any liquor stores near by but if you want to bring beers, wines, liquors etc. you definitely can.The hot pot is great - all you can eat except for some premium stuff on the bottom - but really - you don't need all that. Just pick and choose what you want and you'll get everything in a timely fashion. There is usually a 2 hour time limit - but if you have a big group and if they aren't busy they won't bother you. Just make sure you know what you're getting in terms of soup bases. Just know that the spicy style is sechuan spicy with the pepper corns that have that numbing spicyness. They do have a kim chi version as well.

Not much to be said here that hasn't been said. Just a few pointers:1) Try to avoid the 9:30pm seating (it's the last bar seating) and at this point, Nakazawa-San will no longer ask if you want additional pieces after your omakase. We wanted an extra uni and toro piece but could not get 'em :(2) He also didn't ask us to pick an urchin to open up for our uni piece...I suspect this only occurs during the first seating, but am not positive.3) There is no waiting room in the restaurant, so be prepared to huddle in a corner until it's your turn.4) If you can't get a bar seat, I'd continue trying and pass on the dining room as it's very far away from the action AND Nakazawa-San only prepares the sushi for the bar diners. 5) However, if you must, try to get table #20, which is right next to the bar. Usually reserved for VIPs.Service was great - they paid extra attention to me since I was the girl on crutches #crutchlife. ALSO, Nakazawa-San is as endearing as all the other reviewers made him out to be! He dipped quickly after our omakase, not but before making himself a hand roll to snack on (approx MSRP - $18).

Holy smokes! This place isn't a typical restaurant, and there's nothing fancy about it. But don't let that fool you--this place is the bees knees. Not only is it the best food I've had in months...I've never had Persian food before, and I had no idea what I was missing. They only had 3 options the day that I visited, so I sampled (you must get samples!) of all three. I ended up going with the one that is the crowd pleaser. Did I mention it's like the cheapest meal you can get in NYC? Oh, and healthy! Some 15+ vegetables are used in these dishes.Make sure to get the garlic crunchies and yogurt on top if the cashier recommends it with the dish! You won't be disappointed.

An amazing meal. Great cocktails, incredible wine list, attentive & professional service, wonderful food. Mussels escabeche were succulent & delicate, quail superb, but the black rice with squid simply amazing; I wanted another portion to take home! We followed these 'appetizers' with the cod which was flavorful and beautifully prepared, along with the flank steak which was out of this worth. I've never had a more tender or tastier piece of meat. Well worth the visit and totally deserving of the attention it's getting.

I have to give this place five stars here's why!Pros-everything on the menu is hecka cheap! From the bagels to burgers you can get lots of items even if you had 15 bucks on you.-he actual place looks like your in a Manhattan deli or cafe very well lit and a clean place to sit in with friends just if you didn't want to go home.-they do deliver to your door and they don't expect tips they do it with a smile on their facesNo cons here all smiles and thumb up for this cheap(as in good) place!

Of all the latest plays I've seen, bedbugs!!! surprisingly has been my favorite, and on top of that, it's a musical. If you love campy, mutant musicals, this is the best of it's genre! I have never seen a show/musical where the show was bigger than the venue. The show is so good it makes the entire place seem bigger than it really is. It's hard to explain this feeling unless you see it. It was amazing. It feels like the theatre was too small to contain the energetic, flashy, and 'big' musical. But at the same time I am so happy that it's at a small theatre because the show was so up close that it made it even more amazing. I couldn't believe it is an Off-Broadway show! There were really no bad seats in the Arclight Theatre because the theatre is tiny. We sat in the second row so it felt like everything was happening right in front of us. AWESOME! I knew nothing of this play when we decided to go see it because of the 20 at 20 promotion. So glad I convinced my bf to go see the play with me. He would have never believed how good the musical is if he didn't go and see it for himself. The evil Lord Cimex completely reminded me of Dr. Frank-N-Furter from The Rocky Horror Picture Show. I loved every character. The actress who played the mad scientist Carly is an amazing singer and actress. And I totally loved Dionne Salon played by Brian Charles Rooney. I laughed through the entire show. It was the most entertaining and fun time I've had at a musical. Because of the writeup from NY Times, Critic's Pick, the show has been super popular. Bedbugs!!! continues through Oct. 26, 2014 at the ArcLight Theatre. I suggest you run to see this show before it is gone. You gotta see it!!!

This is a great date spot, beautiful ambiance, attentive and friendly staff. Ahem, good looking too. Came here on a Wednesday night for late dinner and drinks. At 10pm, the place still had a few tables and the vibe was really chill, cozy and welcoming. Good deep house playing also helps. I arrive early and didn't want to wait outside as it was blustering cold. I walked in and was greeted by a very handsome staff. He was friendly and sat me right up close to the bar. I order a Cuvee bubbly to get the warmth going. I sit at the bar for about 20 minutes waiting for the lust of my life. And while I waited, I got to chat up the staff. Everyone that works here is European, no Americans. The handsome Italian with insanely sick dimples was very kind to also charge my phone. Now that is good service. And extremely mesmerizing eye candy. My date arrives and we are moved to a table that faces the front of the restaurant. We order up a few draft beers and decided on the mezze platter ($35) which includes hummus, stuffed grape leaves, spicy feta dip, roasted eggplant and artichoke dip. This was a nice serving size for 2 and it came with plenty of pita bread. We also ordered the shrimp mezze ($15). Everything was excellent albeit a bit pricy. But remember, you are in Nolita. You're paying their rent also and feeding those models. I was told that on the weekends, it gets pretty lively and they kick up the deep house music a bit. I will definitely be back to ogle the hot staff, shake my booty a bit, nosh on some yummy tapas, and flirt to my heart's content.

My new Warby Parker glasses and I are still casually dating, but I think we're going to get a little more serious because I'm starting to really like them. I've been wearing contacts daily for more than ten years and only ordinary (i.e. sad-looking) glasses for those times right before bed and such. When those ordinary glasses broke recently, I knew that it was time to get a pair I could actually wear during the day without embarrassing myself.This location is on the smaller side, but there are also fewer customers. Frames (both prescription and sunglasses) are placed on back-lit shelves, and customers are free to try on as many pairs as they'd like. I love:1. the staff. When I was first browsing, they completely left me alone, but when I grew a bit overwhelmed with the selection (I guess my body language made it obvious?) one staff member swiftly came over and eased my anxiety and suggested frames that went well with my face. Even though I took forever in making a decision and asked at least three different staff members to pick from my top two, everyone made the experience seamless and enjoyable. 2. how easy it was to purchase frames. All prescription frames are $95 total with an option to get high-index lenses for higher prescriptions at only $30 more. They accept eyeglass prescriptions that are up to a year old, but they can also call your eye doctor or schedule you for an eye exam there for $75.3. their home try-on system. I went to the store because I live relatively close by and because I wanted to try on as many frames in as many colors as possible, but most people opt to do the home try-on. It gives people an opportunity to get up to 5 frames to try on for 5 days with free shipping both ways. The only sad thing is that some frames aren't part of the home try-on for some reason.4. the Warby Parker blog. It seems the Warby Parker team is very interested in all things literary; the most obvious clue comes from the library setup of all of their Manhattan stores, and the less obvious clue comes from their blog. They update their blog with infographics of things to read and see, and they're oftentimes very funny. I also learned that the store's name is derived from two Kerouac characters: Warby Pepper and Zagg Parker (Zagg Pepper would also have been a cool store name). 5. their buy a pair, give a pair philosophy. They make a monthly donation based on the number of glasses sold, and those funds go to training, glasses, and eye exams in developing countries. 6. their monocle (warbyparker.com/monocle).Likelihood of another visit:When these glasses break.

tl;drThis place tops everything I have reviewed. 5.5 stars.tl;dr 2If you don't read anything in my review, go to Benton on a Friday (EARLY! like before 12:30 PM) and get their Friday special chirashi. Then come back and read this review. You will know why I freaking rave about this place.----If I could give 5.5 stars, Benton gets it. No, Chez Panisse and Ippudo are nowhere close to getting 5.5 stars.What makes Benton so magical is that they make the most incredible benton boxes that I have ever tasted -- no, EXPERIENCED -- in the United States. I spent some time studying abroad in Tokyo when I was in college, and I used to drop by this bento shop after my language school classes were over at around 4:30 PM. They were still selling the leftover bento boxes from lunch at a discount, and if I'm lucky I could score a bento for just 750 yen or so and have it as a yummy dinner. Benton is the reincarnation of that neighborhood bento shop in New York City.Benton's bento boxes are REALLY TASTY. I repeat, REALLY TASTY. You are probably used to shelling out $15 for the Soba Totto or the Sakagura lunch specials. To be honest, I stopped going to Soba Totto or Sakagura for lunch altogether after I discovered Benton. Their lunch specials are just as good, for HALF THE PRICE. It's so amazing, I have no idea how they do it.Every single one of Benton's bento boxes is a carefully curated symphony of flavors - it's crazy how many contrasting tastes they can pack into one bento box - we're talking a main course, rice, plus 3-4 side dishes! The side dishes are truly the stars of the bento - for example, you might see a clump of spinach next to your katsu for lunch, but rest assured, that spinach will certainly not be the plain boiled spinach you eat at home. One day it will be lightly tossed with vinegar, the next you might find a small dallop of sesame dressing at the bottom. Some of the small dishes are simply delightful - they often make these cute little vegetable skewers (we're talking 3 inches long) and then they deep fry the whole thing and pack it into a bento for your dining pleasure. Who does that??? What do YOU eat for lunch? A box of randomly chopped vegetables that cost you $10 at Chopt? A greasy hamburger smashed together over a smoky grill with onions and tomatoes carelessly thrown on top??I really admire the dedication and the time that is simply so evident in Benton's bento boxes. Yes, they may make food "to go," but I would honestly pay double the price for sit down portions of their bentos in a restaurant. Woorijip in Ktown used to a go-to place for packed boxed meals, but I was just at Woorijip last night and it almost makes me angry that Woorijip is such a large establishment and open at all hours, while Benton is a small corner storefront in midtown that's functionally only open for lunch. I'm angry that Woorijip's food is so inferior compared to Benton, and I'm angry that Benton does not get more recognition.Anyways, just go and prepare for your mind to be blown. And it will be, if you know what good Japanese food taste like ;)IF YOU GO:-Benton has amazing (usually some form of sushi donburi) lunch specials on the weekdays. If you want to partake, please go EARLY. They are usually almost out by 1 PM and certainly out any time after that. The bento boxes luckily are not part of the special but they usually run out by 2 PM too.-Not only does Benton have amazing sushi/bentos, their cold noodle/rice bowls offerings are great too! I had the opportunity to try their bibim-noodle (like a bibimbap but with noodles, get it? :P) and their hiyashi chuka (cold noodles with sesame sauce) and both are fantastic! I also like their sauce katsu rice bowl.-They also make hot food (soba, udon, and ramen). I've actually never seen anybody order it because it probably takes some time, but you could try it if you want.-Free miso soup with purchase of bento. Make sure you ask for it! Sometimes the cashier doesn't give it to you unless you ask for it.-They have a rewards program, but it's unfortunately one of the most low-yield reward programs, to the order of something like buy 25 bentos, get 1 free. But still, better than nothing!-They're open on Saturday, but the selection is very small and looks almost like recycled Friday food (even though I'm sure it isn't). I would recommend to pass on Saturday.-They also have bread and onigiri if you don't want a bowl or a boxed lunch :)-Every meal is around $8. Seriously.This is so much text. I can't handle it. Just go. Sparknotes now:- Go on Thurs/Fri lunch and get their chirashis (Friday is better)- Try ANY of their bento boxes- Repeat. Rinse. Fall in love. TRY ALL OF THEM.I had two weeks when I was just studying for my board exams - I had Benton every single day for lunch. I was so happy. I was in love :)

If, by chance, you started a foolish quest to try each of the top 250 beers on Beer Advocate within a calendar year, The Jeffrey would be a frequent source of aid. You might encounter bottles from The Bruery, Maine Beer Co., and even, on rarer occasion, the rarest Belgians. And assuming you're sane enough not to attempt an endeavor so frustrating, the bar remains more than worth the trip. The rotating drafts run the gamut from the accessible (at the moment, Captain Lawrence's Liquid Gold) to the arcane (at the moment, Anderson Valley's The Kimmie, The Yink, and The Holy Gose), and change frequently enough to warrant stopping by more often than your wallet will appreciate. However, what propels The Jeffrey to perfection are the generous, extensive, and thoughtfully curated Growler program (not to mention the loyalty program therein (buy 9 growlers of beer, the tenth is free - after the 30th, get a personalized growler and 15% off for life)), and the fantastic lunch and happy hour specials. Lunch is a mere $10 for a happy hour brew and a sandwich or salad, and none of the food options are afterthoughts. The sandwiches are preposterously good, not in comparison to typical bar fare, but in comparison to standalone sandwich shops. Happy hour is impressive in both the breadth of hours and the depth of beer selections available. People may lament the fact that The Jeffrey is all the way up on 60th and 1st (whiners), but truthfully, the area was in need of a place so objectively great. Being far from the useless hipster masses is just a bonus.

TOP FIVE DINING EXPERIENCEBest steak I ever had, wonderful service, cool yet unpretentious atmosphere.Reservations are not easily had, let's just say they aren't on opentable and you just can't call up- if you get the number. Entering through a door next to a graffiti covered storefront, you have no idea that a Japanese steak place would be at the end of that long hallway- well, yes you do, this is New York and we all know about going through phone booths to get into bars and standing on our heads and spinning three times in front of the Statue Of Columbus to get into Thomas Keller's secret speakeasy underneath the Time Warner Center...oh you didn't know about that one- you should go try it out, let me get my camera.So getting back to Bohemian, it is small- seven tables and a bar for four. As others have pointed out on here, it is like being in someone's living room. The chairs were fine for me, people have mentioned some awkwardness in trying to eat because the chairs were too low or something but I was fine. The service was really great- all smiles all the time, very gracious, made us feel welcome. The food: me and my wife each got the short rib sashimi, the foie gras sushi, we split the smoked bacon, and split a 13 oz waygu strip loin. The first three dishes were all great, and I loved everything- but the steak was not of this earth. It literally melted in my mouth. When you get a porterhouse or a ribeye, sure there is a ton of flavor, but you get a lot of fat and crap you can't eat. Every part of this steak was eaten, there was nothing left over. And I would say that one a scale of 1 to 10, the flavor would be a 9. I've had some steaks that were 10, but again, they would be very fatty or a little chewy. So to have a touch less of that beefy flavor and have a 10 in texture- that is my idea of a perfect steak. Yours might be different, but I guarantee you will love the steak here. And at $73 for 13 oz for a high grade piece- not bad.

Detail Oriented // Artistic Hotel Delicious RestaurantWell appointed interior, beautiful, eclectic and modern designs. Love this neighborhood gem. Whether you're looking for a place to have a nice dinner date, catch up with friends, or have a business meeting this is a solid option downtown. Whether dining at the bar alone, or at a table for two, three or four. I have enjoyed my meals and conversations here. There is just enough space for privacy, and it has a cozy vibe. The fish here is delicious, yes the salmon, and their white fish, love the side options - snap peas are among my favorite. Handcrafted cocktails are superb, and the service is great as well. Though reservations can be difficult at times, it's well worth the wait if you're entertaining.The Scene: Modern, LuxeDestination Rating: 8Date Rating: 8Hob Nob Potential: 5  Note: seasonal menu, and reservations in advance. Limited bar seats on a busy night. The Chef is wonderful when it comes to avoiding food allergies.

I'm so glad a place like this opened up in my neighborhood. Affordable and convenient. Let's face it, Midtown East / Murray Hill isn't that much of a culinary destination. Nonetheless, I can get my fix of crunchy baguette bread filled with well seasoned meats. I had the pork belly and it was perfectly tender. I really liked the contrast with the crunchy vegetables too.Points also for the hoison sauce, Siracha and the red chili sauce on every table.My sandwich came to about $9 for a very generous size, both in terms of bread length and toppings. Keep in mind it's cash only (but there's an ATM inside the store). Next time I'm hungry in the hood or surfing on Seamless, I'm going to order from this place!

It's not too noticeable at first, but this is absolutely the place for ramen on a cold night. It is not expensive at all ($10-$12 for a bowl of ramen is standard and absolutely filling). The staff is also so nice and tries the best to meet everyone's needs. We had the miso ramen - which was decorated beautifully and made so quickly. Also, be sure to ask for complimentary green tea. Goes down so well with ramen.Just note - this place is fairly small (but it includes a bar set up in the front for single seaters so it's great if you're coming alone), so it's not the best place for groups, but they will always try to accommodate. They are also fairly new, so when we arrived they had run out of menus, but it wasn't much of an issue because they still had 2 left for 3 people. I really like it here and I would totally come again.

Thank you, oh sweet Beer Gods, for bestowing this heavenly brewery upon our humble neighborhood.Gun Hill Brewing Company is a shining star in the Northeast Bronx, providing us with innovative and delicious craft beers, brewed right here at a low price. $5 for a pint and $9 for a flight? You call me so sweetly.I am now officially obsessed with their Cherry Tree Ale and their oatmeal stout! The space is large, casual, and well-ventilated (can't say that for a lot of beer places) and their pretzels are tasty. There's a man selling chicken outside, too!This is a revolutionary addition to our community and it's desperately needed. Please support the brewery! It's not that bad a walk from the 5 train, and you can always take the Bx28, Bx38, or the Bx30 :]

One of my favorite spots in all of manhattan. The food is creative, delicious and very hearty. Comfort food at its finest. My favorite is the Chicken and Waffle. They have a beautifully fried chicken on top of a purple taro waffle. The best thing since spaghetti and meatballs is the beautiful carmelized coconut sauce that goes with it. It's so delicious and goes perfectly with the savory chicken and the starchy waffle. I love their blend of flavors and it satisfied the dessert sweet tooth even as you're eating your meal. I want to drink that sauce!Their tapsilog is another of my favorites. The marinated steak, the flavorful garlic rice and the egg...I just love to douse it all in the banana ketchup and shovel every bite into my mouth in happiness.The staff is always excellent and well versed in their menu, and the restaurant is hopping with a killer soundtrack always playing in the background. Be aware that it's ok to sing along to their 90's hits. I also want to note that the restaurant is small and that seating is difficult. Make reservations and make sure your party is completely intact and on time. They are strict about this and it's for good reason. They have a lot of customers and brunch is very popular and packed! I have yet to try their sister restaurant Jeepney, but I am looking forward to doing that soon. Stay tuned!

Toho Shoji is a Japanese bead/crafts store - so glad I found it! I used to buy Toho beads in Japan when I was into making things when I was younger. I got back into beading recently and found this store through Yelp - so glad I went! Everything is high quality (although more expensive than other bead stores in the area, but you can see the difference) and the people that work there are all Japanese and very helpful. This one woman helped me find what I was looking for and I was in there looking at everything for a while. Everything in the store is very organized and clean (unlike the nearby Chinese stores that are all dusty - my hands felt very dirty after going there!) and the lighting in the store is as it should be. Overall, I would definitely come back here to buy beads once I finish my current projects!**UPDATE** I've been into Toho and other bead stores in the surrounding area and have found that Toho sells the cheapest chains with the highest quality! For example, I bought a chain for a long necklace that was $0.60/ft whereas across the street at Bead Center they sold a similar chain, with cheaper quality, for $3.00/ft. I also bought a chain with an infinity link online (it didn't seem to feel like real metal, felt light and almost plastic like when compared) for a couple of cents cheaper than the infinity link chain I bought at Toho - it was shinier, had a good weight and looked more expensive, for about $1.80/ft. Toho will definitely be my go-to spot for buying all sorts of chains - they have a wider variety, are all superior in quality and have a really good price!

One of the top 5 meals I've ever had. And it wasn't even my birthday. Came here for my roommate's birthday and some friends, for the third installment of our Ron Swanson series. I set up everything through Open Table and we got seated upstairs, near the window, which had a really nice view. The overall atmosphere is very lively, and we were glad that we were placed at a table that was a little less loud. My friends thought I had planned the table placement, but I'll never tell. Anyways, we started off with some drinks, and our server was very chatty and great with recommendations. I went with a Lagavulin, neat, just like Ron Swanson would. Delicious and smokey, and just the right start to our meal.My friends and I each ordered our own steaks and I ordered the sides for the table. We got the mushrooms, potatoes au gratin, creamed spinach, cauliflower, and skillet potatoes. It was crazy because a flock of waitresses came out with the sides and distributed them to our plates for us. My favorite sides were the cauliflower and the spinach. Cauliflower was roasted perfectly and the spinach wasn't too mushy and actually had some texture with all of that cream. All the sides were great, except I probably wouldn't order the skillet potatoes again, because it was like ordering homemade potato chips, which were good, but not $14 good. That being said, out of all of the steakhouses I've been to in New York, the sides at Del Frisco's, as a whole, are probably the best I've ever had. I ordered the prime porterhouse, which was prepared at just the right temperature, and well-seasoned. I tried my friend's ribeye as well, which was delicious, but a bit on the fatty side. But yeah, the steak was great, as expected, and everyone was too happy to talk for awhile. Our waiter kept checking in on us and told us stories about NFL Draft prospects coming in that day (the day before the NFL Draft) and being too scared to order nice things. Those kids. They'll learn soon enough.The waiter caught wind that it was my roommate's birthday and surprised us with a complimentary wedge of lemon cake, which was enormous and delicious. The cake itself was moist, and the frosting had a bit of tang and wasn't too overwhelming. We had to loosen a few belt buckles, but we didn't feel disgusting afterwards, which was great. Overall, an impeccable experience at Del Frisco's. I'll definitely recommend it to anyone looking for a great steak experience in the city.

Come here if you want to listen to some good old hip hop music.Come here if you want to escape the EDM crazed New York City.Come here if you want delicious asian fusion food ranging from porkbuns, to delicious salt and pepper squid (highly recommended).Come here if you want to dance with a bunch of strangers doing your stupid prom moves.Come here if you just want to enjoy the game.Come here if you like cute awesome bartenders (yes you Shannon)!Come here if you want 6-9pm happy hour specials that's unheard of in New York.Come here if you want to casually bump shoulders with the actual owner of the place!Most importantly come here if you want a just want a great time with some great people!TIP: There are cover friday and saturday nights. Lines do get long but not until really late (12pm/1am). Bartenders are awesome to hangout with and talk to if you want early enough. Enjoy!

I stumbled upon this place while wandering around on Greenwich Avenue in the West Village.Saikai (formerly Shuka dining bar) is an Izakaya Japanese restaurant that serves small plates of tapas, grilled dishes, salads and rice/noodle creations. The menu reflects the classic and contemporary Japanese cuisine.The Mizuna Shirasu salad was very delicious. It had Mizuna greens, Shirasu (dried baby anchovy), dried baby shrimp, cream cheese and nikiri soy. The salty and sweet flavors blend beautifully with the natural flavor of Mizuna. I was told by the manager that it was one of the chef's best dishes.I chose the Yakitori Tasting from the menu which was the chef's selection of 5 assorted organic chicken skewers. Each skewer came with a different flavor that suited my sake (Tip: Take it easy on sake! It can rack up the bill.)I capped the night with complimentary sorbet. Although they are still revising their menu (soft opening), I can tell that this place is very promising and I look forward in coming back pretty soon.

If you want a guaranteed great night out, this is a place that consistently delivers. Employees Only certainly has a lot going for it. Nice looking bartenders who serve up a fantastic selection of drinks and craft cocktails, good food, a warm atmosphere, and a stellar playlist of 80's throwbacks. I've found this place also draws in a lively bunch of friendly folks, which is a huge plus in my opinion. We've never been here and not met some cool friendly people to chat with.
