They've also been consistent with airport pickups, and if anything are just 10 minutes behind schedule, which I don't mind.Friendly drivers who respect your privacy and never talk too much, always a plus in my book.

When you come here, I think there are a couple things that you have to take for granted: you're going to spend a lot of money, and there is no way you're going to spend an amount that feels a bit high. At least that was my reaction once we got seated in ZZ's, which has a very speakeasy feel to it. You have 9 seats at 4 tables, and another 4 seats along the wall - and that's it. I'm pretty sure a reservation is required regardless of how many people are inside, just given the fact that you have a guy wearing a suit standing in front of the door with (what I presume is) a list of names and spots available - so don't plan on wandering through Greenwich Village to end up here. The service is quick and pretty simple; there are a couple of waiters who bring your dishes as they are prepared. You have music playing at a decent volume in the background, though, so this doesn't come off as a true speakeasy - there were times when I felt the volume the 8 or so of us were generating is more than would be tolerated at a place that really keeps an ear out for the volume.ZZ's, although it calls itself a clam bar, is really more generally focused on seafood - only a few of the menu items are clams (or clam-based). It also focuses on the cocktails, all of which (at least according to the waitress) are original concoctions. The vast majority are based on fruit flavors, and the two that we had (Mango and Strawberry) were delicious. In particular, the mango flavor blended seamlessly with the bourbon to create a drink with a little bite, but not overwhelmingly so, and the giant ice cube that sits in the middle helps to temper the drink as it melts. The strawberry is also really good, with the light flavor of the berry providing a gentle overtone to whatever alcohol was used as the base (I forget what it was), with an herbed finish.The real star, though, has to be the food. I think it's pretty easy to blanche on first glance at the menu - every single menu item is over $15, with some running as high as $100(!) - very expensive, considering that everything here is pretty much an appetizer-style dish, not an entree. If you want to stick with oysters and clams, those are pretty standard price ($3 a pop or so, on average). Before we ordered, we were served an amuse bouche of clam flatbread, which was just so damn phenomenal we asked the waitress if there was any way we could order it (it's not on the menu, and the answer was no - apparently everyone asks). I usually like my flatbreads relatively plain, but the clam had an interesting smoky flavor, and the amount of cheese was just right - creating a bite that makes you wonder how you can get more. Of the other dishes we ordered, I would absolutely recommend two the ones we had: the tuna carpaccio and the cherry trout crudo. I'd love to try the other carpaccio some time (that one comes with beef and caviar), but the tuna is breathtakingly delicious. You have a circle of fresh tuna that's been pounded into thin slices, covered in foie gras and bone marrow and topped off some chives. It is so good - the double whammy of fatty goodness that the foie and marrow provide brings out the richness of the tuna flavor. Plop it on a piece of toasted brioche toast that comes with it, and you have a dish that will make you nearly forget about the rest of the meal. The cherry trout is served up with trout roe and fried leeks. The trout itself is absolutely delicious - very good flavor - but the roe helps provide dashes of saltiness that helps enhance the dish. The leeks also add additional texture and a dash of greasiness that works really well. The golden eye snapper is not as succulent, but the firmness of the fish is a nice change of texture, and it pairs really well with the strawberry (I think?) garnish on top. The uni toast is decadent, as anything with uni should be; I liked the pretzel bread that was used - gives it a bit of an NY feel to the dish. The seared scallop was really good as well - the scallops is sliced up thinly in the shell, but compared to the other dishes, it doesn't quite stand out as much. The oysters (we got 2 of everything) were very good. All are East Coast, so don't expect anything too sweet, but the oysters from freshwater rivers were very interesting - a much more neutral taste than those that came from elsewhere. We finished the meal with key lime pie - a bit overpriced at $15, but immaculately prepared. With a firm crust on bottom, a key lime filling that bites with pinches of sweet tartness, and what looks like a slightly baked meringue on top, it's a classy - and delicious - way of finishing off a phenomenal meal.Yes, this place is expensive - so don't come here if you don't want to overspend a little. But the originality of the place, the decor, and the high quality of the dishes served, makes this a place not to be missed. It's not anything like an Upstate, where the focus is on the mollusks - but it's a spectacular experience in its own right.

Lovely Literary Collection + Good Reading SuggestionsCozy Intimate, Fantastic Lending LibraryI could hear the voice of someone lecturing in the back room as I perused the store looking at books. Classes, workshops, literary discussion groups. Something about The Center For Fiction felt magical. The lending library seemed to have a robust list of fantastic titles, and the librarian I spoke with seemed quite knowledgeable. Definitely worth paying their membership fees to have access to the entire facility. Would recommend to friends.The Scene: Top Notch, Bibliophiles, Writers, Lit Lovers and MoreDestination Rating: 7 Date Rating: 3 (8 if they're interested in fiction)Hob Nob Potential: 2 (8 if you attend a workshop)Strong Suggestion: If you like reading, stop on by! Make sure you have enough time to take it all in.

This place is amazing. Think Texas bbq meets a burrito. Maybe I just ordered the exact right thing. I've been know to do that. Got a burrito w half brisket half antelope (smoked antelope was their special of the week). Both were awesome with a nice smoked flavor - the antelope reigned supreme - I think the other "stuff" like jalapeños and tomato baste it was sitting in added so much flavor. There does end up being a lot going in with the burrito once u soup it up, but that's your choice. I'd recommend the guacamole, corn (and perhaps squash) add-on for a dollar. Plus some cheese. Cost me 11.50 but I got way more meat than at a chipotle and it tasted way better and something unique.A few operational suggestions for management:* your water dispenser is very slow - perhaps this is deliberate to steer patrons towards soda etc. If so, that's genius* the wrapper on burrito is put on inside out - i believe the foil should be on the outside, and the paper should be on the inside. And now you owe me a free burrito.

We wanted our first day as a married couple to be special, so instead of flying to Tokyo for sushi, we made a reservation at Sushi Nakazawa. The reservation system is a bit elusive, with only 10 bar seats-- more likely than not you will be sitting at a table out of sight of the famed Jiro Ono apprentice. We got lucky though and got to sit right in front! =)The atmosphere is inviting. There was classical music playing in the background (albeit a little loud), modern decor with a granite counter top, even the swivel bar stools had leather arms and a back. The spacing between diners was great--- hands down the most comfortable sushi bar experience I've ever had.Nakazawa-san is in a league of his own. He has this magnetic personality that you would not expect from a high end sushi chef. Most NYC sushi chefs are grumpy-- I don't mind since I respect their craft and their food-- but Nakazawa-san's laugh is intoxicating and he has a really good sense of humor. His English is also surprisingly good. I'm not sure if its a result of his time spent in Seattle but we were able to have a coherent conversation and you could tell he was enjoying the interaction and not annoyed by it. Love it.There is no menu. It's $150/pp Omakase all the way. There is a long drink menu but I recommend just going with the $40 sake pairing. You get 6 glasses of sake with 12? (I lost count because I ended up ordering 5 or 6 pieces on top) pieces of Nigiri and a Toro handroll for $190 before tax/tip. Each additional piece of Nigiri cost about $8/piece. Expected, so no sticker shock here. The Sushi is great! I've written so much about the experience it's hard not to write about the Sushi. I started out with two pieces of Alaskan Wild Salmon, One smoked one not smoked. I was expecting these a little further down the line with the usual white fish first but it made no difference. You'll notice that he chooses quite a few Northwest fish for his lineup. WA Geoduck, Alaskan King Salmon, etc. Then came the Chard, Mackarel, Hamachi, etc etc etc. The pieces that really stand out are the smoked and pickled pieces. It's all technique here fellas-- the flavors and textures are complex so you'll end up sitting there trying to compare it to something you've had before. I couldn't put my finger on some of them and I just love that feeling of experiencing something new.  The scallop is such a crowd pleaser-- a little sea salt on top, some citrus and a little poof in your face jalapeno burn with the delicate crunch of fresh scallop. yum yum. The toro, uni is what you expect-- ridiculously good although he does not crack the uni open from the shell anymore. The meal was perfect. I even bumped into Alex, the owner on our way out. He was personable and took a picture for us outside the restaurant. If you can swing it-- I highly recommend you give Nakazawa a try!

I know I am not supposed to do this (anti-Yelp policy), but...It is like a torrid love affair that you are carrying on and it is explosive and mind-blowing. You want to tell everyone about it, but you can't, the wife will be heartbroken, the husband devastated. This is what I feel when I think about this place. A neighborly place where everybody knows each other, which is cool since we live in a city of 9 million strangers. Excellent fish tacos, and pretty kickass nachos. They have 2 draft beers which include UFO and Harpoon's IPA. Do not miss the spicy watermelon margaritas. Overall, a great night with great friends, and awesome Jane Fonda as Barbarella on-screen. Couldn't have asked for a better Saturday night!

This place is one of the best soup dumplings in the city. Basically, they serve soup dumplings- dumplings with soupy broth and a meatball inside. Upon initial bite, the soup oozes out of the dumpling and the flavors explode in your mouth. The meatball inside is soft and the dumpling's outer layer is soft as well. The whole dumplings consist of higher quality ingredients. It's competitor, more popular, is Joes Shanghai. Joes is very good as well and vastly famous for their soup dumplings; but I'm confident to say Shanghai Café has better soup dumplings. They dumplings are more flavorful. The dumplings were so kind, I felt so loved, they were good to me.

Fun! I'm so glad I did this - thanks to Yelp's 2013 Bucket List! Sort of a surreal experience, flying through the middle of the air through Manhattan, towards the bridge, and then over the river. Definitely offers a different view of the city - and it's definitely a must-do.Logistics: Not too crowded in the early afternoon on a summer Monday. We got on for free (xfers from taking the subway) which I was pleasantly surprised about. No AC to speak of - but once we were moving the breeze came through and it wasn't too bad. When you get off the tram on Roosevelt Island you'll see an adorable little building surrounded by plants & flowers. Go to here immediately. Inside, there will be a lady who is so friendly & kind that she will restore your faith in humanity. You can buy souvenirs, water, postcards, and get a map of the island. Also, when you put your phone down to dig your wallet out of your bag & subsequently leave it there, she will notice. She will hold onto it for you. She will call your dad & explain that his daughter left her phone at the Visitor's Center on Roosevelt Island (like a moron).When you sheepishly come back for your phone, she will say "I called your dad, I hope that's okay". And she will have made your trip to Roosevelt Island completely worthwhile, and even make you want to return someday.

THE BEST lobster roll ANYWHERE. $17 gets you a delicious lobster roll (with mayo.. you can request without with no trouble) on a buttery, toasted potato bun, a bag of kettle-cooked chips and some of the best soda I have ever had. That's saying a lot because I DO NOT drink soda-- carbonation bugs my nose. I'd recommend the blueberry soda. 3 out of 4 times I am here, my boyfriend and I get a third roll to split because it is so darn delicious. This is also probably the only restaurant we don't really speak at while eating because we're relishing in the deliciousness of our food so much. I wish I was joking. If you don't want chips and the soda, the roll itself will cost you $15. They also offer shrimp rolls, crab rolls, grilled cheese, and they have great soup. TIP: The ceramic lobster claws on the tables are filled with old bay seasoning (I believe that's what it is called). If you don't see any claws ask the guy behind the counter for it. It will take your roll from outstanding to "can't-talk-so-delicious".

They say the way to a man's heart is through his stomach; the way to mine is through my feet. Unfortunately, I have to pay people to touch them, as those that love me refuse. (Bunions, hammertoe, crepitus, and arthritis are NOT contagious, y'all.)The experience at ShunFa is worth every penny, and there aren't many needed to cover this unbelievable $25/hour transportive experience. This isn't just a rub of the feet - this is real reflexology, where they hit pressure points that seem to be felt in other areas. (No, not there.)No frills is an understatement: you open the door, and you're instantly in a room smaller than most Manhattan bedrooms. All the action is happening right before your eyes in three big, comfy black leather chairs. While your feet receive pleasure, you will hear sirens and traffic, listen to phone conversations as the receptionist schedules appointments (which are recommended, especially on a weekend), and feel the wind blow every time the door opens, but you won't even care. ShunFa-cking amazing.

Piora is the brain child of Chef Chris Cipollone and restaurateur Simon Kim (formerly of the Tenpenny and the Mark, respectively). Since its opening just 11 days ago, it has already stirred up quite a buzz in town. I'm shocked that no one on Yelp has reviewed Piora yet!Piora is Korean for "blossom," as evidenced by the gorgeous flower mural on the wall by Stephanie Goto (of Aldea and Corton). [When I mentioned how gorgeous the space was, our server immediately began to gush about Ms. Goto. You trained them well, Piora, love it!] Also, most of the food served is Italian with French and Korean influences - interesting!Greeted by the cheerful hostess, we were led past "the Foyer" (bar area) to an intermediate space with only three stool-seating tables. The glass panels enclosing the space provided a more private, intimate environment compared to the open, main dining area in the back. There's also a lush, outdoor garden patio that our server, Joe, assured us will be opened soon.Their menu is divided into six sections in the hopes that you'll order a dish from each. Between the two of us, we only ordered four dishes (not including dessert) to share, so for the average two persons, five to six plates should be reasonable.The amuse bouche of watermelon with mint and pistachio was the first to the table. It was very simple, and there was no cohesion between the ingredients. But the watermelon was perfectly ripe and crispy and the mint was fresh.The six pieces of monkey bread sat snugly in a scalding, black, rectangular skillet. Each piece fit comfortably in the palm of your hand. The bread was not the least bit gooey or overly sweet; it was light and fluffy with a hint of butter, topped with a thin layer of salt. The bread also came with seaweed butter and whipped lardo, presented on unwieldy marble coasters. By itself or slathered on the bread, they were both incredibly delicious.The scallops with sweet corn, chanterelle, and crispy chicken skin was a creative, fancy twist to Southern comfort food. The scallops (two pieces) were cooked just right, with an even, charred layer. I was delighted that they used my favorite part of chicken (crispy skin) to counterbalance the soft corn kernels and creamy corn puree.I have no words for the rigatoni with red wine, duck sausage, spigarello, and charred fig, except that you MUST get it. Each bite contained bursts of flavor from the fragrant fennel in the duck sausage (reminiscent of star anise in Taiwanese braised pork on rice, or lu rou fan), the full-bodied red wine, and sweet fig. The complexity of this dish was outstanding!In the ocean trout with cauliflower, pear, and nduja dish, Chef Cipollone let the perfectly cooked ocean trout speak for itself. It was moist and flakey, where the sweetness of the pear quietly enhanced the flavor of the trout. But it was the plating of the dish that impressed me. If you look carefully, it appears to be an aerial view of the bottom of a lake with a large rock, drifting seaweed, and small pebbles. Absolutely stunning.While service was a bit shaky as the servers and bus boys were still grasping the ropes (Joe was lovely though!), they will surely learn quickly as Mr. Kim was personally checking in on each table the night we were there. The prices are on the higher end, but the food is absolutely worth it; it is such a rarity these days to find a restaurant in which every dish is thought-out carefully and executed flawlessly. Piora will be the next big restaurant and Cipollone/Kim is definitely a team you want to follow!---Notes:- We sadly had to skip dessert, but they have a peach shaved ice and strawberry shortcake with yuzu I definitely want to try.- The entire menu is posted on their website. The barbecued octopus in gochujang with basil, pine nuts, and red pepper flakes also sounded amazing - next time, for sure.

So this was my first time back in about four years. I had one dinner here that I found oddly lacking for all of the hype that was swirling about. Fast forward, and I find myself with a group of friends who all rabidly want to try this place for the first time. Reluctantly I joined, or should I say, fortunately I gave it another shot.This time, I found the food to be much more focused. Numerous courses had flavors that were very sharp, unlike my prior muddled experience filled with bland or muddled dishes. Of course, they also included some of the classics like the smoked egg and the shaved foie gras. It's about 10 courses, and a pretty reasonable amount of food (though you might be a bit hungry afterwards if you are anything like me). On the plus side, unlike many of the other double digit tasting menus I have tried, they keep the dishes moving--since they do two seatings a night, we were in an out in exactly two hours (this might be a good thing or a bad thing depending on what you want to get out of a tasting menu at this price point).The staff was super friendly and accommodating. I definitely plan on coming back much more frequently than my prior four year hiatus.PS: The highlight of the night had to be the 20-something girl walking in and asking for a takeout menu. When she was told it was strictly a reservation-only tasting menu kind of restaurant, she insisted that she would be fine with just taking out a few of the courses. Fortunately we were seated near the door and heard this whole exchange, so much laughter ensued.

I almost don't want to write a review for Shigure because I want to keep it a hidden gem forever, but a place like this really deserves some good press. One of my friends discovered it recently and brought me + 7 others here on a quadruple date. Since there were so many of us and everything on the menu looked interesting, we ordered two of everything. I've never tried everything at a restaurant before, so I can't say this for any other place, but I can definitely declare that everything on Shigure's menu was delicious! My favorites were the washugyu tataki and the duck chashu, but really you can't go wrong with any dish. They also have an extensive selection of sake and though I'm not a connoisseur, the bottle my friend ordered was very smooth and paired well with our food. The space is open with high ceilings and it's great for two people or a large group like ours. Highly recommend.

I was ready to try a new sauna/bath (one of my favorite things), and Juvenex was on the list. It is definitely pricier than the $35 Russian bathhouse, but you're getting a much bigger treatment package. For $115, you do their saunas (dry, steam, and soaking tub) plus a body scrub, hair wash, and facial. I phoned up a coworker, made our appointments and off we went!It took a while to find this place, but once you're inside, you feel like you've stepped to another world. Everything is warm and curvy and natural and lovely! The girl behind the counter was beyond nice. She showed us to the locker "room" (it's really just a general changing area with a half-wall) and was waiting with robes, towels, and cucumber water for us after we got in our suits.Speaking of suits, I think you can go in the buff during the day (women-only hours), but everyone was wearing a suit. First up, dry sauna: This was my favorite. Not the hottest I've ever been in, but way more zen! It was like a stone igloo. It was dark, and had an herbal scent. Lying on the bench, I felt like I was back in the womb!Next, soaking tub: Probably my least favorite. The water was an ok temperature, but I had thought it would be mega hot, like the osen tubs I've read about. This was like a tepid bath. There were lemons floating in the water, which was nice. On to the steam room: I liked this room. It was like a little greenhouse (without the plants). The ceiling was peaked, and the whole room was plastic, instead of marble. Very cool vibe. The heat was good too. Like the dry sauna, it had an herbal thing going on. The scent was nice; more noticeable in the wet heat. After about 15 minutes in each room, two ladies told us it was time for our scrub. We were brought into a side room, and realized we were going to get scrubbed together (same room, separate tables). So now I'm naked and hanging out with my naked coworker. Luckily, we're buddy buds, but if you want to do a spa day with your new mother-in-law, you might want to ask for separate rooms!We get on our tables, nude and giggling. I'm waiting for them to drape a towel over me, but it never happened. You are fully exposed the whole time. Then, I waited for them to get the body scrub mixture---usually a sugar or salt slurry. Nope. They use mega intense mitts. Commence scrubbing! This was not zen. It was militant! At one point my knees were over my ears while I was scrubbed in oh-so-unexpected places. Most hysterical part: We were turned on our sides, and I made a point of ensuring we were back to back. My logic was this way my coworker wouldn't have me staring at her ass. I did not consider that eventually we'd both be on our OTHER sides. Which meant we were now facing each other, naked and getting scrubbed, and trying not to crack up--especially when our legs were being lifted and stretched. While we were on the table, we also got our hair wash and facials. Both were kind of abrupt, but appreciated!So, I could see someone disliking this experience, bcs you're exposed and getting manhandled. But really, it was so insanely fun(ny) and my skin is so incredibly soft now. So I have to say it was 100% worth it!We got to relax in the sauna again after our treatment, and we were offered complimentary tea and fruit. I can't say it enough: the service was top notch. I would definitely recommend checking out Juvenex. Just be sure to get a good sense of what the treatments entail before you go!

Holy Jesus! How have I never been to Barney Greengrass in my 9 years in New York?! This place is right out of the movies. Cash only on the weekend, old New York style, surly waitstaff, and the best smoked fish that has ever danced on my palate. I shoveled Nova Scotia salmon, bagels, bialys, cream cheese into my mouth faster than I ever have before. Important Disclaimer: for those who have never had smoked salmon, do *not* order Lox; order the Nova.It's "pricey" for breakfast, but totally worth it. The fish is absolutely delicious. Grab two friends, order one of the smoked fish platters, and dig in. Oh, and make sure you get some cheese blintzes, too. It's one of those places that makes you happy to call yourself a New Yorker.

I took my boyfriend here for his birthday, but I enjoyed just as much. My inner kid loves the candy and sugar while my adult self believes in imbibing. This place grants me both wishes along with pretty good food. I still plan on taking my girlfriends here. It looks like a great spot for brunch. These giant goblets are made for occasions like that! Plus, I NEEEEED to try the red velvet martini, and red velvet everything...So, we got the lollipop goblet and hazelnut fondue to share and I ordered the steak frites. The drink was an overload of sugar and alcohol, aka whoamazing. I was pleasantly surprised at the great food too. The steak and the fries were perfect. Our fondue? It was like dipping all sorts of stuff into nutella. You can't go wrong.The service was really attentive. I love this place!

Having now been open for the greater part of seven years, I was worried that the Modern would lose its edge. After all, seeming the more avant-garde of the pair is difficult when the other half of said pair is the MoMA. Beyond that, high-end restaurants have a tendency to wheeze softly into complacency once they've achieved a sizable cadre of regulars. Look no further than the recent NY Times review of Daniel for proof of that. Finally, perhaps most troubling of all, was the sheer rate of expansion of the Union Square Hospitality Group empire, the full divestiture of Eleven Madison Park to Daniel Humm notwithstanding. Every great location closing carried with it the buzz that Danny Meyer was eyeing the space for an opening. Maintaining Michelin star standards at one restaurant while simultaneously pursuing the creation and development of others is no small feat. The odds then, were stacked.Upon entering the Bauhaus derived room, you will want to breathe easier, thinking that no space this meticulously, functionally, intuitively arranged would be dragged down by poorly executed dishes. Instead, you will feel a sharp intake of breath at the sheer height of the ceiling, the impossible openness, and the panoply of sculptures seemingly visible from every angle. It is as if Walter Gropius were teleported from 1920s Weimar to construct this utilitarian cathedral in the middle of Manhattan, then ordered to spruce it up with the tiniest hints of Expressionism he so secretly enjoyed. The food embraces this same enviable synthesis of form and function, in less obvious fashions. However, the obligatory test tube amuse aside, the food also manages to convey emotion through aesthetic, insofar as one is capable of following along, and insofar as one is open to the idea that the narrator is not telling the same tale to everyone. While the decor is sleek, obvious and immediate in its minimalist appeal, the food can be erudite, rewarding those who take the time to savor, thereby sussing out tiny flourishes that would be acutely imperceptible to the voracious. The Modern is not a place to be consumed in one desperate journey. Instead, like any great museum, it is a place predicated by and made more immersive through periodic, sustained reflection and at times, rumination.On first taste, the pitted raspberry seems to be an unrefined parlor trick. A tart fruit stuffed with something as rich as foie gras is hardly genius, given the utter propensity of renditions on offer in restaurants throughout the city, the lesser scale here simply a nuance. Then, the juniper coolis reaches your palate. Any sort of smug self-assurances about the course your meal was sure to take that you formulated mere moments ago fall by the wayside with the first hint of pine that juniper berries imbue. You move then to the "Pralines" of foie gras terrine, dubious in equal measure at the server's pronunciation "pray-leen" and the fact that the dish comes with a mango purée. You will then blithely forget your skepticism and spoon the long carpet of pureée from your plate, safe in the knowledge that your peers are too engrossed by their own plates to see and judge you accordingly. Your partner is too busy marveling over the gently roasted Royal Trumpet mushrooms, uncovering each Bouchot mussel with the reaction of a prospector finding a solid nugget of gold. You will wonder when the chef, Gabriel Kreuther, plans on showing his roots. Your wonder will cease when the "Alsatian Dumplings" arrive, and it will begin anew at the first taste of sunchoke and truffle melding with the delicate, gamey rabbit. M regretted ordering the Munster-Brie "Soufflé" in their place, though it too was greater than the sum of its parts. For the entrées to follow such thoughtful and composed appetizers, and to not only match but trump them speaks to a sort of culinary perfectionism that most restaurants only ever dream of achieving. Both the maple brined pork loin and its cracklin, and the beef tenderloin and the bone marrow it comes with, and their respective interspersion of accompaniments are all prepared so flawlessly that you will be forced to hypothesize why cuisine so irreproachably skillful merits but a sole Michelin star. You will reach no answers, but you will take comfort in knowing that in spite of how well it embodies its name, The Modern is timeless.

My moving experience with Unpakt was as good as it could possibly be. With 48 hours notice, I was able to compare prices and secure movers to help me with my Brooklyn relocation. The documents were easy to finalize online, and Angela from their customer support team was PHENOMENAL in helping me address every question and moving issue I had, even when I needed to change things at the absolute last minute.The movers were in constant communication, and both Unpakt and the movers were Johnny-on-the-spot with their confirmations. I always knew what was happening and when it was going down. The guys were on time, and their manifest was identical to what I had registered with Unpakt. I signed the final paperwork when the move was complete, tipped the gentlemen, and was done with the entire process without a drop of sweat spilled.I'm sold on Unpakt. I'll be using them for every move I make (and every breath I take), and they will be my top recommendation for any friends who are moving in the future.

I didn't buy into the whole mixology thing until I walked into Amor y Amargo the second time. Came here to catch up with another former Seattle-ite on a Saturday night --- that was a bad idea (coming here on a Saturday night, not the catching up part). The place is small but not too crowded, so we stood by the bar and ended up getting a beer --- another bad idea.  Came back earlier this week on a weeknight and it was a much more pleasant experience. We briefly looked through the menu, ordered at the bar and promptly found some empty stools. Even though the bar was busy, I love that it didn't get too loud and the bartender was attentive despite us sitting away from the bar. I also love how warm, colorful, cozy, and incredibly intimate this place is. Wait, did I just use the words warm, colorful, cozy, and intimate in a positive light??? My friends would describe me as being extremely aloof, so I generally use these words with slight displease. When I pay $15+ for a drink, I'd like it to be pretty gosh darn good or I expect it to be pretty potent. So far, only Amor y Amargo drinks have lived up exceptionally well to BOTH expectations... and their drinks are actually less than $15! I had a couple Gin & Tonic (my absolute favorite), White Negroni, and a negroni dealer's choice (yes, yes, I had a few drinks on a weeknight, don't judge! It was a long week as Brooklyn B would say). All of the drinks I had were amazing and well worth the price. I can't wait to come back on another "quiet" weeknight.

Once upon a time...A good doughnut was nearly an impossible find in NYC. Dunkin' was king (and unfortunately still is). As a west coast native arriving here 10 years ago, there were 3 things I found shocking about New York's food...1) Crap Donuts. And the "gems" were mediocre at best. Really, I tried them. Yes, I went to Greenpoint.2) Crap Fro-Yo3) Lack of Decent Mexican Food on the Island of Manhattan. No, you cannot count Rosa Mexicana's pomegranate margaritas. Thankfully, in 10 years many things have changed. With all due respect for Dominique Ansel's Cronut Invasion, Doughnut Plant has won the war for my fried, golden dough heart. Would you call them classic? Of course not. The flavors are not the one's you grew up with. However, on taste and texture alone, I would take these everyday of the week (thankfully for my waist, not an everyday thing).The first time I tried the Creme Brulee doughnut was a moment. A moment that told me, "you can do anything, and you like creme filled donuts with a charred sugar crust". An hour later, I ate a porterhouse for two at Peter Luger. True story.You should eat here. Have a moment. Have a filled donut with Cashews & Orange Blossum cream. It tastes like unicorn dreams.

If you're willing to go to Chinatown and shell out $15-$20 per cocktail, you're most likely heading to Apotheke (however you pronounce the name).Because Apotheke is a speakeasy, the exterior is unassuming, save for a man (bouncer) sitting outside of the entrance. Look for an "Gold Flower Restaurant". The Chinese characters don't really match up either, it translates into "Gold Flower Karaoke." These signs were from the prior restaurant that no longer exists.As you walk in, you pass through a panel of heavy curtains, and you find yourself in a darkened room. Mosaic flooring, Victorian-era sofas, and lamps whose bulbs were fashioned out of beakers, line the path to the bar. The yellow tinted bar at the back provides the main source of lighting for the room. It also serves as the focal point of the room.The bar is beautifully aged. Its design is reminiscent of a chemical laboratory. Your bartenders wear white lab coats, your drinks are ordered off of a menu titled "A Selection of House Prescriptions" and all drinks feature some type of exotic, foreign ingredient. All drinks range from $15 to $18. You can't order shots like lemon drops here. Sorry college kids!SERVICE: If you're camped out on the couches, brace yourself for unbelievably slow service. It would be easier for you to grab your drinks at the bar and bring them back to an open table.PEOPLE: a mix of professionals relaxing after a long day, couples on dates - this is not a good first date spot, in my opinion.MUSIC: awesome 90s and throwbacks on weekends. Jazz/live band during the week.Bathrooms are unisex, so guys, be kind and put the seat back down. Also, the bathroom sinks are impossible to figure out. I've been here several times now, and I still don't know how to turn off the faucets.

I broke up with my boyfriend a week ago. Coincidentally, my iPhone screen shattered around that same time, making me absurdly convinced that every time I tried to dial a number or look at my pictures, I was staring into the physical manifestation of my broken relationship.Fast forward to this morning, I couldn't take it anymore. Off to Yelp I go! And at LaptopMD I found myself, plopped on a couch reading the NYTimes for less than 40 minutes. If anything, only 30 minutes. And everyone was so, so nice. My phone is as good as new, which is great because it was new (the last one took a dip in the ocean... (I'm a one-woman economic stimulus package for the post-Steve Jobs Apple stocks)).Contrary to another review down below, there is nothing at all sketchy about LMD. You take the elevator up to the 12th floor and ta-daa, it's an office. A comfy one at that. Bonus, buy the Yelp deal and you get $25 off. Win win win win win win.

This is precisely what vegetarian eating should be. Normally, when I go to a restaurant I am forced to flip directly to the one small portion of the menu that caters to the vegetarians. On large menus there are usually a few items (sometimes even a whole section), but on smaller ones it's sometimes just one. One! Heaven help you if you don't want what they have chosen to serve you. Vegetarians deal with this dilemma every single time they go out to eat.I have been a vegetarian since I was pretty little. If you gave me a ham and cheese sandwich in kindergarten, I would have picked the ham out. It's not a moral thing, the idea of eating animals just creeps me out. When I was little, my dad would tell servers that I had a disease (jokingly, of course). This also happened:Me: What would you recommend for a vegetarian at this restaurant?Server: Ummm, lettuce?So, when I walked into this place and was handed a menu of pages... and pages.... of delicious vegetarian options? Happy doesn't quite cover it. I'm not trying to convert anyone. I'll eat my dinner, you eat yours. As far as I know, I'm not contagious, but it was nice to not have to worry if there is food for me for once.-------------------- Comes down from soapbox. ----------------The decor of this place is swanky and trendy, but not so much that you and a friend can't show up without a reservation and get a table for two. We had a prime spot next to a gorgeous fish tank. If the whole restaurant is as clean as that tank, we are in good shape. It was spotless. Definitely wins the award for cleanest tank ever. Service was prompt and friendly. Although, she never actually mentioned anything about the restaurant, or asked us if we had been here before. Seems like vigilante meat-eaters would want a warning about what they are ordering.We ordered some sake, which was reasonably priced at just $15 for the large. I got the fbeef teriyaki bento box, and my cohort got a fchicken stir fry.* Everything was soo good. The bento box came with salad, edamame, veggie potstickers, fcalifornia roll, and sliced teriyaki beef over vegetables. So much food for only $14! I ended up bringing a bunch of it home for tomorrow. I ended up asking my non-vgetarian cohort if hers was vegetarian too. Her response, "Oh, I don't know. Is it?" Victory. I'm quite sure that I will be back here again and again.* I add f's before anything faux-meat, or "fmeat."

Han Dynasty followed me from Old City, Philly to East Village! And conveniently located next to 99 Miles from Philly...NY is known for great food, but Philly isn't too shabby, either. Han is one of the best Chinese restaurants there (check out their Yelp! reviews), and it's here to prove that Philly can roll with the big boys.Pretty much, you choose your style of preparation (Cumin, Garlic, Double-Cooked, etc.) and a protein. The spicyness ratings are next to each preparation type so you know what you are getting yourself into. My favorites are the Dan Dan Noodles (must get, a large bowl of noodles for $8!) and the Dry Pepper Style fish (a white fish, tilapia, maybe?). A non-spicier option that I like is the 3-Cup Chicken, which is made of gingery, sweet soy sauce base. I also got a complimentary Spicy Crispy Cucumber dish which has an awesome sauce for spreading on your rice later.They are going to serve liquor in a month or so, and the Monthly Monday tastings are coming soon (20 course tasting experience)! Delivery is on its way as well.Sichuan food is spicy, peppercorn spicy. Don't come here looking for General Tso's, you noob.

FULL DISCLOSURE: I hate working out. It's boring, it's time consuming, it's exhausting, and it makes me really thirsty. FlyWheel has saved my girlish figure from turning into a blob of atrophy. The classes are fun and engaging. The equipment is clean, new, and modern. They give you special shoes, hair ties, bobbypins, water, towels, mints, etc. They also adjust the bikes to fit your height.HIGHLIGHTS: Jesse's classes are the best!BUZZKILLS: Pretty spency. The seats are really uncomfortable to the point where I get adorable bruises on my tush.

Hey everyone! Try their trifles! I thought I'd put this out there first because they're definitely always overshadowed by their (also yummy) cupcakes. Give them some sugary love too, yea?This adorable bakery reminds me of my favorite homey coffee shop back home on the west coast, and their cupcake truly trumps Magnolia's (dry & overrated) cupcakes by miles and miles. I'll list them for easy reading:1). Their cupcakes are under $2 each. In NYC. Yes, IN THE CITY!2). Their signage outside listing all the reasons why you should pop in to get a cupcake are all very convincing.2.1) Cupcakes are also most, fluffy, and delicious, so you won't feel betrayed by the sign.2.2) The Sunshine Cupcake is literally a cuppie baked from good ol'e simple sunshine happiness :)3). Not convinced? TRY THEIR TRIFLES. Their largest size is equivalent of an extra-value soda cup at Micky D's for a reason, because they're THAT GOOD that people buy them! My favorite is the chocolate chip. It's in the side case by the way.4). Despite all the rainbows and unicorns that comes with each bite of cupcake, it's not overly sweet, but sweet enough to bring a smile onto anyone's face.5). Love the couches, the lighting, the flowers, the magazines & coffee table. And the always friendly staff!So, basically a small la-la land for you to unwind from the chaos of the city for a bit as you treat yourself to some metaphorical sunshine. Check it out!

Dear Birch Coffee, It was a long wait but boy, am I ecstatic that you opened in the Upper West Side, today!! When I walked in to your cafe, a scent of fragrant coffee tickled my nose. A cup of Birch is somewhere in between strong and just perfectly brewed. Aromatic. Sensory overload. Olfactory system is on full alert, as is my brain after a sip. Lovingly prepared, your espresso is a delectable shot with a thin layer of crema. I spend minutes admiring your cappucino, delivered with a piece of coffee- art, usually in the shape of a heart or a leaf. Thanks for offering assorted muffins (Blueberry with corn flakes, YUM!), croissants and danishes. Your new location is spacious, well lit, and chic. So glad that Birch offers an hour of free wi-fi with a purchase not to mention has really comfortable seating and some tables to linger a bit longer and the awesomest of awesome baristas. Thanks for adding a few more miles to my Birch frequent coffee-card. I'll be at my free 10th cup so soon! I am looking forward to finding out the full food menu offerings and craft brew options. I am thrilled with this new addition to the Upper West Side neighborhood! Good job, Birch! Love, PinkFrames p.s. Birch accepts Credit cards.

Desperately need a few hours away from the chaos of the concrete jungle? Want to feel absolutely pampered from head to toe in luxury? Then you need to take a trip to The Setai Club & Spa!I opted for the Tour of Asia treatment which includes a lava bath, body scrub and shiatsu-like massage on a Friday afternoon. When I booked, I was told to bring loose fitting clothing for the massage portion, I could arrive 15 minutes early to enjoy the Aqua Grotto (steam room, sauna and jacuzzi), and could continue to enjoy after my treatment for as long as I wished. Even though I left my apartment with ample time and GPS in hand, I still managed to get lost. I received a phone call exactly at the time my treatment was to start, and they calmly and very nicely gave me directions. Upon arrival, I was ushered to the locker room, given a quick tour, and my therapist (Renata) was waiting for me at the door with bath already drawn. She added oil infused with lemongrass and rice milk to the lava bath, and left me with chai tea, water, and a green tea ice cream mochi to enjoy with my bath. Ahhhh, the little details! The body scrub was equally phenomenal, as every inch of my bod was scrubbed (minus my boobies and hoo ha). After I rinsed off, my skin felt so moisturized and was as smooth as a baby's bottom!  Renata had clothes laid out for the massage (another unexpected and very nice touch) and continued with the yoga-like massage that melted away my aches and pains. Unlike other spas that offer multiple treatments, this room was set up so everything was there (the bath, the shower to wash off the scrub, the massage table...so convenient and added to the ease and flow of everything). This totally contributed the unhurried feel from one treatment to the next, which resulted in even more relaxation. After my treatment, I was taken to the relaxation room where I was offered water, wine, champagne, and assorted mini treats which ranged from healthy to bite sized sweets. Again, all the little extras, hospitality and attention to detail!Now on to the amenities/facilities: In every locker is a super comfy robe, cushy cotton slippers, and rubber slippers (that actually fit and aren't one-size-fits all enormous) for the aqua grotto. Every fluffy towel is embroidered with their logo. The facility is super clean, and since I went on a weekday during the day, I had the entire aqua grotto to myself! This is hands down, THE BEST spa experience I've ever had...and I've been to spas in many different cities, countries and of every caliber. The staff was so friendly and helpful, the treatments were above and beyond expectations (which expectations are already high given the hefty price tag), and the Aqua Grotto was top notch.  I'll definitely be back!

I'd go back alone for the white sangria and the sea salt potatoes. No. Seriously. I'd put aside $14 every day for that alone.Oh, and, eh, I suppose the rest was okay. On my walks up Pinehurst to the local grocery store over the past few months, I've been slowly watching the transformation of Rusty Mackerel from the old Vines on Pine location. I was a bit bummed at first, presuming it'd be a seafood place based on the title. As I started to follow their Twitter updates, I became a bit more excited with their menu offerings. Upon finding out the opening date, I offered to take the beau for a meal out on opening week. I was literally giddy at work the day of our dinner plans.My giddiness was not in vain.They worked the small space well; tables were a bit tight, but nothing that pulling them out a bit can't fix. A brightly drawn funky mackerel mural shone brightly over an open kitchen area in the rear. There's exposed brick, so, being a sucker for that, I immediately fell in love with the atomosphere. First, I needed sangria. NEEDED IT. A white version mixed with a rhubarb-strawberry reduction was velvety smooth and, legit, one of the best sangrias I've ever had. Second, we ordered the sea salted potatoes with smoked paprika aioli, brought to our table with much aplomb. Oh. My. GOD. I've had salted potatoes like this before, but this wins. Hands down. no contest. The aioli certainly makes these whole-boiled small potatoes not unlike Patatas Bravas. This dish is an absolute winner and a perfect plate to whet your hunger without overfilling you pre-entrees.I ordered the pan-roasted chicken with heirloom tomatoes and pecorino. The chicken was perfect, inside and out. Moist inside, and the chicken skin was perfectly crispy, oozing with oils and juices with each crunch. The beau got the steak frites with yucca fries and a béarnaise sauce. It came out a bit late as a new batch of yucca fries had to be made, but no matter. It was absolutely worth the wait! Medium-rare is the kitchen's perfered way of cooking it, and it was...wow...just wow. I'm also a big fan of yucca, so the fries were inhaled by me...more than him. (Sorry, Adam. Ha!)Last, the service was great. Everyone we talked to was friendly and asked for feedback on our meals. Thumbs up to our sever Jessica. Marcella, the general manager, both greeted us and sent us off, asking our names and shaking our hands. So kind!The food scene up in Washington Heights / Hudson Heights continues to burgeon, and Rusty Mackerel is definitely in the mix now. So glad y'all are here! Please stay. I insist!

in my professional opinion as an american-born korean, this food hits the spot. it's basically like my mom came over with tons of food and told me i need more meat on my bones.my food was packaged nicely in paper, foldable boxes with accoutrements like kimchi. btw the kimchi is full-on, double-complete authentic. it comes free (because a meal without it is blasphemy) along with a wonderful message from the management. you really feel like the business cares a lot about your satisfaction with the new menu.despite korean food being really known for the bbq meat dishes I ordered all vegetarian: the jap-chae, the dumplings, and the paJun. the names are kinda "out-there" and i wasn't sure whether a disco ball was going to pop out of my food but they came through with some great flavor and awesome portions (especially the appetizers). I got 6, maybe 7 perfectly crisped and puffy dumplings. the paejun - the korean version of a scallion pancake - was fluffy on the inside and also perfectly crisped on the edges. my japchae was the slightly sweet and salty mix of sesame+soy sauce flavored glass noodles with marinated veggies.overall, this is officially my go-to for korean food in the FiDi area. honestly, they are pretty much single-handedly repping the cuisine in the area, but do a great job at it. bonus: you can top off your meal with a fro-yo while you're there.

I love the Russian & Turkish Baths on 10th Street! I've been going to this East Village institution for almost a decade and have enjoyed their food and services religiously. Some have complained that the place is "small" or "dirty" compared to some of the newer Korean spas, but to these people I say, "you're an idiot!" I would describe this location as "cozy" with "character" just like my beloved East Village.The Russian & Turkish spa can be a intimidating affair for the first timer, so let me give you some tips that I've picked up over the years. First, check in with the counter person, they'll put all of your personal belongings like phones and wallets into a safe deposit box. Please note that you will not be able to get your phone and wallet out until you pay, so be sure you won't need to make a call. You might risk putting it into your clothes locker, but they don't guarantee safety (not that I've ever had a problem)Once you've got your safe deposit key, you'll be given a locker number. This number is stamped on the key and you can wear it around your wrist or ankle. You'll need to give your locker number whenever you order food or get services for which you pay at the very end. Please try the food, it's reasonably priced and delicious Russian fare. They have a great selection of Russian and Polish Beers and water, which you must have while schvitzing.They provide shorts, sandals, towels and robes. I usually bring my swim trunks and my own sandals. Once ready, go downstairs and take a quick shower. There are 5 rooms of various heat intensity as well as an ice cold bath to refresh you between rooms. Try them all! In some rooms, if it gets too hot you can douse yourself with a bucket of ice cold water.You'll find several employees and regulars downstairs that will offer massages and the infamous Platza aka "waterboarding". If you've never had the Platza, I recommend it at least once. It's where you get beaten by oak leaves. They have ways of making you talk! You'll be so glad you've survived the experience, you'll have a new zest for live. For reals.If the weather's nice you can go up to the roof and sun on the roof deck. You may also see people with mud masks, which you can purchase there. Sometimes I imagine living in NY when this place was the only place you can wash up. Mind blowing.I love to go during the middle of the week and during the day to avoid the crowds. I recommend checking out their schedule as they have Co-Ed times where shorts are required and gender-specific times where you can drop trou! I once went on a men's only day and saw so much penis. I can't unsee it.  On occasion, I have rub shoulders with actors here including; Colin Farrell and Sam Rockwell, so that's kind of coolIf you do like the place you can buy multi-day passes at a discount, but keep in mind the business is run separately by weeks, It's weird, each week is run by either Boris or David. You can tell which week it is by the calendar on their website,. The prices are the same, but when you buy a pass it's week specific so keep that in mind. My buddy and I split the weeks, he has David's weeks and I have Boris' weeks so we're always covered!Anyway, please come. I highly recommend this place! Happy Schvitzing!

I wish I had discovered this place sooner. The happy hour here is outstanding, and if you're a seafood person, not something to miss. The combination of a vast beer, wine, and cocktail menu and a ridiculous amount of seafood options is killer.The happy hour special runs for 4-7 and features $4 beers, wines, and cocktails, $16 pitchers, and amazingly, $4 sliders of lobster, crab cake, or fried oysters. Oh yea, raw oysters are just a buck too. My person favorite was the lobster roll, and unlike so many other places, the Lobster Joint doesn't shy away from giving you heaping pieces of lobster meat. My first slider came with an entire claw in it and the following ones were just as hearty. What really made the sandwich stand out was the balance between the lobster and the mayo. As a person that doesn't love mayo, I sometimes shy away but in this case it was spot on and more importantly it was not used a filler to give you less meat. The space itself is also a refreshing clean design. Very tall ceilings, inviting long tables built for groups of friends to hang out, and tasteful seaside flair on the walls. The wait staff was incredible and friendly, promptly bringing food or drinks when they were ready, and offering helpful suggestions along the way. For any fans of good seafood, happy hours with plenty of options, and great overall experiences, I highly recommend coming in here. I've been happily showing off the pictures of the food to every person I've seen since I left and can't wait to go back.

The crepes here remind me of when the first iPhone was unveiled. It was the perfect case of form combined with function. Simple, amazing and unlike anything we've seen before.Eight Turn Crepe takes that formula, plus a DJ, some promoters, a really good sound system, and throws a party in your mouth. The form is quite simple. It's a cone, which is kind of perfect for New York. It's convenient, understanding the on-the-go lifestyle, and quite frankly, as far as a fork and knife go in consuming my dessert - ain't nobody got time for that. The cone comes in a wrapper that you unwrap diagonally as you make your way down the crepe goodness. I'm proud to say I didn't get an ounce of it on my clothes. As far as the party in my mouth, my crepe was literally a party - the Chocolate Nut Party - 4 types of nuts (almonds, hazelnuts, walnuts, and pistachios)- 3 chocolate elements (chocolate sauce, chocolate custard cream, chocolate Pocky Sticks)Add some vanilla ice cream, homemade whipped yogurt (amazing), and wrap it in a gluten-free rice flour crepe, and drop the beat. "Oh snap, is that Tiesto spinning in my mouth?" you ask. Why, yes. Yes, it is.That was just one of the 10 sweet crepes on the menu. I intend to try the other 9 that have fruit, yogurt, cheesecake, matcha, and other great combinations. Need to wash that party down with something? You will be pleased to know that La Colombe, one of the top roasters in the world, is used to brew the coffee and espresso drinks. Need something sweet in a cup? Try one of the shakes. I had a sip of the Matcha Shake. Green Tea + Ice Cream shake = refreshing, unexpected, revolutionary. Sweet tooth satisfied? or in the mood for something on the entree? These guys have a savory category on their menu that includes eggs (not your diner eggs, Flo - truffled egg white omelet), lox, and turkey. Their salad crepes highlight the Japanese origins of this crepe-in-a-cone business, with an ever-so-slight French accent - Tofu Edamame, Seaweed Sesame, Tuna Nicoise and others will act as a perfect on-the-go lunch. Add some truffled shrooms to that crepe for a greater French accent, or other additions that will satisfy that hunger of yours. This place is going to revolutionize the way you see, eat, and walk with crepes. Ever walk with a crepe? Didn't think so. Prep your guest list and get your permits straight because there is about to be a party in your mouth.

I have been trying to go to all the bars in NYC that offer a nice roof top view/patio/setting. Most roof tops bars are relatively similar. Nice views, overpriced drinks, well dressed patrons, etc, etc, ad nauseam.... This bar hit all those marks.The view here was way better than I expected. The crowd was trendy/cool, the drinks were overpriced, the music was nice. Watching the sky change, with a soft breeze, good company, and with the Chrysler building in the background -- was kind of a perfect night.The roof has nice couches, plenty of places to sit, and strings of light decorating overhead. We got seats, enjoyed a few drinks, and met a few cool people that sat down to share our table. The service was fast, and the drinks were very good. I would come back here. Great place to bring a date, and accommodating enough to seat a group of 6 (comfortably.)Here is what made this place really stand out (to me):Guys, do not wear flip flops here! (maybe this is common sense, but I am clueless about this stuff). We got here, and we were turned away for a gentleman's shoe choice. The bouncer explained he would not be able to let us up to the pent house, because of the guys shoes. It really did appear it was out of his hands, and a rule he had to abide by (understandably). The guy saw our disappointment and LENT US A PAIR OF HIS SHOES. No, really. BRO LENT US A PAIR OF HIS OWN SHOES for our guy to wear (and he wanted nothing in return).  The bar was plenty crowded, they certainly did not need our business, but the guy actually went out of his way to be able to let us in. That was just a really nice thing to do, in my book.

I LOVE THIS PLACE AND CAN'T WAIT TO COME BACK -- the benefits of having Yelp friends that tell you where the best Yakitori is in NYC.My friend and I came and ordered yakitori (the 10 piece combo), pan-fried noodles (yakisoba?), and octopus balls (takoyaki?). All three were unbelievably good. The beef was unbelievably tender. The pork was so savory. The chicken was solid. The shrimp was a little dry but still broke apart in my mouth quite nicely. AND THE VEGGIES. THE VEGGIES WERE GOOD TOO! (I hate veggies. This means quite a lot.) The noodles were good but no spectacular. I think I'd skip that the next time I come. The octopus balls were one of the best I've had -- but not the best, as expected as this is not known for its octopus balls.I can't wait to come back to try the okonomiyaki. Such solid prices and good service.

Decided to stop in and have a drink while waiting for our reservation time at Morimoto around the corner. My boyfriend and I went to the bar and saw that there were no two seats together, but a few on either end of other couples. The bartender saw us attempting to find seats and very kindly asked other parties to move down in order to make room -- love it when they do that.The decor was beautiful and very romantic. It made a great accent to our anniversary night.We sat at the bar and looked at their drink menu. I forgot the name of it, but I got some type of drink that ended up being to floral/herby for me so just sipped on it while my boyfriend fully finished his drink. The bartender saw this and very kindly made me another drink at no charge; he didn't look offended at all and agreed that the drink is a hit or a miss with people.After a few drinks we headed out to make our reservations at Morimoto's. In the end the hostess was very nice when we walked in and the bartender was more than kind. We felt welcomed from beginning to end and never felt like a burden, even when the bartender had every right to make me feel that way after not enjoying my drink. I experienced great customer service and cannot wait to go back to try their food.

My hundredth review. And a five star. THIS PLACE IS SPECIAL.Jk, it sucks, you should never come here. I hope to never see you here.The pork belly is certainly not succulent; the yakitori is not grilled to perfection by a single man whose sole focus and dedication is to carefully turn, glaze, turn impeccable skewers, eyes never shifting away. The house tofu salad is not generous, topped with crack dressing, and almost on-par with EN Japanese Brasserie's much more expensive house-made tofu; the pork katsu in broth is definitely disgusting and not a good idea so just don't get it, actually just don't come here ever because 1.5 hours wait on an average night is a lot more than I am down for. Just stay away and go somewhere stupid like...I don't know, somewhere stupid so I don't have to fight for any more seats at my new favorite restaurant in the city. The hotpot is all sorts of unhealthy with its (not) flavorful yet still (not) light broth and melange of Asian hotpot vegetables and paperthin cuts of beef/porkThe hostesses are not friendly and accommodating and understanding and pleasant as possible despite the packed little entry way and sometimes impatient patrons.Basically, don't come, kthanksbai.For real though, this is my new favorite restaurant. I have been planning my days around off peak hours to come eat here. Actually.

THIS SALON IS THE ABSOLUTE WORST, I'VE BEEN GETTING MY HAIRCUT HERE FOR MONTHS NOW SO DON'T COME HERE.1- the haircuts are grossly overpriced at $50; this includes wash, cut and style. so pricey, even for New York City!2- they give you a nice head and neck massage when washing your hair. ew, who wants those?!3- after they wash your hair, they even try to towel-dry your ears. i mean, how inconsiderate!4- everyone is so polite here, it's gross. are you people on lithium? drugs are bad, you guys.5- after your shampoo/conditioning, they politely walk you to your chair and ask if you want a back massage for free. what's it with you guys and massages?! i came here for a haircut, not to feel pampered, dammit.6- after the stylist cuts your hair, she and an assistant will work together like a team to blow dry your hair quickly and they don't burn your scalp. why are you guys trying to make me feel like a celebrity? nobody wants all that attention all to themselves.DON'T COME HERE. IT'S GROSS.IF YOU'RE ABOUT TO CALL FOR AN APPOINTMENT, DON'T DO IT.STOP FILLING UP ALL THE SPOTS, I DON'T WANT TO HAVE TO FIGHT YOU FOR A HAIRCUT.xoxo

Fantastic spot, can't believe I've never heard of this place being yelp ELITE and all (sarcasm intended). Apparently u have to know someone or who's been there before to go - that always adds cachet.I thought the tasting menu at 58 pp was a great deal, esp given how much food u get. The ambience here is sleek yet not stuffy. A great date place for sure.Dish ratings on a yelp scale: (5 as good as it gets, 1 methinks not)5 - foi gras soba. My fav of the night. Maybe I was hungover and just needed some comfort soup. Broth was light yet flavorful and delicious and the fatty piece of foie gras gave it a wonderful umph to the dish.5- branzino. It just looked and smelled amazing. Charred sides gave added flavor. The sound of crackling and bubbling still cooking made it even cooler. Way large portion - couldn't finish it. Get sea salt on the side to taste. Tip: they should char the rosemary so that u can eat it - it smells deliciously aromatic, but it would be wonderful to taste (had rosemary this style at a random bar food once and it was simple and delicious).4.5 - uni croquette. I still prefer my uni unadultered but the croquette had good creaminess and the flavor did not overpower the uni goodness4.5 beef short rib - raw. So tender and tasty.3.5 fish egg rice bowl - good but the large (salmon?) fish eggs r not my flavor preference3.5 vegetable fondue - not something I'd normally order, but the freshness of the raw veggies was a nice departure from the crap I normally eat.3.5 beef sliders - nothing wrong w it, but nothing wowed me with this. Very beefy, if that makes sense.Drinks were wow good5 - burgamot. WOW. Good. My fav5 - jaguar - never knew whiskey could taste so good w chocolate. Not overly sweet either4 - mint gold - kinda like a mojito w some spice. Came In a very large glass so I suppose if ur really thirsty

There are a few benchmark moments in your New York life. The first time you got an apartment without a cosigner. The moment you got a room big enough to fit a queen bed. The moment when you finally got a grant for that artsy fartsy project you've been working on. For many, an invitation to the Soho House might be the ultimate prize though. The Soho House to me has always been a distant idea. But when I got an invite recently, I couldn't help but play Drake's "Started From the Bottom" over and over and over. I was recently recommended as a member and was invited for a night at the Soho House. I bought a new outfit, took my concord Jordans out of their air and temperature controlled environment, and got into a fancy yellow SUV cab downtown.  I had been before, but this time around, I got the full treatment and I was very impressed. The music was on point and the crowd was oh so good looking. I'm a huge nerd, and don't know if I quite fit in, but for one night I felt like I was hanging out at the cool table.The people I met were so interesting and the place really tries to keep the corporate types out, which is a huge plus in my book. My friend was on a mission to meet some women, and about five minutes in, I could tell his brain and eyes were about to explode. I can't say enough about how cool the crowd was. The drinks were very well made. I don't know if I am gonna be a member, as there is a tiny fee even for invitees, but I might have to take the plunge. If you know someone that is a member, I think you might have found a new best friend.

After years of sitting in front of a computer working on spreadsheets and generally getting abused, I figured it was worth getting a massage beyond the weak ones you get at a typical spa. It's a little tough to find but keep an eye out for the signage. You'll have to walk up a narrow and shady looking stairset before you walk into this small operation. Upon entering, you'll be immediately greeted and asked if you have any specific issues (back, legs, sports injury, etc.). You then agree to a set distribution of time between various parts of your body, in my case, 20 minutes of legs/feet and 40 minutes of back.Don't come in expecting a light patdown. I thoroughly got my ass kicked before leaving. They will really apply the pressure on all your pressure points and challenge you not to shed a tear in the process. If you have lots of knots, you'll hear cracking and popping noises you never thought possible in various parts of your body. I have a high pain tolerance and I almost screamed mercy a few times during the back portion of the massage. Elbows are involved. A not so strong guy to my immediate side was screaming murder. I felt more uncomfortable from the wailing next to me than my immediate pain. I had to look up every now and then to make sure no one was actually getting murdered.All in all, I was sore for two days after and feel like a new man. Dare you to give it a shot!

I am writing this review for the only one thing that I eat at Excellent Pork Chop, #13N-1 Pork with Pickled Mustard Green Noodle Soup. Before I didn't usually come here even though I live one block away. I never really liked Taiwanese Pork Chop over rice because I don't like preserved or sour cabbage. It's not my thing. Taiwanese food has a lot of this type of vegetable in a lot of their dishes so I avoided this place for a long long time....until....One day, last year, my bf convinced me to go with his friend, Helen, for lunch here. I was so worried to go to lunch here because I was afraid I won't like anything but Helen proved me wrong. I walked in late and Helen already ordered for us. Okay, I'll go with the flow. I saw this bowl of noodles on the table. It was bright green from the mustard greens in it. I was afraid to try it because my experience with Taiwanese food has never been very pleasant. One sip of the soup and one taste of the vegetables and I was in love. Wow. I was looking for the menu name and couldn't figure it out until recently, it's called Pork with Pickled Mustard Green Noodle Soup but it was not pickled tasting at all. I don't like pickled greens so I do not think it is pickled. My bf tried it too and doesn't think it is pickled either. There are bitter undertones from the mustard green. It is not super bitter but the mustard green has a natural bitter undertone which tastes great. It's very mild bitter undertone though. Super mild, which I like. I don't really like strong sour or bitter flavoring so this soup is perfect for me. I have had this noodle every time I visited this restaurant recently. It's been great every time. Awesome. I'm glad to have found something I like in a Taiwanese restaurant. Now I don't have to avoid it. It' is only $5.25 for this noodle soup. I highly recommend this bowl of noodles in Excellent Pork Chop. The decor is near none. There is nothing fancy in here. Nothing to look at but I don't care. The reason why I am in here? #13N-1. I had it even during the middle of summer. I was sweating a little but afterwards it gave me a reason to share Taiwanese ice with my boyfriend. We had red beans, taro and condensed milk on our ice that totally cooled us down from the hot soups. Ice is $3.50 with 3 toppings. PERFECT! I love my bowl of soup!

I don't know what has become of me. First I waited in line for cronuts last month and now I've waited in line for the first Umami Burger in NYC (on its first day of business, no less). I hardly ever wait in lines like this. By the way, it's "in line" and not "on line", right? I may be biased because I was starving, I was experiencing voorpret, and I felt rebellious for temporarily ditching my self-imposed no red meat diet. However, after watching fellow patrons and hearing their ooh's and ahh's, I don't think I was the only one who thought it was all worth it. I strongly believe New Yorkers are going to embrace Umami Burger for a very long time. One of the logos is an image of a hamburger that also kind of looks like a kiss mark! It's very fitting.We ordered the:- Original Umami Burger ($12) My favorite! All of the burgers are a variation of the Original, but have additional toppings and condiments. This burger includes a hand-ground, medium rare patty that really doesn't need any help from additional garnishes; it is slightly crispy on the outside, crumbly and juicy on the inside, and well-seasoned throughout. The burger is enhanced with an umami ketchup with strong notes of truffles, a sea kelp powder, bonito flake and oyster extracts, melt-in-your-mouth caramelized onions, an oven roasted tomato, shiitake mushrooms, and a crunchy and salty Parmesan crisp. ALL of this is sandwiched between two delightful, softly toasted, slightly sweet Portuguese buns. The condiments are also on the lower part of the entire burger, so it hits the tongue first and creates a much more dynamic flavor. Yum, yum, yum. Umami, umami, umami. - Manly Burger ($12)This burger is (excuse the gender stereotype) very manly. Delicious beer-cheddar cheese, smoked and crispy salt-onion strings and bacon lardon are stacked high on a very thick patty. With each bite, juices from all of the ingredients dribble onto the buns and sometimes onto the hands. The Manly burger is a messy, but delicious burger. - Vintage Burger ($10)This is an off-menu item. These off-menu items vary between locations and these are the items that make Umami Burger less of a chain, and more of a restaurant group. This burger is similar to the Original, but has a smashed patty. I didn't particularly like the smashed patty as much.- Cheesy Tots ($5)This side dish is also an off-menu item. As the name suggests, they are tater tots filled with cheese and are delicious with the accompanying umami ketchup, garlic aioli, and jalapeño ranch dipping sauces.THE SERVICE IS AMAZING.It was opening day, but none of the employees were the slightest bit frazzled or angry. The gentleman writing down and calling out names was so sweet and apologized profusely for our hour-long wait (which was surprisingly much shorter than what I had imagined it would be). The waiter who brought us to our table apologized for the wait. Our waitress, Jessica, apologized for the wait. Everyone apologized for the wait!! Since it was our first time at an Umami Burger, Jessica explained the burgers to us with great detail and enthusiasm. She also took our cheesy tots order off of our bill because they arrived after our burgers! What?! I really hope this high quality service continues.Likelihood of another visit:I'm usually a pretty light eater, but I almost thought of ordering another Original Burger, so that should tell you something. I'm also excited to try the Truffle Burger and the turkey burger! They also have a pretty extensive list of cocktails with names inspired by things around the neighborhood.

Getting to PH-D is similar to walking through an airport to find the gate of your plane. IDs: Check. Stamp: Check. Then walk straight on, make a left, make a right, get stamp checked, take elevator up to the 12th floor, where they check stamp again, and finally (insert drum ruffle here) YOU MADE IT! To PH-D!!! For a good impression of the experience here, I suggest you watch this: youtube.com/watch?featur…Anyhow, back to PhD rooftop... VIEW: You will be astonished by PH-D's view on NYC's magnificent skyline and the empire state building, which has a different color each day. Only Le Bain might come somewhat close to it when it comes to cool venues with an awesome view. The ceiling inside has beautiful, jaw dropping chandeliers. CROWD: Lots of 'suits', high heeled ladies, models, mixed with normal looking young people. Some of them react to having their table with bottle service in an endearing way, looking all proud, smiles from ear to ear, almost so disproportionately happy with this huge, significant life event, that you can't help but feel happy for them as well. All of this is of course in dark contrast with the promoter/model tables, where the girls are to look bored when they're not dancing, and where it's definitely a faux pas to clap and scream when champagne with fireworks come to the table. PhD also seems to be used as a parking lot by the promoters' hot entourage, until they can move on to 1Oak or Marquee.  MUSIC: The DJ's play pretty good dance music here, mostly Hip-Hop and top 40. They could tone down the amount of female condescending Hip-Hop they spin. Too much 'Ho', "Bitch', 'Put yer fucking hands up' 'Niggas' 'Ass ass ass ass' ....But besides that: Great music. DJ booth looks pretty impressive. It's often flanked by go-go dancers, and sometimes a live violinist or saxophonist performs along with the beats of the music. BOTTOM LINE: PH-D is professionally set up and run. Very well put together. There is a reason I keep coming back here!!! It's got a good vibe and an above decent crowd. I love PH-D on Sunset Saturdays ( starts around 7PM ). Ideally you go to Day & Night Brunch prior, or Lavo Brunch, then to PH-D and then on to Lavo or Marquee if you have energy left.

Takashi is a great treat when it comes to enjoying luxurious cuts of beef and experiencing the cuts of organ meats. Keep in mind many items of the menu are an aquired taste, and the small plates and price might be a deterrent. If you come in hungry, get the Kobe Chuck flat steak (6 oz steak) and rice and you should be able to enjoy the other cuts of beef without worrying that you'll be hungry. My Favorites:Niku-Uni - How can you go wrong, Kobe slice, Fresh Uni, this dish melts in your mouth and you really have to savor it.Kalbi (Kobe Shortrib) - Amazing and buttery cut of beef, the texture was smooth and fatty, we got it marinated with Takashi sauce.The Good:Tsurami (cheek) - very flavorful, we got it with garlic and sesame oil eat bite was delicious and the texture was rough and chewy.Hatsu (Heart) - I liked this a lot, I've eaten chicken heart at some yakitori places but never tried beef heart, this comes in very small bit size bites, you place them on the grill and grill for 1 minute each, the flavor is very hearty but not striking, the texture is like a smooth paste.The service was fantastic and very friendly and attentive, we sat in front of the chefs near the entrance, we got in after a 5 minute wait and were luckily because the people behind us were quoted a 40 minute wait and the manager took their numbers to let them know when a table would be ready. At no point did we feel rushed and we were able to enjoy each part of the meal at our pace.I sat looking at the large warning sign with a silhouette of a cow on it, I didn't really get it until I saw the sign, from my experience Japanese do not eat a whole lot of beef so when they do they explore the small cuts of every part of the cow and discover the flavor of each part. That's what Takashi is to me, beef by nature is a luxury in japan, and Takashi takes the time and energy to translate the experience of japanese beef eating in america where beef is plenty, I learned to slowed down and enjoy the flavors and textures of each parts of the meat, it's an interesting and delicious experiment.

Dinner at Gotham is a must if you're looking for somewhere nice to splurge. After mentioning it in conversation a few times, my friend and I decided to finally make a dinner reservation for 6:30pm here on a Sunday night.The restaurant was surprisingly very empty when we arrived, but by the time we left (around 9pm) it was almost entirely full, which I found very odd for a Sunday night. Another thing I found unusual: the number of families dining there with small children. The table next to us had two preschool-age children, and Gotham seems to be very good at accommodating small kiddies - I overheard the waiter offering the kids a plate of chicken with shoestring potatoes, which was obviously not on their normal dinner menu.As for our own food, my friend and I decided to share two appetizers: the striped bass ceviche and yellowfin tuna tartare. Our waiter kindly offered to split each appetizer into two separate plates for us, which saved us the trouble of having to halve everything ourselves. The striped bass ceviche came with several pieces of fish topped with leaves and citrusy bits, and the waiter poured a slightly spicy Thai broth into the dish.
